DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.046 against the greenback in Taipei Saturday, closing at 34.415.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.339 and the low of 34.43.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$36 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE IN NEW YORK CONDEMN ANTI-CHINESE ATROCITIES IN INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, July 31 (CNA) (By David Wang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A large-scale unified action of several dozen Chinese organizations in New York took place on Friday, in protest over the atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese women by rioters in Indonesia.

Leaders of the groups announced that a federation of Chinese New York residents has been formed to condemn the anti-Chinese racism, and is organizing a big protest slated for August to take place in front of the Indonesian General Consulate in New York and at the headquarters of the United Nations.

The protest is aimed at demanding that the Indonesian government take efficient measures to investigate the widespread and systemic rape and murder of ethnic Chinese in the Southeast Asian country, punish those responsible, and grant compensation to the families of the victims, a member of the federation said.
The federation also urged Chinese people living in the United States to write to their congressmen to request a public hearing on the racially motivated violence.

It has been reported that nearly 200 ethnic Chinese women and girls were gang-raped, tortured and murdered, some of whom were attacked in front of their families, in May riots in Indonesia over the severe economic recession there.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGED TO PROVIDE MAINLAND CHINA RISK INDEX FOR TAIWAN VISITORS

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has, since its establishment in 1991, helped resolve 193 cases involving Taiwan business people's personal safety in mainland China, a SEF spokesman said on Saturday.
Among these cases, 31 were fatal, the spokesman said, adding that 26 were murdered and the remaining five were accident victims.

Forty-three of the cases involved Taiwan investors who were attacked, robbed or extorted; 29 cases were related to kidnapping; 51 cases involved Taiwan business people being put under "house arrest"; and 29 cases involved Taiwan businessmen reported missing.
The most recent case involved Wang Fu-ching, a Taiwan investor in the southern mainland city of Shenzhen, who was beaten to death on July 27, the spokesman said.

The SEF tally, however, did not include the tragic death of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in northeastern mainland China on July 29, because Lin was not a businessperson. Lin died when she was given suspected overdoses of sedatives after being kidnapped in the northeastern mainland port city of Dalian on July 27.
The SEF spokesman said if cases involving non-business Taiwan people falling victim to mainland criminal activities were included, the number would be much greater.

With mainland China's social order deteriorating, opposition Legislator Hsiao Yu-cheng urged the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, to establish a regular warning system for the reference of would-be mainland-bound businesspeople and ordinary travelers.

Hsiao said the MAC should formulate a special rating system to gauge the extent of danger or risk of various mainland cities and regions based on their general crime rates and the number of cases involving Taiwan victims.

Hsiao said the SEF can ask its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), to provide it with information or data concerning social order and crime rates in various mainland districts.
"The MAC should use the data to compile a risk rating index for the reference of local people intending to travel to China," Hsiao said.
She also urged the government to push mainland authorities to investigate the case of Lin Ti-chuan's death and bring to justice all those involved in the case.

Hsiao further said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should sign an agreement on join anti-crime operations to better protect the physical safety and property of the people on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNPO TO HONOR MASTER CHENG YEN

TEXT.P: The Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization (UNPO) has decided to honor the founder of Taiwan's largest charity organization, an UNPO official said on Saturday.

Parris Chang, who is chairman of UNPO's Steering Committee and also a legislator of the Republic of China's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said the organization will present the award for human rights to Master Cheng Yen when the Steering Committee meets in Taipei on September 24-27.
Chang said that master Chang Yen was nominated by the DPP earlier this year, and beat seven other candidates to win the honor.

He said that this is the second year that the UNPO has bestowed the award. The first winner of the award was Ramos Jose Horta, an activist for East Timor independence, who was also the winner of Nobel Peace Prize in 1996.

Chang lauded Master Chen Yen's Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu-chi Foundation, which has expanded its charity work across national borders and has provided large amounts of help to those in need in recent years.
He said UNPO's decision shows that efforts from Taiwan's private sector are being recognized by the international community.

UNPO, founded in 1991 and based in the Hague, Netherlands, aims to provide a platform for those nations, minorities and peoples who are not represented in established international forums such as the United Nations.
UNPO's 50 members, which include the Chechen Republic, East Timor, Taiwan and Tibet, represent over 100 million people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURKISH WOMEN STILL FACE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: According to the researches by Turkey's Family Research Institute, 92 percent of women physically abused by their husbands said that they encountered violence in the first weeks of their marriage.
The research results show that of the 50 percent of women who face domestic violence, 33 percent of their husbands have alcohol problems and 19 percent are drug addicts.

According to the research results, 77 percent of women do not tell anyone about the abuse, while 67 percent of women who have been beaten by their fathers and then by their husbands do not hesitate to use violence against their own children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURKEY'S NEIGHBORS TURNING AGAINST IT

TEXT.P: A growing Turkish-Israeli relationship is concerning Turkey's neighbors, high-ranking officers of the Turkish General Staff said on Friday.

The sources said Iran, Armenia, Greece and Syria, which openly complained about Turkey's ties with the Jewish state, have signed military cooperation agreements. The most recent accord between Armenia and Iran provides training in Iran for Armenian officers and a discount to Armenia in the prices of weapons manufactured by Iran.
Greece and Syria also signed a military agreement three months ago, the same sources said.
The sources added that Syrian Defense Minister Mustafa Tlas is expected to visit Greece with three of his generals, most probably in October.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR SLATED ON ONE NATION AND ITS GLOBAL IMPACT

TEXT.P: The Asia Pacific Public Affairs Forum (APPAF), based in southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung, and the University of Queensland, are to jointly sponsor a seminar on the global impact of Australia's One Nation party.
The one-day seminar in Brisbane will be attended by more than 70 people, including Brisbane Mayor Jim Soorley, Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, and academic scholars.
The theme of the seminar will be "Australia's One Nation Party and Its Impact on Global Civil Society."

In an interview with the CNA on Saturday, University of Queensland Associate Professor C.L. Chiou said: "The rise of Pauline Hanson's One Nation party has not only altered the Australian political landscape, it has also caused great concern in Asia."

He said many Asians are asking: "Is Hansonism going to become the mainstream political agenda in Australia? Is the white Australia policy making a comeback? What is going to happen to Asia-Australia relations, especially in areas of trade, tourism and cultural and educational exchanges?"

He said the seminar is seeking to answer these questions so that people in Taiwan and other Asian countries will have a better understanding of the rise of One Nation and will be able to cope with its impact in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMMIGRANTS IN AUSTRALIA DEMONSTRATE AGAINST ONE NATION

TEXT.P: Thousands of immigrants in Australia on Saturday staged a rally in Sydney to protest the anti-immigration, anti-foreign investment policies of the One Nation party.

The rally was organized by several Chinese, Asian, Italian and Greek associations in New South Wales, who said the mainstream parties, particularly the Liberal and the National parties, must learn from the June 13 election in Queensland in which the two parties lost heavily.

Despite its surge in popularity, One Nation and its leader, Pauline Hanson, have recently suffered a series of setbacks, as one demonstration after another against the party has taken place all over the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AUSTRALIAN SPACE SITE GIVEN NEW LEASE OF LIFE

TEXT.P: A former space launch site at Woomera in northern South Australia is being given a new lease of life, with the US-based Kistler Aerospace Corporation set to begin test flights there in the first half of 1999.

Kistler's Australian subsidiary -- Spaceport Woomera -- will spend US$45 million to construct a spaceport, and the US company plans to use the site to put communications satellites into orbit, using its K-1 reusable space launch vehicle.
Spaceport Woomera chairman Robert Wang said the satellite launch market is buoyant and his company is negotiating with potential users.

The Australian state and federal governments have offered incentives to Kistler to help set up the operation at Woomera, which was formerly a base for British and European rocket launch activities in the 1950s and 1960s.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SIGNS STRATEGIC ALLIANCE ACCORDS WITH TWO US FIRMS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs of the Republic of China on Friday signed letters of intent for the formation of strategic alliances with US firms GTE Corp. and United Biomedical, Inc. (UBI).

The signing ceremonies were held separately at the Chinese Information and Culture Center in New York. ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs C.P. Chang, GTE Vice President Anthony Knight, and UBI President Dr. Chang-yi Wang inked the documents on behalf of their respective entities.

With the signing of the agreements, GTE and UBI become the ROC's 59th and 60th strategic alliance partners since the MOEA began its strategic alliance policy in 1993 with the aim of promoting Taiwan's technological and economic development.
GTE is a world famous telecommunications giant which has made great contributions to the upgrading of global telecommunications technologies, industrial development, and quality of service.

The telecommunications industry in Taiwan is now undergoing extremely rapid development, and the MOEA hopes that GTE will invest in joint ventures with Taiwan companies. The ministry has promised to do all it can to help GTE achieve its goals regarding the island.

UBI is a major US-based biopharmaceutical company founded in 1985 by Dr. Chang-yi Wang, a Chinese American who emigrated from Taiwan. The company develops immunotherapeutic, vaccines, and diagnostic products for human and veterinary use, and set up UBI-Asia in Taiwan earlier this year to serve as its operations center in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: LT. GEN. CHEN YOU-WU TAKES CIST HELM

TEXT.P: Lt. Gen. Chen You-wu has taken the helm of the Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology (CIST), a Ministry of National Defense spokesman announced on Saturday.
Chen, 53, took over the post from Lt. Gen. Shen Fang-ping at a ceremony on Saturday witnessed by Minister of National Defense Chiang Chung-ling, the spokesman said.

Addressing the changeover ceremony, Chiang said that under the leadership of previous directors, the CIST has nurtured talent in national defense technology, conducted research on hi-tech weaponry systems, and dramatically upgraded the nation's defense capability.
Chiang also decorated the outgoing Shen with a medal in recognition of his contributions to upgrading national defense technology and combat readiness.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LAUNCHES MANHUNT FOR 6 MURDER SUSPECTS

TEXT.P: Beijing has launched a nationwide manhunt for six people wanted in connection with the murder of Taiwan councilor Lin Ti-chuan in the mainland China city of Haicheng, Liaoning Province, according to Hong Kong-based newspapers.

Photos of the six suspects, including prime suspect Li Guangzhi, have been distributed to ports, airports, traffic checkpoints, and security bureaus across the country, the pro-Beijing dailies Wen Wei Pao and Ta Kung Pao reported on Saturday.

More than 1,000 public security personnel have been deployed to set up roadblocks around Liaoning, and a task force code named "729" -- a reference to the date when the case came to light -- headed by Haicheng City Mayor Zhang Dianchun, has been formed to probe the case and bring those responsible to justice.

Li is a business associate of Lin's Taiwan boyfriend Wei Tien-kang. He reportedly lured the couple to Dalian on Sunday with an offer of a business deal, before kidnapping them on Monday and taking them to Haicheng, about 200 kilometers to the north.

Wei, who managed to escape and alarm the authorities on Wednesday, said Li demanded a ransom of US$200,000, but the newspapers said that in reality, Li was probably trying to collect a US$700,000 debt from Wei.

Lin was taken to the Haicheng City Central Hospital on Wednesday by a young man who claimed to be her husband. The man disappeared after Lin was pronounced dead from kidney failure caused by an overdose of the sedatives which Wei said was used by their abductors to subdue them.

Wei, the owner of a Taiwan-based firm which imports mineral ore from mainland China, is now under public security protection at a local guest house, while Taiwan police have opened an investigation into his role in the case, according to the local TTV television station.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS DOWN; FUTURES UP

TEXT.P: A late-day rally was not enough to push shares higher as the Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, closed 30.83 points lower at 7,622.68 on Saturday.
The index's decline followed overnight losses on Wall Street and a further depreciation in the value of the Japanese yen.
The bourse opened at 7,580.16, fell as low as 7,562.37 and closed at the day's high. The technology sector saw heavy trading in the day's session.
Overall, losers outnumbered gainers 265 to 146, with 80 stocks unchanged.
Some 14.73 billion shares changed hand on a turnover of NT$71.75 billion (US$2.09 billion), the lowest daily turnover in six months.
Textile issues closed 0.5 percent higher, while the rest of the eight major categories posted losses.

Foodstuff shares fell the most at 2 percent; followed by electrical stocks at 0.6 percent; cement issues at 0.5 percent; construction stocks at 0.4 percent; and plastic and chemical, paper and pulp, and banking and securities shares all at 0.2 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers on Saturday were CMC Magnetics, Winbond Electronics, United Micro Electronics, Mosel Vitelic, Compal Electronics, ACER, CLEVO, ACER Peripherals and ASE.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures closed higher.

Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September rose nine points, closing at 7,609, with 378 transaction contracts; October futures moved up 11 points to 7,610, with one transaction contract; and December futures rose four points to 7,725, with five transaction contracts.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX) reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures on Saturday were 7,600 points for September; 7,599 for October; 7,721 for December; 7,900 for March; and 7,969 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA REDOUBLES EFFORTS TO ATTRACT ASIAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Australia is redoubling efforts to attract more foreign students from Taiwan and Hong Kong, as well as from countries such as mainland China, India and Vietnam to reverse declining enrollment numbers -- largely the result of a region-wide financial crisis.

Between 1986 and 1996, Australia has attracted students from throughout the world, although Asia has been a key focus. Over the past decade, the number of foreign students studying in Australia has increased steadily.

Last year, however, the growth rate fell to about 5 percent, the country's first year-on-year growth rate decline in more than a decade. About 150,000 foreign students studied in Australia last year, according to Australian Educational International (AEI), a government agency that promotes education.
AEI officials attribute the lower growth rate to the Asian financial crisis, which first hit Thailand and then spread to the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore.
They predicted the number of foreign students in 1998 would remain marginally higher than that of the previous year.
The reason for the fall is the substantial depreciation of the currencies of these countries against the Australian dollar, making an Australian education too expensive for some students.
Most overseas students studying in Australia last year came from South Korea, followed by Indonesia, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Taiwan, Thailand, India and mainland China. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS SAY WTO ENTRY BENEFICIAL: POLL

TEXT.P: Most of Taiwan manufacturers believed that Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) will help cut import costs and have substantial benefits, according to a survey unveiled Saturday.
The survey, conducted by the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), found that 70.6 percent of the polled said that the entry will help cut import costs.

Only 5.9 percent said that the entry will be detrimental, showing that most of the polled believed that Taiwan's entry into the WTO will be beneficial to manufacturers who rely on imported raw materials.

On whether Taiwan's entry will pose pressure to domestic industries, 27.1 percent of Taiwan manufacturers polled said that the pressure of competition will be tremendous, while 45.9 percent said that the pressure will be modest. Some 27.1 percent said they feel no pressure.

This shows that most of Taiwan's manufacturers have made adjustment during the past years to prepare for the cutting of tariffs and the opening of market in Taiwan's bid to enter the world trade organization.

Those who believed that the pressure will be modest or not exist belong to machinery and instrument manufacturing sectors, while those that said the pressure will be high are mostly in food and soft drink sectors.
CNFI conducted the survey between July 9 and July 16. It has issued questionnaire to 381 members and received 85 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE LAUNCH LARGE-SCALE ANTI-CRIME CRACKDOWN

TEXT.P: Police nationwide on Saturday continued a large-scale crackdown on criminal activity on the island.
The current crackdown, which began on Friday, is the fifth this year, as the government is attempting to demonstrate its determination to stomp out crime in Taiwan.
As of Saturday morning, 45 hooligans, including ones allegedly involved in a scandal over military procurement bribes, had been rounded up.

Police arrested 35 people believed to be members of organized crime rings, 42 who were found to be illegally possessing or selling firearms, 426 suspected of violating drug laws, 123 involved in illegal gambling activities and 19 accused of running underground banks.
In addition, a total of 33 guns, 82 bullets and more than 1,000 grams of drugs including amphetamines, heroin and morphine were seized.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND DISSIDENTS REQUEST RE-TRIAL OF FORMER BEIJING MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 1 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Seven mainland Chinese dissidents from Zhejiang province co-signed a letter to mainland China's Supreme People's Court on Friday requesting that a former Beijing mayor be re-tried after being convicted of corruption and dereliction of duty.

Former Beijing Major Chen Xitong, who was also a local Communist party boss, was sentenced to 16 years in prison by the Beijing Municipal Higher People's Court on Friday. Chen was found guilty of accepting a 550,000-yuan bribe.

As the dissidents pointed out in their letter, however, mainland Chinese law stipulates that accepting a bribe of more than 100,000 yuan is a capital offense. The dissidents claimed that because of political considerations, Chen received a lighter sentence than would have been given to a lower-ranking official.
His offense is more serious than those of most executed criminals, the dissidents said in a news release faxed to New York by the Information Center for Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China.
Chen served first as mayor and then as city party boss from 1983 to 1995 and presided over the city during the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Based on the principle that on one is above law, remarked the dissidents, Chen should be sentenced to death. The dissidents requested the Supreme Court overturn the verdict of the Beijing Municipal Higher People's Court and that Chen be re-tried. They also called for the re-trial to be broadcast live on television.

The information center noted that the Zhejiang dissidents' request was the third one in the past three days calling for Chen to receive the death sentence. The center said this indicates not only the public's anger toward corruption but also their loathing toward those considered responsible for the Tiananmen Square massacre.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY ORGANIZES EIGHT PRIMARIES

TEXT.P: The New Party held eight primaries on Saturday to choose party candidates for year-end legislative elections.

The party's general campaign manager, Chao Shau-kong, urged all candidates to encourage their supporters to turn out for what he called the first ever "open" party primary. Any ROC national who will be at least 20 years old by Dec. 3 is eligible to cast a ballot.

Chao, the architect of the primaries, dismissed criticism that members of other political parties could sabotage the elections and influence election results. Primary candidates should know how to drum up enough support to neutralize any such attempts, he said.

Among the party supporters who turned out to vote on Saturday was Kao Koong-lian, chairman of the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission and a senior Kuomintang member. He told surprised reporters that he would like to help the New Party choose its legislative candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT LEGISLATORS SWORN IN

TEXT.P: On Saturday 3,664 local government legislators were sworn in without incident.
The legislators represent 309 county municipalities, cities and rural townships and will serve local governments under Taiwan province. Elected on June 13, the legislators will serve four-year terms.
After the legislators' respective swearing-in ceremonies, they chose their local speakers.

Noteworthy among the newly elected legislators was Lin Chi-jui, from Shenkang Rural Township in Changhua County. Lin was elected as speaker despite his involvement in a shooting incident in which he was charged with firing warning shots at the residences of two local politicians on June 20. He was released on NT$300,000 bail.
Also sworn in on Saturday were 6,797 administrators from boroughs and villages under Taiwan province.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL WOMEN'S RIGHTS ACTIVISTS TO LEAVE FOR INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Nine representatives of women's rights organizations in Taiwan, including the Garden of Hope Foundation, will leave for Indonesia Sunday to help ethnic Chinese women raped or otherwise abused during riots there in May.

The group plans to visit members of women's welfare organizations and human rights organizations in Indonesia. They will appeal for official protection of that country's ethnic Chinese population, who were targeted in May's riots, said a group spokesperson on Saturday.
The spokesperson said that the nine-member delegation also plans to visit victims of the atrocities and to help them receive medical treatment.
The mission will also investigate claims that the attacks against the ethnic-Chinese population in Indonesia were systematic and deliberate, the spokesperson said.
It has been reported that some 200 ethnic Chinese women and girls were raped, tortured and murdered by Indonesian rioters.
The delegation will also deliver donations from a local fund-raising campaign aimed at helping victims of the violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LARGEST OPPOSITION PARTY CHANGES GUARD

TEXT.P: The pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) changed guard on Saturday, with veteran political dissident Lin Yi-hsiung taking the helm of Taiwan's largest opposition party.
Lin, 56, took the party's reins from Hsu Hsin-liang in a green-tinged ceremony held at DPP headquarters in downtown Taipei. Green is the DPP's favorite color.
In his inaugural speech, Lin expressed a strong ambition that the DPP become Taiwan's ruling party in the not-too-distant future.
Lin, a vocal independence supporter, also stressed that only residents on the island can determine Taiwan's future.
"Local people may have different political views and stances, but they all agree that neither the United States nor the Chinese communist government is entitled to determine our destiny," Lin said.
Stressing that only the people of Taiwan know which kind of country they need, Lin said Taiwan's future can only be determined by its people.
The soft-spoken DPP chairman acknowledged that Taiwan's development is facing enormous difficulties and challenges because of the recent international situation and mainland China's military threat.
"Addressing these challenges is a tall order for Taiwan's politicians and ordinary people as well," Lin said.
In the face of the adversity, Lin said Taiwan should become even more cautious and prudent in handling issues related to its future.

He further said if all Taiwan residents fail to stand firm and united, not only will mainland China constantly intimidate or suppress the island but, "The international community will also disregard us."
"History has proved it that only when the people of a country show a strong will and determination to defend their country can they avoid aggression or invasion by other nations," he warned.

Lin went on to say it is the DPP's consistent stance that all local residents, no matter when they came to the island, can jointly create an independent country that will be able to enjoy an high standing in the international community and contribute to the civilization and well-being of all mankind.
Nevertheless, Lin said the DPP will not force local people who have different political views and stances to accept its platform.

As for the DPP's current political tasks, Lin said the DPP should exercise extreme caution and express a strong determination to defend Taiwan's sovereignty and security in developing relations with mainland China.
Moreover, Lin said the DPP should also feel an a sense of urgency in becoming the ruling party to realize its ideals and policies in domestic administration.

Lin further said reforming local society and making Taiwan a lovable country is the DPP's only goal should it become the ruling party. "I'm convinced that if many of the DPP's policies and reform plans can be implemented smoothly, more people on the island will identify with Taiwan rather than China."

The ceremony was overshadowed by sadness as one of the party's rising stars, Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan, was kidnapped and murdered in mainland China earlier this week. She was originally tapped to serve as master of ceremonies. All the participants observed a minute of silence in memory of the councilor before the ceremony.

Outgoing DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang got a surprise fist from a radical independence supporter, Lee You-cheng, when Hsu stepped out of his car to attend the ceremony. Lee said he slapped Hsu to protest Hsu's call for broad engagement with Beijing. Lee was arrested by police.
The unexpected episode did not seem to bother Hsu. Hsu said he has encountered many such ordeals and adversities in his long political career.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF ANGRY WITH BEIJING'S SNUB

TEXT.P: The semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) expressed deep regret on Saturday over Beijing's rejection of its plan to send staff members to mainland China to help the family of a Taiwan councilor kidnapped and murdered on the mainland.

"We are extremely dissatisfied with Beijing's snub of our plan," said SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng. "Beijing should assume all the responsibility for its unfriendly move, which has hurt the feelings of local people and may affect exchanges across the Taiwan Strait."
Jan made the remarks after receiving a phone call from Liu Gangqi, deputy secretary-general of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Liu, who was in the northeastern mainland city of Haicheng to help handle the aftermath of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan's tragic death, told Jan that he sees no need for any SEF staff member to come to the mainland.

Jan said the SEF originally planned to send Tsai Chin-mei, deputy director of the SEF's Travel Service Department, to accompany Lin's parents to the mainland to offer counseling services or assistance.
Although Tsai managed to accompany Lin's parents to Hong Kong, she was forced to return to Taipei late Friday night because Beijing would not give her an entry permit.
Jan said the SEF sent seven letters by fax to the ARATS on Friday asking for its assistance to arrange for Tsai's mainland trip. "The ARATS didn't respond to our letters."
Jan said the SEF also tried numerous times to contact Liu or other ARATS staff members via telephone on Friday. "However, we couldn't get in touch with Liu until this morning."

Jan said the ARATS should not have rejected SEF's plan to help the grieving Lin family. "Our plan was based on humanitarian grounds. Beijing should not have rejected it out of political considerations," he insisted.
Lin was kidnapped shortly after she arrived in the northeastern mainland port city of Dalian on July 27. She died on July 29 of a suspected drug overdose, injected by her kidnappers.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

SEF Chairman C. F. Koo, who plans to travel to mainland China this fall to meet his ARATS counterpart, said Saturday afternoon that if Beijing fails to handle Lin's case with sincerity, cross-strait exchanges will certainly be affected.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SUSPENDS CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest opposition party also said its Legislative Yuan caucus will take steps to push the ROC government to stop cultural, athletic and other social exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

The DPP made the announcements after Beijing failed to respond to its three-point ultimatum delivered earlier in the day over the kidnap-murder in mainland China of one of its rising political stars, Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan.
The DPP sent the ultimatum to Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) via the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foudnation (SEF).
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
The DPP demanded that Beijing allow SEF staff members to travel to the mainland to help the grieving Lin family handle the aftermath of the councilwoman's tragic death.

The party also demanded that Beijing quickly approve visa applications by DPP members to travel to the mainland to help the Lin family and that Beijing definitely promise to agree to the return of Lin's body. In the past, Beijing only allowed the return of cremated ashes of Taiwan people who died on the mainland.
The DPP asked Beijing to respond to its demand by 5 p.m. Saturday. The ARATS, however, didn't give any response until the deadline.

An angry DPP Legislator Chang Chun-hung, also a DPP heavyweight, said the party will ask the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, who charts Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, to tighten restrictions on mainland officials' applications for visits to Taiwan.

DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, who just assumed office on Saturday morning, condemned communist China's consistent suppression of human rights and failure to protect personal safety of visitors from Taiwan. Lin urged local people not to make pleasure trips to that risky, dangerous country.
The DPP formed a five-member task force to help handle the aftermath of Lin Ti-chuan's death and other related affairs, with Chang Chun-hung as the convener.
Meanwhile, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-hung urged Beijing to agree to the SEF's plan to send staff members to the mainland to help the Lin family handle related affairs.

Jan said five SEF staff members, including Tsai Chin-mei, deputy director of the SEF's Travel Service Department, are ready to travel to the mainland. "They can leave for the mainland as soon as receiving Beijing's entry permits," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CENTRAL BANK TO LOWER RESERVE REQUIREMENT MONDAY

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China in Taipei announced Saturday that it will lower the reserve requirements by 0.2 to 0.5 percentage points, effective Monday, to help energize the economy.

The requirements on check deposits, demand deposits, and demand savings deposits will be cut by 0.5 percentage points. As a result, the reserve requirements will be slashed to 19.25 percent on check deposits, 17.25 percent on demand deposits, and 9.75 percent on demand savings deposits.
The reserve requirements on time deposits and time savings deposits will be cut by 0.2 percentage points to 7.55 percent and 5.55 percent respectively.
The weighted average reserve requirements on the various deposits will be lowered from 8.3 percent to 8.0 percent as a result of the adjustment in reserve requirements.

The adjustment is expected to release NT$36.7 billion into the money market to help the economy. The central bank will also release another NT$10 billion in postal savings fund to the money market, Deputy Governor Shea Jia-dong of the central bank said at a press conference.

General Manager Ho Kuo-hwa of the Bank of Taiwan, Chairman Huang Tien-lin of the First Commercial Bank, and high-ranking officials of some other leading commercial banks in Taiwan said almost unanimously Saturday afternoon that they are glad to see the central bank make the adjustment and that their banks will consider lowering their prime rates and other interest rates next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND SAYS IT DID NOT HELP S. AFRICA DEVELOP CB WEAPONS

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense said Saturday that his ministry did not help South Africa develop chemical and biological (CB) weapons, and that it is Taiwan's long-standing policy not to develop nuclear and CB weapons.

He made the remarks when asked by the press to comment on a foreign wire news report that South African military doctor Wouter Basson said Friday that western, Japanese, and Taiwanese scientists helped the apartheid government set up its CB warfare program by swapping sensitive information. The report also said a document showed Basson had been briefed in May 1981 in Taipei on Taiwan's CB warfare facilities.
The spokesman said his ministry has "absolutely not" helped South Africa do research on or develop CB weapons.
Taiwan is making no efforts to develop nuclear or CB weapons, he said, adding that it only does research on such defensive CB equipment as gas masks.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF SLAIN TAIWAN WOMAN ARRIVES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Family members of a slain Taiwan councilwoman arrived in the mainland China city of Haicheng on Saturday morning after an eight-hour delay, according to the victim's office in Kaohsiung City.

The parents, younger brother, and sister-in-law of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan went immediately to a local hospital to identify her body upon their arrival at 9:20 a.m., said Lin's office staff, who are keeping close contact with the family.
The family is being accompanied by Kaohsiung City Councilor Huang Chao-hsing, lawyer Kao Tsung-liang, Lin's office director Kao Tsung-yin, and two employees from a local funeral home.

They left the southern port city of Kaohsiung at 1:00 p.m. on Friday, but a series of delays meant they did not arrive in the mainland city of Dalian until about 1:00 a.m., where it took them another three hours to clear customs.

Airport officials refused to hasten the examination of their travel documents, despite a promise by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to help them clear customs quickly, Lin's Kaohsiung office said.

Lin was kidnapped along with her Taiwan businessman boyfriend on Monday during a private visit to Dalian, and taken to Haicheng, a city about 200 kilometers further north. After receiving an overdose of sedatives administered by her abductors on Wednesday, she was dumped at a hospital, where she died.
Her boyfriend managed to escape and alerted the authorities.
The Haicheng public security bureau is reported to have launched a wide-scale manhunt for Li Guangzhi, a major suspect in the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER PREDICTS MODERATE ECONOMIC GROWTH
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite Asia's financial crisis, Taiwan's economy will grow 5.5 percent in 1998, ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang said on Sunday at an investment seminar in New York.
Although Taiwan has also been affected by the regional financial storm that broke out one year ago, Chang said Taiwan's economy remains stable compared with those of neighboring countries.

The vice economics minister made the remarks while addressing an investment seminar to introduce Taiwan's efforts to promote high-tech development. More than 200 academic, business and financial experts from New York's Chinese community took part in the event.

Attributing Taiwan's stable economic development to its low levels of foreign debts, a trade surplus of more than US$80 million and bullish private-sector investment, Chang said the ROC government's economic liberalization and globalization policies have also given local industries a boost.

Taiwan is currently the world's 14-largest economy, and the island's two-way trade totaled US$237 billion in 1997, more than double the total of a decade ago, Chang said. The island is also an important source of capital supply in the international community, having invested US$15 million directly in other countries over the past decade.

Chang said trade figures indicate foreign investors are confident in Taiwan's investment climate. Foreign investment in Taiwan hit a record high of US$4.3 billion last year, a 73 percent increase over 1996. The amount of foreign capital that poured into Taiwan during the first five months of this year totaled US$1.2 billion, 37.4 percent higher than the same period one year ago.

Foreign investors are welcome to work hand in hand with the Republic of China government to develop new hi-tech industries on the island, as Taiwan needs greater diversification of its hi-tech industries, he said.

In recent years hi-tech industries have accounted for an increasing percentage of the island's manufacturing sector, Chang said. Last year the output of Taiwan's hi-tech industries totaled NT$2.7 trillion (US$77 billion), accounting for 43 percent of the overall production value of the manufacturing sector.

The vice economic affairs minister arrived in New York on Wednesday at the head of 22-member delegation aimed at attracting investment in Taiwan. He is scheduled to proceed to San Francisco on Tuesday.
Before leaving New York, Chang will host another investment seminar in Manhattan on Monday. More than 150 local business executives have applied to participate in the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEEDS TO IMPROVE INTERNATIONALIZATION EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has to step up internationalization efforts to improve its global competitiveness, according to a report released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The CEPD report said that Taiwan ranked 16th in global competitiveness in 1998, according to the Swiss-based International Institute for Management and Development (IMD), which began publishing an annual World Competitiveness Yearbook 11 years ago.

Eight categories comprising 244 criteria are used to measure a country's competitiveness. They are domestic economic strength, internationalization, government efficiency, banking services, infrastructure development, technological strength, industrial management, as well as manpower planning and living quality.
Taiwan ranked 11th in the IMD world competitiveness rankings in 1992 and 1993, slid to 22nd in 1994, rebounded to 14th in 1995, fell again to 18th in 1996 and further dropped to 23rd in 1997.

Taiwan's internationalization score continued to fall this year, though the island made gains in other categories. Taiwan's internationalization rating plunged to 32nd from the past three's year's ratings of 24th, 26th and 28th, signaling the island has declined in terms of internationalization compared with other countries.
Analyzing Taiwan's internationalization rating, which consists of 40 criteria, the CEPD said that Taiwan performed well in four areas but had bad ratings in 15 areas of the total.

The IMD gave Taiwan high marks on balance of current account, export of goods and labor services as a percentage of GDP, total foreign trade volume and stability of local currency against major international currencies.

Taiwan fared poorly in balance of trade of labor services, raking 43rd; balance of trade of labor services as a percentage of GDP, ranking 42nd; immigration law, ranking 42nd; diversification of export markets, ranking 41st; tourism revenue, ranking 37th; public departments and risk of multinational operations, ranking 35th; growth of foreign investment, ranking 34th; accumulated amount of foreign investment and protection of foreign investment, ranking 29th; and regional trade integration, ranking 26th.

Meanwhile, the CEPD pointed out that Taiwan's internationalization rating was behind Singapore, which finished second; Hong's Kong, third; Malaysia, 24th; and the Philippines, 28th. Taiwan ranked higher than South Korea, however, which finished 46th.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAINLAND AFFAIRS RESEARCH DIRECTOR LEAVES FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: Chang Rong-kung, director of the ruling Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Research Department, said on Sunday Beijing should properly handle the aftermath of the kidnapping and murder of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan on the mainland.
Chang made the remarks before leaving for Beijing to attend an academic seminar on cross-strait relations.
During his stay on the mainland, Chang said he will use the opportunity to convey Taiwan public opinion over Lin's death to the Beijing authorities.
Lin, 32, of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, died of a drug overdose after she was kidnapped on July 27 in Dalian City in the northeastern province of Liaoning.
According to Chang, in addition to meeting any demands from the victim's family, Beijing should permit Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) personnel to go to the mainland to help Lin's family.

Chang, the first KMT mainland affairs department chief to visit the mainland in 50 years, pointed out that over the past few years the safety of Taiwan business people on the mainland has been compromised. He urged Beijing to pay greater attention to the problem.

Commenting on the fate of four Taiwanese businessmen who are facing trial on charges of espionage, Chang said he hopes Beijing will take into account the feelings of Taiwan business people on the mainland and the status of cross-strait relations, and permit the four men to return to Taiwan as soon as possible.
Since 1992 mainland China has held annual seminars on cross-strait relations. Chang is scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 9 after attending this year's three-day meeting in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAM PLEDGES TO EXPAND TRADE WITH WTO MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Vietnam has pledged to expand trade and investment ties with World Trade Organization (WTO) members in its bid to expand multilateral trade, according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade body on Saturday.
Hanoi's application to join the WTO will form the basis for its trade policy in the next decade, Truong Dinh Tuyen, Vietnam's trade minister, was quoted as saying.

Tuyen told the first session of the working party on Vietnam's accession that the application was part of Hanoi's policy of expanding trade and investment ties with WTO members. "We are very conscious of the fact that joining the multilateral trade institution brings both rights and obligations," he said.

The two-day session in Geneva ushered in a new stage in Vietnam's trade policies in various fields, especially those related to commodities and investment, the WTO report said. A second session of the working party focusing on the transparency of Vietnam's policies will likely be held in Geneva in November.
Vietnam has trade ties with 105 countries and territories, and external trade has risen from US$4.42 billion in 1991 to US$19.5 billion in 1997.
Hanoi has issued 2,320 foreign investment licenses to investors from 61 countries and territories with prescribed capital amounting to US$31.2 billion by the end of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S GROUPS VISITING INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Aug. 2 (CNA) (By Peng Chou & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Representatives from women's rights groups in Taiwan on Sunday arrived in Indonesia for a four-day visit aimed at expressing their concern to the ethnic Chinese women who fell victim to sexual abuse during rioting there in May.

Taiwan's vice representative to Indonesia, Chang Yuan-lang, and his wife greeted the nine-member delegation, headed by Wang Ching-feng, a prominent women's rights activist and also a former member of Control Yuan, at the airport.

Before departing from Taipei, Wang said at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that the group plans to meet with some of the abused Indonesian Chinese, with the assistance of women's rights and human rights groups in the Southeast Asian country.

The delegation hopes to get more facts about the atrocities committed against the Chinese people during the chaotic period in May, Wang said, adding that they will help the victims seek medical treatment.

During the group's four-day stay there, Wang said that they expect to visit the nation's Women's Affairs Ministry, Social Welfare Ministry and National Human Rights Committee to urge the Indonesian government to provide women with adequate protection and guarantee such events will never happen again.

Saying the brutal killing of Chinese people and the raping of Chinese women in Indonesia has aroused widespread anger on the island, Wang stressed that it is time to take practical action to respond to such horrific events.

Wang, along with several women's rights groups as well as Voice of Taipei Broadcasting Co., on Wednesday launched a fund-raising campaign to help Chinese women in Indonesia. They also called on the people of Taiwan to scrap their travel plans to Indonesia and to write letters or send e-mail messages to relevant Indonesian agencies to protest the May riots.
It is estimated that some 1,200 ethnic Chinese were killed and several hundred ethnic Chinese women were raped during May's riots, which toppled former president Suharto.

During the past three days, a total of NT$150,000 has been received, of which NT$50,000 came from Foreign Minister Jason Hu on the first day of the campaign. The money will be donated to women's rights groups in Indonesia for emergency use.

The delegation is made up of representatives from the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, the Garden of Hope Foundation, the Termination of Child Prostitution Association and the Taiwan Human Rights Promotion Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP POISED TO BOYCOTT EXCHANGES WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: A task force of the leading opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Sunday it will submit a four-point resolution to the party, asking it suspend cross-strait exchanges to protest the kidnapping and murder of a DPP member in the mainland.

Legislator Chang Chun-Hung, one of the five-member task force and a DPP heavyweight, said the party strongly regretted that Beijing was unwilling to allow the return of Lin Ti-chuan's body to Taiwan on Monday, as her family had demanded. He added that the task force has decided to refer the four-point resolution to the party's Central Standing Committee at its next weekly meeting on Wednesday.

The resolution calls for a series of boycotts against mainland China by stalling a wide range of cross-strait activities, including the tightening of restrictions on visits by mainland Chinese personnel to Taiwan.

A 32-year-old DPP Kaohsiung City councilwoman, Lin was kidnapped and murdered last week in the northeastern province of Liaoning during a private visit to mainland China. Lin's family went to the mainland on Friday to bring back Lin's body.

The DPP's caucus in the Legislative Yuan will also visit the Mainland Affairs Council, Taiwan's highest agency in charge of formulating policy toward the mainland, on Wednesday. On Thursday the caucus will call on the Straits Exchanges Foundation to discuss the situation, said Chang.

In the short term, the DPP will request mainland authorities meet the demands raised by the party and Lin's family, while the party's long-term goal is to improve the safety and security of Taiwan businessmen on the mainland, as well as their property, through negotiations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Meanwhile another DPP Legislator, Lin Cho-shui, said Sunday on a television program that his party has overwhelmingly demanded that cultural, athletic and educational exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China be suspended because of Beijing's lack of respect for human rights, as demonstrated in their handling of the aftermath of Lin Ti-chuan's death.

Explaining the DPP's decision to call for a halt to nearly all bilateral exchanges with mainland China, Lin Cho-shui said the DPP believes such a forceful response is needed for Beijing to improve its handling of the situation.

Lin stressed that mainland China has become one of the most dangerous investment destinations for Taiwan businessmen overseas. Citing government statistics, he said as many as 30 Taiwan businessmen have been killed in the mainland. In Xiamen alone, there have been more than 200 reported kidnappings of Taiwan businessmen.

The DPP's decision to suspend cross-strait exchanges, he said, is not based solely on Lin Ti-chuan's death; the decision is based in the large number of Taiwan businessmen whose human rights are obviously ignored by mainalnd authorities.

He expressed the hope that the move would pressure Beijing to improve its protection of and respect for Taiwan people in the mainland. If the DPP did not call for the suspension of ties, how could the party expect to help protect Taiwan business interests in the mainland and the personal safety of Taiwan tourists, who make more than 10 million trips there every year? he asked.

A telephone poll regarding the DPP's decision to cut cross-strait exchanges was conducted during the program. Of the more than 30,000 people questioned about the DPP's decision, about two-thirds said they agreed with the move.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINATRUST CONSIDERS BUYING ORIENTAL BANK IN PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: The ROC government has urged Taiwan banks to acquire, merge with or lend funds to Paraguay's Oriental Investment and Development Bank, which mainly serves the South American country's ethnic Chinese community.
The Oriental Investment and Development Bank in Paraguay, or Banco Oriental de Inversion y Fomento -- its official name in Spanish -- has encountered financial difficulties in recent months.
At present, Chinatrust Commercial Bank is in negotiations with Oriental, and the ROC government is hopeful the bank will be bought by Chinatrust, said ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Agustin Liu.
Oriental has called a shareholders meeting for Aug. 16 to discuss the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR CRITICIZES BEIJING ON COUNCILWOMAN CASE

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih on Sunday accused Beijing of improperly handling affairs related to the death of Lin Ti-chuan and said the matter has raised dissatisfaction among people in Taiwan.

Lin, a 32-year-old Kaohsiung City councilwoman and member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was abducted July 27 in Dalian City in the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning. She died of a drug overdose after receiving repeated drug injections from her abductors.
She had gone to the mainland with her boyfriend, 36-year-old Wei Tien-kang of Kaohsiung. Wei was likewise kidnapped, but later escaped and reported in the incident to local authorities.

Beijing has refused a demand by Lin's family that no anatomy be performed on the body, and Wu said Beijing's refusal has sown dissatisfaction among the people of Taiwan. The decision has negatively affected cross-strait relations, he stressed.

Frank Hsieh, the DPP's Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, also expressed his indignation over Beijing's insistence on an anatomy. He urged the public to support Lin's family in their request that the body be returned untouched.
Reports from the mainland indicate Lin's family is still at odds with mainland authorities over the issue.

The Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait convened an emergency meeting Sunday to discuss whether an anatomy will be performed. The meeting was presided over by ARATS' deputy chief Tang Shubei, and a decision on the matter was expected some time Sunday evening.
According to a tentative schedule, Lin's body will leave Dalian Monday at 10 a.m. and arrive at Kaohsiung's Siaokang Airport at 5:30 p.m.
Wei has expressed a desire to accompany his girlfriend's body back to Taiwan, but his request was turned down by mainland authorities, who insist that Wei stay to help with the investigation.

On Sunday Wei said he had taken Lin to the mainland for sightseeing and that he does not know when will be allowed to return to Taiwan. He expressed his regret over Lin's death to her family. "It's all my fault," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3,000 IN-LINE SKATERS FORM LONG CHAIN BEFORE PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: A group of some 3,000 people on Sunday formed a long chain in front of the Presidential Office in downtown Taipei, all of them wearing in-line skates.

According to the organizer of the event, the 3,000 in-line skaters, who formed a spectacular winding line, one kilometer long, in front of the Presidential Office for nearly 40 minutes, have broken the Guinness Book of World Records for the number of people in an in-line skate chain.
Despite scorching hot weather, in-line skating enthusiasts, most of whom are children and young people, began to swarm into the plaza in front of the Presidential Office Sunday morning.

Around 9 a.m., President Lee Teng-hui showed up and spoke briefly to the participants before striking a gong to kick off the event. President Lee said that seeing those active skaters, he had the feeling that it is good to be young.
President Lee also encouraged them to make the most of their time and talent, stressing that with determination and perseverance, nothing is impossible.

Many government officials and public figures, including Lai Kuo-chou, President Lee's son-in-law and director-general of ruling Kuomintang's Youth Affairs Department, and Su Chi, vice secretary-general to the president, were among those in the chain.

But the most prominent participant was the KMT's Taipei mayoral candidate, Ma Ying-jeou, an in-line skating novice. Though nearly falling over, Ma, wearing a helmet and protective gear, soon proved his athletic prowess.

Vice President Lien Chan also became part of the event by giving awards to skaters at the closing ceremony. As the Presidential Palace is also open to visitors on Sunday, the area was crowded with people.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK POLITICAL PARTY LEADERS, SCHOLARS VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: About 10 Hong Kong political party leaders and scholars left for Taipei Sunday to visit Taiwan's science and technological industries.

The visitors include Chairman Allen Lee Peng-fei of the Liberal Party and Christine Loh Kung-wai of the Citizens' Party, as well as Lee Wah-ming of the Democratic Party and Chen Kam Lam of the Democratic Alliance for Betterment of Hong Kong.
This is the largest group of Hong Kong political leaders and scholars to visit Taipei since the handover of the territory to Beijing in July 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY THREATENS HUNGER STRIKE IF LIN'S BODY UNDERGOES AUTOPSY

TEXT.P: Family members of Lin Ti-chuan, the Kaohsiung City Councilwoman and opposition Democratic Progressive Party member murdered last week in the mainland, are preparing to stage a hunger strike if the mainland authorities do not cancel a planned autopsy and allow her body to be returned to Taiwan untouched.

Kaohsiung City Councilor Huang Cho-hsing, who accompanied Lin's family to mainland China, announced her family's intentions while speaking by phone with Lin's office in Kaohsiung. Huang and Lin's parents flew to the mainland on Friday after being informed of her death on Wednesday.

As local mainland Chinese public security authorities still insist on carrying out an autopsy to determine the exact cause of Lin's death, Huang said Lin's parents, who strongly oppose the idea, are preparing to stage a hunger strike.

Former DPP Legislator Huang Chao-hui, who is the acting head of Lin's office in Kaohsiung, said Lin's friends will also stage a hunger strike in Kaohsiung if mainland China refuses to allow the return of Lin's body.

Huang, however, said the situation should not be difficult to resolve, as the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) has promised to negotiate with the Beijing-based Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) over the issue.
SEF and ARATS are the semi-official bodies authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contacts.

The DPP's Women's Development Department held a commemorative service in Kaohsiung to pay tribute to the 32-year-old Lin. It also issued a statement demanding mainland authorities quickly resolve the case and allow Lin's body to return to Taiwan.

While condemning the mainland authorities' arrogance in their refusal to allow the return of Lin's body, the statement said the department would not break off contacts with the mainland authorities and would continue to monitor their handling of the case.

Lin and her boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, left for mainland China on Sunday for a three-day, private visit. The couple were abducted by a group of armed men and taken to Haicheng City in the northeastern province of Liaoning on Monday. Wei escaped from his kidnappers on Wednesday and reported the incident to local police.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRADE OFFICIALS: WTO ENTRY PRICE 'TOO HIGH'

TEXT.P: Beijing said its trade partners are demanding too high a price for the country's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade body on Sunday.

"The main obstacle to China's entering the WTO is certain member countries demanding too high a price for China to pay in its current economic development," trade minister Shi Guangsheng was quoted as telling visiting French farm minister Louis Le Pensec.

Shi, who did not specify which WTO members were being referred to, urged France and the European Union (EU) to help "bring the price down to a reasonable level if they really want China in the WTO," the report said.

The United States and many other industrialized countries have resisted mainland China's repeated demand that it be allowed to enter the global trade body under the relaxed terms offered to developing countries.

Opponents of mainland China's entry under such terms argue that mainland China's economy is too big and its exports too strong to be admitted under conditions designed to help the world's poorest nations boost their economies through trade.
Another sticking point with US and EU negotiators has been mainland China's insistence on maintaining high tariffs on products such as cars, chemicals, films and liquor, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE DIES, ANOTHER SERIOUSLY INJURED IN CPC EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: One worker died and another was seriously injured in a gas explosion at a petrochemical plant of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) in southern Taiwan Monday morning.
The explosion occurred at 10:15 a.m. at the plant's third naphtha cracker, located in Linyuan, Kaohsiung County.

Severely burned in the blast were contract workers Lee Chun-te and Chan Kuo-an. The two were rushed to an area hospital. Lee later died while Chan, who suffered burns to more than 50 percent of his head, was still being treated as of early Monday afternoon.
CPC officials said that at the time of the accident the naphtha cracker was undergoing annual checks and maintenance procedures, which began Saturday.
The explosion may have resulted from wielding sparks, according to an initial investigation by CPC officials.
Although no further explosions were expected, firefighters remained at the plant Monday afternoon to guard against further mishaps.
