DOC.HEADLINE: KMT URGES CALM DESPITE CALLS TO SUSPEND CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A ranking Kuomintang official on Monday urged the public to be rational in passing judgment on the government's mainland policy, despite calls by members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party for Taiwan to suspend bilateral exchanges with mainland China.

The recent murder of DPP member and Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in the mainland has aroused widespread concern in Taiwan, KMT Secretary-General John Chang acknowledged, but he said national security must be a consideration in the government's dealings with mainland China.
Moreover, the KMT bases its mainland policy on popular opinion, he stressed.

Although some DPP members have called for a suspension of exchanges with mainland China, Chang noted that any such proposal must first be approved by the party. The KMT will continue to monitor the issue, he added.
Chang said the KMT will also demand mainland Chinese authorities properly handle the case and bring the culprits to justice quickly.

Chang's remarks followed an announcement Sunday by a five-member DPP task force that it will present a four-point resolution to the party's Central Standing Committee at its weekly meeting on Wednesday, calling for a series of cross-strait exchange suspensions to protest mainland China's handling of affairs related to Lin's death.

Lin, 32, was kidnapped Monday by a group of armed men during a private visit to the northeastern province of Liaoning. She died two days later of a drug overdose, apparently the result of repeated injections given by her kidnappers.

Lin's family traveled to the mainland on Friday in hopes of bringing her body back to Taiwan on Monday. Local officials, however, insist on first performing an autopsy, which Lin's family strongly objects to.
Lin's family and local police are still seeking a compromise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIAL OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN ACCUSED OF ESPIONAGE BEGINS

TEXT.P: The families of four Taiwan businessmen who are being tried in a Beijing court on charges of espionage said Monday that they will patiently wait for a verdict.

The trial of the four men -- Kou Chien-ming, Chen Shao-yu, Han Yue-ting and Chou Chang-ming -- began Monday, and the men's families called on the public not to speculate on the trial's outcome until a verdict is formally announced.

The families of the four businessmen traveled to Beijing this past weekend after being informed by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait that the men's trial would begin Monday.
The four Taiwan citizens have been in detention since they were arrested in late March by mainland China's state security authorities. They are accused of spying for Taiwan's military.
The Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense has denied the charges and demanded that mainland China provide concrete evidence to support the accusations.
Due to the nature of the charges, the trial is not open to the public, nor are the media allowed to cover it.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO HANDLE KIDNAP-MURDER CASE WITH PRUDENCE

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan on Monday urged Beijing to exercise prudence in handling issues related to last week's kidnap-murder of a Taiwan councilor in mainland China.

Liu made the appeal after a briefing from Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan's kidnap-murder in the northeastern mainland city of Haicheng on July 29.

"We look forward to seeing the mainland authorities handle the aftermath of Lin's tragic death with prudence, care, and thought for future relations across the Taiwan Strait," said Liu, who concurrently serves as convener of the Cabinet's mainland policy panel.
Liu said mainland authorities should respect the desire and opinions of the Lin family, as well as the feelings of all Taiwan people, in dealing with the case.

"We regret that Beijing rejected the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation's plan to send members of its staff to accompany Lin's grieving parents to the mainland to handle the aftermath of the incident," Liu said.

Nevertheless, Liu said he doesn't think the government should immediately suspend cross-strait exchanges to protest Beijing's snubbing of the SEF's plan, as the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has urged. Lin was a DPP member.

"We should remain calm and keep a close watch on Beijing's handling of the situation. If Beijing fails to deal with the case satisfactorily, we'll take countermeasures," Liu said, adding that the government should take into consideration overall national interests and the well-being of all Taiwan's residents when formulating its mainland policy.

The vice premier went on to say that Lin's tragic death has once again manifested many practical problems existing in cross-strait exchanges, particularly the personal safety and property rights of Taiwan businesspeople and ordinary travelers in mainland China.

"We hope Beijing will not ignore these issues any longer and will immediately resume cross-strait dialogue to work out effective measures to better protect the personal safety and legitimate rights of Taiwan investors and travelers," Liu said.
Meanwhile, MAC Chairman Chang said he hopes SEF Chairman C.F. Koo's plan to make a landmark visit to the mainland this fall will proceed smoothly.

"If Koo's travel plans can be realized, he will be able to exchange views with his mainland counterpart (Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait Chairman Wang Daohan) on these issues," said Chang.
The SEF is authorized by the ROC government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties between the two sides.

Commenting on the DPP's call for an across-the-board suspension of cross-strait exchanges in the wake of Liu's kidnap-murder, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said the government consistently respects the opinions expressed by the country's different political parties.
However, he said it is inappropriate for the government to comment on views or opinions expressed by individual persons or political parties.
Chen further said that if mainland China fails to handle the Lin case properly, it will certainly have an adverse bearing on the feelings of the people of Taiwan, and on cross-strait ties in general.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES EXCHANGE LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 23.64 points to close at 7,599.04.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,715.8 and fell as low as 7,599.04 at the close of trading.
A total of 15.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.25 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with both foodstuff stocks and pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by cement shares at 1 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, electrical stocks at 0.6 percent, and both plastics and chemical shares and construction stocks at 0.3 percent.
Only the bank and insurance category posted a gain, moving up at 0.7 percent.
Meanwhile, Taipei's stock index futures were generally lower.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down 57 points to close at 7,552, while those for October slid 58 points to close at 7,550. December futures, however, remained unchanged at 7,730.
The number of contract transactions for the three futures were 293, two and three, respectively.
The TAIEX Index Futures for March dropped 59 points to close at 7,850 with one contract transaction, and there were no transactions of June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX) reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 7,609 points for September; 7,608 for October; 7,730 for December; 7,909 for March; and 7,978 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.004 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at 34.419.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.35, and had a low of 34.45.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$290 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROOM FOR FURTHER CUTS IN PETROLEUM PRICES: CPC

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said on Monday that there is still room for further cuts in petroleum prices in August.
CPC officials said the cost of imported crude oil was US$11.62 per barrel in July, down by nearly US$1 dollar from the previous month.

The officials said that in the wake of a continued slide in crude prices on the international market, the CPC cut petroleum prices by 2.85 percent in July, costing the CPC NT$700 million (US$20.29 million) in lost revenue.
The CPC imported 18.72 million barrels of crude in July at a cost of more than US$217 million.

The officials said that while the Legislative Yuan has yet to review the budget for the CPC in the new fiscal year, the company itself has tentatively set this year's surplus at NT$22.4 billion (US$649.27 million), the same figure as last year.

The CPC recorded a pre-tax surplus of NT$3.85 billion (US$111.68 million) in June, almost double its targeted surplus of NT$1.99 billion for the period, prompting the officials to say there is still room for further cuts in petroleum prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOR MAINLAND CHINA, FLOODING IS TORRENT OF TROUBLE

TEXT.P: More than 1,200 people have been killed and millions more have lost their homes in the worst flooding of mainland China's Yangtze River since 1954, according to a report in Sunday's Los Angeles Times.
A staff writer filed the story from the scene in Wuhan, an industrial city of 7 million people in Hubei province.
After weeks of unrelenting rain, the Yangtze, mainland China's longest river, has inundated huge swaths of central and eastern mainland China, creating damage estimated at US$5 billion to date.
About 60 percent of Hunan province, the birthplace of Mao Tsetung, is currently underwater, while the provinces of Anhui and Jiangsu have declared states of emergency.

And still the rain continues to fall on the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze and its tributaries, adding to the possibility that yet another peak of rushing water -- the region's fourth -- may hurtle downriver and wreak further destruction.
Seasonal typhoons predicted for later this month could also be catastrophic.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MEDICAL TECHNICIAN URGED TO RECEIVE AIDS TREATMENT

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Monday urged a former medical technician to come forward and seek medical treatment for AIDS as soon as possible.

The technician, who is in his 20s, left Shin Kong Wu Ho Su Memorial Hospital in March. He tested positive for human-immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in the Veterans General Hospital-Taipei in April but had not yet developed AIDS symptoms.
The DOH announcement follows reports in the local press that the technician contracted HIV during the course of his work, probably from a prick by an infected hypodermic needle.

A Shin Kong hospital spokesman stressed that the channel through which the technician contracted HIV is by no means certain, adding that while the hospital lost contact with the technician after March, there are no records of him having been pricked by needles during his work.

The DOH officials urged the man to go to the hospital as soon as possible to receive treatment for his condition, pointing out that the new "drug cocktail" therapy can be quite successful, especially if it is started at an early stage of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPLOSION ABOARD NAVAL VESSEL KILLS 7

TEXT.P: A gas explosion on a naval vessel on Monday afternoon killed seven of its officers and crewmen, according to the Naval Fleet Command.
The vessel, the "Suei Yang" was carrying out a routine fire drill off the coast of Tsoying, in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, when the explosion took place at around 3:00 p.m.
The vessel was towed back to the Tsoying naval base by rescue boats pending a full investigation by the fleet command to determine the cause of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL VISITS XINHUA NEWS AGENCY

TEXT.P: Guo Chaoren, president of Xinhua News Agency, met with Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang Central Department of Mainland Research, here Monday to exchange views on how to improve news exchanges between mainland China and Taiwan.

During the meeting, Chang briefed Guo on the transformation of the Taipei-based Central News Agency during the past seven decades, and how it reports mainland Chinese news. He expressed the hope that Xinhua will report more news about Taiwan.

Guo briefed Chang on the recent development of Xinhua, and said that, with the development of cross-strait relations, Xinhua needs to station news reporters in Taiwan for direct and accurate reports of news.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN ACTIVISTS EXPRESS CONCERN TO INDONESIAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: A group of women's rights activists from Taiwan met with Indonesian Women's Affairs Minister Tutty Alawiyah on Monday to express their concern about atrocities committed by Indonesian rioters against ethnic Chinese women.

The delegation presented a three-point statement to Alawiyah urging the Indonesian government to attach importance to the abuse of women and girls during the political turmoil which swept the Southeast Asian country in May.
The statement said the Indonesian government should do its utmost to investigate the organized atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese women and girls during the chaotic period.

"The Indonesian government should bring to justice all those who have organized, instigated or committed brutalities against Chinese women and girls during the May rioting," the statement said, adding that Indonesian authorities should provide adequate compensation for the victims.

The statement also demanded that the Indonesian government take all steps necessary to maintain law and order in order to protect the personal safety of its citizens and to prevent any recurrence of similar atrocities or misfortune.

The statement urged the Indonesian government to promote harmony between the minority ethnic Chinese and the majority ethnic Indonesian racial groups, and to throw its support, encouragement and assistance behind non-government organizations dedicated to promoting racial integration and cooperation.
It further demanded that the Indonesian authorities abolish any law or regulation which discriminates against minority racial groups and to protect their basic human rights and freedoms.
The delegation, which arrived in Jakarta on Sunday, was accompanied at the meeting with the Indonesian minister by ROC Deputy Representative to Indonesia Chang Yung-lang.

Responding to her guests, Alawiyah said not a single ethnic Chinese woman has yet come forward to report the ordeals she endured during the May rioting to the special task force formed by the Indonesian Women's Affairs Ministry.

Alawiyah said that although some Indonesian private groups claim that 168 ethnic Chinese women and girls were raped during the riots, many Indonesian people do not believe that the number of victims is so high.

Alawiyah told the delegation that she issued a statement on June 8 condemning the abuse of ethnic Chinese women. "I stressed in the statement that such violent actions against these women have violated human rights and the Indonesian constitution," she said.

Alawiyah went on to say she has asked the 12 women police officers at Indonesia's National Police Bureau, as well as volunteers with various private organizations, to help investigate and interview alleged victims.
"All telephone calls or faxes received so far by the special task force relating to the atrocities have been given by third parties, not by victims themselves," Alawiyah said.

"There were reports that 96 sexual assault victims simultaneously went to a large Indonesian hospital to receive medical treatment. However, investigations by my ministry's special task force show that there were only nine victims in the hospital. One of the victims had already died and eight others were injured. Most of the injured sustained only minor injuries and didn't seem to have been raped," Alawiyah explained.

Noting that Indonesian President B.J. Habibie is strongly concerned about the incidents, Alawiyah said the first lady is heading a special investigative team composed of five Cabinet ministers, to probe the case.

"This investigative team is scheduled to come up with a report in three months," Alawiyah said, adding that any person who is found guilty of committing atrocities will be given a 13-to-20-year jail term.
Alawiyah also promised that the Women's Affairs Ministry will give support and assistance to abused women intending to go abroad for medical treatment.

Wang Ching-feng, a member of the Taiwan delegation, said it is not uncommon that no victim is willing to come forward to report her ordeals. "Indonesian investigators should conduct thorough checks of clues provided by third parties in order to locate victims and their abusers or attackers," said Wang, a lawyer and a former Taiwan Control Yuan member.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA OFFICIAL WARNS LOCAL INVESTORS OF UNPREDICTABLE RENMINBI

TEXT.P: An official of the Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) warned Taiwan businesspeople on Monday to be aware of the risks of a devalued renminbi, the currency of mainland China.

Chang Yao-tsung, director-general of the Department of Statistics under the MOEA, said that the recent depreciation of the Japanese yen is putting the Beijing authorities under greater pressure to devalue the renminbi, and advised Taiwan investors to take all measures necessary to avoid being affected.
Mainland China is not a well-developed free economic market, Chang pointed out, which means any devaluation of the currency involves political considerations, making it hard to predict trends.

The battered yen has continued its plunge in recent days, with its exchange rate hovering at around 144 to the US dollar, close to the rate of 146 to the greenback recorded when US President Bill Clinton made his recent visit to mainland China.

Mainland China's newspapers have said openly in recent days that if the downward spiral of the yen does not end soon, it will force the Beijing authorities to devalue its currency. The People's Bank of China has been intervening in its foreign exchange market since last week, indicating that the renminbi is facing rather heavy pressure to devalue.

Chang said the MOEA will provide Taiwan businesspeople with sufficient information about forward foreign exchange trading and spot foreign exchange trading, as well as offer advice about holding US dollars, which are viewed as hard currency, so that Taiwan traders in mainland China might avoid any losses resulting from a weaker exchange rate.

The MOEA official stressed that the most important task at the moment is stabilizing Asia's economy and financial market, adding that the value of the renminbi should not be judged based solely on its impact upon mainland China's exports, but rather on its effect on the Asian and world economy as a whole.

DOC.HEADLINE: 23 DISSIDENTS WANT TO GO TO JAIL FOR DEMOCRACY'S SAKE

TEXT.P: Twenty-three dissidents Sunday jointly issued an open letter to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, saying they would accompany three other dissidents to prison for the sake of democracy, if the three are wrongfully indicted.

According to a news release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, the open letter said more than 20 dissidents have been detained after US President Bill Clinton ended his visit to mainland China in early July. Three of them-- Wang Youcai, Lin Hui, and Zhang Shanguang-- have not been released.

Wang and Lin were arrested in Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province in mid-July after they and other dissidents announced the establishment of a preparatory committee for the formation of "Chinese Democratic Party." Zhang, of Hunan Province, was arrested for his plan to establish an association for protecting the rights of laid-off workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU PUB ARSON SUSPECT ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Police on Monday arrested in central Taiwan's Changhua County Lee Hsin-tsun, whom police suspect set fire to a pub in Hsinchu one week earlier, killing eight and injuring 12.
"It was all because of alcohol. I am very sorry," said Lee, while confessing to setting the blaze.
According to police, Lee claimed he had been beaten by two bar patrons the night he set the bar ablaze. The beating clouded his judgment and he was not aware of what he was doing, he said.

After the fire, Lee traveled by taxi to Taipei, where he then caught a train to Taichung. From the train station in Taichung, he took another taxi to a chicken farm, belonging to Lee's distant aunt, in Changhua County.
For the next week, Lee dared not leave the farm during the day, he said, adding that his 80-year-old aunt was not aware that he was hiding at the farm.
Lee was rounded up in a field not far from the farm at the moment when he was looking for drinking water, police said.
When Lee was apprehended, he was wearing the same black suit that he had worn the night of the fire, said the police, adding that he smelled of chicken feces.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-THAILAND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A 29-member Thai delegation will leave for Taipei Tuesday to attend the ninth economic cooperation conference between the two countries on Wednesday.

During the one-day meeting, former Thai deputy prime minister Korn Dabbarangsi will speak on the investment climate in Thailand, while former Thai commerce minister Naronchai Akransanee will talk about the prospect of Thai economy.

Participants of the two countries in the meeting will exchange views on matters concerning tourism, public constructions, real estate, science park, export-oriented industries, agriculture, auto industry, machinery, electronics appliances, and communications equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER CALLS ON INDONESIAN GOVERNMENT TO INVESTIGATE RIOTS

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Monday urged Jakarta to consider the feelings of the people of the Republic of China and properly investigate allegations that some 200 ethnic Chinese women were raped during rioting in May.

Hu made the remarks while receiving a group of more than 200 protesters, led by Legislator Lee Ching-hua of the opposition New Party (NP), and Chen Wei-cheng, president of the Indonesian Overseas Chinese Association.

Before visiting the Foreign Ministry, the protesters -- some carrying placards that read "We Demand Justice and Compensation for the Victims" or "Indonesian Government Please Note: Raping and Killing Toward the Weak Woman. This Is Very Shameful Way of the Indonesian Nation" -- demonstrated outside the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei.

They met with the office's vice chairman, Ahmed Bey Sofwan, as well as other office officials. Sofwan expressed regret over the atrocities and said that the Indonesian government is caring for and protecting the victims, and an investigation into the incidents is underway, he said.

Lee, an NP lawmaker from Taipei, read a protest letter that called on the government to punish the rapists, immediately apologize for the atrocities, provide medical care and compensation to the victims and offer assurances that similar incidents will not happen in the future.

Chen, who was born in Indonesia and educated in Taiwan, appealed to the Indonesian government to protect and respect human rights, and to treat fairly all Chinese Indonesians in accordance with the country's constitution.
He also asked the ROC Foreign Ministry to relax visa regulations limiting how long Indonesian passport holders can stay in Taiwan.
In his reply, the foreign minister said he will soon invite related government agencies to a special meeting on the matter.

Responding to protesters' calls for Taiwan to stop investing in Indonesia, Hu said the Indonesian government has ordered an investigation into the sexual assaults and has vowed repeatedly to punish those responsible for the attacks.

Hu said that, in view of public opinion in Taiwan, he hopes the Indonesian government will properly handle the matter. Obviously, he added, both ROC government policy toward Indonesia and Taiwan businesses' willingness to invest there are likely to be affected by the attacks.
So far, Taiwan invested more than US$13 billion in Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-US ECONOMICS MEETING TO OPEN FRIDAY IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: An annual economics meeting between the Republic of China and the United States is slated to open in Washington Friday.
Ranking economics and finance officials from the two sides will discuss issues on trade and investment, financial liberalization and cooperation on customs-related affairs.
ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu will head Taiwan's delegation to the meeting, the highest official contact between the United States and the Republic of China.

Other members of the Taiwan delegation include Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang and a deputy governor of the Central Bank of China.
US Deputy Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence Summers, as well as officials from the Trade Representative Office and Federal Reserve Board are expected to take part in the meeting.
Lin and his delegation will leave for the United States on Tuesday.
Lin said he plans to take advantage of the meeting to complete the signing of an agreement between the two countries on Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The Republic of China completed WTO bilateral talks with Washington in February, when the two sides signed a draft accord.
Besides the United States, the European Union, Hong Kong and Canada have completed bilateral negotiations with Taiwan on its WTO accession, but have not yet signed official agreements to that effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES DEMAND WORKING RIGHTS

TEXT.P: More than 2,000 employees of Taiwan's provincial government on Monday appealed to Provincial Governor James Soong to help them secure working rights as the deadline for downsizing the provincial government looms near.

The employees gathered in front of the Provincial Government building, located in Nantou County, central Taiwan, at 11:30 a.m. Monday. Some carried placards and banners with messages such as "Fight for Our Rights, Governor, Please Support Us," "We Want To Survive," and "Don't Let Us Be Separated From Our Families."

According to the constitutional amendment passed by the National Assembly last July, the provincial government should be downsized as part of an effort to upgrade government efficiency. In addition, the elections for provincial governor and provincial assembly should be abolished.

At 11:45 a.m. Soong came out of his office to accept the petition. Soong told the demonstrators that today was the most painful day he had encountered since being elected to his current post in the provincial government four years ago. He added that he felt very sorry his employees had to take to streets to fight for their rights.

Soong also pointed out that some two years ago, when the issue of downsizing the provincial government was raised, he foresaw protests. He said that, unfortunately, no one at the central government wanted to listen to him at that time.
In a quivering voice, Soong stressed that what the provincial government employees want is dignity, care and equal treatment.
The central government is responsible for making arrangements for the employees, Soong said, adding that the employees should have a say in what their future will be.

In the petition, the demonstrators said that the deadline for downsizing the provincial government is approaching, but the central government has made no specific plans about how to provide for employees of the provincial government.

They said that due to feelings of uncertainty about their future, they have been forced to organize the "Taiwan Provincial Government Employees Self-Rescue Alliance," to fight for their working rights.

Two appeals were proposed in the petition. One is that their basic working rights should be secured. The central government should not force them to retire or dismiss them with severance money. Second, they demanded that their new jobs should be in the same geographic areas where they are working now. They should not be forced to depart from their families and work in a different area.

In addition, the employees demanded to meet with Premier Vincent Siew and to be invited to attend the meetings regarding the downsizing of the provincial government. They also said that the central government should hold public hearings to on how to provide for provincial government employees, should hold workshops to let the employees know what will be done and should praise the contribution the provincial government employees have made to the society.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPLOSION ABOARD NAVAL VESSEL KILLS 7, WOUNDS 5

TEXT.P: A boiler explosion on a naval destroyer Monday afternoon killed seven of its crewmen and seriously wounded five others, according to the Naval Fleet Command.

The destroyer "Suei Yang" was conducting a routine drill 12 miles off the coast of Tsoying, in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County, when a fire broke out in the boiler room, resulting in an explosion at 2:05 p.m.
At a hastily convened press conference in the evening, Naval Fleet Commander Lai Kuang-yu extended his condolences to the victims of the blast.
The vessel was towed back to the Tsoying naval base by rescue boats, and the fleet command has launched a full investigation to determine the cause of the accident.

"Suei Yang," which has been in service for 47 years, is expected to be decommissioned soon since Taiwan is upgrading its fleet after acquiring US-made Knox-class and Perry-class frigates and French-made Lafayette frigates.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES SEASON'S FIRST TYPHOON WARNING

TEXT.P: Light typhoon Otto is bearing down on southern and eastern Taiwan with ever-increasing strength, the Central Weather Bureau warned on Monday.

The bureau posted its first typhoon warning of the season at 2:55 p.m., when the center of the typhoon was located about 490 kilometers southeast of Hengchun, the southernmost tip of Taiwan. The storm was moving in a northwesterly direction at 23 kilometers per hour, up from the 18 kilometers per hour recorded earlier in the day.

The bureau said that the storm, packing torrential rain and winds of up to 23 meters per second with gusting of 30 meters per second, will threaten the Hengchun peninsula, as well as the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien.

Although still described as light at the current stage, Otto's strength is steadily increasing and it might intensify into a medium typhoon, the bureau said, warning the public to remain aware of subsequent advisories.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA, TAIWAN TO HOLD MINISTERIAL-LEVEL ECONOMIC MEETING IN SEPT.

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang will lead a delegation to attend the second ministerial-level economic meeting between Taiwan and Malaysia, to be held on Sept. 4-5 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

MOEA officials said that Wang and his Malaysian counterpart will exchange views on bilateral trade, multilateral trade and investment issue during the meeting. Wang will also ask Malaysia to support Taiwan to become a dialogue partner of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

Ever since Taiwan and Malaysia held the first ministerial-level economic meeting in 1997, the bilateral economic relationship has become closer, economic officials said. Taiwan was Malaysia's fourth-largest trading partner in 1997, while Malaysia was Taiwan's seven-largest trading partner during the same period.

According to statistics compiled by Malaysian authorities, as of the end of April this year, investment from Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia has accumulated to US$8.46 billion, making Taiwan the Southeast Asian country's second-largest investor, behind only Japan.

Prior to the official economic meeting, an economic meeting in both countries' private sectors will take place on Sept. 3. The Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce will organize a delegation to attend the meeting, the 11th of its kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE CALLS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF CHINESE CULTURE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday called for the preservation of traditional Chinese culture and for the advancement of an even greater Chinese culture.
Lee made the remark at the opening of the third general meeting of the World Chinese Writers Association, which was held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
More than 100 Chinese authors from 36 countries are taking part in the five-day meeting, which includes a seminar on Chinese culture and literature.

The president presented a "Cultural Contribution Award" and a "Life-long Accomplishment Award" to Wang You-theng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, and to noted writer Lin Hai-ying in recognition of their outstanding contributions to the promotion of international cultural exchanges.
Lee pointed out that both Chinese culture and literature are not only important assets to mankind but also a precious treasure of the Republic of China.
The president also praised overseas Chinese writers for their contributions to Chinese culture.

He noted that Chinese people began to emigrate from the mainland several hundred years ago. Many such emigrants have strived to preserve traditional Chinese culture, creating many beautiful and great Chinese literary works. They have introduced new concepts and offered a wider vision, and their works have had a profound impact on Chinese culture.
Because of its unique geographical position and history, Taiwan has also played an important role in the promotion of Chinese culture, Lee said.
He explained that during the past half century, Taiwan has achieved miraculous economic and political development.

In the future, Lee said, Taiwan will engage in cultural development, preserving traditional culture on the one hand and absorbing the cream of world culture on the other, to further enlarge and improve Chinese culture.
He expressed his belief that this goal conforms with the ideals of overseas Chinese writers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVIDES RELIEF TO TIDAL WAVE VICTIMS IN PAPUA NEW GUINEA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan relief delegation has donated more than US$440,000 to Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific country that was decimated by a July 17 tidal wave that killed 2,200 people and injured more than 9,000 others.

Roy Wu, spokesman for the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), announced the donations at a press conference in Taipei on Monday, a day after the delegation returned to Taiwan from Papua New Guinea.

MOFA brought together the group, which comprised volunteers from civil welfare organizations such as World Vision of Taiwan, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association, the International Fo Kuang Association and the Ming Tau Cultural Center.
Wu said that several members of the group have remained in Port Moresby, the capital of Papua New Guinea, to provide relief to victims of the massive tidal wave.
At the conference, Wu expressed his appreciation toward those organizations involved in the relief effort.
The Tzu Chi Association donated US$100,000 worth of medical equipment, in addition to monetary donations, an association spokesperson said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PATHOLOGIST TO JOIN MAINLAND COUNTERPARTS IN EXAMINATION

TEXT.P: Beijing authorities are allowing a Taiwan pathologist to join its experts in examining the body of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan, said the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Monday.

Chen Yao-chang, dean of the coroners department at National Taiwan University's medical school, will fly to Hong Kong on Tuesday and from there proceed to Haicheng, which is located in the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning.
Chen said he expects to arrive in Haicheng at about 10 p.m. Tuesday, which means Lin's body will not be examined until Wednesday at the earliest.
A National Assembly member appointed by the DPP, Chen said his mission is to help determine the cause of Lin's death while preserving her body.

He said he does not know, however, whether he will be allowed to bring back blood, urine and tissue samples for further analysis, adding that he must receive permission to do so from the mainland authorities.

Chen and Yen Wan-chin, director-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Department of China Affairs, had asked to travel to Haicheng along with Lin's family on Aug. 1 but were denied permission by Beijing.
Beijing later recanted and agreed to allow Chen looking on during the examination at the request of Lin's fmaily as a condition to carry out the examination, but Yen is still denied entry.
Beijing made the decision after reaching an agreement with Lin's family that an "examination", rather than an autopsy, would be conducted on the 32-year-old city councilor and DPP member.

Liaoning authorities originally argued that mainland law requires an autopsy be performed to determine the cause of any unnatural death. Lin's parents, however, want the body returned to Taiwan untouched.
Under the agreement, Liaoning medical examiners may inspect the corpse and obtain cell samples but may not dissect the body, said a staff member of Lin's Kaohsiung office.
Lin's body is expected to be returned to Taiwan on Aug. 7 or 8, said the staff member.

Lin was kidnapped, along with her Taiwanese boyfriend, in Dalian, located in Liaoning province, on July 27 while visiting the mainland. She died two days later of a drug overdose after receiving repeated injections from her abductors.
Her boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, escaped from the kidnappers and reported the incident to the local police.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR GREEK PARLIAMENT MEMBERS ARRIVE FOR SIX-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Four members of Greece's parliament arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a six-day visit.

During their stay, the representatives -- Eleftherios Papanikolaou, Theodoros Skrekas and two other members of parliament -- will meet Wang Jin-pyng, vice president of the Legislative Yuan; Lee Ta-wei, vice minister of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council; and Frederic P. N. Chang, deputy director general of the Government Information Office.
The four will also meet with other government officials and visit cultural and economic institutions.
They are scheduled to leave Aug. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON OTTO LANDS ON EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Light typhoon Otto landed on eastern Taiwan's Taitung County at 12:20 p.m. Tuesday, bringing strong winds and rain to the eastern and southern parts of Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau said.

The typhoon, with a radius of 150 kilometers, is moving northwest at 20 kilometers per hour, the bureau said, adding that the island is expected to escape the storm circle between Tuesday night and early Wednesday morning.

Airports were shut down in the Taitung County, the Hualien County and the Pingtung County as well as offshore islands of Green Island and Lanyu. In addition, the railroad transportation in the eastern Taiwan was suspended from 9:00 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ALMOST CERTAIN TO CANCEL TRIP TO AFRICA

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew is almost sure to scrap his trip to Africa after his recent prostrate surgery, sources close to Siew said on Tuesday.
Sources said that Siew, who underwent the surgery last week to correct an enlarged prostrate, was expected to check out of the hospital this Thursday.
Doctors have advised Siew to stay longer, although he has recovered well and hopes to leave the hospital sooner.
Siew is expected to convalesce at home before returning to work next Monday.
But because of the surgery, it is almost certain that Siew will scrap his original schedule to visit Africa in September, although other government officials might take the trip.

The enlargement of Siew's prostrate was detected when he underwent a routine checkup in May. He complained at the time of a frequent need to urinate and of experiencing pain while urinating. At the suggestion of doctors, Siew checked into Veterans General Hospital Wednesday afternoon.
