DOC.HEADLINE: MND CONFIRMS SUCCESSFUL TEST-FIRING OF ANTI-MISSILE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed on Tuesday that the locally developed anti-tactical ballistic missile (ATBM) system has undergone an electronic simulative test late last month.
However, the ministry denied local press reports that the new missile defense system will be ready for deployment in two years.

"The Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology-developed ATBM system already underwent an initial test-firing late last year and also completed an electronic simulative test in late July," said MND spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding.

Noting that the ATBM anti-missile system is adapted from the CIST-developed Tien-kung II (Sky Bow II) surface-to-air missile, Kung said the military-run CIST is still developing several related technologies.

"We'll evaluate whether to mass-produce the new defense system after the CIST completes development of certain key technologies," Kung explained, adding it is premature at this moment to predict that the military will be able to finalize test-firming and deployment of ATBM in two years' time.

In the face of communist China's mounting missile threat, Kung said Taiwan must beef up its anti-ballistic missile defense capabilities to ensure national security and protect its people's personal safety and property rights.
Against this background, Kung said, the military is focusing efforts on developing an ATBM defense system and a long-range radar system to upgrade its early warning and air defense capabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WARSHIPS COULD VISIT THE PHILIPPINES FOR EXERCISES

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada said Monday that national security is his chief consideration in supporting the proposed visiting forces agreement (VFA) between Manila and Washington.

The president said he had been assured by the United States, through Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, that the US warships conducting military exercises under the agreement would not carry any nuclear weapons.
Estrada said the country's policy toward the United States, which has been in place since the time of US President George Bush, will be strictly observed under the VFA.
Estrada said other countries which have bigger and better-equipped armies such as Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia have also entered into similar military agreements with the Unites States.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC EXPERT HEADS FOR MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Chen Yao-chang, director of the Forensic Medicine Department of National Taiwan University Hospital, left for mainland China Tuesday to help examine the body of Lin Ti-chuan, a Kaohsiung City councilwoman who was kidnapped and murdered last week in the mainland.

Accompanied by Tsai Chin-mei, deputy director of the Department of Tourism Services under the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Yen Wen-chin, head of the Mainland China Affairs Department of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, will travel to Haicheng in Liaoning Province via Hong Kong. Both Chen and Yen are DPP members, as was Lin.
Lin's body is currently at a local hospital in Haicheng.
Speaking prior to his departure from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Chen said he is going to the mainland to seek better terms for the transport of Lin's body back to Taiwan by her family.
In addition, Chen said, he will also join forces with local authorities to determine the exact cause of Lin's death without dissecting her body.

As Lin's parents and local police authorities reached an agreement Monday night that permitted local medical officials to examine, but not perform an autopsy on, Lin's body, Chen said he believes that the whole matter will proceed smoothly. It is expected that Lin's body will be returned to Taiwan on Saturday.
Lin's family originally planned to bring her body back to Taiwan Monday, but could not do so because local police insisted that an autopsy be performed on the body before it returned to Taiwan.

Lin, 32, and her boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, were abducted at knife-point by a group of men last Monday during a private visit to the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning. She was pronounced dead two days later at a Haicheng hospital.
Wei escaped from the kidnappers and reported the case to Haicheng police.
An initial investigation indicates Lin died of a drug overdose, the result of repeated injections by her kidnappers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA WILLING TO HELP RESOLVE ANGOLAN CONFLICT

TEXT.P: Any South African involvement in troubled Angola would be solely in peacekeeping operations in response to requests by the United Nations, Defence Minister Joe Modise said in Cape Town Monday.
Modise said that according to the information South Africa was getting, both sides in Angola -- the government and UNITA -- were preparing for conflict.

Deputy Defence Minister Ronnie Kasrils said South Africa wanted to see international role-players, such as the United States and Portugal, playing an energetic role in helping resolve to the conflict. This, however, had not yet happened, Kasrils added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWITZERLAND GIVES SOUTH AFRICA US$2.5 MILLION FOR STUDENT AID

TEXT.P: Visiting Swiss President Flavio Cotti, who is also Switzerland's foreign minister, signed a 16-million-rand (about US$2.5 million) student aid agreement with South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo in Cape Town Monday.
The object of the agreement is to enable the South African government to establish a national student financial aid scheme.

A second agreement signed by Cotti and Nzo at the ceremony, witnessed by South African President Nelson Mandela, was a declaration of intent between the two foreign ministers on joint actions and projects on issues of common interest to their ministries.
The ceremony followed a 40-minute talk between presidents Mandela and Cotti.
Cotti is currently on a three-day visit to South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANGOLAN REFUGEES ARRIVE IN ZAMBIA

TEXT.P: More than 60,000 refugees fleeing UNITA military conscription in eastern and northeastern Angola have arrived in Zambia, according to a statement by Zambia-based human rights organizations Monday.
"Inter-African Network for Human Rights and Development" and "Human Rights Watch" said in the statement that UNITA rebels were about to execute a major military offensive in Angola.
It said UNITA was forcibly drafting men and women aged 13 to 30 to beef up their defenses.
The United Nations High Commission for Refugees and Zambia's interior ministry said they would verify the figures later this week.

Presidents Frederick Chiluba of Zambia and Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe have appealed to the international community to exert pressure on UNITA to implement the Lusaka Protocol, signed Nov. 20, 1994, to prevent another outbreak of war in Angola.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA VOWS TO PUSH HARD FOR VFA PASSAGE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Estrada has said he would "lobby hard" for the passage of the proposed Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA).
The president made the commitment to visiting US Defense Secretary William Cohen during the latter's courtesy call on Estrada at Malacanang.
"The president feels strongly that he endorses the agreement and will lobby hard for it," Cohen said.
Cohen maintained, however, that relations between Manila and Washington would not be affected even if the Philippine Senate rejects the agreement.
Cohen told reporters that the VFA "will help contribute to the stability in the entire region."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S AID PROGRAM FOR INDONESIA STALLED

TEXT.P: Singapore's US$5 billion trade financing scheme for Indonesia is stalled because Indonesia is finding it difficult to fulfill some of the conditions of the agreement, according to Indonesia's special economic envoy to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).
"Indonesia is finding it difficult to meet some of the requirements of the scheme at this time," Iman Taufik, special envoy of Indonesian President Habibie to ASEAN was quoted as saying Monday.

Taufik, who is leading an eight-member delegation of the Indonesian Chamber of Commerce and Industry to Singapore, said that of the US$1 billion remitted by the United States to Jakarta for a similar trade financing plan, only about 20 percent has been utilized so far.
He said that many Indonesian companies were debt-ridden and not able to use the trade financing funds made available by countries such as the United States, Germany and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE CHILD TO RETURN HOME WITH A NEW FACE

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese baby boy who has undergone two operations to restructure his face, disfigured by congenital abnormalities, will return home with his mother on Wednesday, a Taipei-based charity organization said on Tuesday.
Compassion International said that the 18-month-old infant, whose nickname is Ar Fu, and his mother will fly back to Ho Chi Minh City on Wednesday, ending their more than two-month stay in Taiwan.

A spokesman for Compassion International, which arranged for Ar Fu's operations in Taiwan, said that the organization wanted to thank the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in the Taipei suburb of Linkou for performing the expensive operations free of charge.
The operations were described as successful by a medical team at the hospital. Several plastic surgeons and cranial nerve specialists were included in the team.

The first operation was conducted on June 19, during which the team remodeled the baby's distorted, swollen cranium. A second operation on July 6 was performed to remodel his cleft palate, deformed eyelids and nose.

The spokesman said that Ar Fu, whose hands and feet are also deformed, has been receiving rehabilitation therapy at Chang Gung Hospital during his stay here. After returning to Vietnam, the rehabilitation will continue and may last for at least 10 years, he added.
Founded in 1995, Compassion International aims to help children in Cambodia and Vietnam, as well as Taiwan's aboriginal children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO STUDENTS SERIOUSLY INJURED IN FACTORY EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: Six students were injured on Tuesday with two in critical condition when an explosion broke out at a plastics factory in Taoyuan County, Northern Taiwan, police said.
The injured students were rushed to the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou near Taipei for urgent medical treatment.
Doctors said the injured, aged between 16 and 17, were sent to the hospital at 10:30 a.m., adding that two of them are in critical condition.

Chen Juei-hsin suffered burns to 98 percent of his body, while Chang Chih-fu suffered burns to 95 percent of his body, doctors said. Other students suffered burns ranging from 4 percent to 27 percent of their bodies.
The students were working at the Chen Feng Plastic Co. in Kueishan, Taoyuan County, under a cooperation program between the vocational school they are attending and the factory.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR QUICK RETURN OF LIN'S BODY

TEXT.P: Despite an earlier call to suspend cross-strait exchanges, the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) seems to have softened its stance following an agreement between the family of Lin Ti-chuan, a DPP member killed in mainland China, and local police authorities on a post-mortem examination of Lin's body.

Legislator Chang Chun-hung, organizer of a five-member DPP task force, said Tuesday that recent tensions between the two sides caused by Lin's death would ease if mainland China agreed to allow her body to return to Taiwan soon. He also urged mainland China to quickly arrest the culprits and bring them to trial.

The task force originally planned to present a four-point resolution to the DPP's Central Standing Committee at its regular weekly meeting on Wednesday, urging the party to stall exchanges with the mainland. But Chang said now that they have decided to suspend the call, pending a final decision by mainland China on the disposition of Lin's body.
Denying that the DPP has politicized the affair, he said the task force took such a hardline approach in hopes of resolving the incident.

Chang's remarks came after the Taiwan media reported that Lin's parents and local mainland Chinese police authorities have reached an agreement to examine Lin's body without performing a full autopsy before it is returned to Taiwan.
Lin's parents had demanded that authorities release Lin's body untouched, but local police had insisted on first performing an autopsy.
Lin, 32, was abducted and killed by a group of armed men last week during a private visit to the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning.
Stressing that what happened to Lin was not an isolated occurrence, Chang said the personal safety and property of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China should be better protected.

The DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan will call on the Mainland Affairs Council Wednesday to discuss with officials issues related to the protection of Taiwan business and investment interests in the mainland, according to Chang.

Chou Po-lun, a DPP whip in the legislature, said the DPP's aim is to relax tensions between the two sides and solve the problem, not to suspend exchanges with mainland China. But he added that Lin's case has underscored the need for both sides to resume talks on technical issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved down NT$0.008 to the greenback in Taipei, closing at 34.427.
The local currency opened at 34.383 and was traded between 34.381 and 34.455.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$225.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC SEEKS STRATEGIC INVESTORS AMID PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: The Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) invited interested strategic investors to buy its shares in a presentation Tuesday in preparation for its privatization.
With 905.59 million shares, the AIDC hopes to release more than 50 percent of them so that it can complete its goal of privatization by the end of 1998.

The AIDC made a public announcement in late July, inviting those in domestic and foreign aviation, air shipping, electronics, metal and steel, and financial industries to take part in Tuesday's presentation.
A screening team is expected to select strategic investors in the first half of next year.

AIDC, whose predecessor is the Aero Industrial Development Center of Chungshan Institute of Science Technology under the Ministry of National Defense, has developed the AT3 trainer plane and the Indigenous Defense Fighter in recent years.
AIDC Chairman Tsai Chun-huei said one of the priorities in screening strategic investors is to ensure that after the privatization, the AIDC will continue to serve the military.
Tsai said that it is expected that AIDC will encounter slow business in 2000 and 2001, and that those strategic investors that bring in business opportunities will be given priority consideration.

Economics officials expressed the hope that foreign and domestic strategic investors could buy AIDC shares to help introduce business and technology to help tap international markets, adding that the AIDC is the hub of talents and technology in aviation.
Foreign strategic investors, such as Boeing of the United States, Rolls Royce of Britain and STE from Singapore, have made contact with AIDC.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTED DENGUE FEVER CASES REACH 48

TEXT.P: Three more imported cases of dengue fever -- one each contracted in the Philippines, Thailand and Cambodia -- were reported recently, according to statistics from the Department of Health (DOH) released Tuesday.
The number of people in Taiwan who have contracted the disease overseas has increased to 48 compared with only 20 imported cases during the same period last year.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, urged people traveling to Southeast Asia areas such as Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia, Vietnam, Malaysia, Burma, Cambodia and Laos to beware of dengue fever, the infectious disease carried by mosquitoes in tropical climates.
Doctors observing patients with unidentified fever, rashes or muscle and bone pain should report their findings to local health authorities immediately, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES LOWER, FUTURES HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 5.9 points to close at 7,593.14.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7,573.03 and peaked at 7,639.42.

A total of 16.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$85.12 billion, an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 15.13 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$79.25 billion.
Two of the eight major categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up 1.2 percent and pulp and paper issues 0.2 percent.

Other major categories lost ground, with foodstuff shares moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.2 percent, construction stocks at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.7 percent and cement issues at 0.6 percent.
Meanwhile, Taiwan stock index futures were generally higher Tuesday.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved up eight points to close at 7,560, while those for October rose 20 points to close at 7,550. December futures, however, slid 10 points to 7,745.
The number of contract transactions for the three futures were 302, one and three, respectively.
TAIEX Index Futures for March dropped 17 points to close at 7,835 with two contract transactions. There were no transactions for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX) reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,552 points for September; 7,530 for October; 7,755 for December; 7,852 for March; and 7,921 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT BABY TRADING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration announced on Tuesday it has busted a criminal ring trading infants across the Taiwan Strait.
CIB officers said they already arrested a key suspect involved in the illegal trade on Monday.

The suspect was identified as Hung Chih-hui, 45, who worked as an instructor at a private driving training center in Taipei. Hung was suspected to have been a go-between in the cross-strait baby smuggling operation.
The CIB was tipped off earlier this year that Wutien Gynecology-Obstetrics Clinic on Neichiang Street in western Taipei had been involved in cross-strait infant trade.
It also uncovered in early July that the clinic had issued a false birth certificate for an infant boy born out of wedlock by a Taiwan businessperson in mainland China.

Police then arrested Wutien's chief doctor, Tien Ching-chun, 83, for questioning. Tien denied he had ever engaged in cross-strait infant trading. He fled to mainland China shortly after being released on bail.

Police confiscated birth data and documents concerning more than 100 infants "born" at the clinic between 1995 and 1998 for study. Through DNA tests on the infants and their parents, police found that 30 of the 100-plus babies examined do not have biological ties with their current "parents."
The "parents" of 11 suspected problem babies have admitted that they are not the birth parents. They said Wutien clinic had told then that the babies were born by local unmarried women.
But CIB sources said most of the babies available at the clinic were either stolen, swindled or bought from the mainland.

The sources said mainland human smuggling rings sold those babies to their Taiwan counterparts for 10,000 renminbi (US$1,208) each. The mainland criminal elements usually placed babies in cupboard cases smuggled into Taiwan by fishing boats. The mainland criminals laced sleeping pills in milk to make babies sleep to facilitate shipment.

According to the sources, Taiwan human smugglers would then send the mainland babies to Wutien clinic for sale. The clinic allegedly issued false birth certificates for those babies and sold them to infertile couples or women who sought children. Each mainland baby was sold for NT$300,000 (US$8,721), the sources said, adding that Hung Chih-hui acted as a go-between in the trade.
Police said they had monitored Hung's activities for some time before arresting him on Monday. "We did find that Hung maintained unusually close ties with Wutien clinic," said a CIB officer.

Police also detained a 78-year-old woman doctor, Liu-Han Hsia-chen, for questioning on Monday. Liu-Han admitted that she had falsified 12 birth certificates, but she denied any knowledge of the origins of those babies. She was released on bail late Monday evening.
CIB officers said they will further investigate the case in order to bring to justice other possible accomplices.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PRIVATE INVESTMENT MAY GROW 16 PERCENT THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang predicted on Tuesday that private investment in Taiwan this year may grow 16 percent from last year's level.
He offered the estimate after hearing a report at the fifth session of a meeting by the Committee for Investment Promotion under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

According to MOEA statistics, in the first seven months of this year, there were 141 newly added major investment projects, each worth more than NT$200 million. The combined value of those projects is NT$268 billion.

In addition, it was estimated that 251 investment projects -- worth a total of NT$454.7 billion -- will be completed by the end of this year. The above figures have shown that domestic private investment for this year still performing quite good, the MOEA said.
Moreover, as of the end of June, 53 applications have been submitted for the establishment and development of industrial and commercial complexes.

Of that number, 34 applications have been approved by the MOEA. Those projects will entail the development of more than 300 hectares and the creation of nearly 75,000 jobs, while the combined value of those projects is NT$181 billion.

The MOEA noted that of the 34 projects it has approved, 22 have underwent environmental impact assessment screening. Of those, ground has already been broken on four projects, two others will break ground by September and eight others have obtained development licenses.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NOT OPPOSED TO `TRACK TWO' DIALOGUE CHANNELS: FM

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday that the Republic of China has never rejected a proposal to forge "Track Two" informal Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue channels.
Hu made the remarks while fielding questions at a meeting of the Control Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee.

He said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) believes that the so-called "Track Two" informal dialogue channels with the United States can provide a forum to help American media and academics better understand the ROC's policy toward mainland China and the current state of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"As long as the `Track Two' informal dialogue channels do not affect the operations of the `Track One' formal dialogue channels, we welcome any form of dialogue or consultations with both Washington and Beijing," Hu explained.
The "Track Two" proposal was initiated by former US Defense Secretary William Perry during trips he made to mainland China and Taiwan earlier this year.
Perry said Taipei and Beijing should forge "Track Two" informal dialogue channels with the United States to reduce tension and avoid military confrontation in the Taiwan Strait.
Hu told Control Yuan members that there are already several channels for informal Taipei-Washington dialogue.

"Several US think tanks have invited scholars and experts from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to conduct closed-door bilateral or three-way discussions on cross-strait or Asia-Pacific regional issues," Hu said, adding that American officials and diplomats from both sides of the Taiwan Strait stationed in the United States also attended some of those seminars.
The foreign minister went on to say that Taiwan has never rejected the participation of mainland representatives in those seminars.

He further said that several Taiwan think tanks will join forces with their American counterparts to sponsor large-scale symposia in the United States in the near future to discuss US relations with Taipei and Beijing, as well as cross-strait ties and other matters of mutual concern.

Hu said that although the "Track Two" informal dialogue channels cannot replace formal dialogue channels, they can help opinion leaders and shapers from Taipei, Beijing and Washington to forge consensus and minimize misunderstandings.
Such informal dialogue is also expected to influence policy formation and opinions of the three sides in the long run, he noted.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Hu said, Taipei and Washington have maintained close contact. "The officially sanctioned or authorized dialogue channels between us have operated smoothly," he added.
As for cross-strait ties, Hu said Taiwan hopes that informal Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue can help make mainland authorities understand that both Taipei and Beijing belong to a "divided China".

"We hope Beijing will understand that before China is unified, the ROC must take part in international activities to ensure survival and development for the 21.8 million Taiwan people. Beijing should stop its attempt to isolate and suppress Taiwan in the world community," Hu said.

The minister added that the ROC also hopes that regular dialogue between the two officially authorized intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- can be resumed as soon as possible.

Beijing unilaterally suspended institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue in mid-1995 to vent its anger at ROC President Lee Teng-hui's landmark visit to the United States in June 1995. Beijing regarded Lee's visit as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Responding to a proposal by a Control Yuan member that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait join forces to help ethnic Chinese women raped or abused by Indonesian rioters during May's political turmoil in that country, Hu said the overture requires further study by all relevant government agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLING, A SERIOUS PROBLEM IN MAINLAND CHINA: PEOPLE'S DAILY

TEXT.P: The impact of smuggling in mainland China has reached an unprecedented scope, size and depth, affecting the mainland's reform and modernization efforts, said the People's Daily on Tuesday.

An article in the Communist Party mouthpiece reported that smuggling by sea has become particularly rampant recently, as watches, cigarettes and home appliances that constituted most contraband have given to raw materials, such as oil and materials used in the chemical engineering industry.
Of the total amount of known smuggling in the mainland last year, 65 percent, or 5,575 million renminbi worth of goods, was detected by mainland China's customs house.
Making matters worse is the involvement of mainland corporations in illegal smuggling, according to the story.
The smuggling has cost the government billions of renminbi in revenue, which has affected the mainland's economy.

The illegal activity has undermined attempts to create open markets, stifled fair competition, hurt the interests of legitimate enterprises and negatively affected mainland markets and industries, as well as state-run enterprises.
The smuggling activities have poisoned the common practices of the society and undermined the authority of the government, stressed the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND SAYS IT WON'T DEVELOP NUCLEAR WEAPONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) reiterated Tuesday that it is Taiwan's firm policy not to do research on, develop, or produce chemical, biological, or nuclear weapons.

An MND spokesman made the statement when asked by the press to comment on an article in Tuesday's Asian Wall Street Journal by Gerald Segal, director of studies at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London.

The article, titled "Taiwan's Nuclear Card," said that, "In order to forestall American efforts to push them into the arms of mainland China, representatives of the Taipei government are embarking on a subtle campaign to remind the world that Taiwanese military retains the option of completing the development of a nuclear deterrent."

"They evidently hope that a nuclear card will force the US to reaffirm its commitment to protect Taiwan's security, in order to avoid seeing the stand-off across the Taiwan Strait go nuclear," it added.

Taiwan's armed forces only conduct defensive training against chemical, biological, and nuclear attacks, the spokesman said, adding that there is no point in speculating on Taiwan's capability to produce nuclear weapons. The MND has made similar statements before.

The spokesman said that it is the responsibility of any nation to defend its own national security, and that Taiwan has never asked the United States for protection. "We only hope that the US government will continue to sell us defensive weapons according to the Taiwan Relations Act," he said, refuting an assertion in the article that "a nuclear card will force the US to reaffirm its commitment to protect Taiwan's security."

In the article Segal quoted Australian analyst Andrew Mack as saying in 1996 that "There is little doubt that Taiwan's scientists and engineers have the technical ability to build nuclear weapons." However, Segal said Taiwan's nuclear weapons program remains hobbled by its lack of a capability to enrich fissile material to weapons grade.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGED NOT TO POLITICIZE COUNCILWOMAN'S DEATH

TEXT.P: A ranking mainland Chinese negotiator with Taiwan on Tuesday urged both sides to act calmly, rationally, and practically in the wake of the murder last week in mainland China of Lin Ti-chuan, a member of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Tang Shubei, vice chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), promised that the mainland authorities will arrest the criminals quickly, and allow Lin's family to bring her body back to Taiwan as soon as possible. He also called on the Taiwan side to cooperate in evidence gathering.
Expressing "deep regret and shock" over the tragedy, Tang said the ARATS has already dispatched Vice Secretary-General Liu Gangqi to help Lin's family handle the relevant affairs.
He said that the kidnap-murder was the result of a financial dispute and an isolated case, urging the DPP not to use the incident to affect bilateral relations.

Commenting on the long-expected second meeting between ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan and his Taiwan counterpart, Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Tang said Koo is still welcome to visit the mainland this fall.

However, he went on to say that if Taipei fails to respond clearly to Beijing's proposal that the two sides start procedural talks to pave the way for future political negotiations, there will be no fixed agenda for the talks, and Koo and Wang will be free to talk about whatever they choose.

Chang Rong-kung, director of the ruling Kuomintang's Department of Mainland Research, said in Beijing that Taiwan is not opposed to holding political negotiations with mainland China. But he claimed that Lin's murder has demonstrated yet again that talks on technical issues arising from bilateral exchanges are far more important to people's interests.

Chang, the first ranking KMT official to visit mainland China since 1949, is currently in Beijing to attend a seminar on cross-strait relations. He made the remarks following a private meeting to discuss general cross-strait affairs with Tang.

The ARATS' refusal to allow SEF officials to accompany Lin's family to the mainland has provoked strong discontent within the DPP, Chang said, adding that this may affect the future development of bilateral ties and will not benefit mainland China.
Speaking of the planned Koo-Wang meeting, Chang said it would be better if their deputies can meet first to make prior arrangements regarding the talks.

Chang also quoted Tang as saying that the SEF and the ARATS are irreplaceable in cross-strait negotiations. The two semi-official organizations are authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to engage in bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contacts.
Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in 1993, breaking an impasse of almost half a century between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

However, regular SEF-ARATS discussions were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in 1995 after President Lee Teng-hui paid a visit to the United States earlier that year, a move seen by Beijing as a covert attempt to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY COUNCIL MISSION LEAVES FOR LITHUANIA

TEXT.P: A Taipei City Council mission, led by Council Speaker Chen Chien-chih, left Taipei for the Republic of Lithuania in Eastern Europe on Tuesday.

Members of the mission included Taipei City councilors Lin Chin-chang, Yang Chen-hsiung, and Chin Li-fang, Taipei City Government Deputy Secretary-General Sheau-lin Shann, Taipei City Council Secretary-General Lin Chia-chi and Public Relations Director Lin Wen-pin.
They are scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 21.
Taipei City and the Lithuanian capital of Vilnius established sister city relations in May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COUNCILWOMAN'S BODY TO RETURN ON SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The body of murdered Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan is scheduled to be brought back to Kaohsiung from mainland China on Saturday, staff at her Kaohsiung office said on Tuesday.

Lin's coffin, along with the members of her family who flew to the city of Haicheng, Liaoning Province to claim her body, will arrive at the airport in the southern port city of Kaohsiung at 3:00 p.m. on Saturday.
After a brief religious ceremony at the airport, Lin's coffin is expected to be paraded through downtown Kaohsiung to her office before being taken to the city morgue.

Her funeral will take place in a marquee near the city stadium, but the date has yet to be decided, said her staff, adding that the Kaohsiung City branch office of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, of which Lin was a member, will set up a five-member committee to organize the funeral.
The branch office flew the party flag at half-staff on Tuesday to mark the seventh day of Lin's death, which is usually observed with Buddhist rites by the surviving family.

Lin was kidnapped in the city of Dalian on July 26 while on a private visit and was found dead on July 29 from an overdose of what is believed to have been heroin injected as a sedative by her abductors.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S CRIME RATE UP DURING FIRST HALF OF THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The overall crime rate in Singapore rose 4.7 percent in the first six months of this year over the same period last year, the Singapore Police Department said Monday.
There were 23,884 reported crimes in the first half of this year, 1,073 more than in the same period last year.
Releasing the statistics Monday, the Singapore police said there is no cause for alarm.
Police Commissioner Khoo Boon Hui said Monday that the expected crime rate for 1998 would be similar to that of 1996.
"Even so, our crime rate is likely to be among the lowest in the world," he said.
The number of murders rose year-on-year from 18 to 30, a 66.7 percent increase.
Petty theft and motor vehicle theft, were up 55.5 percent and 42.3 percent, respectively, while the number of rapes increased 28.9 percent.

Many of the arrests involved serial offenders, like the 43-year-old Malaysian who was caught breaking into 50 premises. Short-term visitors who come planning specifically to commit a crime are a source of concern, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN ERROR MAY BE BEHIND WARSHIP FIRE

TEXT.P: The fire that claimed the lives of seven seamen aboard a naval ship on Monday might have been caused by human error, a senior naval officer said on Tuesday.

"Initial investigations show that failure to properly close the root valve of a boiler on destroyer No. DDG926, also known as the Suei Yang, might have been the cause of the tragic incident," said Naval Fleet Commander Lai Kuang-shu.
"The failure was not a big mistake, but the fire raged too fast," an emotional Lai said, adding that he himself should be held responsible for the incident.

"Inexperience and inadequate training on the part of crew members was the main reason for the tragedy, but I don't blame any crewman. I myself should be blamed for this misfortune," a tearful Lai said.

He expressed his heartfelt condolences and apologies to the families of the victims, adding that the Ministry of National Defense has formed a special task force to investigate the accident, and has also assigned personnel to provide counseling and assistance for the families of the dead.
Six of the deceased were seamen second class, while the seventh was a petty officer third class. They will all be buried in a military cemetery, Lai said.
He further said military medical personnel will do their utmost to help rehabilitate five additional injured sailors.
The accident occurred at around 2:00 p.m. on Monday when the vessel was on a routine training mission off the coast of southern Taiwan near the Tsoying naval base.
The Suei Yang is one of Taiwan's Yang-class destroyers, which the navy purchased from the United States more than four decades ago.

Although most the Yang-class warships are on the verge of retirement, the navy has still spent a lot of money to modernize the weapons systems aboard the aging vessels. The Suei Yang boasts one of the best weapons systems among the ships of its class.

Naval authorities said that with the exception of its boiler room, the Suei Yang did not sustain serious damage in Monday's fire. The ship will resume service in about two months after the necessary repairs and maintenance have been carried out.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO BLOCK TAIWAN'S ADMISSION TO WTO: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing has decided to block Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in order to cut off its economic connection with the rest of the world, according to a report in the Aug. 5 issue of the Open Magazine in Hong Kong.

The monthly magazine reported that in order to undermine Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy, Beijing has mapped out three new strategies against Taiwan, including a plan to damage Taiwan's bid to join the WTO. The strategies were made after US President Bill Clinton's recent visit to Beijing.

The report quoted informed sources as saying that, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin wanted to cut off Taiwan's economic connection with the outside world so as to further isolate Taiwan in the world community. Beijing will also put stronger pressure on the US government with a purpose to further isolate Taiwan, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON OTTO KILLS ONE IN EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: People residing in mountainous areas of Taiwan were warned on Tuesday to take precautions against landslides following the passage of typhoon Otto across the island.

The light typhoon made landfall in the easthern county of Taitung on Tuesday noon, bringing with it strong winds and heavy downpours. Weathermen warned the storm was increasing in force and moving northwest, although the eye of the typhoon left Taiwan at Taichung at around 6:00 p.m.

Meteorologists at the Central Weather Bureau said the island is still in the radius of the typhoon, adding that the bureau will not call off the land typhoon warning until midnight, when the storm is expected to be entirely away from the island.

As of Tuesday evening, Typhoon Otto had killed one person and injured another in Taitung County, and had caused nearly 20,000 households there to suffer blackouts, according to the Central Natural Disasters Prevention and Relief Center.

Shenmu Village in Nantou County was again beset by landslides triggered by heavy rains brought by the storm, closing roads to the mountain village and trapping residents and a number of tourists, the center reported.
The small village was devastated by mudslides and flooding in August 1996, when Typhoon Herb struck Taiwan.
The center warned that similar mudflows may occur in eastern mountainous areas in Hualien, Taitung and Ilan counties.

The center further said that air, train and maritime traffics were all suspended in Taitung County because of the typhoon, while flight services in Hualien and Pingtung, as well as to the offshore Green Island and Lanyu, were suspended.
Several roads have been washed out in Hualien and Taitung counties, the center reported.
Meanwhile, reports from the Central Weather Bureau indicated that in addition to the eastern area, heavy rain has also affected the south and west of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAKING 3-PRONGED DRIVE AGAINST TAIPEI: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 4 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Beijing has secretly drafted a new "three-pronged" strategy against Taipei, according to a report appearing in the latest issue of Open magazine, which hits newsstands on Aug. 5.

The report in the Hong Kong magazine, citing well-informed sources in Beijing, notes that Beijing's Political Bureau drafted the new strategy aimed at reunification with Taiwan in the wake of US President Bill Clinton's tour of mainland China.
The three prongs of the strategy include strategy toward the United States, strategy toward political parties in Taiwan, and strategy toward the people of Taiwan, the report says.
In it's strategy toward the United States, President Jiang Zemin will utilize his newly established relationship with Clinton to ask him to put further pressure on Taiwan, including:
-- Asking Clinton to influence American politicians to reduce their hostility toward Beijing;
-- Requesting Washington to bar US entry to activists who advocate Taiwan independence;
-- Using influence to stop Taiwan from entering international organizations, including the World Trade Organization;
-- Requesting the United States to further limit its arms sales to Taiwan; and
-- Asking the US to influence other nations to follow the US example by adopting the "three-noes" policy regarding Taiwan.
In it's strategy against Taiwan, the sources pointed out that the overthrowing of President Lee Teng-hui will become a priority task for Beijing in the future.
As for it's strategy toward the people of Taiwan, the sources said, Beijing has decided to adopt a two-pronged offensive, using the strategies "intimidate with force," and "beguile with money."

DOC.HEADLINE: BLOOMING TRADE SEEN AT TAIPEI COMPUTER SHOW

TEXT.P: Nearly 140,000 people have visited the 1998 Taipei Computer Application Exhibition which concluded on Tuesday, up 12 percent on the 1997 show's record, according to sponsors.

Heavy buying was prompted by Microsoft's promotion of its Chinese-version Windows 98 operating system, and by price reductions for Intel processors, said the sponsors, the Taipei Computer Association and the China External Trade Development Council.

A large number of businesses received more orders than expected, the sponsors said, adding that this is expected to lead to vigorous development of the local computer industry in the second half of this year.
Salesmen for Leo Systems Inc. said that they sold over 2,000 desktop computers and notebook PCs during the five-day show, a record far higher than expected.
Executives of Twinhead International Corp. also revealed that their company gained more than 700 orders and follow-up orders as a result of its participation in the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON OTTO CAUSES OVER US$370,000-WORTH OF AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Light typhoon Otto, which hit Taiwan on Tuesday, has caused about NT$l3 million (US$377,900)-worth of agricultural losses, according to preliminary official statistics.

The figures released by the Taiwan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Forestry indicate that the typhoon damaged 546 hectares of orchards in eastern Taitung County, where the typhoon first made landfall.
The strong winds and heavy rain brought by the storm have also resulted in one death and at least one serious injury.
As of Tuesday evening, the island was still within the radius of the storm, although the eye had moved out into the Taiwan Strait, heading for mainland China.
Nevertheless, weathermen warned residents to take precautions against further heavy downpours.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRIP TO MAINLAND CHINA BY ROC PRESIDENT MIGHT BE RAISED IN KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Cheng-fu said on Tuesday that he might explore the possibility of a trip to mainland China by ROC President Lee Teng-hui when he meets his mainland counterpart this fall.

Pointing out that an international event such as the annual summit of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum would be an ideal occasion for a preliminary get-acquainted meeting between Lee and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Koo said the possibility is slim because of Beijing's wariness of such an encounter.

Therefore, Koo told local reporters at a press conference, he would like to exchange views on a possible visit to mainland China by Lee when he meets with Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) . Lee offered to make such a trip in his inauguration speech.

Other issues of mutual concern will certainly be on the meeting agenda, including political topics and the possibility of formal talks, Koo said, apparently in an attempt to persuade Beijing to resume regular contacts between the SEF and the ARATS.
Koo said political issues could be included on the agenda of the second formal round of negotiations between him and Wang sometime in the future.
Taipei has previously said that political topics should not be discussed until negotiations on technical aspects of cross-strait relations have been carried out.

Koo and Wang held their historic first round of talks in Singapore in 1993, and were scheduled to have a second round in 1995. These talks were shelved indefinitely by Beijing after President Lee Teng-hui's trip to the United States in June 1995.

The chilly ties warmed up somewhat earlier this year when SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng visited Beijing, followed by a visit to Taipei on July 26 by ARATS Deputy Secretary-General Li Yafei.
The visit to mainland China by Koo is in the pipeline for this fall, although Beijing would rather describe Koo's rendezvous with Wang a meeting, rather than a round of talks.
A detailed itinerary for Koo's trip has not yet been worked out because of the political wangling over the nature and agenda of the meeting.
Koo said the recent killings of a Taiwan councilwoman and a Taiwan businessman in mainland China underline the importance of resuming regular contacts between the SEF and the ARATS.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN TRIED IN BEIJING RETURN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Lung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The families of four Taiwan businessmen tried in a Beijing court on charges of espionage decided to return to Taiwan Wednesday to await the verdict.

The families of the four men said that if the verdict were expected soon, they would remain in Beijing. But after learning that a verdict is not expected in the near future, they decided to return to Taiwan.
The trial has already been concluded.

The families of the men -- Kou Chien-ming, Chen Shao-yu, Han Yue-ting and Chou Chang-ming -- traveled to Beijing on Friday after being informed by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait that the trial would begin Monday.
The four Taiwan businessmen were arrested by mainland China's state national security forces in late March for allegedly spying for Taiwan's military.
The Republic of China's Ministry of National Defense has denied the charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR PROPER HANDLING OF LIN TI-CHUAN AFFAIR

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh Wednesday urged mainland China to properly and quickly resolve affairs related to the death of Lin Ti-chuan, a Kaohsiung City councilwoman murdered last week in mainland China.

Expressing regrets that officials with the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation were refused entry into mainland China to help Lin's family, Chang stressed that the mainland must adequately and carefully handle the case by fully respecting the will of Lin's family and the feelings of the Taiwan people.

Cross-strait exchanges should be conducted in an orderly way, and issues of major concern to the interest of people on both sides should be placed high on the agenda of bilateral negotiations, Chang said.

The MAC head made the remarks while meeting with a five-member task force from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), of which Lin was a member. The group was set up to protest mainland China's handling of Lin's aftermath.

Task force members exchanged views with Chang on issues related to Taiwan business interests in the mainland, such as the signing of agreements on investment guarantees, trade and judicial arbitration.
Lin was abducted at knife-point on July 27 by a group of men during a private visit to the northeastern province of Liaoning.

Lin was pronounced dead two days later at a local hospital in Haicheng after her body was found there by local police, who were acting on information given by Lin's boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang. He managed to escape the kidnappers and reported the case to police.
