DOC.HEADLINE: SIA, CAL FORGE MOU FOR CLOSER TIES

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and China Airlines (CAL) on Tuesday forged a memorandum of understanding (MOU) establishing a strategic business alliance to further consolidate cooperation between the airlines.

The MOU was first signed by CAL Chairman Chiang Hung-I in Taipei Tuesday morning and was then flown aboard a CAL airplane to Singapore, where SIA Deputy Chairman and CEO Cheong Choong Kong inked it later in the day.

Under the MOU, CIA will initially buy 5 percent to 10 percent of CAL's shares, initiating a company stock exchange between the two companies. Buying 10 percent of CAL's shares would cost SIA an estimated US$117 million, said CAL spokesman Steve Yang.

Also stipulated in the draft agreement are joint aircraft purchases and a code-sharing program, under which CAL will be allowed to sell SIA seats on Europe-bound flights while SIA will be able to sell CAL seats on US-bound flights.
SIA will also provide CAL with aviation safety and flight management training, while CAL will provide catering, ground maintenance and cargo services.
A formal agreement on the MOU is expected to be signed in six months, said Yang.

The knotting of cooperative ties between SIA and CAL is seen an eyebrow raiser in the international airline industry at a time when most regional airlines are suffering from unprecedented sluggishness as Asian economies remain in the doldrums.

SIA, often named as one of the world's best airlines, posted a pre-tax profit of S$1.17 billion in the last fiscal year, up 8.9 percent over its year-earlier level. CAL, which is known for generating one of the highest profit levels of all Asian airlines, has no plans to lower its fiscal 1998 profit-target of US$79 million, despite its worst-ever airline crash last February.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS WELCOME TO KOO'S PLANNED VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Long and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China's top Taiwan affairs official reaffirmed on Wednesday that Taiwan's chief negotiator with Beijing is welcome to visit the mainland this fall.

Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, made the statement while meeting with Chang Jung-kung, director of the Mainland Research Department of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.
"We welcome the planned visit to the mainland in autumn by C. F. Koo, chairman of Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF)," Chen said.

Chen, who concurrently serves as director of the Office for Taiwan Affairs under the Communist Party of China, further said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should conduct political talks as soon as possible.

"If Taiwan has difficulties opening cross-strait negotiations on political issues at the moment, the two sides should at least hold talks on procedural issues, including possible meeting date and venue, to pave the way for political talks," Chen said.
Meanwhile, Chen said he hopes last week's kidnapping and murder in northeastern mainland China of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan will not affect cross-strait relations.
Chen said relevant mainland authorities are doing their utmost to handle related affairs, including pursuing all those involved in the crime.

For his part, Chang said Taiwan hopes the top day-to-day affairs managers of the two intermediary bodies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can meet first to set the agenda for a planned meeting between Koo and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), during Koo's mainland trip.
"By so doing, the long talked-about Koo-Wang meeting will be able to achieve more constructive results," Chang said.

Chang further said mainland China, while pushing for cross-strait political talks, should not ignore the many practical issues that are closely related to the rights and interests of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and that require concerted efforts by both sides to address immediately.
"We hope SEF and ARATS can resume regular dialogue and consultations on practical issues in the near future for the well-being of people on both sides of the strait," Chang said.

Beijing unilaterally suspended institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995. Beijing viewed Lee's visit as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

Chang went on to say that the KMT's mainland policy focuses on pursuing peaceful and constructive cross-strait interaction. As for China's unification, Chang said, the goal hinges on the democratization of all of China.

"The pace of unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait depends on progress in mainland China's democratization," Chang stressed, adding the KMT is pleased to see that mainland China has held self-government elections at grass-roots levels.
Chang is currently is Beijing to attend a seminar on cross-strait affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA GREEN LIGHTS CETRA'S PLANS TO BRANCH INTO THE MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang on Wednesday gave his approval to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) branching out into mainland China.

CETRA, a non-profit organization supervised by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), has long been a major trade-promotion arm of Taiwan, one that plays an important role in the island's foreign trade.

Wang's approval marks the MOEA's second major gesture of goodwill toward mainland China since June of this year, when the ministry agreed to allow 29 Taiwan businesses and industries to establish liaison offices or offshoot operations in the mainland. Those receiving permission are involved in such businesses and industries as stocks, bonds and securities; construction; real estate; travel and tourism; and import and export trade.

Whether CETRA will be allowed to set up affiliates in the mainland still hinges on the Mainland Affairs Council -- Taiwan's top agency in charge of charting the island's policy toward the mainland -- said Chintan Huang, deputy executive secretary of the MOEA's Investment Commission. Although the MOEA has considered CETRA's bid from an economic perspective, MAC will consider it from a political one.

Taiwan businessmen, who reportedly have invested at least US$2.3 billion in mainland China over the past decade, have long yearned for more direct and efficient government-initiated services, as those offered by the Straits Exchange Foundation are often limited and indirect, according to CETRA Chairman Lin Chen-kuo, who visited mainland China and met with Taiwan investors a couple of months ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved down NT$0.001 against greenback in Taipei, closing at 34.428.
The local currency opened at day's high of 34.356, and had a low of 34.449.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$249 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES EXCHANGE LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 93.41 points to close at 7,499.73.
The bourse opened at 7,524.83 and closed at 7,499.73. Dealers said the market was affected by a heavy drop of the industrial index on the New York Stock Exchange.
A total of 17.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.09 billion.

All eight major categories lost ground, with bank and insurance stock moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 2.1 percent, cement stocks at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.5 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent, construction shares at 1 percent, electrical stocks at 0.3 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, Taipei's stock index futures were also generally lower on Wednesday.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down 73 points to close at 7,487, while those for December slid 24 points to close at 7,721. March futures decreased 55 points to 7,780.
The number of contract transactions for the three futures were 455, 13, and 15, respectively.
There were no transactions for TAIEX Index Futures for either October or June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX) reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 7,560 points for September; 7,538 for October; 7,745 for December; 7,835 for March; and 7,929 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC POLITICAL PARTIES ADJUST TO NEW REALITIES (I)

TEXT.P: United States President Bill Clinton's reiteration of the "three noes" policy on Taiwan is forcing the Republic of China's major political parties to readjust their approaches towards mainland China.

In a commentary published on Wednesday, The Straits Times newspaper of Singapore said the ruling Kuomintang, for one, has found that it will have to accept political negotiation earlier than it would have liked to, it said.

Before the two summit meetings between Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, the KMT's strategy was to engage mainland China in talks on functional issues while avoiding political matters.
The rationale for this was that success in settling practical problems would pave the way for handling the more difficult political issues.
Beijing, however, preferred to settle "matters of principle" first, its position being that as long as both sides agreed to the "one China" principle, all practical issues could be solved easily.

The KMT was forced to concede on this. In a National Unification Council meeting held to take stock of the Beijing summit, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh warned that Taiwan should be "psychologically prepared for political negotiation."

President Lee Teng-hui agreed to "hold consultations based on the reality of a divided China and sign a cross-strait peace agreement, thereby ending the state of hostility and promoting harmony in cross-strait relations."
This proposal to sign a peace agreement is similar to one made by Jiang in his program for cross-strait ties announced in 1995.
However, there is one significant difference.
Jiang proposed that the peace treaty be signed under the "one China" principle, while Lee's counter-proposal was that it be signed "based on the reality of a divided China."

The rhetoric of "one China" versus "one divided China" reflects the diametrically opposing positions taken by mainland China and Taiwan, the commentary noted. Yet, both sides agree that it could be the starting point for political negotiations.
The largest opposition party, the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is also feeling the pressure to speed up dialogue with the Chinese Communist Party, the commentary said.
The DPP's policy had been one of "strengthening our own base while moving westward," but after Clinton's mainland visit, the party was forced to review its priorities.

DPP Secretary-General Chiou I-jen paid a four-day visit to the mainland city of Xiamen on July 24. To quell internal opposition, he did not go in his official capacity, and purposely avoided political centers such as Beijing and Shanghai.
Chiou, who used to dub any Taiwan politician visiting the mainland a "traitor," returned from the trip in quite an upbeat mood.

He defended his trip, describing it as a brave move. He insisted that, as the international environment is worsening for Taiwan, it would be fatal if the island continued to reject exchanges with the mainland.
Former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang recently advocated the concept of "one system, one country" as a means to break the present impasse, the commentary said.

According to this concept, Taiwan will wait until mainland China undertakes political reforms to close the gap between the two sides. Only then will they have more common ground to hold discussions on "one country."
This represented a major departure from the party's pro-independence program, the commentary noted.
Hsu also expressed his wish to visit Beijing if he could secure a meeting with Premier Zhu Rongji.
Given his stature in the opposition movement, the DPP heavyweight's change of mind came as a surprise to many, the commentary said. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC POLITICAL PARTIES ADJUST TO NEW REALITIES (II)

TEXT.P: The New Party, Taiwan's third-largest party, used to advocate "one China" on Taiwan's terms, the commentary continued.
It has since changed its tack, and now calls for "peaceful negotiation to protect Taiwan and reject independence."
Its spokesman for mainland affairs announced that the party plans to set up a Beijing office to facilitate this change.
It is clear from the above that all three major parties have been adjusting their cross-strait policies carefully to take into account the new reality, the commentary said.
Worst affected were the country's pro-independence advocates, because the "three noes" policy obliterates their political space entirely, it commented.
A strong sense of being cornered has forced them to adopt a more drastic and militant approach, the commentary noted.

The Taiwan Independence Party, for example, has advocated holding an immediate referendum on independence. While it is a tiny party, its reaction has underlined another fact: intensified international pressure could prove counterproductive, it commented.
Past opinion polls have shown that there is a strong correlation between external pressure and support for Taiwan independence.
The latest opinion poll conducted to gauge public reaction to the Sino-US summit again confirmed this correlation, according to the newspaper.
It showed, for the first time, that support for "eventual independence" (44 percent) exceeds support for "eventual unification" (34 percent) by a significant margin.
This finding is something the political parties cannot afford to ignore, the commentary concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE COMMUNIST MILITARY FORGET THE LONG MARCH: PAPER

TEXT.P: Since Beijing adopted its openness and reform policies two decades ago, the Chinese communist military has forgotten the traditional spirit of the revolutionaries who made history as soldiers in Mao Zedong's Long March.
Instead, they have devoted themselves to making money, setting up a multi-billion dollar commercial empire, a New Delhi-based English-language daily said in an editorial on Tuesday.

Now, an order from mainland China's President Jiang Zemin for the military to relinquish this empire, as part of his moves to root out corruption in the army, could be a stunning revelation of what is happening to the descendants of the revolutionaries, The Hindu said on Tuesday.

"If the Chinese army is now running multi-billion dollar commercial enterprises including five-star hotels, it is perhaps because old visions fade, yielding to the new reality, part of which is the creeping in of smuggling, corruption and the rest of the capitalist ills which the Maoists were committed to ending," the paper said.

"With the objectives spelt out by the establishment failing to inspire the army and thanks to the glitter of the gains from corruption, the Chinese army has obviously become morally very vulnerable, much to the dismay of Jiang Zemin," the paper said.

The newspaper said that if the old revolutionaries, still clinging to and cherishing their ideology, see what is going on with detachment, they will perhaps realize that mainland China cannot remain an island in a world where expediency influences behavior and dictates policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY MUST INTENSIFY TRAINING: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday expressed his concern about a fire on a naval warship earlier this week that killed seven crew members and injured five others.

At a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee in his capacity as KMT chairman, Lee said that the mishap underscores the need for the military to intensify manpower training.
The president said he called a meeting of top military brass on Tuesday to discuss the cause of the tragic incident.
"An analysis of the initial investigation shows that the deadly incident was related more to a manpower shortage and inadequate training than to the age of the warship," Lee said.
Quoting military sources, Lee said Monday's fire on the Yang-class Sueiyang destroyer was caused by mishandling of a boiler in the warship's rear boiler room.

"The incident indicates that the military should reinforce troop training and recruit more non-commissioned officers with specialized skills to avoid the recurrence of a similar misfortune," Lee said.

Speaking on the same occasion, Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yi said the government should set aside a larger budget for renovation of weapons systems and other military equipment, in addition to strengthening manpower training and combat preparedness.

Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said the government should pay more attention to the gap between policy making and execution, referring to problems involving newly acquired warplanes, such as F-16 and Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters being damaged by pigeons.
Meanwhile, the Navy Fleet Command announced on Wednesday that a public funeral for the seven deceased Sueiyang crewmen will be held at the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan on Sunday.

A fleet command spokesman said all seven dead seamen will be given posthumous citations and promotions. "Flags on all warships berthed at the Tsoying naval base will be flown at half-mast on the day of the funeral to show respect for the dead," the spokesman said.

He also said the military has formed a special task force to investigate into the exact cause of the accident. "The navy will also conduct an across-the-board examination of engineering equipment on all Yang-class destroyers now in service," the spokesman added.

Noting that naval authorities will offer psychological counseling to all personnel serving aboard the more than 10 Yang-class warships in service in the ROC navy, the spokesman said the fleet command hopes all naval units will learn a lesson from the incident. "We hope all units will strengthen security education and tighten discipline to avoid the recurrence of a similar tragedy."

The deadly incident happened at 2:05 p.m. on Monday in the rear boiler room of the destroyer as the ship was carrying out a routine training mission some 18 nautical miles off the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan.

The Sueiyang is one of the Yang-class destroyers bought from the United States more than four decades ago. Although most of the ships are on the verge of retirement, the navy has spent a lot of money modernizing the weapons systems aboard the aging vessels. The Sueiyang boasts one of the best weapons systems among the vessels of its class.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COUNTS THE COST OF TYPHOON OTTO

TEXT.P: Typhoon Otto left Taiwan in the early hours of Wednesday, roaring westward into mainland China's Fujian Province, the Central Weather Bureau reported.

Bureau meteorologists called off land and sea typhoon warnings on Wednesday, but said that accumulated rain brought by the typhoon to central and southern mountainous areas has amounted to some 400 millimeters. They warned that any further downpours could trigger flooding or mudslides in the worst-affected areas.
Warm and cloudy summer weather has returned to the island in Otto's wake, the weathermen said, forecasting that showers might occur over the next few days.
The typhoon, which made landfall in the eastern county of Taitung on Tuesday, has been blamed for four deaths, five injuries and one disappearance.

A resident of southern Chiayi County was killed by falling stones while driving on Tuesday. His wife and a child, who were also in the car, were both injured, according to the Disaster Prevention and Relief Center under the Ministry of Interior (MOI).

In central Nantou County, a head-on collision at the height of the storm claimed three lives and seriously injured another, while a Taitung resident and a Tainan resident were reported hurt by falling objects.
The center also said that an angler swept into the sea in Hualien County was missing and believed dead. Rescue teams were still searching for him.
The center reported that a number of roads in Chiayi and Nantou counties have been damaged by landslips resulting from heavy rain, trapping residents of some mountainous areas.
As of Wednesday noon, about 230 residents of Nantou County's Shenmu Village were still cut off, with their only traffic link yet to be repaired, according to the center.
The small village was devastated by landslides and flooding in August 1996, when Typhoon Herb struck Taiwan.

Four domestic airports in Taitung, Hualien, Green Island and Orchid Island were closed for the duration of the typhoon, with all flight services suspended. Rail links were also affected, but services began returning to normal on Wednesday.
More than 87,000 households suffered blackouts, with Taitung and Hualien counties the most seriously affected, official statistics show.
Several roads in Hualien, Taitung, Kaohsiung and Pintung counties were washed out, according to the statistics.
Meanwhile, agricultural losses islandwide have been estimated at NT$250 million (US$7.29 million), according to the Taiwan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Forestry.
Hualien County has been worst-hit, with losses of NT$186 million (US$5.42 million), department tallies show.
The damage has already led to 20 percent to 30 percent hikes in vegetable prices, the department reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REFUTES ARATS CHARGES AGAINST SEF

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Wednesday refuted accusations by mainland China that Taiwan is seeking to use the recent murder of a Kaohsiung City councilor in mainland China to disrupt cross-strait relations.

Describing mainland China's charges as totally back-to-front, Chang said it was the obligation of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to help Lin Ti-chuan's family handle the affairs relating to her death.

Taiwan should therefore not be blamed for "making trouble" over the incident, especially when the mainland Chinese itself was to blame by repeatedly refusing entry to the SEF personnel assigned to help Lin's family, he said.

Lin, 32, was kidnapped and murdered last week by a group of armed men during a private visit to northeastern Liaoning Province. Lin's family had asked the SEF to help them handle the situation, but SEF officials were repeatedly refused entry by mainland officials.

The Beijing-based Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) sent a letter on Tuesday night to the Taipei-based SEF, accusing it of trying to use Lin's death to "exacerbate differences," and "derail the positive feelings among compatriots" on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

In addition, the ARATS also asked the SEF to cherish the progress in bilateral ties resulting from recent cross-strait exchanges, especially at a time when the two sides are preparing a visit to the mainland by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator in cross-strait affairs.
The ARATS response, Chang said, is a reflection that the two sides have very different understandings of Lin's case.

The SEF, as a semi-official organization set up to serve the Taiwan people in cross-strait dealings, has a responsibility to help those who request its help, Chang explained. This is normal practice, as the mainland would understand if it had a better understanding of a democratic society, he noted.

As to the question on whether the incident would affect the planned trip to mainland China by Koo this fall, a soft-tongued but firm Chang said he did not know the true purpose of the letter, but added: "I prefer to believe that mainland China has no ulterior motive."

Lin's tragic death, and the recent murder in mainland China of Taiwan businessman Wang Fu-ching, have underlined the importance of continued dialogue and communication on issues of major concern to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Chang said, urging the mainland not to create unnecessary barriers in this regard.

Responding to the ARATS letter, SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow called its charges "totally untrue." He called on the mainland Chinese side to act responsibly and not to make wild accusations on the issue.

In the past, the SEF has always sent officials to help Taiwan people who have lost family members in the mainland, citing the 1994 Qiandao Lake incident in Zhejiang Province in which 24 Taiwan tourists were slaughtered by mainland robbers.

The SEF and ARATS have never reached agreement on entrusting each other to handle such incidents, Shi went on, saying that this is because the ARATS "is apparently incapable of protecting the interests of the people from the other side" of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF DEAD SEAMEN ANGRY WITH `HUMAN ERROR' THEORY

TEXT.P: The families of seven sailors killed in Monday's fire aboard a naval destroyer protested on Wednesday the military's attribution of the cause of the mishap to human error.
The families expressed their dissatisfaction to Rear-Adm. Lei Kuang-shu, commander of the ROC Navy's 124th Fleet, during a meeting with Lei at the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan.

Lei told a news conference on Tuesday that initial investigations by military investigators show that human error might have been the cause of the deadly boiler fire that broke out on Monday afternoon on the Yang-class No. 926 Sueiyang destroyer, part of his fleet.
Responding to the protest, Lei said he was not blaming any of the deceased Sueiyang crew members, comprising six seamen second-class and a petty officer third-class.

"It is the ship's chief officers who should be blamed for their failure to strictly require all crewmen to follow operational rules and guidelines," Lei said, adding that he himself should also be held responsible for the tragic incident.
The families demanded that the military punish all the officers responsible for the accident.
Lei said the captain and chief engineer of the destroyer have been referred to military prosecutors as part of an investigation into their responsibility.
Lei also promised that a special military task force set up to probe the case will release an initial report on the cause of the fire before Sunday.
Navy Commander-in-Chief Adm. Wu Shih-wen and many other senior naval officers paid respect to the dead crewmen at a makeshift funeral hall at the Tsoying base Wednesday afternoon.
Meanwhile, the Navy Fleet Command announced on Wednesday that a public funeral for the seven deceased crewmen will be held at the Tsoying naval base on Sunday.

A fleet command spokesman said all seven dead seamen will be given posthumous citations and promotions. "Flags on all warships berthed at the Tsoying base will be flown at half-mast on the day of the funeral to show respect for the dead," the spokesman said.
He also said the navy will conduct an across-the-board examination of engineering equipment on all Yang-class destroyers now in service.

Noting that naval authorities will offer psychological counseling to all personnel serving aboard the more than 10 Yang-class warships in service in the ROC navy, the spokesman said the fleet command hopes all naval units will learn a lesson from the incident. "We hope all units will strengthen security education and tighten discipline to avoid the recurrence of a similar tragedy."

In related news, President Lee Teng-hui said at a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee in his capacity as KMT chairman that the military should intensify personnel training in the wake of the Sueiyang fire.
Lei said at Tuesday's news conference that the accident happened as a sailor was trying to replace an oil rod for the No. 4 boiler in the Sueiyang's rear boiler room.

"The sailor did not completely shut off the root valve, which controls the oil volume of the boiler, before he pulled out the oil rod. The mishandling caused oil to burst out of the boiler which then caught fire and soon spread to the whole boiler room," Lei said, adding that the seven sailors operating in the small boiler room were killed instantly because of lack of oxygen.

The Sueiyang is one of more than 10 Yang-class destroyers bought from the United States 47 years ago. Although most of the ships are on the verge of retirement, the navy has spent a lot of money modernizing the weaponry systems on the aging vessels.

Naval authorities said the Sueiyang did not sustain serious damage in Monday's fire. "The ship will resume service in about two months after the necessary repairs and maintenance have been carried out," said a naval officer.
The Sueiyang boasts one of the best weaponry systems among the ships of the same class.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER CAUTIOUS ON SUGGESTION ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul Chiu on Wednesday was cautious in his response to a suggestion that the ceiling for single investors in a listed company be lifted.
The suggestion that the 15 percent ceiling be lifted came from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

Current regulations stipulate that an individual foreign investor in a listed company should not own more than a 15 percent stake in a listed company, while total foreign investment should not exceed 30 percent of a listed company.
The CEPD suggested a lifting of the restriction on individual investors, while retaining the ceiling on total foreign investment until 2000.
Chiu declined to make a direct response to the suggestions, saying only that he has to respect the views of the Central Bank of China on the free flow of foreign capital.
According to the schedule, the Ministry of Finance will lift all restrictions on foreign investment in the local bourse by 2000, Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 WORKERS INJURED IN KAOHSIUNG GAS EXPLOSION

TEXT.P: Four workers were injured, two seriously, in a gas explosion at the construction site of what will be the tallest building in southern Taiwan, police said on Wednesday.
The four were testing a gas pipe in the first basement of the 85-story Tuntex skyscraper in Kaohsiung City when the explosion occurred at around 9 a.m.
Wang Chuan-ping, 23, and Shih Tsai-cheng, 35, suffered serious burns and inhaled toxic gases. Both are still in critical condition at a local hospital.
Lin Chien-hung, 24, and Chen Ching-yi, 30, suffered minor burns and remain under observation at the hospital.

A foreman at the construction site said that the testing had been going for about a week, and that the four workers took four steel gas cylinders to the basement on Wednesday morning to conduct tests on the gas pipes there.

An initial investigation by police showed that the explosion, which blew out two walls and scattered debris over a wide area, might have been caused by one of the gas cylinders, which should have contained nitrogen but had apparently been mistakenly filled with flammable gas.
Police said that the cylinder will be sent for further examination.
Construction of the Tuntex skyscraper is almost complete, and only interior installation and decorating work remains to be carried out. It is expected to be inaugurated early next year.
At least six accidents have occurred at the skyscraper since construction began, according to news reports.

The United Evening News reported that several construction workers have fallen to their deaths during the construction, while in 1996, a steel beam fell from 70-plus story and crashed through the roof of a neighboring house.
Fires have also broken out over the past two years, none of which were serious thanks to the concrete structure of the building.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAY SUSPEND IMPORTS OF INDONESIAN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan may suspend imports of Indonesian workers if Indonesia fails to harshly punish those who raped or abused ethnic Chinese women during the May rioting in that country, a senior official said on Wednesday.
Chan Hou-sheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA), made the statement while meeting with a group of parliamentarians from the opposition New Party.

The New Party parliamentarians, including Legislators Chu Hui-liang and Chen Yi-hsin and National Assembly Deputies Chi Hsin and Lee Hsin, said they lodged a protest to the Indonesian representative office in Taipei last week.

"However, the Indonesian office has so far failed to give any positive response to our calls for punishment of Indonesian rioters and compensation for abused Chinese women and girls," said NA Deputy Chi.
Against this background, Chi said, the New Party hopes the CLA will take some steps to force Indonesian authorities to actively respond to its demand.
Responding to the New Party's overture, Chan said the CLA will consider suspending introduction of Indonesians for working in the local manufacturing sector.
Chan said there are currently 15,961 Indonesian passport holders legally working in Taiwan, accounting for 6 percent of total legal foreign workers here.
Among them, 10,500 Indonesians work in the manufacturing sector; 263 in the fishing industry; 1,700 in the construction industry; and 3,400 work as domestic helpers.
According to Chan, most of those serving as domestic helpers here are Chinese-Indonesians.

Chan said if Indonesia fails to make proper response to Taiwan's calls for better protection of ethnic Chinese people's legitimate rights, punishment of Indonesians who committed atrocities against ethnic Chinese women during the May riots, the CLA may first ban local manufacturers from importing Indonesian workers for the time being.
"We may also consider cutting the import quota for Indonesian workers," Chan said.
Chan said the CLA has adopted a "measured" policy on imports of foreign workers in order to protect job opportunities for local people.
As mainland China has not renounced its attempt to use force against Taiwan, Chan said the CLA cannot lift the ban on imports of mainland workers at the moment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HOST APEC EARTHQUAKE WORKSHOP

TEXT.P: Taiwan is sponsoring an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum workshop on earthquake-related sciences later this month, sources from the National Science Council (NSC) reported on Wednesday.

The APEC Workshop on Seismic Design and Retrofit of Structures, the first of its kind in the Asia Pacific region, is scheduled to be held in Taipei from Aug. 10-12 under the auspices of the National Center for Research on Earthquake Engineering (NCREE), said center director Luo Chun-hsiung.
A total of 44 scholars and specialists from 14 APEC member countries and areas will take part in the workshop and deliver research papers, said Luo.

Luo said the NCREE will be proud to unveil its newly-founded laboratory, which is unequaled in Asia, during the workshop. The lab, which features a tri-axial seismic simulator, a reaction wall, and a strong-floor testing system, will help experts advance their research in the field.

The NCREE would like to share its expertise and know-how with other APEC economies to raise the regional standards of earthquake engineering research in order to help offset the damage incurred from massive earthquakes, Luo added.

It will be the second time Taiwan has hosted an APEC meeting this year. The Second APEC Technomart kicked off at the Taipei World Trade Center on Jan. 21 with the participation of 13 APEC member economies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HAILS SEF HANDLING OF LIN'S INCIDENT

TEXT.P: A legislator with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hailed Wednesday the Straits Exchange Foundation's (SEF) handling of the Lin Ti-chuan affair, saying mainland China was extremely rude in accusing the SEF of using the incident to block cross-strait ties.

A DPP heavyweight and organizer of a five-member task force set up by the party after a dispute erupted between mainland officials and Lin's family over the disposition of her body, Chang Chun-hung stressed that the SEF has done its best to address the issue.
Lin, 32, a DPP member and Kaohsiung City councilwoman, was kidnapped and murdered in the mainland last week.

Chang made the remarks at a news conference following a meeting with Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh. The meeting came one day after the Beijing-based Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) sent a letter to the SEF accusing it of trying to use the incident to disrupt bilateral relations.

The legislator said his meeting with Chang was aimed not only at discussing the Lin Ti-chuan affair but also at finding a way to break the current impasse between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He said the DPP hopes the MAC will review its policy toward mainland China and that Lin's case would serve as an example of the strained state of cross-strait dealings.

According to the legislator, he and the MAC chairman also exchanged opinions on a series of issues arising from cross-strait exchanges, such as the signing of agreements on investment guarantees, trade and judicial arbitration. Five points of consensus were reached during their meeting, which lasted nearly two hours.
Second, Taiwan will continue to promote agreements reached in the non-partisan National Development Conference held in Dec. 1996;
Third, Taiwan will set up risk indexes regarding travel and doing business in mainland China;
Fourth, Taiwan will make public all details of incidents involving with Taiwan people in the mainland;
Fifth, the SEF should refute rationally all the accusations made by the ARATS.

Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yih-jen said the party will not make noticeable changes in its mainland policy, because mainland China has shown some degree of goodwill in its handling of the dispute over Lin's body.
Since the United States is increasing its engagement with mainland China, Chiu said the DPP has already made necessary adjustments in its policy toward the mainland.
The leadership of the major opposition party supports across-the-board dealings and dialogue with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: FACTORY EXPLOSION CLAIMS LIVES OF TWO STUDENTS

TEXT.P: The Tuesday morning explosion at a plastics factory in Taoyuan county, Northern Taiwan, has claimed the lives of two students.

Chang Chih-fu, who suffered burns to 95 percent of his body, died several hours after he was rushed to nearby Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou. Chen Juei-hsin, who suffered burns to 98 percent of his body, died Wednesday morning.

Four others were injured when the explosion broke out at the Chen Feng Plastics Co. They suffered burns ranging from 4 percent to 27 percent of their bodies, but doctors described their conditions as stable.

Chang was a vocational high school student in Taoyuan, while Chen had been admitted into a college in a recent exam. One of the injured is a dropout, and the remaining three were working there under a cooperation program between the vocational school they are attending in Kaohsiung and the factory.

One factory official told police that the fire occurred at around 10 a.m. Tuesday on the building's second floor. Despite the fact that workers soon put out fire with fire extinguishers, the students who were taking a break there at that time were severely injured.

One of the injured said that the explosion was caused because some of the students defied the non-smoking ban in the factory. A student dropped a cigarette butt into a bucket of oil cleaner, which caused the explosion, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER PREDICTS SLOWDOWN IN TAIWAN'S GROWTH

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang predicted on Wednesday that Taiwan's economic growth will slow down this year, and that comparing with some other Asian countries which are heading toward recession, Taiwan's performance is still looking good.

Wang made the remarks while commenting on recent, drastic plunges in international stock markets. He pointed out that Taiwan's economic growth increased from 5.7 percent in 1996 to 6.8 percent in 1997, with outstanding performances in exports, investments and industrial production.
As for this year, the economics minister said, growth of at least 5.5 percent is expected.

Wall Street took its worst beating of the year Tuesday, as the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted 299.43 points, or 3.40 percent, to close at 8,487.30. The plunge was felt throughout Asia the next day. On Wednesday, Taiwan stocks fell 1.2 percent, or 93.41 points, to 7,499.73.

Wang said the Wall Street's affect on the Taiwan market was mainly psychological. He urged the public not to be influenced by overseas markets, since Taiwan's economic growth is merely slowing, not stopping.

Yeh Huey-ching, executive secretary of the Committee of Economic Research and Development under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the plunge in New York on Tuesday was perhaps just a "one-day market price."

Meanwhile, the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan said on Wednesday that the United States' economic grew at a slower rate during the second quarter. The council, however, ruled out the possibility of a recession this year in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN'S RIGHTS ACTIVISTS RETURN FROM INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A group of women's rights activists returned to Taipei on Wednesday after a four-day fact-finding trip to Indonesia aimed at helping ethnic Chinese women raped or abused by Indonesian rioters during the May rioting there.

Wang Ching-feng, a former Control Yuan member who headed the delegation, said the trip was fruitful even though the group failed to meet any Chinese victim or arrange for any of them to travel to Taiwan to receive medical treatment.

"The visit has enabled us to better understand the facts about the atrocities committed by Indonesian rioters against ethnic Chinese women and girls during May's political turmoil in that country," said the lawyer-turned-women's rights activist.

In addition to meeting with the Indonesian women's affairs minister and senior officials of Indonesia's National Human Rights Commission, Wang said, the delegation managed to meet with the leaders of a major Indonesian opposition party and several non-government rescue and relief organizations.

"Through talks with them, we have come to a better understanding of the ordeals endured by ethnic Chinese women and girls during the May riots," Wang said, adding that at least 150 ethnic Chinese women and girls were sexually assaulted during that chaotic period.

"More worrisome is that similar events are still occurring," Wang said, citing that the Jakarta office of Taiwan's largest charity, the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, handled a case involving an ethnic Chinese woman raped by Indonesians in July.

Wang quoted the leader of an Indonesian rescue organization as saying that some abused Chinese women have committed suicide or been reported missing. "Some victims even found that they became pregnant after being raped."

Wang said there is sufficient evidence proving that the atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese women were organized and planned actions. As a result, many Chinese-Indonesians are unwilling to return to Indonesia before the Indonesian government severely punishes all those who instigated, encouraged or committed the atrocities.

Wang said Indonesian and ethnic Chinese women's rights activists have suggested that local women's rights groups send volunteers to Indonesia to help abused victims forget their bitter ordeals and regain peace of mind.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO SPONSOR IDU MEETING IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The 1998 International Democratic Union (IDU) conference will be held in Taipei this November under the sponsorship of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang, party sources said Tuesday.
Leaders of political parties in the United States, Sweden, Russia, South Korea and other countries are expected to take part in the event.
Attaching great importance to the conference, KMT Secretary-General John Chang has asked party officials to do their best to make it a success.
IDU is an organization comprising conservative political parties worldwide. It currently has 29 member countries and about 40 observers. The KMT was admitted into the body in 1992.

DOC.HEADLINE: GHOST POPULATION IN TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG NOT CONSIDERED SERIOUS

TEXT.P: The so-called ghost population issue in Taipei and Kaohsiung is not serious enough to affect the results of year-end mayoral elections in those cities, the Ministry of Interior (MOI) said on Wednesday.

The mayoral elections and elections for city councilors will be held on Dec. 5. In addition, residents of the two cities, along with residents of other parts of Taiwan, will elect national lawmakers on the same day.
According to election laws, people are required to have lived in a city or an area continuously for at least four months before they can vote as a resident of that city or area.

That means if citizens outside Taipei and Kaohsiung want to vote as residents of either of those cities, they will have to actually move into the cities or at least change their registered residential addresses to those of people who are residents of those cities -- as the ghost population does -- on or before Aug. 4.

Chen Wy-hsiung, director of MOI's Population Administration Department, said that according to statistics, the population of Taipei increased by 21,000 people, or 0.81 percent, from Jan. 1 to Aug. 4, while the population of Kaohsiung increased by 15,811, or 1.09 percent.
Both increases can be described as normal, Chen said, though he added that in June and July the population increase in Taipei was extraordinarily high.

From June 1 to Aug. 4, Taipei recorded a population increase of 14,341, with 8,380 in June, 5,026 in July and 935 in August. As Kuomintang Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou announced his candidacy on May 30, the jump in Taipei's population might be a result of Ma's entering the mayoral race.

In Kaohsiung, the population increase during July and the first four day of August stood at 1,596, not particularly high. However, the population increased in February by 7,082, which might have some connection with grassroots-level elections in June.
Chen said that even if there is so-called ghost population in both cities, the number is not large enough to have any significant influence on election results.

He stressed that though the constitution guarantees people the right to move around freely, members of ghost population violate population administration laws. Once ghost population members are identified, they will be punished and lose their voting rights.

In related news, according to statistics compiled by the Bureau of Civil Affairs under the Taipei Government, the population in Taipei totaled 2,629,828 as of the end of Aug. 4 with the number of citizens standing at 1,876,424.
The statistics showed that between June 1 and July 31, Taipei saw its population increase by 16,064 with 10,689 of them being citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT APPROVES P. Y. TENG AS NEW ENVOY TO SOLOMON

TEXT.P: P. Y. Teng, formerly a representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Center in New Delhi, was appointed Wednesday as the ROC's Ambassador to the Solomon Islands, succeeding Thomas Tong-liang Hsieh.
The appointment was approved at a meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee Wednesday morning.

Teng, 55, has served as chief of Chung Hwa Travel Service in Hong Kong, deputy director general of the Bureau of Consular Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) and director of MOFA's East Asia and Pacific Affairs Department.
The Executive Yuan approved the resignation of Hsieh at a meeting last Thursday.
Hsieh, who was recalled to Taipei July 25, offered his resignation last Tuesday in the wake of allegations that he made improper remarks about his host government.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUANG KUN-HUEI TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to the president, will leave for Paraguay on Aug. 10 to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President Raul Cubas Grau on Aug. 15, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

Huang, who was designated by President Lee Teng-hui to lead Taiwan's delegation to the inauguration, will leave for the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion via Los Angeles and Miami. He is scheduled to arrive in Asuncion on Aug. 13.

During his five-day stay in the Southern American country, in addition to attending the inauguration ceremony, Huang will meet with staff members of the ROC Embassy, the ROC agricultural mission stationed there and members of Chinese communities.

Meanwhile, Huang will visit former President Juan Carlos Wasmosy and thank him for supporting the Republic of China in the international community in the past. He will also meet with President Cubas to exchange views of mutual concern.
The ROC delegation will include Jason Hu, minister of foreign affairs, and Ling Shiang-nung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, as well as a number of business executives.
Huang and the delegation are scheduled to depart Asuncion on Aug. 17 and arrive in Taipei on Aug. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE IN JAPAN CALLS FOR JAPANESE SUPPORT

TEXT.P: ROC Representative in Japan Chuang Ming-yao on Wednesday called on the Japanese people to support the entry of Taiwan into the United Nations and other international organizations.

In an interview with the Sankei Shimbun, Chuang, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan, said Taiwan maintains diplomatic relations with 27 countries and boasted the world's 18th-largest gross national product last year.

The dignity of the Republic of China under a system of democracy, liberty and human rights should be respected, and it is unfair to keep this nation outside international institutions, including the United Nations, Chuang said. He called for the support of the Japanese people in this regard.

Referring to the close relations between Taipei and Tokyo, Chuang noted that Taiwan is Japan's fourth-largest trade partner with the two countries' bilateral trade volume reaching US$40.7 billion last year. Japan is also Taiwan's largest foreign investor, investing US$850 million last year alone.
Chuang spoke highly of the Japan-US security treaty, which he said is a deterrent against any disturbance and will contribute to the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific region.
Any incident occurring in the Taiwan Strait will be an international matter, not an internal affair of mainland China, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE WRITERS CONDEMN ATROCITIES IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese writers condemned on Wednesday the atrocities committed against Indonesia's ethnic Chinese and urged Indonesian authorities to bring those responsible to justice.

In a joint statement, the Chinese writers gathered in Taipei for the third World Chinese Writers Conference compared the persecution suffered by Indonesia's ethnic Chinese -- which manifested itself in the forms of beating, ransacking, looting, raping, burning and killing -- to the cruelties committed by the Japanese Imperial Army and the Nazis during World War II.
They lodged a written protest with the Indonesian government over the plight of ethnic Chinese in that country and urged the Indonesian government to take effective and strong action to address it.

They also called on the United Nations' Human Rights Commission and on UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan to take action in accordance with the UN's Declaration of Human Rights to press the Indonesia government to ensure the personal safety and the security of property owned by the ethnic Chinese living in that country.
In addition to its written protest, the group launched a fund-raising campaign and is collecting aid for the victims of May's rioting.

The conference, which opened in Taipei on Monday, has brought together about 100 Chinese writers from 36 countries. Discussions during the five-day meeting will center on Chinese culture and literature.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP REAFFIRMS ITS MAINLAND CHINA POLICY IS UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reaffirmed on Wednesday that its policy toward mainland China remains unchanged despite criticism that party policy is wavering.

Chiou I-jen, DPP secretary-general, stressed that the DPP policy would not be changed in a single day, and that if the DPP allows outsiders to harbor such a misunderstanding, the party should be held responsible.
Chiou, after returning from a visit to Xiamen in the mainland late last month, said the DPP will conduct across-the-board contact and engagement with the mainland from now on.
Chiou said at the time that if Taiwan continues to refuse to negotiate with the mainland, it will be deemed a "troublemaker" and risk losing the support and sympathy of the international community.
But after the kidnap and murder of DPP Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in the mainland, the DPP has toughened its stance.
A DPP task force formed after Lin's death on July 29 criticized the way mainland China handled the case and threatened to push the government to suspend exchanges with the mainland.

The task force strongly demanded that Beijing allow the intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to send officials to the mainland, allow the DPP to send officials to the mainland to help Lin's family and allow the body of Lin to return to Taiwan without a full autopsy in line with the wishes of Lin's family.
After Beijing agreed to allow DPP officials in and promised to conduct minimal examination of Lin's body, the DPP reversed its stance and ceased to talk about suspending cross-strait exchanges.
Chiou denied that this indicates the party is wavering on its mainland policy, saying that the tough stance of the DPP has helped Lin's family in handling their loss.

The DPP Central Standing Committee reaffirmed that the value of human rights should not be trampled upon, and that the DPP hopes that the proper handling of the case will serve as an example for cross-strait relations.

The committee also said that it will actively push for discussion on such topics as investment guarantee agreements, trade arbitration agreements, judicial assistance and joint crackdowns on crimes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The committee suggested that the government set up a warning system regarding travel and doing business in the mainland.
It also asked the government to fully investigate reports of Taiwan people being abused while in the mainland.

The committee also urged the government to refute accusations by the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, the SEF counterpart in the mainland, that Taiwan sought to use the Lin Ti-chuan incident to disrupt cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA SIGNS HISTORIC LAND TREATY WITH NATIVES

TEXT.P: Canada's federal and provincial governments signed a historic treaty with the Nisga'a natives in British Columbia Tuesday.
The Nisga'a people of British Columbia have been fighting for more than 100 years for control of the Nass Valley.

The agreement gives the Nisga'a 1,930 square kilometers of land in the lower Nass Valley in northwestern British Columbia, self-government powers akin to those of municipal governments and C$300 million.
The Nisga'a get resource rights over their lands, allowing them access to forests and fish. They can set up their own courts, although Canada's criminal code and constitution still apply.
In return, the Nisga'a give up the right to future land claims and their tax-exempt status.

"The Nisga'a canoe returns to the Nass River, with a cargo of hope and reconciliation." That was the word from a Nisga'a chief as the treaty was inked at a ceremony attended by more than 1,500 people, most of them Nisga'a.

Chief Joseph Gosnell said the treaty was a triumph for both the Nisga'a people and the people of Canada. British Columbia Premier Glen Clark and federal Indian Affairs Minister Jane Stewart were on hand for the ceremony.

There are dozens of outstanding land treaties across British Columbia. Stewart said she hoped the Nisga'a deal will move other negotiations onto a fast track. The treaty is a "signal to the other first nations of British Columbia that treaty negotiations do work," Stewart said.
Though the treaty has been signed, it is not all clear sailing for the Nisga'a canoe. It will have to pass a referendum by the Nisga'a, as well as by provincial and federal legislatures.

Observers said the treaty could become a hot political issue. Some Nisga'a call the treaty a sellout and said they will not ratify it. Many non-natives believe the agreement is of such importance that it should be tested in a province-wide referendum.
Clark pre-empted his political enemies by telling those who criticize the deal not to "deny our history" and not to be "blind to the injustices of the past."
Those opposing the deal would be rejecting 30 years of negotiations and compromise from all sides, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES BEIJING TO HANDLE LIN TI-CHUAN INCIDENT PROPERLY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday urged Beijing to properly handle the incident related to the death of a Taiwan councilwoman in the mainland.

In receiving a group of Hong Kong visitors, Lee called on Beijing for fair, just and legal response to the death of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan, who was kidnapped and killed in Dalian, located in the northeastern mainland province of Liaoning, last week.

Addressing concerns raised by his visitors, Lee said the time is not ripe for Taiwan to contemplate direct postal, shipping and trade links with mainland China since Beijing still refuses to recognize the Republic of China as a sovereignty and treat it accordingly.
"Without safeguarding national security and interests, it is not the time for people in Taiwan to mull the idea. They simply will not accept it," he said.

Emphasizing the fact that "China" is now divided and ruled by two separate administrations, Lee urged Beijing to come to terms with this political reality. He further said the "one country, two systems" reunification formula put forth by Beijing is ambiguous, paradoxical and non-democratic.

The Republic of China, as a sovereign country, is different from Hong Kong, and the "one country, two systems" formula prescribed by Beijing for Hong Kong is absolutely unacceptable to Taiwan, said Lee.
The Hong Kong group, led by Liberal Party leader Allen Lee Peng-fei, includes legislators Emily Lau Wai-hing, Christine Loh Kung-wai, Fred Lee Wing-tat and Chan Kam-lam, as well as several scholars.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIA TO TAKE EQUITY STAKE IN CAL

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and China Airlines (CAL) have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to form a strategic alliance, SIA announced Tuessday.
The MOU also sets out general principles for SIA's purchase of CAL shares within six months.
SIA Deputy Chairman and CEO Cheong Choong Kong said that SIA was thinking of a stake of "between 5 and 10 percent" in CAL.

"We see China Airlines as a good investment," said Cheong. "It demonstrates our faith in the long-term future of the aviation industry in this region, notwithstanding the present economic difficulties. In conjunction with equity participation, we shall be exploring joint ventures in airline-related businesses with China Airlines."

The proposed alliance aims to benefit customers by providing a seamless travel service between the two carriers, SIA said. Flight schedules will be coordinated to allow for fast and convenient connections, and code-sharing on certain routes will provide travelers with a wider choice of travel options.
Commenting on the benefits, Cheong said the proposed tie-up would strengthen the competitive position of the two airlines.

"The formation of strategic alliances is a trend in the international aviation industry today, and the focus of our development has been on building up our competitive resources through the choice of a strategic partner with a high degree of complementarity and a low degree of cultural difference," China Airlines Chairman Chiang Hung-i said.
"We are delighted that after several months of negotiations we are able to enter into this historic cooperative relationship with our ideal strategic alliance partner, Singapore Airlines," he added.

This is the third strategic alliance announced by SIA since mid-1997 and the first since then involving equity participation. SIA has already entered into alliances with Lufthansa in Europe and with Air New Zealand and Ansett.

SIA operates a fleet of 87 aircraft and offers flights to 76 destinations in 41 countries. For the fiscal year ending March 31, 1998, the Singapore International Group's total revenue was S$7.72 billion.

CAL was established in 1959 and operates a fleet of 52 of the latest Boeing, McDonnell Douglas and Airbus jetliners. China Airlines and its two subsidiaries, Mandarin Airlines and Formosa Airlines, serve 46 destinations in 20 countries. The company's operating revenue in 1997 totaled NT$55.85 billion and its pre-tax profit, NT$2.77 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: DNA TESTS TO BE ADOPTED TO PREVENT VISITS BY FAKE MAINLAND RELATIVES

TEXT.P: Taiwan security authorities are considering adopting DNA tests to prevent "fake" mainland Chinese relatives from coming to Taiwan for visits.

According to the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau, an underground mainland Chinese ring was recently found to have provided bogus documents certifying that some mainlanders were related to Taiwan residents allowing them to legally come to Taiwan to visit relatives.
MJIB officials believe several hundred mainland Chinese residents obtained permission to visit Taiwan through this illegal channel.
Some of these people were found to be gathering intelligence in Taiwan for mainland authorities, according to MJIB officials.

Others are suspected of involvement in the swindling of large amounts of death benefits in Taiwan with counterfeit documents certifying their relation to deceased veterans who came to Taiwan four or five decades ago from mainland China and passed away alone on the island, the officials noted.

The ring -- composed of several Taiwan lawyers, some retired Taiwan servicemen originally from the mainland and an unknown number of mainland Chinese officials in charge of notarization -- was found to have made away with several hundred million NT dollars through fraudulent claims for deceased ROC veteran death benefits.

According to existing Taiwan laws governing civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, parents or children of Taiwan residents are legitimately allowed to visit Taiwan for short- or long-term visits depending on circumstances.
On average, there are about 50,000 mainlanders who are "legally" visiting Taiwan every day, said MJIB officials.
Once the DNA examination measure is put into force, mainland relatives who intend to visit Taiwan will be asked to include a specimen with their entrance application for DNA comparison, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO EXPAND COOPERATION WITH SOUTH AFRICA
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Aug. 5 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The representative of the Taipei Liaison Office in South Africa on Wednesday pledged to promote friendship and cooperation between the Republic of China and South Africa.
Du Ling made the remarks during his speech to the African-Asian Society in Johannesburg.
He said he will devote himself to eliminating barriers in Taipei-Pretoria relations despite there being no official diplomatic ties between the two sides.
South Africa switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing from Taipei at the beginning of this year. Taipei severed official ties with Pretoria in retaliation.

Trade between Taiwan and South Africa was posted at around US$1.8 billion last year, a figure which accounts for less than 1 percent of Taiwan's entire foreign trade in 1997, Du noted. The amount of trade reflects the fact that there is ample room for both sides to increase trade, he added.
Taiwan ranks as South Africa's sixth largest trade partner.

About 620 Taiwan businesses have invested over US$1.5 billion in the African country. Most of the enterprises built factories to produce a range of goods including computers, clothes, and household goods, according to the ROC official.
The African-Asian Society, formed to promote relations between southern Africa and Asia, is comprised of members in the political, academic, trade and economic, and information sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND AMBASSADOR FAILS TO ATTEND HUMAN RIGHTS MEETING

TEXT.P: The boycott of a US House subcommittee meeting Wednesday morning by a mainland Chinese ambassador "raises grave doubts about the value of a promise made by a representative of the Chinese government," a US congressman said.

Mainland Chinese Ambassador Li Zhaoxing had promised to attend a meeting of the House Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights, chaired by Rep. Christopher Smith (R-NJ), but backed out minutes prior to his scheduled appearance.
Smith reiterated an invitation for Li to attend the subcommittee's meeting and made it clear that Li was welcome to the meeting whenever he decides to appear.
"Ambassador Li, there is nothing to fear, so long as your government does not fear the truth," the congressman said in a statement.

Smith explained that the subcommittee meeting was called to conduct a frank and open discussion with Li on the subject of human rights in China. The meeting was arranged after Smith received a call from the political counselor at the Chinese embassy stating that Li would like to accept Smith's invitation to present Beijing's official comments on human rights in China.
However, as soon as the subcommittee agreed to schedule a hearing, the Chinese embassy began placing numerous conditions on the ambassador's attendance.

First, they argued over the shape of the table, insisting that the tables and chairs be arranged so that the ambassador would sit directly across from the members of the subcommittee and on the same level with them rather than at a witness table with the members sitting on a dais.
Then the Chinese embassy insisted that the subcommittee not call the meeting a "hearing," although this is the word customarily used to describe an open meeting of the House subcommittee.

Later, the embassy insisted that no other outside party be invited or permitted to make statements or answer questions at the meeting. It was quite firm on not wanting Li to appear on the same platform or even on the same day as such Chinese human rights activists as former political prisoners Wei Jingsheng and Harry Wu.
But in the interest of having the ambassador appear and defend Beijing's record on human rights, the House subcommittee agreed to all these conditions, Smith noted.

Unfortunately, the subcommittee was notified 20 minutes before the scheduled Wednesday meeting that the ambassador was not coming, "even though the embassy no longer believes that we violated the ground rules," the congressman said.

It is really too bad, Smith added, because "we had planned to ask him some very direct and detailed questions about human rights in China, starting with the facts: Did anybody really die at Tiananmen Square in 1989? Are there forced abortions in China? Are there political and religious prisoners? Do elements of the Chinese military sell organs harvested from executed prisoners? Where is the nine-year-old Panchen Lama, who was abducted three years ago by agents of the Chinese government?"

On these questions and so many others, it is useless to exchange opinions "until we get to the bottom of serious factual disputes," Smith said. In each case, human rights advocates, reputable journalists, international organizations, and/or foreign government have made detailed findings of serious human rights violations, and in each case, the Chinese government has simply denied that anything had happened.

Smith said, "We will not learn this morning how the Chinese government explains these amazing discrepancies. Instead, we have learned yet another lesson about negotiating with the government of the People's Republic of China."

DOC.HEADLINE: AQUINO WINS RAMON MAGASAYSAY AWARD

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada on Wednesday congratulated former President Corazon Aquino for winning the 1998 Ramon Magasaysay Award for international understanding.
The recent peaceful transfer of presidential powers was partly a direct result of the democracy she installed, the president said.
Aquino's triumph was a victory for all peace-loving Filipinos who continued to protect the democratic freedoms she helped them obtain, Estrada added.
The Magasaysay Award is said Asia's equivalent of the Nobel Prize. Aquino is the 29th Filipino to receive the award.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAKISTAN TO DRAFT CHARTER FOR ISLAMIC INTER-PARLIAMENTARY UNION

TEXT.P: Pakistan will present a draft charter proposing closer interaction among parliamentarians of Islamic counties to the Inter-Parliamentary Union meeting in Moscow, according to the Associated Press of Pakistan.
The "Islamic Inter-Parliamentary Union" will be presented after a meeting of parliament leaders from Pakistan and Iran in Islamabad.

Pakistan's National Assembly Speaker Elahi Bukhsh Soomro told the visiting Jawed Larijani, deputy chairman of the Foreign Policy Committee of the Iran parliament that the matter should be discussed by representatives of Islamic countries at the Moscow meeting.

Larijani said the coordination committee which was set up to implement the cooperative plan will meet shortly in Tehran to finalize the agenda, venue and time for the first meeting of the proposed body.
The Iranian speaker said the IIPU will operate in harmony and cooperation with the Organization of Islamic Conference and the Inter-Parliamentary Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: 50 US-BRED OSTRICHES 'EMIGRATE' TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The first batch of 200 live, farm-bred ostriches arrived in the northern port city of Keelung Thursday from Los Angeles, marking the first such import to Taiwan.
The 50 birds were immediately transported to a plant and animal quarantine center in Hsichih, suburban Taipei, for a quarantine check.
The 14 male and 36 female birds will then be delivered to their buyer -- Chianan Ostrich Range in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan -- for permanent settlement.

An additional 150 similar birds are expected to arrive in Taiwan in the coming weeks as the application process to import them is underway. The deliveries were divided into four groups because of the limited capacity of the quarantine center, said the importer.

The 200 birds are all adults aged between 4 and 5 years old, and stand at about 180 centimeters tall. All of them have been tested for fertility and were selected from ostrich farms in Utah, Texas and California.
The importer hopes to breed the birds and expand the ostrich population on the island.
Ostriches live an average of 50 to 60 years and remain fertile for 20 to 30 years. Female birds produce an average of 50 eggs per year.
A bird of high economic value, ostriches are bred for their skin, feathers and eggs.

Currently, the importer, which also imports ostrich meat from the United States, provides about 20 metric tons of frozen ostrich meat to local gourmet restaurants. Ostrich meat tastes like beef but is a healthy alternative to red meat as it is low in fat, the importer said.
