DOC.HEADLINE: MISSION TO CONTINUE SUPPORT FOR WOMEN VICTIMS IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: A Taiwan mission said Thursday it will continue to provide professional counseling to women in Indonesia who were assaulted and raped during the May riots.

The group, returning from a four-day, fact-finding trip to Indonesia Wednesday night, said in a news conference that it found the Southeast Asian country lacks the experience and support system to help victims.
The delegation said it will continue to offer long-term support to victims through existing channels in Indonesia.

Comprised of officials from local civic groups such as the Garden of Hope, Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, Taiwan Association for Human Rights, and End Child Prostitution Association of Taiwan, the mission was headed by Wang Ching-feng, a former Control Yuan member.
Members of the mission originally wanted to meet with victims of assaults and rapes, but later concluded it may be unwise to do so, saying that they fully understood how the victims felt.
From meetings with local women's groups, Wang said that there are 168 established cases of sexual abuse which occurred during the riots.
The Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation said it has received more donations and will use the money to cover support and medical expenses for the victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY OF COUNCILWOMAN TO BE ESCORTED TO TAIWAN SATURDAY

TEXT.P: The body of Lin Ti-chuan, a member of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party, is expected to arrive in Taiwan on Saturday.

A hearse carrying Lin's body left Haicheng, Liaoning province, Thursday morning. In the company of Lin's brother and sister-in-law, the hearse and its accompanying motorcade arrived at Beijing Thursday night.
Lin's parents and another DPP Councilman, Huang Chao-hsing, also left Haicheng by car Thursday for Shengyang and there took a flight to Beijing.

With her beloved family, Lin's body will be flown from Beijing to Hong Kong Saturday and from there onto Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan. The plane transporting her body is expected to land at Kaohsiung's airport by 4:50 p.m., in line with a local custom that the body of someone who dies overseas must be brought back before nightfall.
Lin's friends and relatives, as well as DPP officials, will hold a memorial at a makeshift funeral hall at a lot in the airport.

The exact cause of Lin's death has not yet been determined, although the results of an examination of her body performed Wednesday indicate the Kaohsiung City councilwoman was not assaulted or physically mistreated during her abduction.

Chen Yao-chang, a forensics expert from National Taiwan University who was requested by Lin's family to travel to the mainland to take part in the examination, said that the examination was conducted in accordance with the wishes of the family, who had refused to allow a full autopsy to be performed.
Chen said that five puncture marks were found on Lin's upper right arm. There were also what were apparently slight bruises to her legs and arms, suggesting she may have been tied up.

Lin, one of the rising stars of the DPP, made her debut in politics at the age of 28. She and her boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, arrived at Dalian, Liaoning province, on July 27. Shortly thereafter they were abducted and taken to Haicheng.

According to Wei, he and Lin were given injections by their abductors every few hours. On July 29, Lin was found to be foaming at the mouth and was rushed to the hospital, where she was pronounced dead. Meanwhile, Wei managed to escape and reported the incident to the police.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR LU HSIU-YI DIES OF CANCER

TEXT.P: Legislator Lu Hsiu-yi, one of the most prominent and respected politicians in the opposition camp, died of adeno carcinoma at a hospital in Taipei County on Thursday at the age of 57.
Lu, a three-term lawmaker from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), passed away at 3:27 a.m. at the Koo Foundation-Sun Yat-sen Cancer Center in Tamsui on the outskirts of Taipei.

Lu was rushed to the hospital on Tuesday evening when he developed severe respiratory problems. After emergency medical treatment, his condition initially stabilized but worsened Wednesday evening. Respecting Lu's wishes, doctors decided not to administer further life-saving measures.
A physical checkup at National Taiwan University Hospital after Lu swooned during a brawl on the legislative floor on April 15, 1991 revealed a small stain on Lu's right lung.
Doctors advised Lu either to undergo surgery or receive regular checkups. Because of his hectic schedule, Lu did not bother to undergo another checkup until July 1995.

By that time, the stain on Lu's lung had expanded, and doctors diagnosed it as a malignant tumor. Lu was pronounced terminally ill when he was admitted to the Sun Yat-sen Cancer Center in late 1995. By then, cancer cells had already invaded his right collarbone.

Over the past three years, Lu demonstrated enormous courage and strong willpower in fighting the cancer. During the period, he scaled Taiwan's highest peak, Mt. Jade, twice. In his first try, he failed to reach the top of the mountain. But he made it in his second assault.
A native of Taipei County, Lu dedicated himself to Taiwan's democratization and the development of indigenous culture.
Lu and his wife, a musician, jointly set up the Egret Cultural Foundation some 10 years ago to promote musical education in rural areas.
As one of the DPP's founding members, Lu demonstrated his love and loyalty to the party by helping the DPP retain its control of the island's largest and most populous county late last year.

Although terminally ill, Lu rejected his doctor's advice and went out to stump for the DPP's candidate for the Taipei County magistrate election, Su Chen-chang. He even knelt down at Su's last campaign forum on Nov. 28, 1997 to solicit popular support for his DPP comrade.

Lu's unexpected move pulled at the heartstrings of many voters present at the occasion. Some political observers said Lu's kneeling contributed much to Su's narrow victory over a strong competitor from the ruling Kuomintang.

Su rushed to the hospital early Thursday morning to pay tribute to Lu. "Lu's passing is a great loss to the DPP. I appreciate his campaigning for me. I'll redouble my efforts to improve the Taipei County Government's administration to fulfill his wish and repay his assistance."
Many other DPP heavyweights, including party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, also visited the hospital to extend condolences to Lu's family.

Lin praised Lu as a courageous man, not only for his fight for Taiwan's democratization but also for his fight against cancer. "I'm saddened by his death. I has lost a good partner in fight for the DPP's cause."

Taipei Mayor Chen said Lu's passing was not only a loss to the DPP but also a loss to the whole of Taiwan. "We have much to learn from his optimism and dedication to promoting Taiwan's democratization."
With a doctoral degree in political science from Paris University, Lu once taught at Chinese Culture University and National Tsinghua University before entering politics in 1989.

Lu also once served a three-year prison term from 1983 through 1986 on a charge of sedition for promoting Taiwan independence. At that time, Taiwan was still under martial law and advocating independence was a taboo.

A witty, humorous person, Lu often acted as an opinion leader in the Legislative Yuan. His profound knowledge, rational manner and resourcefulness helped him win much respect and admiration by his legislative colleagues and by journalists.
Lu's body is being kept at the Taipei County Public Funeral Parlor. A funeral is scheduled to be held on Aug. 18. Lu is survived by his wife, two daughters and one son.

DOC.HEADLINE: E. SUN BANK OPENS MANILA OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The E. Sun Bank will open a representative office in Manila Friday, becoming the sixth Taiwan-based bank to do so.

The International Commercial Bank of China and Chinatrust Commercial Bank have already set up branches in Manila, while the First Commercial Bank, United World Chinese Bank and Taiwan Cooperative Bank have opened offices in the city.

Chen Tsung-jung, manager of E. Sun's Manila office, said the Taipei head office's decision to open an office here was made in line with the ROC government's "go south" investment policy, and because the bank believes that Southeast Asia has great development potential.

"The Manila office's opening on the first-month anniversary of President Joseph Estrada's inauguration is an indication that we are confident in the Philippines' economic development under Estrada's leadership," Chen said.
Chen said the office will provide Taiwan businessmen in both the Philippines and Taiwan with a variety of financial services.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.072 against the greenback in Taipei Thursday, closing at 34.5.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.379, and had a low of 34.534.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$252.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LINCOLN SCHOOL TO BE GRANTED LAND LICENSE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday denied that it secretly asked a local government to legalize the existence of the Lincoln American School on a spot zoned for residential use only.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu made the statement during a news conference in a bid to clarify a report on the MOFA's alleged secret order.

The widely-circulated United Daily News reported on Thursday that the Taiwan Provincial Department of Reconstruction (DOR) has recognized the Lincoln school as a "necessary public facility" within Taichung's scenic Takeng district, according to a confidential MOFA document.
The recognition legalizes the relocation of the school, run by Anna Lee, daughter of President Lee Teng-hui, the report said.
It was found in late May that the foreign school had moved from the city's Taya district to the Takeng district, a scenic area that is zoned for resort use.

Sung Ai-ko, a Taiwan provincial assemblyman from the opposition New Party, disclosed the existence of an official agreement Wednesday. He rebuked the government for discussing the issue through confidential documents and he condemned some of the officials involved in the incident for extending special privileges, according to the report.
Wu said documents such as the one that has been cited allow exchanges of opinion among government agencies.

The document in question, he said, merely contains calls from American nationals living on the island for proper educational facilities for their children. Wu stressed that MOFA did not specifically mention the Lincoln American School in the confidential document.
Nearly 2,000 American nationals currently live in central Taiwan, according to MOFA.
Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying said on Thursday her government is expected to grant a license to the Lincoln school within two weeks.
The approval was issued after MOFA, DOR and the Taichung City Government agreed that the Lincoln American School can be regarded as a necessary public facility, Chang said.
The Lincoln American School has a total of 15 classes, from kindergarten to the 12th grade. As a foreign school, it may accept only foreign students or Taiwan students possessing dual citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: FILIPINO CHINESE SLAM INDONESIAN ATROCITIES AGAINST ETHNIC CHINESE
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A total of 35 Chinese groups based in the Philippines issued a statement on Thursday, strongly condemning the recent Indonesian atrocities against ethnic Chinese.

The statement also urged the United Nations Human Rights Committee to pay attention to the anti-Chinese resentment in Indonesia and to demand that the Indonesian government fully protect its ethnic Chinese population. The horrible racial discrimination in the Southeast Asian nation should be stopped, it said.

The Indonesian government cannot shed its responsibilities, and should address the fact that its inability to protect the personal safety and property of ethnic Chinese has led to great suffering and damage, the statement said.

Ethnic Chinese were cruelly robbed, abused, and killed, and more than 160 ethnic Chinese women were raped during widespread Indonesian civil unrest in May which led to the downfall of President Suharto.
The statement urged the ROC government not to ease its stance and to continue pushing the Indonesian government to quickly arrest the rioters and bring the culprits to trial.
The ROC government should also continue monitoring subsequent developments closely and work out effective measures to protect overseas Chinese, the statement concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC PRAISES SEF'S EFFORTS TO DEAL WITH LIN INCIDENT

TEXT.P: Although the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) could not fully fulfill its function in dealing with matters concerning the murder of Kaohsiung City Councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in mainland China, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) nevertheless praised SEF's efforts.
Lin was a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. After her death, SEF attempted to gain consent for foundation officials to accompany Lin's family to the mainland.

In addition, SEF communicated with its mainland counterpart, the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), and with ARATS' assistance was able to convey calls to mainland officials to fully investigate Lin's murder. Afterward, SEF called for Taiwan businesspeople in Shenyang, Liaoning province, to hold a reception for Lin's family.

ROC nationals have been permitted to travel to the mainland for the past 10 years, and during that time there have been 195 reports of threats to the security of Taiwan tourists and businesspeople in the mainland, said MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin on Thursday.

Taipei has called repeatedly for SEF and ARATS to hold discussions on the safety of Taiwan people in the mainland and the protection of their property, as well as on cross-strait cooperation in criminal investigations, said Lin. ARATS, however, has rejected the overtures, instead preferring that political negotiations take place first, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARBIN, BEIJING DELICACIES TO BE EXHIBITED AT TAIPEI FOOD FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Top-notch chefs from Beijing and the northeastern mainland Chinese city of Harbin are expected to show off their culinary skills with native delicacies at the 1998 Taipei Food Festival, slated to open Aug. 8 and last until Aug. 11.

Chefs from Harbin will present a "feast of flying dragon." The flying dragon, as it is commonly known by locals, is an animal native only to northeastern mainland China, in the deep forests along Amur River, which serves as the country's border with Russia. The bird is renowned for its heavenly taste and tenderness.
Other dishes to be served up by the chefs from Harbin include deer tendon, wild chicken, and pine and hazel mushrooms.

The will also demonstrate their ice-carving skills, while chefs from the United States, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and mainland China will take part in ice, fruit and vegetable carving contests.

Chefs from Beijing are expected to prepare foods that graced the tables of many a royal feast, such as the "Empire" fish, an offshoot of the Chinese sturgeon that is said to have been served at royal feasts during the Ching dynasty.
Culinary masterpieces from 18 leading tourist-oriented restaurants and hotels in Taiwan will be on display at the festival, which is being sponsored by the Taiwan Visitors Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL OFFICIAL'S US VISIT CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: Presidential Office officials confirmed on Thursday that Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, made a visit to the United States late last month.

The officials were responding to a local newspaper report that Ding traveled to New York last week to meet with US Deputy National Security Adviser James Steinberg on Taipei-Washington ties and relations across the Taiwan Strait.
The officials said Ding left for New York on July 26 in the company of a close aide, and that he had reported his travel plans to President Lee Teng-hui prior to his departure.
However, they would not divulge when Ding is scheduled to return, nor would they explain the purpose of his trip.

Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said Ding's visit was arranged by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which was founded by US authorities in 1979 to handle exchanges with the Republic of China following the severing of formal diplomatic ties.

Lee declined to reveal whom Ding has met during his stay in the United States, nor would he divulge any details of times, venues, or contents of any meetings. He also refused to confirm whether Ding is still in the United States.
The trip is Ding's second to the United States so far this year. He was originally also scheduled to visit France in May, but later canceled the trip for unknown reasons.

The China Times reported on Thursday that Ding met secretly with Steinberg in a New York hotel last week, and that Thomas Pickering, US under secretary of state for political affairs, was also present at the meeting.
According to the paper, the de facto ROC envoy to the United States, Stephen Chen, and Vice Foreign Minister Lee also attended the meeting.

The paper said the two countries arranged details about the meeting when AIT Chairman Richard Bush visited Taipei in early July to brief ROC officials on US President Bill Clinton's June 25-July 3 visit to mainland China.
The paper said Steinberg told Ding during their talks that the United States maintains a very transparent stance on issues related to Taiwan.

Steinberg reportedly also assured Ding that Clinton's mainland visit has not undermined Taiwan's interests, nor did the United States and mainland China reach any Taiwan-related secret agreements or understandings during Clinton's trip.
Lee declined to comment on the reports, saying instead that dialogue channels between Taipei and Washington operate very smoothly.
The AIT's Taipei office also refused to comment on the China Times report.

Taipei and Washington began holding confidential high-level dialogue in New York in the spring of 1996, when mainland China conducted live-fire war games and missile tests in waters near Taiwan to intimidate Taiwan voters in the run-up to the ROC's first direct presidential election.
Last week's meeting was the fourth of its kind. Ding has consistently served as the chief ROC delegate in all those meetings.

The United States was originally represented by Sandy Berger, then deputy national security adviser. In January 1997, Steinberg replaced Berger as the US delegate. Berger is now national security adviser.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE PUBLIC PRAISES JUDICIARY

TEXT.P: Most Singaporeans feel the country's judiciary administers justice fairly and upholds law and order efficiently, a recent survey shows.
Forbes Research, a market research company, was commissioned by Singapore's Subordinate Courts in May to conduct the survey.
A total of 1,519 people aged 15 or older were interviewed between May and July. The findings in the survey were released Wednesday.

Ninety-seven percent of respondents said the courts administer justice fairly, while 96 percent said the courts operate independently; an equal percentage said court rulings are obeyed. Ninety-five percent said the judiciary is efficient in upholding law and order, and 93 percent said the sentences meted out by the courts were effective or very effective as a deterrent to potential offenders.
Confidence in an efficient and prompt resolution to disputes was expressed by 90 percent of respondents.
On public perception of crime levels and the effectiveness of sentencing, almost all respondents said they feel safe in Singapore, affirming that the judiciary has much to do with it.
The survey indicated 94 percent of respondents received information about the courts from television, 76 percent from The Straits Times and 68 percent from radio.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU RONGJI, JIANG ZEMIN TO FORM ALLIANCE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji and President Jiang Zemin have decided to form a "power alliance" to deal with their opponents' attacks on their economic policy, the South China Morning Post of Hong Kong reported Thursday.

The report said they expected that some opponents will criticize their economic policy and question them about social and economic problems at the upcoming Bedaihe Conference of top government leaders. At the meeting at least one member of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee will ask Zhu to lower the jobless rate.

It pointed out that Zhu, whose power base is generally believed to be rather weak, has repeatedly said in recent months he would "follow the leadership of the party with comrade Jiang Zemin at the core."

Zhu's policy to lay off employees of state enterprises has displeased many party members, who have echoed in recent months Jiang's remarks that "To the mass of people in the country, the most important thing is to have foods on the table."

Zhu's plan to make bank loans easier to get in order to stimulate the economy may also be attacked at the meeting, because critics believe the plan will lead to more waste and inefficiency, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S DEFENSE WHITE PAPER CONTAINS NOTHING NEW: MAC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Thursday criticized Beijing's new national defense white paper, saying it contains nothing new and that it lacks transparency.

Stressing that Beijing has not changed its position toward Taiwan on either the political or military fronts, MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said Beijing's reluctance to renounce the use of force against Taiwan is apparently contradictory to its claim that mainland China will not be an aggressor to other countries.
Even if mainland China "becomes strong and powerful in the future, it absolutely will not take to the road of foreign aggression and expansion," according to the white paper.

But it also says that mainland China "seeks to achieve the reunification of the country by peaceful means, but will not commit itself to a promise not to resort to force. Every sovereign state has the right to use all means it deems necessary, including military means, to safeguard its own sovereignty and territorial integrity."

Lin said the 30,000-character white paper, made public by Beijing on July 27, is not transparent enough, as it falls short of reporting the aims of mainland China's national defense policy, and does not touch on its military deployments, exercises, or combat programs.

Lin was also skeptical about mainland China's military expenditures as tallied in the white paper, saying that the international community estimates that the real figure may be from two to ten times higher than the figure claimed by Beijing.

Citing the latest issue of the Military Balance 97/98, published by a London-based international strategical policy research center, Lin said mainland China may have allocated as much as US$38 billion toward its defense spending over the past year.

According to the white paper, mainland China has made "relatively major reductions" in defense inputs. It says mainland China's defense expenditure in 1997 was US$9.8 billion, only 3.67 percent of the amount spent by the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WILL HELP ETHNIC CHINESE VICTIMS SEEK TREATMENT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday said that it is willing to help ethnic Chinese women who have been raped in Indonesia to seek medical treatment in Taiwan.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the decision to offer assistance was made at the 11th ministerial-level meeting on the Indonesian situation, which was attended by representatives of the ministries of foreign affairs, national defense, education, communications and transportation, economic affairs, and the interior.

Those present at the meeting, which was presided over by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, also agreed that the MOFA will instruct its representative to Indonesia to continuously press the relevant Indonesian agencies to ensure the personal and property security of ethnic Chinese living in the Southeast Asian country.
Wu said that although the participants decided not to issue a formal statement warning Taiwan tourists not to visit Indonesia, they urged Taiwan people to exercise caution while there.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW RETURNS TO WORK, VOWS TO REVITALIZE ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew returned to work on Thursday after undergoing prostrate surgery last week.
Siew, who has a six-year medical history of enlarged prostate, received the surgery at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei last Thursday.

The surgery was uneventful, and Siew's doctors allowed him to return to work starting Thursday. But the premier is required to go back to the hospital every day for the next week so that his convalescence can be monitored.
Siew, 59, was his customary smiling self when he left the hospital early in the morning, accompanied by his wife.
"I feel good after having `old parts of my body repaired,'" Siew told local reporters covering his discharge from the hospital. "After a week of rest, I now have more energy to fulfill my duties."

Siew said he was grateful that many local citizens have sent him greeting cards, flowers and e-mail to express their concern for his health. "I'll redouble my efforts to perform my duties to repay their goodwill and kindness," he said.

Siew chaired a weekly Cabinet meeting after returning to work, where he announced that the government will spend an additional NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) on public infrastructure construction over the next two years to bolster domestic economic development.
The planned extra expenditure is aimed at revitalizing the domestic economy amid a slowdown caused by the Asian financial turmoil, Siew said.
"Stimulating domestic demand through construction projects is vital to maintain stable economic growth in the face of the regional financial chaos," the premier explained.
Siew said the move is also expected to stimulate private investment.
The premier also stressed the importance of government restructuring, saying it is the government's most important political engineering work for the moment.

Noting that Taiwan's current administrative structure is obsolete due to the changing social environment, Siew said government agencies at all levels should work closely to complete a comprehensive structural overhaul.
"We must adjust the hierarchy, cut red tape, and trim redundant workers in order to upgrade our administrative efficiency and overall national competitiveness," Siew said.

He urged the Taiwan Provincial Government to strengthen communication with the Legislative Yuan in order to push the legislature to pass a budget bill for central government grants for the provincial government.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, FRANCE TO FORGE BROADCASTING ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: The Central Broadcasting System (CBS) of the Republic of China will forge a strategic alliance with Radio France International, CBS Chairman Chu Wan-ching said in Paris on Wednesday.
The agreement will allow the two broadcasters to exchange programs and offer training to staff members from the opposite side, Chu said.
The purpose of the agreement is to offer listeners a variety of programming covering a range of topics in Chinese, English, French, and Southeast Asian dialects, Chu said.
The agreeement was reached at a meeting between Chu and Jeannet Magadoux, dirctor of the International Development Department of Radio France International.
CBS has established similar alliance with the national broadcasting companies of Canada, Australia, and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLAND OBTAINS TAIWAN IMPORT QUOTA FOR COMPACT CARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has agreed to grant Poland an import quota for compact cars, making the eastern European country the eighth to obtain this type of quota prior to Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, a trade official said on Thursday.

An official with the Board of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said that Poland will get an annual import quota of 3,000 compact cars, with an annual 10 percent growth rate, before Taiwan is granted WTO admission.
The official said that Poland raised the quota issue in May when Taiwan trade officials were in Geneva, Switzerland to attend a WTO working meeting

Both Poland and Thailand were granted the privilege of exporting cars into Taiwan this year. So far, Taiwan has given import quotas for compact cars to eight countries -- Malaysia, Australia, the Czech Republic, South Korea, Japan, Mexico, Thailand, and Poland -- as part of the island's efforts to enter the international trade regulatory organization.

The quota for 1998, along with the annual growth rate allowed for each country, is as follows: Malaysia -- 1,500, with zero percent annual growth; Australia -- 2,200, with 10 percent annual growth; the Czech Republic -- 2,662, with 10 percent growth; South Korea -- 8,470, with 10 percent growth; Japan -- 8,470, with 10 percent growth; Mexico -- 5,500, with 10 percent growth; Poland -- 3,000, with 10 percent growth; and Thailand -- 4,000, with 10 percent growth.

Meanwhile, Taiwan has also agreed that the worldwide import quota for compact cars will also increase by 10 percent each year and that the cars will be imported and distributed by 12 car manufacturers in Taiwan, including China Motors, Ford Lio Ho, Kuozul Motors, Prince Motors, Yulon Motors, San Yang Industrial Co., and Yeu Tyan Machinery Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISGRUNTLED POSTMAN BURNS MAIL

TEXT.P: Police on Thursday apprehended a Taichung County postman who was discovered burning a bag of mail in a Taichung City parking lot.
Hsiao Wen-cheng, 26, a contracted worker who has worked as a mail carrier for two years, told police that his heavy workload prompted him to burn the mail.
However, an official from the national post office headquarters described the workload during the summer vacation as normal, and said that Hsiao's personality was the main reason behind the incident.
The Directorate General of Posts expressed regret over the incident, but said that the senders of the ill-fated letters would not be compensated.
The official said that the burned mail was found out to consist of some 60 ordinary or printed materials letters, while compensation is only provided for registered letters.
For each damaged registered letter, the sender is entitled to compensation of NT$450, while compensation for packages varies from NT$450 to NT$1,200, depending on the weight of the package.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2 SUSPECTS IN LIN MURDER ARRESTED IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Public security forces in the northeastern mainland China province of Liaoning announced on Thursday that two suspects wanted for the kidnap of a Taiwan city councilwoman have been arrested.

Liu Linlin, deputy head of the Public Security Bureau in Anshan City, confirmed the arrests of Huang Shidong and Zhang Shifeng. Three other accomplices, including Li Guangzhi, organizer of the abduction, were described as still at large.
Liu said they will announce subsequent developments regarding the case as soon as the other three suspects are nabbed.
Huang, 23, was arrested on Tuesday in Heilongjiang Province, while Zhang, 21, was arrested on Thursday on board a Shanghai-bound train departing from Yantai City in Shandong Province, Liu said.

According to Liu, Huang has confessed to taking Lin Ti-chuan, 32, a city councilwoman from the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung, to a local hospital in Liaoning Province's Haicheng City. He also admitted to running away upon discovering that Lin was dead.

Huang, along with his four accomplices, abducted Lin and her boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, on July 27 in the city of Dalian. The couple was taken to Haicheng, some 200 kilometers north of Dalian, and detained in an empty room.
Lin and Wei were given repeated injections of drugs until Lin began to have difficulty breathing and other complications, and was taken to a local hospital by Huang on July 29.

During this time, Wei managed to escape the kidnappers unharmed and alerted the police, who later found Lin's body at the hospital. Lin was pronounced dead from an overdose of the drug used by her captors to subdue her.
According to Huang, the two ROC nationals were abducted in an attempt to force Wei to return a business debt of US$700,000 to Li, one of his trading partners.

In another development, it was reported that Lin's family and mainland police authorities had reached agreement on transporting Lin's body back to Taiwan via Hong Kong, instead of through Macao. Her body, which is currently being embalmed in Beijing, is scheduled to be brought back to Taiwan on Saturday.
Wei will have to stay in Haicheng for some time until the conclusion of the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HONG KONG AND FUJIAN FINANCIAL CONFERENCE OPENS

TEXT.P: A delegation from Taiwan is attending a conference opening Friday in Hong Kong in which Taiwan, Hong Kong and Fujian representatives will discuss financial exchanges and cooperation.

The 30-member delegation, led by Chinatrust Bank Chairman Jeffrey Koo, comprises banking leaders including Chinatrust policy-making committee leader Samuel Shieh, Taipei Bank Chairman Liao Cheng-ching and Far Eastern International Bank Chairman Y. Z. Hsu, a Chinastrust spokesperson said.

The group will talk with several dozen financial heavyweights from Hong Kong and mainland China's Fujian during the conference on mutual cooperation and ways to prevent financial crises, such as the one now pummeling Asian economies, the spokesperson said.
The conference, sponsored by the Hong Kong Chinese Bankers Association, is bringing together more than 100 financial leaders and executives from the three economically developed communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAESTRO DEBIT CARD HITS TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: The Maestro debit card, the first of its kind in Taiwan, was introduced Thursday, providing consumers with an alternative to credit cards, sources from MasterCard International reported on Friday.

In a keynote speech at a ceremony marking the consumer launch of the inter-bank Maestro in Taiwan, Finance Minister Paul Chiu noted that an increasing number of Taiwan people are paying for purchases both at home and abroad with credit cards, and this change is bringing Taiwan consumers in line with consumers worldwide.
The introduction of Maestro in Taiwan will both enhance local payment options and contribute to Taiwan's goal of developing itself into an Asia-Pacific finance center, Chiu said.

The 34 million automatic teller machine (ATM) cards currently in use in Taiwan can be enhanced with Maestro debit-payment functions in the near future, enabling cardholders to make purchases at point of sales in more than 2 million locations worldwide, said Willie Fung, country manager of MasterCard International Taiwan.
Initially 16 banks and financial institutions are participating in the first phase of the consumer launch of Maestro in Taiwan.

"First launched in 1992, Maestro has quickly become one of the most popular payment cards in the world with 160 million cards issued by the first quarter of 1998," said Jeff Portelli, vice president of debit services at MasterCard International. Maestro is the world's only 100 percent personal identification number (PIN)-based global on-line debit network, he said.
"Introducing Maestro in Taiwan will bring more payment convenience to the Taiwanese," he added.

In the opening ceremony, Lin Chen-chen, general manager of the Financial Information System Center, said Taiwan has the highest ATM penetration in the Asia-Pacific region, with an average of 2.25 ATM cards per adult. This creates a very strong base for the successful development of point of sales debit services, she noted.

"Maestro can not only help us launch a successful domestic point of sales debit product in Taiwan, but also ensure our local Maestro card and point of sales terminals are inter-operable with those around the world. This will contribute to the internationalization of Taiwan's financial services industry," she added.

"We look forward to seeing all the 34 million ATM cards in Taiwan enhanced with Maestro within the next three to five years and to the debit market reaching NT$206 billion (US$6 billion) in transaction volume by the year 2000," he said.

Debit card payment options, when added to an ATM card, allow the cost of purchases to be deducted directly from a checking or savings account. If there are not enough funds in the account, the transaction will not be processed, which will help consumers manage their finances and avoid over-spending, Fung said.

And whereas credit cards are more commonly used for larger purchases, debit cards have proved popular for everyday purchases, such as those made at gas stations and neighborhood supermarkets, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA GIVES C$2.3 MILLION IN AID TO STARVING SUDANESE

TEXT.P: Canada announced the donation of another C$2.3 million (US$1.5 million) to victims of civil war and famine in Sudan Thursday, bringing Canada's total aid to Sudan for this year to C$11.3 million (US$7.45 million).

"There are estimates that about 2.6 million people are short of food in Sudan and some 700,000 are in the most affected area of Bahr El Ghazal," Diane Marleau, minister for international co-operation, said.
She added that Canada continues to stress the immediate need for a negotiated settlement to Sudan's civil conflict so that food can reach those most in need.

The latest aid package from the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) will be used mainly for air transportation of relief supplies, the most expensive aspect of delivering food to isolated regions beset by rebel soldiers.
Canadian relief funds will also go to therapeutic feeding programs for children under 5 and starving adults.
The funds will provide medical assistance, clean water and cooking supplies to people in Sudan, especially those in Bahr El Ghazal.
In addition, six Canadians will travel to Sudan to work with the International Committee of the Red Cross in emergency operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA VIEWED AS FUTURE THREAT TO THE US: POLL

TEXT.P: Despite the "constructive engagement" policy pursued by US President Bill Clinton, most Americans -- 71 percent -- believe that mainland China poses a future threat to the United States, while only 22 percent disagree, according to a new opinion poll.
The national survey also shows that 48 percent of Americans believe that mainland China is an enemy of the United States at present, while 43 percent disagree.

The Center for Security Policy, the Claremont Institute, the Free Congress Foundation, the Family Research Council and the Heritage Foundation commissioned The Polling Company to conduct the nationwide opinion survey of 800 voters on national security, ballistic missiles and missile defense systems. The poll was conducted July 26 - 29 and has a margin of error of 3.5 percent at the 95 percent confidence level.

Although President Clinton reached a missile de-targeting agreement with the Beijing leadership during his June 25 - July 3 visit to mainland China, 62 percent of respondents are "not very" or "not at all" confident that mainland Chinese missiles are not pointed at the United States.
Only 14 percent are "extremely" or "very" confident while 22 percent are "somewhat" confident.
Meanwhile, 56 percent said they think mainland China will one day launch a nuclear attack against the United States, while 29 percent disagreed.
Seventy-eight percent said the United States should not transfer "sensitive technology," such as advanced satellite technology that could be used for military or civilian purposes, to mainland China.
Moreover, 76 percent of Americans believe that the Beijing government does not value human life as much as the US government does.

Mainland China appears to have replaced Russia as the United States' arch rival, as 63 percent of respondents said Russia is not an enemy of the United States. Nevertheless, 51 percent said Russia poses a future threat to the United States.

Meanwhile, 88 percent of Americans believe that there are countries other than Russia and mainland China that are getting ballistic missiles capable of delivering chemical, biological or nuclear weapons to the United States or its troops and allies overseas.

Seventy-one percent of respondents are worried that a nuclear war may occur in the near future in the wake of India and Pakistan's demonstrations of their nuclear capabilities. Twenty-five percent are not worried about these recent developments hastening a nuclear conflagration, according to the survey.

In addition, 89 percent believe that nations like North Korea, Iraq and Iran will have nuclear weapons of their own within 10 years. And 58 percent of Americans believe that if these rogue nations possess nuclear weapons, they will pose an "extremely" or "very" serious threat to the United States or its forces and allies.

When told that the US military cannot destroy even a single incoming missile, 86 percent of Americans said they favor the deployment of a missile defense system. Forty-six percent favor such a deployment and believe it should be an "urgent priority." Only 8 percent is opposed to such a system.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA'S SOVEREIGN RISK RATING DOWNGRADED

TEXT.P: Thomson Bankwatch, the world's largest bank rating agency, announced Thursday it was downgrading Malaysia's sovereign risk rating from A- to BBB.

This downgrade is based on the mutually reinforcing effects of this year's sharper-than-expected economic slowdown, ongoing financial market volatility, mounting domestic debt and worsening problems in the country's banking and corporate sectors, the agency said.
Malaysia's current status calls into question the adequacy of government efforts to revive Malaysia's domestic economy and to re-capitalize local financial institutions, according to the agency.

A key concern is the further deterioration in asset quality throughout the banking system, and the number of non-performing loans is expected to increase in the coming months, according to the agency, which provides ratings, analysis and research on over 1,000 financial institutions in more than 94 countries.

Conditions in the non-banking sector are also worsening, as reflected in this year's rising level of corporate debt and worse-than-expected earnings results. With sharp downturns in local stock and property markets and the scaling back of several large infrastructure projects, the overall business climate in Malaysia remains gloomy.
The recent decision to lower rates is likely to intensify pressure on the ringgit and raises concerns about the possibility of a further outflow of foreign funds, the agency said.

On the positive side, the bank rating agency said, Malaysia has demonstrated a strong track record of economic policy management over the past 15 years, which has endowed the economy with stronger fundamentals than several of its regional neighbors have.

Both foreign debt and the debt-serving costs remain low, and the proportion of short-term debt maturation in the country remains manageable, the agency stated, adding that the country's efforts to modernize its economy and diversify its export mix provide it with more of a cushion to withstand periods of economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON URGED TO CALL FOR PROTECTION OF CHINESE IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: US Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi condemned Thursday attacks on ethnic Chinese in Indonesia and asked members of Congress to join her in sending a letter to President Bill Clinton on the urgent need to restore the confidence and security of the ethnic Chinese in that Southeast Asian country.
In the letter the Californian Democrat urged Clinton to make the treatment of ethnic Chinese central to the administration's policy toward Indonesia.
Rep. Pelosi said there are credible reports that at least 168 ethnic Chinese women and girls were raped during the mid-May riots in Jakarta.

"These acts of brutality against ethnic Chinese women and their families are well-documented and cannot be condoned," she wrote, adding "The confidence and security of the ethnic Chinese community in Indonesia must be part of any credible reform program by President Habibie."

The Indonesian military has come under criticism for failing to protect the Chinese minority during the rioting and unrest that has been linked to the country's ongoing political and economic crisis, noted the congresswoman.

The letter also urged the Clinton administration to impress upon the Indonesian government that it must end all official discrimination against ethnic Chinese, prevent any further attacks, identify and prosecute those responsible for the May abuses, and issue an apology and provide compensation to the victims.

Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright were also urged to raise concerns over these issues, particularly the raping of ethnic Chinese women, in possible upcoming meetings with Indonesian President Habibie and Foreign Minister Alatas.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND TO BUILD NUCLEAR ACTIVITY MONITORING STATIONS

TEXT.P: Thailand will build a seismic monitoring station and a radio nuclide monitoring station, following India and Pakistan's underground nuclear tests last May.

Kriangsak Patrakom, secretary-general of the Atomic Energy for Peace Office, said that as a signatory of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), Thailand was chosen as the site of deployment for the equipment.

Thailand singed in November 1996 the treaty banning all means of nuclear weapons testing. However, India, which conducted five underground tests in May, said the CTBT was not a total test ban treaty because it excludes computer-simulation nuclear tests, the Thai nuclear expert said.
The seismic monitoring station will be built in the northern province of Ching Mai while the radio nuclide monitoring station will be located in Bangkok.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IN US STAGE PROTESTS AGAINST ATROCITIES IN INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese in New York, Boston and Chicago are scheduled to hold demonstrations in the next two days to protest the atrocities committed against Indonesia's ethnic Chinese during rioting there earlier this year.
The demonstrations follow a similar one Wednesday in front of the Indonesian mission to the United Nations.

The "Association of Chinese People Protesting Atrocities in Indonesia," which comprises 60 overseas Chinese groups in New York, will stage a large-scale protest Friday in front of the Indonesian Consulate General in New York.

Organizers of the protest said that to demonstrate the solidarity of Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the participants will not carry the national flags of the Republic of China and mainland China; instead they will carry US flags.
The organizers said that the demonstration will be conducted in a peaceful, rational and non-violent manner.

Overseas Chinese in Chicago will also parade to the Indonesian Consulate in that city on Friday, asking the Indonesian government to investigate the atrocities, severely punish the perpetrators and take effective measures to protect the property and personal safety of ethnic Chinese.

Overseas Chinese in Boston will stage a demonstration in downtown Boston on Saturday to express their indignation at the atrocities and to solicit attention from the international community. In addition, they will form a committee to engage in works aimed at providing long-term support.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONCERNED ABOUT JAPAN'S 'THREE NOES'

TEXT.P: Japan should not sign any agreement or joint communique with mainland China on issues related to the Republic of China, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu made the statement in response to reports that Beijing is pushing Tokyo to codify the so-called "three noes" toward Taiwan during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's state visit to Japan early next month.
According to press reports, Japan and mainland China will sign a third joint communique expressing their intention to forge a long-term strategic relationship during Jiang's Tokyo visit.

The reports said although Japan has yet to decide whether to include the Beijing-proposed "three noes" into the joint communique, Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi is likely to throw verbal support behind the "three noes" in his speech at a welcoming party for Jiang.

The "three noes" refer to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.
Commenting on the reports, Wu said MOFA has directed the ROC representative office in Tokyo to express the country's concern and stance on the issue.
Wu said that as a sovereign state, the Republic of China does not want to see any Taiwan-related issue enshrined in any official documents between mainland China and other countries.
Moreover, Wu said, mainland China has no legitimate right to represent the 21.8 million people in Taiwan, nor is it entitled to negotiate ROC-related issues with other countries.
"We hope Japan will reject Beijing's unreasonable demand and discuss any Taiwan-related issues directly with ROC authorities rather than with Beijing," Wu said.
He further urged Japan not to engage mainland China at the expense of the well-being of the people of Taiwan and long-standing friendly relations between Taipei and Tokyo.
Wu said Japan has informed the Republic of China through proper diplomatic channels of its understanding of Taipei's stance on the "three noes" issue.
The "three noes" came into the limelight after US President Bill Clinton mentioned them at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai during his June 25-July 3 mainland visit.

Meanwhile, Wu dismissed as "untrue" a newspaper report that Taipei-Tokyo ties are in danger because ROC Representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao has not devoted his full energy to his diplomatic duties.
"The report doesn't fit the facts," Wu said. "The reality is that Chuang, a retired admiral, has worked wholeheartedly since assuming his current post."
Wu further said Taipei-Tokyo ties have never been in better shape than at the moment.

"Through the concerted efforts of Chuang and all the staff at the ROC representative office, Japan has allowed Taiwan's EVA Airways to operate direct Taipei-Osaka flights since April 1. This marks a significant progress in bilateral relations," Wu said.

Under Beijing's pressure, Japan forced Taiwan's flagship China Airlines to discontinue its flight services between Taipei and Osaka shortly after it switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972.

In addition, Wu said, Japan resumed on June 8 the extension of 72-hour visa-free privileges to ROC nationals intending to make transit stops in Japanese territory. "The measure has contributed much to bilateral commercial, cultural and tourist exchanges," he noted.

Furthermore, Wu said, the Republic of China and Japan have held three rounds of fishery talks since 1996. "The talks have prompted Japan to respect the established fishing order in some disputed waters as well as the rights and interests of Taiwan fishermen," Wu explained, adding that this is another of Chuang's achievements during his tenure.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CANCELS SWAZILAND TRIP

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) confirmed on Friday that Premier Vincent Siew will cancel a scheduled trip to Swaziland following his prostate surgery last week.

Timothy Yang, director-general of the MOFA's Department of African Affairs, said that although Siew was discharged from the hospital on Thursday after successful surgery to correct an enlarged prostate, he still needs time to convalesce.
Yang said that Swaziland is an important ally of the ROC, and that the plan to send a high-ranking official to that country as an envoy of President Lee Teng-hui has not changed.
The Presidential Office has yet to decide on who will make the trip in Siew's place.

The timing of the trip is significant because this year marks the 30th anniversary of the establishment of ties between the ROC and the African nation. Siew originally wanted to depart for Swaziland in early September to attend its national day celebration on Sept. 6, and the 30th birthday celebration for King Mswati III.
Siew was then to have traveled north to Malawi, according to his original schedule, to take part in a cultural exchange and visit overseas Chinese living there.
Yang said the government has already explained Siew's condition to the Swazi authorities through the ROC embassy in that country, and that Swaziland understands the reason for Siew's cancellation.
He added that an ROC delegation will still visit Swaziland for its national day celebrations, and that it will include a 60-member dance troupe.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT PETROLEUM SUMMIT TO OPEN

TEXT.P: Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) President Pan Wen-yian will visit mainland China on Monday at the head of a delegation of ranking CPC officials, to take part in a petroleum summit meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

During the meeting, Pan will talk with his counterparts from three mainland companies, including the China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC), on cooperation in oil resource exploration and the CPC's push to enter the mainland market, CPC officials said on Friday.

A significant cross-strait cooperation agreement was forged on March 1, under the terms of which the CPC and the CNOOC will jointly prospect for crude oil in a 15,400 square kilometer area southeast of the Zhujiang Basin in the South China Sea.
The state-owned CPC has also spared no effort in opening overseas markets in a bid to sharpen its competitive edge in the wake of Taiwan's trade liberalization in this sector.
Mainland China is regarded as a leading potential buyer for CPC products, including liquefied petroleum gas, diesel and gasoline.
The CPC has recently shipped 2,000 kilotons of liquid petroleum gas via Hong Kong to Guangdong, in order to test the mainland market, the CPC officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS REASSURE WORRIED LIFEGUARDS OVER AIDS FEARS

TEXT.P: The chances are negligible that two local lifeguards have contracted HIV as a result of administering cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR), Doctor Hung Chien-ching of National Taiwan University Hospital said on Friday.
The two lifeguards at Shalun Beach in Tamshui, suburban Taipei, tried CPR on a man who was dragged out of the sea unconscious on Aug. 1.
They were only told after the man was rushed to the hospital, where he later died, that the 61-year-old swimmer was an AIDS patient.
The lifeguards were terrified that they may have been infected with the AIDS-causing HIV, since both men conducted mouth-to-mouth resuscitation on the man.

However, Hung, who had treated the man with a three-in-one "drug cocktail" therapy for a year, said he is almost 100 percent sure that the two lifeguards have not been infected by his former patient, as the virus in his case had been eliminated to the extent that it was undetectable.
In addition, Hung said, the lifeguards told him that they have no tooth problems and no injuries in their mouths.

Nevertheless, the doctor recommended that both men check into Mackay Memorial Hospital for thorough check-ups, including a four-week course of preventive medication therapy and a six-month follow-up monitoring period, just to make sure they are virus-free.

Liu Wu-cheh, a physician with Veterans General Hospital-Taipei, said mouth-to-mouth resuscitation is similar to kissing, and pointed out that it is virtually impossible to transmit the virus in this manner, unless the rescuers have injuries or open wounds in their mouths.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, an official with the Department of Health, urged the general public, including lifeguards, not to be panicked by the incident, and not to let groundless fears stand in the way of saving people's lives, or cause AIDS victims to be shunned.

Doctors have repeated that the AIDS virus can only be transmitted through intimate sexual contact, transfusions of untreated blood products, and injections with AIDS-contaminated needles. (Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES EXCHANGE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 58.28 points to close at 7,530.02.
The bourse opened at 7,501.27 points, 29.53 higher than Thursday's closing, and closed at 7,530.02. Dealers said the market was encouraged by a rebound on the New York Stock Exchange.
A total of 15.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$76.75 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.7 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.9 percent, both textile issues and pulp and paper stocks at 1.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 1 percent, electrical issues at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.5 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.4 percent.
Meanwhile, Taipei's stock index futures were also generally higher on Friday.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved up 53 points to close at 7,515, while those for October increased 90 points to close at 7,530. However, December futures decreased 10 points to 7,710.
The number of contract transactions for the three futures were 453, one, and six, respectively.
TAIEX Index Futures for March also decreased two points to close at 7,735, with one transaction. There were no transactions for June futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX) reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 7,462 for September; 7,440 for October; 7,720 for December; 7,737 for March; and 7,831 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FARMING POPULATION GRAYING AND SHRINKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's farm population is not only graying but also diminishing as time passes and social structures change, the Council of Agriculture (COA) reported on Friday.
According to the latest COA tallies, of the 3.7 million farmers and their dependents islandwide, 12 percent were aged 65 and above in 1997, compared with 7.93 percent in 1991.

As of the end of 1997, the number of farming households islandwide stood at 780,246, constituting about 13 percent of the entire number of households in Taiwan. The 1997 figure was 44,000 less than that recorded in 1991, said COA officials.

The number of people relying on farming for a living totaled 3,720,757 as of the end of 1997, representing 17 percent of Taiwan's entire population, down 6 percent, or 476,000, from the figure posted in 1991, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CHINESE WRITERS CONFERENCE CONCLUDES

TEXT.P: The Third World Chinese Writers Conference concluded on Friday in Taipei after five days of discussion centering on Chinese culture and literature.
A joint statement released at the end of the conference called for creation of and research into Chinese literature.

Also in the statement, nearly 200 Chinese writers from 38 countries and areas expressed their great concern over the suffering of Indonesia's ethnic Chinese population during the May riots which brought down President Suharto.

The statement urged the Indonesian authorities to investigate the atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese. The persecution, which manifested itself as beatings, ransacking, looting, rape, arson and murder, is widely said to have been carried out under an orchestrated policy of systemic racial discrimination.
The joint statement also called on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to raise relief funds for the victims and their families.

Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan attended the closing ceremony, and bestowed awards to the leaders of several sub-groups of the World Chinese Writers Association, which are spread over the whole world, in recognition of their contributions to the promotion of literary creation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar plunged NT$0.1 against the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 34.6.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.415 and had a low of 34.64.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$337 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAILED EX-TRADER LEESON HAS COLON CANCER

TEXT.P: Former British futures trader Nick Leeson, 31, who bankrupted Britain's oldest merchant bank and was jailed in Singapore in 1995 for fraud, has colon cancer, it was reported on Friday.
He is now being treated at the prison ward of the Changi General Hospital.
A Singapore Prisons Department spokesman confirmed his condition, but declined to give details.
His London lawyers, Kingsley Napley, said in a statement on Thursday that the cancer has already spread to his lymph nodes.
The Prisons Department spokesman declined to comment on how the illness will affect Leeson's jail term, or on whether he will be transferred to a British jail.
Leeson was sentenced to six-and-a-half years in jail in December 1995, after pleading guilty to fraud.
As the general manager of Baring Futures (Singapore), he chalked up trading losses amounting to S$1.8 billion, leading to the collapse of Barings, the oldest merchant bank in Britain.
He fled Singapore with his wife, Lisa, but was found in Germany and brought back to Singapore to stand trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TRADE DECLINE CONTINUED IN JULY: MOF

TEXT.P: Taiwan's imports and exports in July 1998 declined 22.1 percent and 16.3 percent, respectively, compared with the same period of last year, according to statistics issued on Friday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

Taiwan's total import value in July amounted to US$7.9 billion, while export value amounted to US$8.96 billion. The plunge in imports and exports compared with the same period of 1997 is a record slide since July 1982 and July 1976, respectively, the statistics show.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF Department of Statistics, pointed out that July's export decline resulted from a 34 percent decrease in exports to Japan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states, as well as a 23.2 percent drop in exports to Hong Kong.
The fall in imports was primarily due to a sharp downturn in the amount of goods imported from the US, Japan, Europe and the ASEAN region, said Hsu.

He further said that a recovery in Taiwan's exports to other Asian nations depends on the recovery of Japan's economy and on whether the economies of the nations of Southeast Asia can be stabilized. Hsu added that he is afraid Taiwan's exports will not rise before the fourth quarter of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENTIAL SPECIAL ENVOY TO VISIT PARAGUAY

TEXT.P: The special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui, Secretary-General to the President Huang Kun-huei, will head a delegation which is to attend the inauguration of President-elect Raul Cubas Grau of the Republic of Paraguay.

Director of the Central and South American Affairs Department Francisco L.Y. Hwang said on Friday that Huang, who will also be accompanied by Foreign Minister Jason Hu, will leave Taipei on Aug. 11 and arrive in Asuncion, Paraguay's capital, on Aug. 13.
During their stay in Asuncion, Huang and Hu will both be decorated by the Paraguayan government in recognition of their contributions to the promotion of ROC-Paraguayan relations, Hwang said.
Prior to attending Grau's inauguration on Aug. 15, the delegation will also pay a courtesy call on President Juan Carlos Wasmosy on Aug. 14 to present their credentials.

Members of the delegation will meet with overseas Chinese leaders in Paraguay, personnel of the ROC Embassy in Asuncion, and members of an ROC Agricultural Technical Mission stationed in the South American country.
They will return to Taipei on Aug. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE KUAN YEW MEMOIRS TO BE LAUNCHED ON SEPT. 16

TEXT.P: The first volume of Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew's memoirs will be launched on Sept. 16, coinciding with his 75th birthday.
Titled "The Singapore Story: Memoirs of Lee Kuan Yew", the book will be published in two volumes, in both English and Chinese versions.
The memoirs draw on previously unpublished government papers and archival materials from Britain and Singapore, as well as Lee's personal correspondence.
The first 680-page volume details his early years, his student days in Cambridge, his entry into politics, and his battles against the colonialists, communists and communalists.

The second volume, which is expected to be published next year, will pick up the narrative from 1965 to the present. It describes vividly the post-independence years and the challenges Lee and his colleagues encountered in building Singapore's education, defense, economy and infrastructure.

Lee's memoirs have received strong endorsements from world leaders such as former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and former US President George Bush, who were sent extracts of the early proofs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODERN FATHERS MOST CONCERNED ABOUT KIDS: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of local fathers say that the family is the institution they most treasure, according to an opinion survey released on Friday.
The survey of 460 married men residing throughout the island was conducted by the Women's Rights Promotion Foundation late last month to mark this year's Father's Day, which falls on Saturday.
The survey results show that 80 percent of the respondents chose "a happy family" as their top priority, while only 17 percent said career achievements are more important to them.

Within the family, local fathers are most concerned about their children, their wives, and their parents, in that order, although the majority of those surveyed said they owe the most to their parents.
Asked what would make them feel happiest and most fortunate, 61 percent cited a happy marriage; 33 percent mentioned their children's achievements; and about 20 percent cited the amassing of wealth.
Thirty-five percent said they feel miserable if their wives make frequent complaints, while 28.7 percent said the most depressing thing is when children fail to study hard or behave themselves.

About 54 percent said they can happily accept the fact that their wife is a strong woman; 17.8 percent said such a thing would be unthinkable; 14.8 percent said they would feel threatened; and 7 percent said they would be unable to accept it.
While 62 percent said they do not mind if their wives outpace them in terms of career, 20 percent said they would feel embarrassed, and 6 percent said they would feel ashamed.

On their expectations for their children, 67 percent said they hope all of their children will receive higher education; 8.3 percent said they hope their sons will receive higher education, but do not mind whether their daughters receive higher education or not.

Meanwhile, 30 percent of the respondents said they hope all of their children will excel in their studies and their careers, while 66.5 percent said they will take delight in seeing their children pursue their own life goals. However, 1.3 percent said they want to see their sons succeed in their careers, while not minding whether their daughters do or not.

Professor Tseng Hua-yuan of Tunghai University said the poll results show that local fathers have high expectations for their children and that some of them still hold the traditional concept that males should take precedence over females.
Lai Kuo-chou, director of the ruling Kuomintang's Youth Affairs Department, said developing close relationships with their children is a great challenge for modern fathers.
"Fathers should never hesitate to express their love for their children," Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHAIRMAN VISTING VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Chairman P.K. Chiang of the Council for Economic Planning and Development on Friday left for Vietnam for a five-day visit.
At the invitation of the Jin Wen Institute of Technology, Chiang will attend a ground-breaking ceremony for a cultural and trade center in Ho Chi Minh City.
During his visit, Chiang will also meet with several Vietnamese financial and economics officials.
Chiang is scheduled to fly back to Taiwan on Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS TO PETITION FOR ABOLITION OF LABOR CAMPS

TEXT.P: Nine mainland Chinese dissidents in Shanghai Wednesday boldly asked the Public Security Bureau of the city for permission to collect signitures on a petition for the abolition of the "reeducation through labor camps" system.

In their application filed with the bureau, the nine dissidents asked permission to set up tables at three public locations in the city for collecting 10,000 signitures on the petition, according to a press release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China.
The information said the application has not been approved by the bureau.
The dissidents expressed the hope that their application will be approved, because it is one of the basic rights of the people to collect signitures for petition at designated public locations.

They said in the application that the system, under which public security authorities can throw people into the labor camps for up to three years without trial, is in gross violation of the Constitution. "This authoritarian system must be abolished," they said.

Mainland Chinese public security authorities often send dissidents to the camps for muzzling them. Of the nine dissidents, Han Lifa, Yao Zhenxian, Li Guotao, and Dai Xuezhong have been "reeducated" in the labor camps. The other five are Cai Guihua, Ma Wei, Zhou Jianhe, Zhang Rujun, and Zhang Hualin.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF FIVE DIE IN BLAST

TEXT.P: A family of five, including three children, have been killed in a fire in central Taiwan's Taichung County, police said on Friday.
Police said that the blaze broke out at 4:30 a.m. on Friday in Taipin township. Although it was contained within half an hour, the house owner and his family were unable to escape the inferno.

The bodies of Wu Hsu-feng, 31, his wife Liu Ming-fen, 30, and their sons aged three, four, and five years of age, were found in a bathroom on the third floor. All five died of smoke inhalation, police said.
The first and second floors of the building had been used as a machine plating factory, while Wu and his family lived on the third floor. Wu had been running the factory for about a year.

The building was constructed from corrugated alloy sheeting and had iron-barred windows, which allowed extremely high temperatures to build up when the fire broke out, making the chances of survival very slim, police said.
An initial investigation by police showed that a short circuit might have sparked the blaze.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF INDONESIAN CHINESE YOUTH STUDYING IN TAIWAN INCREASES

TEXT.P: The recent rioting targeted at ethnic Chinese in Indonesia has prompted many Chinese youths to travel to Taiwan to continue their education, a China Times Express report said Friday.

Chang Pi-chuang, principal of the Overseas Chinese High School, said 102 of over 300 of the school's students are Indonesian Chinese. She added that the number of Indonesian Chinese students studying in Taiwan is steadily increasing after a series of political and economic problems struck the Southeast Asian country.

Pang Yi-chien, director of the school's Chinese language center, said more than 50 ethnic Chinese students from Indonesia have enrolled at the school since January when rioting and looting targeted at ethnic Chinese first began. An additional 30 Chinese students from Indonesia have applied to study at the school since July, Pang was cited as saying.

The number of Chinese female students from Indonesia who have applied to study at the school has noticeably increased after the May rioting, according to the paper. Of the 15 ethnic Chinese students who have arrived in Taiwan last month, 12 were female.

Since the Indonesian government has not yet apprehended those who took part in the May rioting and looting, some Indonesian Chinese students who are now studying in Taiwan said they do not plan to return to Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US HOLD SUB-CABINET-LEVEL MEETING IN D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A sub-Cabinet-level meeting between the Republic of China and the United States will be held in Washington, D.C. on Friday to discuss trade, finance and other matters of mutual concern.

Both sides have attached great importance to the meeting because it take places in the wake of an Asia financial crisis and a summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing on June 27.

The ROC delegation, headed by Vice Economics MInister Lin Yi-fe, arrived here on Wednesday. The delegation includes officials from the the ministries of Economic Affairs and Finance, as well as from the Council of Economic Planning and Development, the Council of Agriculture and the Central Bank of China.

US Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers will lead the American mission, which will comprise officials from the State Department, the US Trade Representative office, the Federal Reserve (Fed), the Customs Service and other related agencies.

High on the agenda will be trade and investment, financial liberalization and the prevention of financial crimes. The two sides will also review technical problems arising from the enforcement of some bilateral cooperative agreements, including a customs services cooperative pact.
Vice Economics Minister Lin said the two sides will take advantage of the meeting to discuss some remaining issues concerning terms for Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Taipei and Washington already finalized bilateral WTO talks and initialed an accord early this year. But the two sides have yet to complete checks on tariff rates for seven fishery and industrial products.
"There are some differences between our meeting records. As a result, we need to mend our differences over tariff rates for the seven items," Lin said.
If the two sides can resolve the tariff rate issues, Lin said, a fomral agreement on terms for Taiwan's WTO entry will be signed at the sub-Cabinet-level meeting.
Lin paid a courtesy call on US Deputy Trade Representative Richard Fisher on Thursday.

During the meeting, Fisher told Lin that some American firms have asked the Clinton administration to place Taiwan in an annual special 301 "blacklist" again for its alleged failure to fully protect intellectual property rights.
Lin said he briefed Fisher on Taiwan's recent achievements in IPR protection and crackdown on commercial piracy.

The first ROC-US sub-Cabinet-level meeting was held in Washington, D.C. on June 22, 1995, and the second such meeting took place in Taipei on Sept. 16, 1997. The third meeting was originally scheduled for 1997, but was later postponed to this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO ATTEND APEC MEETING IN KUALA LUMPUR

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will head a Taiwan delegation to attend the fifth Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Small and Medium Enterprises ministerial meeting in Kuala Lumpur from Sept. 7 to 8.
A preparatory meeting was held at the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Friday to discuss details of the APEC gathering.

Minister Wang said he will leave for Kuala Lumpur on Sept. 3 to attend an economic and trade consultation with Malaysian representatives prior to the APEC meeting. He will also host a seminar to listen to views from Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia.

According to Wang, Taiwan's relative stable economic performance during Asia's financial turmoil has drawn the attention of other APEC members. He added that he plans to exchange views with other APEC representatives on the region's economic situation.

In addition to human resource development, marketing, technology, financing, and information gathering, topics to be discussed at the SME ministerial meeting will include a SME five-year action plan, SME financial stability, and electronic commerce.
Taiwan will also hold bilateral talks with various APEC member representatives to promote economic and trade cooperation as well as SME exchanges.
Wang and his delegation are scheduled to return to Taipei on Sept. 9.

Formed in 1989, APEC members currently include Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States. Russia, Vietnam and Peru are set to join in November.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZED CRIME YIELDS HUGE ILLEGAL PROFITS: SOUTH AFRICAN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Organized crime earned about 9.3 trillion rand (approximately US$1.5 trillion) globally last year, or 4 percent of the world's economy, South African Safety and Security Minister Sydney Mufamadi said.
He said in Cape Town Thursday that profit from the illegal drug trade alone was larger than the GDP of the whole of Africa.
Mufamadi said since the advent of democracy in South Africa, there has been rapid growth in cross-border trade and transportation, providing increased cover for organized crime syndicates.

As of June 10 this year, 22 foreign citizens have been arrested in South Africa for drug trafficking, while a total of 110 South Africans were jailed in Latin American countries, Asia and Europe on similar charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR IMPROVED ROC-JAPAN TIES

TEXT.P: A ranking Democratic Progressive Party official said Taipei should actively pursue improved ties with Tokyo following reports that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is slated to visit Japan in September.

Yen Wen-chin, director of the DPP's Mainland China Affairs Department, said Jiang's planned trip is not expected to affect the current relationship between Taiwan and Japan, but Taiwan should take measures to enhance bilateral ties similar to its dealings with the United States after Washington showed signs of increasing its engagement with Beijing.
Yen expressed concern over the visit's possible long-term impact on Taiwan due to increased difficulties for the island to take part in the international arena.

In the face of a possible strategic partnership between Japan and mainland China, Taiwan should make greater effort to improve its ties with Japan, which has exhibited a strong fear of the Chinese communists, Yen said.

Mainland China will play a more important role in the Asia-Pacific region and the world's strategic deployment amid its efforts to expand its relations in the international community, Yen explained, warning that Taiwan may face the danger of being excluded from international affairs in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI FOREIGN CURRENCY RISE HIGHLIGHTS FEARS OF DEVALUATION

TEXT.P: Foreign currency deposits held by individuals in Shanghai have risen markedly in the first half of this year, demonstrating concern among mainland China's public that mainland China might have to devalue its currency.
