The value of these deposits in mainland China's largest city reached US$5.3 billion as of the end of June, up 13.2 percent -- about US$700 million -- since the beginning of this year, according to a report in the Financial Times.
Beijing has pledged to hold the renminbi steady in the interests of restoring financial stability to Asia.

However, mainland China's decelerating economy, the sharp decline in export growth in the first half of this year, and the weakening Japanese yen, have raised questions about how long the mainland Chinese government will stick to its no-devaluation pledge.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR SUSPECTS IN LIN MURDER CASE ARRESTED

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese Ministry of Public Security confirmed on Friday that four suspects in the kidnap and murder of Taiwan's Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan have been arrested.
The four were identified as Huang Shidong, Zhang Shifeng, Yang Rongxi and Zhao Chuang. Another suspect Li Guangzhi is still at large.

The mainland's Xinhua News Agency quoted the ministry as saying Huang was captured in northeastern China's Heilongjiang Province Tuesday afternoon, Zhang was apprehended on board a train bound for Shanghai from Yantai, Shandong Province, Thursday morning, Yang was arrested in Dalian, Liaoning Province, Thursday afternoon, and Zhao gave himself up to police in Haicheng, Liaoning Province, Thursday afternoon.

Li Guangzhi, a manager at Dazhi trading company, is believed to have been behind the plan to kidnap Lin and her boyfriend Wei Tien-kang. Huang, Zhang, Yang and Zhao are suspected of having committed the kidnapping.

In order to force Taiwan businessman Wei to repay merchandise money, Li instructed the four men to kidnap Wei and Lin when they arrived in Dalian on July 27. The two were brought to a vacant house in Haicheng City, in the province's southwestern region.
Wei and Lin were injected with an unknown drug which may have been heroin by one of the four kidnappers, and then fell unconscious.

Lin reportedly experienced difficulty in breathing and her face turned pale on the morning of July 29. She was rushed to a Haicheng hospital and was declared dead on arrival. The four criminal suspects then fled.
Wei regained consciousness while being held at the house and escaped to notify local public security authorities of the kidnapping.
Mainland Chinese public security authorities are continuing their search for Li.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW PAYS VISIT TO PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday paid a courtesy call on both President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan to express his appreciation for their concern during his hospitalization.

Siew, who has suffered from an enlarged prostate for the last six years, underwent surgery at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei last Thursday. He returned to work on Thursday, but at the advice of his doctor, no visits were scheduled at his office.
However, the premier went directly from the hospital to the Presidential Office this morning. Sources said the three spoke briefly.
At a time when the government is facing several problematic issues, whether Lee, Lien and Siew touched upon these areas has drawn public attention.

Issues of concern include the kidnap and murder of Democratic Progressive Party Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan in the mainland, the fall visit of Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu to the mainland, National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih's recent visit to the United States, Beijing and Japan are expected to establish a long-term strategic relationship, and the restructuring of the Taiwan Provincial government is facing difficulties.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S LONGEST KITE TO FLY OVER HSINCHU SKIES

TEXT.P: An attempt to break the world's record for the longest kite flown will take place in Taiwan's northern city of Hsinchu this weekend as a part of the city's efforts to make history.
The "super kite," measuring 1,003 meters in length and composed of 700 smaller kites, is slated to take to the skies on Saturday, the closing day of Hsinchu's Folk Culture Day.
Chang Fu-cheng, chairman of Hsinchu's Acrobatic Kite Association and owner of the super kite, said he is confident his kite will smoothly fly if weather permits.
If the wind speed and direction are suitable on Saturday, Chang said his kite will challenge the current world record set by a 1,000 meter-long kite.

Chang, a kite aficionado, said the aim of his attempt is to leave something memorable to Hsinchu, which has had a long relationship with kites. The city, about 80 kilometers south of Taipei, has been described as a "windy city" as breezes frequently pass through the city.
On Saturday, more than 200 kite fliers from across the island will exhibit a wide variety of kites, including several specially-designed kites which have won international prizes.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR WELCOMES KAOHSIUNG PORT DECISION

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yi on Friday welcomed an Executive Yuan decision to put the Kaohsiung port under the city's jurisdiction.

Wu made the remark prior to leaving for Brisbane, Australia. However, he said he did not see the related document and was not sure if the approved version of the proposal was the same as the one he supported.

The mayor said he was glad to see that years of effort in pushing for a combination of a port and city authority have been fruitful. When Wu ran for office four years ago, the combination issue was among the campaign promises he made to supporters.
The news that Premier Vincent Siew approved the project to include Kaohsiung port under Kaohsiung City was announced by government spokesman Cheng Chien-jen earlier in the day.

According to Cheng, the Kaohsiung port administration will be defined as an independent agency, whose supervisor is commissioned to the Kaohsiung government by the Ministry of Communications and Transportation. The operations of the port should be in line with the MOCT's relevant regulations.

Asked if the approval will help him boost his chances in seeking reelection, Wu replied that he raised the issue some eight years ago when he came to Kaohsiung as an appointed mayor. The decision had nothing to do with the reelection, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS MUM ON SEF REQUEST FOR INFORMATION ON DETAINED BUSINESSMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei is waiting for a reply from mainland Chinese authorities regarding the detainment of a Taiwan businessman, the Straits Exchange Foundation said Friday.

The SEF, a semi-official intermediary body formed to handle cross-strait affairs in absence of official contacts, said it sent a letter to its mainland counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits on July 22. The letter requested ARATS to check on information regarding Hsu Chai-hsin who reportedly has been in detention for nearly one year.
SEF Vice Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing said they have yet to receive a reply from ARATS regarding this matter.
The letter was written in response to a petition from Hsu's family on July 21, Wu said.

According to the petition, Hsu invested US$10 million toward the establishment of a golf club in the mainland five years ago. On July 31, 1997 Hsu was arrested in Beijing and was charged with bribery. During his detention, Hsu has not been allowed to meet with his family and was forced to transfer the property rights of the golf club.
In its letter to the ARATS, the SEF urged the mainland to coordinate with the relevant authorities to find out the facts of the case and make sure Hsu's rights are upheld.

Wu also called on authorities to ensure the personal safety and protection of property of Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland, adding that the SEF and the ARATS should cooperate to establish systematic channels to deal with such issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKS TO MODIFY AVIATION PACTS WITH PHILIPPINES, THAILAND

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced Friday that it will seek to modify bilateral aviation agreements with the Philippines and Thailand in the near future.

Acting CAA Director-General Chang Chia-chu said the CAA will dispatch officials to negotiate modifications with the Philippines in the current bilateral aviation agreement in a trade ministers' meeting slated for mid-August.
The CAA is expected to discuss the opening of a Taiwan-Subic Bay route for cargo planes with the Philippine.
Negotiations in ROC-Thailand aviation talks, tentatively scheduled for late August, will focus on an increase of two-way flight services due to a demand from both countries, according to the CAA.

China Airlines and EVA Airways Corporation, Taiwan's two largest carriers, have expressed hope that their Europe-bound planes can directly proceed to European cities via Bangkok without passing through countries in the Middle East.
Chang said the CAA has targeted several countries for similar talks, including Palau, Singapore, Germany, and Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN WANTS ADDED NUMBER OF FLIGHTS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Japanese air carrier is to ask for Taiwan's consent to add flights from Japan to Taiwan to meet ever-increasing demand, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said on Saturday.

In an upcoming bilateral aviation consultation, Japan Asia Airways (JAA) will request that 40 charter flights be added to its annual number of flights to Taiwan, the first time that Japan has made such a request.

An unofficial request was made recently by Japan's Ministry of Transport to Taipei through the Interchange Association, which represents Japan's interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, CAA officials said.
In past years, only Taiwan has asked for increases in the number of flights from Taiwan to Japan, and Japan has usually taken two to three years to give its agreement.
The CAA has already agreed in principle to JAA's request, and in the meantime, will ask for a corresponding increase in the number of Taiwan flights to Japan, the officials said.
If the two sides reach consensus on the issue, the annual number of Taiwan's charter flights to Japan will be increased from the current 700 to 740, the officials noted.
They further said the CAA will also enter a series of aviation talks with other Asian countries and areas in the near future.

In talks tentatively scheduled for late August, the CAA will ask Thailand to upgrade its aviation accord signing body from private to official level, and will ask for additional flights, as well as an increase in the number of destination points, said CAA acting Director-General Chang Chia-chu.
In negotiations with the Philippines, also expected to be held in late August, the CAA will discuss the opening of all-cargo flights between Taiwan and the Philippines, Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE WILLING TO FIGHT FOR HOMELAND: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people are willing to fight for their homeland should mainland China invade the island, according to the results of a public opinion poll released on Saturday.

The telephone poll of 1,149 adults residing throughout the island, conducted by the Chinese Euro-Asia Society, also found that even though mainland China refuses to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, most local people do not believe that war will really break out between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Asked if they think there may be a cross-strait military confrontation in the future, 61.2 percent answered either "unlikely" or "very unlikely," while only 3.6 percent responded "very likely," and 22.8 percent said "likely."
Meanwhile, the survey found that 87.7 percent said they will stand up to fight for Taiwan if the mainland attacks the island, while 6.8 percent said they will not.

Analyzing the survey results, Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said the high percentage of local people willing to defend their homeland is worthy of attention.
Wu Hsin-hsing, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said the poll results indicate that Taiwan people have high expectations for peace across the Taiwan Strait.
"Nevertheless, the survey findings also manifest the determination of the people of Taiwan to fight against communist invasion," Wu stressed.
The same survey further found that 67 percent of the respondents do not think that allowing local youths to study in mainland China is an important issue.

Commenting on this finding, Lin said it indicates that the government need not take bold steps to recognize academic degrees conferred by mainland universities or colleges at the moment. "The government should instead exercise prudence in tackling the issue and adopt a gradual manner in accrediting mainland degrees."
Asked if they think mainland-educated Taiwan students are likely to become pro-Beijing, 42.6 percent answered in the affirmative, 30.4 percent said no, and 18.5 percent said they did not know.

According to the poll, 64 percent said they believe that President Lee Teng-hui has a strong determination to protect Taiwan's security; while 66.8 percent said they are convinced that Lee has a firm determination to defend the Republic of China's national dignity.
The poll also found that nearly 70 percent support the government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China.

Under the policy, the government bans investment in mainland China's high-tech industries and infrastructure projects, and requires that each mainland investment project should not exceed US$50 million.

While 70 percent gave a thumbs-up to the government's regulation that each mainland investment project should not exceed US$50 million; 66 percent threw support behind the government's ban on investment in mainland China's high-tech industries; and 54 percent said they support the current ban on investment in mainland China's infrastructure construction projects, such as highways, railways and power plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US SIGN WTO PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China signed a formal agreement with the United States Friday on the terms for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization.
The agreement was signed here by ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and US Assistant Trade Representative Robert Cassidy on behalf of their respective governments.
The accord marked a huge step forward in the ROC's bid to join the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.

US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky issued a statement expressing her delight at the conclusion of the accord with the ROC. The United States will soon pass the document on to the WTO Secretariat for reference, she said.

Barshefsky added that the United States will continue discussing several trade issues with Taiwan through multilateral WTO consultation channels, including Taiwan's farm subsidies and import procedures for agricultural products.

Taiwan and the United States finalized bilateral WTO talks in February. After several months of examining the meeting minutes, the two sides finally came to terms on tariff rates for more than 8,000 agricultural and industrial products.

Sources close to the ROC delegation said Taiwan made minor concessions on tariff rates for four fishery products and three industrial items at the last minute to smooth the way for a final agreement. The sources, however, would not elaborate on the details.

According to the agreement, Taiwan will largely cut tariff rates on a number of American agricultural and industrial products in addition to opening its telecommunications and financial service markets.
Taiwan also promised to sign the WTO-sponsored multilateral government procurement and civil aviation aircraft agreements immediately after its WTO accession.
To date, Taiwan has sealed bilateral agreements with 23 of the 26 WTO contracting parties which had expressed the desire to hold talks with the island on its WTO accession terms.
Taiwan has also completed bilateral consultations with the 15-member European Union, Canada and Hong Kong, but the three economies have yet to sign formal accords with the ROC.

Hong Kong reportedly has assured ROC economics officials that it will not be the last to seal a bilateral WTO pact with Taiwan. The biggest obstacle may lie in negotiations with Canada, ROC sources said.
Canada has asked the ROC to offer it the same "down payment" that Taipei offered to the United States. The request has been denied, the sources said.
The "down payment" refers to Taiwan's consent to imports of 5,000 tons of pork offal, 10,000 tons of chicken meat and 12,500 tons of animal intestines from the United States before its WTO accession.

The ROC's representative office in Geneva just concluded another round of talks with the WTO working party responsible for screening Taiwan's membership application. The consultations focused on farm trade and subsidy issues. A similar multilateral meeting will also be held in October to speed up Taiwan's WTO entry.
ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said earlier this year that Taiwan expects to be formally admitted to the WTO in the second half of next year.

Taiwan applied to join the WTO's precursor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, in 1990 as an independent customs terriotry, while Beijing filed its application in 1986. Although Taiwan is ahead of mainland China in membership talks, it remains unclear whether Taiwan can enter the WTO ahead of Beijing. Both Taipei and Beijing are now WTO observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND FACE DIFFICULTY: THE ECONOMIST
DOC.DATELINE: London, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The murder of a Taiwan city councilor in mainland China last week has highlighted the difficult situation Taiwan businessmen in the mainland face, the latest issue of The Economist reported.
The weekly magazine said mainland China is one of the most dangerous places in the world to do business.

Taiwan businessmen, like other foreign nationals, face problems with bureaucracy, losses and adjustment difficulties, but unlike others, they have also had to deal with being assaulted, kidnapped and murdered, the article said.

Citing figures from Taiwan's intermediary body, the Straits Exchange Foundation, The Economist said 59 businessmen from Taiwan have been reported missing or murdered in the past seven years. During the same period, 127 Taiwan nationals have been kidnapped, robbed or detained after encountering business disputes.
The figures may be even higher as many victims choose not to report crimes committed against them to hide their investments in an effort to evade taxes, the article said.

Taiwan businessmen have become a prominent target because of their large number. There are an estimated 200,000 Taiwan businessmen in the mainland at any time. The political rivalry across the Taiwan Strait has also made them more vulnerable.

However, The Economist noted that the behavior of some Taiwan businessmen in the mainland may also contribute to the problem. Some Taiwan businessmen, taking advantage of common language and cultural background, have ventured to inland provinces of the mainland to operate businesses which can cause trouble. Also, those who like to show off their wealth can attract resentment and make them easy targets for crime.
The article said despite the risks, Taiwan businessmen continue to seek opportunities in the mainland because of the perceived business potential and the need for cheap labor.
Some major Taiwan enterprises in the mainland have formed groups to protect themselves against such criminal acts, the article said.
There are reportedly 43 such groups. Because they employ a large number of people, these groups have become a local business council or an unofficial consulate because of its influence locally.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE IN US PROTEST AGAINST ATROCITIES IN INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Jay Chen, H.C. Huang, and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Chinese people throughout the United States protested on Friday against atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese by Indonesian rioters in May.

Hundreds of demonstrators massed in front of the Indonesian Embassy in Washington, D.C., where they held placards and shouted slogans to express their anger over the attacks against Chinese people during May's political upheaval in Indonesia.
They urged the Indonesian government to ensure the personal safety of ethnic Chinese living in the Southeast Asian country and bring to justice those responsible for the brutal attacks.
The protesters, including a large number of Chinese students, came from as far away as Cincinnati, Ohio, a 10-hour drive from Washington.
An estimated 1,200 ethnic Chinese people were killed and more than a hundred ethnic Chinese women were raped during the chaotic period in Indonesia which eventually toppled President Suharto.

One of the organizers of the event, Lee Hsing-kuo, called on Chinese people around the world to stand firm behind their compatriots in Indonesia, saying such horrific events could also occur in Australia, Canada, and other countries.
Lee, chairman of the Association of Chinese Students and Scholars at Cincinnati University, said that Friday's demonstration was part of a series of protest activities against Indonesian government.

He said that the organizers will present petitions to the US Congress and the Clinton Administration, asking them to help press Indonesia to honor its promise that a thorough investigation into the May rioting will uncover the truth, and that all those who committed the atrocities will be severely punished.

The Indonesian government should guarantee that this kind of horror against ethnic Chinese should never happen again, Lee said, adding that when international organizations such as the International Monetary Fund provides financial aid to Indonesia, it should set a condition that the Southeast Asian country improve its human rights record.

The largest protest against Indonesia in the United States was staged in New York, attracting more than three thousand people. Chanting "Shame on You," the protesters condemned the Indonesian government for standing by and watching the rioters attack ethnic Chinese and rape ethnic Chinese women.

They demanded the Indonesian government uncover the truth about the rioting, bring to justice all those who committed or masterminded the atrocities, provide compensation for losses sustained by ethnic Chinese, offer medical treatment to the injured, compensate the families of the deceased and institute legislation to protect the lives and property of the ethnic Chinese living there.
Two representatives of the protesters sent a written protest to the Indonesian Consulate General in New York, which was accepted by one of its officials.

The protest was initiated by New York-based Association of Chinese People Protesting Atrocities in Indonesia. During the two-hour demonstration, the organizers announced a declaration, calling on the United Nations and the governments around the world to impose an economic sanction on Indonesia as part of efforts to press the country to work hard to uncover the truth about the rioting and to bring the rioters to justice.
Liu Kuo-kai, an official with the association, said that the protest was aimed at safeguarding the dignity and rights of Chinese people.
Liu said that next week, they will present a name list containing over 10,000 signatures to the United Nations. The signatures were collected during a campaign last month.
Similar protests also took place in Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles, and San Francisco, as well as in the Canadian cities of Toronto and Vancouver.
In Los Angeles, the protest was attended by nearly 3,000 people. They peacefully expressed concern to what the ethnic Chinese have suffered during the chaos in May.

In a written protest to the Indonesian Consulate General, they demanded that the Indonesian government apologize to Chinese Indonesians, provide compensation for losses sustained by ethnic Chinese, set up a committee to investigate into the rioting, and make sure such horrific events will not happen again.
Organizers of the event said that if the Indonesian government failed to respond to their requests, they do not exclude the possibilities of staging another protest on Aug. 17.
On Saturday, Washington, D.C., and Boston will be the scenes of similar protests against Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODY OF COUNCILWOMAN RETURNED TO KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The body of murdered Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan was flown back to her southern Taiwan hometown via Hong Kong at around 4:50 p.m. on Saturday.
The return of Lin's body signals a tentative wrapping up of an episode which is seen as having clouded cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

Lin, 32, a member of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was killed accidentally by an overdose of drugs administered during a botched kidnap in the northeastern mainland Chinese city of Haicheng late last month.
Lin's body was flown to Hong Kong at around 11 a.m. from Beijing, where the hearse carrying her body from Haicheng arrived on Thursday.
Taiwan's top representative in Hong Kong, Cheng An-kuo, met the flight when it arrived in Hong Kong, where he expressed his condolences to Lin's family.

A DPP delegation, including eight female DPP lawmakers, flew to Hong Kong from Taiwan on Saturday morning to beef up the procession ushering Lin's body back to Taiwan. Three officials from the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) also traveled to Hong Kong to offer their help to deal with the aftermath of the incident.
Lin's parents, brother and several of her DPP colleagues held a joint press conference in Hong Kong on Saturday afternoon prior to their departure for Kaohsiung.

In Kaohsiung, trees along the route between the airport and her office were decorated with yellow ribbons to show sadness and remembrance. A short memorial service was held at the airport, while formal funeral rites will be conducted at her office, according to DPP sources in Kaohsiung.

Lin and her boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, were abducted by five mainland Chinese men in Dalian City upon their arrival in the northeastern city on July 27. It was Lin's first visit to mainland China. Wei, a Kaohsiung businessman who runs an import-export business, travels frequently across the Taiwan Strait.

According to mainland Chinese authorities, four of the five suspected kidnappers had been apprehended as of Friday. The fifth, Li Guangzhi, who is said to have been the mastermind behind the kidnapping, is still at large.

The arrested suspects said that Li ordered Wei's kidnapping to force him to repay a debt he owed to Li. The two victims were abducted by the four men, taken about 200 kilometers north to Haicheng City, and hidden in an empty apartment.

Wei and Lin were injected with an unknown drug which may have been heroin, and fell into on-and-off unconsciousness. Lin later reportedly experienced difficulty breathing and turned pale on July 29. She was rushed to a Haicheng hospital, where she was declared dead on arrival. The four suspects then fled.
Wei regained consciousness during their absence and managed to escape and notify local public security authorities of the kidnapping.

Since news of the incident broke, authorities in Taiwan, including officials from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the SEF, were barred from joining the rescue effort or negotiating on behalf of Lin's family.

In addition to Lin's family and her DPP colleagues, the Beijing authorities allowed only one local forensic expert, Dr. Chen Yao-chang of National Taiwan University Hospital, to travel to the mainland. He took part in an autopsy carried out to determine the cause of Lin's death.
One of the rising stars of the DPP, Lin made her debut in politics at the age of 28. A political maverick, Lin was dubbed "the little chili" for her spicy interpellation style.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL SPEAKS ON ROC'S PROSPECTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 7 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Affected by the financial crisis in Southeast Asia, Taiwan's economic growth has slowed down and its exports recorded negative growth, a high-ranking economics official said Friday.

Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said the government has decided to stimulate domestic demand and promote investment to attain the goal of 5.5 percent growth rate this year.
Schive was reporting on the economic prospects in the Republic of China during a sub-Cabinet-level meeting between the ROC and the US Friday.
He used the short-term "growth recession" to describe the ROC's present economic situation.

Schive said that among economies on both sides of the Pacific, the US thinks that economically, the US, Taiwan and the mainland have fared well this year. But he said the US has adjusted upward its prediction of economic growth twice, while Taiwan has revised downward its prediction.

Hit by the financial crisis in Southeast Asia, Taiwan's economic growth in the first quarter this year has slowed down to 5.9 percent from 6.86 percent in the whole year in 1997, the vice chairman said.
Meanwhile, the misery index, which takes into consideration the unemployment and inflation rates, has risen to 4.3 percent in Taiwan, far higher than the 3.1 percent in Singapore.

The export of commodities in the first half this year declined by 7.1 percent, while imports declined by 3.5 percent. In terms of the New Taiwan dollar, it amounts to zero growth in Taiwan's exports in the first half of this year.

Schive noted that Taiwan's strong economic performance last year did not come from the exports, but was triggered by private investment as high as 15.6 percent. Private investment in the first quarter of this year rose by 42.8 percent. The government is estimating that private investment this year could reach a growth rate of 20 percent.

He said the ROC government has announced substantial economic stimulus packages in the hope that the private sector will increase participation in public construction projects to achieve an economic growth rate of 5.5 percent this year.

US officials were optimistic about Taiwan's plans to expand domestic demand. They said in a statement that maintaining a sound economic policy in Taiwan and promoting a stable Taiwan currency is in the best interests of the island as well as the whole Asian region.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL MEETS TOP MAINLAND NEGOTIATOR WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan said Saturday he looks forward to meeting C. F. Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, in Shanghai this fall.

Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, made the statement in a meeting with Chang Jung-kung, director of Taiwan's Mainland Research Department under the ruling Kuomintang.
Wang told Chang that Koo is welcome to visit mainland China this fall and added, "We'll arrange his itinerary in accordance to his wish."
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in April 1993 to lay the framework for regular contact and dialogue between the two organizations.

The second Koo-Wang meeting was originally scheduled for the autumn of 1995, but Beijing unilaterally suspended the meeting and cut off all regular SEF-ARATS dialogue shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui visited the United States in June 1995. Beijing regarded Lee's visit as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

After over three years at an impasse, the two sides have gradually resumed contact this year, and SEF Chairman Koo is scheduled to travel to the mainland to meet Wang either in September or in October. The two sides, however, have yet to finalize an agenda for the planned Koo-Wang meeting.
Wang also exchanged views with Chang on relations across the Taiwan Strait. Chang said he hopes the two sides will pool their wisdom to break the deadlock and forge rapprochement for mutual benefit.
Chang arrived in Shanghai Friday evening after attending a seminar on cross-strait affairs in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO HONOR CONCESSION COMMITMENTS TO US FOR WTO BID

TEXT.P: Taiwan will begin honoring its commitments to further open its agricultural and industrial markets to the US after the signing of a formal US-Taiwan agreement on terms for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization Saturday.

Taiwan and the United States forged a formal WTO agreement in Washington, formally wrapping up years of bilateral negotiations which were loosely completed in February this year with only minor details not tackled.

According to the agreement, Taiwan will allow the import of US-made automobiles to a tune of 160,000 during the first year of Taiwan's accession to the WTO. That figure is approximately 32 percent of the island's entire automobile market.
Previously, Taiwan agreed that the US-made cars will enter the island at an import tariff rate of 20 percent upon Taiwan's WTO accession, 10 percent lower than the current average.

But according to the WTO principle of the most-favored-nation treatment, the 20 percent commitment to the US may be further slashed to 17.5 percent since Taiwan has agreed to lower import tariffs on European cars to 17.5 percent over a 10-year period, said officials from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

Taiwan also agreed to lower the local-content rate for compact cars from the current 50 percent to 40 percent beginning Jan. 1, 1999, and cancel preferential commodity tax rates for locally developed engines, chassises and auto designs.
For other industrial products, Taiwan agreed to lower the average import tariffs to 4.9 percent before 2002 from the current 6.5 percent, and gradually down to 4.7 percent by 2004.
On medical equipment and related products, Taiwan agreed to scrap import tariffs on certain items, and will remove them across-the-board before 2002.

On tobacco and cigarette imports, Taiwan promised to continue efforts to end the tobacco monopoly, agreed to impose zero-tariffs on imported liquor products by 2000, stop imposing import tariffs on beer in 2005, and cut tariffs on imported grape wine to 10 percent by 2002.

On agricultural trade, one of the thorniest issues in the US-Taiwan WTO talks, Taiwan agreed to partially open its agricultural markets immediately to US imports as a "down payment" for exchange of US support for Taiwan's WTO bid.

The "down payment" includes 5,000 metric tons of pork bellies, 7,500 metric tons of pig offals and pork chops, 10,000 metric tons of chicken meat, and 5,000 metric tons of beef chops and offals, said BOFT officials.

The "down payment" means an extra market of US$18 million for US pork dealers, and US$10 million more sales for US chicken dealers. By 2004, US$43 million worth of American chicken products will be cutting into the Taiwan market, the officials noted.
Also in the agreement, Taiwan will open its rice market to US imports, allowing some US$60 million worth of American rice to hit the Taiwan shelves over the next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF DETAINED BUSINESSMAN REMAINS UNKNOWN: SEF

TEXT.P: Taipei has not received a reply from mainland Chinese authorities regarding the detainment of a Taiwan businessman, the Straits Exchange Foundation said Saturday.

SEF Vice Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing said that the SEF sent a letter to its mainland counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits on July 22. The letter requested ARATS to check on information regarding Hsu Chai-hsin who reportedly has been held in detention for nearly one year.
Wu said that the SEF is still waiting for a reply from the ARATS regarding this matter.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies formed to handle cross-strait affairs in absence of official contacts.

Hsu's case was another financial dispute involving businessmen between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Wu said, adding that over the past 10 years, there were some 485 cross-strait financial dispute cases.

He also criticized the mainland authorities for detaining Wu for such a long time without handling out a verdict to the case. The mainland authorities should make sure the rights of Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland are upheld, he stressed.

Wu said that the SEF learned Wu's case from a petition sent by Hsu's family on July 21. According to the petition, Hsu, who invested US$10 million toward the establishment of a golf club, was arrested in Beijing on July 31, 1997.

Hsu was then charged with bribery. Since then, he has been held in detention without being allowed to meet with his family. He was also forced to transfer the property rights of the golf club, the petition said.

Wu once again called on ARATS to assume talks with the SEF. He said that the two intermediary bodies should discuss ways to ensure personal and property security of Taiwan businessmen based in the mainland and put the issue into an agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HOPES LIN INCIDENT WILL NOT AFFECT KOO-WANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation sent a letter Friday to its Beijing counterpart expressing hope that the recent death of a Kaohsiung city councilor will not affect the planned meeting between the two sides.
The SEF sent the letter in response to a letter from the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait dated Aug. 4.

The SEF's letter said Taipei regretted ARATS' harsh condemnation of the SEF's handling of the death of Lin Ti-chuan, who was also a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. Lin died in a botched kidnapping incident in Haicheng in mainland China's northeast Liaoning Province late July.

The ARATS letter criticized the SEF for "taking advantage of the incident to deliberately create and exacerbate differences in order to to sow dissension between compatriots across the strait." In addition, the letter hinted at possible uncertainty over the upcoming meeting in the fall between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.

Shi Hwei-yow, SEF vice chairman and secretary-general, told reporters the SEF regrets that Lin's death and that of Taiwan businessman Wang Fu-ching remain unresolved. He added that the ARATS censured the SEF's humanistic request to allow the SEF's legal expert to visit the mainland along with relatives of the victim.

Also, the SEF cannot understand the ARATS criticism that the SEF impeded the mainland's efforts to conduct an autopsy on Lin's remains as the SEF repeatedly exhibited respect for the opinions of professionals as well as Lin's family, Shi said.

As to the forthcoming Koo-Wang meeting and the trend of cross-strait relations, Shi observed that dialogue between the two sides have been halted for more than three years, a matter the two quasi-official bodies have worked hard to end recently with plans for the Koo-Wang meeting slated for later this year.

Shi expressed the hope that the SEF and ARATS will help each other handle issues which arise across the strait based on mutual respect, and resume a dialogue as soon as possible. He added that priority should be given to topics regarding ensuring the rights and protection of interests of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Against such a backdrop, stressed Shi, improved relations across the strait will be more likely to be guaranteed.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE FEEL MAINLAND CHINA IS 'UNFRIENDLY'

TEXT.P: The number of local people supporting Taiwan independence has increased in the wake of the kidnap and murder of a local councilor in mainland China in late July, according to results of a public opinion poll released Saturday.

The poll of 902 adult citizens, conducted by a research and personnel training center operated by the ruling Kuomintang on Aug. 6-7, found that 23.4 percent of the respondents hope to see Taiwan move toward independence, compared to 13 percent of those who want to see unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"The gap between percentages of independence and unification supporters is the largest in all similar KMT surveys," said Tsai Pi-huang, director of the KMT research and training center. "In previous surveys, the gap was only about 3 to 4 percent."
Tsai, also a legislator-at large, further said the percentage of unification supporters is the lowest compared to similar polls conducted in recent years.
Meanwhile, 42.4 percent of the respondents said they prefer to see the status quo in cross-strait relations maintained.
The latest poll results also show that 62 percent feel mainland China is unfriendly toward Taiwan, while only 5 percent said they feel mainland China is friendly.

Analyzing the poll results, Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said the number of independence supporters has consistently increased whenever mainland China threatened to use force against Taiwan or adopted unfriendly behavior toward Taiwan.
"We hope mainland China will pay more attention to Taiwan people's feelings and sentiments to reduce animosity and forge rapprochement," Wu said.

The poll found that 41 percent were dissatisfied with Beijing's handling of issues related to the kidnap and murder of Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan in northeastern China in late July; only 18.7 percent approved of Beijing's handling.

Wu said Beijing's refusal to allow Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation staff members to the mainland to help the Lin family handle the aftermath concerning the councilor's death was a mistake.
Wu said denying entry of SEF staff to the mainland has had an adverse effect on the Taiwan public's perceptions of the mainland government.
The same survey also found that 47.2 percent of local people support the government's "no haste, be patient" policy on mainland-bound investment; while 24.9 percent were against the policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOWS GOOD WILL IN SUB-CABINET-LEVEL MEETING WITH ROC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and the United States held a sub-Cabinet-level meeting in Washington, D.C. on Friday to discuss trade, economic and financial issues.
The two countries signed a formal agreement on terms for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) and forged consensus on many points during the one-day meeting.
The United States showed good will in the meeting, allowing for the first time electornic media cameramen to enter the conference room to shoot footage.

The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) also issued a press release on the event. The move seemed to call US media attention to the fact that Washington and Taipei held a high-level dialogue following a summit meeting between President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing on June 27.

ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu served as chief Taiwan negotiator, while the United States was represented by Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers. AIT Chairman Richard Bush and ROC Representative to the US Stephen Chen were also present at the meeting.

In addition to sealing a bilateral WTO accord, the two sides agreed to sign a customs cooperation agreement before the end of this year and reviewed progress in negotiations for the singing of a bilateral investment agreement.
The two sides also discuss issues related to finaical management and liberalization, trade and investment, as well as the prevention of economic and fianncial crimes.
Lin said after the meeting that both sides agree that Taiwan's maintaining a sound economic policy and promoting stability of its currency are in Taiwan's and entire Asia's interests.
An American delegate said the United States hopes to continue similar engagement or to conduct any other forms of constructive dialogue with Taiwan.
Lin said the ROC is hopeful that similar sub-Cabinet-level meeting will be held regularly in the future. The time, place and format for the next sub-Cabinet-level meeting will be decided later.

The first sub-Cabinet-level meeting was held in Washington, D.C. in June 1995, and the second meeting took place in Taipei in September 1996. The third meeting was originally scheduled for 1997, but was later postponed to this year.

The United States reportedly will decide whether to hold similar conferences with the ROC in the future after conducting an interministerial review of the results of the three previous sub-Cabinet-level meetings.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND MIGHT INVESTIGATE MAINLAND CHINA DUMPING

TEXT.P: Thailand is expected to investigate the alleged dumping of cheap fabric in the kingdom by mainland China, a Thai Textile Manufacturers' Association official said on Friday.
The official said that locally made fabrics sell at about 58 baht (US$1.45) per meter, but fabric from mainland China sells at just 40 baht per meter.
The Commerce Ministry is collecting information about the price of imported Chinese fabrics against the price in its home market, following complaints by the association.
The textile sector is one of the local industries suffering severely from the recession, the official said.

Thailand exported textiles and garments worth US$2.03 billion during the first five months of 1998. The country expects to achieve this year's export target of US$5.93 billion, representing a growth of 35 percent compared to last year, the Department of Export Promotion said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX CANADIAN MP'S TO VISIT TAIWAN NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: Six Canadian members of parliament will visit the Republic of China from Aug. 9-15.
The six are Mac Harb, John Maloney, Ivan Grose, Richard Harris, Madeleine Dalphond and Paul Bonwick.
An official of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada said the parliamentarians will try to discuss real issues between the two countries.

Currently the biggest issue between Taiwan and Canada is probably a Canadian proposal to sign an agreement on the avoidance of double taxation with Taiwan. Taipei balks at signing the treaty because of opposition from Taiwan emigrants to Canada.

Taiwan immigrants in Canada are fiercely opposed to the treaty because it would enable Canada to tax their overseas assets. The Canadian government insists it's a fair deal which will only hurt tax dodgers.

Last spring, another group of Canadian MP's visited Taiwan and returned to report to their colleagues in the House of Commons that they support the government's initiative to sign such a treaty with Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC FUNERAL FOR DECEASED WARSHIP CREWMEN HELD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui issued citations to the seven deceased Suei Yang crewmen during their funeral rites held at the Tsoying naval base in southern Taiwan on Sunday.

The public funeral rites were presided over by Navy Fleet Commander Miao Yung-ching. He read an order from Commander-in-Chief of Chinese Navy Adm. Wu Shih-wen, giving the seven dead seamen posthumous promotions.

Huang Chi-yuan was promoted to petty officer second class from petty officer third class, while Wu Cheng-yang and five other seamen second class were promoted to petty officers third class. As a token of respect, their coffins were covered with national flags which were later given to their families.
Adm. Wu and representatives from many agencies, including Chung Yung-chi, deputy secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, were on hand to extend their condolences to the families of the victims.
Meanwhile, flags on the Navy Fleet Command and on all warships berthed at the Tsoying naval base were flown at half-mast.

The seven men were killed and five others injured on Monday afternoon when a rear boiler room of the destroyer ship exploded during a routine training mission some 18 nautical miles off the Tsoying naval base.

The Suei Yang is one of the Yang-class destroyers bought from the United States more than four decades ago. The General Headquarters of Navy has instructed all ships to improve their maintenance and repair services to avoid the recurrence of a similar misfortune.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN PREFER TO RESOLVE DISPUTES PRIVATELY: POLL

TEXT.P: About 65 percent of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China have encountered disputes there and 91 percent of these people resorted to private mediation for resolution, the results of a recent survey showed.

According to the survey conducted by the monthly Teacher Chang magazine, 68 percent of businessmen based in the mainland would prefer to get help from Taiwan businessmen's associations. Only 1.3 percent said they would ask one of the two semi-official organizations -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation or Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- for help.

The most frequent cause of disputes arose in dealings with local authorities and local trade partners. Violations of patents or trademarks, disputes regarding labor-management relations and land acquisitions were also common, the survey found.

Although many Taiwan businessmen surveyed acknowledged that a high percentage of fighting, kidnappings or even murders of Taiwan businessmen were in connection with love affairs between Taiwan men and local mainland Chinese women, it is worth noting that most of them chose not to comment such affairs.

Chen Ming-chang, publisher of the magazine, said most Taiwan businessmen will first try to resolve their business problems through "private relationships" which many times result in blackmail or kidnapping. Businessmen who turn to the SEF are usually those who have no other avenue of recourse, he noted.

According to Chen, the survey was conducted by 66 representatives of the magazine who made several trips to the mainland in the first half of this year. The survey was commissioned by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

In the light of increased business disputes and crimes targeting Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, a leader of a Taiwan businessmen's group, whose name was not made known, called on Taiwan investors to behave themselves while doing business in the mainland.
The blackmailing and kidnapping of Taiwan investors would be largely reduced if they abide by local rules and keep a low profile in their private lives, he said.

A survey by the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries in July also found that Taiwan businessmen based in mainland China would rather resolve their disputes through private channels in order to not annoy local mainland officials.
Seeking help from the SEF or ARATS would only pose greater danger to their personal safety and create more difficulties to their businesses, it indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL DRUG RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau officers busted an international drug ring Saturday, seizing 22 bricks of heroin weighing eight kilograms with an estimated street value of NT$300 million (NT$8.4 million).

Teng Ter-ming, one member of the four-man drug trafficking operation, was a former official of mainland China's State Council stationed in Hong Kong, the bureau said. A Taiwanese buyer, Hsu Chin-chuan, was also arrested along with three accomplices from Hong Kong identified by police as Cheng Wei-wen, Lee Kuo-chiang, and Tan Chien-chi.

Huang Yu-huan, a prosecutor with the Taipei District Prosecutors Office in charge of the case, said the drugs were smuggled into Taiwan from the mainland's Yunnan Province, rather than from the Golden Triangle in the Southeast Asia.

Expressing doubt that other mainland Chinese officials were involved in the case, Huang said the case needs to be thoroughly investigated. He called for greater efforts from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to jointly crack down on cross-strait criminal activities.
Acting on tip, Huang, in conjunction with Investigation Bureau agents in Taipei and Hsinchu, as well as military police, began to monitor and probe movements of the suspects a year ago.

Through their monitoring efforts, investigators found that Teng moved a large amount of heroin into Taiwan from Hong Kong last Wednesday. Hsu had met Teng at the airport and later met with Tan in a hotel in downtown Taipei on Thursday.

Following a 24-hour wait, investigators learned that the drugs were stashed by the smuggling ring separately in two locations in downtown Taipei, one on Hoping East Road and the other on Linsen North Road.
Agents found Teng and Tan with some of the drugs on Saturday when they were enroute to delivering them to Hsu. The remainder of the drugs were found hidden in the two buildings later the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL MEETS WITH ARATS CHIEF ON CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Chang Lung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's chief in charge of mainland Chinese affairs urged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to pool their wisdom and work toward a common ground which would contribute to the reunification of China.
The KMT's Mainland Research Department Director General Chang Jung-kung made the call during his meeting with Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan in Shanghai Saturday.
Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, told Chang the two sides should develop their relations under the "one China" principle.
Speaking on cross-strait talks, Wang said the current priority is to end the prevailing hostility on both sides and promote common interests.

Beijing has called for cross-strait negotiations on China's reunification to take place in an equal and peaceful manner, Wang said, but he noted the talks should take place under the "one China" principle. Beijing's version of the principle maintains that Taiwan is a province of China and Beijing is the only legitimate government of China.

Wang said Taipei should authorize its Straits Exchange Foundation to conduct political negotiations with the mainland. Such a channel for dialogue can help resolve problems related to the security of the Pacific region and Taiwan, Wang stressed.
The SEF and ARATS are two intermediary bodies formed by Taipei and Beijing authorities to deal with cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links.
Responding to Wang's comments, Chang said that the "one China" principle should be interpreted based on the principles of historical consistency, the reality and future prospects.

According to Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, Chang said, the KMT's mainland policy is based on the reality of a "separated China." The policy states that both sides of the strait should work toward a newly unified China where freedom, democracy and prosperity exists.
Chang arrived in Shanghai on Friday after attending a seminar on cross-strait affairs in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATOR CALLS FOR PRECAUTIONS AGAINST MAINLAND CAPITAL INFLOW

TEXT.P: A legislator urged the government Sunday to take precautions against the capital inflow of mainland Chinese funds into Taiwan's stock and real estate markets as it would influence Taiwan's economy.
Chang Chun-hung from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party made the call in a written interpellation to the Executive Yuan, according to a news release.
The DPP lawmaker said Beijing is expected to intervene in Taiwan's year-end legislative elections through any means possible, including use of their capital.
Injecting money into Taiwan through financial and economic institutions is the easiest way Beijing can manipulate the island's elections, Chang warned.

He noted that mainland Chinese funds can be transferred to Taiwan in huge quantities through two channels. One of those is through Taiwan investment companies in Hong Kong where capital can flow into Taiwan's trading in stock and real estates, two sectors that play leading roles in a economic system.
The other channel is through foreign businesses with mainland funds, including those in Hong Kong, Chang said.
Currently, the authorities in charge of foreign investment affairs, the Investment Commission, holds no power to launch investigations into tracing the source of foreign capital, the legislator said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RELEASE OF MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENT WANG YOUCAI URGED

TEXT.P: Fifty-three mainland Chinese dissidents in Zhejian Province Saturday issued an open letter, calling for the release of dissident Wang Youcai, through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China.

Wang, who attempted to legally register a preparatory committee for the formation of an opposition "Chinese Democratic Party" in Hangzhou on June 25, was picked up by public security authorities on July 10, and was formally arrested Saturday on charges of inciting people to overthrow "the country's ruling power."

In the open letter, the 53 dissidents said what Wang has done is exercising his freedom of association guaranteed by the Constitution. His advocacy of political reforms by peaceful, rational, and nonviolent means does not constitute any crime, they said. Under mainland Chinese law, inciting people to overthrow the government is a serious crime. It is feared that Wang will be indicted.

Wang, 32, was one of the 21 student leaders most wanted by police for their part in the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy incident. He was later sentenced to three years in prison. Hangzhou is the capital city of Zhejiang Province in eastern mainland China.
Meanwhile, members of four dissident groups in Hong Kong Sunday staged a demonstration at the Hong Kong branch office of Xinhua News Agency, calling for the release of Wang.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, PHILIPPINES TO HOLD SIX MORE WAR GAMES

TEXT.P: Washington and Manila will conduct six small-scale joint military exercises similar to the recent live-fire exercises in the South China Sea, Philippine Defense Secretary Orlando Mercado said Friday.

The exercises, involving not more than 30 soldiers from both sides, have taken place in international waters since Dec. 1997 due to the lack of a bilateral agreement regarding joint military training between the two countries.
US Secretary of Defense William Cohen visited Manila Sunday to begin two-day talks with Philippine officials regarding Washington's Visiting Forces Agreement.

The agreement was offered after the United States withdrew its military bases from the Philippines. It allows free visits by US war planes and ships to any air and sea port in the country in exchange for military assistance and economic aid. It also obliges US troops to conduct military exercises with their Phillipine counterparts.
Mercado, who along with current President Joseph Estrada were strong opponents to the extension of a contract allowing US military bases to remain in the Philippines, supports the agreement.
"Ratification of the Visiting Forces Agreement will pave the way for large-scale joint military exercises in the Philippine territory," said Mercado.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 10TH AMONG EU TRADING PARTNERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan was rated as the European Union's 10th largest trading partner in the first quarter of this year, according to EU statistics.
During the period, Taiwan exports to the EU grew 29 percent from last year, a record jump among the EU's largest trade partners.
Figures indicated that Taiwan's imports from the EU posted a 17 percent growth in the three-month period, ranking sixth among EU's importers.

The vigorous trade between Taiwan and the EU, however, is being threatened by increasing imports from South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand and other Southeast Asian countries to the European economy, the China External Trade Development Council warned.
Products from these areas are more competitive in price than those from Taiwan due to their devalued currencies, CETRA officials said.
Most Southeast Asian nations, as well as South Korea and Japan, sustained severe currency devaluation in Asia's financial meltdown.
The EU's top 10 trading partners for the period in descending order were the United States, Switzerland, Japan, Norway, mainland China, Russia, Poland, Turkey, Hong Kong, and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON STATE GOVERNOR HAILS PRESIDENT LEE
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Washington State Governor Gary Locke on Saturday praised Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui as an outstanding leader with visionary plans for Taiwan's future.
Locke, the United States' first ethnic Chinese state governor, said under Lee's leadership, Taiwan has set itself as a model of democracy, freedom and economic development for other Asian countries.

Locke, who recently returned from a weeklong visit to Taiwan, said one of the most important things he accomplished during his trip was meeting President Lee. Their meeting was extended from half an hour to an hour amid an enthusiastic exchange of opinions, he noted.

Stating that President Lee is a man of extensive knowledge and has a good understanding of bilateral relations between Taiwan and Washington State, Locke said he was very surprised when the president said he has instructed relevant authorities to clamp down on the import of fake Washington apples from mainland China.
The Washington governor made the remarks while attending the opening ceremony of the 21st annual conference of the Formosan Club across the United States held in Seattle.

Although Locke was reluctant to make a comparison between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said his trip back to his hometown in mainland China's Guangdong Province last year was like a "return to the 18th century," as it has no tap water, telephones, nor electricity.

Republican Senator Slade Gorton from Washington State said in his speech that supporting Taiwan has become a mainstream position in the United States, pointing out that the US Senate passed a resolution to support Taiwan in a vote of 92 to 0 shortly after US President Bill Clinton concluded his trip to mainland China in early July.
Taiwan "deserves and will receive" US support, Gorton said, adding that there is still ample room for the two countries to strengthen bilateral ties and expand two-way cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF MAINLAND DISSIDENT TO PROTEST IN BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 8 (CNA) (By J.J. Hwang & Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: A New York-based Chinese human rights organization said Saturday the family of Liu Nienchun, a mainland political dissident, will go to Beijing on Aug. 10 to protest against his persecution.

In a letter to Beijing authorities on Aug. 2, Liu's mother Wu Huifen and his wife Tsu Hailan noted that Liu was sentenced to a labor camp for three years for his political beliefs. The letter said Liu was ill-treated while in prison and has suffered from various illnesses including high blood pressure and a serious stomach ailment.

Prior to the visits of US Vice President Albert Gore and Speaker of the House of Representatives Newt Gingrich in 1997, and President Bill Clinton's tour of mainland this year, Beijing authorities assured Liu's family that he will receive medical care outside prison on the condition that they do not meet with the visiting officials or reporters.
After complying with the authorities' demands, Liu has yet to receive medical attention outside prison. His family has expressed dissatisfaction over Beijing's false promises.

There has been no improvement in Liu's medical care and treatment, Wu and Tsu said. Therefore, the two have decided to appeal directly to Beijing authorities. If they are not received by relevant agency representatives, then they will protest in front of the Beijing City Committee building.
Liu, a noted mainland dissident, took part in the 1978 Democracy Wall movement. He was one of the leaders of the Peace Charter movement and Laborers' Rights Protection Union.

The dissident has been arrested many times. He was secretly detained for 17 months two times, and twice sentenced to serve in labor camps for a total of six years. Due to prolonged maltreatment, he reportedly suffered from several illnesses which have so altered his appearance that his mother barely recognized him.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN OFFICIAL MEETS WITH CHINESE PROTESTERS IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Over 500 Chinese Canadians staged an angry but peaceful rally Saturday in front of the Indonesian embassy in Ottawa to protest crimes of violence committed against Chinese Indonesians.

In an unexpected move, an embassy official met with two of the group's leaders and received a letter of protest. Achsan Djunaedi, assistant to the head of the embassy's political section, also expressed Jakarta's "deep regret" over the incidents.
The meeting was an improvement from the embassy's previous reaction to a protest against Jakarta's occupation of East Timor, a policeman guarding the Indonesian embassy said.

At the head of the protesters, the Federation of Ottawa-Carleton Chinese Organization collected several thousand signatures in a petition and will deliver it to Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien next week in Parliament.

The petition decries the treatment of Chinese Indonesians during the May riots which subsequently toppled then President Suharto and seeks Canada's condemnation of the violation of human rights. It also urges Jakarta to thoroughly investigate the cases and punish those found guilty.
Gangs of rioters have been accused of targeting ethnic Chinese by looting and burning their property and assaulting and raping Chinese Indonesian women.
The federation strongly condemned Jakarta for having failed to prevent the racial violence and crimes, demanding that it "severely punish all those" who participated in the horrendous acts.

They also demanded that Indonesia adopt immediate and effective measures to protect Chinese Indonesians' rights and compensate all victims of violence. They then urged Indonesia to pass legislation to prevent the recurrence of similar violence in the future.

In response, Achsan said the Indonesian government has no intention of covering up the cases, but he noted Jakarta is experiencing difficulty in punishing those criminals because few victims were willing to come forward and testify in court. The Indonesian official asked the federation for help in providing evidence that will lead to the conviction of criminals. By S.C. Chang

DOC.HEADLINE: FRIENDSHIP ASSOCIATION OF TAIWANESE MEETS IN SEATTLE

TEXT.P: The 21st annual conference of the Taiwanese Friendship Association in the United States opened here Saturday with leaders of Taiwanese American communities in the US participating.

In the meeting, the participants pledged their strong support for the government of the Republic of China on Taiwan in its endeavor to pursue national unification under the principles of freedom, democracy, and equitable distribution of wealth for all Chinese.
They also pledged to help improve the relationship between Taiwan and the US, and to help promote economic and social development in Taiwan.
In his congratulatory message to the conference, President Bill Clinton praised Taiwanese Americans for their contribution to the peace and prosperity enjoyed by people in the US.
President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, and Premier Vincent Siew also sent congratulatory messages to the meeting.

In the conference, Governor Gary Locke of Washington State praised President Lee for his far-sightedness and able leadership. Locke visited Taipei July 26-30 for trade promotion. Some other US leaders also attended the meeting.

Addressing the conference, Minister Chiao Jen-ho of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission of the Executive Yuan praised members of the association for their strong support for the government of the Republic of China. He also briefed the participants in the meeting on the current situations in Taiwan and the current relations between Taiwan and mainland China.

When turning to the problem concerning the rape of many ethnic Chinese women in recent Indonesian riots, Chiao said it is the government policy of the Republic of China on Taiwan to protect the interests of all overseas Chinese in the world. He added that the time is not ripe for the governments in Taipei and Beijing to cooperate in dealing with the problem in Indonesia at the present time, because cross-strait relations still stay in the stage of civilian exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIMSTEC TO SET UP FREE TRADE ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Bangladesh, India, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, and Thailand have agreed to set up a free trade alliance once an organization is established to resolve remaining obstacles, a Thai official said Saturday.

Thailand Deputy Prime Minister and Commerce Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi said the decision was made Friday at an informal meeting of commerce ministers in Bangkok of the Bangladesh, India, Myanmar, Sri Lanka and Thailand Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC). BIMSTEC was launched last year to forge closer links among the five countries.
The proposal will be presented at the second BIMSTEC foreign ministers meeting to be held Dhaka, Bangladesh early next month.

Commerce ministers also agreed to use BIMSTEC to link the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation, creating the biggest free trade alliance, Supachai said.
The five commerce ministers agreed to set up sub-working groups to oversee six sectors which will be used as pilot projects for cooperation.

Bangladesh will chair the sub-working group on trade and investment, India will chair technology, Thailand will chair transportation and communication, Myanmar will chair energy and Sri Lanka tourism and fishery.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY ON SINGLE-PARENT FAMILIES RELEASED

TEXT.P: There were a total of 176,000 single-parent families in Taiwan, a recent survey released on Sunday by the Ministry of the Interior showed.
There were more divorced, single-parent families in urban areas than rural areas, accounting for 64 percent of the total, the survey found.
Most of the single-parent families in rural areas were the result of the death of one parent, with 43 percent belonging to this category.

According to the survey, each single-parent family has an average monthly income of NT$23,350 (about US$660), as 36 percent of the overall single-parent families islandwide earn between NT$20,000 and NT$30,000 a month.

Some 28 percent of Taiwan's single-parent families earn between NT$10,000 and NT$20,000 each month, while 17 percent earn between NT$30,000 and NT$40,000. About 10 percent earn less NT$10,000, while 6.3 percent and 3.5 percent enjoy a relatively high monthly income of between NT$40,000-NT$50,000, or over NT$50,000.

The survey found that each single-parent family spends an average of NT$7,446, nearly one third of its monthly income, on education fees or nursery care every month, an indication that Taiwan's single-parent families may have difficulty meeting economic requirements for child care and career development.

Judging from social welfare indexes, single-parent families also require more medical care and higher insurance, increased subsidiaries for accidents, daily expenses, housing loans, and higher priority in the application for public housing.

As to those single-parent families without stable incomes, most of them live on government subsidiaries and charity. Some also live on assistance from relatives or earn compensation money or pensions.
The survey also indicated that single-mother families have greater economic difficulties than single-father families as many such mothers are unemployed.

Figures showed that most of both the single mothers and fathers are employees in the manufacturing sector or white-collar workers, while many of them are also salesmen and vendors, as well as farmers or fishermen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUBLIC AGAINST HIGHER QUOTA FOR MAINLAND SPOUSES: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of people surveyed are opposed to making a large increase in the quota for mainland Chinese spouses allowed to live in Taiwan, the results of an opinion poll released Sunday found.

The survey, conducted by the Public Administration Society of the Republic of China, found that 69 percent of respondents were against a large-scale increase in the quota for mainland spouses permitted to reside in Taiwan.

At present, the government allows about 1,800 mainland spouses to come to the island to live with their families. Sixty-six percent of the poll's respondents said too many mainlanders in Taiwan could threaten social stability.

As for law and order, 89 percent of the respondents believe stowaways from the mainland would affect the stability of Taiwan's society, while 54.5 percent believe Beijing may haved played a role behind the screen in the serious cross-strait smuggling of guns and drugs.

The public opinion poll also found that 58 percent of respondents believe the "three noes" policy presented by US President Bill Clinton would damage Taiwan's international position, while 39 percent believe the US has good faith in the performance of safeguaring Taiwan's security, and 38.8 percent said they doubt the US sincerity.
The survey was conducted between July 15 and 21. Adults islandwide were polled, and 1,190 valid responses were received.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISNEY HITS MAINLAND'S BRICK WALL OF RED TAPE

TEXT.P: Walt Disney's latest animated film, Mulan, has hit a wall of red tape in mainland China, the Los Angeles Times reported Saturday.

The film is based on a Chinese legend about a girl who marches off to war in her father's place. It has been earning relatively healthy revenue in North America, but it has yet to play in the country which it was intended.
The article said it is uncertain if or when the film will play in mainland China.

Mulan's case illustrates the unpredictable and often frustrating workings of the mainland's entertainment industry, a minefield for enthusiastic but unwary foreigners and an uneasy intersection of politics and culture in the world's most populous nation, the article said.
Few observers doubt that the waiting game for Disney, which is on a rocky footing with the Beijing regime, turns as much on delicate questions of policy and politics as on aesthetic merit.

Complications include everything from the low limit slapped on the number of international films allowed in theaters, to the prickly reaction to Tibet, a sensitive issue that triggered a cat-and-mouse game between Beijing and Disney over a year ago.

Only about a dozen foreign movies are permitted to show films in mainland theaters annually on a profit-sharing basis between Beijing and the original distributors, a quota that chafes studio executives. (Lu-sheng Chu)

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO-WANG TALKS NOT LIKELY SOON: OPINION POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan residents believe dialogue between Taiwan and mainland China is conducive to better relations, but many do not think the long-stalled talks will resume any time soon, results of a recent poll showed.

The survey, conducted by Sigma Poll, found that 63 percent of those interviewed were in favor of an early resumption of the Koo-Wang talks. Koo-Wang refers to a previous meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Koo and Wang, authorized by their respective governments, met for the first time in Singapore in 1993. During the landmark meeting, the two sides loosely agreed on a framework for regular dialogue in the future.
Beijing slammed the negotiation door shut on Taiwan after President Lee Teng-hui made a personal visit to the United States in 1995, which Beijing saw as a move promoting Taiwan independence.

The poll, carried out between Aug. 3 and 5 at the request of New Party legislative candidate Lee Ping, found that 50 percent of Taiwan residents polled do not believe the Koo-Wang talks will resume this year because "Beijing has shown no sincerity toward such an initiative."

About 40 percent were in favor of Taiwan independence while another 40 percent were opposed to it. Also, 57 percent believed Beijing would launch a military attack against Taiwan if the island were to declare independence. Forty-six percent believed the United States may come to Taiwan's defense in the event of such an attack.

A total of 56 percent of the respondents believed the political status quo across the Taiwan Strait will remain unchanged in the next five years, while 24 percent believed the status quo will remain unchanged in the next 10 years. Only 7.6 percent said the status quo will not change in 30 years.

In addition, 39 percent said they supported President Lee's "no haste, be patient" policy on Taiwan's business and trade activities in mainland China. Another 33 percent said the policy will undermine Taiwan businesses' development potential in mainland China.
The poll found that 55 percent favor a personal visit to mainland China by President Lee, while 67 percent would welcome a visit by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
As many as 70 percent of the respondents said they would be gravely concerned if their relatives were to visit mainland China either for business or pleasure.

The New Party's Lee, a Taiwan-born ROC citizen who studied business management in the United States and has been doing business in Shanghai for over 10 years, ordered the poll to gain insight to Taiwan public's opinion on cross-strait relations. He is seeking a seat in the legislature in the year-end elections and said he will represent the interests of Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China.
During the three-day poll of Taiwan adults islandwide, Sigma obtained 1,081 valid responses.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT YET 'RIPE' FOR CROSS-STRAIT COOPERATION IN RAPE CASES
DOC.DATELINE: Seattle, Aug. 9 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The time is not yet "ripe" for cooperation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to deal with the atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese women by Indonesian rioters earlier this year, a Taiwan official said.
Chiao Jen-ho, visiting ROC minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, made the remarks Saturday in response to questions of such possible cooperation.
Ethnic Chinese Indonesians were targeted in the days of rioting, looting, burning of property and sexual assaults which eventually toppled the Suharto regime in May.
Chiao said at present, cross-strait exchanges and cooperation have been confined to the private level.

He added that most of the ethnic Chinese living in Indonesia are not willing to leave Indonesia, and that the ROC government should be cautious in expressing its views on the issue as it may exacerbate the situation for Chinese Indonesians.

Media reports of the atrocities committed against Chinese Indonesian women during the riots naturally caused widespread indignation, Chiao said, but the commission has yet to receive a direct appeal for help from the victims. The commission is nevertheless trying to obtain more information about the crimes.
He said the problem in Indonesia is complex as economic, political, cultural, and religious factors are all involved. It would be better that Amnesty International come forward to handle the problem.

Chiao, former secretary-general of Taipei's intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation, also said if private groups in the mainland were to invite him for a visit, he would certainly accept the invitation.
