He said if overseas groups and Chinese language schools from the mainland were to need Chinese textbooks, the commission would be willing to provide them. He added that the move would not affect the commission's present budget or resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER PRAISES CRACKDOWN EFFORTS AGAINST DRUG RING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice will continue its efforts to eradicate illegal drug operations and seek international cooperation to crack down on drug trafficking, Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo said Monday.

Cheng made the remarks while receiving the task force which brought down an international drug ring over the weekend. Five suspects were arrested, and eight kilograms of heroin from mainland China's Yunnan Province with an estimated street value of NT$300 million (US$8.6 million) was seized.

Cheng said the arrests were a good example of cooperation between police and prosecutors. He added that the continued crackdown on drug use and trafficking is of great importance to the improvement of public security.

The justice minister, who inspected the Kaohsiung Female Prison last week, said up to 85 percent of the inmates were held on charges related to drug crimes, and vowed to make Taiwan free from all illegal narcotics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO REINFORCE ENGAGEMENT WITH FOREIGN EMBASSIES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) called a meeting on Monday of resident ambassadors from countries that maintain formal diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
It was the first time that the MOFA has held such a meeting aimed at shoring up the ROC's relations with its diplomatic allies, which now number 27.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who personally chaired the conference, said the Foreign Ministry decided to hold this kind of meeting once a year in the future to boost mutual understanding and friendship.
Moreover, Hu said, the three vice foreign ministers will also hold biannual meetings with envoys from the ROC's diplomatic allies.

"In the past, we didn't maintain close contact with foreign embassies. We must make an improvement and step up efforts to strengthen engagement and exchanges with them," Hu told local reporters after the meeting.

Hu said he has instructed department directors in charge of relations with different continents to intensify contact with foreign embassies here. Most of the ROC's diplomatic allies are located in Latin America and Africa.

During Monday's meeting, Hu said he exchanged views with foreign ambassadors on a broad range of issues, including the substance of the June 27 summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, the latest situation in Taiwan and abroad, the Asian financial crisis and other matters of mutual concern.
Noting that the meeting was helpful to boost exchanges between the MOFA and foreign embassies here, Hu said he takes pleasure in briefing foreign envoys on major ROC policies that interest them.
Meanwhile, Hu said the MOFA has consistently attached great importance to the security of foreign institutions in Taiwan.
"We have tightened security measures at foreign embassies, consulates and representative offices here in the wake of bomb attacks at US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania on Friday," Hu said.
The minister went on to say that a 16-story building in Taipei's Tienmu district is scheduled for completion at the end of the year to accommodate foreign embassies and consulates in Taiwan.
The new building, constructed by the MOFA, will make a concentration of security forces easier, Hu said.

At present, security at foreign embassies and consulates is handled by a task force under the National Police Administration. Due to the wide distribution of these institutions, district police forces are also in charge of protecting foreign officials in Taiwan.

Hu said the new building will enable the MOFA to offer better protection and services to foreign diplomats stationed here. But Hu added he could not yet confirm whether the staff of foreign embassies and consulates will be able to move into the building by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTEST AGAINST INDONESIAN MINISTER ABORTED

TEXT.P: A planned protest against an Indonesian minister was aborted Monday after the official canceled his visit to Taiwan.

Members of the Chinese Compatriot Association, led by Taipei City Councilor Lee Cheng-lung, were forced to abandon their planned protest against Indonesian Investment Minister Hamzah Haz outside the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
When Haz failed to appear, the group was received by Hsieh Fa-ta, director general of the MOEA's International Cooperation Department.

Media reports indicate that ethnic Chinese women in Indonesia are continuing to be victims of rape, the association charged, adding that they wished to express their opposition of such brutality to Haz. The CCA had protested in front of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei shortly after rioting broke out in Indonesia in May.

The CCA said they are currently working on a long-term campaign aimed at urging Chinese people around the world to "adequately educate the Indonesian people" as part of efforts to stop further abuses and violation of human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE-YEAR-OLD BOY TESTS POSITIVE FOR HIV

TEXT.P: Shocked by the tragic incident, Hsu Kuo-hsiung, director of the DOH Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said the department will step up the investigation into the source of the blood and may resort to publicizing the name of the donor.

The child received three bags of red blood cell concentration and seven units of platelet during a stomach operation in a southern Taiwan hospital in March this year. Doctors at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou, northern Taiwan, recently examined and diagnosed the boy.
The boy checked into Chang Gung after sustaining blisters, milia and crusts all over his body, unlike symptoms of chicken pox, a common childhood disease.

Chang Gung doctors conducted an HIV test on the child and found that he tested positive for the virus that causes AIDS. They concluded that the skin disorder was an indication of full-blown AIDS, which he contracted through blood transfusions during his operation.

The DOH is considering publicizing the name of the donor to prevent other people with AIDS from donating blood who were either intentionally trying to spread the disease or due to ignorance. Hsu said the department will first consult with relevant specialists about the handling of the situation.
He said the DOH will fully discuss the possible outcome of the name-publication initiative, including whether it will affect blood donors' willingness, its legality, and the donors' privacy rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES EXCHANGE DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Market Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 157.9 points to close at 7,372.
The bourse opened at 7,477.9 points, 52.12 lower than the previous trading session.
A total of 12.20 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.36 billion.
All eight major categories lost ground during the three-hour trading session, with electrical stocks shedding the most at 2.6 percent.

Plastics and chemical shares dropped 2.3 percent, followed by both textile issues and bank and insurance stocks at 2.1 percent, construction shares at 2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.9 percent, cement stocks at 1.8 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.8 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures mostly posted declines.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down 150 points to close at 7,365, while those for December slid 110 points to 7,600, and those for March dropped 59 points to 7,701.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 345, four, and two, respectively.
No transactions were registered on trading for October and June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were listed as 7,515 points for September; 7,530 for October; 7,710 for December; 7,760 for March; and 7,884 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND'S CONSTRUCTION OF NUCLEAR REACTOR DELAYED

TEXT.P: Thailand's plans to build a nuclear reactor will be delayed after the Office of Atomic Energy for Peace failed twice to produce a safety analysis report in the past year.

OAEP Secretary General Kriengsak Bhadarakom said the agency was dissatisfied with the preliminary report prepared by the contractor, US-based General Atomics, as the OAEP failed again to produce a safety analysis report for consideration by the nuclear facility safety subcommittee last week.
GA submitted the first report to OAEP last December but it needed to be revised several times, Kriengsak revealed.
The contract, signed by OAEP and GA on June 26 last year, requires the contractor to complete the report within 48 months.

The subcommittee insisted that the analysis be reviewed by the regulatory body of the vendor's country, but the US Nuclear Regulatory Commission has declined to do so because the reactor is not planned for construction on US soil.
Kriengsak said the report was being reviewed by nuclear experts of the International Atomic Energy Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING SUGGESTS PUTTING THE BRAKES ON PRIVATIZATION

TEXT.P: Beijing called for a slowdown in the sell-off of small state-owned enterprises, underlining its concern that their sale would increase unemployment and undermine social stability.
The call suggests that Beijing's commitment to state sector reform is weakening in the face of slowing economic growth and rising redundancies, according to a report in the Financial Times.

"The spree of selling enterprises is spreading, which disrupts the ongoing work of re-employing laid-off state firm workers. This has triggered serious social problems in some areas," the newspaper quoted the People's Daily as saying.
Regional governments must take urgent measures to arrest the trend, it added.
"Small state firms employ a large number of people and they play an indispensable role in easing unemployment pressure and maintaining social stability," the report said.

The transfer of small state enterprises into private hands was one of the central elements of President Jiang Zemin's address at the Communist Party Congress in September, which was intended to set the country's strategic course for the next five years.

According to official figures, mainland China's state enterprises are due to lay off 3.5 million workers this year alone. There are currently 11.5 million people officially registered as unemployed, but economists privately suggest the true number is much higher.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS TOLD TO BE PREPARED FOR SLOWER GROWTH

TEXT.P: Singaporeans have to brace themselves for slower growth given the region's economic downturn, Singapore Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Sunday.
Little can be done to boost the economy to the 7.8 percent level of growth the city state enjoyed last year, he told reporters at a National Day ceremony.
Noting that the government had introduced a S$2 billion (US$1.1 billion) package of measures in June to help reduce business costs, Lee said introducing such measures was not something done casually.

"We have to accept that this will be a slow year, less growth, smaller bonuses, maybe pay cuts, some retrenchments," he said. "But we are not going to starve. We have been through worse before. So I think we can manage it."
The official growth forecast of between 0.5 percent and 1.5 percent for this year was realistic, he added.

He also urged Singaporeans to stay calm, steady and resolute in the face of criticism from Malaysia of Singapore's decision to move its customs and immigration facilities from the Tanjong Pagar railway station to Woodlands at the border with Malaysia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE IN INDONESIA SAID STILL AT RISK

TEXT.P: Indonesia is unsafe for the thousands of ethnic Chinese who fled the country amid rioting in May as the danger of further violence and rioting remains, according to the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC).

In an interview with The Australian, the Jakarta-based Indonesian government agency made the warning in contrast to a statement by President B.J. Habibie who urged all ethnic Chinese to return to the Southeast Asian country.
"I would be less than honest to say that this is the time to come back," NHRC Deputy Chairman Marzuki Darusman said in Jakarta on Sunday.

The NHRC was established by the Indonesian government to help investigate the circumstances of the May riots. Human rights groups claim that 168 rapes occurred during the riots mainly against Chinese girls and women.

"The targeting of the Chinese has strained relations between Indonesia and China, Taiwan and Singapore. Concerns have also been expressed over continuing damage to the stricken economy caused by the absence of Chinese capital and professional expertise," according to the human rights group.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSMEN THREATEN TO BOYCOTT AUSTRALIAN PM'S PARTY

TEXT.P: Some migrants from Asia, Israel and Iran have expressed anger with Prime Minister John Howard over his handling of the One Nation Party and said they would boycott his Liberal Party in the next federal election.

Some business representatives from Hong Kong and some countries in Southeast Asia are withholding political donations because of Howard's prevarication on the One Nation Party, which is accused of being racist and anti-multiculturalism.
They said they would donate their money to the Labor Party or fund independent candidates who are against the One Nation Party.
These businessmen believe Australia's image has been damaged in Asia by the One Nation Party which makes conducting business in the region more difficult.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar plunged NT$0.181 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at 34.781.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.453, and had a low of 34.8.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$243.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARKETING OF VIAGRA MAY BE POSTPONED

TEXT.P: The anti-impotency drug Viagra may not hit local pharmacies in September as previously expected, a senior official with the Cabinet-level Department of Health said Monday.
Hu Yo-fu, director of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs said US-based Pfizer Co., Viagra's manufacturer, filed an application with the department on June 18 to market the new drug in Taiwan.

"We began to screen the application in early July. We have asked the applicant to furnish us with some additional documents to facilitate our examination of the drug's effectiveness and safety," Hu said.
The additional documents required by the DOH include research reports on 39 foreign nationals suspected to have died from the use of Viagra.
"We need to know the causes of those deaths and their medical history to ascertain the safety of the drug," Hu explained.

The maker is also required to present reports on clinical tests at several local hospitals. "It is a required procedure for the marketing of new drugs on the island," Hu explained, adding that clinical test reports are needed to determine local patients' reaction to the drug and the dosage most suitable for Taiwan users.
Moreover, Hu said, Pfizer must produce documents proving the drug has been permitted to be marketed in Australia since it plans to import Viagra manufactured there to Taiwan.
Hu said even though Viagra has been legally marketed in the United States, the DOH will still strictly follow normal domestic legal proceudres in screening the Pfizer application.
"The legal marketing of Viagra hinges on when the applicant can submit all these required documents," Hu stressed.
As Canberra has not yet issued the green light for marketing the drug in Australia, Taiwan nationals may have a long wait before Viagra is legally available here.

According to previous news reports, over 200 volunteers have undergone clinical tests involving Viagra at the National Taiwan University Hospital, Veterans General Hospital and four other major hospitals in line with application requirements.
Black market prices reportedly have soared up to NT$2,500 (about US$72) here after the US-developed drug caught worldwide attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STRUGGLES AMID ASIA-INDUCED RECESSION

TEXT.P: Australia is seen struggling amid an Asia-induced recession as its major Asian trading partners experience slow economic growth, according to Access Economics in Melbourne.

In its latest five-year business outlook, AE warned that economic growth within Australia's major trading partners will be far slower than the estimate by the Australian government when it presented its annual budget in May this year.
The problems in Asia are turning 1999 into a year of risks, the report said, adding that "Asia is a huge problem for Australia and a recession is far from an impossibility."
AE forecasted gross domestic product growth among Australia's major trading partners at just 0.4 percent in 1998-99, compared to the government's forecast of 1.75 percent.
The report also warned that a second wave of financial turmoil could still engulf Asia as South Korea is being pressured by a weak yen, increased corporate failures and labor unrest.
It added that the US economy may run out of steam just as Asian economies come back on line, causing more problems for Australia.
The AE predicted that Australia's gross domestic product may only reach about 2.1 percent in fiscal 1999-2000, down from the government's forecast of 3.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC SET TO ANNOUNCE PETROLEUM PRICE CUTS

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. said Monday it will likely announce a further cut of petroleum prices Tuesday, and the level of cuts could be within 3 percent.
CPC officials said with the continued slump of international petroleum prices, the purchase cost for the CPC has set lows not seen since 1989.
The CPC imported over 18.72 million barrels of crude in July at a cost of US$217 million, averaging US$11.62 a barrel. Costs in June were US$242 million at an average cost of US$12.6 per barrel.
The officials said CPC revenues in July reached NT$33.88 billion (US$97.36 million), with a pre-tax surplus of NT$4.1 billion, or NT$1.87 billion over the targeted surplus.

They said although the Taiwan dollar has depreciated in the past months, the CPC has met the targeted surplus and it is not ruling out a further crude cut this month with the continued slump of international petroleum prices.
If the CPC announces crude cuts Tuesday, it will be the third such cut this year following two cuts in July.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BOOST BUDGET TO STIMULATE ECONOMIC PROSPERITY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew is expected to discuss a project on expanding domestic demand later this week, an official from the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development said Monday.
Thomas M. F. Yeh, CEPD director of Economic Research Department, said the project is expected to be approved in an Executive Yuan meeting on Thursday.

The implementation of the project is expected to contribute about 0.3 percent to Taiwan's economic growth this year and about 0.6 percent next year, Yeh said. This boost would push Taiwan's economic growth rate in 1998 to about 5.8 percent and nearly 6 percent in 1999.

Siew has earlier indicated that budgets for both fiscal 1999 and 2000 will be increased by NT$100 billion each year to speed up public investment and to expand domestic demand as an effort to boost the economy.
Yeh said by the end of this year, there will be NT$20 billion newly added funds in public investment, and from January to December 1999, there will be NT$48 billion such funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN MONETARY STORM & FLOODS DRAG MAINLAND'S ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Dragged down by the Asian financial turmoil and natural disasters, mainland China's economic growth continued its downward spiral and did not make an upward swing as expected.
Mainland China's gross domestic product rose 7 percent in the first half of 1998, below the 8 percent target Beijing set for the whole year.

Since the beginning of the year, the falling trend of the mainland's economic growth has not ended. It fell to a new low of 6.8 percent in the second quarter of 1998 after registering 7.2 percent in the first quarter.
Facing a downward spiral in economic growth, Beijing confessed in an article in the Hong Kong-based Wen Wei Bao daily that the figures have taken many Beijing authorities by surprise.

Beijing economic experts predicted at the beginning of this year that the slipping economy would bottom out in the first quarter of 1998. In addition, Qiu Xiaohua, chief economist of the State Statistical Bureau under the State Council, forecasted at the end of the first quarter that the mainland's half-year economic growth would surely surpass the figure registered in the first quarter.

The poor performance of mainland China's economy, said Qiu, was due to two unexpected factors, one of which was the lingering effects of increasingly devalued Asian currencies, and the El Nina weather phenomenon which caused serious flooding along the Yangtze River.
Beijing authorities now are pinning their hopes on the economic performance to recover and turn upward in the third quarter of 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: DORNIER-228 PLANES GROUNDED FOR EXAMINATION

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration on Monday ordered all Dornier-228 aircraft in service in Taiwan be temporarily grounded for an across-the-board examination.
The CAA issued the directive after a UNI Airlines Dornier-228 ran off the runway Sunday as it was making a landing at Peikan Airport on the offshore Matsu island group.

It was the second mishap involving this model of aircraft in Taiwan so far this month. On Aug. 5, a Formosa Airlines Dornier-228 also veered off the runway when it landed at Makung Airport on the offshore Penghu archipelago. No injuries or casualties were reported in either accident.
Initial investigations show that both incidents were caused by failure in the aircraft's brake systems.
In August 1997, a Formosa Airlines Dornier-228 crashed in Matsu, killing all 16 crew members and passengers aboard.

"In view of the comparatively high frequency of accidents involving the German-made 19-seat aircraft, we have decided to ground all Dornier-228s for thorough examinations and maintenance," CAA Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said at a news conference.
Among domestic airlines, only Formosa Airlines and UNI Airlines have Dornier-228 aircraft. Each carrier has three Dornier-228s for flight services between Taiwan and its offshore islands.
The CAA's order has forced the two carriers to suspend a total of 53 Taipei-Matsu, Taitung-Green Island, Taitung-Orchid Island, Kaohsiung-Taitung, and Chimei-Makung daily flights.
It will take at least two days to complete examinations and maintenance, airline sources said.

In the interim, passengers between Taipei and Matsu must rely on chopper services offered by Daily Air Corp., while travelers between Taitung and Orchid Island must resort to Asia Pacific Airlines' chopper services.

Meanwhile, the CAA has demanded UNI Airlines to reduce the number of its daily flights because of the frequency of flight accidents. In July alone, 14 mishaps involving the carrier were reported. Nearly all mishaps involved the carrier's BAE-146 aircraft.

CAA Deputy Director-General Chang attributed the frequency of flight mishaps mainly to the carrier's merge with Great China Airlines and Taiwan Airlines on July 1, which resulted in a serious shortage of maintenance manpower.
"To ensure flight safety and protect personal safety of passengers, we must demand UNI Airlines to trim the number of its daily flights," Chang said.
Chang said the CAA is still discussing with the carrier the exact number of flights to be cut. "We'll make a formal announcement after a final decision is made.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL OPTIMISTIC ABOUT KOO'S PLANNED VISIT

TEXT.P: A planned visit to mainland China by Taiwan's chief negotiator with Beijing this fall will be realized smoothly despite the recent twists and turns in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a Kuomintang official predicted on Monday.

Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the KMT's Department of Mainland Research, said he is cautiously optimistic about relations across the Taiwan Strait in the coming months despite the kidnap and murder in northeastern mainland China of Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan in late July and the recent verbal sparring between the intermediary bodies on either side of the strait.
Chang returned to Taipei on Sunday after traveling to Beijing and Shanghai to take part in seminars on cross-strait affairs.

During his visit, Chang met with Chen Yunlin, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under Beijing's State Council, who also serves as director of the Office for Taiwan Affairs under the Chinese Communist Party. He also met with mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chairman Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Although he exchanged views on cross-strait ties with Chen and Wang, as well as issues surrounding the planned mainland visit by Koo Chen-fu, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Chang described the meetings as courtesy calls rather than negotiations.

Addressing the issues arising from the Lin murder, Chang said he told the mainland Chinese authorities that Taiwan's populace is well-informed as a result of the island's efficient mass media. This led to widespread anger in Taiwan when the mainland authorities failed to abide by requests from Lin's family regarding the treatment of her body, and when they barred SEF personnel from helping to deal with the situation.

He said although the mainland authorities told him that Koo is welcome to visit this fall, he suggested that a meeting between SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow and his ARATS counterpart, Tang Shubei, be arranged prior to Koo's arrival, in order to discuss procedural details of the visit.
The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LEADERS MEET IN BEIDAIHE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Beijing leaders are in Beidaihe for their annual conference on important problems facing the nation, the Hong Kong Economic Journal reported Monday.

High on the agenda of the conference are economic issues, including the possible economic performance of the nation in the second half of this year, the progress of state-enterprise reform, and the measures to stabilize the currency amid Asian financial crisis.
Problems caused by the flooding along the Yangtze River and its tributaries this summer will also be discussed at the meeting, the report said.
One of the important items to be discussed is the formation of several conglomerates in the country, which will be similar to those of South Korea in many aspects, the report said.
Mainland Chinese delegations visited South Korea and several other countries last month to study the management and operations of their big enterprises, it added.
Beidaihe is a seaside summer resort some 160 miles from Beijing. Top government leaders meet there once a year for discussion of important national issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: NINETY-ONE DISSIDENTS PROTEST WANG YOUCAI'S ARREST

TEXT.P: Ninety-one dissidents from 21 mainland Chinese cities and provinces have jointly issued an open letter, calling for the release of Wang Youcai, who have been arrested for attempting to establish an opposition party in mainland China.

Wang, who applied with the government for establishing a preparatory committee for the formation of an opposition "Chinese Democratic Party" in Hangzhou, the capital city of Zejiang Province in eastern mainland China, on June 25, was taken away from his home by police on July 10, and was formally arrested Saturday on charges of inciting people to overthrow "the country's ruling power."

The New York-based Human Rights in China (HRIC) said Monday that, in the letter the 91 dissidents also called for the release of Zhang Shanguang, who was arrested for attempting to establish an association for protecting the rights of laid-off workers in Hunan Province.

The open letter said that what Wang and Zhang have done are conducive to political modernization in mainland China, and that their behavior is consistent with mainland Chinese law and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

Under mainland China law, inciting people to overthrow the government is a serious crime. It is feared that Wang will be indicted. Fifty-three dissidents in Zhejiang Province issued an open letter Saturday, calling for Wang's release.

Meanwhile, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Monday in a press release that Xu Wenli of Beijing will go to Hangzhou with other dissidents during Wang's trial. They may stage a demonstration in that city during that time. They said they would be pleased to go to jail for doing that.
Wang, 32, was one of the student leaders most wanted by police for their role in the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL OFFICIAL CALLS FOR MORE VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: An official of the Mackay Memorial Hospital called on Monday for more people to participate in volunteer work at the hospital.

The official said that people aged between 18 and 65 with a good command of Mandarin and Taiwanese are welcome to register as volunteers if they can provide their services for at least three hours each week. Volunteers must undertake a 12-hour training course before taking up their duties, he said.
The call coincided with the release of statistics showing that nearly 87 percent of the volunteers at the hospital are female.

The official said that Mackay has a total of 562 volunteers, 487 of whom are women and 75 of whom are men. Forty-four percent of the volunteers described themselves as followers of Buddhism, while 22 percent said that they are Christians.

Although the general belief is that volunteers are usually middle-aged, elderly, or housewives, the statistics show that a number of young people and career people also dedicate a portion of their time to hospital volunteer work.
Nearly 40 percent of the volunteers at the hospital are aged between 21 to 40, with those aged between 21 to 30 accounting for 17 percent of the total, the statistics show.
The statistics also show that 36 percent of the volunteers hold full-time jobs, while only 39 percent are housewives.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY TRANSACTION TAX REVENUE DROPS TO NT$8.2 BILLION

TEXT.P: The revenue from securities transaction taxes in July totaled NT$8.2 billion, a drop of 50.4 percent in comparison with the same month of last year, and a record low since March 1996, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced on Monday.
Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the MOF's Department of Accounting, attributed the drop in revenue to impact from the Asian financial turmoil and economic slowdown.

According to statistics compiled by the MOF, total national tax revenue in July totaled NT$150.01 billion, a decrease of NT$1.8 billion, or 1.2 percent, compared with the corresponding month of last year.

The decline was attributed to a drop of NT$8.4 billion, or 50.4 percent, in securities transaction taxes; followed by a decrease of NT$3.2 billion, or 32.8 percent, in commodities taxes, for a total of NT$6.6 billion; and a drop of NT$3 billion, or 21.2 percent, in land taxes, for a total of NT$11.1 billion.
However, the revenue from income taxes in July totaled NT$54.9 billion, an increase of NT$10.5 billion, or 23.5 percent, from the same month of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM HU DENIES ADJUSTMENT OF FOREIGN POLICY

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu denied on Monday that the government will adjust its foreign policy by stressing "quality" instead of "quantity."

Hu dismissed as "untrue" the press reports that the Republic of China will no longer focus on forging ties with small-sized countries and will devote more energy to upgrading substantive relations with influential or powerful countries.
"The reports don't fit the facts," Hu stressed, adding that the ROC has consistently intended to make friends with as many countries as possible.

Hu went on to say that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has attached equal importance to quality and quantity in expanding its external ties and diplomatic frontiers. "What we care most in seeking foreign friends is sincerity."

In the face of Beijing's constant attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community, Hu said, the ROC must try its utmost to make friends with as many countries as possible, no matter how large or how small those countries may be. "This is our country's demand and the MOFA's policy."

Hu, also a National Assembly deputy, said he has been carrying out his diplomatic duties using the fundamental guideline of political campaign -- "Shaking hands with every hand you can shake and knocking on every door you can knock."
"With this in mind, we are unlikely to adopt a discriminatory attitude in forging ties with countries around the world," Hu added.
Meanwhile, Hu said the MOFA has spared no efforts to contain the possible adverse effect of the so-called "three noes" toward Taiwan.

The "three noes" refer to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.
The Beijing-proposed "three noes" came into the limelight after US President Bill Clinton mentioned them at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai during his June 25-July 3 state visit to mainland China.
Beijing reportedly is pushing Tokyo to throw its support for the "three noes" during mainland President Jiang Zemin's state visit to Japan in September.

Commenting on the reports, Hu said he hopes all of the ROC's diplomatic allies and countries in the Asia-Pacific region will understand that if they indiscriminatingly yield to Beijing's unreasonable demands, they will incessantly be required to make concessions to Beijing.

"We are also hopeful that Beijing will understand that if it continues taking advantage of its engagement with other countries to hurt Taiwan's position, relations across the Taiwan Strait cannot make headway and unification of the two sides will only be hindered," Hu stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MULTI-PURPOSE SMART CARDS TO BE ISSUED IN 2001

TEXT.P: A multi-purpose electronic "smart card" is expected to be ready for issue in 2001 at the earliest, the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said on Monday.

The smart card project, which will combine the present ID card with the national insurance card, and various other electronic cards, is currently in the planning stages by the RDEC and will be pushed by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI).
BNHI officials said the new card will help reduce abuse of the country's medical resources.

They said that the issuance of the smart card will cut bureaucracy, help the bureau trace those who fail to pay their insurance premiums, and help in the computerization of the island's medical institutions.

The card will also prevent tampering by the public or by the hospitals, as cardholders will be unable to lend their cards to others, which the officials say will greatly save valuable medical resources.
The right to issue the card was awarded to a 15-member consortium headed by the China Rebar Group, which beat out bids by three competing consortiums, RDEC Chairman Kirby Yang said.

The four consortiums presented their proposals on June 30, and a screening committee comprised of seven scholars and four government officials conducted the screening on Sunday, announcing the result the following day.

Yang said that the winning consortium, named the Republic of China Card Management Team, will begin discussions with the government on a formal contract to issue the smart card within three months. After the signing of the contract, the consortium is expected to take 30 months to prepare for the issuance of the card, giving a projected launch date of 2001 at the earliest.
If the contract falls through, the committee will start the screening process from scratch.
Yang stressed that the screening operation focused on overall planning, professional management capacity, and financial planning, adding that the winning consortium stood out in all three key areas.
He said the card is expected to simplify paperwork in the government and private sectors, which will help boost the efficiency of an "electronic government."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ISSUES WARNING AGAINST TRAVELING TO CAMBODIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs on Monday issued a warning against traveling to Cambodia, suggesting that all unnecessary visits to the country by ROC nationals be avoided.

Ministry officials said that travel to the country is not recommended, as the elections held on July 26 have led to an unstable political and economic situation there. Public security has deteriorated and the environment is currently unsuitable for business activities, the officials said.
Information on the situation as it develops, and necessary assistance, will be offered by ROC representative offices based in Ho Chi Minh City and in Bangkok.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY PLEDGES TO ELIMINATE ELECTION BRIBERY

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party will offer a reward of NT$1 million (US$28,800) to anyone who informs on bribery in the party primary elections for legislative candidates, Jaw Shau-kong, a high-ranking party official, said on Monday.

The supervisor for the party's campaign affairs stressed during a press conference that his party will at the same time impose harsh punishment on bribery and vote-buying culprits, including denunciation and expulsion from the party.
However, although there have already been reports of dirty deeds in the primaries since they started on Aug. 1, the party will never give up its campaign, described by Jaw as an exercise democracy.
The island's second-largest opposition party has so far held four primaries for candidates for the legislature and for the city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung cities in the year-end elections.
Vote-buying has been rampant during all the primary elections, with the two most recent cases coming to light on Sunday in Taichung and Taoyuan counties, respectively, according to party officials.

It has also been reported that several candidates are planning to hire public relations companies to increase their voter base and provide additional vote-buying channels, as voting in the New Party primaries is not restricted only to party members but is open to all voters, the officials said.

The press conference followed a meeting of New Party leaders to discuss election irregularities. Those taking part included: Jaw; Chou Yang-shan, convener of the National Campaign and Development Committee; Lee Sheng-feng, who is in charge of primary elections planning affairs; Legislator Hau Long-ping; and Chen Kuei-miao, convener of a task force supervising the party's election affairs in Taiwan's northern area.

In order to reinforce their determination to eliminate election bribery, the party has contracted three credit information firms to investigate and collect evidence to support the findings of the seven-member task force.

Jaw stressed that if the party cannot elect candidates of good character who can speak for the Taiwan people and who can maintain the New Party's "clean image" in the Legislative Yuan, they will consider scrapping the primaries and adopting a "flexible nomination" whereby candidates will be selected by the party leadership.
The New Party was founded in August 1993 by a group of disgruntled Kuomintang members who broke away from the ruling party in protest against its "undemocratic practices."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SHOULD ENJOY SOVEREIGN RIGHTS IN INTERNATIONAL COMMUNITY: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew stressed on Monday that the Republic of China is a sovereign country which should have the right to take its place as a full member of the international community.
Siew made the remarks while receiving a delegation of Japan's Association for Japan-ROC Friendship headed by Kobayashi Tatsuya.
Tatsuya and his group paid a courtesy call on the premier at the Executive Yuan, accompanied by Lin Chin-ching, chairman of Taiwan's Association of East Asian Relations.

Commenting on the "three noes" remarks made by US President Bill Clinton in Shanghai, Siew pointed out that since the Republic of China is a sovereign country, there is no need for it to declare independence.
Therefore, he added, the US refusal to support Taiwan independence, and its refusal to support "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," has no significant meaning for the ROC.
Siew stressed that until unification of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the ROC and the Chinese mainland will remain separate political entities on an equal footing.

He added that in order to seek its own international space, the ROC has the right to take part in international community affairs, and is therefore firmly opposed to and will not accept the US refusal to support Taiwan's membership in international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.

The premier thanked his guests for their long-term promotion of ROC-Japanese exchanges in the fields of economy and culture, and for helping overseas Chinese working and studying in Japan. He also expressed his hope that the association, which has great influence at the grassroots level in Japan, will continue to enhance the substantive ties between the two countries.

On July 24, the association held its general meeting, when it passed a resolution asking the Japanese government not to make remarks similar to those made by Clinton, when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin makes a state visit to Tokyo in September.
The request, in the form of a petition, has been submitted to Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN POLICE EXAM SCAM

TEXT.P: A computer expert at the Central Police University was arrested on Monday for allegedly manipulating police entrance exam results in exchange for big-figure bribes, police officials said.

Kuo Chen-yuan, former director of the university's Electronic Computing Center, was apprehended at his girlfriend's house. Police had been looking for Kuo following a report on Friday from university President Hsieh Ruey-chi.
During an initial police interrogation, Kuo denied all the accusations against him.

Kuo, 37, is believed to have altered the report cards of 43 participants in the entrance exam for the two-year course. Each of the examinees reportedly paid between NT$1 million and NT$1.5 million to several unidentified brokers, who investigators said might also be police officers.

The stringent exam, which is open only to incumbent police officers and graduates of the junior police college, means that the school has a very low admission rate. This year, for example, only 205 out of nearly 15,000 examinees advanced to the oral stage, which was held earlier this month.

Kuo had already been demoted and removed from his position as head of the computing center before the exam was held on July 10-11, although he was still on the university's staff. However, as the designer of the university's computerized examination grading and scoring system, he was invited to provide assistance in operating the system, giving him the chance to alter the scores.

Kuo might have got away with his crime, had it not been for Hsieh's determination to eradicate irregularities in the exams. For years rumors have been circulating of cheating in the Central Police University entrance exams, but they had not been taken seriously until Hsieh was appointed university president last July.

After being tipped off that Kuo had manipulated several report cards, Hsieh decided to mobilize 200 university faculty and students to check the English exam answer cards for inconsistencies. The week-long task revealed that 43 scores had been altered. Checks on scores for other subjects confirmed the findings.
Police have also questioned most of the 43 examinees, some of whom have reportedly admitted paying bribes to Kuo.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY LEAVES FOR PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, left for Paraguay on Monday in his capacity as Lee's special envoy, to attend the inauguration of Paraguay's President-elect Paul Cubas Grau.
Speaking prior to his departure from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Huang said he feels honored and delighted to have been chosen as Lee's envoy for the ceremony slated for Aug. 15.

Paraguay has long been a close ally of the Republic of China, and has always given its firm support to the ROC's bids for participation in international activities, Huang said, noting that the ROC government values this friendship.
He added that in addition to participating in the inauguration, he will meet with ranking Paraguayan officials to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.
He will also meet with ethnic Chinese living in Paraguay, and visit an ROC Agricultural Technical Mission stationed in the South American nation.
Huang and his entourage are scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INTERVIEWED BY FORBES (I)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's relative success amid the region's financial turmoil can largely be attributed to its democratic system and sound economic fundamentals, Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said in a recent Forbes magazine interview.
Describing the island's economic performance as being the "sturdiest" in the region, the article sought to determine what set Taiwan apart from its regional neighbors.

Touching on a variety of topics including the conditions for Asian economic recovery, US President Bill Clinton's comments on the "three noes" and mainland China's emerging role as a regional leader, Siew gave an interview to Andrew Tanzer for an article in the Aug. 24 issue of Forbes.

The premier identified Taiwan's democratic system, its tight control over the banking system, and its resilient enterprises as key to minimizing the damaging effects of the region's financial and economic woes.

"Democracy creates more transparency between government and the business community. Democracy also helps the government to face the crisis," Siew said, adding, "Taiwan's democratic system, legal institutions and the free press all work to monitor relations between government and business and reduce the likelihood that the government will steer its banks to funnel capital to the consortiums it favors."
The government has strict control over the banking system -- the proportion of overdue loans made by banks is less than 4 percent, Siew stated.
Also, the fact that 98 percent of Taiwan's domestic industry is composed of small- and medium-sized enterprises makes them more resilient and flexible when responding to external elements.
Siew said the quality of Taiwan's goods has continually risen, with high-tech products emerging as the mainstream of Taiwan's production and exports.

He added that the financial structure for domestic enterprises has remained good. The capital-to-assets ratio of Taiwan enterprises is 53.9 percent -- much higher than the ratio in South Korea and Japan -- so the debt ratio is lower.
Other contributing factors were a lack of dependency on foreign capital and the fact that the New Taiwan dollar was not overvalued.

In response to the question of economic recovery, Siew listed three necessary conditions which were political stability in Indonesia, the restoration of Japan's consumer confidence and Beijing maintaining its promise to not devalue the renminbi. If all these conditions are met, recovery could take one or two years, he predicted.

When asked whether the lack of democracy was going to slow down the mainland's growth, Siew said that if one looked at the history of economic development in modern countries, one would see that after a certain period of economic growth, people would want to see political reform, so that the benefits of economic growth can be shared.
"That's what we're seeing in Indonesia now. That happened in Taiwan 10 years ago, but we had a quiet revolution," Siew said.
The issue between Taiwan and the mainland is a conflict of systems, the premier said in response to a question of reunification.

"Only a good system that will bring the whole of China toward modernization and provide for the welfare of the people can serve as a foundation for unification," Siew said. "We have a very clear objective: We will pursue peaceful unification on the principles of democracy, freedom and equitable prosperity."

The premier also spoke on US President Bill Clinton's comments on the "three noes" -- no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two China" or "one Taiwan, one China" and no support for Taiwan's membership in any organizations for which statehood is a requirement -- when he visited the mainland recently.

Siew said that the talks between Clinton and his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin have not directly resulted in any substantive harm to Taiwan, and both President Clinton and US policy officials have repeatedly stated that US policy toward the Republic of China remains unchanged. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER (II)
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By David Wang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nevertheless, Siew said that President Clinton's statement has caused a considerable degree of misunderstanding in the international community and especially among nations friendly to the Republic of China.

"Although Clinton's declaration had negative implications, the US president also made numerous comments favorable to the ROC, including twice calling on Beijing -- and only Beijing -- to resume bilateral talks as soon as possible. This shows that the US understands Taipei's sincerity in seeking to resume consultations with Beijing," Siew said.

He noted that President Clinton on five occasions repeated that the cross-strait questions should be resolved by peaceful means. At a time when the mainland repeatedly refuses to renounce the use of military force against Taiwan, these remarks were particularly significant. Even more significant, Siew said, was Clinton's clear rejection of Beijing's position on US arms sales to Taiwan.

Responding to the possibility that China may emerge from the regional financial crisis as the leader of Asia, Siew noted that one of the greatest obstacles to the continued development of the mainland economy was institutional.

He said that most state-run enterprises in the mainland are losing money and have been unable to repay bank loans. This accumulated bad debt represents a crisis in the making. Unemployment on the mainland has risen, social order has deteriorated, and political and administration reforms have been implemented too slowly. The economy still lags far behind such an economic powerhouse as Japan.
The interview titled "We had a quiet revolution," also featured a photo of Siew showing him full of confidence with his trademark smile and the ROC national flag in the background.
