DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET DEMAND TO INCREASE IN EUROPE

TEXT.P: Demand for Internet access is on the rise throughout Europe as businesses increase use of the network and a greater number of consumers move online.

According Forrester's European research center, overall Internet access spending in Europe will climb from US$2.5 billion in 1998 to US$11.8 billion in 2001. Driven by the growth of Internet commerce in Europe, business access and not consumer access will be the primary source of revenue by 2001.
As larger companies pull their partners online and fend off incursions from global competitors, there will be a surge in demand for new connections and more bandwidth, the center said.

The demand from large- and medium-sized companies will generate 77 percent of business access expenditures in 2001. In contrast, small businesses which account for more than 90 percent of enterprises in the region will stick to simple dial-up accounts, contributing a considerably smaller share to overall growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S ECONOMY SLOWS TO 1.6% IN 2ND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Singapore's economy slowed further in the second quarter of this year to 1.6 percent from the revised 6.1 percent in the first quarter, the Economic Development Board announced Tuesday.
The slowdown was attributed to the adverse developments in the global electronics industry, which had an adverse effect on Singapore's manufacturing industry and in turn, its service exports.

Growth in all sectors moderated, the EDB said. Signaling deteriorating growth momentum, the manufacturing sector turned in two consecutive quarters of negative quarter-on-quarter growth while the commerce sector registered a third consecutive quarter of quarter-on-quarter decline.

Manufacturing output shrank by 1.1 percent on a year-on-year basis, down from 6.1 percent growth in the first quarter, the EDB said. Nearly all segments shrank, or grew more slowly than in the first quarter.

Despite healthy US and European Union economies, a worsening industry supply-and-demand imbalance, sharp price erosion and intense competition combined to cut Singapore's electronics output by 7 percent.

Stock market activity was healthy, but this largely reflected selling pressures arising from a slew of unfavorable news including uncertainty over the Japanese economic reform, the weakness of the yen, Indonesia's May riots and weak corporate performance, the EDB said.

Singapore's trade performance weakened significantly as total trade declined by 7.7 percent in the second quarter compared to registering a 4.2 percent growth in the first quarter. Total exports declined by 1.2 percent.

The EDB predicted that Singapore's economic growth will weaken further in the remainder of the year. The Singapore Ministry of Trade and Industry is maintaining its economic growth forecast to 0.5 percent to 1.5 percent for 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUNK FOOD, LARGE QUANTITIES OF MEAT SEEN CONTRIBUTING TO CANCER

TEXT.P: The heavy consumption of meat and junk food loaded with sulfur preservatives is turning people's digestive systems into war zones between natural healthy microbes and bad bugs which can cause colon cancer.

Research by Dr. John Cummings of the Dunn Nutrition Unit in Cambridge found that when daily meat consumption rises from 60 grams to 600 grams, sulfides in the feces of patients increase tenfold, the Sydney Morning Herald reported Tuesday.

Cummings said these toxic sulfides might promote cancerous changes in gut cells by damaging their DNA. He plans to continue with his research to determine how much sulfur people typically consume and how much of this total is derived from meat and food additives.

A leading Australian researcher at the Department of Surgery at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Adelaide in South Australia told the daily that he had tried unsuccessfully to get funding for similar research in Australia.
However, Assistant Professor William Roediger said the latest British research reinforced the health message that people should eat much more fiber than meat and resist processed foods.
He said sulfur has been used as a preservative for thousands of years in beverages but modern people consume far more because it is also used to preserve foods on store shelves.
Roediger said he has found a link between sulfides and the disease colitis. Meanwhile, Cummings said he believed sulfur bacteria could be implicated in a range of bowel diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.029 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 34.81.
The local currency opened at 34.795, and was traded between 34.75 and 34.85.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$225 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF IMPORTED DENGUE FEVER CASES REACH 51: DOH

TEXT.P: There are 51 confirmed imported cases of dengue fever so far this year, over twice the number from the same period last year, Department of Health officials said Tuesday.
Officials said the 51st patient was a 46-year-old woman who became ill after traveling to Burma and was diagnosed as having dengue fever on Monday.
Hsu Hsu-mei, deputy director of DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said compared to the 22 imported cases of dengue fever last year, this year's number is obviously too high.

Hsu also confirmed that the patients all contracted the disease from Southeast Asia. Thailand topped the list with 15 cases, followed by 10 cases contracted from the Philippines, and nine and seven cases from Indonesia and Burma respectively.

Among the 51 patients, 12 cases are reported in Taipei County, eight cases from Kaohsiung City, and six cases each in Pingtung and Taoyuan Counties. The remainder of the cases were scattered in other regions around the island.

DOH officials again urged the public to exercise great care when traveling to Southeast Asia. They also advised travelers to upgrade their accommodations to cleaner facilities to prevent the contraction of diseases spread by infected mosquitoes.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'NO MORE FLIGHT DELAYS', TRANSASIA AIRWAYS TOLD

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has asked TransAsia Airways to improve its problems in meeting flight schedules after receiving complaints from passengers.

CAA officials on Tuesday also threatened to cut the number of TransAsia' flights if it fails to address the problem accordingly. As a remedy for its revenue loss in recent years, TransAsia has recently adopted a wage cut package.

Employees have apparently contributed to flight delays as a means to demonstrate their dissatisfaction with the package, and the delays in recent days have caused a large number of passengers to complain.
Saying that the CAA will not intervene with the management of an airline, the officials said that any measures airlines take should not affect the interests of their passengers.
Continued delays will result in the suspension of some of the flights TransAsia has been permitted to fly, the CAA said. Any delay beyond 15 minutes from the boarding time is considered a delay.
TransAsia officials said the wage cuts were made as a last resort, but they believed the airline's wage level is still one of the best among local airlines.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES ANOTHER OIL PRICES CUT

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. announced yet another oil price cut on Tuesday to reflect its reduced crude oil import costs.
Starting Wednesday, domestic prices for a variety of petroleum products will be lowered by an average of 1.53 percent, a CPC spokesman said.
This is the third time since July that the CPC has offered an across-the-board price cut for its products amid a downward spiral in international crude oil prices.
After the adjustment, the retail price for premium gasoline will drop to NT$17.6 (US$0.51) per liter from the current NT$17.8, while the price for fuel oil will be slashed by NT$82 per kiloliter.
The price for 95-unleaded gasoline will decline to NT$17.4 from NT$17.6 and 92-unleaded gasoline will be cut to NT$16.4 from NT$16.6.
The price for high-grade diesel will fall to NT$12.5 from NT$12.7, while normal-grade diesel will slide to NT$11.3 from NT$11.5.
Meanwhile, prices for household-use and vehicle-use liquefied petroleum gas will be cut by NT$0.19 and NT$0.1 per kilogram, respectively.

The CPC spokesman said the new prices were calculated based on three criteria -- crude oil prices at NT$13.55 per barrel, the currency exchange rate at NT$34.52 against the US dollar, and the annual profit target at NT$22.2 billion.

With weak crude oil prices in the international market, CPC's crude import costs dropped to an average of US$11.62 a barrel in July, the lowest level in more than a decade. As a result, the state monopoly registered a pre-tax profit of NT$4.1 billion for the month, or NT$1.87 billion over the targeted surplus.
Against this background, the CPC decided to further lower prices for its products starting Wednesday.
The company first offered a 1.57 percent cut in prices for its products on July 1, and again trimmed its prices by an average of 1.28 percent on July 22.

The CPC has conducted a weekly review of domestic petroleum prices since March, enabling the company to adjust its prices in tandem with international crude oil prices and the local currency's exchange rate against the greenback.

Economic observers said the CPC's oil price cuts will help maintain domestic price stability. Nevertheless, another state monopoly, Taiwan Power Co. said it will not lower its electricity rates because the latest CPC price cut will have only a limited effect on its power generation costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AN FENG STEEL TEMPORARILY SUSPENDS PROJECT IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung-based An Feng Steel Corp. has temporarily put its US$1.1 billion steel construction project plans for Australia on hold due to the Asian crisis and falling steel prices.
The planned joint venture between An Feng and Kingstream Resources in Perth was put on hold after funding for the operation was suspended, Kingstream Vice Chairman Ken Court said Monday.
Kingstream's Taiwan steel subsidiaries have had to pursue debt restructuring options with the China Development Corporation in Taipei with a view to eliminating debts approaching US$560 million.
"We really are in the hands now of China Development Corp. And while the Taiwanese seem to prefer short-term debt contracts, we'd like to see them extended over a much longer term," Court said.
He said a fall in demand for steel products and a slump in world steel prices have severely affected the financial position of the company's Taiwanese steel operations.

The steel company is now negotiating the terms of an engineering, procurement, construction and management contract with Japan's Mitsui and Co., Ltd. in which Mitsui will arrange US$675 million in financing for the joint venture project, which is expected to produce 2.6 million metric tonnes of steel a year after construction is completed in the next two years.

Court said stage one of the project, including some leveling for the steel plant, had been completed at a cost of around US$2.7 million, but stage two would not begin until a debt restructuring of the Taiwanese entities had been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX, FUTURES EXCHANGE DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 11.86 points to close at 7,383.98.
The bourse opened at 7,361.19 points, 10.93 lower than Monday's closing.

A total of 12.83 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$63.68 billion, increasing slightly from the previous trading session which saw 12.29 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$63.36 billion.

Three of the eight major categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by construction shares at 0.4 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.2 percent.

Three other categories posted a loss, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 0.6 percent, followed by both plastics and chemical stocks, and textile issues at 0.3 percent, while both cement shares and electrical stocks remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures mostly posted declines.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down five points to close at 7,360, while those for December slid 20 points to 7,580, and those for March dropped 20 points to 7,630.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 386, one, and 15, respectively.
No transactions were registered on trading for October and June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were listed as 7,365 points for September; 7,380 for October; 7,600 for December; 7,650 for March; and 7,734 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI TO HOST ANNUAL STEEL INDUSTRY CONFERENCE IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will, for the first time, host the annual meeting of the International Iron and Steel Institute (IISI) from Oct. 4 to 7 at the Taipei International Convention Center.
China Steel Corp., the only IISI member in Taiwan, represented the island in a bid to host the 32nd IISI meeting in April last year.
Over 600 steel industry representatives from 53 countries are expected to participate in the event.
President Lee Teng-hui and other high-level government officials have been invited to address the conference.

The IISI was founded in Brussels in 1967. It has six committees which hold periodical seminars regarding technology, environmental affairs, human resources, economic studies, raw materials, as well as promotion and market development. (by Leah Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: WHY MAINLAND CHINA DOESN'T DEVALUE ITS CURRENCY

TEXT.P: Beijing is being praised for not devaluing its currency despite suffering from fewer exports and a lower economic growth rate than forecasted, the Australian Financial Review said Tuesday.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the daily's correspondent Rowan Callick said mainland China has received kudos for keeping the renminbi at a rate of about 8.3 to the greenback. The exchange rate in the black market however is over 9 renminbi to the dollar.
Callick said mainland China is beginning to emerge as the United States' favored ally in Asia, supplanting Japan and disorienting Taiwan, since US President Bill Clinton's visit to the mainland.

With the relative strength in the renminbi, Western leaders and investors are overlooking growing problems elsewhere in the mainland's economy, Callick noted, saying that it is being compared favorably to Japan which has been unable to take a lead in solving its economic problems.

Beijing recognizes that devaluing its currency to an excess of 20 percent may contribute to a downside which could translate into a massive loss in mainland China's domestic confidence. It could also send the stock exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen plummeting, reducing the prospects of raising capital to reform the state sector, Callick wrote.

Mainland authorities have already acted to boost exports in a more targeted way than devaluing the currency. Premier Zhu Rongji has also been forced to extend the deadlines for reform in state-run enterprises.

Neither mainland China nor Hong Kong are being driven to devalue their currencies by a lack of funds. The mainland holds US$141 billion and Hong Kong US$97 billion in foreign exchange reserves. Since the renminbi is not convertible on the capital account, the mainland Chinese government and not the market holds the upper hand, leading analysts to believe the currency will not be devalued at least until the end of this year, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO URGES DIALOGUE WITH ASIAN NATIONS ON FINANCIAL PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Taipei's top negotiator with Beijing on Tuesday called for a meeting among Asian leaders including both sides of the Taiwan Strait to discuss the region's financial problems if the Japanese yen continues its plunge.
"A game of devaluation" may take place across Asia if the Japanese currency slides further, said Koo Chen-fu, Senior Advisor to the President and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation.
He added that Taipei could do something to interfere in its foreign exchanges although only on a limited scale.
Koo made the remarks to the media after attending a meeting at the invitation of the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan.

The burden of economic reform in Japan has resulted in much pressure on the depreciation of the yen, Koo stated. He went on to say that given a continued sagging yen, an adverse effect on Asia as a whole can occur which may lead to "a game of devaluation" in the region or even a new wave of monetary turmoil.
It is hard to predict when the yen will stop sliding, Koo said, but the New Taiwan dollar is truly over-devalued.

Responding to the question of what was a reasonable value for Taiwan's currency, Koo said it was difficult to determine as the foreign exchange rate is a "relative issue" and no financial minister of any country would dare assert a reasonable value for a currency.

Regarding what measures Taipei should take, Koo said the government should take some action, although interference should be limited. This was because a high New Taiwan dollar would not do us much good, Koo observed.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK CHIEF SECRETARY DUE TO VISIT SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Chief Secretary Anson Chan is due to arrive in Singapore for a three-day visit Thursday, the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office in Singapore announced.

Chan is scheduled to meet Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew and Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. She is expected to attend a dinner hosted by Foreign Minister S. Jayakumar and call on mainland China's ambassador to Singapore Chen Baoliu.
Upon her arrival, Chan will deliver a speech at the 14th Gordon Ransome Arthur Oration at the Mandarin Hotel. Her lecture is titled "Continuity and Change" and centers on Hong Kong's civil service.
The lecture, held once every two years since 1971, is the highlight of the Singapore-Malaysia Congress of Medicine. It is organized by the Council of the Academy of Medicine in Singapore.

The Hong Kong official is also scheduled to attend a breakfast meeting with key members of the Hong Kong-Singapore Business Association on Friday, and will later address a business luncheon hosted jointly by the Hong Kong Economic and Trade Office in Singapore and the Singapore International Chamber of Commerce.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE DISSIDENTS CALL FOR WANG YOUCAI'S RELEASE

TEXT.P: The number of mainland Chinese dissidents calling for the release of dissident Wang Youcai have increased from 53 on Saturday to 91 on Sunday and 136 on Monday.

Wang was formally arrested Saturday by the Public Security Bureau in Hangzhou, the capital city of Zhejiang Province , after he applied with the provincial government on June 25 for establishing a preparatory committee for the formation of an opposition "Chinese Democratic Party." He was taken away from his home by police on July 10, and then formally arrested on charges of inciting people "to overthrow the country's ruling power."

The 136 dissidents jointly sent a letter to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji Monday through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, asking for immediate release of Wang from jail. It is feared that Wang will be indicted.

In the letter the 136 dissidents expressed anger at Wang's arrest. They said that Wang was merely exercising a citizen's basic rights enshrined in the Constitution when he applied for permission to set up the preparatory committee, and that his arrest has given rise to the grave concern of many people in the world.

Meanwhile, 40 dissidents jointly filed an application with the Changsha City People's Government on Aug. 6 for permission to stage a demonstration in Changsha, the capital city of Hunan Province, in order to call for the release of Wang and Chang Shanguang. Chang has been arrested for attempting to establish an association to protect the rights of laid-off workers in Hunan Province. The application has not been approved so far, the information center said Monday in a press release.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT IN POLICE EXAM SCAM ADMITS TO CRIMINAL ACT

TEXT.P: The key suspect in a police exam scandal involving the Central Police University admitted that he manipulated the police entrance exam results through the university's computer system in exchange for bribes.

Kuo Chen-yuan, 35, former acting director of the university's computer center, told police that he received bribes ranging from NT$300,000 to NT$500,000 from a dozen examinees through brokers in March and April.

Kuo said the money was remitted to his three bank accounts. He also claimed it was the first time he had rigged the entrance exam for the two-year university course despite the fact that he assumed the post in 1994.

However, the preliminary police investigation revealed that Kuo had altered the report cards of at least 43 participants in the exam, which was open only to incumbent police officers who were graduates of the junior police college.
In addition, after being interrogated, 14 of the 43 police officers on suspension have admitted paying between NT$800,000 and NT$1.5 million in exchange for higher scores in the difficult exam.

Some 9,600 ground-level policemen throughout the island attended the exam this year with only 205 police officers permitted to advance to the oral exam segment which was held earlier this month. After having finished the program, the police officers are automatically eligible for a big promotion.

Investigators said they have thus far discovered at least 10 people who were acting as brokers for Kuo. Known as "white gloves," most of these brokers are also police officers or students of the Central Police University.

One of the main brokers was Kuo's nephew, Wang Chun-chie, who graduated from the university this year. Wang, who has admitted his involvement in the bribery, has been turned over to military prosecutors for further investigation as he is currently serving his military service.
For years, rumors of cheating in the Central Police University entrance exams have circulated, but they had not been taken seriously until Hsieh Ruey-chi was appointed university president last July.

Hsieh removed Kuo from his position as head of the computer center days before the exam was held on July 10-11, but kept him on the university's staff. The move, however, failed to prevent the cheating in the exam results. As the designer of the university's computerized examination grading and scoring system, Kuo was invited to provide assistance in operating the system, giving him the opportunity to alter exam scores.

After receiving a tip that Kuo had manipulated several report cards, Hsieh mobilized 200 university faculty and students to check the English exam answer cards for inconsistencies. The week-long task revealed that 43 scores had been altered. Checks on the scores for other subjects confirmed the findings.
Hsieh reported the incident to prosecutors in Taoyuan on Friday which led to Kuo's capture at his girlfriend's house in downtown Taipei on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION HEADED FOR PARAGUAY STOPS OVER IN LOS ANGELES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 10 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Huang Kun-huei, head of a Republic of China delegation traveling to attend the inauguration of Paraguayan President Raul Cubas Grau, arrived in Los Angeles on Monday.
Huang, secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, will leave for the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion via Miami on Tuesday. He is scheduled to arrive in Asuncion on Thursday.
Other delegates include Jason Hu, foreign minister, Ling Shiang-nung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, and Mao Chih-kuo, vice minister of communications and transportation.

Huang said he will represent President Lee during the inauguration ceremony on Saturday. He will also visit former President Juan Carlos Wasmosy to thank him for supporting the ROC in the international community over the past years.

During the five-day stay in the Southern American country, Huang and the delegation will also meet with staff members of the ROC embassy, the ROC agricultural mission stationed there and members of the Chinese community.

According to news sources in Asuncion, the Paraguayan government has decided to host a party in honor of the ROC delegation on Thursday. Meanwhile, Huang and Hu will be decorated in recognition of their contribution to the promotion of bilateral relations.
The delegation is scheduled to depart Asuncion on Monday and will arrive in Taipei on Aug. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO SHOULD AVOID COMMENT ON 'THREE NOES', SAYS JAPANESE PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-ming and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Japan should in no way involve itself in negotiations between the two rivals across the Taiwan Strait, Japan's Mainichi Shimbun national paper said in an editorial Tuesday.
The daily said Japan should avoid making any comment on the so-called "three noes" policy which US President Bill Clinton committed to during his visit to mainland China in late June.

Clinton spelled out the United States' policy toward Taiwan during the Shanghai leg of his mainland tour on June 30, saying that the US does not support independence for Taiwan, does not support "two Chinas," or "one Taiwan, one China," and does not support Taiwan's membership in any organization for which statehood is a requirement.

In the editorial titled "No Need for Another Joint Statement on New Japan-China Diplomacy," the daily questioned Beijing's attempt to get Japan to sign a new bilateral diplomatic joint statement in which Tokyo's support for the "three noes" will be carried. It questioned whether Beijing intended to use such a statement as a bargaining chip in its negotiations with Taipei on reunification.
Following Clinton's comment on the "three noes," Beijing has reportedly asked for a similar statement by the Japanese government when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin visits Tokyo in September.

Beijing will ask Tokyo to commit to a new bilateral diplomatic joint statement as an addition to the 1972 Joint Statement and the 1978 Treaty on Peace and Friendship signed between Japan and mainland China, the paper noted.
In the prospective new statement, Beijing will ask Tokyo to codify in black and white the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan, it added.

The Mainichi Shimbun reiterated that no matter when or how, Japan should not comment on issues concerning relations or reunification between Taiwan and mainland China, given that Japan agreed in the San Francisco Treaty to forsake its colonial rule over Taiwan as well as all rights of say in Taiwan's sovereignty.

Tokyo and Beijing both have their eyes on different issues. Tokyo is concerned with an action plan for future cooperation between the two sides while Beijing is only concerned with the Taiwan issue and some historic recognition points, the paper said.

Japan has no need to be hasty in forging a new joint statement with Beijing as the 1972 Joint Statement and the 1978 treaty are sufficient frameworks from which relations between the two sides can operate on, the editorial said.
The new treaty is worth signing only if it is of long-term benefit to both sides as they approach the 21st century, the paper said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICAN EXPRESS ADOPTS 'REPUBLIC OF CHINA' IN DATA NETWORK

TEXT.P: American Express International Inc. has adopted the name "Republic of China" in its computer data network in the United States since the beginning of August.
The change was regarded as the conglomerate's recognition and respect for the ROC despite a strong blockade against such a move by Beijing authorities.
American Express had previously referred to Taiwan as "Taiwan, Province of China" on its credit card bills mailed to its Optima-class customers in the United States.
The classification led the ROC's Government Information Office (GIO) to protest that the label "downplayed the independent sovereignty of Taiwan."

The GIO's US office explained to the American company that the ROC has been an independent state since its establishment in 1912, and that the name "China," which is commonly used to refer to the People's Republic of China on the mainland in international circles, does not include the ROC on Taiwan.
Taiwan and the mainland have been divided since the end of the 1949 civil war, and are under the rule of two separate governments with no link to one another.
In Taiwan, American Express has issued over 310,000 credit cards as of the end of June, according to the ROC's Ministry of Finance. It is one of the world's leading issuers of credit cards.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN WILL NOT ACKNOWLEDGE CLINTON'S `THREE NOES' STATEMENT: REPORT

TEXT.P: Japan will not acknowledge the so-called "three noes" stance regarding Taiwan when it hosts a visit early next month by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin, a New-Delhi newspaper reported on Tuesday.

"Within the Japanese ruling Liberal Democracy Party there is great opposition to altering or expanding on the existing bland `one China' policy," while Beijing wants Japan to acknowledge the "three noes" statement regarding Taiwan made by US President Bill Clinton during his recent visit to mainland China, The Hindu reported.
The newspaper reported from Tokyo that one of the most serious disagreements between mainland China and Japan is over the scope of the redefined US-Japan Security Treaty.
"China is allergic to the specific exclusion but implicit inclusion of Taiwan and the Taiwan Strait in the new US-Japan defense guidelines," it reported.
Top Japanese ministers said the new guidelines are not geographically specific but flexibly depending on the situation, it added.

Commenting on a recent visit by Japanese Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura to Beijing, The Hindu said the Komura mission produced "some limited institutionalizing in a bilateral relationship" where economically and financially the dice are heavily loaded in Japan's favor.

It stressed that Japan is one of mainland China's top trading partners, its top aid donor and one of its principal foreign investors. "Thus, both countries have decided to establish a standing committee on economic and financial matters at vice ministerial level," it added.

The newspaper indicated that Japan is not doing enough to prevent mainland China from devaluing the renminbi, "because among other things a weaker yen and deflation at home prevents Japan from importing more Chinese goods."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CITES ROC AS GUIDEPOST FOR MAINLAND CHINA'S DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday reiterated that the unification of China should be based on freedom, democracy and the equitable distribution of wealth, rather than on the autocratic and totalitarian communist system.

Lee made the remarks when receiving a group of 27 overseas Chinese leaders from the United States which was paying a courtesy call at the Presidential Office, accompanied by Chiao Jen-ho, minister of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.
On behalf of overseas Chinese organizations in the southwestern United States, the group extended support for the Republic of China and expressed concern over cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The president told his guests that the unification of China should be carried out peacefully. For this reason, Lee said, the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Rebellion was terminated on May 1, 1991, signifying the ROC government's determination not to use force to achieve national unification.

However, Lee noted, not only has Beijing failed to make a friendly response to this gesture, it has strengthened its moves to isolate the ROC in the world community, and still refuses to renounce the use of force as a means of unification.

He went on to point out that the two sides have now been separated for nearly 50 years, and that different systems and lifestyles on either side of the Taiwan Strait have created feelings of alienation on both sides.

To expedite future cross-strait unification, Lee suggested that Beijing should change its strong ideology. In addition to opening up its economy, he said, Beijing should allow people to enjoy full democracy and freedom, should treat the ROC as an equal political entity, and should engage in peaceful exchanges and dialogue.

The president further said that freedom and democracy is not only a world trend, but also a common goal sought by many of the Chinese immigrants who have spread across the globe and by the ancestors of modern Taiwanese who moved to Taiwan from mainland China.

Lee said, the Republic of China on Taiwan has become the first place in China to ever completely implement freedom and democracy, and has become a model for the future development of mainland China. It has also become a guidepost for all Chinese people who are seeking national unification, he said.
Therefore, the president said, the existence and development of the ROC on Taiwan will play a very important role in history.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND'S MAORI SAID TO HAVE ORIGINATED FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A DNA researcher has reportedly traced the origins of New Zealand's Maori to descendants from Taiwan, The Australian said in an article Tuesday.

Geoffrey Chambers from Victoria University in Wellington believes the Maori traveled from Taiwan through the Philippines and Indonesia to West Polynesia on the islands of East Polynesia and then southwest where they eventually settled in New Zealand.
"There is an exact living record of these voyages of colonization preserved in the DNA of their modern-day descendants, who are still living in these places along the route," Chambers said.
His research made use of DNA data first obtained for another purpose by researchers at the university's Institute of Molecular Systematic (IMS) molecular biology laboratory.
The Victoria University data from several IMS human genetic studies in New Zealand were then compared with similar information from other populations around the world, he said.
The research report said forensic DNA profiling studies done at the Victoria University also found that Polynesians in general show less genetic diversity than many other ethnic groups.

The overall probability of finding two individuals possessing the same multi-locus DNA profile with a particular DNA probe was found to be one in 112 million for Asians, one in 47 million for Caucasians, one in 6.7 million for Polynesians and one in 2.8 million for Maori, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SENIOR SIA OFFICIALS TO JOIN CAL

TEXT.P: Two senior officials from Singapore Airlines (SIA) are scheduled to join the management team of Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) under the terms of a recent cooperative agreement between the two carriers.

The two officials, Capt. Pow Tuk Kwan and Capt. Gui Wee Kee, will work for two years in Taipei as CAL's flight vice president, and special aide to the carrier's president, respectively, a CAL spokesman said on Tuesday.
Pow, 54, is a former chief pilot of SIA's A340 fleet and a board member of the Singapore Academy of Flight. He will be in charge of CAL's flight management and training from Sept. 1.

Gui, 51, is a former deputy chief pilot of SIA's B747-400 fleet and is currently a management consultant for Singapore's civil aeronautics authority. He will join CAL's team for coordination and consultancy in flight operations and management.
The move marks the first cooperative program between the two carriers after they signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to form a strategic alliance on Aug. 4.

The proposed alliance aims to benefit regional customers by providing better coordination between the two carriers, including code-sharing on certain routes which will provide customers with a wider choice of travel options.
The MOU also sets out general principles for SIA's purchase of between 5 percent and 10 percent of CAL shares within six months.
SIA has also agreed to provide CAL with aviation safety and flight management training, while CAL will provide catering, ground maintenance and cargo services.
A formal agreement on the MOU is expected to be signed in six months time, said the spokesman.

SIA operates a fleet of 87 aircraft and offers flights to 76 destinations in 41 countries. For the fiscal year ending March 31, 1998, the total revenue of the Singapore International Group, the mother company of SIA, was S$7.72 billion.

CAL was established in 1959 and operates a fleet of 52 of the latest Boeing, McDonnell Douglas and Airbus jetliners. CAL and its two subsidiaries, Mandarin Airlines and Formosa Airlines, serve 46 destinations in 20 countries. The company's operating revenue in 1997 totaled NT$55.85 billion (US$1.63 billion) and its pre-tax profit was NT$2.77 billion (US$80 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST PEOPLE IN TAIWAN DON'T KNOW 'THREE NOES' POLICY: SURVEY

TEXT.P: A survey report released Tuesday by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan reveals that 83.6 percent of people in Taiwan do not know what is the "three noes" policy of the United States toward Taiwan.

US President Bill Clinton said in an informal setting in Shanghai during his visit to the Chinese mainland on June 25-July 3 that the US government does not support "independence for Taiwan", "Two Chinas or One China, one Taiwan", and Taiwan's bid to join "international organizations for which statehood is a requirement." This US position is usually called the "three noes" policy.

In the survey conducted between July 17 and 20, randomly- selected people over 20 years of age were interviewed by telephone to find out their attitudes after Clinton's last summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing. There were 1,098 effective samples, with a sampling error of plus and minus 3 percent.

The survey also finds that only 13.9 percent of the people interviewed knew the US government does not support Taiwan independence, that only 4.8 percent knew the US does not support "Two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan," and that only 10.7 percent knew the US does not support Taiwan's bid to join international bodies for which statehood is a requirement.

The survey also revealed that more than 50 percent of the people interviewed believed Taiwan and mainland China can hold consultations on matters of economic, practical, and even political nature. Only 19 percent oppose such consultations.

When asked whether the last Clinton-Jiang summit has affected cross-strait relations, 34 percent said "no," 25 percent said "yes," and 10.5 percent said the summit is helpful to cross-strait relations.

Meanwhile, MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin predicted Tuesday that Beijing will make great efforts to ask Japan, France, and other leading countries in the world to formally mention their "three noes" policy toward Taiwan in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTERS DEGREE HOLDER WANTS TO WORK AS STREET CLEANER

TEXT.P: A local resident who holds a master's degree in electronic engineering from an American university is trying to make a career from his physical strength, rather than from his intelligence.

The 28-year-old Kaohsiung citizen, surnamed Huang, applied in June for a job on a cleaning squad in the southern port city government's Department of Environmental Protection (DOEP), department officials revealed on Tuesday.
The officials told CNA that Huang had expressed a desire to earn his living from the sweat of his brow after becoming tired of working with his brain.

The DOEP approved Huang's application to work as a city street cleaner, and put him at the bottom of a long waiting list, behind more than 1,300 male and around 1,500 female applicants vying for a limited number of vacancies.
The DOEP officials said that Huang will have to wait for at least seven years to obtain a position. The current monthly wage of a city sanitation worker is about NT$34,000 (US$980).

Kaohsiung City's cleaning squad currently comprises around 2,200 workers. Most of the official employees have a junior or senior high school education, although 10 have degrees from local universities, according to the DOEP.
Any Kaohsiung citizen aged between 18 and 40 who has at least a junior high school education and is physically and mentally healthy can apply to work as a sanitation worker, the department said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER: 74 MISSIONS TO PROMOTE TRADE IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Tuesday that a total of 74 trade promotion missions will be sent to Japan in fiscal 1999 to try to narrow a trade deficit which it is estimated will reach US$18 billion this year.
Wang made the remarks at a meeting held at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on how to enhance trade promotion and reduce the trade deficit with Japan.

Participants at the meeting included: Senior Advisor to the President Koo Chen-fu; Chinese National Federation of Industries Chairman Kao Chin-yen; General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China Chairman Wang You-theng; and representatives from related government agencies and professional associations.

The minister pointed out that the Asian financial turmoil, Japan's domestic economic recession, and the foot and mouth disease epidemic last March, have caused Taiwan's exports to Japan since August 1997 to continuously suffer two-digit negative growth for each consecutive month.

To cope with the situation, Wang said, the MOEA in fiscal 1999 will organize at least 74 professional missions to promote industrial products such as electronics, electrical appliances, machinery, bags and shoes. Meanwhile, more Japanese investment in Taiwan is needed to boost Taiwan's exports to the Japanese market, he added.

In addition, the MOEA will conduct market surveys on the Japanese market, and will hold seven trade and investment seminars in Japan to encourage Japanese businesses to organize purchasing groups to visit Taiwan. The MOEA will also enhance training of human resources related to trade promotion in Japan.

According to statistics compiled by the MOEA's Board of Foreign Trade, Taiwan suffered a deficit of US$10.58 billion in its trade with Japan during the first seven months of this year, an increase of 26.2 percent in comparison with the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN ERROR CAUSE OF WARSHIP FIRE, SAYS MND

TEXT.P: The fire that claimed the lives of seven seamen aboard the naval destroyer "Suei Yang" on Aug. 3 was caused mainly by human error, a Ministry of National Defense (MND) official said on Tuesday.
The accident happened as a sailor was trying to replace an oil rod for the No. 4 boiler in the destroyer's rear boiler room.

The sailor did not completely shut off the root valve, which controls the oil volume in the boiler, before pulling out the oil rod, said Maj. Gen. Ma Ke from the MND's United Operations and Supervision Department.

The mistake caused oil to burst from the boiler. The oil then caught fire and soon spread to the whole boiler room, killing the seven sailors instantly and injuring five others working in the enclosed area.

The task force formed to investigate Taiwan's worst naval accident in recent decades also attributed inexperience, inadequate training, and insufficient shift management, as other contributing factors.
In addition, Ma said, maintenance defects and manpower shortages were also blamed as root causes of the mishap.

The "Suei Yang," one of 18 Yang-class destroyers the ROC Navy bought from the United States nearly 50 years ago, has been in service for 47 years. Although some of the aging fleet have been recommissioned and now undertake only second-line duties, most of the destroyers have had their weaponry and radar systems extensively upgraded, and remain the backbone of Taiwan's naval combat force.
The ROC Navy's combat force also includes 14 US-made Knox- and Perry-class frigates, and six French-made Lafayette-class frigates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CONDEMNS BOMBINGS OF US EMBASSIES IN KENYA, TANZANIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Tuesday condemned the bombings of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last week.

"The people and government of the Republic of China strongly condemn the violence committed by the international terrorists, and call for international cooperation to stop these crimes", the Foreign Affairs Ministry said.
The death toll from the two incidents so far stood at more than 200 with up to 5,000 injured. The ministry also expressed its condolences to the victims and families.
The ministry said that following the assaults, it has tightened security measures for foreign embassies and representative offices as well as their personnel in Taiwan. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN WORKERS IN TAIWAN ON THE INCREASE

TEXT.P: The number of legal foreign workers in Taiwan had reached over 250,000 as of the end of June, up 17,000 from the year-earlier level, according to statistics released on Tuesday by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).
CLA officials said the growth resulted from increasing demand from the manufacturing and construction companies which have contracts relating to the government's public infrastructure projects.
Of these foreign workers, 120,000 were from Thailand, while 100,000 were from the Philippines, and 15,000 came from Indonesia, the statistics show.
The figures also indicate that 2,353 foreign workers ran away from their workplaces during the first half of this year, down 895 from the same period of last year.
From January to March, 21 crimes committed by foreign workers were reported around the island, 13 fewer than in the same period of last year, the CLA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Cabinet will discuss measures to stimulate economy Wednesday.
The China Times: Japanese Prime Minister Obuchi reaffirms commitments to abiding by two Tokyo-Beijing joint communiques on Taiwan issues.
The United Daily News: Taiwan is again placed on US Special 301 watch list.
The Liberty Times: Police administration white paper sheds light on poor coordination between the National Police Administration and National Police University.
The Independence Morning Post: The Japanese yen plunged to a fresh 8-year low of 147.5 against the US dollar Tuesday.
The Commons Daily: The KMT is gearing up to defend current Taipei-Tokyo ties and to stem expansion of the "three noes" effect.
The China News: NT dollar is hammered as yen hits 8-year low.
The China Post: New revelations are unveiled in police test scam.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND-MADE MOBILE PHONE HANDSETS STILL BARRED FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) approved 44 categories of mainland Chinese-made goods for indirect import Tuesday, but the much-favored mobile phone handsets did not make the list.
Of the 93 categories of items up for approval, 34 were rejected and 15 others are pending.
As mobile phones are a popular item around the island, Taiwan importers were disappointed by the board's decision as mainland-made handsets would have made prices more competitive.

The Dutch-based company Philips was given the green light to import all of the approval list's four electrical appliances, they are vacuum cleaners, electric irons, electric teapots and electric frying pots. The BOFT rejected the company's application for hair dryers and air cleaning machines.

Other items which made the approval list included powdered oyster essence, yeast abstract, cotton-combing machines, live eels, palm leaves, coconut husks, frozen white asparagus, frozen baby corn, coconut fibers, and dried water lily leaves.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs has continued to relax restrictions on mainland-made products over the past several years. As of July this year, the ministry has given the green light to 5,483 categories of mainland-originating products for indirect import. Of the total, 5,099 were industrial products and 384 were agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD PROPOSES NEW 'THREE LINKS' WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs on Wednesday proposed forging three "new direct links" aimed at narrowing psychological and cultural differences between the two rivals across the Taiwan Strait.

Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which crafts Taiwan's mainland Chinese policies, called for Beijing's support in promoting direct links of mind, technology information, and culture across the Taiwan Strait to pave the way for reunification.
Chang said only when those on both sides of the strait are mentally, intelligently and culturally able to communicate that reunification can be easily achieved.
He urged Beijing authorities to discard the "zero win" hegemonic mentality toward Taiwan and forsake political interference and containment schemes against Taiwan.
Chang stressed the importance of cultural interaction across the Taiwan Strait, saying that closer cultural exchanges is the only way to narrow the lifestyle and ideological gaps.
He also urged Beijing authorities to relax controls on the digital world, including the Internet to allow the mainland public access to the truth and facts.

The MAC head said in addition to accelerating private exchanges between the two sides, the council is actively promoting cross-strait dialogue, hoping that through step-by-step talks, the two sides will work out resolutions to issues regarding the welfare and interests of the people across the Taiwan Strait.

In previous years, there have been proposals to set up direct postal, transportation and commercial links, or the so-called "three links" across the Taiwan Strait. Taiwan has continued to resist such proposals on the grounds that Beijing continues to regard Taipei as a local government and not an equal "political entity."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEVENTH NATIONAL PARK IN THE OFFING
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Nengdan National Park in central Taiwan is expected to open at the end of this year which would make it the island's seventh national park.

The proposed park, located in the Central Mountain Range -- the backbone of Taiwan -- is noted for its great numbers of mountain lakes and indigenous animals and plants. It was recommended as a national park by scholars, outdoor activists and wildlife conservationists, said officials from the Construction and Planning Administration.

An area of more than 100,000 hectares, the Nengdan National Park stretches from Mt. Nengkao in the north to Mt. Dandah in the south. There are more than 30 mountains standing at least 3,000 meters high in the area, numerous forests, mountain lakes, five ancient hiking routes, the highest temple in the island, and rich resources of wildlife.

If officially approved, the park will be the largest national park on the island, boasting unique natural scenic attractions coupled with historical and geological treasures. It will also help form Taiwan's "ecology corridor" together with the neighboring Mt. Jade, Sheipa and Toroko National Parks.
The other three existing national parks of Taiwan are Kenting National Park, Yangmingshan National Park and the offshore Kinmen National Park.
