DOC.HEADLINE: ISRAEL BUYS TIME IN MIDDLE EAST PEACE PROCESS: MBEKI

TEXT.P: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is buying time to implement his own programs rather than working toward peace in the Middle East, South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said Tuesday.

Mbeki said it was surprising that Netanyahu had not accepted the US' proposals aimed at enhancing Middle East's peace process. He said the proposals have already been accepted by the Palestinian liberation authority.
Mbeki made the remarks after meeting with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat in Cape Town.
The Middle East peace process is a critical issue and South Africa will do everything possible to help the region achieve this goal, Mbeki said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA COMPLETES COMPLEX FOR FOREIGN EMBASSIES AND CONSULATES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has recently completed a complex built to accommodate foreign embassies and consulates in Taipei, a ministry official said Wednesday.
John Feng, MOFA director of protocol, said the complex contains two buildings -- one for offices and the other for residential use.
The office building consists of 28 units with each unit measuring about 100 pings (roughly equivalent to 3,600-square feet). The monthly rent for a unit is NT$50,000 (US$1,440).

Each residential unit occupies an area of around 60 pings (2,160 square feet), which will be offered at a monthly rent of NT$30,000, Feng said. The complex's security will be handled by an elite police group under the Police Administration.
The complex is expected to relieve some of the enormous costs the island's foreign allies have had to pay for office rent in the downtown Taipei area.

The building complex is situated on Tienmu West Road in suburban Taipei across from the Chen Hsing Hospital. The road in front of the building is a one-way street, which allows for more effective security control.
MOFA Spokesman Roy Wu said the complex is located in an area where security is a priority.

Safety, convenience and an ease of general management are the reasons why the ministry has constructed the complex, Wu said, adding that similar buildings also exist for the same reasons in many countries such as South Korea and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SA-SPONSORED COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE LESOTHO ELECTION RESULTS

TEXT.P: South Africa will sponsor a committee to investigate whether the Lesotho general elections in May were flawed.

South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki said in Cape Town Tuesday that South Africa had been given the "responsibility" to organize a team of experts to work with the Independent Electoral Commission to investigate complaints surrounding the election.
He said South Africa would consult Botswana and Zimbabwe as "guarantors of Lesotho's democracy."
Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo also said the committee is expected to present its findings within two weeks.
He said Lesotho's new Prime Minister Pakalitha Mosisili had offered to step down should the South African sponsored committee find that the May polls in the mountainous kingdom were seriously flawed.
The Lesotho opposition parties, who are contesting the validity of the May polls, have promised to respect the result of the committee's investigation, the foreign minister said.
Nzo accompanied Mbeki to the Lesotho capital of Maseru to try and negotiate an end to the dispute which has seen Lesotho's government and opposition supporters pitted against each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OVERTAKES JAPAN IN SEMICONDUCTOR PURCHASES FROM NO. 1 SUPPLIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan has overtaken Japan as Asia's largest purchaser of Applied Materials Inc. products as the semiconductor industry suffers greater losses due to the Asian crisis.

Applied Materials, the world's largest supplier of wafer fabrication system and services to the global semiconductor industry, reported Tuesday that sale figures from its third fiscal quarter at US$884 million were down 16 percent from the same period last year and down 25 percent from the second quarter this year.

"The semiconductor industry downturn continued to deepen during the third fiscal quarter because of poor economic conditions in Asia, industry over-capacity and weaker than expected PC sales compounded by a movement to lower priced PCs," said James Morgan, chairman and CEO of Applied Materials.
Taiwan is emerging from the regional morass in relatively better shape than Japan and Korea, whose semiconductor industries have either canceled or delayed orders of new manufacturing equipment.
According to Applied Materials, Taiwan overtook Japan and Europe as the second largest buyer of Applied Materials equipment and services in the third quarter of 1998.

Of Applied Materials' US$608 million new orders, North America represented 45 percent, Taiwan 20 percent and Japan 18 percent. Korea's semiconductor industry limited its expansion by reducing its purchases of new equipment from Applied Materials which represented only 5 percent of the company's revenue.
In the second quarter of the year, Taiwan ranked fourth among Applied Materials' purchasers, after North America, Europe and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES EXCHANGE DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 32.47 points to close at 7,351.51.
The bourse opened at 7,301.52 points, 82.46 lower than Tuesday's close, and experienced a low of 7,300.

A total of 13.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$67.21 billion, an increase from the previous trading session which saw 12.83 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$63.68 billion.
Two of the eight major categories gained ground, with foodstuff shares moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 0.6 percent.

Six other categories registered losses, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by construction shares at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.5 percent, textile issues at 0.3 percent, pulp and paper shares at 0.2 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures also posted a general decline.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down 30 points to close at 7,330, while those for October slid 15 points to 7,360, and those for December dropped 80 points to 7,525.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 384, four, and three, respectively.
The TAIEX Index Futures for March moved down 140 points to close at 7,505, with five contract transactions. No transactions were registered for June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were listed as: 7,360 points for September; 7,375 for October; 7,605 for December; 7,645 for March; and 7,729 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OPPOSES US TROOP DEPLOYMENT IN ASIA PACIFIC REGION

TEXT.P: Mainland China has expressed its opposition to troop deployment by the United States in the Asia Pacific region, and has raised concern over the rise of Australia's One Nation party.

Mainland China's Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Yang Jiechi, who was leading a delegation attending a two-day human rights conference with Australia in Canberra, reiterated Beijing's opposition to American troop deployments in the region, and also voiced its opposition to US alliances in the Pacific.

Yang said: "China believes, and it is our consistent policy, that there should not be troops deployed in foreign countries. This is a long-held policy of China, not a new policy. China is not in favor of any country stationing troops in foreign countries."

"In the post-Cold War era, the strengthening of military alliances does not conform with the trends of the times," he said, referring to the military alliance which exists between Australia and the United States.

Yang's comments contradicted remarks made recently by US Defense Secretary William Cohen, who said Beijing now accepts that America's forward military deployment in the region is in mainland China's own interest.
Yang also raised Beijing's concern over the rise of One Nation, and asked Australia to take appropriate measures to counter its racist ideology.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD NOT BE DETERRED BY BOMBINGS: CLINTON

TEXT.P: The Aug. 7 bombings at the US embassies in Nairobi, Kenya and Dar es Dalaam, Tanzania will not deter the United States from its global involvement, nor from its fight against terrorism, said President Bill Clinton Tuesday.
The president made the remarks at the top of a speech on the environment delivered at an event in San Bruno, California.

"It is important that we all, as Americans, send a clear signal to the world that we are not going to back away from our involvement with other people, and we are not going to back away from our opposition to terrorism," noted Clinton.

Eleven American citizens killed in the bombing in Nairobi "are coming home and Hillary and I will go to Andrews Air Force Base to meet that sad homecoming plane on Thursday," Clinton said. A 12th US victim, married to a Kenyan, will be buried in Kenya.
Clinton added that in addition to the American deaths, "well over 200 African citizens have been killed and almost 5,000 injured," and over 500 people still remain in the hospital in Nairobi.

The United States has "worked very closely with the governments of Kenya and Tanzania in, first of all, determining and finding those who were killed and those who were injured and now in their treatment. And also they are working very closely with us in our attempts to find those who are responsible," said the president.

Clinton added, "in an ever more open world, where people are traveling more and where more information and technology and, unfortunately, weaponry are available across national lines, and more and more information (is available) through the Internet .... It makes us more vulnerable as targets because we have taken the toughest stand around the world against terrorism. Now is the time to bear down, not back up, on that. And that is my determination. And I believe that's what the American people support. And I hope all of you will."

President Clinton cut short his domestic travels by a day to return to Washington for a meeting Wednesday at the White House with his national security team. The meeting will focus on the African bombings, but other issues such as Kosovo and Iraq could also come up, Deputy Press Secretary Joe Lockhart said.

Secretary of State Madeleine Albright leaves Washington early Wednesday to go to Ramstein Air Force Base in Germany to escort the bodies of the 11 US victims home. She is also expected to visit with some of the wounded who are being treated at a US military hospital there at the German Air Force Base.

In his formal report to top leaders of the US Congress, President Clinton said a joint task force of US military specialists was deployed to Nairobi, Kenya last Friday to coordinate medical and disaster relief efforts.
He also noted that small contingents of armed security personnel arrived at both sites last Saturday.

"Although US forces are equipped for combat," he said in a letter to the speaker of the House of Representatives and the president pro tempore of the Senate Monday, "This movement is being undertaken solely for the purpose of enhancing embassy security and ensuring the security of American citizens. United States forces will re-deploy as soon as the additional security support is determined to be unnecessary."

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLEGED `TAIWAN SPY' GIVEN FOUR-YEAR SENTENCE BY BEIJING

TEXT.P: The leader of four Taiwan businessmen who have been detained in mainland China since March on charges of spying was given a four-year jail sentence on Wednesday, according to sources from Beijing.
The Beijing First Secondary People's Court concluded the trials of all four businessmen -- Ko Chien-ming, Chen Shao-yu, Han Yueh-ting and Chou Chang-ming -- but only Ko was sentenced to jail.
The other three, although all found guilty of espionage, were released because they "made major contributions to the country," the court said without elaborating on the form these contributions took.

The sources quoted a report from Beijing's China News Service (CNS) on the trials, which said that the men -- all members of the Taipei-based Chinese Association for the Promotion of Cross-Strait Civil Exchanges -- used the association as cover for their espionage operations in mainland China between June 1993 and March 1998.
These operations included the collection of political, economic, and military intelligence for Taiwan, according to the court.
The court said that Ko had confessed to spying for Taiwan and that it had solid evidence to prove his guilt.

Beijing announced on May 28 that it had broken a Taiwan spy ring and arrested four Taiwan businessmen on espionage charges. It accused the four of working for Taiwan's Military Intelligence Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense, charges which the ministry categorically denies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO MONITOR JIANG-OBUCHI MEETING DEVELOPMENTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday that it has worked out countermeasures to deal with possible developments arising from a planned visit to Japan in September by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said Chuang Ming-yao, Taiwan's de-facto ambassador to Japan, will also return to Taipei to raise proposals and report to the government on the situation.

Wu said the MOFA will monitor developments relevant to Taiwan regarding a planned meeting between Jiang and Japanese Premier Keizo Obuchi, and the signing of a new Japan-mainland China communique on Taiwan.
The Republic of China will express its concern and opinions to Japan through the proper channels and at the proper time, he added.

Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, said he believes that Japan will not discuss issues with mainland China which might violate ROC sovereignty, in order to maintain good relations with Taiwan.

Local media have reported that Jiang will use his September trip to Japan to seek Tokyo's commitment to supporting the "three noes" -- no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.
In related news, the local Liberty Times reported that a legislative delegation will head for Japan later this month to express Taiwan's opposition to Japan's reiteration of the "three noes."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA DISSIDENT DENOUNCES HUMAN RIGHTS TALKS IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A leading mainland Chinese dissident on Wednesday denounced a bilateral human rights dialogue between Australia and mainland China, saying the talks did not address the most serious human rights abuses in the mainland.
US-based Harry Wu, who spent 19 years in the laogai -- mainland China's gulag -- said Australia did not raise the central issues on mainland China's violation of human rights abuses.

"If this is a real human rights dialogue, we have to talk about forced abortion, forced sterilization, we have to talk about religious freedom, about Tibet fighting for its future, we have to talk about the labor camp system in China, about organ trafficking," Wu told the Australian newspaper in an interview.
The Australia Tibet Council also condemned the talks for the lack of progress on the Tibet problem.

"We have yet to see a single positive outcome for Tibetans from any bilateral dialogue," said council member Paul Bourke. "On the contrary, over the past 12 months, China has continued to imprison, torture and even kill Tibetans who try to express their political beliefs," he said.

The two-day closed door dialogue in Canberra ended on Wednesday. In a statement released after the meeting between senior Australian and mainland Chinese officials, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said the talks were designed to make human rights issues "an integral part of our bilateral relationship."

Australian officials later said they had raised human rights issues, and that a mainland Chinese government observer will attend an Asia-Pacific human rights forum in Jakarta next month. Australia will also provide mainland China with technical advice on submitting reports to the UN Human Rights Commission.

Mainland Chinese officials will attend courses in international human rights law at Australian universities, according to the daily, while Australian experts will continue to lecture at the Chinese National Judges College in Beijing.
But Wu was skeptical about the programs.
"I don't think training communist judges is important. Did you ever train Soviet judges or the KGB? It's ridiculous," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BE PLACED ON US SPECIAL 301 WATCH LIST

TEXT.P: US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky announced on Tuesday that Taiwan will be placed on the US Special 301 watch list because of continuing concerns about enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPRs) in Taiwan.

Barshefsky said in a statement that the United States is concerned that Taiwan's efforts on IPR enforcement "have not been effective in reducing the production and export of pirated and counterfeit goods, especially video games and components, CD-ROMs, and music and video CDs."
According to US data, Taiwan remains one of the top four sources of pirated goods seized by US Customs, and is also a major source of such exports to Latin American markets, especially Paraguay.

Barshefsky also expressed concern about the "persistent difficulties" US patent, trademark, and copyright holders face in Taiwan courts and administrative bodies when defending their interests against IPR infringements.

But she promised to consider removing Taiwan from the watch list once Taiwan takes definitive enforcement actions and makes other necessary changes to its laws to remedy these long-standing bilateral irritants.
Taiwan was removed from the special 301 list in November 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: `FAIR, JUST SOCIETY' TO BE KMT CAMPAIGN SLOGAN FOR YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: A fair and just new society will be the main thrust of the ruling Kuomintang's campaign slogan for the year-end elections, according to the KMT's Central Standing Committee.

KMT spokesperson Huang Li-ching pointed out after a regular weekly central standing committee meeting that the tenures of the victors -- in the legislative elections and the elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung city mayors and city councilors -- will extend into the next century.
Huang said that as the new millennium approaches, the KMT will work with the public to foster a new vision in which the people of the island will live in a just society and enjoy a life of harmony.

The KMT had earlier invited the public to contribute their ideas about a suitable campaign slogan for the year-end elections. "A fair and just society and a prosperous and stable life" received the most support.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION EN ROUTE TO PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Aug. 11 (CNA) (By L.S. Chu and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Presidential Special Envoy Huang Kun-huei departed for Miami on Tuesday after a stopover in Los Angeles, en route to attend Saturday's inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Raul Cubas Grau.

Huang, secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, who is traveling at the head of an ROC delegation, will stay overnight in Miami before leaving for the Paraguayan capital of Asuncion, where he is scheduled to arrive on Thursday.

During a five-day stay in the South American country, Huang and his delegation will meet with staff of the ROC embassy, an ROC agricultural mission stationed there, and members of Paraguay's Chinese community.
He will also visit former President Juan Carlos Wasmosy to thank him for his support for the ROC over the years.
Other ROC delegates traveling with Huang include Foreign Minister Jason Hu, Council of Agriculture Chairman Ling Shiang-nung, and Mao Chih-kuo, vice minister of transportation and communications.

According to news sources in Asuncion, the Paraguayan government has decided to host a party on Thursday in honor of the ROC delegation. Huang and Hu will also be decorated in recognition of their contributions to the promotion of bilateral relations.
The delegation is scheduled to depart Asuncion on Monday and will arrive back in Taipei on Aug. 21.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPRECIATION MAY RESULT IN HIGHER ASIAN INTEREST RATES

TEXT.P: Asian governments are encountering increasing pressure to devalue their currencies because of the weakened Japanese yen, a Central Bank of China official said on Wednesday.
However, central bank intervention to avoid devaluation will lead to a general raising of interest rates, the official from the Economic Research Department of the Central Bank said.

He cited as an example the recent interference by Hong Kong's foreign exchange officials in its currency exchange rate, carried out to maintain the stability of the Hong Kong dollar after it was hard hit by international speculators.
That interference caused Hong Kong's short-term interest rates to rise sharply, the official said.
Large-scale fluctuations in interest rates will surely affect the willingness of private investors and stifle national economic growth, and therefore have to be taken seriously, said the official.

When depreciation occurs, the research official explained, and a country decides to stabilize its foreign exchange rate, its central bank must intervene. This measure will tighten the market capital and make a rise in short-term interest rates inevitable, he added.

Since Taiwan's market capital has been stringent in recent days, short-term interest rates have hit the danger line of 7 percent set by the Central Bank. This is regarded by experts as a result of Central Bank interference.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN PRESIDENT OFFERS SUPPORT TO PALESTINIAN LEADER

TEXT.P: South Africa will play its part in ensuring that Palestine assumes its rightful position in the international community, South African President Nelson Mandela said in Cape Town on Tuesday.

Speaking at a banquet in honor of visiting Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, Mandela focused on the faltering peace process in the Middle East. He said that although South Africa cannot solve the problems of others, "we stand ready to assist in whatever way we can within the limits of our capacity."
After meeting South African opposition leaders earlier on Tuesday, Arafat said Palestine needs South Africa's help in order to save the peace process.
Arafat arrived in South Africa on Monday night. He was scheduled to address a joint parliamentary sitting on Wednesday afternoon, and will leave the country on Thursday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARABIAN DATES SUCCESSFULLY CULTIVATED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC) has successfully cultivated Arabian jujube trees in Tainan County in southern Taiwan as the first crop hit the market on Wednesday.

Yang Yao-pik, deputy chief of the AVRDC farm in Ta Nei Village of Tainan County, said he planted more than 300 date trees on a land measuring about one hectare. As the crop was good this year, he had sent the fruit to the market for the first time.
Meanwhile, Yang also planted another 10,000 saplings to be supplied to farmers in Ta Nei Village in the hopes of promoting Ta Nei as a special area which grows Arabian dates.

Yang had served as a member of an agriculture technological team to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia 21 years ago. After his return from that country, Yang began researching how best to plant the date trees in Taiwan.
About 14 years ago, Yang was successful in the propagation of the jujube trees, and six years ago, the trees started to bear fruit in red, yellow, violet and orange colors.
Yang said although it takes about seven years for a date tree to mature, by using a technique of pruning, the growth period can be reduced to three to five years.

According to Yang, although date trees are native to desert areas, they are also adaptable to Taiwan's subtropical weather. They are remarkably adaptable to salted land areas, making them suitable for planting on coastal areas, he added.
Yang noted that earlier, experts at the Taisugar Research Institute had tried but failed to cultivate Arabian dates in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI 'REGRETS' US PUTTING IT ON SPECIAL 301 LIST

TEXT.P: Taiwan said on Wednesday that it was surprised at being put back on US "Special 301 Watch List."

Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu expressed regret over the move, saying Washington should not ignore Taiwan's long-term efforts in protecting intellectual property rights (IPR) based on a one-sided complaint by a few US businesses.

In a news release, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) took issue with the US trade representative for accusing Taiwan of not having been "effective in reducing the production and export of pirated and counterfeit goods," emphasizing that the MOEA's efforts to fight against commercial pirating never faltered.

According to a statement made by US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky Tuesday in Washington, Taiwan was listed as one of the four leading sources of illegally copied goods seized by US customs officials.

The US statement also illustrates the USTR's concerns over "persistent difficulties US patent, trademark and copyright holders face defending their interests against infringements in Taiwan courts and administrative bodies."

USTR officials explained that their concerns were mainly triggered by the setback of several American companies, including Princeton Biomeditech Co. and Microsoft Inc. The two companies are in the process of suing Taiwan manufacturers for alleged patent and IPR violations.
The MOEA said in its news release that it was "unfair and unreasonable" that the USTR placed Taiwan on its "black list" based on a few failed IPR and patent related lawsuits.
Taipei regrets the USTR's actions that have obviously ignored the fact that the country's judicial operation is independent of the government's administration, the MOEA said.
Meanwhile, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said his ministry has spared no effort in seizing pirated and counterfeit goods, similar to actions taken by US customs authorities.
However, Taiwan authorities can not confiscate suspected IPR violated goods without a court order. Every enforcement act should be made according to the laws, Yen stressed.

Lin Rong-chu, chief of customs administration under the Ministry of Finance, defended the department's anti-pirate efforts. He said according to official statistics, from Jan. 1 to July 31, customs officials cracked down on a total of 11 cases involving in counterfeit items and seized 23,855 illegally copied CDs for video games, 18,100 units of pirated cellular phone components, 4,820 counterfeited CD-ROMs, and 1,193 copied Intel micro processors.

Taiwan was removed from the Special 301 Watch List in 1996. The list is under provisions of a US law that allow punitive measures against countries believed to have harmed the export US goods or services.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO NEGOTIATE NEW AVIATION RIGHTS WITH OTHER COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has targeted countries in South Asia, South America, East Europe and South Europe to negotiate new aviation pacts to meet trade and tourist demand, a civil aviation official said on Wednesday.

The official with the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said many countries are willing to exchange aviation rights with the ROC since Taiwan allowed its citizens to make overseas sightseeing trips in the late 1980s.

In terms of the needs of local business people and travel agencies, the officials said the CAA has given top priority to exchanging aviation rights with South Asian, South American, East and South European countries.

The official pointed out that a major obstacle to negotiating new aviation rights with countries in Europe and Latin America lies with the fact that Taiwan's geographical location makes it difficult for carriers of those countries to obtain benefits or commercial profits comparable to what Taiwan carriers can acquire.
Meanwhile, the official said the CAA plans to increase the number of flights and destinations that local carriers can serve in the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, Britain and Germany.

"We are planning to negotiate amendments to our existing aviation agreements with those countries in the near future," the official said, adding that consultations with the Philippines and Thailand are scheduled for mid-August and late August, respectively.
In addition, the official said Singapore has expressed its intention to negotiate a new aviation pact with Taiwan with a view to expand its flight services to the United States and Canada via Taiwan.

As the benefits Singapore will gain from increased flights to the United States and Canada through Taiwan will surpass the interests Taiwan will reap from extending flights from Singapore to other countries, the official said the CAA has yet to make a final decision on whether to open negotiations with the Southeast Asian city-state on aviation pact amendments.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD CHANGE ITS STRATEGY ON TAIPEI-BEIJING RELATIONS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A former US presidential assistant has urged the United States to make clear that it believes Taiwan's status is up to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
In an article in Wednesday's Japan Times daily, Douglas Bandow, who worked for former US President Ronald Reagan, said Washington should also emphasize the importance of a peaceful resolution.

In the article titled "US exacerbating China-Taiwan tension," Bandow, now a senior fellow at the Cato Institute, said US President Bill Clinton's bizarre mixture of appeasement and threats to Beijing risk turning Taipei into an even greater flash point than the Korean Peninsula.

During his tour of mainland China, Clinton explicitly opposed independence for Taiwan and Taipei's entrance into international organizations in which statehood is a requirement. This damaged Taiwan's bargaining position in any negotiations with Beijing, Bandow said.

Clinton's policy shift presages a reduction and eventual elimination of arms sales to Taiwan and this could leave Taipei highly vulnerable to Beijing's intimidation or outright military coercion within a decade, Bandow quoted a colleague at the institute as saying.

Yet, at the same time, the Clinton administration apparently continues to threaten a military response to Beijing's attempts at intimidation or coercion, thus the administration risks the security of Americans as well as the people on Taiwan if Beijing does not take such threats seriously.

The Clinton administration's approach to the Taipei-Beijing issue is "stupid" in every way, Bandow wrote. He notes that the US opposes self-determination by people who have built a highly successful capitalist and democratic society, and is moving to deny the ability on the part of Taiwan to defend itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MORE CHILDREN DIE FROM ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: A deadly intestinal virus outbreak has claimed two more lives in Taiwan, bringing the death toll of the enterovirus epidemic to 57, the Department of Health (DOH) under the Executive Yuan announced on Wednesday.

H.M. Hsu, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said the latest victim was a four-year-old boy who died at Changhua Christian Hospital in Changhua, central Taiwan, early Wednesday, two days after he was hospitalized.
A one-year-old baby boy died at Taipei Municipal Hospital for Women & Children in Taipei on Aug. 9, three days after he was admitted to the hospital.
Hsu said the two new cases have brought the number of serious cases on the island to 320, with 57 fatalities as of Wednesday. Another 11 patients are still being hospitalized, she added.

Although the epidemic has shown signs of slowing down, serious cases are still occasionally being reported. Therefore, Hsu urged the public to continue to be on alert and diligent in fighting the spread of the disease.
Of the 11 patients who are still being hospitalized, only three were admitted in August, and the remainder were admitted in July or earlier, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA CANCELS 62 UNI AIRLINES FLIGHTS FOR TWO MONTHS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) will cancel 62 daily UNI Airlines flights beginning Friday for two months.
UNI has experienced numerous irregular landings and mechanical problems since it merged with Taiwan Airlines and Great China on July 1 due to its lack of trained maintenance personnel, CAA said.

The administration has given UNI two months to improve the situation. In the meantime, in consideration of passenger safety, the number of daily flights have been reduced. If the personnel problem is not corrected, the flights may be suspended beyond two months, the CAA said.

Daily flights affected by the cancellation are as follows: one Taipei-Penghu flight, two Taipei-Kaohsiung flights, two Taipei-Tainan flights, one Tainan-Penghu flight, three Taipei-Chiayi flights, two Taichung-Penghu flights, two Chiayi-Penghu flights, one Kaohsiung-Kinmen flight, one Taipei-Penghu flight, four Taipei-Matsu flights, two Taitung-Green Island flights, two Taitung-Orchid Island flights, three Kaohsiung-Penghu flights, and one Tainan-Penghu flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR HEALTHY DEVELOPMENT OF SECURITIES MARKETS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday called for a more rigorous regulatory mechanism for security and futures markets and closer monitoring of the flow of foreign capital to boost investor confidence.

Lee made the remarks after listening to a report by Lin Chung-yung, chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), at a regular weekly Central Standing Committee meeting of the ruling Kuomintang.
Lee noted that a workable system, order and good service are essential to the development of the securities and futures market.

He noted that to promote the liberalization and globalization of Taiwan's financial market, Taiwan's bid to become the regional financial center, the Ministry of Finance and the commission will have to shoulder the regulatory responsibility of related businesses.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu said that as a result of accelerated globalization and liberalization, the capital market has played an increasingly important role in the nation's economic development.
Chiu noted that with the approach of the 21st century, all nations are committed to pushing for financial reforms and mapping out development strategies.
C.F. Koo, a KMT Central Standing Committee member, said the government has to be just and fair to exclude any irregularities such as insider trading in the securities market.

Hsu Li-teh, another KMT Central Standing Committee member, said that with Taiwan's expected entry into the World Trade Organization, the government should address the problems of the opening market squarely.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN THAILAND'S 5TH LARGEST FOREIGN MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan was Thailand's fifth largest market or goods during the first half of 1998, a government spokesman said Wednesday.
Exports to Taiwan from Thailand totaled US$810 million, an increase of 5 percent compared to the same period last year.
The United States was the top importer with US$5.73 billion worth of goods, followed by Japan with US$3.71 billion, Hong Kong with US$1.45 billion, and mainland China with US$860 million.

The export of Thai products to other members of the Association of South East Asian Nations dropped 22.5 percent to US$4.94 billion in the first six months of the year. Meanwhile, Thailand's exports to the 15 members of the European Union increased 12.1 percent to US$4.83 billion.

Thailand's exports in the first six months of 1998 decreased 4.1 percent to US$26.93 billion, and its imports were down 38.1 percent to US$21.44 million. The country registered a US$5.49 billion trade surplus in the first half of the year.

Among Thailand's main export products, agricultural products decreased 8.6 percent to US$3.62 billion but industrial products increased 13.4 percent to US$2.42 billion and manufacturing products in the kingdom decreased 5.1 percent. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: BAYER ASKED TO DECIDE IF IT WILL RENT LAND IN TAICHUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: The German-based Bayer Taiwan Co. Ltd. will be asked if it wants to sign a contract to lease a parcel of land in the Taichung Harbor area, where the company previously planned to build a chemical plant.

Despite the fact that Bayer scrapped the proposed NT$50 billion plan to build a toluene di-isocyanate (TDI) plant in face of strong opposition from residents in Taichung County, it has never relinquished its right to rent the land owned by the Taiwan Provincial Government.

As the Executive Yuan has approved the land lease contract, the Bureau of Taichung Harbor Administration will notify Bayer of the decision and ask the multinational to sign a contract, the provincial government said.
If Bayer fails to ink a contract within 10 days from the date it receives the notification, it will automatically waive its right to rent the 78-hectare land.

The controversial land contract passed its critical stage in February when it cleared the Taiwan Provincial Assembly following several rounds of heated discussions and even physical confrontation between the assembly deputies.

In the end, Bayer's headquarters in Germany announced on March 18 it would suspend the plan once and for all on the grounds that the company had no confidence that Taiwan could provide the legal framework required for it to go ahead with the project.
The fact that Bayer did not announce any intention to give up its right to lease the land prompted rumors that Bayer might stage a comeback with a plan for a similar chemical plant.

A spokesman with Bayer Taiwan said on Wednesday that ever since the German headquarters made its decision to move the proposed investment project from Taiwan to Texas, no instruction has been given on the leasing of the land.

The Asian financial crisis has made the German group reassess the situation in Taiwan, he said, adding that whether Bayer signs the contract depends on a number of variables. The whole situation is not optimistic, he said. (by Lin Wen-fen)

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI MINISTER THROWS HAT IN RING FOR TOP WTO POST

TEXT.P: Thai Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi said he would stand as a candidate to head the World Trade Organization (WTO) after Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai reluctantly backed the decision, the WTO reported Wednesday.

The prime minister was reportedly reluctant to release his deputy as he felt Supachai could contribute to the country's economic recovery. Supachai said earlier that he would retire from politics if he were elected to the trade organization.
WTO candidates must be nominated by their governments before Sept. 30. The term of the current WTO chief, Renato Ruggiero, expires next April 30.

Former Canadian Trade Minister Roy MacLaren is also widely expected to join the race as are former New Zealand Prime Minister Mike Moore, Brazil's Foreign Minister Luiz Felipe Lampreia, and former Morocco Trade Minister Hassan Abouyoub.

Diplomats expect the competition to be high, partly because the post has gained a high profile under Ruggiero, a former Italian trade minister and European Union official who has been praised for boosting the credibility of the fledgling WTO.
Under Ruggiero, the WTO has clinched sweeping global accords to open up the booming telecommunication, information technology, and banking and financial service industries.
The Geneva-based institution, with a channel for dispute resolution, has a membership of 132 with some 30 more countries, including mainland China and Taiwan, negotiating for admission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS CHAMPIONSHIP IN PONY BRONCO BASEBALL GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 12 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei baseball team on Wednesday shut out Puerto Rico for the Pony Bronco World Series championship in Monterey, California.
The primary schoolboys won by a decisive score of 11-0. One run was scored in third inning, two each in the fourth and fifth innings, and six were scored in the sixth inning.
The team secured the right to play in the finals after defeating the US team from the eastern region 12-2 and Hawaii 13-1.
The victorious boys will return to Taipei on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO KEEP EYE ON FOREIGN COMPANIES SEEKING CAPITAL IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will keep an eye on foreign companies seeking to raise capital in Taiwan, Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Wednesday following comments from President Lee Teng-hui.

President Lee asked the Securities and Futures Commission under the MOF to closely monitor the flow of foreign capital and establish a crisis-handling mechanism during a regular weekly Central Standing Committee meeting of the ruling Kuomintang.

Chiu said there was no need to worry about professional foreign investment institutions making investments in Taiwan, but the ministry will closely watch foreign companies seeking to raise capital on the island.
He said if foreign companies want to raise capital in Taiwan, they must be reputable businesses with credible and excellent performance records.
Meanwhile, an official from the Central Bank of China (CBC) said Wednesday that the bank is closely monitoring the foreign exchange market.
The CBC has not discovered any abnormal movement of foreign capital, said Chou A-ting, director of CBC's foreign exchange department.
The CBC announced earlier that between January and June, the net inflow of foreign capital totaled US$700 million.
In face of further financial turmoil in Asia, the department has expressed the hope that foreign capital in Taiwan should not be used in short-term manipulation of the island's currency.

The department, which announces the figures of foreign capital investment in the local bourse every month, noted that foreign investors could invest US$86.68 billion, or 30 percent of the total market value of listed and over-the-board stocks as of July 8.

The department estimated that as of July 8, foreign capital only accounts for 3.45 percent of the total market value of listed and over-the-board stocks, showing that the ratio of foreign capitals in local securities is still low.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Cabinet will take measures to stimulate domestic demand.
The China Times: Government sources divulge that the Koo-Wang meeting will be postponed to October.
The United Daily News: Beijing meted out sentences for the spying case involving four Taiwan men, with Kou Chien-ming getting four years in jail and three others let off the hook.
The Liberty Times: The government will spend NT$200 billion bolstering domestic economic growth.
The Independence Morning Post: Beijing on Wednesday exempted three Taiwan businessmen from punishment for "making significant contributions" to solving an alleged spying case.
The Commons Daily: President Lee on Wednesday directed the Securities and Futures Commission to tighten monitoring of capital flow.
The China News: Beijing gave sentences in the spying case involving four Taiwan men on Wednesday.
The China Post: President Lee calls for stricter monitoring of financial markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PHILIPPINE ECONOMIC CONFERENCE TO START NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The seventh joint economic cooperation conference between the Philippines and the Republic of China is scheduled to begin in Manila next Tuesday.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will head the Taiwan delegation at the two-day meeting where the two sides will discuss issues on trade, investment, tourism, labor, technology, agriculture, and economic cooperation.
Taiwan will also seek support from the Philippines for its bid to become a dialogue partner of the Association for Southeast Asian Nations.
Relations between the two sides have become closer since the first such conference was held in Taipei in 1992, economic officials said.
In 1997, Taiwan was the fourth largest trading partner of the Philippines, its ninth largest investor, and the third largest source of foreign tourists.
According to official statistics, Taiwan investment in the Philippines totaled US$740 million between 1986 and 1997.
Economic officials said that officials from both sides need to step up communications to maintain substantial trade relations.
In tandem with the official conference, a meeting between private sectors of the two countries will take place.
The 13th joint meeting of the Philippine-Chinese and Chinese-Philippine Councils will be held in Manila Aug. 18-21.
Jeffrey Koo, honorary chairman of the Philippine-Chinese business Council and Leslie Koo, chairman of the council, will lead the ROC delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RICH WOMEN SEEN LESS LIKELY TO BEAT BREAST CANCER

TEXT.P: Rich women are less likely to beat breast cancer, according to new research by the New South Wales Cancer Council.
Researchers said there may be biological differences in breast cancer found in women from different socio-economic groups.
Council director Professor Bruce Armstrong said this could be caused by factors influencing estrogen production, which has been linked to breast cancer deaths.

Estrogen production depended on such lifestyle factors as diet, obesity, exercise and alcohol intake. Biological factors appeared to outweigh any possibly difference in medical treatment for the different groups.

The study of women diagnosed with breast cancer since 1973 found that about 76 percent from the highest of five socio-economic groups survived for five years after diagnosis. In the lowest group, the figure was nearly 78 percent.
The study also found that overall five-year survival rates for breast cancer increased from 73 percent in the early 1970s to 81.5 percent for the period between 1988 and 1995.

Women in their 40s had the best survival rate with 77.5 percent of those diagnosed since 1973 surviving at least five years. Only 74 percent of women under 39 survived for five years. Older women also had a higher death rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: WARTIME ENEMIES TO MEET FOR FRIENDSHIP

TEXT.P: A Chinese National Air Force pilot who fought against Japanese fighters during World War II, will meet in Tokyo Saturday with the Japanese pilot who shot him down almost 58 years ago.

Gen. Hsu Hua-chiang and Kazuyoshi Mikami, both 81, will meet at a ceremony commemorating Japan's defeat planned for Saturday. It will mark the pair's first meeting since the two battled in the skies over Chungqing on Sept. 13, 1940.
In an interview with the Taipei-based United Daily News, Mikami, a retired stationary merchant, said he is a little worried over whether he should greet Hsu with "how do you do" or "I'm sorry."

On one misty autumn morning in 1940, a squadron of Japanese "Zero fighters" quietly approached the skies above western China's mountainous city of Chungqing. Before long, six Russian-made fighters from the Chinese National Air Force rose to meet the Japanese.

After locking in several rounds of dogfights, Mikami shot down three Chinese fighters and continued to aim at the fourth, which was commandeered by Hsu. Mikami shot at the fighter and saw it nose-dive, emitting black smoke.
Mikami did not follow the downed fighter plane with machine gun fire, which was a rule of Japan's Imperial Forces to ensure that the enemy was dead, he told the United Daily.
"I don't know why didn't I continue the shooting. Maybe it was the subtle empathy of a warrior," he said.

In 1996, when Mikami became acquainted with Hsu through mutual friends, he discovered what had happened to the fourth Chinese fighter who not only survived but later became a deputy commander-in-chief of the Republic of China Air Force.
After Mikami and Hsu first began to write each other in 1996, the two former enemies from different countries became friends who shared many common memories.

Mikami said among his 13 fellow comrades, only three including himself survived the war. He became a businessman after the war and never spoke about his involvement in the cross-border assault five decades ago.

His son was shocked when he read a book about the "Zero fighters" in a bookstore and found his father's name among the other pilots. It was the first time that his son knew Mikami was a fighter pilot during World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CONDEMNS HARASSMENT OF FOREIGN DIPLOMATS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Thursday condemned the harassment of foreign diplomats and representatives at their offices and residences by local politicians and members of the general public.
"MOFA deplores this sort of uncivilized behavior," the ministry said in a statement, adding that such actions have tarnished the Republic of China's international image.
The ministry appealed to the public to help put a stop to such activity before more harm is done.
MOFA pointed out in the statement that recent demonstrations led by some local politicians have targeted foreign embassies and representative offices.

"Unfortunately, they turned into disorderly incidents that violated the personal safety and privacy of foreign envoys and diplomats and hampered their freedom of movement and their ability to perform official business," the ministry said.
For example, some protesters against US President Bill Clinton's June 25-July 3 visit to mainland China posted banners on the walls of the American Institute in Taiwan facilities, MOFA said.

Anti-Japanese protesters went to the residence of the director of the Japanese Interchange Association in June, where they defaced the walls, lights and intercom with paint, eggs and graffiti and physically vandalized the property, MOFA said.
In addition to trespassing on the premises, MOFA said, the anti-Japanese protesters also threatened to intrude at night.

In July, demonstrators against the rape of ethnic Chinese women in Indonesia threw bags of urine, damaged office facilities, and physically attacked the vice chairman of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei who went out to receive them.
The ministry said it has continued to receive complaints and concerns registered by foreign envoys.

Meanwhile, the ministry said, foreign friends in Taiwan have begun to worry that this uncivilized and seemingly behavior will not only portray the Republic of China as being unfriendly to foreigners, but also invite retaliation against Taiwan diplomats, businessmen and even tourists overseas.
"The grandstanding by politicians should be stopped immediately and be condemned in the strongest possible terms," MOFA stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRIAL VIOLATES BASIC HUMAN RIGHTS: MAC

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities violated the human rights of four Taiwan businessmen by not giving them an open trial, an official with the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

Sheu Ke-sheng, MAC vice chairman, made the remarks a day after Beijing's Number One Intermediate People's Court sentenced Kou Chien-ming, one of the four men, to four years in prison on spying charges.
The three others identified as Chen Shao-yu, Han Ming-wen, and Chou Chang-ming were also convicted of espionage but were exempted from punishment because their crimes were considered minor.
Sheu said many questions in the case remain unclear, and Beijing, which began the trial Aug. 3 behind closed doors, has violated the principle of basic human rights
The case has raised concern among many Taiwan businessmen operating in the mainland as they are worried that their human rights will not be protected.

Kou has filed an appeal with the higher court. Meanwhile, the other three are now under protection of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), Beijing's intermediary body established to deal with Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

The three men should be allowed to return to Taiwan as soon as possible, Sheu said. He added that the MAC will continue to ask SEF to convey to the mainland the sense that the MAC will give its full support to Kou in his appeal.

Sheu said he hoped the mainland can resolve the case without damaging the relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. He also asked the mainland to address a series of cases involving the protection of Taiwan people's personal safety and property in the mainland.

He urged SEF and ARATS to actively pursue "constructive" consultation on issues that directly affect the lives and interests of the people on both sides of the strait, including the protection of personal safety and property of Taiwan businessmen, judicial assistance, trade dispute arbitration and joint crackdown on crime.

Beijing accused Kou, who established the Taipei-based Chinese Cross-Strait Civilian Exchanges Association in 1971, and the other three men, who are all members of the association, of using the association as a cover for spying operations in mainland China between June 1993 and March 1998.
These operations included the collection of political, economic and military intelligence, according to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S 2ND-QUARTER GROWTH REVISED DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Canadian authorities on Wednesday revised downward its estimate for second-quarter growth in the country's real gross domestic product to 2.5 percent from 3 percent.
The summer 1998 edition of the Bank of Canada Review painted an otherwise positive picture for the Canadian economy, saying there was a strong momentum in the economy for at least the short term.
It forecast that Canada's 1998 annual growth rate will reach a healthy 3.5 percent.

The quarterly review confirmed that Asia's economic crisis has had a negative effect on Canada. Less manufacturing in Asia means less demand for Canadian materials, but the losses caused by Asia have been offset by the booming US economy which absorbed 80 percent of Canadian exports, the report said.

"Here in Canada, allowing for the effects of temporary factors such as layoffs associated with the strike at General Motors, the underlying momentum in the economy continues to be positive," an update in the review said.

Inflation should remain in the bottom end of the bank's 1 percent to 3 percent target range for the remainder of the year, business investment remains strong, retail sales continue to climb and employment and income continue to grow.

In the longer term, the bank warned that the US Federal Reserve may have to raise interest rates to curb the overheated US economy. No change, however, is anticipated in the next few months, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FM ANGRY AT ONE NATION ATTACK OF ASIANS

TEXT.P: Australia's foreign minister hit out at a One Nation Party supporter for writing a letter to the Bangkok Post to attack Asians.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer described the letter as an appalling, abusive and racist attack. He called on party leaders including Pauline Hanson to reject the letter which was attributed to a Hanson supporter from Queensland, the Australian Financial Review reported Thursday.

The letter said most Asians originated from a lower socio-economic class and did not fit into Australia's western society. It said the Asian-occupied suburbs of Australia were dirty, undesirable and flourishing in crime.

The letter writer also attacked "excessive" Japanese and South Korean tourists for discouraging white Australians from "visiting their very own country" and described Asian athletes are "either drug cheats or insignificant in their abilities."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARAFAT CALLS FOR SAVING OF MIDDLE EAST PEACE

TEXT.P: Palestinian Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat Wednesday urged the international community to help save the peace process in the Middle East from collapsing.
Speaking at the South African parliament, Arafat said saving the peace process is an international necessity and in its best interest.
He also called for the United States, as a major sponsor of peace in the region, to broker a solution to the impasse.
The Palestinian leader asked South African President Nelson Mandela to tell US President Bill Clinton to be tough with those who were refusing a peaceful initiative.
Arafat arrived in South Africa Monday for a two-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA KEEPING CLOSE WATCH ON INDONESIAN SITUATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Thursday it is keeping a close watch on the situation in Indonesia amid reports that new riots may erupt again later this month.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the ROC representative office in Indonesia has also called a series of meetings with Chinese community leaders and representatives of Taiwan business people in that country to exchange views on the possibility of new rioting breaking out on Aug. 17, Indonesia's National Day.

"The staff of our representative office in Jakarta has also discussed feasible measures with Chinese community leaders and senior executives of major Taiwan trade associations to cope with possible developments in the Southeast Asian country," Wu said.

To his knowledge, Wu said, the Indonesian government has attached great importance to the possible outbreak of new riots and has taken precautionary measures to prevent the recurrence of political turmoil in May that led to the downfall of the Suharto government.

Responding to foreign wire service reports that the Indonesian government will ask US, Taiwan and mainland Chinese law enforcement authorities to jointly investigate atrocities committed by Indonesian rioters against ethnic Chinese women during May riots, Wu said both the ROC government and its private sector have coordinated their efforts to assist Indonesian authorities in handling related issues.

For example, Wu said, the ROC representative office in Jakarta has promised to help search for ethnic Chinese women raped or abused by Indonesian rioters and to report those cases to the Indonesian government for reference.

"Our representative office has long taken the initiative to coordinate with Indonesian authorities with a view to better protect personal safety and property rights of ROC nationals and overseas Chinese there," Wu said.

Meanwhile, Wu said, local women's rights groups have sent representatives to Indonesia to forge channels of communications with Indonesian authorities and women's rights activists to facilitate relief measures for abused ethnic Chinese women and to gain a better understanding of the facts surrounding reported atrocities committed by Indonesian rioters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FIRST AMONG ASIAN TIGERS IN IMD TECHNOLOGY RATING

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked seventh in the world for its scientific and technological strengths, the highest such ranking it has ever achieved, according to the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The ranking, issued by the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management and Development (IMD), noted Taiwan's advance in science and technology development. The island ranked 10th in the 1997 survey, CEPD officials said.
The officials said compared with other Asian economies, Taiwan was seen to have made significant progress in sharpening its competitive edge in the technology industry.
The IMD's competitive study placed Taiwan on top among the tiger economies in Asia, ahead of Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore.

Taiwan ranked among the top 12 in four sub-categories. It ranked 12th for resources in research and development, fifth in science and technology management, sixth in scientific research environment, and seventh in intellectual property protection, according to the IMD World Competitive Yearbook.

The Swiss institute annually compares the competitiveness of 46 economies by measuring economic strength, the economic openness to international trade, government efficiency, financial services, infrastructure, management, science and technology, education and training. The study defines national competitiveness as a country's ability to help keep businesses competitive.
Taiwan was listed 16th in the 1998 general rating, up seven notches from its 1997 ranking.

CEPD officials pointed out that technology is regarded as the key battle field of the world's economic campaigns in the approach to the 21st century. Taiwan must now concentrate on its technological progress and further enhance its competitiveness, which are currently its most important tasks, they said.

However, the economic experts warned that although Taiwan enjoyed a boost in its IMD intellectual property protection rating, its record on patent applications and patented goods -- which are key criteria for the competitive rating -- were seen declining over the past two years. The decreases are expected to pull down Taiwan's future ranking in the field, they said.
According to latest statistics released by the National Bureau of Standards, the authority approved 19,551 local patent applications in 1997, and 19,410 cases in 1996, down from 20,717 in 1995.
Growth in the number of approved patents posted at 0.73 percent last year, while there was a negative figure in 1996 following the 64.9 percent growth in 1995, the figures showed.

Taiwan should also pay more attention to its protection of intellectual property rights especially after the United States reinstated the island to its "Special 301 Watch List." The list, under provisions of a US law, allows punitive measures to be taken against countries deemed to have harmed the export of US goods or services.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX, FUTURES EXCHANGE DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices recovered on the Taiwan Stock Market (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 11.04 points to close at 7,362.55.

The bourse, encouraged by the appreciation of the Japanese yen and stock market rebounds in both Europe and the United States, opened nearly 100 points higher than Wednesday's closing but declined under selling pressure of electronics stocks near the end of the trading session.
The market turnover was NT$82.44 billion, an increase from the previous trading session which saw NT$67.21 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers by 280 to 134, with 82 issues remaining unchanged.
Construction stocks registered a gain, moving up by 1.6 percent, followed by chemical shares at 1.2 percent, and tourism issues at 1.1 percent.
Rubber issues lost ground, dropping 3.1 percent, followed by transportation shares at 1.1 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures also posted a general decline.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down 39 points to close at 7,291, while those for October surged 105 points to 7,450, and those for December dropped 49 points to 7,476.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 496, one, and four, respectively.
The Taiex Index Futures for March moved up seven points to close at 7,512 with six contract transactions. No transactions were registered for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEBERTHAL SAID TO PLAY CONSTRUCTIVE ROLE IN US-TAIWAN TIES

TEXT.P: The de facto US ambassador to Taiwan has said that he believes Kenneth Lieberthal, the new senior director in charge of Asia-Pacific affairs under the US National Security Council (NSC), will play a constructive role in US-Taiwan relations.

Darryl N. Johnson, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of official ties, made the remarks in an exclusive interview with the CNA on Tuesday.
Describing Lieberthal as "a very good friend of mine," Johnson said Taiwan need not be concerned over Lieberthal's appointment to the NSC post.

Johnson recalled that he last met Lieberthal in Taipei in February, when the noted China hand traveled to the island to attend a conference on mainland China's political and economic development in the wake of the 15th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party and on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Johnson said Lieberthal was "very impressed, very positively impressed" by his Taipei visit.
Noting that Lieberthal is a brilliant scholar, Johnson said the former director of the China Policy Research Center of the University of Michigan is highly qualified for his new NSC position.

However, Johnson said Lieberthal may not be accurately understood in Taiwan in terms of his personal views and in terms of his background. He pointed out that Lieberthal has many years of experience in management of US relationships with both Beijing and Taipei.

"It's of vital significance to the United States. So I think with him in the position at the National Security Council, he will certainly take guidance from the president and from the other people in the policy process. I have every hope and expectation that his role will be very constructive," Johnson explained.
During his Taipei visit, Lieberthal presented a paper urging the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to sign a 50-year provisional agreement to regulate bilateral relations under a "one China" principle.

According to the Lieberthal-proposed agreement, Taiwan should recognize itself as part of China and promise not to seek de jure independence, while mainland China is required to renounce the use of force against Taiwan. During the 50-year period, the two sides should hold regular high-level talks to pave the way for eventual reunification.
Lieberthal's proposal triggered negative responses in Taiwan, but Johnson said the reaction was partly due to the fact that Lieberthal's views were misunderstood.
In fact, Johnson said, the objective of Lieberthal's paper was to try to lay out some ideas for maintaining the status quo. "That's what it was about," he said.

Johnson further said that what Lieberthal was trying to do was to lay out a framework for maintaining the status quo in a constructive way that would allow Taiwan and mainland China to go about their business for an almost indefinite time, without worrying about the question of future status.

Commenting on some local observers' worries that Lieberthal may take advantage of his new post to force Taiwan to negotiate political issues with Beijing, Johnson said it is US policy to encourage cross-strait dialogue.

"The policy of encouraging dialogue between Taiwan and the mainland goes back many years. It does not depend on any one individual. It is US policy. We do support dialogue. We have long supported dialogue. This is not something dependent on who is on the National Security Council," Johnson stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US COMMUNICATION CHANNEL EFFECTIVE: AIT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The existing communications channel between Taiwan and the United States is "extremely effective," said a ranking US official in charge of Taiwan affairs on Tuesday.

Darryl N. Johnson, director of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei Office, said although there have been suggestions recently that a "Track Two" communication channel be set up between Taiwan and the US, the "Track One" communication channel representing the two parties is working efficiently and smoothly.

As the top US liaison official in Taiwan, the AIT official said he and his counterpart Stephen Chang, Taiwan's representative based in Washington D.C., do not have any difficulties in meeting local people.
"I don't think there is any problem as far as communicating between people representing these two bodies (is concerned)," he stressed.
As to meetings between Taiwanese and US officials, Johnson said they still represent the "Track One" approach.

Despite the fact that the two countries maintain no official diplomatic relations, these meetings have a special "unofficial characteristic, because they are meetings between people with a specified responsibility and authority on both sides," the AIT official said.

The idea for a Track Two communication channel was proposed by former US officials and academics, including former US Defense Secretary William Perry, Johnson said, noting that the 1996 Taiwan Strait missile crisis was one of five or six most serious issues Perry had to deal with during his tenure as defense chief.
This event may have motivated Perry to try to play a more constructive role, Johnson added.

However, Johnson emphasized that Perry, who is not an incumbent US official, does not speak for or act on behalf of the US government. "His meetings with people in the States or with people here or in other places are the same as those between any other unofficial private American and people in responsible positions here," he went on to say.

"My own view is that as long as you have good communications on Track One between the authorized representatives on both sides, Track Two is basically something extra," Johnson said. "It's something which may provide additional outside ideas, additional motivations, or additional influences if you like. It does not change the context within which the players participate."
Citing remarks made by President Lee Teng-hui about a year ago during a meeting between the two, the AIT Taipei Office director said, "We don't lack for messengers, we lack for a message."

"A lot of people want to be messengers to carry messages back and forth," he said, "but the point is what is the context of the message. And for that we have adequate channels, and the mechanism is quite effective."

Asked whether the US already has a candidate in mind for the Track Two talks -- such as Koo Cheng-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation -- Johnson stressed the US government and the AIT take no position on who should participate in "informal conversations."

"There are many people in the US who have an interest in encouraging peaceful resolutions ... Some of them have official authority, and many do not," he noted. "They are driven in most cases by an effort to try to help, but they do not act on behalf of the US government."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US RELATIONS STRONG AND HEALTHY: AIT DIRECTOR (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 13 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Although the word "American" appears in its title, the school has no affiliation with the AIT, Johnson explained. He expressed confidence that the whole matter will be properly handled by the Taiwan provincial and central authorities.

When asked whether the incident has been overpoliticized, Johnson was hesitant to comment on the issue, but he said the AIT, as an agency which represents the US government in Taiwan, is concerned about the welfare of American students and citizens here.

Speaking on the recent tragic terrorist bombings of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, Johnson said the AIT is cooperating very closely with the authorities in Taipei to increase security measures for its facilities.
In his view, Taiwan is a safe place to live and work. "We have no reason to assume otherwise," the AIT official said.

"We have to be vigilant, and I think that is true everywhere. But we intend to keep our doors open and intend to continue operating, to issue visas, and to receive people. We will do so with care and sensible prudence," he added.

Hailing Taiwan's democratization, Johnson called himself an interested observer of the year-end elections as "democracy is a wonderful thing." However, the AIT is not in the position to make a comment in this regard. "But we support the free exercise of political opinions, and we applaud the process."

The veteran diplomat, who previously served as US ambassador to Lithuania and has been at his current post for more than two years, said he and his wife have been "deeply touched, impressed and moved by the warmth of the people of Taiwan. This applies not only to high officials but also to lots of ordinary people."

"We like to get out a lot and get around on the island, and to visit people in the private sector, as well as government institutions and schools," Johnson said, concluding that "we have been very pleased to be here."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-US RELATIONS STRONG AND HEALTHY: AIT DIRECTOR (I)

TEXT.P: The top US liaison official in Taiwan said on Tuesday that Taiwan-US relations are healthy and strong, and that there is universal support in the United States for Taiwan.

Darryl N. Johnson, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), told the CNA in an exclusive interview that there has never been such a broad range of good feeling, understanding, and close relations between the two countries.

Apart from some core issues and a few "very hard problems" on intellectual property rights and certain commercial activities, "I think it (the Taiwan-US relationship) is a very healthy and strong relationship," he asserted.
When asked to comment on remarks by US Senator Slade Gorton last week that supporting Taiwan has become a mainstream position in the United States, Johnson said he agrees with Gorton's observation.

Stressing that US public opinion toward Taiwan has always been favorable, especially in the last 11 years, as democracy has flourished on the island, Johnson said: "I think it is true to say that there is almost no difference in opinion across the political spectrum (and) no opposition to Taiwan democracy. It is considered a great success story, economically as well.
"Maintaining the deepest possible contacts with Taiwan has been and is the US policy," the ranking AIT official said.

However, Johnson said that maintaining friendly relations with Taiwan does not mean being hostile to mainland China, or vice versa. "We don't do this as an `either-or' situation because most of the American people think it is both possible and desirable to have good relations with both, and we do. It is true now," he continued.

Asked whether US President Bill Clinton's engagement policy with mainland China goes against the will of the American people, Johnson said that although there have been several advances, there have been no big changes in US engagement policy toward Taiwan and mainland China, and that Clinton is only following the policy set as far back as the Carter administration, and carried on through the successive administrations of Reagan and Bush.

Referring to two recent resolutions which were almost unanimously passed in the Senate and the House of Representatives to extend congressional support for Taiwan, Johnson said that the passage of the resolutions served to "reaffirm the basis of our policy towards Taiwan and the mainland."

"The administration did not oppose these resolutions. Extracting the political language and looking at the wording of the documents, in this case, there were no important differences between what the Congress was saying and what the administration says," he said.
The Taiwan Relations Acts signed by former President Jimmy Carter in 1979 has been, and still is the basis for US policy toward Taiwan, he noted.

Turning to other current issues, Johnson commented on the case of the Taichung Lincoln American School, a central Taiwan school for foreign children which made headlines after it was discovered to have been illegally built on land zoned for resort use.
Johnson made clear that the role played by the AIT was purely as a "receiver of information" from the local community there. "We have been no party in any way at all." (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENVOY REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN US POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN (I)

TEXT.P: The de facto US ambassador to Taiwan has reaffirmed that there is no change in Washington's policy of selling defensive weapons to the Republic of China.

"The United States will continue to sell arms of defense nature to Taiwan," Darryl N. Johnson, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), said in an exclusive interview with the CNA on Tuesday.
The United States has consistently sold a number of defense items to Taiwan annually, Johnson said, adding that such deals will be continued in the years ahead.
The veteran career diplomat, however, would not elaborate on the items, quantity and prices concerning a new deal expected to be announced in the near future.
"The point is, as our president said in Beijing, that we do intend to continue our arms sales policy to Taiwan," Johnson said.

He pointed out that US President Bill Clinton clearly explained the basic elements of the US arms sales policy toward Taiwan during his June 25-July 3 state visit to mainland China. Clinton also reaffirmed US commitment to abiding by the Taiwan Relations Act, a US law that regulates its relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Johnson stressed that Clinton is the first US president to state on mainland China's territory the US intention to continue arms sales to Taiwan.

The amicable American envoy further said there are generally no conflicting views between Taiwan and the United States concerning arms deals. The two countries also maintain close military cooperation, he said, adding, "We hope Taiwan is satisfied with military equipment provided by us."

Touching on the possible impact of improving Beijing-Washington ties on the interaction between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Johnson said the United States is hopeful that better Washington-Beijing ties will create an incentive for Beijing to moderate its policy toward Taiwan and to improve the conditions for better cross-strait relations.

Johnson said it will become clear in the coming month whether both sides of the strait are prepared to move toward a better relationship. He was referring to a planned landmark trip to mainland China by Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, C. F. Koo, this fall. During his trip, Koo is expected to meet his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan.
Johnson said the planned "Koo-Wang" meeting this fall was not necessarily prompted by Clinton's high-profile mainland visit.
"I think the event has its own engine, its own momentum," Johnson noted.
Asked if Taiwan's drive to expand its international space will be limited by Clinton's recent "three noes" statement, Johnson said Taiwan need not worry about that.

Clinton mentioned the "three noes" at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai on June 30, which refers to no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for "two Chinas, or one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.
Johnson said a major development in Taiwan-US ties in recent months was the signing of a formal agreement on terms for Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) last Friday.
The agreement manifests US support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations for which statehood is not a requirement, Johnson said.

He pointed out although the United States does not support Taiwan's entry to the United Nations and UN-related bodies, it has never hesitated to support Taiwan's participation in non-political international organizations.

Commenting on news reports that Beijing is pushing Tokyo to either codify or throw its verbal support behind the so-called "three noes" during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan early next month, Johnson said he believes there will be no important changes in Japan's approach to Taiwan-related issues.
