Johnson supported his assessment by citing Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's recent call on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to resort to peaceful dialogue for a peaceful solution to their disputes.
As for how Japan will deal with those issues, Johnson said it is up to the Japanese to make their own decision. (By Sofia Wu) (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGE IN US POLICY (II)

TEXT.P: In the course of the interview, Johnson would not directly confirm a newspaper report that Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the ROC's National Security Council, met with US Deputy National Security Adviser James Steinberg in New York late last month.
Nevertheless, Johnson did say that although such a meeting would have been of an unofficial nature, it would still have been part of the "Track One" dialogue between the two countries.

Johnson explained that although Taiwan and the United States do not maintain official ties, meetings between authorized representatives from both sides, namely the AIT and the ROC representative office in Washington, D.C., should still be defined as "Track One" dialogue. "And such meetings have been very helpful," he added.
"I don't think there is any problem as far as communication between the people representing these two bodies (is concerned)," he said.

Commenting on the idea presented by former US Defense Secretary William Perry and several American scholars to set up "Track Two" informal dialogue channels, Johnson said he thinks such channels can provide additional ideas, opinions and motivation.
However, Johnson said he does not think "Track Two" dialogue channels can change the "context within which the players participate."
Johnson further said the United States is fully aware that Taiwan is highly sensitive to any improvement in Washington-Beijing relations.

"There are people here who believe that better US-PRC relations must be disadvantageous, must be not beneficial for Taiwan. In fact, our view, and my strongly held personal view, is that the opposite is true," Johnson said.
Johnson further pointed out that US public opinion toward Taiwan has always been favorable, especially in the past 11 years, as democracy has taken root and flourished on the island.

"I think it is true to say that there is almost no difference in opinion across the political spectrum (and) no opposition to Taiwan democracy. It is considered a great success story," Johnson said, adding that maintaining the deepest possible contacts with Taiwan "has been and is the US policy."
However, Johnson said that maintaining friendly ties with Taiwan does not mean being hostile to mainland China, or vice versa.
"We don't do this as an `either-or' situation, because most of the American people think it is both possible and desirable to have good relations with both, and we do," he explained.

Johnson further said apart from some core issues and a few "very hard problems" on intellectual property rights protection and certain commercial activities, the United States has never maintained such expansive, friendly and close relationships with both sides of the Taiwan Strait as it does now.
The soft-spoken American envoy, who has been in his current stint for more than two years, said he and his wife have been "deeply touched, impressed and moved by the warmth of the people of Taiwan."

As the the tenure for the AIT directorship is usually three years, Johnson said it will not become clear until either late this year or early next year who his successor and what his own next job assignment will be.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB ACKNOWLEDGES SURVEILLANCE OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau has maintained surveillance operations for reasons of national security, bureau officials said Thursday.
The officials made the remarks after a local news magazine reported that the government has stepped up political surveillance of personnel on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

According to The Journalist weekly, the MJIB decided on Feb. 13 that it would monitor Taiwan people traveling to the mainland for investment, tourism and cultural exchanges, those who are suspected of smuggling guns and ammunition from the mainland, illegal mainland immigrants, Taiwan gangsters traveling to the mainland and those in the publishing industry.
Even entertainers who have recently made frequent visits to the mainland will also be monitored, the report said.
The MJIB would not confirm the report, saying only that it monitors the past and present telecommunications, whereabouts and connections of related personnel for safeguarding of national security.
The Journalist said the MJIB has another project which targets religious figures traveling to the mainland and foreign nationals in Taiwan.

Those targeted included local temple personnel who organize group pilgrimages to the mainland, foreign nationals who are in Taiwan to collect financial, industrial technology and political information and foreign laborers employed by local manufacturers.
It is understood that the project aims to prevent foreign and religious figures from being lured and used in the collection of information for mainland China.
The reports said another project was established on March 1, 1992 and it monitors mainlanders who snuck into Taiwan and those who came to Taiwan to visit or live with their relatives.
The bureau officials said the purpose of the project was to prevent the infiltration of mainland spies.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUANG KUN-HUEI, JASON HU TO BE DECORATED BY PARAGUAYAN GOV'T

TEXT.P: Republic of China Presidential Secretary General Huang Kun-huei and Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu are scheduled to arrive in Asuncion Thursday to attend the inauguration of Paraguay President Raul Cubas Grau Saturday.
Both Huang and Hu will be decorated with the National Order of Merit by Paraguayan Foreign Minister Ruben Melgarejo Lanzoni upon their arrival.
The medal is often given to foreign heads of state, vice presidents, princes, cardinals, government ministers, or former presidents.
The decorating ceremony will culminate Melgarejo's official activities as foreign minister of Paraguay. He will step down from the government post on Saturday when the new Cabinet is sworn in.
Huang, who is leading a delegation of about 20 members , will also likely meet with Chinese residing in Paraguay in a dinner party on Thursday.

ROC Vice Minister Francisco H.L. Ou, Secretary-General of the International Cooperation and Development Fund, Loh Ping-cheang, and Section Chief of the Department of Central and South American Affairs, Chou Lin, arrived two days earlier.

The ROC delegation also includes Transportation and Communications Vice Minister Mao Chi-kuo, Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung, Taiwan Sugar Corporation President Chen Ping-tsai, and Taiwan Vegetable Oil Manufacturers Association President Wang Ling-yi.
Loh and Ling will discuss with Paraguayan officials plans to grant loans to local small- and medium-sized businesses, and issues related to Paraguayan agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUABLE 5TH CENTURY B.C. INSTRUMENT BOUND FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The duplicate of a fifth century B.C. chimed instrument is expected to be imported indirectly from mainland China's Hubei Province to Taiwan in two days.

The instrument, comprised of 65 bronze bells, is considered proof of the sophistication of ancient Chinese musicians and artisans. The original dates back to the Early Warring States Period over 2,000 years ago and was unearthed from the middle chamber of the tomb of Zenghou Yi, a feudal lord, in an area known today as Suixian, in the central province of Hubei.

The duplicated instrument is expected to be included in the collections of the Ethnic Music Center being established by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), said Liao Kuei-ying, executive curator of the private Chang Foundation Museum which is importing the instrument on behalf of the CCA.
The set that is being delivered to Taiwan is one of the three copies made by the Provincial Hubei Museum after the valuable instrument was unearthed in 1978.

The instrument consists of 65 bells or "bianchong" which hang vertically or diagonally under wood beams on three different levels. Each bell can produce two different notes, making the instrument capable of playing almost any modern piece of music, Liao said.

In an overseas performance tour several years ago, mainland Chinese musicians played Beethoven's Fifth Symphony with a duplication of the instrument, debunking the myth that the Chinese have no theory and instruments to play sophisticated music.

What is perhaps most amazing about the ancient chimed instrument is not only that it can produce a full-range of musical notes and 12 semi-tones from C2 to D7, but it also contained gold-inlaid inscriptions revealing the then theory of music and how people from six neighboring states played the same music.

The inscriptions involving 3,755 characters greatly advanced modern-day knowledge of ancient Chinese music, said Liao of the Chang Foundation Museum, which sponsored an exhibition in Taiwan featuring a duplication of the ancient instrument late last year.

Another amazing aspect about the fifth century B.C. musical instrument is the sophistication of the bronze material. The bronze alloy indicated that the metallurgical industry in China 2,000 years ago was well established. Other details, including the casting, painting and carving on the instrument were equally stunning, she said.

The import of the duplication has so far not been smooth, Liao admitted. First, it is not allowed to be directly ordered by the CCA because of the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Second, the Chang Foundation Museum is now facing an import tax and handling fees of more than NT$2 million (US$58,310) charged by customs authorities who do not consider the duplicated instrument as "materials to be used in academic research" as it was claimed by its importer.
The CCA has filed an appeal with the Department of Customs Administration for a re-examination of the import application in the hopes that the instrument will be allowed to be imported duty-free.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S STOCK MARKET, CURRENCY REMAIN UNDER PRESSURE

TEXT.P: Australia's stock market and currency remained under pressure on Thursday as investors worried that Asia's volatility would effect Wall Street amid deepening Asian economic woes.
The All Ordinaries Index edged up slightly in early afternoon trade, rising about four points from Wednesday's close of 2,551, the lowest close since June 17 this year.
The index dropped for the sixth consecutive day since Aug. 5 and analysts said there is still room for the index to fall further in coming days unless good news comes from Wall Street and Japan.

The Australian dollar slipped to 59.12 US cents in early afternoon trade, down from Wednesday's close of 59.85 cents. Analysts said the currency could fall further to 55 US cents if the Japanese yen breached the psychological barrier of 150 to the US dollar.
"The stock and currency markets are volatile and it's more difficult to predict how long they would continue to come under pressure," one analyst said.
"But investors are getting more jittery and they are now liable to get burned if they make a wrong investment," another said.
Analysts said not only Australian investors have suffered losses, but also investors in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Thailand, Japan and other Southeast Asian countries.

Wall Street could fall further because fundamentals are deteriorating rapidly which is further compounded by a deceleration in credit growth as well as lower growth and earning forecasts from Latin America, which accounts for 21 percent of US exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA STEEL GIANT EYES OTHER MARKETS AMID ASIAN SLUMP

TEXT.P: Broken Hill Proprietary Corp. (BHP), Australia's leading industrial conglomerate, registered sharp declines in its steel exports to Taiwan and other Asian countries.

BHP's two operating divisions, BHP Integrated Steel and BHP Steel Products, are reducing their steel exports to one-third from two-thirds of their overall sales of over 3 million tonnes a year in Asia.

BHP officials believe the slump in the first two months of this year will adversely affect the group's steel exports which have led it to shift its promotional focus to other markets to make up some of the losses in Asia.

In addition, BHP is trying to increase its sales of steel products domestically, a company spokesman said. He said the steel market in Asia will remain gloomy and the Asian economic crisis could last longer than early predicted, possibly four instead of two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S CRACKDOWN ON SMUGGLERS DEALS A BLOW TO HK, WESTERN FIRMS

TEXT.P: Mainland China's unprecedented crackdown on military smuggling is dealing a heavy blow to Hong Kong and western companies looking for cheap access to the Chinese market.

In a dispatch from Beijing on Thursday, the Sydney Morning Herald's correspondent David Lague reported that the crackdown is choking a massive inflow of illegal imports from Hong Kong and is threatening to deny many major western companies cheap access to the mainland market.

The early success of the central government's anti-smuggling crusade appears likely to boost mainland's burgeoning trade surplus but it could also hurt Hong Kong's embattled economy, the daily reported.
A major proportion of goods shipped illegally through ports on mainland China's southern coast come from the former British colony.

Elements of the People's Liberation Army and the People's Armed Police reportedly control much of this illegal trade, but the threat of smuggling and official corruption to mainland's economic growth and political stability forced President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji to back the sweeping crackdown.

Special teams of customs inspectors from northern mainland China have been deployed to ports along the south coast over the past month in a bid to halt the rampant smuggling of goods such as cigarettes, electronic items and food, the daily reported.
Beijing authorities estimated it was losing about US$12 billion in revenue a year from unpaid duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES CANADIAN LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday expressed the hope that Canada would support the Republic of China in its bid to join international economic and trade organizations.
He made the remark when receiving a group of Canadian parliamentarians headed by Mac Harb.

Accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan, Harb and his colleagues, including John Maloney, Ivan Grose, Richard Harris, Madeleine Dalphond-Guiral, and Paul Bonwick, paid a courtesy call to Lee at the Presidential Office.
Lee told his guests that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Canada has ample room for growth in the future as it currently averages only US$3 billion annually.
He also expressed the belief that the current trade problems between the two countries will be resolved smoothly after Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Harb praised Taiwan for its vitality and its ability to survive the severe test of the Asian financial turmoil. The lawmaker expressed hope that the two sides would further enhance economic and cultural exchanges in the future. He also reiterated Canada's support for Taiwan's bid to join the WTO.

In addition to expressing his appreciation for Canada's support, Lee said the Republic of China, which is a free and democratic country, has confidence in facing the financial challenges ahead. He attributed the relative small impact the region's economic storm has had on Taiwan to its on-the-track economic and political system, and precautions taken by both the government and public.

The president considers Canada a very good investment destination for Taiwan businessmen. He also welcomes industries with advanced technology from Canada to invest and build factories in Taiwan to improve substantive relations between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.023 against the greenback in Taipei Thursday, closing at 34.771.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.765, and had a low of 34.815.
The interback US dollar trading reached US$259.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN RESIDENTS SCARED BY INVADING MAINLAND FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: Hundreds of mainland Chinese fishing boats have been landing on the beaches of Taiwan's frontline Kinmen island group to poach fish and shrimp in recent months, triggering fears among Kinmen residents, local police said on Thursday.

"We have continued to receive complaints from local residents that mainland fishing boats have been making night landings at low tide to trespass on Kinmen coastline in recent months," a Kinmen police officer said.

The incursions have triggered worry among many Kinmen residents about their personal safety, the officer said, adding that some locals have complained that they cannot sleep at night because of fears of mainland threats and the noise made by the mainland fishermen.
Responding to the mounting complaints, Chang Chang-po, chief of the Kinmen County Police Bureau, made an inspection tour of the region on Wednesday night.

Chang said the issue has become very serious. In the past, mainland fishermen conducted illicit trade deals with their Kinmen counterparts in waters near the center line of the narrow Taiwan Strait that separates Taiwan and mainland China. Later, however, they began intruding into ROC territorial waters near Kinmen to sell agricultural goods.

"And now, they have even started landing on Kinmen's coastal regions to poach fish and shellfish. Their daring provocative actions have imposed heavy pressure on local police and security forces," Chang said.

Initial investigations show that hundreds of mainland fishing boats are often to be found anchored along the coastline from Houfeng port in southwestern Kinmen to the neighboring ports of Kuningtou, Anchi, Housha, Chunglin, Chiuanlin and Liuao.

With so many mainland fishing boats operating during the hours of darkness, police said, the light cast by the ships brightens the night sky and makes Kinmen's coastal region look like a night market.

"Apart from poaching, we are worried that the mainland fishermen may commit crimes such as drug trafficking and smuggling of firearms and humans," Chang said, adding that he is also afraid that some of the mainland fishermen may even commit robberies or burglaries during their secret landings.

Chang said he has ordered all Kinmen's police branches to set up special task forces to intensify coastal patrols to prevent mainland fishermen from making illegal landings, as well as to thwart any smuggling attempts.
The Kinmen military command has also ordered the coast guard to tighten spot checks and patrols to defend the island group's coastline.

Kinmen is closer to mainland China's Fujian province than to Taiwan. As relations across the Taiwan Strait have been very sensitive of late, Kinmen's garrison troops no longer open fire with warning shots on encroaching mainland vessels. Instead, they now just chase them away.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR QUESTIONS LEAKS OF NSC SECRET MEETINGS

TEXT.P: A lawmaker on Thursday called on the National Security Council (NSC) to address the problem of serious leaks within the organization.

Su Huan-dji, an opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislator, said that each of the five secret meetings between high-ranking officials from Washington and Taipei had been leaked to the media, including the contents of one meeting.
He urged the chairman of the NSC, ROC President Lee Teng-hui, to deal with the issue.

Meetings between high-ranking officials from Taipei and Washington have been held on an irregular basis since March 1996 when the missile crisis erupted in the Taiwan Strait. It is the most important "first track" channel of communication between Taipei and Washington, Su said.
The NSC talks have involved sensitive topics regarding cross-strait matters and issues between Taipei and Washington, the legislator said.
Starting from October 1996, a double-tracked, high-level dialogue, directed by the US national security adviser took place between Washington and Beijing, as well as Washington and Taipei, Su said.

The dialogue between Washington and Beijing was conducted by the US national security advisor and Liu Huaqiu, mainland's director of the Office of Foreign Affairs under the State Council. The dialogue between Washington and Taipei involved the US deputy national security adviser and Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the NSC, who was accompanied either by a vice minister of the Foreign Affairs Ministry or Taipei's representative in the US, explained Su.

In an effort to stave off interference from Beijing, Washington demanded that Taipei keep the contents of the talks and its itinerary a secret, Su said. This was why the meetings were held in a low-profile manner and no official details were released to the media.

However, Su remarked, all five meetings between Taipei and Washington were reported in the media. The first three meetings were disclosed two months after the meetings were held, the fourth was known three days later, and in the fifth meeting, details of the discussions appeared in local papers prior to Ding's return.

The lawmaker went on to say that only the itinerary was disclosed in the first two trips while the contents of the dialogue were revealed after the third meeting. The details of the fifth meeting published in newspapers appeared as though they had been recorded from the meeting.

Su said the repeated leaks in the NSC talks may interrupt the dialogue between Washington and Taipei or may result in Washington downgrading the level of officials it sends to the talks. If this were to happen, it would constitute a threat to Taiwan's security, he added.
The legislator said as NSC chairman, Lee should order a thorough investigation into the matter since the NSC has not done anything prior to or following the leaks to prevent a similar recurrence.
The director of the National Security Bureau should also make a report to the legislature on the investigation of the matter, added the DPP lawmaker.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WARNS OF BEIJING'S INCREASING DIPLOMATIC CLOUT

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin may pressure Japan to explicitly exclude Taiwan from the geographic areas covered by the US-Japan defense cooperation pact during his forthcoming visit to Tokyo, a senior official said on Thursday.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, issued the warning in a special report on its working programs delivered at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

"In addition to pushing Japan to throw support behind the so-called 'three noes' toward Taiwan, Jiang is also likely to force Japan to promise not to abide by its defense cooperation guidelines with the United States for any Taiwan-related incidents, " Chang said.
Noting that 1997 was a banner year for mainland China's bid to upgrade its international reputation and status, Chang said Beijing's all-out diplomatic offensive has borne fruit.
Chang cautioned that the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing and Washington-Tokyo-Beijing relations have both shown signs of leaning toward Beijing.

He further pointed out that US President Bill Clinton's recent "three noes" statement has had negative effect on Taiwan. "We must heighten alert on whether Clinton's statement will result in a domino effect on Taiwan's bid to expand international space."

The "three noes" refer to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international bodies in which statehood is a requirement.

Chang said mainland China attaches great importance to relations with the United States. "It intends to use its close ties with the United States to impose further pressure on Taiwan," the chief mainland policy planner warned, adding that Beijing will certainly use Clinton's explicit endorsement on the "three noes" to further squeeze Taiwan's international space and block its presence in international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: CTV TO BECOME TAIWAN'S FIRST LISTED MEDIA COMPANY

TEXT.P: China Television Company (CTV) is expected to become the first listed media company in Taiwan, probably in April next year, sources from CTV reported on Thursday.

CTV President Chiang Feng-chi filed an application with the Taiwan Stock Exchange on Thursday to list the company on the Taiwan stock market, paving the way for CTV to become the first media company in Taiwan to go public.
"Before long, almost every eligible investor in Taiwan can become a CTV shareholder to share the corporate interests and jointly monitor its operations," said Chiang.
CTV will release some 20 million shares to private investors, half of which will be distributed through open bidding, and the rest of which will be distributed through a lottery, he added.

Chiang said he expects the privatization move, which will require the company's operations to be institutionalized and rendered transparent, will consequently exert pressure on rival television channels to follow suit.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ROUND UP SIX DISSIDENTS IN HUNAN

TEXT.P: The Public Security Bureau of Changsha, capital of Hunan Province, rounded up six dissidents Wednesday and released two of them after several hours of interrogation.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said in a press release that the six are among the some 40 dissidents who jointly applied on Aug. 6 for permission to march in Changsha to call for the release of dissidents Wang Youcai and Zhang Shanguang. Their application has been turned down on the grounds that "the march may undermine social order."
Another dissident in Changsha, Liu Jianan, has been missing in these few days. It is feared that he has also been detained by police, the information center said.

Wang was formally arrested on Aug. 8 by the Public Security Bureau in Hangzhou, capital of Zhejiang Province, after he applied with the local government on June 25 for registering a preparatory committee for the formation of an opposition "Chinese Democratic Party." He was taken away from home by policy on July 10, and then formally arrested on charges of inciting people "to overthrow the country's ruling power."

Zhang was taken away from his home by police on June 22 and formally arrested in early July, because he attempted to organize an association for protecting the rights of laid-off workers in Hunan Province. It is feared that both Wang and Zhang may be indicted in the near future.
The six dissidents are Tan Li, Hu Zhouyi, Zhang Fan, Li Jinhong Zou Peifu, and Xie Changfa. Tan and Hu have been released. The whereabouts of the other four are unknown.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENMINBI DEPRECIATION WOULD BENEFIT HONG KONG, TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The depreciation of mainland China's currency would benefit Hong Kong and Taiwan businesses in the long term, according to a Merrill Lynch analysis.
The depreciation of the renminbi would help reduce commodity prices amd production costs in Hong Kong.
For Taiwan investors on the mainland, declined mainland currency will mean lower investment costs for them, it said.
However, the depreciation of the renminbi would increase the economic pressure for Asian countries, including Taiwan and Hong Kong, in the short term, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL FLIGHT CREW GROUNDED FOR `SERIES OF MISTAKES'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Thursday suspended three China Airlines (CAL) flight crew following a meeting to review aviation safety held in the wake of a recent incident involving a CAL cargo jet.
The CAA also instructed the country's former flag-carrier to make improvements to flight safety within a stipulated period or risk losing some or all of its flight concessions, a CAA official said.

The punitive measures were issued in response to an incident on June 27, when a CAL-owned Boeing 747-200F all-cargo aircraft found itself short of fuel and made an unapproved landing at Abu Dhabi airport in the United Arab Emirates.
The plane departed Taiwan for Amsterdam on June 27. However, on its first stopover in Thailand, it suffered a mechanical failure.

The repair procedure burned more fuel than expected, but the plane's flight crew did not follow aviation regulations and request refueling, CAA Deputy Director General Chang Kuo-cheng told reporters after the meeting.

The mishaps continued when the aircraft was unable to fly at its expected altitude due to heavy air traffic en route to Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates. This meant that the fully loaded plane was forced to take an alternative route, which consumed even more fuel, Chang said.

Desperately short of fuel, the plane ran into yet more problems when it was denied permission to land at Abu Dhabi due to bad weather. The plane then made for a nearby reserve airport but this facility had also been closed because of the weather.
Now running on fumes, and with no other recourse, the plane returned to Abu Dhabi airport, where it made an unauthorized landing. No damage or casualties were reported.
The incident was caused by "a series of mistakes," which left the plane with nowhere to go, said Chang, stressing that his bureau is further investigating the case.
The pilot of the plane was suspended from flight duties for four months, while his co-pilot was suspended for two months and the flight engineer was grounded for one month, according to the CAA.

Yeh Yiu-ching, CAL's deputy chief of aviation security, said that in light of the incident, the company has reviewed its accounting methods for reserve fuel, and has also reevaluated regulations for selecting standby airports.
He also said that all CAL flight crew will be required to undertake more training on abnormal flying conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLA SAID OFTEN CONDUCTS MOCK ATTACKS ON TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The army, navy, and air force of mainland China have often conducted mock attacks on Taiwan in military exercises, Gen. Chen Chao-min, commander-in-chief of the Republic of China Air Force, said here Thursday.

Chen made the remarks when asked by the press to comment on a recent foreign wire service report that a mock up of a military air port in central Taiwan has been built somewhere in Gansu Province in northwest mainland China.
Mainland China has never abandoned its attempt to take over Taiwan by military force, Chen said.

The air force of mainland China has built mock military air bases of Taiwan for training purposes, and its army and navy have often launched mock attacks on Taiwan during military exercises on coastal islands, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOH CALLS FOR EARLY IMPLEMENTATION OF ASEAN FREE TRADE AREA

TEXT.P: Early implementation of the Association of Southeast Asian Nation's (ASEAN) free trade area would help restore confidence in the member countries' economies, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said.
Goh made the remarks Wednesday at a dinner in honor of visiting Lao Prime Minister Sisavath Kheobounphanh.
The prime minister noted that the economic crisis has weakened the political and social fabric of the region, and reduced its international prestige as well.

But he said the region, with its inherent strengths and resilience, could "turn the financial crisis to an advantage by confronting difficult economic issues and introducing much-needed measures to reform and strengthen our economic and legal framework."
ASEAN economies could also restore confidence in the region by bringing forward the date for the ASEAN free trade area (AFTA), he said.

The schedule for implementing AFTA is 2003 within the six core ASEAN nations of Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Brunei. Vietnam has agreed to remove its tariffs by 2006, and Myanmar and Laos by 2008.
"Advancing the AFTA timetable will send a powerful signal to international investors of the determination of ASEAN countries to open their economies to trade and investments," Goh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER DENIES REPORT OF SURVEILLANCE OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Cheng Chun-mo on Thursday denied a news report that the Investigation Bureau under his ministry is carrying out surveillance of the activities of targeted figures.

The Journalist weekly magazine reported in its latest issue that the bureau decided on Feb. 13 to monitor certain local people traveling to mainland China for investment, tourism and cultural exchange purposes.
Arms and drugs smugglers, gangsters, and even entertainers and publishing tycoons who have close connections with the mainland are also being targeted by the operation, the report said.
The Investigation Bureau absolutely has not put specified figures under surveillance as has been alleged, Cheng said.

But for the sake of national security and the national interest, as well as social stability, the bureau is only seeking to ensure that persons who have links with the mainland are not endangering national security, he said.
"The `white terror' of past decades, during which certain figures were monitored and even suppressed, is long over, as a result of the island's successful democratization," Cheng said.
The rights and freedom of every citizen are protected under the Constitution, Chen said, adding that the nation's security is the responsibility of everyone in Taiwan.
For these reasons, one of the priority tasks of the bureau is to prevent the infiltration of mainland Chinese spies onto the island, Cheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF HIGH SPEED RAILWAY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday issued a series of instructions after hearing a report at the Executive Yuan on the new high speed rail system project by Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-chen.
The premier stressed the vital importance that construction of the new railway should be a resounding success, with no room for failure or error.

He requested the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to coordinate fully to carry out the project. He pointed out that the private sector has invested some NT$100 billion, and that the government has also earmarked a large amount of money for the project, the largest since the Ten Major Construction Projects of the 1970s.
During the worldwide recession of 1973-74, these projects stimulated other undertakings, provided a large number of jobs, and mitigated the severity of the economic slump.

Wu Jung-ming, deputy governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government, pointed out at the meeting that only a few plots of land along the route of the railway still need to be purchased pending agreement from the Construction & Planning Administration under the Ministry of the Interior.

Siew also asked Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, to set up an ad hoc group without delay to help coordinate with related government agencies. He also instructed Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen to help solve various related problems immediately.
He stressed again the importance of the new railway, and added that officials who fail to "fit in" with the project should be transferred.
The premier also exhorted the MOTC's Engineering Office of Highspeed Rail to do its best on the project, or risk being abrogated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARINE POLICEMAN COMMITS SUICIDE OVER EXAM SCAM

TEXT.P: A marine police officer allegedly involved in the recently exposed police exam scam shot himself dead on Thursday, police said.

Lee San-ming, 27, a marine police chief stationed in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, was supposed to have met with a prosecutor in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County that day for a talk aimed at clearing his role in the rapidly snowballing scandal.

The incident occurred in the early hours of the morning, when Lee was supervising a patrol detail. He asked one of the duty officers to hand him his gun for checking, and then used it to shoot himself between the eyes.
Lee was rushed to a nearby military hospital for treatment, but died later the same day.
Prosecutor Huang Mo-hsin confirmed that Lee was among the police officers who allegedly acted as a broker in the scam involving the entrance exams held by the Central Police University.

The scandal emerged last week when the results of the exam for the two-year university course were found to have been altered. Kuo Chen-yuan, former acting director of the university's computer department, has admitted that he committed the crime in exchange for bribes from a number of examinees. The bribes were paid through brokers, or so-called "white gloves."

An investigation into the scandal has shown that 47 examinees paid between NT$800,000 and NT$1.5 million for higher scores in the exam, which was open only to incumbent police officers who were graduates of the junior police college.
In addition, at least 12 other people were believed to have acted as Kuo's brokers, most of whom were police officers or students at the university.

Meanwhile, the National Police Administration announced that 52 police officers implicated in the scandal have each been given two major demerits and discharged from the service. Forty-three of them were bribe-paying examinees, while the other nine were brokers.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO CUT RISK OF CONTRACTING HIV THROUGH BLOOD TRANSFUSIONS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will discuss on Friday ways to cut the risk of contracting AIDS-causing HIV through transfusions of contaminated blood.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of Communicable Disease Control under the DOH, noted on Thursday that of the 1,750 AIDS cases traced by the DOH so far, 95 percent can be linked to high-risk sexual behavior.

Although victims who contracted the deadly disease through blood transfusions account for only 0.3 percent of the total, the DOH is still determined to cut this risk through more rigorous methods of screening donated blood.
He said that the DOH will invite experts, blood donation center officials, and AIDS advisory council officials to discuss the problem at Friday's meeting.

The discussion will focus on a stipulation which puts a one year waiting period on donations from people who indulge in high-risk sexual behavior, who have had a venereal disease, or who are inmates of a penitentiary. The meeting will be seeking to have the period increased to two years.
It will also seek prosecution of blood donors who are found to have circumvented the waiting period.
Meanwhile, the DOH urged travelers to Southeast Asia to refrain from high-risk sexual behavior such as visiting prostitutes.

Hsu said that of the 5.8 million AIDS victims recorded in the world last year, 1.3 million were from Southeast Asia. This was the second-highest concentration of victims in a single region, behind only Africa.
Most of Southeast Asia's AIDS cases are the result of high-risk sexual behavior, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGED TO SHOW CONCERN OVER VIOLENCE IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui was urged at a public hearing on Thursday to express his concern over the ethnic Chinese women who were raped during the May rioting in Indonesia.

The public hearing on "riots and rapes against ethnic Chinese in Indonesia," jointly sponsored by Taipei Legislator Chien Ta of the opposition New Party, and National Assembly member Tang Sao-cheng, was held at the Legislative Yuan.

Tang noted that many ethnic Chinese have suffered in the anti-Chinese incidents which have drawn anger from Chinese around the world. He urged the government to pay attention to the severe humanitarian problem and to take effective measures to cope with it.

Ou Chi-lung, a professor from National Chengchi University, said many overseas Chinese have expressed the hope that the leader of the Republic of China will stand up and say a few words. He added that it is not necessary for the president to condemn Indonesia, so long as he expresses concern for the victims.

He said many Chinese abroad have described Beijing as "incapable" and Taipei as "helpless" in their governments' reactions to the allegations of mass rapes of ethnic Chinese women and girls by Indonesian rioters.

The tearful scholar, himself an overseas Chinese from Indonesia, suggested that the celebrations for the ROC's Double Ten National Day in Indonesia should be called off as a form of ROC protest. He also suggested that the government should send religious groups to Indonesia and that it should communicate with Indonesia's leadership.

Yu Teh-sheng, an official from the East Asian & Pacific Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, noted that the government has taken various measures to address the situation. He said the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta has done its best to deal with the problem, and should be commended.
Yu said the government is very concerned over the victims, and stressed that the MOFA will provide assistance to ethnic Chinese rape victims who wish to seek medical care.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW CALLS ON BEIJING TO FACE POLITICAL REALITY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday called on mainland China to face the reality that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are ruled by separate political identities.
Siew said in a Cabinet meeting that Taipei and Beijing should conduct cross-strait dialogue and consultation on the basis of mutual respect and mutual benefit.
He also expressed his anger at Beijing's attempts to dwarf the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and block the Republic of China's efforts to seek a greater international presence.

The premier noted that although the kidnap-murder of Kaohsiung councilor Lin Ti-chuan aroused great concern in Taiwan, the mainland authorities denied entry to the SEF officials who wanted to accompany Lin's family to the mainland. This signals that the mainland does not intend to allow the SEF to exercise its function as a cross-strait intermediary body, Siew said.

He stressed that even though the mainland authorities have never given up their attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community, the ROC will make ever-greater efforts to fight for its existence.

Siew also announced that the government will hold a national meeting on mainland policy on Nov. 2, when officials from government agencies will discuss the course of mainland policy in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORECAST FOR 1998 ECONOMIC GROWTH ADJUSTED DOWNWARD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's projected economic growth for 1998 will be adjusted downward to 5.5 percent by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) at a meeting scheduled for Friday.

In a report released in May, the DGBAS predicted that the country's economy will grow by 6.02 percent. At that time, the economic growth for the first quarter was 5.92 percent, while economic growth projections for the second, third and fourth quarters this year stood at 5.78 percent, 6.16 and 6.18 percent, respectively.

However, continuing fallout from the Asian financial crisis has meant the economic growth forecasts for the three quarters have had to be adjusted downward, with fourth quarter growth expected to be the worst-hit, the DGBAS said.
It also said that economic growth for next year has been predicted to reach 6.3 percent because of an Executive Yuan-planned "expanding domestic demand package."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Fifty-two police officers were deprived of jobs on Thursday for involvement in Central Police University examination scam.
The China Times: A police officer shot his superior on Thursday night in a Tainan County police station before killing himself by shooting another bullet into his head.
The United Daily News: Thursday was a dark day for Taiwan's police community. A Tainan County police officer shot his superior before killing himself, while a Kaohsiung marine policeman committed suicide over Central Police University test scandal.
The Liberty Times: A Tainan County police officer shot his superior before killing himself on Thursday night.
The Independence Morning Post: A policeman shot himself after killing his superior on Thursday night.
The Commons Daily: China may soften its stance on issues related to Taiwan's international status.
The China Post: A police officer shot superior, self on Thursday night.
The China News: Cross-strait talks will be postponed; government says it wants to wait until smoke has cleared in current disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, TAIWAN EXPECTED TO SIGN CUSTOMS ACCORD THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to sign a customs cooperative agreement with the United States at the end of this year, sources from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Friday.
The initiative is aimed to further bolster cross-border cooperation in customs and related affairs.

Discussion over the agreement took place during a US-Taiwan vice ministerial meeting held last week in Washington, said Liu Rong-chu, director of the MOF's Department of Customs Administration, who was present at the meeting.

Officials from the two sides reached a consensus on increased bilateral cooperation in the crackdown on arms, drugs and merchandise smuggling, protection of intelligent property rights, as well as the exchange of customs information, personnel and technology, said Liu.

If everything proceeds smoothly, the agreement is expected to be signed at the end of the year between the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States and the American Institute in Taiwan on behalf of their respective governments.

The agreement, the first of its kind between Taiwan and any other country, is expected to advance preventive efforts between Taiwan and the US against cross-border money laundering, credit card fraud, electronic fraud, and other economic crimes, Liu said.
Taiwan has signed memoranda on customs affairs cooperation with South Africa, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAERSK DUBAI CREW GRANTED REFUGEE STATUS IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Four Filipino sailors who jumped the Maersk Dubai container vessel in May 1996 will be allowed to stay in Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds, authorities said Thursday.

Rodolfo Miguel, Ariel Broas, Esmeraldo Esteban and Juanito Ilagan accused the ship's six Taiwan officers of throwing three Romanian stowaways overboard to their deaths in March 1996. The sailors immediately applied for refugee status in Canada once the ship landed in Halifax, Nova Scotia.

"They will be granted landed immigrant status provided they meet medical, security and criminal screening requirements. Once granted permanent residence status, they will be eligible to sponsor their families who reside in the Philippines," the Department of Citizenship and Immigration said in a news release.

The decision to extend favorable consideration on humanitarian grounds are made by the federal government on the merits of each case in accordance with "existing guidelines," according to the government release. The men's applications were rejected twice and at one time a deportation notice was served against them.
The case was mired in a complex legal battle over the question of jurisdiction as Canada does not officially recognize Taiwan.

The Supreme Court of Nova Scotia ruled in March 1997 that it had no jurisdiction over the accused Taiwan officers and allowed them to return to Taiwan to face trail. The island's authorities are continuing in their investigation into the case but the Filipino men, who are the only witnesses to the alleged crime, refuse to travel to Taiwan to testify.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN EXPORTS TO TAIWAN RISE, SEEN FALLING ELSEWHERE

TEXT.P: Australia's exports to Taiwan continue to grow while its sales to other major markets are expected to fall in the second half of the year, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) said Friday.
In a statement faxed to the CNA, the DFAT said Australia's exports to Taiwan in June 1998 rose about 10 percent from the same period last year.
"Taiwan is the only regional export destination which, in smoothed terms, has not showed a noticeable fall at any time during the regional economic crisis," it said.
Between January and June this year, Australia's total exports reached A$43.13 billion (US$29.74 billion), up from A$40.19 billion (US$29.33 billion) in the same period last year.
However, a DFAT spokesperson said exports are expected to fall in the second half of this year as the full effect of the Asian crisis reaches Australia.

Official statistics indicate that between July 1997 and June 1998, Australia's exports to 11 East Asian countries, including Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, China, and South Korea, rose about 5.5 percent to A$47.2 billion (US$34.45 billion) thanks to an increase in sales from a year earlier.
Australian exports to South Korea, Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines fell from 5 percent to 18 percent during the same period.

Australian exports to Taiwan in fiscal 1997-98 jumped 15 percent to A$4.18 billion (US$3.05 billion) from 1996-97. Exports to mainland China rose 8 percent to A$3.87 billion (US$2.82 billion) and to Hong Kong were up 33 percent to A$4.14 billion (US$3.02 billion) during the same period.

Trade officials said Australian exports to China already plunged 11 percent in June this year and the figure is expected to further drop in coming months partly because of the deepening crisis in Asia.
In a dispatch from Beijing, the Sydney Morning Herald's correspondent David Lague on Friday reported Australian shipments of key commodities, including wool, wheat and sugar to China plunged sharply.
It said contrary to earlier expectations, China's imports have shown signs of falling and the outlook for Australian exports to the mainland may be worse in the months ahead.
The report quoted a Hong Kong-based trade analyst as saying, "China is a lot weaker underneath than it appears to be. The blood bath is upon us; it is not out there in the future."

The Canberra-based Access Economics, an institution engaged in economic forecasting, warned that Australia faced its worst trade outlook in decades and risks sliding into recession in 1999 if the Asian crisis continued.

"Asia may cut Australian activity to a crawl by the first half of 1999. With Japan sagging and China not far behind, our major trading partners are going from bad to worse," said an Access Economics analyst.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Canberra said two-way trade between Australia and Taiwan would remain steady in the second half of 1998 despite a decline of Australian exports in other Asian markets.
"We believe our trade with Australia will remain steady in the rest of this year," Henry Yang, director of the TECO's economic division, said in an interview with the CNA.
Australia mainly exports coal, iron ore, crude oil, liquefied natural gas, gold, metals, seafood and agricultural produce to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY COUNCILOR CALLS FOR BAN ON INDECENT TV PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A Taipei City councilor on Friday asked the government to ban a television program which she said openly promotes sex tourism under the guise of finding brides in the mainland.
Chen Yu-mei said in a news conference that the program, aired by a local television station in the early hours on weekdays, has lured Taiwan men to the mainland in search of sex.
She said the Congress Satellite TV Co. features live coverage of the Legislative Yuan's sessions during the day and rents the remainder of its air time to other companies which provide programming.
A clip of the program in question showed a man introducing a host of young mainland Chinese women, and inviting Taiwan men to go to the mainland to meet their "prospective brides."

Those who choose to participate are asked to pay NT$50,000 (US$1,437) and are given their choice of companion for a 10-day trip. If they want to marry their companion, they are asked to pay an additional NT$300,000 (US$8,620).
Chen said after she investigated the program, she found that the group of Taiwan men invited to the mainland was not confined to single men.
She said the news media which openly organizes such groups run counter to social decency and contributed to family disputes.
The councilor asked the government to immediately ban the television program and launch its own investigation into the matter.
Telephone calls to the producer of the program for comment received no response.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NAVAL PATROL SHIP CHRISTENED

TEXT.P: A locally built 500-ton-class naval patrol vessel was christened and launched on Friday at the state-run China Shipbuilding Corp.'s (CSBC) shipyard in Kaohsiung.
Navy Deputy Commander-in-Chief Yeh Shih-wen personally presided over the christening and launching ceremony for the new CSBC-built coastal patrol ship.
The ship, christened the Hsin-chiang (New River), was the second Chin-chiang-class offshore patrol vessel built under the ROC Navy's Kuanghua No. 3 warship building program.

The Hsin-chiang will undergo a series of navigation tests and weaponry installation following its launch, naval officials said, adding that the Navy will take delivery of the ship only after it ascertains that the craft's quality and overall equipment meet its requirements.
The officials said the Chin-chiang-class patrol boat possesses high mobility and requires neither a large crew nor large maintenance costs.

Construction on the Hsin-chiang started last September and is scheduled to be completed by early next year. The ship will be responsible for offshore surveillance and regional patrol after it is commissioned into service, the officials said.
During wartime, the officials, said the ship can be armed with additional weaponry systems and coordinate with mainstream warships in conducting interception and anti-landing operations.

Under the Kuanghua No. 3 program, the Navy has plans to commission the CSBC to build a total of 11 offshore patrol ships patterned after the locally-designed, 500-ton-class Chin-chiang vessel, which was commissioned on Dec. 1, 1994.
The first of the program's 11 Chin-chiang-class patrol vessels, christened the Tan-chiang, was launched in June and is scheduled to be delivered late this year.
Construction on four other Chin-chiang-class coastal patrol boats are also under way. All of the 11 ships are scheduled to be completed by May 2000.
The Kuanghua No. 3 project is part of the Navy's ambitious warship modernization plan aimed at beefing up Taiwan's naval defense capabilities and safeguarding the waters surrounding the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT READJUSTS GROWTH DOWNWARD TO 5.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's projected economic growth rate this year is expected to be sizably readjusted downward to 5.5 percent in a Cabinet meeting Friday afternoon, according to sources from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

In its economic forecast in May, the DGBAS predicted that the country's economy would grow by 6.02 percent for 1998. At that time, the economic growth in the first quarter was 5.92 percent, while growth projections for the second, third and fourth quarters this year stood at 5.78 percent, 6.16 percent and 6.18 percent, respectively.
The new figure was a practical readjustment as a result of the continued decline in Taiwan's foreign trade, which has been a prime mover in the island's economic growth, said DGBAS officials.

Bearing the full brunt of the Asian economic turmoil, Taiwan's foreign trade has declined drastically in the first seven months of this year with exports totaling US$63.4 billion and imports at US$61.1 billion, down 8.6 percent and 6.4 percent, respectively, from the year-earlier levels.

Finance Minister Paul Chiu said even if the economic growth were readjusted downward to below 5.5 percent this year, Taiwan's overall economic performance is not bad compared to other countries and areas in the world. The 5.5 percent growth would be the second highest in Asia behind only that of mainland China, he added.
Meanwhile, the DGBAS announced a "domestic demand expansion package" as a prime-pumping measure to stimulate growth.

Under the package, the value of newly-initiated public investment projects total a gigantic NT$39.7 billion (US$1.16 billion), which is expected to contribute to the country's overall economic growth by 0.5 percent this year helping shore up the annual growth figure to 5.5 percent or even higher, DGBAS officials noted.
They also predicted that Taiwan's economic growth will top 6.2 percent next year, as a result of continuing expansion of domestic investment, including major public construction projects.
Meanwhile, the Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research on Friday cut back their 1998 annual growth figures from the previously projected 5.95 percent to 5.24 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM INTRODUCES NEW TAX PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard has introduced a new tax package which includes a goods and services tax (GST).
With the introduction of a GST, Howard has promised to compensate Australians with tax cuts as they pay 10 percent or more in tax for almost everything they buy, including houses.
Howard's new GST package proposes a A$32 billion (US$20 billion) switch from wholesale and state taxes. It would also revolutionize key business and investment taxes.
The GST would cover most goods and services, including food, but exclude health, education, child care, nursing homes and local government rates, according to officials of the Federal Treasury.

The new GST will be implemented on July 1, 2000 but some of the state taxes slated for removal will not come off until 2001 and the transitional period to the new system effectively starts in mid-1999.
Under the tax reform, the government will reduce the company tax rate to 30 percent from the current 36 percent. The thrust of the tax package favors lower- and middle-income taxpayers.
Howard has described the new GST package as a "visionary taxation reform." But Opposition Leader Kim Beazley dubbed it "unfair"

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODS KEEP MAINLAND AWASH IN SUFFERING

TEXT.P: Massive flooding in mainland China continues as torrential rains are threatening the country's northeastern region and flood waters continue to rise.

Henry Chu, the Los Angeles Times' staff writer stationed in Beijing wrote that as central mainland continues to battle the worst inundation by the Yangtze River since 1954, the province of Heilongjiang on the Sino-Russian border was awash Wednesday in water from the swollen Nen River.

Fed by huge downpours over the last several days, the Nen and its tributaries burst their banks, overflowing "one after another" in the worst season of flooding on record in the area, the People's Daily reported.

There has been no word on how many have perished in the deluge. The official overall death toll from the floods is at about 2,000, but many believe the figure is much higher. Relief workers now fear outbreaks of cholera and other waterborne diseases may claim many more.

Millions of people have been left homeless, mostly along the Yangtze in the central and eastern regions, as soldiers and civilians work around the clock shoring up saturated dikes in danger of collapsing. In all, the government estimates that 240 million people have been effected by the flooding -- nearly the equivalent of the entire US population.

The floods, a perennial problem in mainland China, have caused more than US$4 billion in damage so far this year, leading some economists to forecast that mainland China's annual growth rate could drop by as much as a percentage point when the final toll is tallied. Factories as well as farms have been inundated.

"The worst flooding in four decades is having a considerable negative influence on the industrial sector," an economist told the state-run China Daily in its Wednesday edition. Industrial output should have exceeded 8 percent in the first half of 1998 but had only reached 7.8 percent, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTHER APPEALS FOR HELP TO SAVE HER MAINLAND-IMPRISONED SON
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, eastern Taiwan, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The mother of an Ilan resident convicted of spying and serving a 20-year prison term in mainland China on Friday appealed for government help to save her son.
The distraught mother said her 29-year-old son Lin Yi-lin left Ilan for mainland China four years ago to study dentistry in Fuzhou, in the southern mainland Chinese province of Fujian.

However, Lin was taken away by public security authorities on just his second day in Fuzhou. Without any explanation or public trial, he was sentenced to a 20-year prison term on charges of spying, and ceased all contact with his family in Taiwan.

Lin's family did not hear from him until two years later in 1996, when they were informed that he had been arrested and was in jail in Fujian Province. Lin's father, then 75 years old, flew to Fuzhou to visit him, when he discovered that his son had been unjustly imprisoned.

Lin has been married for 10 years and has two sons, his mother said, but went on to add that his wife became a stranger to the family after he vanished, leaving the two children in the custody of their grandparents.

Distressed over the broken home, the mother contacted the Straits Exchange Foundation for help, but has heard nothing from the quasi-official intermediary agency charged with handling cross-strait affairs in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.
Lin's father received a letter from Lin in June this year, saying that he had been transferred to a reform camp in Putien, Fujian, and asking for a regular allowance to be sent from Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX, FUTURES EXCHANGE UP

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 14.51 to close at 7,348.04.
The bourse opened at 7,345.53 and experienced a low of 7,275.6.
A total of 12.95 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.59 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only bank and insurance stocks posted a gain, moving up at 0.7 percent.

All other categories registered losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.9 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.8 percent, construction shares at 0.6 percent, electrical stocks at 0.5 percent, cement shares at 0.4 percent, and textile issues at 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures posted a general increase.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved up 29 points to close at 7,320, while those for October slid six points to close at 7,300. Futures for December dropped 56 points to 7,439.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 528, three, and five, respectively.
The TAIEX Index Futures for March moved down 11 points to close at 7,501, with nine contract transactions. No transactions were registered for June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were listed as: 7,291 points for September; 7,306 for October; 7,495 for December; 7,512 for March; and 7,660 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER RECEIVES PHILIPPINE FINANCIAL SECRETARY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that the Republic of China would like to share its development experience with the Philippines.

Siew made the remarks when he received a delegation from the Philippines comprising Secretary of the Department of Finance Edgardo Espiritu, Secretary of the Department of Agriculture William Dar, and other financial officials.
ROC officials said that the financial officials are seeking to woo more Taiwan investment in the Philippines, while the agricultural officials want to learn about Taiwan's agricultural development.

The premier told the delegation that the ROC attaches great importance to its relations with the Philippines. Geographically close, the two nations also share the same values of democracy, freedom, and respect for human rights, he said, adding that the two nations should step up bilateral cooperation.
The Philippine delegation said their country could learn a lot from Taiwan's achievements in the fields of tax, finance, and agriculture.
Espiritu earlier called on his ROC counterpart Paul Chiu, to exchange views on tax and financial cooperation.
He expressed the hope that the ROC will invest in his country and that Taiwan's banking and insurance sectors will set up more branches in the Philippines.

Noting that six Taiwan banks have so far set up branches in the Philippines, Chiu said that the ROC Ministry of Finance has to screen all Taiwan banks and insurance companies wishing to set up branches in the Philippines.
The screening process depends heavily on the Philippine economic situation and on the operations of the banks or insurance companies in question, Chiu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTRY TO WOO FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Friday that his ministry will invite at least 15 potential foreign and overseas manufacturers to invest in Taiwan in the next year.

In order to help promote foreign investment in Taiwan, Wang said that the ministry will also broker more than 25 domestic projects involving investment or technology cooperation from Japanese businessmen in the next year.

Wang said that the ministry will also organize hi-tech delegations to visit Europe, the United States, and Japan, to help persuade over 10 manufacturers from those countries to cooperate in technology with Taiwan manufacturers.

He said that recent major foreign investors include US-based General Instrument and Motorola, German-based Chemetall GMBH, and France-based D.F.I. Geant, which will invest a total of about NT$5.15 billion (US$147.99 million) in Taiwan.

Statistics from the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that overseas and foreign investment in Taiwan totaled US$1.6 billion in the first half of the year, down 23.03 percent from last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN TO DONATE US$100,000 TO MAINLAND FLOOD VICTIMS

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT) has decided to donate US$100,000 to mainland China as an initial relief fund to help the people affected by the massive flooding along the Yangtze River.

A WVT spokesman said the organization hopes to raise charity funds to the tune of US$2.8 million this year as additional relief for the people of mainland China. He called for the Taiwan general public to demonstrate their empathy for their mainland compatriots.

According to the WVT, some 290 million mainland people have been affected in 28 flood-stricken provinces and cities. Of this number, 3,000 are estimated to have died, and 14 million have been forced to abandon their homes to the rising water.

The flooding is not restricted only to the areas along the Yangtze River in central China, said the spokesman, adding that many areas along the Heilungjiang River in northern China have also been inundated by summer floods, causing an unprecedented natural disaster.
World Vision Taiwan is constantly sponsoring fund-raisers, including the famed "30-hour famine campaign" to drum up cash and material donations for needy recipients around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.069 against the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 34.702.
The local currency opened at 34.743, and was trade between 34.702 and 34.776.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$275 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT LAUNCHES DRIVE TO FIGHT ONE NATION

TEXT.P: The Australian government on Friday launched the first stage of an anti-racism campaign -- the "Living in Harmony" initiative -- to fight the racist One Nation party.

In a statement faxed to CNA, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said: "Living in Harmony is designed to build upon the cohesiveness of Australian society and make it clear that there is no place for racism in Australia."

"It is the values we all share that bring us together -- those traditional Australian values of fairness, equality and justice -- and they strengthen our ability to resist those who want to divide us on racial or cultural grounds," he said.

One Nation and its leader, Pauline Hanson, are known for their anti-Asian, anti-foreign investment, anti-Aboriginal, and anti-multiculturalism stances. They advocate one flag, one language, one culture and one (white) society.

Emphasizing the social and economic benefits of diversity, Ruddock reinforced the need for individuals and communities throughout Australia to move beyond mere acceptance of cultural or racial difference and towards encouraging active participation of all Australians in community life.

"In the market research for this initiative, people indicated very clearly their desire to focus on what makes us all Australians, to emphasize our common values, and to respect, rather than reinforce, our differences," he said.

He said the government will allocate A$2.5 (US$1.56) million for the first stage of the campaign, to be spent by schools, churches, service clubs, sporting bodies, ethnic communities, indigenous groups, and other sections of the general community.
This will help develop projects designed to promote harmony between people and groups of different cultural backgrounds, Ruddock pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND PRIME MINISTER EXPECTED TO SACK HER DEPUTY

TEXT.P: New Zealand Prime Minister Jenny Shipley is expected to sack her deputy, Winston Peters, following his walkout of the Cabinet on Wednesday night, which set the coalition government on a course for inevitable disintegration.
The complete collapse of the coalition of the National and First Parties in New Zealand is looming, according to a report by the New Zealand Press Association.

Peters, who also serves as treasurer, and leader of the NZ First Party, accused the National Party of doing "something very untrustworthy and thoroughly devious," and later issued a press statement titled "PM's conduct in question."

Asked whether she intended to seek the resignation of other First Party ministers who followed Peters out of the Cabinet, Shipley said all ministers are bound by the convention of collective responsibility and that she would "be considering over the next few days the consequence of any breaches there may have been."

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL CONFERENCE TO OPEN FOR POLICE ADMINISTRATION REFORMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's decaying police administration, highlighted by a recent exam-fixing scandal and three police deaths, prompted Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen on Friday to call a national conference to discuss reforms in police affairs.
Huang stated that the conference will be aimed at making a comprehensive review of personnel affairs, educational training, and the system for police retirement and compensation.

Grass-roots policemen, retired police officers, and scholars and experts in police affairs, will be invited to take part in the conference slated to take place some time between late August and early September, Huang said.

Although he described the police examination scandal, the two police suicides and the murder of a police officer, as "merely isolated cases," Huang pointed out that they have lowered the morale of the entire police force.

The minister paid his respects to grassroots police officers, describing them as anti-crime heroes. He encouraged those allegedly involved in the recent scam to face justice, and urged them to treasure and respect their own lives and those of others.

Huang's statement came in the wake of reports that 32-year-old policeman Huang Chen-jung, who served in a public security police squad stationed in Tainan County, shot his squad leader dead before turning his gun on himself on Thursday night.
A preliminary investigation revealed that the two had allegedly quarreled over a performance evaluation, resulting in Huang shooting his supervisor in the head and chest.

Upon learning of the tragic incident, the first case in Taiwan of a policeman shooting a colleague to death, Ting Yuan-chin, director-general of the National Police Administration (NPA), expressed "extreme sadness."

That same day, a marine police officer stationed in the southern port city of Kaohsiung shot himself dead. Lee San-ming, 27, was supposed to have met with a prosecutor that day for a talk aimed at clearing his role in the recent police examination scam.

The scandal exploded in the media last week when the results of the exam for the two-year university course were found to have been altered. Kuo Chen-yuan, former acting director of the university's computer department, has admitted committing the crime in exchange for bribes.

At least a dozen other people are believed to have acted as Kuo's brokers, introducing examinees to the bribery scam. Most of these so-called "white gloves" were police officers or students at the university.

The NPA announced on Thursday that 52 police officers implicated in the scandal have been given two major demerits and discharged from the service. Forty-three of them were bribe-paying examinees, while the other nine were brokers.

Meanwhile, with the number of policemen committing suicide twice the number of police officers dying in the line of duty, Huang Fu-yuan, director of the crime prevention department of the Central Police University, suggested on Friday that every examinee of the university and other police schools should receive psychological testing before taking entry examinations.

Training courses aimed at teaching police freshmen ways to ease stress should be given in schools, the scholar suggested. Huang also recommended police institutions to provide vacations to police officers suffering from heavy stress, and to offer comprehensive counseling services.
According to NPA statistics, 92 policemen have committed suicide since 1986, six of them during the first eight months of this year alone. Five of the six served at the grassroots level.
Failed love affairs, family disputes, debts, and criminal involvement were the causes of the six latest deaths, according to the NPA educational department.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIV-INFECTED FOREIGN BRIDES ON THE RISE: DOH

TEXT.P: The number of HIV-infected foreign brides has increased significantly, with brides from Thailand accounting for the lion's share, the Department of Health (DOH) warned on Friday.
The Cabinet-level agency issued the warning amid an ever-rising fad among local men for marrying foreign women, particularly those from Southeast Asia.
According to DOH tallies, 21 foreign brides have tested HIV positive, including one from mainland China.

The same statistics further show that five of these HIV-infected foreign brides have transmitted the deadly AIDS-causing virus to their husbands. The figure accounts for nearly 10 percent of the 55 local cases involving HIV transmission between spouses.

DOH officials said the number of confirmed cases of HIV infection involving foreign brides has grown rapidly in recent years. In 1995, only one such case was reported. The number increased to five each in 1996 and 1997, and stands at 10 so far this year.

Hsu Hsu-mei, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said Southeast and South Asian countries, particularly Thailand, Vietnam, Cambodia, and India, are high-risk areas for HIV infection.
"Local people should not engage in high-risk sexual behavior when making trips to Southeast Asian countries if they want to avoid HIV infection," Hsu said.

There are currently 5.8 million AIDS patients around the world, 1.3 million of whom are in Southeast Asia, the second-highest concentration of cases in a single region behind only parts of Africa, according to statistics released by the World Health Organization (WHO).
Hsu quoted WHO as warning that the number of AIDS patients in Southeast Asia may soon surpass those in Africa.
The senior official further pointed out that 72 percent of Thailand's prostitutes are HIV carriers, and that the ratio is even higher in popular Thai tourist destinations, including Chiang Mai.

Hsu said the percentage of HIV-infected prostitutes in other Southeast Asian countries may not necessarily be lower than that in Thailand. "If the figures for other Southeast Asian countries are lower, it may simply be because they are not as active as Thailand in tracking HIV cases," he added.

According to DOH statistics, Taiwan has so far recorded 1,925 confirmed HIV carriers, of whom 1,720 are ROC nationals. Among these, 609 have developed full-blown AIDS and 413 have already died. DOH tallies further show that male homosexuals and bisexuals form the bulk of local HIV carriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OYSTER FARMERS PROTEST AGAINST SMUGGLED SHELLFISH

TEXT.P: Oyster farmers from southern Taiwan demonstrated in Taipei on Friday, demanding that the government put a stop to oyster smuggling from mainland China and prohibit the importation of mainland oysters via a third country or area.
The recent heatwave has caused massive oyster die-offs in Taiwan, triggering rampant smuggling of the popular shellfish from mainland China.

About 300 oyster farmers from the Chiayi area demonstrated in front of the Council of Agriculture (COA), complaining that local producers are losing money because of the huge amount of mainland contraband in local markets.

Officials from the Fisheries Administration of the COA pointed out that oyster production along the coast of Taiwan has decreased by about 30 percent to 40 percent, while the market price has risen this year to NT$150 per kilogram from NT$70-NT$80 per kilogram.
The shortfall in supply, plus the higher selling price, has made smuggling from the mainland more profitable and attractive, the officials said.
The director of the Fisheries Administration, Hu Hsin-hua, and James Sha, director of the Taiwan Fisheries Bureau under the Taiwan Provincial Government, met with the protesters.

The two top-level fisheries officials remarked that the government is concerned about the drop in Taiwan's oyster production resulting from the unusually warm weather brought by the El Nino phenomenon.
With regard to the smuggling problem, Hu and Sha promised to coordinate with the marine police to ensure that more of the smugglers are arrested.
In addition, the COA also indicated that the council is willing to assist oyster farmers in building up domestic product awareness to raise competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN LEADER INVITED TO VISIT ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Presidential envoy Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to President Lee Teng-hui, on Thursday extended an invitation to Paraguay's President-elect Raul Cubas Grau to visit the Republic of China after his inauguration.
The invitation was accepted by Grau, according to Liu Tin-tsu, ROC ambassador to the Republic of Paraguay.

Paraguayan Ambassador to the ROC Ceferino Valdez Peralta later said that he will suggest to the new head of state that he visit the ROC in February 1999. Peralta was accompanying Foreign Minister Jason Hu on a call to new Paraguayan Foreign Minister Dido Florentin Bogado on Friday.
