Meanwhile, Huang, who will attend Grau's inauguration on Aug. 15, paid a courtesy call on outgoing President Juan Carlos Wasmosy to present his credentials.

Other members of the ROC inaugural delegation include Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo, Vice Chairman of the Council of Agriculture Ling Shiang-nung, and International Cooperation and Development Fund Secretary-General Loh Ping-cheung.
Loh said both sides will discuss matters concerning economic, agricultural, and technological cooperation.
The delegation will depart Asuncion on Monday and will arrive in Taipei on Aug. 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS DECORATED BY PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Visiting ROC Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei and Foreign Minister Jason Hu had Paraguay's National Order of Merit conferred upon them on Thursday.
Outgoing Paraguayan Foreign Minister Ruben Melgarejo Lanzoni presided over the ceremony, his last official duty before stepping down.

Melgarejo said the decoration serves to illustrate the long-standing friendship between the Republic of China and Paraguay, and that Huang and Hu fully deserve the honor for their contributions to the promotion of bilateral ties.

Paraguay and its people attach great importance to relations with the ROC, and have never changed their attitude in this regard, Melgarejo said, adding that Paraguay raised a proposal in the United Nation's 1997 General Assembly proposing that Taiwan be included as a full member of the international organization.

In addition to expressing his appreciation for the medal, Huang also took the opportunity to relay President Lee Teng-hui's greetings to Wasmosy and Melgarejo, and to thank Paraguay for its support for the ROC.
Huang and Hu, heading a 20-member delegation, arrived here earlier on Thursday to attend the Saturday inauguration of Paraguayan President-elect Raul Cubas Grau.
Other delegates included Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kao, Council of Agriculture Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung, and various business leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'THREE NOES' IS ONLY A SMALL PART OF US POLICY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A diplomatic official said here Friday that the 'three noes' is only a small part of United States policy toward Taiwan, and that he hoped leaders of other countries would not allow it to obscure their view of US police toward Taiwan.

President Bill Clinton said at an informal setting in Shanghai during his last visit to mainland China on June 25-July 3 that the US doesn't support "independence for Taiwan", "Two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan", and Taiwan's bid to join "international organizations for which statehood is a requirement." This US position is often referred to as the "three noes" policy.

Shen Lyu-shun, director of the North American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, pointed out at a regular press conference that the US government has reiterated many times just before and after Clinton's visit to the mainland that its guarantees to and policy toward Taiwan have not changed, that the Taiwan Relations Act will be properly carried out, and that disputes between Taiwan and the mainland should be resolved by peaceful means.

During this period, the US Congress adopted four resolutions, expressing strong support for Taiwan. The resolutions urged Beijing to renounce the use of force and the threat of using force against Taiwan, and supported Taiwan's bid to join such world organizations as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The executive branch of the US government welcomes the resolutions of Congress.

Shen said that the US goodwill and support for Taiwan is a "clear fact," and that the "three noes" constitutes only a small part of US policy toward Taiwan. Beijing has misunderstood it, and has tried to cause some other nations to misunderstand it, he added.
He expressed the hope that those countries which might mention their "three noes" in public settings at the behest of communist China will watch the whole picture of US policy toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC CRISIS A WAKE-UP CALL FOR HONG KONG: CHIEF SECRETARY

TEXT.P: The current economic crisis is a blessing, because Hong Kong needed a wake-up call, Hong Kong's Chief Secretary Anson Chan said in Singapore on Thursday.
The community had been lulled into a false sense of complacency following 10 to 15 years of sustained economic growth, she noted.
"But as we know, economies work in cycles, and what goes up has to come down, as it is doing now," she said in an interview with The Straits Times newspaper.
The crisis will lessen Hong Kongers' reliance on the government, and will encourage them to look more to their own resources and abilities, she said.
Chan, who arrived in Singapore that day for a three-day visit, said that once Asia overcomes its current turmoil, Hong Kong will be among the first cities to rebound.
"This is because we are very well positioned -- we are very fortunate to be next door to a China that is growing," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND PREMIER SACKS DEPUTY

TEXT.P: New Zealand Prime Minister Jenny Shipley sacked her deputy, Winston Peters, on Friday, after he walked out of the Cabinet on Wednesday following a dispute over administrative issues.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported that Shipley asked for permission from the governor-general to fire Peters, who also serves as treasurer.
With Peters' dismissal, the Shipley administration will remain a minority government and it is expected she will remain in power until the next election in 1999.
Peters had earlier accused the National Party of doing "something very untrustworthy and thoroughly devious," and issued a press statement titled "PM's Conduct in Question."
After the sacking, Peters said he would continue to fight for his rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FAVORED IN INVESTMENT POLL

TEXT.P: The US-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) predicted in its latest report that the Republic of China will be the world's second most profitable place to invest in next year.
The consultancy said Taiwan's gross domestic product will grow by a healthy 5 percent this year and 4 percent next year.

Despite the effects of the current economic crisis, Singapore is still the world's second-most profitable place to invest in this year, BERI said in its 120-page report which ranks profit opportunities in 50 countries.
However, Singapore will be a less attractive destination for investors next year, it added. The report lowered Singapore's profit-opportunity ranking in 1999 to third place behind Taiwan.

BERI predicted that Singapore's gross domestic product will grow by only 1 percent this year and there will be no growth next year. But the fall in profitability will not last long as Singapore is expected to recapture its traditional second spot behind Switzerland within the next five years.

The BERI report is published three times a year -- at the end of March, July and November -- and is based on detailed data from the International Monetary Fund, OECD, World Bank and a panel of about 100 senior bankers, businessmen and government officials worldwide.

Each country is scored on three criteria -- operations risk, which covers the general business environment; remittance and repatriation risk, which measures the ease with which foreign companies can transfer profits and capital out of the country, and political risk.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO ALLOW WIDER USE OF CURRENCY

TEXT.P: The Singapore government announced on Thursday that it will allow wider use of the Singapore dollar for business transactions, but stressed that it will stick by its policy of not internationalizing the currency.

The measures will loosen some key rules that constrict Singapore's development as an international financial hub, said Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in a keynote speech at the launch of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) Electronic Payment System.

Lee, who is also MAS chairman, explained that Singapore's economy and financial sector has outgrown the framework of regulations banks must follow on the international use of the Singapore dollar. This was last revised in 1992, before Singapore's regionalization drive.
The new regulations, with clearer and more explicit provisions, will minimize the need for banks to consult the MAS, he said.

On Singapore dollar credit facilities for use outside Singapore, he clarified that banks can extend local currency financing to residents for overseas projects without consulting the MAS. "In practice, this is already MAS policy, as MAS has publicly stated several times," he added.
Lee also elaborated on the need to develop broad capital markets to attract a broad range of international issuers, investors and intermediaries.

The new notice will make it easier for foreign companies to list Singapore dollar-denominated shares on the Singapore Stock Exchange. Until now, only those with at least 35 percent of their revenues, profits, or expenses attributable to Singapore could have such a listing, but this will now be reduced to 20 percent.
Another measure will allow foreign entities to issue Singapore dollar-denominated bonds, even where the proceeds will be used outside Singapore once converted into foreign currency.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA INTERVIEW WITH DARRYL JOHNSON, DIRECTOR OF AIT

TEXT.P: Q: President Clinton was critized in Congress after he made the "three noes" statement. But on the other hand, he was the first American president to mention the Taiwan Relations Act in mainland China. How significant is his TRA reference?

Johnson: I think both parts are important, because what President Clinton did in the mainland was to reiterate the basis of US policy towards the mainland and towards Taiwan. And when he was asked at Beijing University a specific question about arms sales to Taiwan, he also -- for the first time, I think, on PRC soil -- he reiterated the basis for our continued arms sales; that is, we do not agree that it is an obstacle to better cross-strait relations. We think it is an essential part of helping to create a fair and balanced process. As far as the "three noes," as you know, we have been saying ever since late June that this did not represent any change in policy. It did not -- all three elements have been on the record for a long time. In fact, it did not represent any change in policy. The only thing that was new was that it was the president personally who said it and -- you know maybe that's significant. Certainly, in terms of the content, it was not significant. In term of the form, people attach greater importance to it. But it didn't represent any change in policy. That's important. He was -- the President was very articulate, I think you would agree, in defending the ideas of democracy and openness. He called for Jiang Zemin and for China broadly to evolve in the direction of more openness and more tolerance -- religious tolerance, polical tolerance and so forth. And I think one could read in his words an endorsement of the kind of change which has occurred in Taiwan, especially over the last 11 years.

Q: When Mr. Richard Bush (AIT chairman) visited Taipei last month, President Lee Teng-hui said the majority of Taiwanese people feel that the US stance on cross-strait relations is unbalanced and that this stance will certainly affect the cross-strait relations. Was the US surprised by Taiwan's emotional response?

Johnson: Interestinly enough, in the meetings with President Lee and other senior leaders, the tone was very cordial when Dr. Bush was here. The kinds of concerns that were expressed by the president and by others really were more in terms of efforts to clarify or efforts to understand the points which President Clinton had made and which Dr. Bush and others had made subsequently. I think we are always aware that there is high sensitivity in Taiwan to any improvement in US-PRC relations. There are people here who believe that better US-PRC relations must be disadvantageous, must be not beneficial for Taiwan. In fact, our view and my personal view very strongly is: the opposite is true -- that better US-PRC relations create an incentive for Beijing to moderate its policy towards Taiwan and to improve the conditions for better cross-strait relations. We hope that's the case. I think we will see in the coming months whether both sides are prepared to move forward. But, of course, it's up to them. We hope that the better climate between Washington and Beijing will also lead to better a climate between Taipei and Beijing.

Q: Judging from the murder of Lin Ti-chuan (a Democratic Progressive Party councilor at the Kaohsiung City Council) mainland China and the forthcoming Koo-Wang talks, do you think that cross-strait relations have been affected by Clinton's visit to Beijing?

Johnson: In broad terms, no. In broad terms, I think that those things have their own engine, if you like, their own momentum. Of course, the Lin Ti-chuan case was a tragedy, there is no question, a very tragic accident. And I think frankly that it certainly could have been more wisely handled on both sides. It certainly did not contribute to better understanding. And of course, her case is not the only one involving threats or actual damage to people from Taiwan doing business or visiting the mainland. So I think this is an important area where closer cooperation would be in both sides' interest. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-2

TEXT.P: Q: Did the AIT ask the Mainland Affairs Council to give it information on the Lin Ti-chuan murder case?

Johnson: I don't know, because I was not in that meeting. But we talk to different government organizations all the time. And maybe that was certainly a major issue over the past several days. But we talk to the Lu-Wei-Hui (the Mainland Affairs council) and to the others, to everybody involved on a frequent basis. We were interested, for example, in the recent visit by the PRC minister of science and technology. We were interested in the recent visit by Mr. Li Ya-fei from the ARATS (Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait) and so forth. So, you know, part of our business is to be informed. And we feel that in order to be informed, we need to talk to the people responsible.

Q: Taipei is concerned that Beijing is going to push Tokyo to codify the "three noes" during Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan next month. And some media reports also said that the Japanese prime minister may throw verbal support behind the "three noes" in his speech at a welcoming party. So do you think a so-called domino effect has happened already in this region?

Johnson: I think that everybody has to make their own decision as far as policy (is concerned) and whether it's that subject or another subject. I noticed in the newspaper today that the prime minister of Japan was again quoted as endorsing the principle of peaceful dialogue and peaceful resolution of disputes between Taiwan and the mainland. I don't expect that there is going to be any important change in Japan's approach to the Taiwan question. As for how they choose to address it, that's basically their business, and they will decide.
Q: Taiwan has been trying to seek more international space. Do you think that Taiwan's international space will be limited after President Clinton made the "three noes" statement?

Johnson: Well, no. I don't think so. In fact on the contrary, I think that one of the most important developments, at least between the US and Taiwan in recent months, was the signing of the WTO agreement, which was officially signed last Friday (Aug. 7), although the agreement in principle was reached in February. We very much support the idea of Taiwan's participation in the WTO, which, of course, is an organization which does not require statehood for membership. It's a system which recognizes customs territories and in some cases, economies -- similar to APEC. Taiwan's participation in APEC as an Asian economy is entirely appropriate. And it was substantially the result of American efforts to reach consensus among the other Asian economies that permitted Taiwan to participate as a full participant. So these are examples of organizations where we think Taiwan's participation is appropriate. But, of course, those are not organizations for which statehood is a requirement for membership. So, we don't support Taiwan's efforts to rejoin the United Nations or UN-related bodies.
Q: And how about IMF and the World Bank?

Johnson: Well, those of course are UN-related bodies although the connection is a little distant. I think the real answer is in a way to sort of get past the question of what constitutes an organization that require statehood for membership. If there is a consensus of existing members to permit Taiwan to participate, the US is not going to oppose it. So you know that's the question. It's how to build consensus, how to encourage other countries to support Taiwan's participation in these organizations. To be quite candid, I think that Taiwan's economy -- important because of its economic role in the world as the world's 19th or 18th largest economy -- one can make a case for its participation in a number of multilateral economic organizations.
Q: So you mean that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should build consensus first, then the US will make its decision?

Johnson: Well, the US isn't going to decide these things. These will be decided by the -- you know, in most organizations the US is one of many members. And if it's an organization that requires consensus and the PRC is a member already, then obviously the PRC has to be willing to participate in that consensus. That's a cross-strait issue. On the question of a broader consensus and the US role role -- we play a role sometime, and we don't play a role other times. It depends on the organization; it depends on the issue. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-3

TEXT.P: Q: Some US scholars, including Chas Freeman, have argued that because of the aspiration for independence in certain parts of Taiwan, military conflict in the Taiwan Strait seems more likely now than in any time since 1979. What's your assessment?

Johnson: Ambassador Freeman is a good friend. We've known each other for many years. I think on this subject, his views are intended to encourage peaceful processes in this region. But I think that there is not -- well, I don't agree with the assessment. Let's put it that way. I don't think that the danger of conflict in the Taiwan Strait is greater than it has been since 1979. And in fact, on the contrary, I would hope that the atmosphere will gradually improve. And this is also one of the objectives -- one of President Clinton's objectives -- and one of our broader objectives. But if I can take a part of this question that you didn't ask but nonetheless I think is relevant is: President Clinton reaffirmed in Beijing the basis for US arms sales to Taiwan. And as you mentioned before, he also reiterated our commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act as a part of our principled position. These -- both parts of that -- of those statements continue to be the guiding principles of our policy. We will continue to sell arms of a defensive nature to Taiwan. We will continue to abide by the commitments of the Taiwan Relations Act, which are our law.

Q: Our Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling said because of the unbalanced military developments across the Taiwan Strait, there is an urgent need for Taiwan to acquire sophisticated military equipment and to upgrade its defense capability to ensure its security. And we have heard that the US Congress will soon be notified by the Pentagon about an arms sale to Taiwan. Do you know anything about that?

Johnson: Well, first of all, it's not the Pentagon. It's the State Department that notifies the Congress of the intention to sell or -- I guess the technical term is that the Congress is provided a notification in case they choose to disagree. They have a certain period within which to act if they disagree with a proposed sale of arms, not just to Taiwan, but to any place. So there is a procedure whereby the administration, acting through the State Department, notifies the Congress of its intention to go forward with an arms sale. Yes, I assume that there will be some sales of arms soon, because there always are. I mean every year there are a number of items. And this will not change; it will go forward. As for which particular items, I don't know which itmes are on the agenda right now. I am familiar with the statement that the minister made, and of course, we look carefully at any requests that Taiwan has made, as far as its requirements for defensive weapons.
Q: So you don't know what type of weapons are involved?
Johnson: As regards the items that are presently in the queue, if you like, or being in line to be notified, no, I don't remember which items are on the agenda right now.
Q: And how about the quantity and price?

Johnson: It will depend on the item. There are different quantities and different prices for different items. But the point is that, as the president said in Beijing, we do intend to continue with our arms sales policy to Taiwan. Q: And how soon will the notification be?

Johnson: That is not up to us. It's a decision that's made in Washington. But, you know, there are notifications every couple of months. It sometimes depends on the congressional calendar; it sometimes depends on when the reqeusts are examined, and you known whether there are -- what kinds of alternatives, what kinds of options there are. It's a thorough, long and thorough process. Often from the time of the initial request until the final approval can be, you know, a couple of years. So, it's not a speedy process. Each case must be looked at on its own merits. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-4

TEXT.P: Q: Some media reports also have said that a deal between Taiwan and the US to purchase anti-aircraft stinger missiles has been postponed because of President Clinton's visit to Beijing. What's your comment?

Johnson: I don't think that's true. In fact, my recollection was that that was reported in the newspapers here a year ago, because as I recall, the notification on the Stinger Missiles and the Avenger, which is a variation of the Stinger missile, was sent to the Congress in September or August of last year, not long before President Jiang Zemin's visit to Washington. I think that's right. I think that we sent that up last year. So whatever has occurred since then would simply be negotiations about the actual deliveries and other details.
Q: Some analysts here said that the US is going to take a "policy of appeasement" on arms sales to Taiwan in the future, so Taiwan may not be able to buy certain weapons that it prefers.

Johnson: Well, first of all, the word "appeasement" has a particularly unpleasant ring because it refers usually to the policies in Europe in the 1930s to try to accommodate Hitler and the German Reich. To suggest that there is such an attitude or behavior on the part of the US or other countries at the present time, I think, is clearly out of line. As regards the decision on particular items, there will always be a review of any specific request for military goods. And it is the abiding interest of the US that the two sides settle their differences by peaceful means, not by military means. It is our objective not to contribute to an arms race in the region. And, therefore, we look very carefully at Taiwan's requests and at what we consider to be their legitimate defensive needs. I think, though, that one would have to say if you look at the items that have been provided to Taiwan over the last decade by the United States, there has been no evidence of unwillingness or reluctance to provide defensive weapons to Taiwan. F-16's are perhaps an obvious example. A number have already been delivered and these will continue to be delivered. Those are very modern, very sophisticated weapons.
Q: Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling also asked for information on the possible deployment of TMD (theater missile defense) on Taiwan. Do you know when he may have gotten that information?

Johnson: No, because we are nowhere close to making any kind of decision even in the United States on whether to proceed with any kind of TMD program -- theater missile defense program. It has been a subject of a great debate ever since the idea was first proposed by the Reagan administration, having to do both with its effectiveness and its cost. And, of course, it's always related to arms control issues as well. So far as I know, we are far, far from any decision, from the US side, from our own standpoint in terms of going ahead with a theater missile defense program. I can understand that Taiwan will be interested in information about such a thing, but no such program exists at the present time. So, it is, at minimum, premature, and there certainly will not be any decision on that subject for some considerable time to come.
Q: Do you have anything you'd like to add on the subject of arms sales?

Johnson: I think the main point is that we continue to abide by the Taiwan Relations Act, by the -- our assessment of Taiwan's needs, that this is a strong program which we feel that our view and the view of the Taiwan authorities are very much in harmony. We work very closely with the Taiwan military. And we hope they are satisfied with the kind of equipment which we have provided.

Q: We know that you cannot confirm for us a recent trip to the United States by Ding Mou-shih (secretary general of the National Security Council). Can you tell us how would you define these kinds of meetings between the US and Taiwanese officials? Do you call this "track one" or "track two" communication?

Johnson: Well, that's a good question. The way the second track, track two, is usually used, is to refer to unofficial meetings between people who have no specific official positions. In this case, the participants in these meetings do have official positions. So, in that sense, it represents the first track. The caveat, I guess, you have to say is that because we don't have official diplomatic relations, therefore, these meetings have a special unofficial characteristic. But they still -- I guess I would have to say that they still represent track one because they are meetings between people who have a specified responsibility and authority on both sides. And they are very useful, by the way. I think these meetings are very useful. (MORE) ZCZC CEP033 08-14-98 TRANSCRIPT-5

Q: We hear many US scholars, including former Defense Secretary William Perry, saying that they would like to have a track two communication channel with Taipei. Is that because the first track is not working efficiently?

Johnson: I don't think that's it. I think our communcations with Taiwan are extremely effective. I see people here; others in the AIT see people here. My counterpart in Washington Stephen Chen -- Steve sees people in Washington very frequently. So I don't think there is any problem as far as communicating between people representing these two bodies that conduct their business between their people (are concerned). No, I think that the incentive from the standpoint of Dr. Perry or others who have proposed a track two approach is to try to help resolve an unresolved problem. When Dr. Perry was secretary of defense, the crisis involving the PRC missile tests was one of the most serious issues that came up duing his tenure as secretary of defense. Of the maybe five or six most important issues during his tenure -- that was one of them. So, I think that he feels, as do many other people, that if there is a problem, let's do something and try to solve it. And it is that motivation, I think, above all else that has led him to try to play a constructive role. But I would emphasize that Dr. Perry does not speak for the US administration. He was in the government, but he is not presently in the government. His meetings with the people in the States and with the people here or other places are the same as those between any other unofficial, private American and people in responsible positions here. My own view is that as long as track one -- as long as you have good communication on track one between the authorized representatives on both sides -- track two is something extra. It's something which may provide additional outside ideas, additional motivation, additional influence, if you like, but it doesn't change the context within which the players participate. I think the same is true on the other side. I remember, if I may quote President Lee Teng-hui, I am sure he would not mind. At a meeting that I had with him about a year ago on a different subject, he said, "We don't lack for messengers; we lack for a message." Lots of people want to be messengers to carry messages back and forth, but that is not the point. The point is the content of the message, and for that there are adequate channels. We have adequate channels, I think, across the strait -- the mechanism is quite adequate in conveying messages.

Q: Mr. Perry said he met with Wang Daohan (ARATS chairman) in Hawaii. So, people are wondering if we are going to have a track two communication channel, does the US have any specific candidate in mind to be the chief delegate from the Taipei side, for example, Wang Daohan's counterpart, Mr. Koo Chen-fu?

Johnson: Let me go back to the point I was making. Dr. Perry does not act on behalf of the US government. We have no opinion -- the United States government has no opinion, nor does the AIT have any opinion on who should participate in the informal conversations. There are many people in the United States who have an interest in trying to encourage peaceful resolution of disputes, whether it's this dispute, whether it's Bosnia, whether it's Ireland or the Middle East. Some of them have official authority, and many do not. They are driven in most cases by an effort to try to help -- to try to help resolve problems. But they do not act on belhalf of the United States government. So the question of who Dr. Perry should talk with is for Dr. Perry to decide.
Q: What kind of role did the AIT play in the Lincoln American School issue? What's your major concern?

Johnson: The only role that we played in that dispute was one of receiving information from the people in the school and from the community there, particularly at the end of the last school year when they were very concerned about the disruption of the last two weeks of school for the students, especially those who were graduating, those who were taking exams and so forth, that some way be found to allow the students to finish the school year without disruption. As regards the specific issues involved in the case, we have never a party to any of this, especially we are not familiar with, nor are we actors in any way in the questions that are appropriately handled by the Taiwan authorities -- the provincial authorities as well as the central authorities. They have certain jurisdiction, and that is appropriate. Even though the name "American" appears in the title, the school does not have any affiliation with the AIT. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-6

TEXT.P: Johnson: I am really hesitant to comment on it at all because apart, as I said, from being informed on behalf of the welfare of the students, we have not been a party to this in any way at all. so I don't know whether the charges were justified or not justified, whether the reactions were appropriate or inappropriate. It really is something entirely within Taiwan's jurisdication.
Q: What will you do if, in the future, the school is ordered to close or move?

Johnson: I think we will have to deal with the circumstances at the time. As I said, the one and only concern that this raised with us was the welfare of the students. And certainly as an institution that has a specific responsibility for looking after the welfare of the American citizens, we will be concerned on those grounds that the American citizen-students -- that their efforts to receive an education be honored by the local authorities. But exactly how and in what manner, is really Taiwan's responsibility.
Q: You've been here for almost two years. Can you share with us how you feel about Taiwan? What's your personal view about the yearend Taipei mayor election?

Johnson: Well, let me answer the last question first because that's an easy one. We are interested observers in the process, but that's all -- interested only in the sense that we think democracy is a wonderful thing, and we support the free exercise of political opinion regardless of whose opinion it may be. And this has so far been and will continue to be a very exciting, interesting, stimulating example of democracy in action. But as regards the candidates themselves or the issues for which they stand, this is not something on which the AIT or the United States has a position. It really is not our business at all, and we only applaud the process. With regard to your observation that we have lived here now for two years, we feel -- as I think I mentioned to you some time ago -- my wife and I feel that we have been very warmly welcomed. And I have to say I think even the press has been very kind to me, to us, and fair. And I think we have been really deeply touched, impressed, moved by the warmth of the people of Taiwan with whom we've met. And I should say this applies not only to high officials -- of course, they have been very cordial -- but also to lots of ordinary people that we have a chance to meet at the flower markets or temples or at schools or other places where we travel. We like to get out a lot, and get around the island, and to visit people in the private sector as well as government institutions and schools and so forth. So, we have been very pleased to be here. I might say that my wife's particular interests have to do with the textiles and with art. She is an artist, an art teacher by background. So she has greatly enjoyed meeting people in Taiwan with similar interests.
Q: How long do you expect to stay in Taiwan?
Johnson: We expect to be here for another year. It's normally a three-year assignment, and it will be three years next year.
Q: After that, where can we find you? (Laughters)

Johnson: Well, if I knew the answer, I would probably tell you. But I don't know the answer. And I don't expect to know for probably another six months or so, prabably around the end of the year. And I would expect to hear by early next year and I think by then we would also know who is coming in my place -- by around January or so, we should know.
Q: We have seen reports on CNN -- the explosions in Kenya and Tanzania. Many Taiwanese people come here to AIT every day to apply for visas. Is it safe for them to come here?

Johnson: Well, of course, we certainly assume they are safe to come here, although that question really is one you need to ask the local authorities, I think, in terms of any evidence of possible action against us. We work very closely with the local authorities, of course. And in response to the bombings, the tragic bombings in East Africa, we have worked with the local authorities to increase the protection of our building and of our facilities throughout Taiwan. We feel that this is a safe place to live and work, and we have no reason to assume otherwise. We have to be vigilant, and I think that's true everywhere. But we intend to keep our doors open; we intend to continue operating, to issue visas, and to receive people. We would do so with care, with sensible prudence, but also with a sense of our responsibility to the public that we serve. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-7

TEXT.P: Q: Are you familiar with Kenneth Lieberthal?

Johnson: Yes. Kenneth Lieberthal is a very good friend of mine. I first met him actually in Hong Kong almost 30 years ago, and have seen him many times, including when he visited Taiwan earlier this year. I think it was in February or March. I don't remember exactly. He was here for a conference. I saw him during that time. Yes, he's a good friend of long standing.

Q: He has been named director of the Asia-Pacific Affairs Department of the National Security Council. Many local scholars believe he is pro-Beijing. Do you think his appointment to that position will have any adverse effect on Taiwan-US relations?
Johnson: I have heard reports that Professor Lieberthal will be moving to that position. I have not seen it confirmed yet. But assuming that these reports are accurate ...
Q: Yes, today ...
Johnson: They announced it today?
Q: Yes, yes.

Johnson: In any case, there was no reason to doubt it because he is a highly qualified, very capable person. As to the possible effects on relations between the US and Taiwan, I think that Professor Lieberthal may not be accurately understood here in terms of his own views and in terms of his own background. He is a serious scholar. And he has, for many years, felt that the management of this relationship, both the US-PRC relationship and the US-Taiwan relationship, is of vital significance to the United States. So I think with him in this position at the National Security Council, he will certainly take guidance, of course, from the president, from other people in the policy process. I have every hope and expectation that his role there will be constructive. He was very impressed, very positively impressed by his visit here earlier this year. And he gave a paper there which I also think was widely misunderstood, but nonetheless it was not welcomed, shall we say. And I think that, in an unusual sort of way, had a beneficial effect for him to hear the concerns that people here expressed about the ideas that he had in that paper. But the objective of the paper was to try to lay out some ideas for maintaining the status quo. That was what it was about. It was about maintaining the status quo in a constructive way that will allow Taiwan and the mainland to go about their business for almost an indefinite time without worrying about the question of future status. That was the objective of the paper. So, anyway, I think Professor Lieberthal is a brilliant man. I think he will be a very constructive voice in managing the Taiwan part of our China relationship.
Q: Will he likely push the US government to force Taiwan into speeding up political negotiations with Beijing?

Johnson: Well, first of all, whatever Professor Lieberthal says is going to be mostly on paper, and mostly will involve meeting and talking and presenting ideas with many other people who are involved in the policy process. The policy of encouraging dialogue between Taiwan and the mainland goes back many years. It does not depend on any one individual. It is US policy. We do support dialogue. We have long supported dialogue. And this is not something that depends on who is in the National Security council. It is President Clinton's policy. Before that, it was President Bush's policy. Before that, it was President Reagan's policy, and so forth. We have always supported dialogue, just as we have always supported democratization.

Q: About the policy of appeasement on US arms sales to Taiwan, many local observers believe the United States will gradually change its arms sales policy to Taiwan, and that Taiwan will be denied access to weapons it really needs. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-8

TEXT.P: Johnson: Well, first of all, for reasons I've said before, I can't accept the word appeasement regardless of the context of what you mean, because it doesn't mean anything like that. I don't know what the word is in Chinese that you mean, but it's not the English word. The second thing is that we are guided in relations with Taiwan and the mainland by the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act. One of the three communiques specifies the framework for future arms sales to Taiwan. The Taiwan Relations Act also makes very explicit the commitment by the US to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan and to evaluate requests on the basis of Taiwan's defense needs. And that's what we do. I'm not sure -- I mean I understand that there will always be speculation of one type or another in terms of possible changes. But there has been no change in policy on that or any other aspect of our policy towards Taiwan. Every request will be examined, analyzed and discussed on its merits. And some will be approved, some won't. That would be on the basis of our best judgement of Taiwan's defense needs. There has been no change in that policy and there won't be any change because it's law.
Q: Taiwan needs submarines but it has no way to get that kind of equipment.

Johnson: Well, the question of what Taiwan really needs is a matter that we discuss with the military frequently. And it's always a question of the purposes for which the items are requested, and the question of balance, the question of arms race and so forth. Each case is looked at individually on its merits.

Q: The US Congress has very strong support for Taiwan. Now President Clinton's engagement policy toward mainland China seems to go against the American people's will, at least in the Congress. What's your opinion?

Johnson: The interesting thing is that the resolutions which were introduced in both the Senate and in the House passed overwhelmingly, almost unanimously. In the case of the Senate, it was unanimous. In the case of the House, there was one opposing vote. Obviously those would not have carried with that kind of margin if the president and his party had been against them. What these resolutions did, regardless of what the sponsors said, what these resolutions did was to reaffirm the basis of our policy toward the mainland and Taiwan -- by reaffirming the Taiwan Relations Act. The Taiwan Relations Act was written in 1979, signed by President Carter in 1979. It has been the law ever since, and it still is. And these resolutions simply reaffirmed the law which presently exists. So The administration did not oppose those resolutions. So, you know, it's a question of sort of subtracting the political rhetoric, if you like, the political language which is used by the sponsors. And looking at the actual wording of the document itself, and in this case, there was no important difference between what the Congress was saying and what the administration says.
Q: So actually Clinton is only continuing the policy of the past administrations ...

Johnson: Exactly. Even though there have been very significant differences on many issues since the time of President Nixon through Carter, Reagan, Bush and now Clinton. Oh, add Ford to that. There has been no significant change in policy, even vis-a-vis the PRC or vis-a-vis Taiwan. There have been different events during that time. But the policy of engagement with the mainland, and the policy of maintaining the deepest possible contacts and relationships with the people of Taiwan -- those have been consistent all the way through. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-9

TEXT.P: Q: Sen. Slade Gorton has said that supporting Taiwan is the mainstream position in the United States today. Is this just the view of the US Congress? You have said the administration's opinion of Taiwan does not contradict that held by the US Congress. If so, do you agree that supporting Taiwan is now the mainstream position in the United States?

Johnson: Yes, it always has been. The public opinion in the United States has always been favorable towards Taiwan, especially in the last 11 years, as Taiwan's democracy has flourished here. I think that there really and truly is no difference of opinion across the political spectrum. Some people come at the issue from a different perspective. Even in the old days, we were very strong supporters. Others have come more recently to support the evolution in Taiwan. But I think it is true to say there is almost no place on the political spectrum in the United States where there is opposition to Taiwan, and especially to Taiwan's democracy as it evolves. It is considered a great success story, economically as well as politically. And this is nearly universal. I think Sen. Gorton's observation is very correct. But I would also say we don't feel it as an "either-or" situation. Most people don't say that if you are friendly with Taiwan, therefore, you have to be hostile with the mainland. Or vice versa, if you have good relations with the mainland, you have to be hostile to Taiwan. In fact, most Americans think that it is both possible and desirable to have good relations with both. And we do. Historically, that is true, and it's true now. I mentioned to somebody the other day -- I guess it was in connection to signing the WTO agreement. I said that in terms of core issues, real hard problems, there are still a few intellectual property right protection, some of the issues having to do with the commercial activities here, bidding processes and so forth. There are problems like that. But generally speaking, there has probably never been a time when we had such a broad range of good feeling, good understanding, good relationships as we do now. And I think it's a very healthy and very strong relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DECIDES TO EVACUATE PERSONNEL FROM KINSHASA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) decided Friday evening to evacuate its personnel from Kinshasa, capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
The MOFA made the decision after receiving a report from Taiwan's representative office in Kinshasa, saying that rebels have entered the capital of the war-torn country in Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: 52ND DENGUE FEVER CASE REPORTED

TEXT.P: The Department of Health said Friday that Taiwan's 52nd dengue fever case had been confirmed.

The victim was a 47-year-old woman who contracted the disease while on a visit to the Philippines, said Hsu Hsu-mei, DOH deputy director of communicable disease control. The patient developed symptoms of dengue fever on July 17 and was diagnosed as having the sometimes fatal disease on Aug. 12.
Hsu said all of the reported cases of dengue fever in Taiwan thus far have been contracted outside the island. He warned the public to be on guard while traveling to Southeast Asian countries.

Among the 52 cases, 15 cases originated in Thailand, 11 in the Philippines, nine in Indonesia, five in Malaysia, seven in Burma, one each in Cambodia and Vietnam, two in Cambodia or Vietnam, and one in Thailand or Malaysia.
According to statistics compiled by regional hospitals in Malaysia, about 1,270 dengue fever cases have been reported as of the end of July with 21 deaths, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICFTU-APRO CONDEMNS INDONESIA FOR TRAMPLING ON HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The International Confederation of Free Trade Unions' Asian and Pacific Regional Organization (ICFTU-APRO) condemned Jakarta for ignoring the human rights violations against Chinese Indonesians.

The ICFTU-APRO, representing 33 million laborers from 29 countries in the Asian-Pacific region, condemned the attacks by rioters against ethnic Chinese in May in a letter addressed to Indonesian President B.J. Habibie, Chinese Federation of Labor President Lee Cheng-chong said Friday.
The particularly beastly acts committed against women are beyond toleration in a civilized community, the letter said.
According to human rights groups, at least 168 ethnic Chinese young girls and women were raped during the riots in May, and 20 of these victims later died, some by suicide.

The ICFTU-APRO asked the president to thoroughly investigate the cases and bring all rapists and criminals to justice. The letter also expressed the hope that Habibie would ensure that such criminal acts would not be repeated.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUPPET SHOW LEGEND LEE TIEN-LU DIES AT AGE 90

TEXT.P: Puppet master Lee Tien-lu, one of Taiwan's national treasures, died of heart failure on Thursday at his home in Sanchih, Taipei County. He was 90 years old.
Lee had suffered from poor health in recent years due partly to his advanced age. He was admitted to Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei in June because of his failing heart and lungs.
Knowing his days might be numbered, Lee insisted on returning to his ancestral home a few weeks ago because of his belief in the traditional Chinese concept, "Fallen leaves return to the roots."

The master dedicated his life to puppetry. He began to study the artistry of hand puppets under the tutelage of his father at the tender age of eight. By 22, he had organized his own troupe and embarked on his performing career. His outstanding skills had made him a household name on the island when he turned 37.
His troupe, I Wan Jan, had performed throughout Asia and in the United States and Europe, winning awards at puppetry festivals in New York and France.

Lee had performed puppet shows for US President Bill Clinton on two occasions and received the Lifetime Dedication to Arts Award at the prestigious Lincoln Center in New York. He was also a recipient of the ROC's Folk Arts Master Award.
Possessed of a rapier-sharp wit and strong willpower, Lee never compromised in his pursuit of refined hand puppet skills and artistry.
He was especially popular for his innovative martial arts sequences, acrobatic stunts, and use of modern slang mixed with classical Chinese.
His legendary life was immortalized in local movie director Hou Hsiao-hsien's award-winning film "The Puppetmaster."

Lee ended his performing career at 69 and had devoted the rest of his life to cultivating a new generation of puppeteers. Along with his two sons, Lee had also helped set up two children's puppet troupes, the Wei Wan Jan and the Cheau Wan Jan, both of which were highly praised.

Some of Lee's fans traveled all the way from Europe, the United States and Australia to Taiwan to study with him. Several of his French students formed a troupe, Hsiao Wan Jan, to present professional puppet shows to European audience.

An optimistic, confident man, Lee never hesitated in trying new things. At the age of 75, Lee ventured into movies. He starred in many award-winning films, including the "City of Sadness" and the "Puppetmaster." He earned much acclaim for his moving and sometimes funny performances.

The affable old man did not even mind appearing in TV variety shows to help promote his films. His humorous, witty commentary had won him many young fans. Many entertainers and members of the general public liked to call him "Ah Kung" (grandpa) to show their respect and admiration for him.

Through his strenuous efforts, Taiwan's first puppet museum, the Lee Tien-lu Museum, opened in Lee's hometown, Sanchih on the outskirts of Taipei, late last year. The master's lifelong treasures, including a portable stage he crafted by hand and six 100-year-old puppets adorned in ancient wardrobe, are on display at the museum.
The museum offers year-round workshops for training young puppeteers.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 300 TAIWAN ABORIGINES DIED IN ACCIDENTS LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Accidents remain the leading cause of death among Taiwan's aborigines, officials from the Taiwan Provincial Government's Department of Health said Friday.

The most common causes of death among aborigines last year were accidents, cancer, brain vascular disease, chronic diseases including liver sclerosis, heart disease, diabetes, tuberculosis, pneumonia, bronchitis, emphysema, asthma and other causes including suicide, the officials said.
The leading three causes of death among aborigines have been at the top of the list for the last 10 years, authorities said
Last year, 345 aborigines died in accidents with 177 killed in traffic accidents, 41 drowned, 40 fell to their deaths while the others died in other categories of accidents.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSU HSIN-LIANG BECOMES FOUNDATION'S CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang replaced Sisy Chen on Friday as chairman of the Rising People Foundation, a private non-profit organization.

Ranking government officials, including Premier Vincent Siew, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan, Control Yuan President Wang Tso-yung, as well as National Assembly President Fredrick Chien, Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang, and DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and his predecessors Shih Ming-te and Huang Hsin-chieh, all attended the appointment ceremony at the Taipei Grand Formosa Regent Hotel.
In his address, Siew hailed Hsu for his contributions to Taiwan's democratization and said he hopes Hsu will go on to accomplish even greater achievements in his political career.
The out-spoken Control Yuan head Wang praised both Hsu and Shih as "very outstanding" citizens for their commitment and devotion to the pursuit of Taiwan people's well-being.

Lin, who took over the DPP chairmanship from Hsu on Aug. 1, also had high praise for Hsu, noting his bravery in standing alone to voice his own opinions. Lin said Hsu's encouragement was especially apparent in the face of strong criticism from others.
For his part, Hsu said he was very worried over Taiwan's future as the situation in the international community is becoming increasingly difficult for the island.

Hsu said his "go west" policy, support for broader cross-strait economic exchanges and his prediction that Taiwan would encounter greater international pressure to begin political talks with mainland China have proven correct.

But is Taiwan really ready for these challenges, Hsu asked. He expressed the hope that all Taiwan politicians would think over these issues in light of a foreseeable harsh political climate for the island in the new millennium.

Hsu had said earlier this year that he would take part in Taiwan's next presidential election slated for 2000. Meanwhile Sisy Chen, along with other female DPP members, will devote their time to helping women explore their political potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DOWNGRADES ECONOMIC GROWTH FORECAST FOR 1998

TEXT.P: Taiwan's projected economic growth for 1998 was adjusted downward to 5.3 percent by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) on Friday.

DGBAS Director-General Wei Duan said this will be the eighth time in decades that Taiwan's economic growth rate will register below 6 percent following the years of 1956, 1971, 1981, 1985, 1990, and 1996.

However, compared with other Asian countries, Wei said, Taiwan's overall economic performance for 1998 is not bad at all. The 5.3 economic growth is the second highest in Asia behind only mainland China.

In its economic report in May, the DGBAS predicted that Taiwan's economy would grow by 6.02 percent for 1998. It also said the economic growth for the first quarter of this year was 5.92 percent, while the second, third and fourth quarters were expected to grow by 5.78 percent, 6.16 and 6.18 percent, respectively.

However, continuing fallout from the Asian financial crisis has made the economic growth forecasts appear to be too optimistic, prompting the DGBAS to adjust the economic growth from the first quarter throughout the fourth quarter to 5.86 percent, 5.21 percent, 4.95 percent and 5.21 percent.

The DGBAS said as Taiwan's foreign trade has declined drastically, this year's economic growth has to depend on the private sector's investment. Although growth in private sector investments was slightly adjusted downward to 19.7 percent from 22 percent, the growth represented the highest in 11 years.
The gross national product for 1998 was predicted to reach US$262.1 billion with the per capita national income standing at US$12,030.

The DGBAS also predicted that economic growth will rebound to 5.8 percent for the first half of next year as fallout from the Asian financial turmoil is expected to subside during this period, and investments either in the private or public sector will be boosted by the government's "domestic demand expansion package."

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER VICTIM CONTRACTED AIDS THROUGH TRANSFUSION: DOH

TEXT.P: The Department of Health on Friday revealed that another person in Taiwan had contracted AIDS through a blood transfusion.
Officials said the 24-year-old female patient died of cirrhosis on July 28.
This is the sixth such case since 1988, the year when the DOH began requiring that all donated blood be tested for contamination.

The contaminated blood the victim received was from a regular male donor who first donated blood in May 1993. The man tested HIV positive on April 17 this year when he attempted to make another donation.
The man's last two blood donations were made on July 22, 1997 and Dec. 5, 1997. This blood supply had been given to six people including the victim.
Two of the other recipients died in Dec. 1997 and Feb. 1998. Another recipient tested HIV negative while the remaining two have not yet been located.

DOH officials said the blood donor admitted to patronizing prostitutes while on a trip to a Southeast Asian country in June 1997. He married a Southeast Asian woman in August later that year and brought her back to Taiwan.
The man's wife has also tested HIV positive which led to her deportation back to her home country.
As the number of similar cases are surfacing, the DOH said it will adopt more rigorous methods of screening donated blood.
In a Friday meeting, hosted by the DOH, a number of experts, blood donation center officials, and AIDS advisory council officials discussed the issue.

After the meeting, the DOH announced that as part of efforts to address the issue, the waiting period on donations from high-risk people will be raised from one year to two years. Those who indulge in high-risk sexual behavior, who have had venereal disease, or who are inmates of a penitentiary have to wait two years before they can make any blood donation.

According to the DOH, those blood donors who are found to have circumvented the waiting period will be prosecuted and face severe punishment. In addition, the DOH said that it will require all the blood donation centers to use the latest technique to screen donated blood.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MISERY INDEX RELATIVELY LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwan's misery index in daily life and financial state are both lower than those posted by neighboring countries, a government agency reported on Friday.

According to the Cabinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), Taiwan's misery index in daily life -- which calculates the 2.4 percent unemployment with the 1.7 percent increase in the consumer price index -- totaled 4.1 percent in the first half of this year.

The figure was only slightly higher than Singapore's 2.9 percent, but noticeably lower than the Philippines' 19 percent, South Korea's 14.8 percent, Hong Kong's 8.5 percent and Japan's 5.4 percent, the DGBAS said.
The Asian financial turmoil has had an even greater impact on the countries' financial sectors since the crisis broke out about a year ago, the DGBAS said.

Taiwan's financial misery index -- the combination of a 18.9 percent depreciation in the New Taiwan dollar and a 14.4 percent plunge in share prices -- stood at 33.3 percent, far lower than figures in other neighboring countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia, where the financial misery indexes all exceeded 100 percent, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The China Times: The government plans to amend the Constitution next year to freeze the National Assembly.
The United Daily News: The government adjusts downward this year's economic growth target to 5.3 percent.
The Central Daily News: Return on investment in Taiwan will rank second around the world next year.
The Liberty Times: ROC evacuates its representative office and expatriates from Kinshasa as rebels have entered the capital of the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo in Africa.
The Independence Morning Post: Taiwan Power Company will control its central air conditioning system to cut electricity consumption.
The Commons Daily: China intends to intervene in Taiwan's three-in-one elections scheduled for late this year.
The China Post: Taiwan's GDP growth will fall below 6 percent this year for eighth time.
The China News: Police will convene a forum on reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT SETS UP TASK FORCE TO PROMOTE EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) has announced the formation of a task force to promote exports, in an attempt to slow the decline in the nation's exports caused by the Asian financial crisis.
BOFT officials said that the task force will analyze the reasons for the decreasing exports, and map out a promotion strategy based on this analysis.
Wayne Wu, BOFT deputy director-general, said that the first job for the task force will be to visit domestic manufacturers to learn about the real difficulties they face.
Statistics show that Taiwan's exports declined by 8.6 percent in the first seven months of this year, and by 16.3 percent in July alone.
The semi-official China External Trade Development Council said that most major export items have recorded an across-the-board decline this year.

In terms of monetary value, machinery, fiber yarn, line and fabrics, electronic products, and information and telecommunications products all recorded sharp declines, while plywood, footwear, ceramics, toys, and sporting goods registered the highest declines in export volume.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO DEFEND ITS INTERESTS WHEN JIANG ZEMIN VISITS JAPAN

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers and scholars are scheduled to travel to Japan prior to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's September visit to Japan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Saturday.

The Legislative Yuan and National Assembly members and the scholars, who are making the trip with full government support, will be trying their utmost to express Taipei's position that Taiwan's interests should not be sacrificed by Japan as a result of Jiang's visit, said MOFA spokesman Roy Wu.
The Republic of China does not want to see Jiang's visit adversely affect relations between Taiwan and Japan either, he added.

Announcing the results of a supra-ministerial meeting held on Friday in the face of Jiang's upcoming Japanese visit, Wu said that while it is believed Tokyo will not directly address the so-called "three noes" policy stated by US President Bill Clinton toward Taiwan, Beijing may continue to exert pressure on Tokyo until it makes a similar acknowledgment of the policy.

President Clinton said at an informal setting in Shanghai during his last visit to mainland China on June 25-July 3 that the US doesn't support "independence for Taiwan," "Two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan," and "Taiwan's membership in international orgaziations for which statehood is a requirement." This US position is oftened referred to as the "three noes" policy.

Friday's meeting worked out six resolutions aimed at making Taiwan's position clear and defending Taiwan's interests at a time when Japanese-mainland Chinese engagement may result in an outcome harmful to Taiwan's interests.
The government officials resolved that a supra-party Legislative Yuan mission will visit Japan between Aug. 24 and 27 to voice Taiwan's concerns about Jiang's upcoming visit to Japan.
An academic mission, to be jointly sponsored by the MOFA and the Government Information Office, will also visit Japan later this month with a similar purpose.

Members of the Japanese media will be invited to Taiwan to interview ROC officials, and government agencies will accelerate bilateral contacts so that they can stay well-informed of every development.

Meanwhile, the MOFA urged Tokyo to strengthen parallel relations with Taipei and not make any promises or engage in any activities with mainland China that may result in undermining the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific region.
