DOC.HEADLINE: ENGLISH TO BE TAUGHT IN PRIMARY SCHOOLS FROM 2001

TEXT.P: Three years from now, English will become a regular part of the syllabus for primary school students in the fifth and sixth grades in Taiwan, according to plans drawn up by the Ministry of Education.
Education Minister Lin Ching-jiang said on Friday that from fiscal 2001, fifth and sixth grade students will study English for two hours each week.
The plan calls for some 1,800 teachers to take charge of English teaching in local primary schools.
Lin said that his ministry is working out plans to train these teachers through a variety of channels, adding that they will have to be able to teach English with the correct pronunciation.
University graduates are welcome to apply for jobs as primary school English teachers, but they will have to pass screening exams and undertake a specialized training course, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT NOT SEEKING AMENDMENT TO FREEZE NATIONAL ASSEMBLY: CHANG

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang on Saturday denied that the ruling party is planning to seek a revision to the Constitution which would allow the National Assembly to be abolished.

Chang described a China Times newspaper report on Saturday as untrue. The paper said the KMT is seeking to have the Legislative Yuan propose a constitutional amendment to freeze the National Assembly next year.

The paper said the country's "key decision makers" have recently reached a consensus that the operations of the National Assembly, one of the Republic of China's two chambers of parliament, will be suspended, with its abolition legitimized through another constitutional revision.

It went on to say that President Lee Teng-hui has recently expressed the hope that the parliamentary reforms will be completed within his tenure, and that during a routine weekly meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, he instructed the KMT Policy Coordination Committee to study relevant measures on the initiative.

Chang, however, said that it is true that the structure of the "two-chamber" parliament will be readjusted. Once the National Assembly's constitutional reform task force completes in-depth research on the issue and reaches a consensus, the readjustment will begin, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER PREDICTS ECONOMY WILL REBOUND BY EARLY 2000

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Saturday he is optimistic that the economy will take a turn for the better by late 1999 or early 2000.
Wang made the remarks after the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) adjusted its prediction for Taiwan's economic growth downwards to 5.3 percent.
He said the figure, though not ideal, is acceptable, noting that Asia's economic slowdown will make it difficult to enjoy a rebound in the short time frame involved.

Noting that US-based Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association (WEFA) had earlier predicted that Taiwan's economic growth this year will be 5.2 percent, he said that it is roughly the same as the DGBAS prediction.

He compared the figure with the WEFA forecasts for the other countries in the Asian region, saying that the association predicted economic growth of 0.6 percent for Japan, 1.2 percent for Singapore, and 13 percent negative growth for Indonesia this year, which illustrates the fact that Asian economies in general are in decline.

Wang said that compared with other nations in the world, Taiwan ranks as one of the top 20 in terms of economic growth. Those who are ahead of Taiwan, such as mainland China, have higher predicted growth rates because they are newly developing economies. Taiwan's economic development has reached a more mature stage, causing growth to naturally slow down, he pointed out.
Wang said that the continued slowdown of the Asian economy has inevitably affected Taiwan's exports, adding that Taiwan's economy must now depend on its domestic market.

He said the government will continue to step up public construction projects and promote private investment by removing investment hurdles. Private investment this year is expected to show a 16 percent growth rate, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TOLD JAPAN'S POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN WILL CONTINUE

TEXT.P: A Japanese official said in Washington on Friday that Tokyo has not decided whether to issue a joint statement on Taiwan during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan in early September.

However, Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman Sadaaki Numata added that Foreign Minister Masahiko Komura told US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright during talks earlier in the day "that there will be no change in Japan's position (on Taiwan)."

With Taiwan expected to be one of the issues that Jiang will want to discuss with Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi during his trip, there have been reports that Japan will be asked to issue a joint statement with mainland China reiterating their "one China" policy.

According to these reports, Obuchi will come under pressure from Beijing to follow in US President Bill Clinton's footsteps and enunciate the so-called "Three Noes" on Taiwan -- no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas" and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations where statehood is a requirement.

Komura's meeting with Albright was his first since he became foreign minister last month. During their talks and a working lunch at the State Department, they also discussed the troubled Russian economy, and Clinton's recent visit to mainland China, as well as US-Japan security relations and other bilateral issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE MINISTER CONDEMNS RAPES IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Singapore's Information and Arts Minister Yeo Yong Boon on Friday condemned the mass rapes of ethnic Chinese women in Indonesia, describing the atrocities as "crimes against humanity."
Speaking in Mandarin at a National Day dinner in his constituency, he said: "The ferocity of the anti-Chinese rioting in Indonesia in May was shocking. Some of it was organized.
"The systematic raping of ethnic Chinese women was a crime against humanity. (Indonesian) President Habibie himself has acknowledged this and has called for a thorough investigation."
Yeo was the first Singapore cabinet minister to publicly condemn the rapes.
He also said that Singaporeans must expect the regional situation to become more complicated as a result of the economic crisis in Indonesia.

"(The situation) in Indonesia is worrying. This year, Indonesia will be short of grain by a few million tons. Our bilateral relationship with Malaysia has also worsened. We must prepare ourselves for different eventualities in the region.

"The most important thing for us is to stay united, maintain racial harmony and take National Service seriously. If we rally behind the government, we should weather this crisis and emerge stronger from it."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONALS REMAIN IN KINSHASA

TEXT.P: All 10 Republic of China nationals in the war-torn Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) in central Africa remain safe, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Saturday.

Nevertheless, Wu said, it remains unclear when the two-member ROC mission and eight ROC expatriates in the capital, Kinshasa, can be evacuated, because foreign aircraft have been prohibited from flying into the country for evacuation purposes.
The French-speaking African state has also forbidden the departure of all scheduled or chartered flights from its airports, Wu said.

The ministry on Friday ordered Hsiao Kuang-yu, the de facto ROC ambassador to the DRC, to arrange for evacuation, as rebels were reported to be marching toward Kinshasa from the country's western coastline.
Wu said Belgium, which had originally planned to send a chartered plane on Saturday to evacuate its nationals, had agreed to help pick up the ROC nationals there, including Hsiao.
However, the flight ban meant that the plane could not enter the DRC's airspace, Wu said, adding that a French military aircraft was also barred from entry.

Wu quoted Hsiao as having told him early Saturday morning that the French Embassy in Kinshasa was arranging a ship to evacuate its nationals, as well as 25 Japanese and 46 South Korean expatriates in the country.

"According to the French plan, the ship will carry evacuees across the Zaire River to Brazzaville, capital of Republic of the Congo, which sits on the opposite bank of the river from Kinshasa," Wu said.
He added that Hsiao is negotiating with the French Embassy for its consent to help evacuate the ROC nationals.
Wu said the situation in Kinshasa remains peaceful at the moment and that all the ROC nationals are safe and in good shape.
Many neighboring countries, as well as the United Nations, are planning to send personnel to the DRC to help mediate peace between President Laurent Kabila's government and the rebels, Wu said.

"We hope the situation will stabilize soon," Wu said, adding that the Foreign Ministry is keeping close watch on developments there and is doing its utmost to protect the safety of its staff members and other ROC nationals in the country.

According to foreign wire service reports, an army of Tutsi rebels, Rwandan soldiers, and disenchanted troops from Kabila's army -- the same people who helped Kabila oust longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in May 1997 -- is marching toward Kinshasa, possibly ushering in an inglorious end to Kabila's turbulent 14-month rule.

The DRC was previously known as Zaire. The ROC first established diplomatic ties with Zaire in 1960, but cut such ties in early 1973 after the African state switched diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing in late 1972. In June 1991, the ROC signed an agreement with Zaire on the exchange of representative offices. The ROC's representative office in Kinshasa was inaugurated in July 1991. Zaire changed its national title to the Republic of Congo in May 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALUABLE 5TH CENTURY B.C. INSTRUMENT ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A duplicate of a fifth century B.C. chime unearthed in the mainland Chinese province of Hubei arrived in Taiwan on Friday.

The instrument, crafted by the Provincial Hubei Museum and imported via Hong Kong, was ordered by Taipei's Chang Foundation Museum at the behest of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA).
The chime, comprising 65 bronze bells, is considered proof of the sophistication of ancient Chinese musicians and artisans.

Its original, called a "Bianzhong," dates back to the Early Warring States Period of over 2,000 years ago, and was unearthed from the middle chamber of the tomb of Zenghou Yi, a feudal lord, in an area known today as Suixian, in the central province of Hubei.

The CCA, which had long sought a copy of the instrument in an effort to help preserve the cream of ancient Chinese artifacts and musical theory, will now sponsor a program through which Taiwan musicians can learn to play the instrument, considered to be the most sophisticated musical equipment ever unearthed.

The copy, which cost NT$22 million (US$641,400), is expected to be included in a collection of the Ethnic Music Center being established by the CCA, said Liao Kuei-ying, executive curator of the privately owned Chang Foundation Museum.
The chime is one of three copies made by the Provincial Hubei Museum after the valuable instrument was unearthed in 1978.

Consisting of 65 bells which hang vertically or diagonally under wood beams on three different levels, the chime weighs a staggering 4,421 kilograms. Each bell, the largest of which stands 152 centimeters high, can produce two different notes, making the instrument capable of playing almost any modern piece of music, Liao said.

In an overseas performance tour several years ago, mainland Chinese musicians played Beethoven's Fifth Symphony on a reproduction of the instrument, debunking the myth that the ancient Chinese had no muscial theory and lacked the instruments to play sophisticated music.

What is perhaps most amazing about the chime is not only that it can produce a full-range of musical notes and 12 semi-tones from C2 to D7, but that it also bears gold-inlaid inscriptions revealing the musical theory of the time and the way in which people from six neighboring states played the same music.

The 3,755-character inscription has greatly advanced modern-day knowledge of ancient Chinese music, said Liao, whose museum sponsored an exhibition in Taiwan featuring a reproduction of the ancient instrument late last year.

Another amazing aspect of the chime is the sophistication of the bronze alloy used to make the bells. The alloy indicates that the metallurgical industry in China 2,000 years ago was well established.
Other details, including the casting, painting and carving on the instrument are equally stunning, she said.

Liao admitted that importing the chime was far from easy. First, it was not allowed to be directly ordered by the CCA because of the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Second, the Chang Foundation Museum faced an import tax and handling fees of more than NT$2 million (US$58,310) charged by customs authorities, who did not consider the instrument to be "materials to be used in academic research" as was claimed by the importer.
The CCA then filed an appeal with the Department of Customs Administration (DCA) for a reexamination of the import application, in the hope that the instrument would be allowed entry duty-free.
To the relief and joy of all concerned, the DCA gave a last-minute green light for the importation, and the chime was finally allowed entry into Taiwan duty-free on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENTS ISSUE OPEN LETTER CENSURING BEIJING AUTHORITIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By David Wang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of mainland Chinese dissidents Thursday issued an open letter of protest to Beijing authorities over the detainment of dissident Liu Nianchun and the brutal treatment of Liu's family.
The 27 dissidents, who are currently living in exile in the United States, called for Liu's release and an investigation into the physical confrontation between Liu's family and security officials.

Their letter described how Liu's mother and wife went to the Beijing Municipal Committee on Monday with the intention of protesting against the abuse and detention of Liu. But they were attacked by public security police on their way to the committee, and were dragged away by force to the police station.

The exiled dissidents called on Beijing authorities to immediately investigate and punish the security officers involved in the confrontation with Liu's family. They also urged authorities to take necessary measures to prevent other similar incidents from happening again.

Liu joined the mainland's pro-democracy movement as early as 1978, and was the editor of a periodical titled "Today." He was sentenced to three years in prison in 1982, and detained for five months in May 1994 after organizing a league for the protection of labors' rights. Liu was arrested once again in 1995 and was sentenced to three years of "re-education" which was due to be completed in May 1998.

However, authorities continue to hold Liu in custody without offering a reason. He is reportedly very ill and is not getting proper medical treatment, which led his mother and wife to take his case to the committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: 62 MAJOR SMUGGLING CASES REPORTED THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Customs reported on Saturday that there were 62 major smuggling cases worth a total of NT$134.07 million (US$3.85 million) reported in the first half of this year.
Attempts to smuggle items through containers involved 28 incidents, or 45 percent of all smuggling cases.

"Mules" or people carrying illicit items into the country were involved in 26 incidents, or 41 percent of all cases. Most of these acts involved attempts to bring in drugs, ammunition, endangered wildlife and or their by-products.
Customs authorities will increase their inspection of arrival passengers' baggage and maintain a file of high-risk passengers to stem the incoming flow of smuggling goods, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 23.8 points to finish at 7,371.84.
In all, 1.19 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$54.05 billion (US$1.557 billion).

Paper and pulp stocks rose the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.9 percent; both cement stocks and financial shares at 0.8 percent; foodstuff issues at 0.7 percent; plastic and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent; and construction shares at 0.4 percent.
Electrical engineering issues dropped 0.3 percent, the only category that fell.
Meanwhile, the US dollar rose NT$0.024 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market, closing at NT$34.726.
The greenback opened at 34.695 and was traded between 34.695 and 34.765.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$51.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS' HEAD URGES UPGRADE OF INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan must actively work to upgrade its industries to produce high-end value-added products in the face of higher competition in the region, the head of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) said Saturday.
Y.C. Wang was speaking in Taipei County about his experiences in running the FPG as an example of the importance of upgrading industries.

Taiwan initially gained its success in labor-intensive industries such as processing and manufacturing, but as other regions are offering cheaper conditions with lower labor and production costs, more and more industries are going overseas.

Looking for bargains, Taiwan businessmen are on their way to the mainland. The local wage in the mainland is only one fourth of Taiwan's, Wang said. It is only natural that over 30,000 Taiwan businessmen have been lured to the mainalnd.

He said under these circumstances, Taiwan has to upgrade its technology in shipbuilding, automobile production, heavy industry, high-technology, and closely control its investment costs so it can remain competitive.
Wang was also asked about the three factories under related to the FPC have closed in Taipei County not because they lost money, but because they could not meet their operation targets.

He said the recent closure of Tai Shih Textile Industry Corp. -- a joint venture between the FPG and a Japanese company in Ilan, eastern Taiwan -- was an example of closing an operation to upgrade the industry.

Wang said the government has to carefully assess the industries in Taipei County and their conditions, then determine what other industries need to be developed and how to improve the present conditions.

To promote the expansion of national industry, the focus must be on infrastructures, Wang noted. The mainland is still at a fledgling stage in its steel refinement, shipbuilding and automobile industries but its attitude is aggressive.
In planning for the major industries of the nation, it is important to take into consideration not only its talent, but also education, experience and management, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEILLANCE OPERATIONS AROUSE STRONG PROTEST

TEXT.P: Former Legislative Yuan President Liang Su-jung on Saturday expressed anger over allegedly being placed under surveillance by the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau (MJIB).

Liang said he, along with former Premier Hau Po-chun and former Justice Minister Lin Yang-kang, will present joint petitions to the Executive Yuan and Presidential Office asking them to explain why the MJIB has placed them under surveillance.

Saying that surveillance is a serious invasion of human rights, Liang demanded the MJIB to immediately suspend such activity, or action would be taken against the government in the United Nation's Human Rights Committee.

According to a report carried in the latest issue of The Journalist weekly magazine, the MJIB conducted another round of surveillance in March, which targeted certain local people who travel to mainland China for investment, tourism, religious and cultural exchange purposes.
Liang, chairman of the Chinese Association for the Promotion of Cross-Strait Civil Exchanges, said he discussed the issue with Lin and Hau over the telephone on Friday.

"We all feel very angry. Such a surveillance is absurd and shameless," Liang said in a joint news conference he held with New Party Legislator Lee Ching-hu who is also allegedly targeted by the bureau.

Liang also accused President Lee Teng-hui of being behind the surveillance. Saying that he respects President Lee despite their political differences, Liang used strong language to express his dissatisfaction over the issue. He claimed that President Lee is using the surveillance as an instrument to "terminate" his opponents.

During the news conference, Legislator Lee described the surveillance as an "intimidation" or a "purge." He said that most of the people monitored by the bureau are those who are not in the political mainstream or those who are pro-unification, signaling that the government is actually pro-independence in its agenda.

The legislator said if the government were conducting surveillance for national security, it should target the right people such as those who have power or those who have acted as secret envoys to the mainland and those who were once communists.

In response to the press conference, Justice Minister Cheng chun-mo said that although the political surveillance is the bureau's main priority, it is only part of its mission. Cheng admitted the existence of such surveillance on Thursday.
However, Cheng stressed that the MJIB has not put specified figures under surveillance as has been alleged, rebutting such claims as "nonsense."

Cheng said for the sake of national security, national interests, as well social stability, the bureau is only seeking to ensure that persons who have links with the mainland are not endangering national security.
"The white terror of past decades, during which certain figures were monitored and even suppressed, is long over as a result of the island's successful democratization," Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR TO REBOUND IN SECOND HALF OF THE YEAR: CBC HEAD

TEXT.P: Governor of Central Bank of China (CBC) Perng Fai-nan predicted on Saturday that the local currency will stabilize in the second half of the year.
Perng said in a news conference that the CBC respects the market mechanism and will let it decide the value of the New Taiwan dollar, but he added that sometimes intervention is necessary.
There is room for the NT dollar to rebound against the US dollar in the second half of the year, he said, adding that speculative trading on foreign exchanges has been greatly reduced.
As the new European Union currency, the euro, is expected to make its debut next year, the US dollar will likely lose part of its momentum, Perng said.
Although he refused to predict the movement of the renminbi, the governor said the CBC would like to see the renminbi remain stable.
He also stressed that the CBC will push for financial liberalization and internationalization step by step.

DOC.HEADLINE: FATE OF NEW ZEALAND'S PM SEEMS UNCERTAIN

TEXT.P: The fate of New Zealand's Prime Minister Jenny Shipley seems increasingly uncertain following the sacking of Deputy Prime Minister Winston Peters on Friday, political analysts said.

They said Shipley, leader of the National Party, must now persuade at least seven members of the New Zealand First Party (NZFP) to remain in her Cabinet so she can remain in power. If she is unable to do so, she may face an early election.

Shipley's party has only 44 seats in the 120-seat parliament, but she has support from independent MPs and other minority parties. However, to stay in power, she needs support from at least seven MPs from the NZFP.
Peters, who also served as treasurer, is the leader of NZFP, which has altogether 16 MPs in the parliament, serving as the balance of power.
It is expected that Peters will also try very hard to persuade his colleagues to boycott Shipley's coalition to oust her from power.
In the meantime, another main party -- The Labor Party -- is possibly moving to dethrone Shipley.
Having 37 seats in the parliament, the Labor Party may be trying to win the support of other parties, including the support of some NZFP MPs, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPERT DONATES 2-28 INCIDENT ARCHIVES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An American Taiwan affairs expert has donated to the island a valuable collection of manuscripts and official US documents concerning the tragic incident which occurred in Taiwan on Feb. 28, 1947.

Yeh Poh-wen, curator of Taipei's 2-28 Incident Museum, told a news conference on Saturday that George Kerr, author of the book "Formosa Betrayed," donated the collection to the museum earlier this year.
"The precious archives were already sent to Taiwan. We are examining the collection and will put it on public display next February," Yeh said.
He went on to say that Kerr focused on studying Taiwan-related affairs during a stint at the military intelligence headquarters under the US Defense Department from 1942 to 1943.

Between 1944 and 1946, Kerr served at the US Navy's intelligence center. He was then transferred to the State Department. Kerr was a deputy consul at the US embassy in the Republic of China from 1946 through 1947. When the incident, often referred to as the 2-28 Incident, took place, Kerr was in Taiwan.
Yeh said Kerr had painstakingly recorded the statements, speeches and talks delivered by leading figures involved in the 2-28 Incident as well as their ordeal.
In addition, Yeh said, Kerr took many pictures featuring everyday life and major social events or activities in Taiwan during that turbulent period.

Speaking on the same occasion, Chang Yen-hsien, a research fellow with Academia Sinica's Institute of Social Sciences, said the collection contributed by Kerr is highly valuable because there is limited documentation detailing the incident.
Kerr's collection include geographic maps, photos, books, newspaper clippings, official US documents and private letters.

"The archives provide a glimpse into all aspects of Taiwan from late 19th century to the 1960s, ranging from political, economic and social developments to cultural, environmental and agricultural situation," Chang added.

The 2-28 Incident was sparked by the arrest and beating of an elderly female street vendor selling untaxed cigarettes. Subsequent islandwide rioting and anti-Kuomintang protests followed by a brutal military crackdown caused the death of thousands of innocent people all over Taiwan.

For years, talks about the incident were a taboo. With Taiwan becoming a full-fledged democracy, the government has adopted a more open attitude toward the incident. President Lee Teng-hui has made a public apology to the families of the incident's victims.

The government has also offered financial compensation to their families and set up a foundation to study measures for restoring the reputations of many innocent people who were convicted and executed in connection with the incident. In addition to the 2-28 Museum, a Taipei park has also been renamed the 2-28 Peace Memorial Park in rememberance of those who died in the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS MEET PARAGUAYAN BRASS
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 14 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Huang Kun-huei, presidential secretary-general of the Republic of China, met with outgoing Paraguayan President Juan Carlos Wasmosy on Friday.

Huang, in his capacity as the special envoy of ROC President Lee Teng-hui during newly-elected Paraguayan President Raul Cubas Grau's inauguration, expressed gratitude on behalf of President Lee and the people of Taiwan to Wasmosy for his long-term support for the ROC.
Huang extended President Lee's invitation to President-elect Cubas to Taiwan on Thursday during their meeting. Cubas accepted but said he did not know when he could make the visit.

Meanwhile, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, who is a member of the ROC delegation, met with newly-appointed Paraguayan Foreign Minister Dido Florentin Bogado on Friday. Both of them expressed the hope that bilateral ties between the two countries will be further bolstered, Hu stated.

The new Asuncion government is an energetic group full of ideals, Hu said, adding that it is looking forward to leading Paraguay to a higher-degree of democracy and promoting closer ties with its allies around the world.
Hu said it is uncertain whether Paraguay will sign a cooperative agreement with the ROC on Monday given that the new Paraguayan government needs time to sort things out.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 1,000 SIGN SINGAPORE PETITIONS TO JAKARTA AND UN

TEXT.P: Over 1,000 visitors to an exhibition in Singapore on Friday signed petitions calling for more support for victims raped in Indonesia's May riots and for the punishment of those responsible for the attacks.

The exhibition on the rapes in Indonesia, was organized by the Singapore Association of Women for Action and Research (AWARE), which is sending the petitions to the United Nation's High Commissioner for Human Rights Mary Robinson and President B.J. Habibie in Jakarta.

Within the first hour, nearly 200 people visited the exhibition, which featured accounts of rape and photographs taken from the Internet of people believed to be rape victims. AWARE was not able to verify if the subjects were indeed victims of the May riots and of East Timorese women raped in January.

The petitions call for the condemnation of the rapes in the May riots, for help and compensation for the victims and their families, for the crimes to be investigated and the guilty parties to be punished.
The petition to the UN calls for economic and political sanctions against Indonesia if it fails to act.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD BANK WARNS INDIA OF DEFICIT DANGER

TEXT.P: The World Bank has warned India that its high public sector deficit is threatening the country's macroeconomic stability and dragging its growth, according to reports of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Friday.

In its annual report on India's economy, the World Bank said India urgently needs to cut subsidies and broaden its tax base "to reduce the risk of macroeconomic instability" and increase resources for paid, private-sector led growth.
"High fiscal deficits absorb funding from the private sector, threaten macro-stability and hinder financial sector reform," the report stated.

During the last fiscal year, India's central government deficit was about 6 percent of gross domestic product, one of the largest in the world. Although the budget in June projected a deficit of 5.6 percent of the GDP, the bank said subsequent adjustments, including a rollback in a proposed import tariff, will reduce projected revenues by 0.2 percent in the GDP, leaving the deficit at 5.8 percent.

The report also said India's states are in an "increasingly unsustainable position" due to their excessive subsidies on items such as power to farmers, and this increasingly threatens the provision of the social and physical infrastructure needed for development.

While India's external position was comfortable in the last year, the bank warned of growing pressure on the balance of payments. In 1997-98, the current account deficit rose to an estimated US$6.2 billion, or 1.6 percent of the GDP, up from US$4.4 billion in 1996-97. The bank projected that the current account deficit will rise further to 2.5 percent of the GDP by 1999-2000.
The bank noted that India's foreign exchange reserves, which were US$26.3 billion at the end of March 1998, will fall to US$22.6 billion in the current fiscal year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANBERRA'S CHINESE TO PROTEST AGAINST INDONESIAN ATROCITIES

TEXT.P: Members of Canberra's ethnic Chinese community will stage a 30-minute rally in front of the Indonesian embassy Monday, organizers said Saturday.

Chinese from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Southeast Asian countries will come together to express their outrage and condemnation over atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese in Indonesia during May this year.
The group said they will demand that the Indonesian government punish those found guilty of committing criminal acts against Chinese during the riots.
Foreign media reports estimated that 168 Chinese women, aged between 9 to over 60, were raped, tortured and some killed during the riots.
Media pictures showed that Indonesian troops were involved in the gang-raping with the bodies of the murdered Chinese women covered in anti-Chinese slogans.

The Canberra protest follows a wave of similar rallies against Indonesian atrocities toward ethnic Chinese in many countries. The most recent ones were by students in Beijing and Filipino Chinese students in Manila where an ASEAN regional forum was held recently.

In an effort to escape being victimized by angry Indonesians, many Chinese Indonesian students, especially girls, have gone to Taiwan to continue their education, according to the Australian Financial Review on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC UNVEILS MEASURES TO STEM MONEY SPECULATION

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) announced four measures to stem speculative currency trade in the local monetary markets.

The central bank unveiled the measures in response to President Lee Teng-hui's recent call for more rigorous regulatory mechanisms for securities and futures markets and a closer monitoring of the flow of foreign capital.

CBC Governor Peng Hui-nan told a news conference that the CBC will refer to taxation authorities a list of individual and institutional customers who have purchased a large amount of the US dollar or other foreign currencies. "The information will be useful for probing possible tax evasion by those clients," Peng said.
Moreover, Peng said, the central banks will take steps to control supply of the New Taiwan dollar capital to institutions which have been involved in speculative currency trade.
The central bank will also tighten regulation and monitoring of the figureheads used by foreign speculators to speculate on the NT dollar's exchange rate against the greenback in May, Peng said.

Meanwhile, Peng said, the central bank will require local banks to make immediate reports of large greenback purchase deals to facilitate the CBC's monitoring. The large greenback purchase deals refer to those whose trading amount exceeds US$50,000 each.
This was the first time that the central bank has made public its measures to curb speculation on the NT dollar's exchange rate.

Peng would not predict whether the NT dollar will rise against the US dollar in the second half of this year or not. He instead said the NT dollar's exchange rate will be determined by market mechanism.
Peng further said the central bank will consider further lowering the bank reserve requirements only when the local commodity prices and the NT dollar's exchange rate remain stable.

The senior banker also called on all Asian countries to cooperate and coordinate closely to maintain stability of their currencies. "Otherwise, Asia's economic outlook will become even gloomier in the years ahead," Peng said.
He also reiterated his hope that the mainland Chinese currency will not be depreciated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories of Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The China Times: 480,000 small stores to be free of business tax.
The United Daily News: A Fuhsing Township councilor killed.
The Central Daily News: The Central Bank of China will join hand with the Finance Ministry to stabilize interest rate and local currency.
The Liberty Times: The Central Bank of China adopting measures to stop speculation in foreign exchange market.
The Independence Morning Post: a Fuhsing Township councilor murdered.
The Common Daily: US said to force Taiwan into negotiating table.
The China Post: The Central Bank of China stresses the need to prevent foreign currency speculation.
The China News: Computer Found in examination scandal may contain clues.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC TO CONVERT DEUTSCHE MARKS TO EURO

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) will convert its foreign exchange holdings in deutsche marks to the Euro, the new single currency that will be launched in the European Union (EU) early next year.

CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said recently the CBC will make the change after the Euro is officially introduced in January 1998. He also predicted that the Euro will become a strong currency favored by investors around the world in the future.
The CBC had US$83.2 billion worth of foreign exchange reserves as of the end of June, about one quarter of which is held in deutsche marks.

Currently, the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department has set up a task force to assess the possible impact the Euro may have on the world economy and to study relevant monetary and forex policies for the CBC's reference.
According to the EU's central bank, the Euro will freely circulate within the EU member states in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL URGES CAUTION IN CROSS-STRAIT DEALINGS

TEXT.P: Taiwan must be more cautious in its dealings with mainland China as Beijing has intensified its efforts to entice the island's population, an official in charge of cross-strait affairs said on Sunday.

Wu Hsin-hsing, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said the government must be very careful in its dealings with the mainland because Beijing authorities are now seeking to ruin Taiwan from the inside.
Wu made the remarks at an academic seminar sponsored by the ROC Public Administration Association. He stressed that he was speaking in his capacity as a scholar and not as a government official.
He said the mainstream opinions of the Taiwan people regarding cross-strait exchanges included the following major characteristics:
-- Taiwan people think mainland China is not friendly toward Taiwan;
-- Taiwan people prefer to maintain the status-quo regarding cross-strait exchanges;
-- Taiwan people do not support imminent declaration of independence or unification with mainland China;
-- Taiwan people hope for an improvement in cross-strait ties and a peaceful co-existence across the Taiwan Strait;
-- Taiwan people are opposed to Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification formula; and
-- Taiwan people support the government's "no haste, be patient" policy governing local investment in the mainland.

Although Beijing is trying to use every means possible to isolate Taiwan in the international community, Wu said Taiwan must continue to "reach out" to build greater strength and get bargaining chips for future negotiations with mainland China.

The SEF official, however, called on the public to be careful of the mainland's increased efforts to entice them. Beijing recently held a meeting on Taiwan and decided to shift its focus to a "united front" strategy with the Taiwan public, he noted.

As the state of hostility has not ended between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and cross-strait exchanges are more and more frequent, Wu warned that Taiwan must be more cautious against mainland China's attempt to take advantage of its character as a free society to disintegrate it.
Wu suggested that the government take concrete measures to build a national consensus on national security and unity, since national security takes precedence to all issues.

The SEF official also repeated that Taiwan and mainland China should first resume talks on technical issues, such as joint efforts to crack down on crime and the signing of accords to protect Taiwan business interest and travel safety in the mainland.
The SEF is Taiwan's semi-official body in charge of negotiations and exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official contact between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PRIVATE MANUFACTURING INVESTMENT SLUGGISH

TEXT.P: Investment in Taiwan's domestic manufacturing industries was sluggish while makers of electronic parts and components significantly reduced the amount of investments put into upgrading equipment, a recent survey indicated.

A total of NT$108.84 billion (US$3.14 billion) was invested into upgrading equipment in 1998 compared to NT$111.68 billion recorded in the same period last year, a survey by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) indicated.

The decline was mostly attributed to the semiconductor industry as several large manufacturers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., postponing their plans for business expansion, DGBAS officials said.

The officials noted that the sector's reluctance to invest would lead to a reduction in growth of Taiwan's private manufacturing investments to 14.7 percent in the last half of this year based on projections.

According to the DGBAS survey of domestic investment projects, in July about NT$332.1 billion worth of investments is expected to be put into the manufacturing sector by surveyed businesses. This figure registers a 2.3 percent annual growth, but is down from January's figure by 20 percent.

However, despite the weakened investment environment, the DGBAS predicted that Taiwan's annual growth in private investments will hit 19.7 percent this year. The two-digit rise is mainly attributed to increased textile investment resulting in the sector's expanding production capability, DGBAS officials said.

The DGBAS's July survey showed that domestic investment in the electronic parts and components industry for the construction of facilities was estimated to reach NT$11.14 billion in 1998, down 64.3 percent from the previous year.
In the sector of electrical engineering, the money to be injected into construction projects is expected to be NT$197.36 billion this year, down 49.2 percent from 1997, the survey said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIMEX PROMOTES FUTURES TRADING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's mercantile exchange authority is planning incentives to promote institutional and individual investment in Taiwan's stock index futures.
More than 82,000 investors have opened accounts to take part in futures trading between July 21, the debut of the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX), to Aug. 13, statistics showed.

The number of investors is expected to break the 100,000-mark in August, TAIMEX Secretary-General Hsiao Fang-ming said, adding that the exchange is planning to give an award to the 100,000th account opener in the hopes of further promoting trade on the exchange.

Daily transactions on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures, or TAIEX Index Futures, have increased to more than 500 contracts from 195 on July 21, according to TAIMEX.
TAIMEX Chairman Lin Hsiao-tah estimated that the transactions will reach to 8,000 to 10,000 contracts by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-PANAMA TRADE INCREASING
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 15 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Trade between Taiwan and Panama is increasing at a steady pace, Chen Ming-shi, an economics counselor at the Republic of China Embassy to Panama said Saturday.

Taiwan exported US$200 million worth of products to Panama during the first half of this year, up 6 percent from the same period last year. Imports from Panama were valued at US$3 million in the six-month period, up 400 percent, Chen said.

The imports were mostly aquatic products and hand-made art works, Chen said. He noted that a trade fair will be held in Taipei from Jan. 31 to Feb. 2 to introduce goods from ROC allied countries, including Panama, to the Taiwan public.
Last year, two-way trade between Taiwan and Panama amounted to US$401 million, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of over US$30 million, according to the ROC embassy.

To help Panama's industrial development, experts from Taiwan have held six conferences on the development of small- and medium-sized enterprises in the Latin American country, Chen indicated. He also mentioned that Panama and Taiwan signed an agreement on technology cooperation last Aug. 1.
In the near future, five Taiwan experts in food processing will visit Panama to help upgrade local production.

Chen said Taipei will also soon sign an agreement to offer US$10 million loans for Panamanian small- and medium-sized enterprises, while at the same time the ROC government will invite Panamanian officials in trade and industrial affairs to visit Taiwan to learn about the island's successful economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRISIS WILL BRING SINGAPOREANS CLOSER TOGETHER: LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: The troublesome times Singaporeans and the government face ahead will lead to stronger ties if the two sides are united in standing up against the economic crisis, Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew said Saturday.
He noted that the turmoil in the region sparked by the economic downturn was the most serious crisis Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong and his team have faced since Goh took charge in 1990.
"It is the duty of leaders to instill confidence in the people so that they will stand up to be counted, otherwise all is lost," Lee said at a National Day dinner celebration.

"When together they fight against all odds and win, a bond will be forged between people and leaders, like the deep unshakable feeling of trust between an army and its generals who have been in battle," Lee said.
He likened this to the bond between leaders of his generation and people who during the 1960s fought against communism, communalism, confrontation and the withdrawal of the British troops.
Turning to the economy, Lee said as the "resource-poorest country in the region", Singapore can not afford to be anything other than honest, efficient and capable if it were to stay out of trouble.
To maintain Singapore's competitiveness, costs would have to be kept down, he said. A budget deficit was possible not only next year, but also in 2000, he added.
All major infrastructure projects would have to be brought forward, even if they might not be needed immediately, to generate increased economic activity, he said.
Despite the troubled times ahead, Lee said he was confident Singaporeans will pull through if they keep their nerve and stay on a safe and steady course.
"We have lived through more perilous days when we had less resources, and we made it," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE CANADIANS PETITION CHRETIEN OVER INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Over 200 Chinese Canadians demonstrated in Ottawa Saturday to protest against the savage treatment of ethnic Chinese in Indonesia during that country's May riots.
The Chinese community, supported by other Canadians, urged Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien to strongly condemn the violation of human rights in Indonesia.

In a petition signed by 1,600 people, the Federation of Ottawa-Carleton Chinese organizations asked the Chretien government to press Jakarta to conduct a thorough investigation into the racial attacks and punish those found responsible.
In the middle of the two-hour rally at Parliament Hill, two community leaders were escorted by police into the Center Bloc to submit the petition letter.

Anton Cheng and Fred Wong were greeted by the security and intelligence officer of the Prime Minister's Office, Burnie Bougesis, who received the signed petition and promised to pass it onto Chretien on Monday.

"We, as Canadian citizens and citizens of the world, do not wish to enter the next millennium with claims of progress in civilization if we continue to ignore, or allow atrocities to continue against our fellow human beings," the federation said in its petition.
Last Saturday, more than 500 Chinese Canadians staged an angry but peaceful rally in front of the Indonesian Embassy in Ottawa to protest crimes of violence against Chinese Indonesians.

During days of rioting which toppled President Suharto's regime, many Chinese Indonesians were targeted in the looting and burning of property, as well as violent assaults, reports said. Hundreds of Chinese Indonesian women and girls, some as young as 10 years old, were said to have been sexually assaulted and brutally gang raped. Some of these victims were burned alive or murdered.
All these crimes were allegedly committed by organized gangs with links to Indonesia's security forces, the federation noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS WARN OF JAPAN'S SUPPORT FOR 'THREE NOES'

TEXT.P: Taipei should prepare to counteract against Tokyo's possible commitment to mainland China's "three noes" demand with regard to Taiwan, academics at a seminar on Sunday said.

The seminar, sponsored by the Chinese Culture Association, was held to discuss mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's coming visit to Japan where he is scheduled to meet with Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.

During a recent trip to Beijing, Japanese Foreign Minister Masahito Komura reportedly reached an agreement with mainland authorities on the framework of a new joint communique on bilateral ties to be announced during Jiang's visit early next month, according to Taiwan newspapers.

The news has prompted widespread concern here that Jiang will use the occasion to seek Japan's verbal or written commitment to Beijing's "three noes" regarding Taiwan -- no support for an independent Taiwan, no support for "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership into world bodies for which statehood is a requirement.
Pang Shih-tang, a mainland affairs professor at the Tamkang University, said Jiang will use his September visit to pressure Tokyo into signing a third communique on the "three noes."

Although Japan is not expected to jeopardize Taiwan's interests in clinching such an agreement with mainland China, Taipei must relay its position on the issue to Tokyo through proper channels, Pang said.
Taiwan would welcome Jiang's planned visit to Japan if the purpose of the trip were solely to strengthen Tokyo-Beijing ties and to find ways to fight the Asian financial crisis, he added.

However, Jiang's visit is aimed at "something extra," Pang said, adding that Jiang will undoubtedly seek to build a closer Beijing-Tokyo relationship. Jiang is aware that a closer, long-term strategical partnership with Japan will help him in the Washington-Tokyo-Beijing relationship, the professor said.

Chang Ling-cheng, a political science professor at the National Taiwan University, said Jiang will pressure Japan to voice at least verbal support for the "three noes" now that the United States and the Philippines have done so.
The government should pay greater heed to the possible adverse effect on Taiwan, she warned.
Echoing this view, Fu Jen Catholic University Professor Liang Chung-min said he thinks Tokyo will give way to Beijing and sign a new joint communique on the "three noes."
Liang also expressed concern that Beijing is already trying to undermine a number of the ROC's diplomatic partners, which he said is something that the government must deal with properly.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHOLERA OUTBREAK IN FLOODED AREA IN CHINA REPORTED

TEXT.P: A Hong Kong newspaper reported Sunday that there is a cholera outbreak in certain villages in the Saichenghu area of Jiujiang County in Jiangxi Province, which has been hard hit by Yangtz River flooding in recent weeks.

The Ming Pao Daily News reported that its reporters covering news of flooding in Jiujiang have found small newly-established anti-epidemic stations and smelt the strong odor of antiseptic solutions in those villages, and that local officials have cordoned off the villages.

The report also said that the Saichenghu area is now inundated by deep water, that villagers get around by small boats, and that a boat owner said he had taken antibiotics to protect himself from the infectious disease. The boat owner also said that in the area there is an outbreak of cholera, which is dubbed "the number two disease" by officials.

The State Council of mainland China has recently urged people in flooded areas to prevent the spread of such infectious diseases as cholera and malaria, the report said. Doctors at the anti-epidemic stations in Saichenghu have repeatedly said that the outbreak of cholera is now under control and that reporters may call it "suspected cases of cholera," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOOD VICTIMS IN CHINA COMPLAIN ABOUT FOOD SHORTAGE: REPORT

TEXT.P: Villagers living near Jiujiang in Jiangxi Province have reportedly complained about food shortage after officials dumped 800 tons of wheat and soy beans into water to protect broken dikes on Yangtz River near the city on Aug. 5.

The Ming Pao Daily News of Hong Kong Sunday quoted a Jiujiang official as saying that the annual revenue of the city is less than 100 million yuan (US$12.1 million), but city officials dumped as much as 800 tons of grains into the river.
The Beijing-based Xinhua News Agency has reported that rocks and car loads of soy beans and wheat were dumped into the river on Aug. 5 to protect the broken dikes from further damage.

The report said that many people in Jiangzhou and Xinzhou in suburban Jiujiang were killed in the floods after the dikes were broken, and that what the survivors are most worried about is food shortage.

The report quoted the survivors as saying that the local government has only distributed to each villager a few anti-septic pills, two bottles of drinking water, and four packs of instant noodle so far.
Jiujiang is one of the five provinces in central mainland China ravaged by flooding this summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: INBOUND AND OUTBOUND TRAVEL DECLINES

TEXT.P: Both inbound and outbound travel to and from Taiwan declined in July, the Tourism Bureau reported over the weekend.
Taiwan travelers made a total of 587,600 overseas trips in July, a decrease of 10.2 percent from the same period in 1997, the bureau said.

Travel by Taiwan visitors to the United States posted the smallest decline of 3.7 percent in terms of the number of trips made in July. Travel to Asian and European destinations dropped by 10.6 percent and 12.4 percent, respectively. Visits by Taiwan tourists to Australia, New Zealand, and the Oceania region fell by 13.1 percent.
Taiwan travel to Indonesia dropped by nearly 50 percent from a year ago, while travel to Malaysia, Singapore, the Philippines, South Korea, and Thailand all shrank noticeably, the bureau said.

The number of Taiwan travelers who went abroad in the first seven months of this year declined by 7.4 percent from last year, while the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan in the January-July period dropped by 7.7 percent from the same period last year.
The bureau said people are choosing domestic travel over overseas visits as business conditions remain sluggish in almost every sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Council for Economic Planning and Development integrates all economic stimulus plans.
The China Times: Taiwan's nine-year compulsory education system will undergo sweeping changes in three years' time.
The United Daily News: The ROC and the United States will sign a judicial assistance agreement.
The Liberty Times: The ROC threatens to cut cross-strait exchanges if visitors from China fail to respect its national flag.
The Independence Morning Post: Fifth- and sixth-grade students at elementary schools will be required to study English.
The Commons Daily: The Cabinet will hold a meeting on Monday to discuss restructuring of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau and adjustment of the focus of its functions.
The China Post: The Ministry of Education plans to cut classroom hours for elementary and junior high school students.
The China News: US President Bill Clinton is likely to admit to "affairs."

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA-PACIFIC OPERATIONS CENTER PLAN BEARING FRUIT, THINK-TANK SAYS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's plan to develop itself into an operations center in the Asia Pacific region has begun to pay off, an economic think-tank said Monday.

Since its inception two-and-a-half years ago, the Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center (APROC) has helped increase Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) by 1.65 percentage points, increased two-way trade by 0.7 percentage points, and expanded investment capital by 2.24 percentage points, said the private Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER).

The APROC plan, kicked off in 1995, is scheduled to be carried out in the following three stages: 1995-1997, 1997-2000, and 2000-2005. The plan hopes to establish regional operations centers for manufacturing, shipping, air transportation, banking, telecommunications, and mass media by 2005.

In its first stage of implementation, the APROC plan has led government departments to amend 39 relevant bills, devise 90 new administrative orders, and complete revisions to 35 administrative policies in order to promote free trade and investment, bring down barriers on professional personnel and capital movement, and facilitate the movement of information.

In a review of the APROC implementation after the plan entered its second stage, the CIER, at the request of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), found that the project has contributed significantly to the country's overall economic growth in the last two-and-a-half years.

CEPD officials attributed the achievement to deregulation of government restrictions, privatization of state-own enterprises, acceleration of government efficiency, and the inflow of capital, all developments reportedly brought about by the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD, MOFA HEADS TO VISIT CENTRAL AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 16 (CNA) (By M. H. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang and Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu will lead a delegation to visit two nations in Central America next week.
Chiang will preside over a seminar regarding the ROC sharing its experiences in economic development with Central American countries in San Salvador, the capital city of El Salvador, on Aug. 25.
Foreign ministers, including Hu, and economic ministers from El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica will also be in attendance.

Other members of the ROC delegation will include Leo Tsang, director general of the Department of Economic & Trade Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), and Francisco Hwang, director general of MOFA's Department of Central & South American Affairs.
Four officials from Taiwan's President Group will also travel with the delegation, and they will explore the possibility of investing in electrical power plants in Central America.
Chiang and Hu will then travel to Guatemala to preside over a meeting of ROC diplomats stationed in Central and Southern America from Aug. 26-27 before returning to Taipei on Aug. 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOURISTS STILL HEADING TO INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Y. P. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan tourists are still choosing to travel to Indonesia despite recent news reports that renewed anti-Chinese violence may break out Monday.

A group of 61 Taiwan tourists flew into Jakarta on Sunday and stayed in a hotel not far from the city's center, a local newspaper reported. Some of these tourists bought their children along with them and did not seem concerned about their safety, the paper noted.

A Taiwan tourist surnamed Lin was quoted as saying he was not worried about his personal safety while traveling in Indonesia because the country badly needs tourism revenue to revive its ailing economy.
Lin, who is traveling with his family, added that he thinks Indonesians are quite friendly toward foreign visitors, the paper said.
