DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NATIONALS IN KINSHASA EVACUATED TO GABONESE REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Eight of the 10 Republic of China nationals in the strife-torn Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) have been evacuated to the neighboring Gabonese Republic, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Monday.

"The two staff members of the ROC representative office in Kinshasa and six ROC expatriates in the DRC's capital arrived in Gabon via a leased small commercial plane early this morning," Wu said in response to a press inquiry.
Wu said the evacuees, including Hsiao Kuang-yu, chief of the ROC mission in Kinshasa, arrived in Libreville, capital of the Gabonese Republic, at 7 a.m. Monday (Taipei time.)

The seven other evacuees were Hsu Kai-ping, secretary of the ROC mission in Kinshasa, and six citizens identified as Chiang-Chen Ling-hua, Hsu Mei-lan, Chan Kai-wen, Chan Kai-yi, Chan Kai-yueh (a 3-month-old baby boy) and Hsu Sung-hung.
Wu said through the arrangement of the ROC representative office in the DRC, ROC expatriates in Gabon greeted Hsiao and the other evacuees from Kinshasa at Libreville's international airport.

Most of the evacuees are scheduled to return to Taipei in the near future, Wu said, adding that two other ROC nationals -- Chiang San-lung and Chan Chia-fa -- were unwilling to leave the DRC and are still in Kinshasa.
Diplomatic sources said the Belgian embassy in Kinshasa originally agreed to allow ROC nationals onto its chartered flight leaving the DRC.
As gunshots were heard in Kinshasa on Sunday, a large number of expatriates from Belgium, France and other European Union (EU) member states swarmed the Kinshasa International Airport.
The Belgian embassy then told the ROC mission that it had to back away from its promise to transport ROC nationals because it was required to evacuate Belgian, French and other EU expatriates first.

With the situation in the DRC worsening, the ROC mission decided to rent a small commercial aircraft to evacuate its expatriates to Gabon, diplomatic sources said, adding that the ROC government will assume the evacuation costs.

According to foreign wire service reports, a coalition of Tutsi rebels, Rwandan soldiers and disgruntled members of President Laurent Kabila's army had captured the western Congo river port town of Matadi and are fighting to take up positions closer to Kinshasa.

The DRC was previously known as Zaire. The ROC first established diplomatic relations with Zaire in 1960, but cut such ties in early 1973 after the French-speaking central African state switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in late 1972.

In June 1991, the ROC signed an agreement with Zaire on the exchange of representative offices. The ROC's representative office in Kinshasa was inaugurated in July 1991. Zaire changed its national title to the Republic of Congo in May 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAKISTAN PM TRAVELS TO BEIJING FOR NUCLEAR TALKS

TEXT.P: Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will travel to Beijing Monday for a two-day visit, an Indian newspaper reported Sunday from Islamabad.

The Indian Express, a New Delhi-based English daily, reported that during his stay in Beijing, Sharif is expected to meet mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to discuss matters relating to the signing of a nuclear test ban and a non-proliferation agreement.
Sharif has reportedly been promised financial aid and other assistance to help Pakistan face US sanctions to be imposed due to Pakistani nuclear tests in late May.
The prime minister is expected to explain Pakistan's refusal to sign the two international treaties, and will likely ask Beijing to give more financial aid.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODS THROW BEIJING LEADERS INTO PROPAGANDA OVERDRIVE

TEXT.P: Human forces fighting the massive floods along the Yangtze River are in a losing battle as Beijing leaders are claiming victory, The Times of India reported from Hong Kong Sunday.

The daily noted that the mainland's top three officials, President Jiang Zemin, National People's Congress Chairman Li Peng, and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, have all been shown on state television visiting flood stricken areas during the last few days.

Their visits, like most of the coverage of the floods in China, "are all being placed in the context of a glorious victory being won against the Yangtze by the forces assembled by the Chinese Communist Party", the New Delhi-based English daily reported.
About a million People's Liberation Army soldiers, or roughly one-third of its combat strength, have been fighting the forces of nature but are almost certain to lose the battle, the paper said.
Downplaying the damages of the massive floods, said to be the worst since 1954, is self-defeating and makes little sense, the report noted.

Predictions on the disaster's effect on the country's economic growth have been vastly understated, as is the official death toll of 2,000, The Times of India said. In the floods of 1954, an estimated 30,000 people lost their lives and 30 million people were effected.
With the rains unlikely to cease before October, the daily estimated that the damage and dislocation of people brought about by the floods will have a "lasting impact well into 1999 and even beyond."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LARGEST MUSHROOM HITS SUPERMARKET SHELVES

TEXT.P: A new species of indigenous edible mushroom has been successfully developed by the Taiwan Agriculture Research Institute (TARI) and is being commercially cultivated by farmers in central Taiwan.

The Chinfu mushroom, the island's largest fungus recently put on supermarket shelves for a trial run, is in hot demand despite its high price tag of NT$1,000 (US$29) a kilogram, sources from the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday.
The tasty and fleshy fungus was produced after TARI began researching seven agarics of this species -- tricholoma giganteum in academic terms -- since 1994.
Commercial cultivation began this year, enabling the large fungus, which reportedly tastes like chicken, to be marketed as an ordinary vegetable, COA officials said.

The chinfu mushroom, a genetic-revised species of Taiwan's indigenous tricholoma giganteum, is also one of the largest fungi species in the world. Unlike other species of mushrooms, the chinfu has a small cap and a large thick stalk. Because its stalk tastes like chicken meat and can be shredded and cooked like shredded chicken meat, the fungus is also called "the shredded chicken mushroom."

A clump of the fungus, also called "the king's mushroom" by the Japanese, can be as large as one kilogram with individual stems as thick as a ball-point pen. It stands at an average of 20-centimeters high.

The chinfu mushroom is promising to become a new savior to Taiwan's beleaguered mushroom farmers hit by slow exports and the promise of Taiwan's World Trade Organization bid which will allow the import of foreign-grown mushrooms into the island, COA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SITUATION IN INDONESIA QUIET AMID UNREST RUMORS: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Monday that the situation in Indonesia was quiet amid fears of unrest on the nation's Independence Day.
MOFA spokesperson Roy Wu made the remarks after the ministry contacted the ROC's representative office in Jakarta in the morning.

The office reported that the Indonesian government, paying heed to unrest rumors, sent 15,000 troops and police to patrol the Indonesian capital. The situation is under control and no incidents have been reported, it added.

MOFA has instructed the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta, the de facto ROC embassy in Indonesia, to be on guard and maintain regular contact with the Indonesian government, overseas Chinese groups, and Taiwan businessmen to ensure the safety of ROC nationals.
MOFA officials said ROC Representative Lu Pao-sun and Deputy Representative Chang Yung-lang have been invited to attend festivities marking the independence of Indonesia.

Rumors of fresh unrest circulated as the national holiday approached, leading many in Jakarta to leave the city particularly those among the ethnic Chinese community which has been the target of violence and looting in the past.
Meanwhile, ROC financial officials said exports to Indonesia decreased in the first seven months of this year.

They said exports to Indonesia in the first seven months totaled US$601.1 million, down US$657.7 million, or 52.2 percent from the same period last year. Meanwhile imports from Indonesia totaled US$1.21 billion during the same period, down US$56.2 million, or 4.4 percent form the same period last year.
The officials said after the unrest broke out in May, exports to Indonesia dropped to US$66.9 million in July alone.
They added that since the riots, which eventually toppled former President Suharto, local ethnic Chinese have moved out of Indonesia and investments by Taiwan businessmen also dropped significantly.
If there is fresh unrest, the recovery of Taiwan's trade with Indonesia to earlier levels may take longer, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUHARTO SHOULD BE HELD RESPONSIBLE FOR ATROCITIES: PROTESTERS

TEXT.P: Protesters gathered in front of the Indonesian Embassy in Canberra Monday demanding that former Indonesian President Suharto be tried for the atrocities committed against ethnic Chinese during the May riots.
The over 130 protesters included migrants from Taiwan, Hong Kong, mainland China, Indonesia and other Southeast Asian countries as well as academics from several Australian universities.
Rain dampened some spirits as organizers expected a much larger turnout. Another rally of about 1,000 people was called off because of the continued rain.

Several of the rally's speakers accused the Indonesian government of not protecting the ethnic Chinese during the May riots, in which 168 Chinese women, including a nine year old, were reportedly gang-raped, molested and some killed, while many others suffered massive property losses after their houses and shops were looted and burned down.

Rally speaker Beverly Hong, senior lecturer at the Australian National University, accused the Indonesian government of targeting ethnic Chinese as scapegoats during the May riots after Jakarta was unable to resolve its financial and economic problems.

Dr. Wang Hua, chairman of the Federation of Chinese Community in Canberra, said, "Today, we are here not to celebrate the independence of Indonesia, we are here to voice our anger and outrage over the rape, killing and massive destruction of property of ethnic Chinese Indonesians in the Jakarta riots during May 13-14."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF URGES ARATS TO TREAT EACH OTHER WITH RESPECT

TEXT.P: A senior official with the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said on Monday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should treat each other with respect.

SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow made the appeal in response to a newspaper report that Li Yafei, deputy secretary-general of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), demanded the removal of an ROC national flag in a conference room during his July 24-31 visit.

The Liberty Times said in a front-page article that Li asked Ken Jung-shui, secretary-general of the Taipei-based Great Wall Cultural Foundation, to remove an ROC flag in the press briefing room in the management office of the Kenting National Park on the southernmost tip of the island on July 30.
Without the permission of the Kenting park management office, the paper said, Ken moved the flag to the office's storage house next to the press room.
The paper quoted unnamed government sources as saying that if similar incidents were to take place again, the government will consider suspending exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Commenting on the report, Shi said he still does not have the full details about incident. "I'll look into the case to gain a better understanding," he said.
Shi also expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will engage with each other with a healthy attitude.
"We look forward to seeing SEF and ARATS staff members treat each other with respect and avoid taking any actions that will embarrass the other side," Shi stressed.

As to whether Ken's actions constituted an offense to the Criminal Code, which stipulates that no person is be permitted to insult the country's national flag, Shi said he is not in a position to comment on the issue. "It's up to law enforcement authorities to make a judgment," he added.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS URGE STRATEGY TO DEAL WITH OBUCHI-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Taipei should work out a comprehensive strategy to minimize the impact of mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan in September, local academics said Monday.
The remarks were made in a public hearing hosted by Legislator Chen Hung-chi of the ruling Kuomintang at the Legislative Yuan.
Chen called the public hearing amid concerns that Beijing will push Tokyo to codify the so-called "three noes" toward Taiwan while Jiang is in Japan.
According to press reports, Tokyo and Beijing will sign a third joint communique during Jiang's visit expressing their intention to forge a long-term strategic relationship.

Although Japan has reportedly yet to decide whether to include Beijing's "three noes" into the joint communique, Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi is likely to throw verbal support behind the "three noes" in his speech at a welcoming party for Jiang, the reports said.

Hsieh Shen-chan, president of the Japanese Studies Association of the Republic of China, said that due to its geographic proximity, Japan is more concerned over the mainland China and more cautious in its exchanges with Beijing than the United States or European countries.
He believed that the Obuchi-Jiang meeting will not go beyond the Clinton-Jiang meeting, and that the "three noes" policy will not be spelled out.

Liang Chung-min, associate professor of Fu Jen Catholic University, said Taiwan must step up its diplomatic efforts in all directions and work out separate approaches to countries that have and do not have diplomatic ties with the ROC.

He said civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Japan are friendly, but national interests should take precedence over civilian interests. The ROC has to think of what Tokyo may do from the viewpoint of Japan's national interests.

Pan Hsi-tan of Tamkang University said there could be three possible outcomes of Jiang's meeting with Obuchi. One is the written support of the "three noes," verbal support for the policy, or neither a written nor verbal support for the policy.

Japan may follow US foreign policy and make a verbal support to the "three noes," Pan said, adding that as Japan is seeking a permanent seat in the United Nations' Security Council, its attitude is clear.
He urged the government to map out a strategy and prepare very cautiously for the Obuchi-Jiang meeting.
If the "three noes" policy is written down on paper, it could cast a shadow over the high-level talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait scheduled for October, Pan said.

In such an event, the cross-strait talks may be postponed further as the ROC may think Beijing still harbors hostility toward the island, and the ROC may fall into Beijing's trap if it resumes talks too soon, he added.

The "three noes" came into the limelight after US President Bill Clinton mentioned them at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai during his recent mainland visit. The "three noes" refer to no support for an independent Taiwan, no support for "two Chinas" or a "one Taiwan, one China," and no support for Taiwan's bid to enter international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI'S ARTICLE REPRINTED IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: An article written by Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui was reprinted in the opinion page of The Japan Times, Japan's largest English daily newspaper Monday.

In the original article, which appeared in the Asian Wall Street Journal titled "Taiwan's path to a democratic China," President Lee reminded US President Bill Clinton that the ROC's economic miracle and its democratization are examples of how Chinese people can have a better life with a market economy, and how traditional Chinese culture is compatible with democracy, freedom and human rights.

Lee refuted accusations by the mainland and others in the west that the ROC is carrying out a campaign for "Taiwan independence" or "two Chinas" -- one China, one Taiwan -- saying that this was a total distortion of the truth.

"What we on Taiwan have done all along is preserve, for China, a piece of land that is free from communist rule," Lee wrote, "We have developed the economy and have embraced democracy, becoming the model for a future reunified China."

"We believe that the very existence of a democratic and prosperous Taiwan gives the people in mainland China and Hong Kong greater hope for a democratic way of life," Lee said, adding "We also believe that China must reunify in the future, but that it must be reunified under a democratic system."

"The people on Taiwan cannot accept the undemocratic 'one country, two systems' arrangement, and we cannot abandon our 87 years of history and 52 years as a constitutional sovereign country and turn ourselves into a local government," Lee pointed out.

Asking Taiwan to meet all its responsibilities while denying Taiwan's right to participate in international organizations, even to observe, makes a mockery of the ideas of a global community that pursues human rights and justice, Lee stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1% OF TAIWAN'S POLICE OWN MERCEDES, LEGISLATOR SAYS

TEXT.P: Nearly 1 percent of Taiwan's police force drive expensive German cars of Mercedes Benz, and about 80 percent of these cars are registered under the officers' own names, a ruling Kuomintang legislator said Monday.

Taichung County Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung, quoting a recent survey conducted by Kashide Taiwan, said that out of Taiwan's roughly 80,000 policemen, 767 of them drive Mercedes Benzes. The figure does not include officers with other models of imported luxury cars.

According to the survey, the number of police-owned Mercedes Benzes was particularly high in counties where businesses operate on the edge of legality. These included Yunlin, Changhua, Chiayi, Taipei and Taoyuan Counties, it said.

It is a phenomenon worthy of further study, said Hsu, given that it is almost impossible for a grass roots police officer making a monthly salary of NT$50,000-NT$60,000 (US$1,458-1,749) to buy a Mercedes Benz E220 worth NT$2.3 million (US$67,055) without other sources of income.
Officials from the National Police Administration were shocked by the revelation, saying that the agency will begin an investigation into the matter soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES EXCHANGE DROP

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 97.99 points to close at 7,273.85.
The bourse opened at 7,352.28 points, 19.56 lower than the previous trading session.
A total of 11.34 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$60.09 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only plastics and chemical shares, and construction stocks remained unchanged.

All other major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 2.7 percent, followed by pulp and paper shares at 1.2 percent, textile issues ate 1.1 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.7 percent, and cement stocks at 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock futures posted a general decline.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September moved down 81 points to close at 7,219, while those for October remained unchanged to close at 7,280. Futures for December increased 43 points to 7,481.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 308, four, and 15, respectively.
The TAIEX Index Futures for March moved down 111 point to close at 7,410, with 17 contract transactions. No transactions were registered for June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were listed as follows: 7,300 points for September; 7,280 for October; 7,438 for December; 7,521 for March; and 7,669 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC COMMENTS ON REPORTS OF JIANG'S REFORM PLANS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday a report on Beijing's plan to promote political reforms was denied by mainland authorities to prevent social uncertainty.

The Asian Wall Street Journal reported on its July 23 issue that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin ordered advisers and researchers at government-run think tanks to study the possibility of implementing various political reforms in the mainland, including establishing presidential elections and a multi-party system, separating the party from the army, and strengthening the rule of law.

The Beijing-based Chinese Academy of Social Science has officially denied the report, but the MAC, the highest government agency in charge of charting Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, said the denial may have been issued to prevent widespread social unrest resulting from increased public demand for political reforms in the mainland.

Increased economic and social developments in mainland China have forced Beijing leaders to face the people's call for democracy, a core issue which Beijing cannot ignore and dodge as a pluralistic society is emerging, the MAC analyzed.
The MAC offered four possible reasons why Jiang may be interested in introducing political reforms.

One reason is that following the recent riots and upheaval in Indonesia, Jiang must be aware that political reforms and the rule of law should be further boosted to crack down on corruption and inefficiency if mainland China is to become a genuine world power and establish a real market economy.

Another reason may be due to Jiang's confidence in his political base. Following his two summit meetings with US President Bill Clinton and the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China last fall, Jiang may think he has full control of the mainland's economics and politics. He may also believe that the mainland is now capable of enduring the impact of discussing issues related to human rights.

Also, Jiang may be trying to ensure continued political and economic development in mainland China by promoting political reforms step by step. Direct elections in some small villages have made the international community believe that mainland China is becoming a more open and pluralistic society.

Finally, in an effort to consolidate a legacy in the post-Deng era, Jiang may be seeking to stay in power longer by amending the constitution to allow him to serve a third four-year term as president. Jiang is scheduled to step down in 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: A DEVALUED RENMINBI WOULD BENEFIT TAIWAN & HK'S INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Wang Mann-na & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong investors in mainland China would be benefited by a devalued renminbi rather than be adversely effected, businessmen from the two sides said.

The continued reports and rumors about the possible devaluation of mainland China's currency has resulted in a common concern that it would effect Taiwan and Hong Kong's economies. However, this was dismissed by Taiwan and Hong Kong businesspeople investing in the mainland.

Goo Guomin, board member of a small- and medium-sized enterprises commercial association in Hong Kong, pointed out on Monday that Hong Kong's small- and medium-sized enterprises in the Chinese mainland have been focusing primarily on production and trade.

Therefore, if the Chinese currency were to be devalued while the Hong Kong dollar remained stable, it will be beneficial to Hong Kong investors, Goo said. This is because Hong Kong investors' businesses in the mainland are mostly engaged in importing raw materials which are re-exported after being processed.
If the renminbi were to be devalued, Goo said, there would be no loss incurred from the foreign exchange, instead, a cut in the expenditure of wages and rent of the plant would occur.

Taiwan investors are also largely engaged in this type of processing and re-exporting business. Due to concern over a possible devaluation of the renminbi, many Taiwan investors have exchanged their profits into Hong Kong dollars or US dollars which has recently resulted in a devaluation of the Chinese yuan on the black market.
Most Taiwan and Hong Kong investors in the mainland believe the devaluation of the renminbi will have a more psychological impact than one effecting businesses.

However, some Taiwan investors who have permission to sell domestically in the mainland, will be affected negatively. Nevertheless, these businesspeople accounted for only a small part of Taiwan investment interests in the mainland. Most investors from Taiwan and Hong Kong in the business of processing and re-exporting products would benefit if the renminbi were devalued.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, US MAY SIGN JUDICIAL ASSISTANCE PACT

TEXT.P: The United States is interested in signing a judiciary assistance agreement with the Republic of China, but it remains uncertain when such an accord can be formally sealed, a senior Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said on Monday.

MOJ Vice Minister Chiang Hao made the remarks in response to a newspaper report that the United States will send officials to Taipei next month to discuss a long-talked-about judicial assistance accord aimed at facilitating bilateral cooperation in fighting crimes.
The report also said the United States has sent a draft pact to Taipei and that the MOJ will call an inter-ministerial meeting to review the content of the US-drafted accord.

Commenting on the report, Chiang said the United States has expressed a desire to sign a judicial assistance pact with the ROC to lay out a framework for bilateral cooperation in cracking down on cross-border drug trafficking, money laundering and other criminal activities.
Nevertheless, Chiang said, it is still not clear when American representatives will come to Taipei to exchange views on related issues.

Meanwhile, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said the two countries have consistently cooperated in fighting cross-border criminal activities and have helped each other in accordance with their respective legal regulations.

Under the ROC's statute governing the handling of cases commissioned by foreign courts, Wu said, relevant government agencies can offer such assistance only in a limited number of fields and are subject to many complicated procedures.

With cross-border criminal activities, including drug trafficking, money laundering and computer hacking, becoming ever more rampant, Wu said the two sides have felt an increased urgency to sign a formal agreement to make it easier for expanded judiciary assistance to facilitate joint anti-crime operations.

As the signing of such an agreement involves many problems, Wu said, the two countries must prudently mull all related issues. "Bilateral consultations will continue to go ahead, but we do not have a timetable for concluding the discussion," he added.
According to the United Daily News, the United States agreed to send officials to Taipei in September to discuss guiding principles for the proposed accord at MOJ officials' request.

The paper quoted unidentified sources as saying that MOJ officials took advantage of their visit to Washington, D.C. early this month to attend an ROC-US sub-Cabinet-level meeting to discuss the issue with their counterparts from the US Department of Justice.

The paper further said the United States plans to brief Beijing authorities on its main purposes for signing the pact with the ROC in an effort to soften Beijing's opposition to the proposed Taipei-Washington accord.
As signing such a pact involves sovereignty issues, the paper said, Beijing has strongly opposed the plan.
The United States recognizes Beijing while maintaining close substantive ties with Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.035 against the greenback in Taipei Monday, closing at 34.761.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.712, and had a low of 34.79.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$159.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN MEDIA CALL FOR DIALOGUES ON XINJIANG ISSUE

TEXT.P: Radio Moscow reported on Friday in its Mandarin broadcasting that a Russian newspaper has said Moscow should "support" dialogues between Beijing officials and Xinjiang separatist movement leaders to help maintain stability in the region.

According to the broadcasting monitored here, the "Independence" newspaper said that separatist sentiments in Xinjiang is "very strong," and that leaders of Russia and mainland China are paying close attention to the situations there. The Uygurs in Xinjiang demand separation from mainland China and want to establish an "East Turkistan" state.

The newspaper said Russia doesn't want the situation in Central Asia to become volatile. Therefore, Moscow should support "peaceful dialogues" between Beijing leaders and Xinjiang separatists, and help promote economic development in the region for the welfare of all the people living there.

The newspaper also said that Moscow should condemn terrorist activities in Xinjiang, criticize Beijing and its local government in Xinjiang for violation of human rights and the economic and political freedoms of the people living there, and scold those "foreign forces" that are trying to make troubles in the region.

The broadcasting also said that some Muslim countries are holding sympathy for the Xinjiang separatists. Saudi Arabia, for example, "often gives money and ideas to the separatists in Xinjiang," the radio station said in the broadcasting.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCIDENCE OF DEPRESSION HIGH AMONG WOMEN WITH BREAST CANCER

TEXT.P: About half of women recently diagnosed with breast cancer suffered from some kind of psychiatric disorder such as depression or anxiety, according to a new survey in Melbourne.
The survey of 303 women who were in the early stages of breast cancer found that 42 percent had some form of psychiatric disorder, according to David Kissane of the Melbourne University.
The incidents of psychiatric disorder are almost twice the rate of mental illness found in an average population as identified by official statistics released earlier this year.
"Our findings indicate that psychological morbidity, particularly depression, is substantially greater in women with breast cancer," Kissane said.

He said doctors should be alerted to the ever-present possibility of psychological problems in women with breast cancer and that mental health assessments and therapy should be a consistent part of medical care.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-FILIPINOS PROTEST ANTI-CHINESE ATROCITIES IN INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Sun Ting-wu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 4,000 Chinese-Filipinos gathered on Monday in front of the Indonesian Embassy in Manila to protest the atrocities against ethnic Chinese women in Indonesia's May riots.

Angry roars burst from the throats of the protesters, who demanded that the Indonesian authorities punish those responsible for the rapes and killings of ethnic Chinese residents, compensate the victims, and improve the treatment of ethnic Chinese living in the Southeast Asian nation.

A leader of the protest group, composed of members of Christian, Muslim, Buddhist, human rights, and ethnic Chinese organizations, delivered a letter of protest to embassy authorities, asking for a full investigation into the anti-Chinese atrocities, a comprehensive compensation policy, and legal protection for all minorities in Indonesia, including Chinese.

The group also called for global economic sanctions against Indonesia, where racism against ethnic Chinese has simmered for many years. At the same time, it urged international financial institutions, including the International Monetary Fund, World Bank, and Asian Development Bank, not to offer economic aid to Indonesia until it has improved its treatment of ethnic Chinese.

Nearly 200 ethnic Chinese women were reported raped or murdered in the social unrest in May which led to the downfall of former President Suharto. Numerous Chinese-owned houses and buildings were ransacked and burned.

The "ethnic cleansing" atrocities have been blamed mainly on the collapsed economy caused by the Asian financial meltdown. Although the ethnic Chinese population in Indonesia accounts for just 4 percent of the population, it controls much of the country's economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER ATTENDS ROC-PHILIPPINE ECONOMIC CONFERENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Bear Lee, Leah Lai and Timothy Sun)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang arrived in Manila on Monday at the head of a 33-member Taiwan delegation for the 1998 joint economic cooperation conference between Taiwan and the Philippines.
During the two-day meeting, which will open on Tuesday, the two sides will discuss bilateral cooperation in the fields of trade, investment, tourism, labor, technology, and agriculture.
Wang said that he will propose at the meeting that the Philippines allow foreign investors to enjoy sole business ownership, and allow foreign nationals to own land for industrial use.

He further said he will also ask the Philippines to support Taiwan's bid to become a dialogue partner of the Association of Southeast Nations (ASEAN), to establish a reasonable brokerage system for its export of laborers to Taiwan, and to improve its management of the Subic Bay Industrial Park, in which Taiwan is a major investor.
The Philippines is one of Taiwan's major sources of foreign labor, with more than 100,000 Filipinos currently working on the island.

The annual conference, first held in 1992, has contributed greatly to promoting economic cooperation between the two countries. Taiwan is now the Philippines' fourth-largest trading partner, and its fifth-largest source of foreign investment.
Wang said that Taiwan, which so far has remained relatively unscathed by the Asian financial meltdown, is willing to share its experience in this regard with the Philippines.
Meanwhile, it was announced that a bilateral private sector meeting will take place in tandem with the official conference.
The 13th joint meeting of the ROC-Philippines and Philippines-ROC Business Councils will be held in Manila from Aug. 18-21.
Jeffrey Koo, honorary chairman of the ROC-Philippines Business Council, and Leslie Koo, chairman of the council, will lead the ROC delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE ASSOCIATION URGES HABIBIE TO PUNISH RAPISTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Overseas Chinese Association has sent a letter to Indonesian President B.J. Habibie urging him to punish those responsible for the rape of ethnic Chinese women in May riots in the Southeast Asian nation.

Association President David Hsi-chih Chang said on Monday that he sent a letter to Habibie on Aug. 6, expressing strong condemnation and protest over the anti-Chinese violence. More than 2,000 shops and buildings were looted or destroyed in the rioting, and at least 160 ethnic Chinese girls and women were reported to have been gang-raped.

The letter demanded that the Indonesian government respect human rights, protect the interests of Chinese Indonesians, and ensure that no such incidents occur in the future. The association also requested Jakarta to compensate the victims and issue a formal apology.

Chang, who is concurrently president of the Sino-Indonesian Association, urged Jakarta to improve ties between native Indonesians and ethnic Chinese citizens, in order to achieve economic prosperity and promote Sino-Indonesian friendship.
Similar letters were sent to Mary Robinson, commissioner of the UN High Commission on Human Rights, and Boharuddin, secretary-general of the Indonesia National Human Rights Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRCRAFT FLIGHT SAFETY COMMISSION FORMALLY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: The Aircraft Flight Safety Commission under the Cabinet formally became operational on Monday, marking a step forward in establishing an overall flight safety control system on the island.

Speaking at the inaugural ceremony, Premier Vincent Siew said the commission will operate independently. "I hope all commission members will perform their duties fairly and impartially for building up the commission's credibility," he urged.

The premier pointed out that the commission is expected to fulfill two main tasks: investigating and inspecting causes of flight accidents or mishaps, as well as examining and evaluating flight safety control systems and measures at all local air companies.

"We hope the commission will come up with flight safety improving measures through performing the two main duties," Siew said, adding that the commission is expected to make judgment, not to assume the responsibility of flight safety management.

Siew said the inauguration of the commission just marks a modest step forward in upgrading the country's overall flight safety level. "Improvement of flight safety requires concerted and continued efforts of all relevant personnel," he stressed.

Noting that a series of tragic flight accidents occurring earlier this year were caused by a combination of factors, Siew said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) should cooperate closely with the new commission and formulate a comprehensive civil aviation development policy and a stricter flight safety control system based on the commission's recommendations.

"The MOTC should also direct the Civil Aeronautics Administration to faithfully carry out its duty of pushing all commercial carriers to improve flight safety measures and overseeing operations of the overall flight safety control system," Siew said.

The Cabinet decided to set up an independent flight safety commission in March following a series of air crashes involving local airlines early this year, which resulted in the death of more than 200 crew members and passengers.
The commission was established on May 25, but it didn't begin formal operations until Monday for failing to find an appropriate office.
Wong Cheng-yi, chairman of the five-member commission, said the commision has forged dialogue channels and cooperative ties with its counterparts in the United States, Canada and Australia.
The commission has also finalized a blueprint for establishing a flight safety report system, a flight mishaps databank, and a laborartory for decoding the "black box" recordings.

The commission will employ eight to 10 professional air crash investigators and flight safety controllers as well as several engineers and technicians to probe flight mishaps and carry out some technical work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS COMPLAIN OF INSECURITY IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen attending a seminar in central Changhua County complained on Monday about the Taiwan authorities' inability to protect their interests in mainland China, and said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should begin talks on the issue soon.

The seminar, sponsored by Ko Chin-ter, a Changhua County councilor of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was also attended by officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Apart from complaining that their personal safety is not fully protected in mainland China, the businessmen urged the government to negotiate and sign accords with mainland China as soon as possible on investment guarantees, trade, and judicial arbitration.

They also called on the government to publish regular reports of incidents involving Taiwan businessmen in the mainland, strengthen the SEF's ability to handle emergencies, and help Taiwan entrepreneurs to set up a national association in the mainland to boost communication among them.

Lien Cheng-shih, deputy director of the SEF's Department of Economic and Trade Services, said the SEF has received a total of 485 complaints from Taiwan businessmen arising from trade disputes since its founding in late 1991, 271 of which were forwarded to its mainland China counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- for help. However, ARATS handled only 82 of the cases, he added.

An official from the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs said the scale of investment plans by Taiwan firms in mainland China has decreased over the past two years since cross-strait relations began to sour in mid-1996 following a series of missile tests and military exercises by Beijing in the Taiwan Strait.

The MAC official added that the scale of Taiwan investment, which averages some US$57,000 per project, is expected to continue to decline because of the recent kidnap-murder in the mainland late last month of Lin Ti-chuang, a Kaohsiung City councilwoman and DPP member.

Lin was abducted and murdered by a group of armed men during a private visit to northeastern Liaoning Province. Initial investigations by local police indicate that Lin's death was the result of a business dispute between her boyfriend and his mainland business partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES NICARAGUAN WORKERS: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met on Monday with visiting Nicaraguan Minister of Labor Wilfredo Navarro Moreira to discuss Taiwan's intention to permit the import of Nicaraguan workers.

At a meeting in the Presidential Office, Lee told his guest that his country welcomes Nicaraguans who wish to work in Taiwan, noting that Taiwan already imports workers from several Southeast Asian countries such as Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines.

However, the president warned that in the process of recruiting laborers for export, the Nicaraguan authorities should take precautions against exploitation by unscrupulous labor brokerage companies, a problem that has caused friction among workers from some Southeast Asian countries.
Navarro responded by saying that his ministry will take sole charge of all details concerning the export of labor, and that brokerage firms will not be allowed to participate.

During the meeting, Lee also said that he values the traditional friendship between the Republic of China and Nicaragua, and expressed hope that Navarro's Taiwan visit will serve to strengthen existing bilateral cooperation and exchanges.
For his part, Navarro expressed his gratitude for the ROC's long-term assistance to his nation's economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PM URGED NOT TO VOICE `THREE NOES' POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A number of Republic of China National Assembly deputies called on Monday for Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi not to voice the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan.
In a letter to Obuchi, six deputies expressed their concern that Taiwan's interests might be sacrificed as a result of a September visit to Japan by mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.

The letter, signed by Tang Pi-o (KMT), Lan shih-tsun (KMT), Chen San-si (independent), Chiang Wen-ju (independent), Tsai Chung-chih (DPP), and Chen Chien-ming (DPP), was sent to the Interchange Association's Taipei Office, which was expected to forward the message to the Japanese prime minister.
The Interchange Association represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic relations between the two countries.

The deputies said in the letter that as a key member of the Asian community, the Japanese government's diplomatic utterances and activities serve as an example for other Asian countries. They expressed the hope that Tokyo will not bow to pressure from Beijing to make an acknowledgment similar the one reiterated by US President Bill Clinton during his visit to mainland China earlier this year.

The so-called "three noes" policy spelled out by Clinton states that the US does not support Taiwan independence, does not support "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and does not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.

Tang said that at a time when Japanese-mainland China engagement might result in an outcome harmful to Taiwan's interests, Taipei should clearly express its position that the future of Taiwan should be decided by the people of the island, and not by the United States, Japan, or mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN TO SURGE TO HISTORIC HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan is expected to increase to US$18 billion this year, the highest level in history, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) estimated on Monday.
CETRA researchers said their surveys show that Taiwan's exports to Japan have consistently sustained a two-digit decline over the past 12 months, with a 25 percent drop registered for July.
In the same month, Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan had accumulated to US$10.5 billion since the beginning of this year, the experts said.
They attributed the growing deficit to drops in Japan's consuming expenditure which have continued for 18 months. The serious depreciation of the Japanese yen was also blamed.
Last year, Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$17.3 billion to Japan, according to CETRA statistics.

To try to reduce this enormous deficit, the officials said that the Ministry of Economic Affairs has mapped out plans to increase exports to Japan, especially electronic products, computers and telecommunication products, metal, financial services, mechanical products, plastic goods, furniture, household appliances, bicycles and their parts and components, toys, and sports equipment.
Japan is Taiwan's second-largest trade partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACCUSATIONS AGAINST MERCEDES-OWNING POLICE REBUTTED

TEXT.P: The National Police Administration on Monday rebutted an accusation leveled by a legislator that some grassroots police officers might have used corrupt means to buy expensive German Mercedes Benz cars.
NPA spokesman Liang Chien-ming expressed regret at Legislator Hsu Chung-hsiung's suggestion, saying it has smeared the image of the police and dealt a blow to police morale.

Liang said that a NT$1.4 million Mercedes Benz "should be within the reach of everyone in Taiwan" as car dealers usually offer three-year zero interest to buyers. In addition, he said, considering economic margins, a Mercedes is a good choice.

Police supervisors usually take heed if their subordinates begin running an expensive car, Liang said, adding that as part of efforts to stem corruption, policemen's' assets are checked at the end of each year.

The authenticity of the statistics released by Hsu was also questioned. Liang said that Hsu's statistics show that the number of police-owned Mercedes in Kaohsiung city stand at 53, when according to him, the figure is "only 19."
In a written news release issued later, the NPA said that according to its own statistics, police officers in Taiwan own scores of Mercedes and over 100 BMWs.
Quoting a survey conducted by Kashide Taiwan, Hsu said in a press conference held earlier in the day that of the some 80,000 policemen around the island, 767 drive Mercedes.

Hsu said that for a grass roots police officer who earns between NT$50,000 and NT$60,000 per month, it is almost impossible to buy a Mercedes E220 worth NT$2.3 million without another source of income.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA WILL CONTINUE `PRAGMATIC' POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Canada's "pragmatic" policy toward Taiwan will not be affected by US President Bill Clinton's "three noes" statement on Taiwan made during his recent visit to mainland China, David Mulroney, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei, said on Monday.

In an interview with the CNA, Mulroney, who arrived in Taipei to assume his new post two weeks ago, said that his country's China policy is a "made in Canada policy," and that Clinton's "three noes" statement will not change substantially Canada's relationship with Beijing or any other government in the region.

Clinton's "three noes" statement made clear that his administration will not support Taiwan independence, "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," or Taiwan's entry to any international organization that requires statehood for membership.
Responding to an interviewer's question, the 43-year-old Canadian representative in Taipei said: "We maintain a one-China policy. Within that, there is much we can do."

"For example," he said, "in terms of our relationship with Taiwan, we are cognizant of the realities of the situation locally. And we try to ensure that whatever we do is for the benefit of the people in the region and contributes to the ultimate peaceful resolution of the (Taiwan) issue."
In his view, he said, Canada has maintained a successful "pragmatic" policy toward Taiwan because it is "always seeking to develop a relationship within the limits of a clearly defined policy."

Mulroney pointed out that Canada has been supportive of Taiwan's participation in the Asia Pacific Economic forum and of its accession to the World Trade Organization, although it does not back Taiwan's effort to rejoin the United Nations.
"By and large, we support Taiwan's participation that fits in the overall criteria of our policy," he said. (Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: PROJECT PLANNED TO EXPAND DOMESTIC DEMAND

TEXT.P: Chairman P. K. Chiang of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), on Monday presided over a ministerial meeting to discuss a project aimed at expanding domestic demand.

The draft project, which will focus on how to strengthen public investment on the one hand, and how to promote private investment on the other, will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for further discussion at a meeting scheduled for Thursday.

Public investment is estimated to reach NT$187.3 billion(US$5.4 billion), and private investment might go up to more than NT$54 billion, giving a total of NT$241.4 billion (US$6.95 billion) for the two-year project, up from the original NT$200 billion.

Chiang stressed that the project is needed to cope with the impact of the Asian financial turmoil which has greatly reduced the Republic of China's export surplus. He said he expects the project will improve the health of the ROC's economy, help maintain long-term economic growth, and be conducive to the Asian economy as a whole.
According to the CEPD chief, the Asian region's economic stability will depend very much on development in Indonesia, Japan, and mainland China.

Chiang expressed his hope that the new Japanese Diet, or parliament, will soon pass new laws to help stabilize or even bring about a recovery in its stock and foreign exchange markets. He said he believes these measures will be helpful not only to the Japanese economy, but also to the whole Asian economy and the stability of mainland China's renminbi.

The CEPD estimated that the implementation of the project will contribute about 0.23 percent to Taiwan's economic growth this year and about 0.67 percent next year. This boost would push Taiwan's economic growth rate in 1998 to about 5.03, the lowest since 1985.

Meanwhile, Vice Finance Minister Wang Yung-chou reiterated after the meeting that his ministry will give its full cooperation in raising funds for the implementation of the project, while Finance Minister Paul Chiu said the ministry will enhance the implementation of loans to first-time house-buyers if necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICTIMS OF LINCOLN MANSION COLLAPSE APPEAL FOR GOVERNMENT HELP

TEXT.P: The families of the victims of last year's Lincoln Mansions collapse will appeal on Tuesday to the Executive Yuan for its help in obtaining compensation from the construction company which built the ill-fated apartment blocks.

One of the organizers of the event said that the Taipei County government has failed to help them seek compensation, which is why they are switching their appeal to the central government on the first anniversary of the disaster.

On Aug. 18, 1997, four five-story buildings in Taipei County's "Big Lincoln" community, built on steep mountain slopes, collapsed after being hit by a landslide caused by Typhoon Winnie, claiming the lives of 28 people and injuring another 50.
However, according to a written news release issued by the Taipei County government, the local government has taken action by freezing the 268 lots of land owned by the constructor, Lee Chung-hsien.

It also said that among the 28 victims, the families of 25 have already reached compensation agreements with the construction company. Those who have not made a deal with the company have received comfort money and funeral subsidies.

As for the question of compensation for property losses, 70 percent of the house owners have already reached agreement with the construction company, and a final agreement is expected to be reached after negotiations with the loaning bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-TAIWAN WTO ACCORD HELPS BEIJING'S BID: WTO

TEXT.P: The accord between the United States and Taiwan on Taipei's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) will help Beijing's bid to join the global trade body, according to reports from the Geneva-based world trade body on Monday.
The WTO report quoted a trade official as saying the bilateral deal struck between Washington and Taipei a week ago will not result in Taiwan's gaining entry to the WTO ahead of Beijing.
"The US-Taiwan bilateral accord will be beneficial in speeding up negotiations on China's WTO entry," the report quoted the official as saying.
Beijing has long insisted on political grounds that mainland China must enter the trade-governing body before Taiwan.
Most WTO members have tacitly accepted Beijing's stance, despite criticism that it makes Taiwan a hostage to the slow pace of trade liberalization by the less open mainland.

Mainland China's negotiations are dragging as the United States and other key WTO members balk at Beijing's insistence on keeping high tariffs on major industrial products, and at the narrow scope of its liberalization of the financial, agriculture and distribution sectors.

The WTO report said that as of May, only nine of the mainland's 36 trading partners had concluded bilateral entry negotiations, while Taiwan has to complete bilateral WTO talks with just the European Union, Canada, and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACUPUNCTURE USE SAID GROWING IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The cost to Australia's Medicare of acupuncture treatment reached US$10 million in 1996 as more general practitioners are turning to the traditional Chinese treatment, the Sydney Morning Herald said Monday.

Despite little evidence that acupuncture is effective, 15 percent of the country's general practitioners applied for Medicare rebate for the treatment. The number is believed to be a conservative estimate of the total use of the technique.
Professor Paul Komesaroff from the Department of Medicine at Monash University in Melbourne said the effectiveness and risks of acupuncture have not been sufficiently studied.

Acupuncture can damage nerves, blood vessels, the chest cavity, the lung, and the spinal cord, he said, adding that if needles are not properly disinfected, they can cause infection, even hepatitis or HIV infection.

Regulation of acupuncturists and other practitioners of traditional Chinese medicine will be introduced from 1999 in Victoria and could be adopted nationally after a Victoria committee recently stated that such regulation can protect the public.
Colleges of traditional Chinese medicine will be assessed and reputable ones accredited under the same proposal so that people can have confidence in acupuncturists, Komesaroff said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOYCOTT IMPOSED AGAINST NORTHWEST AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's anti-smoking John Tung Foundation on Monday initiated a boycott of Northwest Airlines, and called on the island's residents not to fly with the US-based carrier.
At a press conference in Taipei, the foundation announced more than 20 charges against the airline relating to what it described as the company's deliberate disregard for its customers' health.

One of the complains was brought by the Chen family, a foundation spokesman said. The spokesman elaborated that four members of the family took a Northwest Airlines flight from Taiwan to the United States in mid-July.

Chen told the foundation that although seated in the non-smoking cabin, their seats were immediately adjacent to a smoking area. During the flight, his two-year-old granddaughter could not stop coughing and experienced difficulty breathing because of second-hand smoke, Chen said.
His repeated requests for a change of seats were rejected, Chen said, adding that his granddaughter was later diagnosed with bronchitis, an ailment linked to second-hand smoke
He also accused a Northwest Airlines stewardess of taping off vacant seats to prevent the family from changing seats of their own accord, the spokesperson said.

The sanction campaign is being supported by several welfare and human rights organizations, including the Child Welfare Legal Foundation, the Consumers' Foundation, and the Chinese human rights association.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU RONGJI INTRODUCES AUSTRALIAN TOILETS TO CHINA

TEXT.P: Australian toilets made inroads to mainland China after then Vice Premier Zhu Rongji made his first state visit to the country last year.
Zhu, who became premier in early 1998, tackled the mainland's notorious toilet problem after he went into a restroom during his visit and discovered how an Australian toilet would be good for China.

The Australian newspaper on Monday reported that security guards became so nervous over the long bathroom break Zhu had taken last year that they had to force open the cubicle door only to find Zhu, a former engineer, carefully studying the innovative two-button dual flush system he had dismantled.
"We must introduce this toilet to China," he reportedly said.
After Zhu returned to Beijing, China began to import Australian toilets from the toilet's maker, Caroma Australia, which is now making progress in China's huge market.

Ordinary Chinese were also delighted by Zhu's hands-on approach to improving the mainland's toilets, the daily reported. The administration in Shanghai recently declared toilet improvement as "the number one task under heaven."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Five New Party candidates were disqualified on Monday for party primary over bribery charges.
The China Times: US President Bill Clinton on Monday began giving grand jury testimony in which he reversed course after months of denial and admitted to an improper relationship with a White House intern.
The United Daily News: US President Bill Clinton on Monday testified before grand jury for an alleged affair.
The Liberty Times: US President Bill Clinton plans to admit to an inappropriate physical relationship with Monica Lewinsky to shun impeachment.
The Independence Morning Post: US President Bill Clinton on Monday testified under oath.
The Commons Daily: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau on Monday denied political surveillance operations.
The China Post: US President Bill Clinton testifies before grand jury.
The China News: Stocks suffer sharp plunge.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY ONE MILLION HIT GIO WEBSITE IN JULY

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office's (GIO) Internet website received nearly one million visitors in July alone, officials said Tuesday.
They said the site had 992,736 million hits from 83 countries and regions by people who wanted to learn more about the Republic of China.

To enhance international understanding about the ROC on Taiwan, the GIO established a website in July 1995 and provided information in Chinese, English, German, Spanish, French, Japanese, and Russian.

As a measure to relieve the volume of inquires and to promote greater interest, the GIO has also established websites overseas. These include sites in New York, San Francisco, Japan, Britain, Hong Kong, Germany, and Panama.
Officials have also added Dutch, Czech, Polish and Hungarian languages to their website since its establishment.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA EXPORTS WATER TECHNOLOGY TO ASIAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Australia is increasing the export of its expertise in water and waste water management to mainland China, Indonesia, the Philippines and South Pacific countries amid the region's financial crisis.

The South Australian Water Corporation (SAWC) is exporting its knowledge of water technology and managerial expertise to these countries and giving its expertise to a large Shanghai project by increasing the city's water flow to 10 gigaliters from the current 7 gigaliters a day.
In Indonesia, the Australian company is in a joint venture in West Java providing five water infrastructure projects worth a total of US$3.1 billion.

SAWC and its contracted companies from Adelaide are supplying operational expertise and technology to improve the water catchment areas in West Java that supply water to Jakarta's residences and industrial operations.
Other Australian firms, including the Canberra-based ACT Electricity and Water Corp. (ACTEW) has been exporting its expertise to more than 60 countries, a senior ACTEW executive told the CNA.
He said ACTEW had not exported its technology to Taiwan because the island's market is too advanced and sophisticated, and the competition is too fierce.
But he said Australian expertise is well placed in the competitive Asian water and waste water management market due to its reputation in environmental management, especially in water management.
West Australian Water Corporation (WAWC) is also one of the Australian firms that export its expertise to the Asian region.

WAWC Executive Director Chris Davis told the Australian Financial Review that the Asian market is, "faced with multiple (Australian) bidders who don't collaborate," and would prefer a recognized consortium rather than poorly financed water firms in direct opposition to each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BOURSE, CURRENCY UP DESPITE FALL IN RUSSIAN RUBLE

TEXT.P: The Australian stock and foreign exchange markets, buoyed by the strong performances in New York, Tokyo, Singapore and Kuala Lumpur, rose in morning trade on Tuesday.

Market analysts told the CNA that the All Ordinaries Index rose 22.2 points to 2,559 in morning trade, compared to Monday's close of 2,536.8. The index plunged 32.2 points on Monday after major losses in major markets, including Wall Street.
A strong recovery on Wall Street, coupled with a rally by Australia's insurance and banking and oil stocks, helped boost the index Tuesday morning, they said.
The Australian dollar edged up marginally in morning trade from Monday's close of 59.13 US cents, thanks to a stronger Japanese yen against the greenback.

Analysts said institutional investors remained cautious in their investment because the latest depreciation of the Russian ruble against the US dollar is expected to cause a damper on the lingering financial crisis in Asia.
One analyst said investors will not likely take large positions in Australia's stock and foreign exchange markets because they are still risky.
The Australian dollar on Monday once fell below 59 US cents when Russia announced the depreciation of its currency on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO AGREEMENT TO ALLOW FOREIGN LAWYERS TO PRACTICE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open its services market wider to overseas competition as foreign lawyers will be allowed to jointly run law offices with their local partners.

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Monday that Taiwan has reached an agreement with other members of the World Trade Organization (WTO) allowing foreign lawyers to jointly operate law offices in Taiwan with local business partners beginning the third year after Taiwan enters the WTO.

These foreign lawyers are required to have practiced law for at least five years previously in their native countries before they are permitted to jointly operate law offices in Taiwan, the BOFT added.

A total of 26 WTO members have voiced a desire to negotiate with Taiwan on its terms for joining the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body. Taiwan has already wrapped up two-way talks and clinched formal accords on its WTO membership with most of them.
Taiwan concluded its bilateral negotiations with the 15-member European Union (EU) last month. The EU had expressed special concern over the protection of foreign lawyers operating in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INVESTMENT CLIMATE WORLD'S 2ND BEST: BERI

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment climate rating has advanced to the world's second best, next only to Switzerland's, a senior official said on Tuesday, quoting the latest survey released by Swiss firm Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI).

"Taiwan tied Singapore at second place in the newly released BERI investment climate and business profit opportunity rating," said Lin Neng-jong, director of the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
"This is the best ranking Taiwan has ever received in the annual BERI survey," Lin said, adding that in all previous BERI polls, Singapore consistently preceded Taiwan in the global rating.

Lin said the advance indicates that amid the Southeast Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan's healthy economic fundamentals and investment climate have won the recognition of professional international market research institutions.
The latest BERI report also forecast that Taiwan's investment climate will remain the world's second best next year. "The forecast manifests that Taiwan is a low-risk investment area," Lin noted.

Nonetheless, Lin cautioned local business people to exercise prudence in making investments in Southeast Asia because most countries in Asia have seen their BERI investment climate ratings downgraded significantly. Southeast Asia has been one of the most popular investment destinations for Taiwan entrepreneurs.

Among major Asian countries, Indonesia registered the most serious drop of 16 slots from its 1997 rating to 47th; Malaysia dropped five notches to 22nd; South Korea retreated three slots to 23rd; Thailand fell three places to 32nd; and Japan slid one notch to fourth.
Mainland China ranked 19th, while Vietnam tied the Philippines at 40th.
Lin said South Korea was downgraded to a medium-risk investment region from a low-risk area a year ago.
According to the newly released BERI survey, Holland tied Japan at fourth place; Germany ranked sixth; Norway, seventh; the United States and Austria tied at eighth; and Belgium ranked 10th.
The BERI rating is based on three criteria -- the business operations risk index, the political risk index and the foreign exchange payment capability.
