DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST DENGUE HEMORRHAGIC FEVER CONFIRMED

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Tuesday confirmed that Taiwan's first case of dengue hemorrhagic fever this year had been reported.
The patient, a 47-year-old woman from Taipei, checked into a hospital in late July after returning from a trip to Thailand, DOH officials said.

Hsu Hsu-mei, deputy director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said the patient's symptoms included small hemorrhagic spots on her skin, accumulation of liquid in the thorax, and platelet count decrease.
The patient has received treatment and is now fully recovered, Hsu said.
Since 1994, 21 cases of dengue hemorrhagic fever have been reported in Taiwan, of those cases, one patient has died, Hsu said.

The DOH also announced another four cases of dengue fever have been reported, bringing the total number of cases this year to 56, or a sharp increase compared with 23 cases during the same period last year.
The patients -- two men in Taipei and a married couple in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan -- all contracted the mosquito-transmitting disease after returning from Thailand.
Hsu again urged the public to be on guard against mosquito bites when traveling to Southeast Asian nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION DEPARTS FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation, which was here to attend Saturday's inauguration of President Raul Cubas Grau, departed for Taiwan Monday following a five-day visit.

Secretary General to the President Huang Kung-huei, leader of the delegation, said he felt very honored to be received twice by President Cubas and expressed confidence that bilateral relations between the two sides will continue to grow and herald a new era.
The ROC will continue to assist Paraguay by playing a constructive and efficient role in the country's economic development, Huang said.
Huang, on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui, invited Cubas to visit Taiwan. Accepting the invitation, the new Paraguayan president said he would travel to Taiwan as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'MILLENNIUM BUG' SEEN RISKING AIRLINE SAFETY

TEXT.P: The "millennium bug," often referred to as the Y2K, will likely pose major safety problems in the aviation industry as its computerized systems could be effected, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) of Australia said.
In a letter to pilots and airlines in Australia, CASA's director of air safety Mick Toller said airline operators have not taken the warning seriously.

He said computerized systems, including hardware and software used for aircraft control displays, navigation, communications, engine controls, flight controls and loading of flight data, could be hit by the bug.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Tuesday quoted Toller as saying, "By now you ought to know that some systems with embedded computer chips, and some computer programs, will either shut down or malfunction on January 1, 2000."

"This is not a media beat-up, but the considered opinion of the most informed authorities on the subject. It is the responsibility of senior managers and directors of aviation companies to ensure that computer-based equipment that affect safety will not be compounded by the changeover to the year 2000," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR IMPORTS FROM QUEENSLAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan Sugar Corp. has recently ordered more than US$11 million worth of sugar from Queensland, Australia.

Queensland's Deputy Premier Jim Elder told Australian media that he had successfully convinced Taisugar and other Taiwanese enterprises during his trip last week to Taiwan that the Queensland government desires to do business with Taiwan and other Asian countries.
Beatie earlier told the CNA that his government valued the state's two-way trade with Taiwan and welcomed Taiwan students and Taiwanese tourists to Queensland.

Elder said Taiwan Sugar has ordered A$10 million (US$6.25 million) from the Queensland Sugar Corp. and A$8 million (US$5 million) worth of refined sugar from Mackay Refined Sugar, quantities higher than the usual contracts.
"This means that Queensland products are once again being considered solely on their merits and in this sense at least, it means we're able to compete again on a level playing field," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE IN NEW YORK STAGE ANOTHER PROTEST AGAINST INDONESIA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By K. C. Hwang & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: A group of ethnic Chinese in New York staged another round of protests on Monday, demanding the Indonesian government to guarantee that the Chinese in that country not be targeted in any form of atrocities.

The demonstration, which coincided with Indonesia's Independence Day, was attended by 500 people. They gathered outside the Indonesian Consulate General, shouting slogans to express their anger over the attacks against Chinese people during May's rioting in Indonesia.

In a written protest to the consulate general, the group demanded that Jakarta uncover the truth behind the rioting, bring to justice all those who committed or were behind the atrocities, provide compensation for losses sustained by ethnic Chinese, offer medical treatment to the injured, compensate the families of the deceased, and institute legislation to protect the lives and property of the ethnic Chinese living there.

An estimated 1,200 ethnic Chinese people were killed and more than a hundred ethnic Chinese women and girls were raped in Indonesia during the chaotic days of riots in May which eventually toppled then President Suharto's regime.

This was second protest initiated by the New York-based Association of Chinese People Protesting Atrocities in Indonesia in less than two weeks. A large-scale protest on Aug. 7 attracted more than 3,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STILL HAS HIGH EXPECTATIONS FOR KOO-WANG MEETING: MAC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Tuesday it still holds high expectations for a planned visit to mainland China this fall by C. F. Koo, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

"Even though some unexpected incidents occurred between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait recently, we still hope Koo's planned mainland trip will proceed smoothly," said MAC Chairman Chang King-yuh.

Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with Beijing, is scheduled to make a landmark visit to mainland China this autumn, during which time he is expected to meet with Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Chang said the MAC, which oversees SEF operations, has not ruled out the possibility of including political issues into the agenda for the proposed Koo-Wang meeting.
Nevertheless, Chang said, Taiwan still hopes that issues related the rights and interests of people on both sides of the strait will be addressed first.

If necessary, Chang said, the MAC is hopeful that SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow will travel to mainland China to discuss with his ARATS counterpart the itinerary for Koo's mainland trip as well as the agenda for the planned Koo-Wang meeting.
Chang went on to say Taiwan's basic stance on cross-strait dialogue is that any topics can be discussed, but those related to people's rights and interests should be given the priority.
"We earnestly hope that Koo's planned mainland trip will mark resumption of institutionalized SEF-ARATS dialogue and usher in a new era in cross-strait relations," Chang said.
The chief mainland policy planner also urged Beijing not to deliberately downgrade its contacts or exchanges with SEF. "Otherwise, cross-strait relations will never make headway," Chang stressed.

Koo and Wang met for the first time in Singapore in April 1993. During that historic meeting, the two sides signed several agreements to lay a framework for institutionalized contacts and dialogue between SEF and ARATS.

The second Koo-Wang meeting was originally scheduled for the autumn of 1995, but a landmark visit to the United States in June that year by ROC President Lee Teng-hui angered Beijing, which suspended the meeting and launched a series of war games and missile tests to try to intimidate Taiwan. Beijing viewed Lee's US visit as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGES IN KMT CENTRAL STANDING COMMITTEE EXPECTED TO BE MODEST

TEXT.P: Secretary-General John Chang of the ruling Kuomintang said Tuesday that changes in the KMT's Central Standing Committee members will be modest.
The party will hold its second plenary session of the 15th Central Committee at the Taipei International Convention Center Aug. 22-23.
During the meeting, participants will listen to reports on government and party affairs, discuss the election campaigns for the year-end elections, and reshuffle the Central Standing Committee.
Chang confirmed that Lee Huan, an appointed Central Standing Committee member, has tendered his resignation and President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as the KMT party chairman, has accepted it.
Chang said changes to the Central Standing Committee members will not be major, but final decisions have yet to be made.
The KMT Central Standing Committee has 33 seats, including 16 appointed seats and 17 elected seats.

The appointed members are chosen based on their representative role in society. They include Premier Vincent Siew, Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung, National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, Examination Yuan President Su Shui-teh, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan, Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei, National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling and Taiwan Governor James Soong.
Several presently elected members may not be in the running this year, sources said. One such example is Yeh Chin-feng, former Minister of the Interior, who now works in the party.

Others who may leave the policy-making body of the party include Tai Tung-yuan, president of the National Taiwan University Hospital, who offered his resignation; Hsieh Lung-sheng, deputy speaker of the National Assembly, who is seriously ill; and James Chu, former minister of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, who was sent overseas and may not be able to resume his work.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.027 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 34.734.
The local currency opened at 34.737 and was trade between 34.702 and 34.75.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$197 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MEMBERS TO DEFEND CLEAN PRIMARIES

TEXT.P: A New Party member who seeks a party nomination in the year-end legislative election on Tuesday initiated an "anti-illegal mobilization alliance" calling for more party members to defend clean primaries.

Lee Sheng-feng, who seeks nomination as a legislative candidate in Taipei County, said members of the alliance should pledge not to get involved in any form of irregularities in manipulating the outcome of primary elections such as offering money, gifts, free banquets or free trips to potential voters.

Alliance members are also not permitted to seek assistance from other political parties or any conglomerates to help them win in primary elections which select candidates for the legislative, and Taipei and Kaohsiung city council elections. The primaries are not restricted to only party members, but are open to all registered voters.

Lee said so far, over 20 New Party members have joined the alliance, adding that alliance members will launch joint campaigns to drum up support for themselves in an effort to fight against possible irregularities by other candidates.

Rumors of bribery have been rampant since the party's primary elections started on Aug. 1. To show its determination to eliminate any form of vote-buying, the New Party on Monday revoked the qualifications of five candidates to run in the primaries.

A New Party primary monitoring committee announced that the five candidates, including incumbent Taiwan Provincial Assembly deputy Sung Ai-ko, were reportedly involved in "improper mobilization" in the primary elections. After careful investigations, the allegations proved to be true, the committee said, but it refused to describe what actions were deemed improper in order to protect the informers.

The committee, headed by Legislator Chen Kuei-miao, also decided that because Huang Lin-chien, who was one of the five, committed more serious violations, his case will be forwarded to the party's anti-corruption committee to decide if he will be expelled from the party.

According to the committee, after it announced on Aug. 10 that the party would offer a reward of NT$1 million (US$28,800) to anyone reporting cases of bribery in the primary elections, the party has been swamped with bribery reports.

After a six-hour marathon session, the committee determined that of all the reported cases, only four could be confirmed, three through credit information firms that the party contracted to help it investigate and collect evidence against bribery accusations.
The New Party was founded in August 1993 by a group of disgruntled Kuomintang members who broke away from the ruling party to protest against its "undemocratic practices."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DROPS ON TAIEX, FUTURES EXCHANGE UP

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 92.26 points to close at 7,181.59.
Encouraged by a price surge in the New York Stock Exchange, the bourse opened at the day's high of 7,284.6 points, 10.75 higher than Monday's closing, and experienced a low of 7,088.73.
A total of 19.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$111.68 billion.

All eight major categories lost ground, with foodstuff stocks moving down the most at 2.5 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.7 percent, textile issues at 1.4 percent, construction shares at 0.8 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.5 percent, and both pulp and paper issues and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures posted a general increase.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for both September and October edged up one point to close at 7,220 and 7,200 respectively, while those for December increased two points to 7,483.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 574, one, and four, respectively.
The TAIEX Index Futures for March move down five points to close at 7,405, with six contract transactions. No transactions were registered for June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were listed as follows: 7,219 points for September; 7,199 for October; 7,481 for December; 7,410 for March; and 7,588 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: US, MAINLAND CHINA MOVE TO FIX FRACTURED TRADE PACT

TEXT.P: Washington and Beijing authorities have agreed to meet later this month for talks aimed at repairing a fractured maritime relationship that threatens to disrupt trade, the World Trade Organization said Tuesday.

Negotiations are set to begin in Beijing on Aug. 24 and will come less than two weeks after the US Federal Maritime Commission (FMC) launched an investigation into the mainland's shipping policies and port practices. The outcome of the investigation could lead to sanctions imposed against the US' fourth-largest trading partner, the Geneva-based trade organization said.
The independent shipping watchdog agency said it received complaints from federal agencies and the US maritime industry about the mainland's unwillingness to open its container shipping markets.
In what promises to be a busy two weeks, the US maritime delegation headed to Beijing will first visit Tokyo for a round of discussions on a dispute similar to the one heating up with China.

The FMC imposed a temporary US$100,000 fine last year on all Japanese container ships entering US ports after determining that Japanese port practices were anti-competitive. The Beijing meetings are considered the more urgent of the two negotiations.
A 10-year-old bilateral shipping agreement between the United States and the mainland is set to expire Sept. 15. The pact would have expired June 15 but was extended by three months.

US-China maritime relations hit rock bottom in March with the sudden collapse of a market-opening deal struck in December. That pact was designed to benefit the mainland's state-owned shipping line, Communist China Ocean Shipping Co., and two top US container ship operators, Sea-Land Service Inc. and APL Ltd.
Beijing pledged to give Sea-Land and APL freer access to mainland ports and to allow Sea-Land to proceed on the joint development of a major terminal in Tianjin, one of two main northern China ports.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CITIZENS THANK GOVERNMENT FOR EVACUATION ASSISTANCE

TEXT.P: Six Republic of China nationals who were evacuated from the war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) have expressed their appreciation to Taipei for its assistance.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs, through arrangements by its representative office in the DRC's Kinshasa, leased a small commercial aircraft Monday to transport ROC nationals to the neighboring Gabonese Republic.

Hsiao Kuang-yu, head of the ROC representative office in Kinshasa, said in a telegram sent Tuesday from Libreville, Gabon's capital, that the six ROC nationals asked him to convey their appreciation to the government for helping them leave the DRC.
Members of the group were also quoted as saying they were deeply touched by the effort particularly after seeing that many mainland Chinese citizens were still waiting to be evacuated from Kinshasa.

Eight of the remaining 10 ROC nationals left in the DRC were evacuated Monday, including two members of the ROC representative office in Kinshasa. Recent fighting between the military and rebel forces prompted the evacuation of foreign nationals and airlines to cancel their flights to Kinshasa.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND'S OPPOSITION PARTY ESTABLISHES BRANCH IN US
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By K. C. Hwang & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The only nation-wide mainland Chinese opposition party, which was founded in February 1998, established a US East Coast branch in New York City on Sunday.

Over 30 people attended the Chinese Democratic Justice Party's (CDJP) opening ceremony which was held at the party's provisional headquarters in New York. They included members of the party, representatives of other pro-democracy groups and guests from various fields.
Party spokesman Wang Bingzhang and CDJP Secretary-General Fu Shengqi said at the gathering that now is the time to terminate one-party autocracy and establish a system of democracy in mainland China.
Wang urged party members to lay a firm foundation for a revolutionary public. He said that everyone should have the will and determination to topple the autocratic regime.
Fu said the primary tasks should focus on propaganda, organization and action, adding that propaganda can promote the organization while organization can enhance the strength of action.
The CDJP's East Coast US branch has about 20 members with Tao Wanzhang acting as its spokesman. Other core-members include Wei Chuanbao, Ni Jinbing, Lin Yao and Ma Hangzhung.
There are over 20 branches of the CDJP established in mainland China, and overseas branch offices have been set up in the West Coast of the US, Europe and Hong Kong.
The names of members in the CDJP in the mainland are kept secret. Meanwhile, the overseas branches of the party have attracted about 200 members.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCILOR'S FUNERAL SERVICES HELD IN KAOHSIUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Southern Taiwan, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Funeral services were held Tuesday for Lin Ti-chuan, the late Kaohsiung City councilor who was drugged to death by her abductors during a botched kidnap in mainland China late July.

Lin, 32, a member of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), was accidentally killed by an overdose of drugs administered while she was being held by her captors in mainland China's northeast city of Haicheng.

Lin's body was flown back to her hometown in Kaohsiung from Beijing via Hong Kong on Aug. 8. Some of her family members and colleagues who traveled to the mainland went through labored negotiation with authorities to have her body returned to Taiwan.

President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, and Premier Vincent Siew all sent funeral tablets and scrolls with accolades to commend the late councilor. Some 1,000 people, including DPP heavyweights and officials from the Kaohsiung city government, attended the services.
Lin and her Kaohsiung businessman boyfriend, Wei Tien-kang, were reportedly abducted by five mainland Chinese men in Dalien upon their arrival in the northeastern city on July 27.
According to mainland authorities, four of the five suspected kidnappers have been apprehended. The fifth, Li Guangzhi, who is said to have been the mastermind behind the kidnap, is still at large.

The arrested suspects said Li ordered Wei's kidnapping to force him to repay a debt he owed to Li. The two victims were abducted by the four men, taken about 200 kilometers north to Haicheng City, and hidden in an empty apartment.

Wei and Lin were injected with an unknown drug which may have been heroin, and fell in and out of unconsciousness. Lin later reportedly experienced difficulty breathing and turned pale on July 29. She was rushed to a Haicheng hospital, where she was declared dead on arrival. The four suspects then fled.
Wei regained consciousness during their absence and managed to escape and notify local public security authorities of the incident.

Wei, who stated that he loved Lin, said he was sorry that Lin's first mainland trip resulted in such a tragedy. He could not attend the funeral as he was technically taken into custody by the Haicheng public security authorities for questioning about the alleged kidnap and murder.

The Kaohsiung businessman, distressed at being kept under house arrest, told Taiwan media through telephone conversations Monday that he would take "radical" action if the mainland authorities continue to prevent him from returning to Taiwan. He said he was a victim, not an accomplice, in the kidnap.
One of the rising stars of the DPP, Lin made her debut in politics at the age of 28. A political maverick, Lin was dubbed "the little chili" for her spicy interpellation style.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN REPUBLIC PRESIDENT TO VISIT TAICHUNG COUNTY

TEXT.P: President Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Republic will visit Taichung County during his tour of Taiwan in mid-1999, according to Ambassador Victor Sanchez.
Sanchez made the announcement during a courtesy call to Taichung County Council Speaker C.B. Yen Tuesday.
Sanchez noted that President Fernandez, who was originally expected to visit Taiwan on July 23 this year, has postponed the trip until mid-1999 due to a heavy domestic schedule.

The speaker and the ambassador also discussed matters related to the establishment of a sisterhood relationship between Taichung County and Santiago, the second largest city in the Central American country.

During the meeting, the Dominican envoy briefed Yen and his colleagues, including Councilors Liu Sung-wu, Su Li-hua and Tsai Wen-hsiung, on the geographical position as well as industrial and commercial development in the Dominican Republic.
Yen also accepted Sanchez's invitation to lead a Taichung County mission to visit Santiago in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER `THE EGRET' LAID TO REST

TEXT.P: A grand funeral for late Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lu Hsiu-yi was held in Panchiao, Taipei County on Tuesday.

Many senior government officials, including President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew, as well as DPP heavyweights, attended the funeral to pay tribute to one of the most prominent and respected politicians in Taiwan's opposition camp.

Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-fan, Control Yuan President Wang Tso-yung, and Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh also attended, as well as thousands of Lu's supporters from around the island.

Observers said the presence of President Lee and so many other central government officials illustrated the DPP's growing political strength. The pro-independence party now controls more mayoral and county magistrate positions than the ruling Kuomintang.
Lu, a three-term lawmaker and a vocal proponent of Taiwan independence, died of lung cancer on Aug. 6 at the age of 57.

The funeral rites began with a performance of French composer Gabriel Faure's "Song of Pathos" by the Formosa Egret Symphony Orchestra, which was founded with the support of Lu and his wife, a musician.
A posthumous citation, which was issued by President Lee and lauded Lu for his contributions to education and Taiwan's democratization, was read at the funeral.
Chen Chu, director of the Bureau of Social Affairs under the Taipei City Government, gave an emotional and sentimental resume of Lu's life story.

Describing Lu as a sage with a historian's perspective and vision, Chen recounted the scholar-turned-lawmaker's dedication to academic study, promotion of Taiwan's democratic reforms, love for his family, and contributions to the DPP.
"Lu was a man of action. He regarded politics as a career, a serious undertaking," said Chen, one of only a few influential DPP female politicians.

Chen further said that although Lu had left this world to begin "another form of existence," his passion, straightforwardness, courage, moral stature, and optimism, will live in the hearts and minds of all his family and friends forever.
Lu, who earned a doctoral degree in political science from the Sorbonne in Paris, taught at Chinese Culture University and National Tsinghua University before entering politics in 1989.

He also served a three-year prison term from 1983 through 1986 on charges of sedition for his promotion of Taiwan independence. At the time, Taiwan was still under martial law and advocacy of independence was taboo.
It was during his time in jail that Lu's hair turned pure white, prompting him to take the sobriquet "The Egret," after the snowy white crested wading bird common in rural Taiwan.

A witty, humorous man, Lu was a key opinion leader in the Legislative Yuan. His profound knowledge, resourcefulness, cultured manner, and taste for the arts, helped him win a great deal of respect and admiration from his legislative colleagues and from the island's media.
The funeral procession extended several kilometers as thousands of Lu's supporters, including many taxi drivers, escorted Lu's coffin to the crematorium where Lu's body was cremated.
The DPP held an overnight vigil on Monday to pay tribute to one of its most popular standard bearer.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE TV ACTRESS ON 3-DAY VISIT TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Japanese television actress, Naomi Kawashima, arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a three-day visit.

Kawashima, known regionally for her performance in the television drama series "Paradise Lost," is on her first visit to Taiwan to promote the new television serial "Red Flower" which will be shown on Formosa Television.
The actress is scheduled to make several public appearances during her visit, including an autograph-signing session.
Meanwhile, Junichi Watanabe, a physician turned writer who authored "Paradise Lost," a novel about an extramarital affair, also arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a brief visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: OIL COMPANIES OF TAIWAN, M'LAND ENTER INTO JOINT VENTURE

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) of Taiwan and the China National Offshore Oil Corp. (CNOOC) of mainland China have agreed to invest US$450,000 each for oil exploration in the Zhu Jiang River estuary in Guangdong Province.

CPC General Manager Pan Wen-yen said Tuesday that the agreement was signed between CNOOC and CPC's subsidiary, Overseas Petroleum Investment Corp., earlier this year, but details of the joint venture were finalized during his visit to the mainland on Aug. 9-17.

The exploration, which will cover an area of 15,400 square kilometers in the southeastern section of the Zhu Jiang River estuary, has been approved by the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, Pan said. It is the first joint venture of the state-run oil companies of Taiwan and mainland China.

Pan also said that the CPC plans to develop its market on the mainland, and that several big companies of mainland China have shown interest in buying liquefied natural gas and lubricant from the CPC. The oil products will be exported to the mainland through a third country, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORTHWEST AIRLINES PLEDGES TO IMPROVE FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: The US-based Northwest Airlines pledged on Tuesday to improve its services, starting with the implementation from Aug. 1 of a total smoking ban on all its flights.

A statement released by the carrier indicated that while the company is sincere in its desire to resolve every customer complaint, it will consider filing suit if cases of deliberate defamation are uncovered.

The statement stressed that Northwest, the first foreign airline to establish itself in Taiwan, has been operating here for 48 years. All of the company's services and flight operations follow US Federal Aviation Administration regulations, and are monitored by the administration.

The statement reiterated the company will seek a satisfactory resolution to the latest charges leveled by dissatisfied customer Wu Pei-min, and that it hopes to retain the goodwill of local consumers.

Wu's lawsuit against Northwest will soon come to trial. The case has drawn wide attention since it is the first case in Taiwan against businesses which have failed to implement a comprehensive ban on smoking in public places, which include the skies above the island.

Wu says his youngest daughter, a one-year-old baby, was diagnosed as suffering from contact bronchitis, an ailment linked to passive smoking, after being a victim of second-hand smoke for several hours during a Northwest flight to San Francisco from Taipei on April 2.
He further says that his wife and two other daughters also suffered from the smoke during the entire flight trip, although they had been seated in a non-smoking cabin, but adjacent to a smoking area.

Wu sued the carrier in late July for compensation of NT$11.76 million (US$338,000). He describes the lawsuit as an action against Northwest Airlines' ignorance of Taiwan's smoking ban, and for its compromising of the health of his children.
Taiwan enacted tough anti-smoking legislation last September.
On Monday, Northwest was the subject of a boycott initiated by Taiwan's anti-smoking John Tung Foundation, which urged the island's residents not to fly with the company.
At a press conference held in Taipei, the foundation unveiled more than 20 other complaints similar to the Wu case.

The campaign has won the support of a number of leading welfare and human rights organizations on the island, including the Consumers' Foundation, the Chinese Association for Human Rights, and the Child Welfare Legal Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Swaziland's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade Albert Heshane Shabangu will arrive in Taiwan on Wednesday for a weeklong visit.

During his stay, Shabangu will call on President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew and other ranking officials. They will also visit key cultural and economic establishments, according to a press release from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The Republic of China and the Kingdom of Swaziland have maintained a close relationship since forging diplomatic ties in 1968. Shabangu's Taiwan visit is expected to further enhance the friendship and understanding between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILLING TO SHARE EXPERIENCE WITH NEIGHBORS: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: The seventh Taiwan-Philippines ministerial-level economic cooperation meeting kicked off in Manila on Tuesday, chaired jointly by Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang and Philippine Trade and Industry Secretary Jose Pardo.

In a keynote speech at the opening ceremony, Wang said the ROC is more than willing to share its development experience with friendly nations, and is not reluctant to help neighboring governments to stabilize their finances and revitalize their economies.
Wang also lauded Philippine President Joseph Estrada as a sagacious leader, saying that under Estrada's capable leadership, the Philippines' economy is sure to recover quickly.

For his part, Pardo praised Taiwan for its ability to remain relatively unscathed by the Asian financial crisis. He said he hopes that Taiwan, whose economic growth enjoyed an enviable 6.8 percent growth last year, will continue to strengthen trade and investment ties with the Philippines so as to help the Southeast Asian nation's economic recovery.

Pardo said he hopes to see the four panel discussions on trade and industrial cooperation, investment in tourism, agriculture, and labor affairs, expanded to five, to also discuss science and technology cooperation.
The annual meeting, attended by about 150 delegates from the two countries, is scheduled to wrap up on Wednesday.
Meanwhile, the 13th joint meeting of the Chinese-Philippine Business Council and the Philippine-Chinese Business Council is scheduled to open on Wednesday, also in Manila.

Philippine Labor Affairs Minister Bienvenido Laguesma met with his Taiwan counterpart Chan Huo-sheng on Tuesday afternoon for an exchange of views on labor cooperation between the two countries in advance of the main meeting.

Major topics to be discussed at the joint meeting will include investment, tourism, agriculture, food processing, technology information, electronics, and the development of industrial processing zones.

Jeffrey Koo, honorary chairman of the Chinese-Philippine Business Council, will be decorated on Wednesday by Estrada, in recognition of his contributions to bilateral economic exchanges between Taiwan and the Philippines.

The annual joint meeting of the two business councils has been held alternately in Taipei and Manila since 1984, greatly contributing to trade, business and investment cooperation between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS TO VISIT JAPAN TO DEFEND TAIWAN'S INTERESTS

TEXT.P: A group of 19 Taiwan legislators is scheduled to leave for Tokyo on Aug. 24 in an effort to defend Taiwan's interests prior to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's September visit to Japan, Legislative Yuan sources said on Tuesday.

The Legislative Yuan has decided to release a position paper on Thursday to make known its concerns about Jiang's upcoming trip, which may have an outcome harmful to Taiwan's interests, said Legislative Yuan Vice President Wang Chin-ping.

The position paper will carry statements using stronger language than that used by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), as the paper reflects the opinions of the parliament, rather than the government, said Wang.

Vice Foreign Minister David Lee visited the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday, bringing with him a copy of a proposed MOFA position paper to be used by the legislators as a reference when they are drafting their own position paper.

Wang said the Legislative Yuan paper will mainly call for Japan not to make any commitment during the summit between Jiang and Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi that may result in the undermining of the interests of the 21.5 million people of Taiwan.

During their two-day stay in Tokyo, members of the supra-party Legislative Yuan mission will meet with Sadanori Yamanaka, chairman of the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, Liberal Democratic Party heavyweights, members of Japanese opposition parties, and academic and media opinion leaders in Japan, said Wang.
However, he declined to disclose which of Obuchi's cabinet ministers the Taiwan legislators will meet with.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND ALLOWS ELDERLY TAIWAN TOURISTS LONGER STAYS

TEXT.P: Thailand is to allow tourists over the age of 55 from the Republic of China, mainland China, and Malaysia, to remain in the kingdom for up to a year on a tourist visa in 1998 and 1999, an Interior Ministry official said on Tuesday.
The Thai government will also allow Taiwan, Chinese and Malaysian tourists to apply for visas on arrival at any international airport in the kingdom, he said.
The proposal was approved at a recent joint meeting of the Interior Ministry, the Foreign Ministry, the Tourism Authority, and the Immigration Police.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS CHINESE IN JAPAN CALL FOR NO SUPPORT FOR `THREE NOES'
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-ming and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Members of the Taiwan community residing in Japan on Tuesday asked the Japanese government not to harm the interests of the Republic of China during the visit of mainland China's President Jiang Zemin in September.

Nearly 50 leaders of overseas Chinese organizations in Japan held a meeting in Tokyo in which they decided to submit written statements to the Japanese Diet, the Prime Minister's Office and other ministries.

In the statement, the leaders called for no Japanese support for the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan voiced by US President Bill Clinton during his recent visit to mainland China. They also urged the Japanese authorities not to make any compromises during the talks with Jiang which might harm the friendly Taipei-Tokyo relations.

The statement pointed out that China is now governed by two political entities -- the ROC and the People's Republic of China -- and that the ROC can contribute greatly to the international community if it is allowed to join international bodies.
The statement also urged Japan to keep the Taiwan Strait covered by the Japan-US defense pact, since it plays a crucial role in the safety and peace of the entire region.

The "three noes" are: no support for Taiwan independence; no support for "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas,"; and no support for Taiwan membership in international organizations in which a statehood is required.
Clinton's statement is regarded by both the ROC government and the people as having harmed Taiwan's national interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER MEETS PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Huang Hui-wen)

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada said on Tuesday that he is deeply impressed by Taiwan's excellent performance in the face of the Asian financial meltdown.

Estrada made the remarks during a meeting with a Republic of China delegation led by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang. The delegation is in Manila for the seventh ROC-Philippines ministerial-level economic cooperation conference which opened earlier in the day.

Estrada said that Taiwan's huge foreign exchange reserves, low foreign debt, and low inflation, has allowed the island to successfully weather the economic crisis which has battered many Asian nations. He added that the Taiwan experience can serve as a model for his own country.
Pointing out that the Philippines is adopting measures to improve its investment climate, Estrada expressed the hope that Taiwan businesses will invest in his country.

Wang for his part extended ROC President Lee Teng-hui's congratulations to Estrada for his recent election victory, and said that the many measures Estrada has taken since assuming office have greatly improved the country's social order, which will contribute to attracting foreign investment.
Wang said that Taiwan and the Philippines, with their close geographic, trade, and economic links, should join hands to help promote Asia's economic recovery.
Those accompanying Wang at the meeting included ROC Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chan Hou-sheng and ranking Philippine officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: US President Bill Clinton confesses to sexual relationship and apologizes for misleading the nation and his family.
The China Times: Clinton admitted to the American people in a televised speech late Monday that he had an "inappropriate" relationship with Monica Lewinsky and said he regretted misleading the nation and his family.
The United Daily News: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that Beijing's inability to face up to the reality will hamper China's unification.
The Liberty Times: Clinton admitted to the American people that he had an improper relationship with Monica Lewinsky.
The Independence Morning Post: Clinton said he deeply regretted that he had "misled people, including even my wife."
The Commons Daily: The ruling Kuomintang on Tuesday nominated 26 candidates for the year-end Kaohsiung City Council elections.
The China Post: The world pauses for Clinton's sex admission.
The China News: Clinton confesses to an improper relationship with Monica Lewinsky.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S SUPPORT FOR 'THREE NOES' UNCERTAIN: PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Tokyo is reportedly finding it difficult to codify the "three noes" policy with regard to Taiwan in joint official documents with Beijing, the Nihon Keizo Shimbun reported Wednesday.

Chinese President Jiang Zemin's scheduled visit to Japan in September has turned up the pressure for Japan to commit to the "three noes," which refers to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.

How Japan will respond to the mainland's request will become the focus of Jiang's visit to Japan. Beijing is expecting Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi to at least throw verbal support behind the "three noes," even if Tokyo does not give its written support for the policy in a bilateral joint document expected to be signed during the visit, the newspaper said.

Both the United States and Japan are cautious about signing formal documents with Beijing codifying their positions regarding the "three noes" despite the fact that the two countries have expressed their commitment to the policy to Beijing in the past, according to the newspaper.
US President Bill Clinton spelled out his support for the "three noes" at an informal roundtable meeting in Shanghai during his recent visit to the mainland.
