DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO RECRUIT MAINLAND CHINESE IC TALENT
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, Northern Taiwan, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should try to recruit integrated circuit (IC) talent and specialists from mainland China to boost its standing in the semiconductor industry, a US industry executive said on Wednesday.

Gerald Hsu, chairman of the Silicon Valley-based Avant Corporation!, the third largest semiconductor designing company in the world, said people's talent should transcend racial or political barriers as the industry does not recognize such differences.

He said Taiwan should follow the example of the United States which allows high-technology corporations to employ up to 15 percent foreign nationals. Talent from the mainland could help beef up the island's IC-designing capabilities, he added.

Hsu was speaking on global development trends in IC design at an international seminar held at the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park. He said the IC industry, which is gradually becoming a three-in-one industry comprised of IPR (intellectual property rights), EDA (electronic designing automation) and IC design manufacturing, is poised to become one of the most important high-technology industries in the world in the coming decade.

Hsu, who visits more than 1,000 semiconductor operators around the world annually, said he has high expectations for the long-term development of the semiconductor industry in Taiwan, which he foresees to be one of the last winners in a complete reshuffle of the industry worldwide as a result of the current global stagnation.

Compared to the United States, which has the strongest human resources of the semiconductor industry, Taiwan is rich in capital but has insufficient support machinery and facility industries, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SECURITY CHIEF COMMISSIONED TO MAKE AFRICAN VISIT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has officially asked Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, to lead a special delegation to the Kingdom of Swaziland and attend its 30th anniversary celebrations in September.

Ding and the delegation will set off for the African nation Sept. 2 and make a scheduled stopover in South Africa. They will then visit Malawi before heading to Swaziland, according to Presidential Office sources.
Ding was commissioned to take over the African visit from Premier Vincent Siew who underwent prostrate surgery in early August. Doctors recommended that Siew not take a long tour, sources said.
The special mission is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Sept. 10.
Ding, having served as the Republic of China's chief representative to the United States, has a background in foreign affairs. He has also made several previous visits to Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAGS BEHING OTHER ASIAN DRAGONS IN EXPORTS TO US
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan registered a modest 4 percent growth in its exports to the United States in the first half of this year, ranking third among the four Asian Dragons, according to statistics released by the US Department of Commerce on Tuesday.
The DOC tallies show that Taiwan exported US$15.8 billion worth of merchandise to the United States between January and June, marking a 4 percent year-on-year rise.

Compared with the three other Asian Dragons, Taiwan's growth rate far lagged behind South Korea's 19.1 percent and Hong Kong's 9.8 percent. Taiwan only preceded Singapore which saw a 4.9 percent decline in its exports to the United States during the six-month period.

According to DOC tallies, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$6.63 billion with the United States for the January-June period, up 16.2 percent from the year-earlier level. During the six-month period, Taiwan's imports from the United States increased 9.7 percent compared with the same period of 1997.
The same statistics show that Taiwan is now America's seventh largest trade partner and sixth largest source of its trade deficit.
Meanwhile, Taiwan became the eighth largest overseas market of US-made automobiles, down two slots from last year's rating.

Taiwan imported US$117 million worth of cars from the United States in the first six months of this year, marking a 56 percent drop from the year-earlier level. The plunge was attributed to significant depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback as well as a slowdown in Taiwan's economic growth.
During the same period, Taiwan also imported US$25 million worth of trucks and vans from the United States, in addition to US$39 million worth of US-made auto parts and components.

DOC.HEADLINE: 30 MAINLAND STOWAWAYS CAPTURED

TEXT.P: Republic of China marine authorities intercepted a human smuggling boat with 30 mainland Chinese nationals in the early hours Wednesday morning, in waters off of Tainan County.

Acting on several tips, three marine patrol boats converged upon waters off Mashago in Tainan County, southern Taiwan, at midnight Tuesday. Soon after, the patrol boats saw the Taipei County-registered fishing boat "Chindali" approaching the shore. Once the vessel docked, authorities apprehended the boat's passengers.
Marine police found 30 mainland Chinese men and five crew members aboard the fishing boat.

The mainlanders, all from Pingtan in Fujian Province, admitted to paying a "snake head" and were sneaking into Taiwan. A "snake head" refers to an underground figure who specializes in smuggling human cargo.
The fishing boat was escorted to the Taichung Port in central Taiwan Wednesday morning, and is under the custody of the Taichung marine police authorities.
Meanwhile, marine authorities announced that they seized a major haul of fish smuggled from the mainland to an area near Yeliu, northeastern Taiwan also in the wee hours of Wednesday.

The smuggled catch, including fresh-water shrimp, sea eels, and other fish and squid, was packed in 2,700 cartons concealed under the cabin of the Taipei County-registered fishing boat "Hungli No. 26," marine police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OAS TO WATCH REFERENDUM IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 18 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Organization of American States (OAS) will send a 15-member mission to observe the scheduled referendum in Panama on Aug. 30, the Foreign Ministry of Panama said in a news release.

The Foreign Ministry said the Panamanian envoy to Washington, Lawrence Chewning Fabrega, and OAS Secretary General Cesar Gaviria on Tuesday inked an agreement stating that the OAS would send an international observers' mission to the referendum.
Led by Santiago Murray, a specialist, the delegation is expected to arrive in Panama shortly. They will then travel throughout Panama to observe the referendum process.

The government, through the referendum, seeks to gain approval to amend the constitution permitting the president to run for another term, introduce an autonomy budget for the electoral tribune, and abolish the revocatory mandate of parliamentarians.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN CENTRAL BANK VOWS TO STABILIZE FINANCIAL MARKETS

TEXT.P: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has vowed to stabilize local financial markets and maintain current interest rates, despite a new wave of economic turmoil from Asia.

RBA officials said the central bank spent A$2.6 billion (US$1.63 billion) in June to halt a slump in the Australian dollar when it depreciated against the US dollar as a result of the Asian financial crisis and the plunge in the Japanese yen.
The officials said Australia's economic growth has slowed, and that the second wave of the Asian crisis has forced it to downgrade its gross domestic product to between 2 percent and 2.5 percent.
They also said that Australian exporters have switched to new non-Asian markets that are unaffected by the Asian regional crisis.
One major worry, however, is a rise in the unemployment level. Australia's jobless rate now hovers at around 8.2 percent, with about 750,000 people out of work.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S ADDRESS, AN END TO HIS PROBLEM OR START OF A CRISIS?

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's admission to the American people that he had an "inappropriate" relationship with Monica Lewinsky could either mark an end to a seven-month saga or the beginning of a political crisis.

In its editorial headlined "Clinton Takes Responsibility" on Wednesday, the Sydney Morning Herald said, "The most important question is whether it marks an end to something that has gone on far too long or the beginning of an even deeper descent into a debilitating political crisis."

"The US political system is a model of a free and open democracy. But in this affair the central forces -- the political parties, the media, the 'moral majority' -- within American democracy have produced a situation where the original cause is so out of proportion to its broad political effects the world stands amazed," the paper said.

The editorial noted that Clinton's admission could bring possible offenses against him which are being investigated by independent prosecutor Kenneth Starr. At the core is whether Clinton tried to convince Lewinsky and others to lie, obstruct justice or tamper with witnesses.

In an editorial headlined "Mr. Clinton's Desperate Performance" on Wednesday, the Australian said, "Central to whether US President Bill Clinton is impeached, is not whether he had sex with Monica Lewinsky, nor perhaps that he lied about it, but whether he tried to obstruct justice by getting her to alter her story, asked her to hide evidence or attempted to buy her silence by trying to get her a job."

"The President has scarcely been hypocritical in condemning adultery in others while conducting it himself. But undoubtedly Mr. Clinton's actions have damaged further his poor reputation of personal morality, while putting a cloud over the acknowledged achievements of his administration," the paper said.

"His address to the nation played to an audience that wants to put Monicagate behind it; that wants the US to concentrate on doing what it does best -- being the biggest and brashest country in the world," it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB TO OFFER US$140M LOAN FOR MAINLAND RAILWAY PROJECT

TEXT.P: The Asian Development Bank on Tuesday approved a loan of US$140 million to mainland China for the construction of a railway in Guizhou Province.

The project is expected to help boost employment and reduce poverty to one of the mainland's six poorest provinces. Over 92,000 people, or about 40 percent of the people living in the area, will likely benefit from improved living conditions and the 20,000 new jobs projected. The construction will also offer such basic social benefits as health coverage, education and communications network.

The 121-kilometer railway project aims to connect Liupanshui to Baiguo and is a part of Beijing's efforts to improve its railway system, considered one of the major constraints to efficient, sustained economic growth.
The ADB loan will finance 37 percent of US$381 million project. Guizhou Shuibai Railway Corporation and the State Development Bank will provide the remainder of the financing.

The ADB loan will be financed from ADB's ordinary capital resources at an interest rate determined in accordance with the bank's pool-based variable lending rate for US dollars. Repayment will be made over 25 years including a grace period of five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NZ PRIME MINISTER SURVIVES POLITICAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: New Zealand Prime Minister Jenny Shipley has survived the walkout of her former deputy and coalition partner Winston Peters with enough support in Parliament to maintain her hold on power.
Shipley secured support from 62 members of Parliament including 44 from her National Party, and several from Peters' New Zealand First Party.
Peters was sacked after challenging Shipley's leadership over differences which arose on the sale of the Wellington Airport. He will now become the opposition leader in the 120-seat Parliament.
With sufficient support for her Cabinet, Shipley will not be forced to announce an early election which had earlier been predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN MINISTERS OFFER TO MEDIATE IN DRC CONFLICT

TEXT.P: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo and Defense Minister Joe Modise left Pretoria for Rwanda Tuesday, according to a report from Cape Town.
South African Press Association said the visit appears to be a follow-up to earlier South African efforts to mediate a solution to the uprising in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC).
Nzo and Modise visited Lubumbashi in the DRC two weeks ago and held talks with DRC President Laurent Kabila.
Kabila was reportedly in Zimbabwe Tuesday, seeking help from that country as well as Angola and Namibia to defeat the Rwandan-backed rebel forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOMSON BANKWATCH DOWNGRADES CHINFON BANK OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Thomson Bankwatch, the world's largest bank rating agency, announced Tuesday the downgrading of the short-term local currency debt rating of Chinfon Bank of Taiwan from LC-2 to LC-3.
The bank rating agency said in a report that Chinfon Bank's weak overall performance in a more difficult market environment was the reason behind the downgrading.

Chinfon Bank was converted into a commercial bank in 1994 from its previous status as a trust and investment company. It has since experienced some difficulty in maintaining a satisfactory performance and been plagued by weak asset quality and profitability as well as low liquidity levels, the agency indicated.

The bank's overdue loan ratio was around 8 percent in the fiscal year 1997, one of the highest levels in the country, the agency reported. In addition, overdue loans were estimated at a huge 60 percent of total loan loss reserves and equity.

Chinfon Bank had low, worse-than-average liquidity ratios in the fiscal year 1997 and its deposit growth was mainly pushed by interbank deposits which are a less stable funding source than customer deposits, the report said.
The bank posted excessive exposure to the broad property sector, but aims at reducing it in the future and expanding its exposure to manufacturing industries, Thomson Bankwatch reported.
The bank rating agency provides research on over 1,000 financial institutions in more than 94 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'INFORMATION POVERTY' GAP IS WIDENING

TEXT.P: The distinction between developed and developing countries will no longer be measured by which has more roads or skyscrapers but by which has more Internet users or data transmission lines, a telecom executive said Tuesday.

Claudine Simson, vice president of Canada's Northern Telecom, told a conference of the Association of Commonwealth Universities in Ottawa that with the world increasingly turning to a knowledge-based economy, countries that do not make relevant skills training a priority will find themselves among the "info-poor."

"There is a real danger when so many countries do not have adequate 'infostructure.' Their people cannot connect with the rest of the world. They cannot participate in the global economy. And this is creating a new form of poverty -- information poverty -- and the gap is widening," she said.
Conference data showed that industrialized countries are home to 84 percent of the world's mobile-phone users, 91 percent of all fax machines, and 97 percent of all Internet host computers.
Simson said universities have to make a concerted effort to provide high-tech training to their students so there will be an adequate labor force available for the burgeoning digital economy.
Distance learning is one of the new concepts that universities, particularly in the developing world, are starting to embrace as a method of providing access to a cutting-edge education.
Ranjith Arthenayake, vice-chancellor of the Open University of Sri Lanka, said the developing world has much to gain by the cost-effectiveness, accessibility and flexibility of distance learning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PUSHING FOR 2ND KOO-WANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China official in charge of cross-strait affairs said here on Monday that Taiwan is doing its best to push for a second meeting between the top negotiators on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lin Chong-ping, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), reiterated that Taiwan stands firm on its policy that Taiwan and mainland China must continue their exchanges, despite the chill which has descended on bilateral relations following the recent kidnap-murder of a Taiwan city councilwoman in mainland China.

The MAC vice chairman, who flew into San Francisco earlier on Monday from Los Angeles, made the remarks while answering questions at a seminar on cross-strait ties. Tseng Ching-yuan, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in San Francisco, together with more than 50 academics, attended the seminar.

Lin added, however, that it depends on mainland China's attitude whether or not the second meeting will take place this fall as scheduled between Koo Chen-fu, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) chairman, and his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Lin called on mainland China to forswear its Cold War ideology in its dealings with Taiwan, because it adversely affects Taiwan people's feelings toward the mainland, and hinders the process of China's unification.
He admitted that mainland China's drive to push Japan into emulating the United States by declaring support for the "three noes" regarding Taiwan will result in greater pressure on the island.
But Lin asserted that Taiwan will not deviate from its policy of continued exchanges and negotiations with the mainland. Time will prove this policy correct, he added.

Beijing may believe that the international situation is in its favor, and refuse to lessen its efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international community, Lin analyzed. He pointed out that such an approach will only further hurt bilateral ties and serve to illustrate that Beijing's policy contradicts its stated goals.

Lin, who formerly taught at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., said that in the wake of US President Bill Clinton's recent visit to mainland China, Washington-Beijing ties have reached a point that makes it hard for them to see any major breakthroughs in the near future.
The two countries are more likely to devote their efforts over the next two years to resolving disputes over human rights, trade friction, and weapons proliferation, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA INTERVIEW WITH DAVID MULRONEY, DIRECTOR OF THE CANADIAN TRADE OFFICE IN TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Q: How do you feel so far? What are you going to do in the future to promote the bilateral relationship between Taiwan and Canada?

Mulroney: Well, so far I feel very excited and positive about my mew responsibilities and about living here in Taipei. I arrived here with my family two weeks ago. So I am still a relatively new comer. But we have been very impressed by what we've seen, not just the dynamism of downtown -- I think we expected a little bit of that -- it certainly lived up to our expectations, but also the natural beauty of the surroundings and the city -- the mountains, the backdrop. We were very impressed by that. We've been up to Yangmingshan. So it's going to be a very enjoyable and interesting place to live professionally. Although we have been busy -- we had a delegation of MP's in, we had Canadian business people, and we've had Canadian cultural performers coming in this weekend. So it's a very active place to promote Canadian interests.

My own objectives are tow-fold. I think that the impression of Canada in Taiwan is very positive. But I think it can be expanded on, and that he job will take a long time and a lot of efforts. But it really is one of the basic jobs of this office. And that is to say that not only is Canada a big country and it's a beautiful country, with the mountains and variety, and it's a friendly country, but it is also a technologically sophisticated country. It has technologies that are of interest to Taiwanese entrepreneurs. It is a multi-cultural country. It is a diverse country in terms of its cultural performances. It is a country with high-quality educational services. So not just Canada of the pictures you see, but we'd like to create a new image of Canada which is even more interesting. Perhaps the image is not a widely recognized one -- that's our responsibility to convey that.

Similarly, I think that for Canadians they need to study and see how quickly Taiwan is changing. Because Taiwan is changing so quickly, inevitably perceptions will lag behind a few years. We'd like them to realize the spirit and entrepreneurship in Taiwan, the kind of technology in Taiwan that is advancing, and the opportunities for collaboration between Taiwanese investors and Canadian investors perhaps at third markets. Certainly Canadians are taking note of the fact that Taiwan has not been unaffected by the Asian problems, is surviving and handling the situation much better than most of its neighbors. And that realization will lead people to think why is that the case. And I think they will come back to look at the fundamentals of the economy, the number of very innovative and flexible smaller companies, the soundness of the financial sector. So we think we can also encourage Canadians to look for new opportunities in Taiwan toward a two-fold communications challenge. I categorize the relationship as positive.

We look at our trade -- it's currently at about 5 billion Canadian dollars. Yesterday, in addressing our parliamentarians, President Lee Teng-hui said that is not enough. That's right. I think we can do more. There is beginning of a two-way investment. But again we can agree to do more there. And we are working very hard through our trade section to bring venture capitalists from Taiwan to Canada to look for opportunities, and to bring Canadians investors here to look for opportunities. We can do more of that. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT (2)
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: We have a people-to-people exchange that brings 100,000 Taiwanese visitors to Canada. We'd like to see that increased. We'll be expanding our visa issuing capacity here. As you can see, we have some space constraints in the office we are in. We have now secured the budget to expand the size and also to hire more people, so we can facilitate things there.

We have a Canadian education center that is already introducing Canadian schools, Canadian education to prospective students from Taiwan. We're very enthusiastic about that. The office has already mounted some road shows that are taking the message out to other places. We want to do even more of that, because we think that Canada not only offers its benefits in attempts of having high-quality universities coast to coast, but it also offers an attractive living environment. If you are sending your most precious possessions, that is, your children, overseas to universities, I think that parents can feel at ease knowing they are going to Canada, knowing they are going to cities like Vancouver, Toronto, London, Montreal or Halifax. So we have a good story to tell there.

As far as cultural exchanges are concerned, I think we made a very good start. And there is even more we can do tomorrow night. For example, we have a concert of Canadian performer who is increasingly well-known in Taiwan. We have other projects we are looking at. We see Canadian performers come here and also see Taiwanese performers go to Canada. That again helps to contribute to the broadening and growth of awareness of what each place is really like. Is it a job you can do in six months? No, it's not a job you can do in six years. You must continually -- continually work because there are so many competing interests for both Canada and Taiwan, for example. The US is obviously a large, attractive and dominant cultural force and business presence. And that's good, but that's means we have to work even harder to say: when you look at northern America, don't just look at the US. Take a look at Canada, too. So, this office has been working very hard. And we will continue to do that.
Q: You mentioned trade, economic, cultural, people-to-people exchanges. How about expansion of exchanges in the political area, such as high-level visits between Taiwan and Canada?

Mulroney: What we look at when we look at the visits and exchanges is a question of substance where we can advance key issues in those areas and priorities, like economic exchanges and cultural exchanges, and visits should serve that purpose. They should also fit in with the overall context of our policy, our international policy. And where we can do that, we support such policy. And I think we have an exchange now that really is mutually beneficial, but is consistent with our policy.

Q: President Lee Teng-hui said yesterday when meeting with Canadian parliamentarians that there are still trade barriers on both sides. What concrete measures are you going to take in order to eliminate various barriers? Could you be more specific on how you are going to do more? (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT (3)
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mulroney: I think the best single way of eliminating any existing trade barriers is for Taiwan to exceed and take up all the rights and responsibilities of WTO membership. We did talk about this a little bit yesterday. Where does Canada stand on this? Well, we support Taiwan's accession to the WTO as an important economy, and it makes obvious sense for this to happen. We have been very close to achieving an agreement with Taiwan. We reached this point last fall, and we only left a few issues to be resolved until we finally sign the agreement.

We also had the understanding that in any other negotiations that Taiwan had with other contracting parties of the WTO, any special provisions will be done on a MFN basis, meaning everybody will enjoy. So, where we, for example, made progress in areas like financial services, specifically private banking, those benefits would apply to all WTO members. So we weren't just doing it for Canada -- of course, that was one dimension -- we were doing it in the spirit of the WTO. Subsequently, we lost ground on some of those issues. There are some agricultural issues, there is the issue of private banking. We lost ground. We weren't able to see the results we thought we would see. And in addition, when Taiwan concluded its agreement with the US, there was a provision allowing American suppliers early access -- pre-accession access -- to the market here for certain meat products.

What we are saying is: we would like to conclude the agreement, which means meeting the undertakings that we agreed on in the fall. And we are disappointed that in the negotiations with the US, they were given the special one-on-one deal. And I should be very clear on this. We are not asking for some special benefits for Canadians only. What we are saying is that we believe that the spirit of the WTO is such that there should be uniformity and a level playing field. And we've asked to sit down again, so that we can quickly resolve the issues that are outstanding. We really do think we need to resolve them before we sign the agreement. I'm confident we can do this, and in discussions with the appropriate authorities here to make sure that that can happen. So, we're disappointed that we haven't signed already, but we are confident that we can bring our negotiators back together and discuss this issue quickly, and we can resolve them.
Q: Rumors have said that Canada will be the last one to sign the WTO deal with Taiwan. Is that true?

Mulroney: No, not true. We want to sign it as soon as we settle these issues, because, as I said, we support Taiwan's accession. We think it's important. But we really do. These issues are important to our exporters, but they are also important because that's what the WTO is all about. It's about a level playing field, it's about transparency, and it's about the same advantages applying to all. So there is a point of principle here that I think we have to make. And I think other contracting parties share those views.

Q: Every relationship has its ups and downs. Can we say that when the Maersk Dubai (ship) case happened, that was the time when the bilateral relationship between Taiwan and Canada was down. How do you evaluate the relationship at present. Can we call it a good time? Or can we say it's somewhere right in the middle? (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT (4)
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mulroney: I would say it's a good time. And I would say also that if we look at the Maersk Dubai case, people worked very hard to find a solution; that the most important consideration was the judicial review, an examination to see whether alleged criminal acts had indeed taken place; that this be brought before the appropriate court of law. And I think the result that prevailed which saw the sailors returned for trial or prosecution here in Taiwan was the appropriate result, and the best result in the interests of justice. For that to happen, there was dialogue; there was, I think, a degree of understanding achieved. So I don't think that as a bad point in relationship. I think it shows the vitality of the relationship.

Right now, in any relationship, there are going to be some disagreements and irritations. You look at the Canada-US relationship. It's tremendously positive, but we often have disagreements on trade issues, for example. This is the nature of relationships. I think our relationship with Taiwan -- if you look at the number of exchanges I outlined at the beginning -- the size of the trade, the growth of investment, people flying back and forth -- you have to categorize it as very positive.
Q: Do you expect the Dubai case to have any new developments after the Filipinos get their citizenship in Canada?

Mulroney: Well, they were allowed to remain in Canada on compassionate grounds, but we are simply awaiting the results of the prosecution in Kaohsiung. And we have always said we are willing to furnish evidence that was collected in the course of the judicial review in Canada, should that be required by the authorities. So we simply await results from Kaohsiung.

Q: You mentioned the Canada-US relationship. People in Taiwan are curious. They are sensitive about the "three-noes" statement by US President Bill Clinton. Will that have any impact on Canada's China policy?

Mulroney: Canada's China policy is a "made-in-Canada" policy. It (the statement) does not substantially in any way change Canada's relationship with China or anywhere in the region. We maintain a one-China policy. And within that, there is much that we can do, for example, in terms of our relationship with Taiwan. We are cognizant of the realities of the situation locally, and we try to ensure that whatever we do is for the benefit of people in the region and contributes to the ultimate peaceful resolution of the (Taiwan) issue. So I think we have been pragmatic in terms of always seeking to develop a relationship within limits of a clearly defined policy. And I think we've been successful to date.
Q: One of the "three noes" is that the US will not support Taiwan's entry into any organization for which statehood is required. What is Canada's position?

Mulroney: Canada is supportive of Taiwan's participation in organizations like the WTO and like APEC. Other cases we have not been able to support, such as the UN application. But by and large, we support Taiwan's participation in fora that fit within the criteria of our policy. But that being said, there has been much that we can do, and we have encouraged Taiwan's participation in fora where that is not an issue.
Q: On the people-to-people exchange, will the Canadian government consider giving visa-free treatment to Taiwanese tourists? (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT (5)
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Q: On the people-to-people exchange, will the Canadian government consider giving visa-free treatment to Taiwanese tourists? Mulroney: First of all, the most important thing is, people should be able to travel to Canada as quickly and easily as possible. And I think our office issued 140,000 visas last year. We offer very quick service -- normally 24 to 48 hours. So we are confident that we are not unduly holding people up.

Why do we impose a visa? I think the main problem is that there have been attempts by people -- not Taiwanese, but from outside of Taiwan to use or misuse a Taiwanese passport to travel to countries like Canada. We've had numerous cases recently where people had obtained Taiwanese passports fraudulently and attempt to illegally enter Canada. Normally they obtain this by first obtaining an identity card. My understanding of the situation is the passport is very difficult to counterfeit or obtain illegally; the identity card is a little bit easier to obtain. And because we have this concern about the illegal entry into Canada by people from outside of Taiwan, we have had to maintain the visa waiver. We are in discussion with the authorities here. We talked about enhanced security measures, and I think if we solve that problem, we go a long way towards solving the visa issue. But that is an issue that has still remained.
Q: Are those people from mainland China that use forged ID to get passports? And how many of them are we talking about?
Mulroney: I don't have precise numbers. But I think it's over 100 within the last year, and primarily from mainland China.
Q: What was the local authorities' response?
Mulroney: My understanding is that the identity card is under review and there will be new measures to ensure it's more secure. But that's going to take some time.
Q: What kind of role do Taiwanese immigrants play in Canada? Are they worried about anti-immigrant sentiments Taiwan immigrants are now facing in Australia?

Mulroney: Before I left Canada -- I have been living in Toronto -- I stopped in Vancouver and met with groups of entrepreneurs who recently arrived in probably five or six different groups. We sat down and I chatted with them about their experiences, how they thought about Canada, what it was like to come to Canada, and some of the services and things we might be able to provide before they leave. I can tell you categorically everything I heard in my own experience is that it's very positive. You have seen Vancouver. Toronto is equally multicultural, because so many Canadians have come from other countries. They are very very welcoming, because they also see the success and contribution that the Taiwanese immigrants have made. And that is undeniable. It's a positive experience.

We're conscious of the fact that we are sort of the first Canadian -- the window with a doorway on Canada. So from the moment they come here, we are trying to create the most positive impression and I think that's something that continues right through to their arrival in whatever city they go to. So all the stories I've heard were positive. And think the prevailing sense in Canada is highly positive. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT (6)
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 17 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Q: Anything else you would like to add?

Mulroney: No, just -- I guess my enthusiasm for being here. I very much look forward to -- I got a lot of people I want to see and call on here in Taipei, but I also want to get out and see other parts of Taiwan and meet people because we have to take our story out to other places. We have to meet people. I'm very proud of this office. It provides good service, and we are committed to service, always looking our service statement which is on the wall -- it's "Always look for feedback and comments." And we want to create as welcoming and as positive an experience for people here as we can. That's really my fundamental job.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGES ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices surged on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, rising 111.81 points to close at 7293.4.
Encouraged by a price surge in the New York Stock Exchange, the local bourse opened at 7261.85 points, 80.26 higher than Tuesday closing.
A total of 1.61 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.61 billion (US$2.55 billion).

Electrical shares rose the most at 2.3 percent, followed by financial shares at 1.9 percent; plastic and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent; textile shares at 1 percent; cement stocks at 0.6 percent; and construction shares 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff shares dropped 0.2 percent, while pulp and paper issues fell 0.7 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures posted a general increase.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September rose 65 point to close at 7,285 with 543 contract transactions, while those for December dropped 78 points to 7,405 with two contract transactions.
The TAIEX Index Futures for March moved up 186 points to close at 7,598, with two contract transactions. No transactions were registered for October and next June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were listed as follows: 7,220 points for September; 7,200 for October; 7,483 for December; 7,412 for March; and 7,589 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped NT$0.035 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Wednesday, closing at NT$34.699.
The greenback opened at 34.695 and was traded between 34.695 and 34.730.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$297 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA SAID RISING TO LOCAL POLITICS
DOC.DATELINE: Tainan, southern Taiwan, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The anti-impotency drug Viagra has emerged as a new campaign tool in the southern county of Tainan, even though the "small blue pill" has not yet been legally marketed in Taiwan.

Local political sources say many of those who intend to run in the year-end legislative elections in this agricultural constitutency are cashing in on the recent worldwide craze for Viagra to boost their electoral bids.

Although the elections are still more than three months away, campaign activities have been gradually heating up. The ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) have nominated a total of 11 candidates to vie for the nine regional legislative seats up for grabs in the county, while 14 other hopefuls have also expressed the intention of joining in the race. Against this background, competition is expected to be very fierce.
It has long been a common practice in local society for political candidates to present gifts to community leaders and other influential figures as part of their campaign strategies.

Gift-giving is an art, and it requires wisdom to choose suitable gifts. Over the past few years, red wine has become the most popular and welcome campaign booster. However, the popularity of wine seems to have diminished, to be replaced by Viagra as the most favored vote-getting gift.
Political sources say both KMT and DPP candidates have asked their friends and supporters in the medical community to help them smuggle Viagra into Taiwan.

One DPP candidate for the upcoming elections was quoted as saying that Viagra has proved to be a useful "advance deployment" for the year-end elections. "Response from recipients has been fervent and uplifting," he said.

The candidate further said Viagra has become a symbol of a person's influence or clout in local politics. "With a Viagra tablet in your hand, you will attract much more attention than if you are wearing a big diamond ring," he said.
Viagra is also an effective tool for forging ties with political heavyweights. "A sense of familiarity wells up when you exchange views or information about Viagra with them."

Some local politicians have said that if the KMT wants to win a majority in the legislature, it should not belittle the importance of the tablets. "It should instead legalize imports of Viagra as soon as possible to ensure a year-end victory."
Sex and politics have been described as the "drug of choice" for many men. From a psychological standpoint, the DPP candidate said, Viagra might well emerge as the best popularity riser of all.
There have been a wide variety of campaign gimmacks in the past, ranging from performances on the back of trucks by scantily-clad dancers, to entertaining potential supporters in clubs or bars.
Vigara seems to have replaced all of these, perhaps heralding the arrival of the "fast food" age in local politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The government will spend more than NT$1 trillion on public construction projects to help stimulate domestic demand.
The China Times: The director of the Asian Affairs Bureau of the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Wednesday that Japan will not codify the "three noes" over Taiwan.
The United Daily News: The Taiwan Provincial Government will be completely "marginalized" and related legislation will be finalized by the end of October.
The Liberty Times: The ruling Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party have reached a consensus that the Taiwan Provincial Government will be marginalized lke the Fukien Provincial Government.
The Independence Morning Post: Prosecution and police authorities will form the backbone of the anti-organized crime forces.
The Commons Daily: The Taiwan Provincial Government will be thoroughly marginalized.
The China Post: PRC makes new offer on Taiwan chief negotiator's visit.
The China News: Police are now free to wiretap.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER DENIES US$10M LOAN REPORT

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu denied on Wednesday that the Republic of China promised to give a US$10 million loan to Guatemala to help it with agricultural development.

Hu, who returned to Taipei from a trip to Paraguay, where he attended President Raul Cubas Grau's inauguration, said at the airport that a foreign news agency's report on the Taiwan loan was absolutely untrue.
Hu is scheduled to fly to El Salvador next week to attend a multilateral economic conference, and will proceed to Guatemala for an official visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN INSURANCE FIRMS REJECT CLAIMS FOR Y2K LOSSES

TEXT.P: Australian insurance firms will not cover any claims for losses incurred by the millennium bug and a battle appears to be looming between these companies and their clients.

The Insurance Council of Australia has issued over 500 million brochures to business policy holders, warning them that insurance companies will not cover any losses or claims from the bug also known as Y2K.
An earlier global survey indicated that losses from the Y2K could exceed US$600 billion. In Australia, the losses are estimated at several billions of dollars.

The warning seeks to absolve insurance companies of direct responsibility for Y2K claims. It in effect moves the insurance liability up the purchasing chain to vendors and manufacturers, according to the Australian Financial Review.
The daily reported the insurance industry in Australia is fighting to protect insurers from Y2K claims from this sector as well.

The daily quoted Alan Asher, deputy chairman of the Australian Consumer Competition Commission, as saying that consumers and small businesses have the right to demand that vendors refund, replace or repair Y2K non-compliant systems bought less than three years ago.

Retailers forced to pay claims involving Y2K-defective products could seek compensation from either their manufacturer suppliers or their insurers under product liability or product guarantee policies, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMIC GROWTH DOWN SLIGHTLY IN JUNE

TEXT.P: Australia's economy dropped slightly in June from May amid the Asian economic crisis, which hit local share market and the non-residential building sector.

The leading index of economic activity produced by Westpac Banking Corp. and the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research (MIAESR) showed that economic growth fell by 0.2 percent in June from May.
This translated into an annualized growth rate of the index down from a revised reading of 3.3 percent in May to 2.9 percent in June.

The figures indicated that the result of the June decline was largely due to the decline in Australian share market and the drop in the non-residential building approvals recorded in June from the previous month.

"The economies of the Asia Pacific region are likely to remain in recession for the rest of the year, although the composite Asian Pacific leading index suggests a trough may be near," the MIAESR report said.

"Whilst the growth rate of the leading index has fallen by only 0.4 percent, the important message is that the index is now on a much lower growth path than last month," Wespect's general manager Bill Evans said.

He said the leading index of inflation in Australia also fell to 4.9 percent in June from 5.1 percent in May. "This is the lowest level of the index since January this year, indicating that inflationary pressures remain subdued," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS EXPLAIN REASONS OF FLOODS IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The floods devastating mainland China's Yangtze basin may be an act of nature, but deforestation and extensive land development have also played a hand, conservationists and water experts said.
An official account of the damages caused by the floods so far include over 2,000 people killed, 13.8 million rendered homeless, and 11 million acres of the nation's cropland destroyed.

The transportation of both goods and people has also been disrupted by the closing of roads, rail lines and docks. The overall effect on the Chinese economy will be felt for many months, Lester Brown, president of the Washington-based WorldWatch Institute, predicted.

The conservation expert noted that Beijing is treating this disaster as an act of nature, and indeed, floods during the monsoon season from June through September in southern China are a regular occurrence. However, there is also a human hand in this year's floods in the form of deforestation and extensive land development.

Brian Halweil, WorldWatch staff researcher and a specialist in water resources, noted that the Yangtze basin is home to 400 million people, making it one of the most densely populated river basins on earth. This density puts intense pressure on the land.

To begin with, the Yangtze River basin, which originates on the Tibetan Plateau, has lost 85 percent of its original forest cover. The forests that once absorbed and held huge quantities of monsoon rainfall, which could then percolate slowly into the ground, are now largely gone. The result is a much greater runoff of water into the river, said Halweil.

The construction of buildings and roads in the basin is increasing at a staggering pace. With the average household in mainland China consisting of fewer than four people, a population of 400 million means 100 million housing units. And land hunger is forcing more and more homes to be built on the river flood plain.

The water resources expert added that the extent of factory construction also defies the imagination. Although there is no precise data on the size of the industrial workforce in the basin, a rough estimate would be at least 50 million. With the average factory in the private sector employing fewer than 100 people, this means half a million factories.

Each factory needs a warehouse to store raw materials coming into the factory and for the finished products while they await shipment. Each factory must also have a road connecting it with the rest of the country. Collectively, these homes, factories and roads cover a vast area, further reducing the capacity of the land to absorb rainfall.

At the global level, Brown noted, the human influence on the floods is less direct but no less real. The global temperature during the first seven months of this year was the highest of any comparable period on earth. Furthermore, the month of July was the warmest month since record keeping began in 1866.

Higher temperatures mean more evaporation, more intense storms, and more rapid snow melt. All three can be contributing to the floods. While there is no way of conclusively linking global warming to specific weather events, the likelihood that they are linked has grown with each passing year in which higher temperatures are accompanied by more extreme weather events. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOODS IN MAINLAND CHINA (Part II)

TEXT.P: That higher temperatures mean more evaporation is certain. And when more moisture goes up, more comes down. Where it comes down is less predictable. But the Yangtze basin may well be one of the areas receiving some of the additional rainfall.

Another likely effect is more intense monsoons -- the result of seasonal warming over the continents as summer unfolds. As temperatures climb over the land, air rises, pulling moisture-laden air from the oceans inland. The higher the temperature over the land, the stronger the monsoon, according to Brown.

Higher global temperatures are also leading to increased snow melt. "We don't know with certainty whether the temperature has risen this year in the snow-covered regions that feed the upper Yangtze, but, given the dramatic rise in the global average in recent months, it likely has," said the conservation expert.

With the international community unable to agree on a meaningful effort to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, rising atmospheric levels of this greenhouse gas promise even higher temperatures in the future with the potential for more evaporation, more rainfall, and even stronger monsoons.
While the Yangtze flood may be the worst in 44 years, Brown said, "We can expect even worse floods in years ahead."
If the basin adds another 100 million people as projected over the next few decades, China will need to build another 25 million homes.

As industrialization continues at a rapid pace, factory and road construction will also continue, further reducing the area of land that can absorb water and increasing the amount that will ultimately flow into the Yangtze, added Halweil.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, INDIA TO FORGE INVESTMENT GUARANTEE PACT

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to sign an investment guarantee agreement with India later this month to further bolster economic ties between the two countries, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

Lin Neng-chung, director general of MOEA's Industrial Development and Investment Center, confirmed that he will lead a Taiwan mission to New Delhi at the end of this month to meet with Indian officials to sign the agreement.

Lin said a department director of the Indian Economics Ministry surnamed Kumar was instrumental in the bilateral investment guarantee pact. Kumar discussed the initiative with MOFA during his visit to Taipei last year.
India, formerly a closed market, took to liberalizing its economy after adopting a free-market policy in 1991.

Although two-way trade between India and Taiwan has been insignificant in the past, it posted an increase of 30 percent last year compared to the year-earlier level amounting to US$1.21 billion, with Taiwan's exports to India totaling US$549 million and imports at US$662 million.
As of June this year, Taiwan investment in India totaled about US$36.1 million.
India will be the 18th country to sign an investment guarantee agreement with Taiwan. Costa Rica and Guatemala are also planning to sign similar pacts with Taiwan, said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC AMBASSADOR SPEAKS ON GOVERNMENT'S MAINLAND POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China continues to ban direct links with mainland China for the sake of national security and the welfare of the people, Loh I-cheng, former ambassador to South Africa said on Wednesday.

Loh, leading an ROC academic delegation, was speaking at the Fairbank Center for East Asian Research at Harvard University in Boston. He was responding to professor Roderick MacFarquhar's question of why Taiwan was dragging its feet in establishing the three direct links -- trade, postal and transportation -- with the mainland.

Loh said President Lee Teng-hui's "go slow, be patient" policy toward investing in the mainland aims to keep the root of enterprises on the island so that the lifeline of Taiwan's economy will not fall into the hands of the mainland.
He also said Beijing's promotion of its "one country, two systems" model for unification was to lure Taiwan into its fold, and is itself a contradictory and unworkable idea.

Professor Leng tze-kang of National Chengchi University said Beijing's proposal of establishing the three direct links have economic as well as political concerns, and the ROC government has to respond cautiously.
Taiwan should not stall on the issue of direct links, professor Joseph Fewsmith of Boston University suggested, but instead engage in serious talks with Beijing.

In response, professor Chiou Chao-lin of National Taiwan University said Beijing has turned to the United States after failing to pressure Taipei into such talks. The mainland is using its relationship with the US to force Taiwan to the negotiating table.

She urged the US not to cave into such pressure. Washington should not decide the future of Taiwan through its talks with Beijing, but maintain parallel relations with Taiwan to promote positive exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lin Wen-cheng of National Chung Cheng University suggested that both sides of the strait could start with technical issues before turning their attention to political issues.

Loh and his delegation left Taiwan for the US on Aug. 11. Since his arrival, he has met with US media such as the Boston Globe and Christian Science Monitor, academic figures as well as members of think tanks.
The delegation visited New York and Washington D. C. before going to Boston. Their next stop will be Los Angeles and they are due to return to Taiwan on Aug. 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH WARNS AGAINST CHOLERA IN INDIA

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) on Friday said those traveling to India should be on special guard against cholera.

Noting that New Delhi has recorded 534 cases of cholera in July, up from 229 cases during the same period last year, DOH officials urged Taiwan tourists to avoid eating raw food and to pay particular attention to personal hygiene.
The sharp increase in cholera could be attributed to water shortages in New Delhi in July, resulting in problems in water hygiene, they said.

India's rainy season, which is between July and October in New Delhi, is especially susceptible to the spread of malaria and dengue fever, officials noted. The number of deaths from dengue fever numbered over 500 in New Delhi last year, they added.

The officials also urged the public to be vigilant against mosquito bites when traveling in Southeast Asian nations. Those feeling unwell and who are suffering from fever and rashes -- symptoms of dengue fever -- should seek immediate medical assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'SHI-TANG MEETING' A MATTER OF PRINCIPLE
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Aug. 19 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The day-to-day affairs managers of the two intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait must meet as a matter of principle prior to a meeting between the top leaders of the organizations, a visiting ROC official said Wednesday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks after learning that the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) had invited Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China to make a week-long visit to Beijing and Shanghai either on Sept. 15-21 or on Oct. 12-18.

ARATS said in its Aug. 19 letter to its Taipei counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), that SEF Chairman C.F. Koo is also welcome to visit other mainland cities if desired. It further said Koo can freely exchange views with ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan on matters of mutual concern or issues either side is interested in discussing.
ARATS also said that if necessary, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Chi-horng may travel to the mainland again to put final touches on Koo's itinerary.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Responding to ARATS' invitation, Lin said Taiwan still hopes that the "responsible persons" of the two intermediary bodies -- namely SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow and ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei -- can first meet to outline an agenda for the much-anticipated Koo-Wang meeting.

"This is a matter of principle that the high-profile Koo-Wang meeting is preceded by a Shi-Tang meeting. Otherwise, we'll see a scenario that mainland China unilaterally decides the levels and the delegates for all future cross-strait talks," Lin said.

However, Lin would not say whether a Shi-Tang meeting is a prerequisite for the long-stalled Koo-Wang meeting. He simply said that without a Shi-Tang meeting, it may be difficult for Koo to meet his ARATS counterpart.
Reports from Taipei quoted SEF officials as saying there are practical reasons for holding a Shi-Tang meeting which would pave the way for a summit meeting between the two intermediary bodies.

Lin arrived in San Francisco earlier this week to attend a seminar on the current state of cross-strait ties and Taiwan's mainland policy. He said here on Monday that ARATS officials were not fully authorized to discuss issues related to Koo's planned mainland visit during their two meetings with SEF officials held earlier this year.
"The ARATS officials only brought with them 'several pieces of paper and a pencil' and didn't show sincerity in discussing practical issues," Lin noted.
SEF is under the supervision of the Mainland Affairs Council.
Lin left here for Vancouver, Canada Wednesday afternoon for a speech tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINE YOUTHS CONQUER S.E. ASIAN PEAK
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of 16 youths from Taiwan's aboriginal Bunun tribe on Thursday scaled Southeast Asia's highest peak, making them the youngest to successfully challenge Mount Kinabalu in Malaysia.
The mountain stands 4,095 meters above sea level and is located in the northeast region of Sarawak and Sabah states.

The 16 youngsters, aged between 9 and 13, erected a Republic of China national flag on the top of Mount Kinabalu to mark their achievement. Their leader John Wu, principal of the Tungpu Primary School of Hsinyi Hsiang in Nantou County, also performed a sun-worshiping ritual to express the group's exhilaration.

The Bunun team arrived in Sabah's capital of Kota Kinabalu Monday and proceed to climb the 3,300-meter Crocker Rang the next day. After the one-day warm-up exercise, the young Bunun climbers scaled Mount Kinabalu Thursday morning.
This expedition follows the group's successful attempt last year up Mount Jade, Taiwan and Northeast Asia's highest peak.

According to team coach Wu Ah-hao, a Bunun tribeswoman in her 40s and a trained athlete from the Taipei Physical Education College, the youths are good hikers because of their Bunun blood. The Bunun people, indigenous to Mount Jade and Taiwan's Central Mountain Range, are brave people and are born athletes, she said.

To qualify for the team, each member had to pass a two-week test in steep hiking conditions in Tatajia, a 2,400-meter range of Mount Jade. After the Tatajia test, the youths ran up the 2,881-meter Lulin Mountain. Those who could not sustain the physical challenge failed to make the team.

Team leader Wu Hung-sheng, 12, said he wanted to challenge Mount Kinabalu for his father, a Bunun mountain climber who died during a rescue mission in Hsuehshan, a high-altitude mountain range in central Taiwan several years ago.

Other group members include Wu Li-wei and Wu Shih-wei, 11-year-old twin brothers, who come from a mountain climbing family. Their grandfather carried the bronze statue of Yu You-jen, the late president of the Control Yuan, the ROC's highest watchdog agency, to the top of Mount Jade where it sat until recently.
Among the 16 youths, four are girls. Their gender by no means makes them physically inferior to their boy peers, coach Wu said.
The team is scheduled to return to Taiwan Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA INTERVIEW WITH ROC DEFENSE MINISTER CHIANG

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling of the Republic of China on Taiwan said Thursday that Taiwan will eventually serve as a good model for the development of the Chinese nation in the future, but it has to strengthen its armed forces at the present time.
Chiang made the remarks in an interview with the CNA on the eve of the 40th anniversary of the Taiwan Strait Crisis, which began on Aug. 23, 1958.
During the 44-day crisis, the People's Liberation Army of communist China pounded the islands of Kinmen with 474,000 artillery shells with a purpose to seize the islands and conquer Taiwan.

The event marks the starting point of different economic and political development on Taiwan and the Chinese mainland. Taiwan's policy to develop an export-oriented economy and constitutional democracy has led to economic prosperity and social stability, while the series of disastrous social movements, including the Great Leap Forward and the Great Culture Revolution, have resulted in long years of social and economic turmoil on the Chinese mainland, Chiang said.

Beijing's awakening to the reality and adopting the "reform and openness" policy have clearly shown that all Chinese people welcome democracy and freedom, and look forward to the improvement of their living conditions, Chiang said.

"China will be eventually united under the principles of democracy, freedom, and equitable distribution of wealth for all Chinese people," he said, adding that Taiwan will become a model for future development.

Chiang said however that Beijing has never abandoned its attempt to take over Taiwan by force, as can be seen from its missile test-firing exercises in the Taiwan Strait in 1996 and its national defense white paper issued earlier this year.
"In order to avoid war, we can not ignore war. We have to learn from it," he said.
"We can not protect ourselves without strength," he stressed, adding that "In order to safeguard our country we must build up a defensive force strong to protect ourselves." (more)
