DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL NEWS AGENCY'S INTERVIEW WITH DEFENSE MINISTER CHIANG CHUNG-LING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Q: On the occasion of 40th anniversary of the Aug. 23 bombardment of Kinmen, what activities will be sponsored by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to mark this historic memorial day?
A: First of all, I would like to point out that the Republic of China has managed to stand upright since undergoing the severe test of the ruthless bombardment which began on Aug. 23, 1958.

Under the outstanding leadership of late presidents Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo, as well as President Lee Teng-hui, the country has grown and developed toward prosperity, wealth, and happiness, creating an economic miracle-- the "Taiwan experience"--which becomes the envy of the world. We can say that the ROC's victory in the Aug. 23 battle was an important demarcation point in Taiwan's development.

To mark this historic memorial day, the MND began sponsoring various commemorative activities starting from July 1. These activities include: a national essay contest; a historical exhibition; an art exhibition; and an academic seminar.

Meanwhile, in memory of the officers and men killed during the bombardment, and to commend their loyalty and bravery, the MND will hold a series of memorial services from Aug. 20-22 and from Aug. 26-29 on Kinmen.
Representatives of the officers and men who took part in the battle have been invited to attend the services, and to visit military establishments on the island.

The MND will also hold "completion ceremonies for the Aug. 23 battle monument" from Aug. 23 through September in Kaohsiung City, Taichung City and Chungho City, to which representatives of the officers and men involved will also be invited to attend. These ceremonies will include the conferral of "Aug. 23 battle honor badges."

We hope that this series of commemorative activities will arouse public consensus that there should be no distinction drawn between patriots and protectors of the homeland, and that only through faith, unity, and love of the country, can people enjoy victory and glory together. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-2
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Q: Can you review and explian the Aug. 23 artillery bombardment, and talk about your personal impressions and feelings?

A: 1. The Chinese Communists suddenly launched a cluster of artillery bombarments on the Kinmen and its adjacent islands at 6:30 p.m. on Aug. 23, 1958 in an attempt to destroy Kinmen with drum-fire at a blow, and to invade Taiwan.

Within 44 days from Aug. 23 to Oct. 6, the Communist gunners fired more than 474,000 shells at the island, for an average of 1,473 shells per aquare kilometer of the island. A total of 587 officers and men died in the battle (including three deputy commanders of the Kinmen Defense Command, namely Chao Chia-siang, Chang Chieh and Chi Sing-wen), another 2,016 were injured, with signal corps suffered the highest ratio of casualties.

A total of 80 civilians were killed, 85 heavily injured, and 136 suffered minor injuries. Meanwhile, 2,649 houses were totally destroyed and 2,397 were damaged, with Little Kinmen suffered the heaviest damage.

However, due to the far-sighted leadership of the late President Chiang, and the composure of the armed forces of the Republic of China, although nearly half a million shells dropped on Kinmen in 44 days, and many fierce naval and air battles took place. The morale of the troops was very high, they become braver after each fight, and with the successful delivery of supplies via the beach, the Chinese Communists were forced to announce a ceasefire on Oct. 5, they then changed their strategy, and begun shelling the islands on alternate days, slowing down their attempt to "liberate Taiwan with force". This battle basically assured the peace and stability of the Taiwan Strait.

2. The Aug. 23 Taiwan Strait Battle 40 years ago has shaped entirely different courses of development for Chinese people on either side of the strait. Since that time, Beijing has actively promoted the "General Line for Socialist Construction", and practiced the "People's Communes", and later culminated in the "Cultural Revolution," bringing bloody massacres and long-term unrest to the Chinese mainland.

Taipei, on the other hand, chose the strategy of export- oriented growth, promoted various construction projects, and created the world-famous economic miracle. Because of the implementation of nine-year of free education, the quality of national human resources was raised and the local self- government was enhanced, laying a good foundation for future political development.

3. After 40 years, when we review the important military campaign which turned Taiwan from danger to safety, we know that although the artillery fire has ceased, but Beijing still refuses to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Forty years ago, despite extremely poor material condition, the entire nation was able to unite under a strong common cause. The whole population--both military men and civilians, of one heart and one mind, with no differentiation as to origin--was able to resist a strong enemy and surmount the crisis.

After 40 years, we now enjoy prosperity, social atability and political democracy. But with the enemy still there, the people have gradually forgotten the lessons of gunfire, and some are seeking personal benefit, quite often over national interests.

We should learn from the history that the best way to avoid war is not to deceive ourselves and to overlook war, but to learn from war and to turn the teaching of war into practical action of military preparation for war. In this way, and with actual strength, we can be confident that the enemy dare not launch an attack, and the national security can be assured. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-3
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Q: We know the Aug. 23, 1958 artillery battle was a watershed for both sides of the strait, can you talk about the significance of and the enlightenment gained from the battle?

A: The Aug. 23 Taiwan Strait military campaign was a demarcation point in the development of both sides. Due to the fact that all efforts by the armed forces and private citizens were united for a common purpose during wartime, a stable and peace situation in the Taiwan Strait was basically assured.

However, from there, the Chinese Communists went on to launch a series of political movements including "The Three Red Banners," "The Big Backyard Furnace," "The Four Cleanups" as well as the 10-year "Cultural Revolution." The series of errors and power struggles resulted in a recession on the mainland.

Meanwhile, Taiwan has actively engaged in various reconstruction projects and marched toward prosperity. For the past 40 years, the "Taiwan experience" that we helped establish has become a marvel of the world.

Because at present China is under separate reign, there is no so-called "one China." There is only a China with separate governing heads. However, the government of the Republic of China -- which has spared no effort in developing its economy and implementing democracy -- will no doubt be the model of a future unified China.

Under the present circumstances, Beijing has been forced to change its policy to "reform and open," clear proof that the improvement of people's living standard, desire for democracy and freedom is not only a global trend, but also a common wish of Chinese people on both sides of the strait.

China should be unified, but such unification must be under a system of democracy, freedom and equal distribution of wealth, a system that takes care of the interests of all Chinese on one hand, and on the other, follows a world trend.

In the future, both sides of the strait should adopt a rational and peaceful manner of interaction instead of war or conflict. Beijing must renounce the use of force as a threat against Taiwan to lay a good foundation for the development of a Chinese nation and protect the welfare of the people on both sides of the strait. This is what we should learn from the Aug. 23 bombardment. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-4
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Q: Do you think the Aug. 23 artillery bombardment has had any impact on the development of the ROC's armed forces buildup and national defense?
A: The Aug. 23 military campaign has had a decisive impact on both the survival and development of Taiwan, as well as the bright future of China.

In other words, if we failed in that military campaign, the Chinese communists may have already "blood-washed" Taiwan and there would not have been a "Taiwan experience" worthy of world envy. Therefore, we can say the Aug. 23 military campaign in the Taiwan Strait is a historic demarcation point of development for both sides of the strait.

Thanks to the bravery of the armed forces in their fighting, the Taiwan Strait was able to maintain a relative peace after this military campaign. Taiwan, with 40 years of stability, was able to engage in various reconstruction projects.

However, since Beijing has not completely renounced the use of force against Taiwan, the ROC's armed forces should look to the brave performance during the Aug. 23 military campaign as their model, to be more diligent in their training, to enhance their combat readiness, to support the government, and to be a solid force in safeguarding peace and stability in the strait.

Meanwhile, people from all walks of life in the country should also clearly understand the circumstances of our nation and the developing cross-strait situation. They should give more support and encouragement to officers and men, and back up national defense developments which will reinforce national defense. People should also establish a consensus on national defense to assure our security. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-5
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Q: Beijing has never abandoned its attempt to grab Taiwan by force, as can be seen from its ballistic missile test-firing exercises in the Taiwan Strait in 1996 and its national defense white paper issued earlier this year. Do you have any comment on this? Do you have any advice to the people of this country in this regard?

A: As it is well-known, the Chinese communists firmly believe that "Political power comes from the barrel of the gun." They have never abandoned the option of using force against Taiwan. The Chinese Communist regime has long tried to achieve their goal of "liberating Taiwan" by force, as can be seen from the series of military threat against Taiwan and military actions against Taiwan troops on Kuningtou and Tengpu islets in 1949, on Tadan and Erdan islets in 1950, on Yikiangshan islet in 1955, on Kinmen and Matsu in 1958, and the three missile-firing exercises in the Taiwan Strait to intimidate us in 1996.

Although Beijing took the military actions in the name of fighting against international imperialism, its real intention is to take over Taiwan in one stroke. Therefore, the people of this country have to heighten their vigilance.

What I want to emphasize here is that we can not protect ourselves without strength, and that in order to safeguard our country we must build up a defensive force strong enough to protect ourselves. To promote the concept of peace and help establish a regional security system is also our long-standing goal, because it is important to our national security.

Therefore, we have to acquire adequate defensive weapons and equipment from foreign countries and step up our research and development efforts, although we have no intention to engage in an arms race with mainland China. By doing so, we shall be able to strengthen our national defense, avoid military conflicts, and improve cross-strait relations for eventual national unification.

I would call upon our people to give full support to the government's plan to make our armed forces strong enough to protect ourselves. We should rely on our own strength rather than hoping that the enemy will not come to attack us.
Q: Can you please elaborate on the nation's policy on military buildup, and the program to build up a new generation of armed forces?

A: It is our present policy to carry out the government's strategy of "keeping the situations in the Taiwan Strait peaceful and stable." Therefore, our defensive warfare guidelines are based on the strategy of "strong defensive posture" and "effective deterrance." On this basis, we are actively building up a new generation of armed forces, which will have "top efficiency" and "rapid response capability." (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSCRIPT-6
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu) (By Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Under the plan, we are modernizing our weapon systems for the air, sea, and anti-landing defense forces in several stages.
For air defense, we have produced Indiginous Defense Fighters (IDF) and ordered other advanced jet fighters from the United States and France. We have taken delivery of some of the aircraft.

We have already put into service some 80 IDFs, 50 US-made F-16 jet fighters, and 30 French-made Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters. The three types of aircraft will greatly upgrade our air-defense capability.

We have also deployed six locally-made Tienkung (Sky Bow) surface-to-air missile systems and have received all of the improved MADS air-defense missiles we have ordered. The project for the improvement of 20 US-made Kawk ground-to-air missile sets has also been completed. By doing these, we will be able to improve the automation and integration features of our air-defense operations step by step.

For sea defense, we have commissioned six Chenkung-class warships and six Kangting-class warships. The six Knox-class frigates rented from the United States have been received. These warships will be able to enhance the naval defense capability.
For anti-landing combats, we have taken delivery of 240 M60A3TTS tanks, about 40 AH-1W attack helicopters, and 20 OH58D search-attack helicopters.
In order to modernize our national defense force, we have made great efforts in weapon research and development.

We have been able to produce IDF warplanes and land-fired Tienchien (Sky Sword) I missiles. We are producing Tienchien II and Tienkung II missiles, and have already deployed Tienkung I missiles. Hsiungfeng II anti-ship missiles have been installed for use on land and warships.

We are also doing researches for the development of low-altitude anti-tactical ballistic missiles and other weapons to strengthen our defensive forces. It is believed that our armed forces will have "high efficiency" and "fast response capability" when our military modernization project is completed in 2001.

The four-year project, which will be completed in three stages, will enable the government to reduce the number of military servicemen from 450,000 to 400,000 and to make the armed forces stronger and more efficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN MILITARY POSTMAN PROUD TO HAVE FULFILLED 'MISSION IMPOSSIBLE'

TEXT.P: Postman Dong Wen-chien considers it a matter of pride that he was able to successfully continue delivering mail during mainland China's 44-day bombardment of the Kinmen island group 40 years ago.

At the tender age of 19, Dong began working as a military postman in 1956. Two years later, on Aug. 23, 1958, mainland China launched a massive bombardment campaign against the islands, and Dong found himself an active participant in the historic battle. He dodged live shells to deliver each item of mail to every addressee.
In those days 40 years ago, everyone on the Kinmen islands was dependent on the military for postal services -- civilians and servicemen alike.

Dong had to arm himself to the teeth to carry out his "mission impossible" during the battle. Few other postmen can boast of having to put on a steel helmet before going off to deliver letters by bicycle.
It was much like playing a game of life and death in those days, a reminiscing Dong said. I had to duck dropping shells and avoid falling into craters formed by the exploding bombs, he added.
All the efforts were worthwhile, Dong said, particularly after soldiers received letters from their families expressing deep gratitude to the man who was able to deliver their messages.

There were tens of thousands of letters and parcels which needed to be delivered each day during the battle. And considering the military postman's doctrine, which is that every piece of mail must be delivered every day, Dong did an excellent job.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER SATISFIED WITH FRUITFUL VISIT TO PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Thursday that his just-concluded visit to the Philippines was successful and fruitful.
Wang said during his three-day visit to Manila, he managed to meet with Philippine President Joseph E. Estrada for wide-ranging talks.
"Estrada told me that Taiwan entrepreneurs are welcome to invest in the Philippines and that the Philippine government is determined to improve the country's investment climate," Wang said.
During his stay in Manila, Wang attended the an annual economic cooperation conference between the two countries.
"The two sides reached consensus on many points, including cooperation in trade, agriculture, tourism and labor affairs," Wang said.
For one thing, the two sides signed a temporary admission of goods agreement.

Meanwhile, the ROC agreed to send foodstuff experts to the Philippines in October to teach food processing technology. The Philippines will send a fact-finding mission to Taiwan later this year to study Taiwan's sugar-making and aquacultural technologies.
In addition, the Philippines has agreed to resume imports of Taiwan pork, which was suspended since a foot-and-mouth disease swept Taiwan's hog farms more than a year ago.

The Philippines also agreed to hold a meeting with the ROC in December to discuss possible amendments to the existing bilateral aviation pact. "The Philippines has tentatively agreed to allow Taiwan carriers to operate all-cargo flight services," Wang said.
Moreover, the Philippines promised to revise its current law to allow foreign investors to own industrial land in its territory.
The Philippines has also agreed to more strictly screen personal data of Philippine nationals to work in Taiwan and to work out more reasonable standards for labor brokering fees.

Taiwan and the Philippines began to hold an economic cooperation meeting annually in 1992. Substantive relations between the two countries have since become ever closer. In 1997, Taiwan was the Philippines' fourth largest trading partner, the ninth largest investor and the third largest source of tourists.

According to Philippine tallies, Taiwan poured a total of US$740 million in the Philippines between 1986 and 1997 for various investment projects, making it the Philippines' fifth largest capital source.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN COMFORT WOMAN VISITS TAIWAN TO PROMOTE CAUSE

TEXT.P: A former South Korean comfort woman arrived in Taipei on Thursday to inspect what may be the remains of a military brothel run by the imperial Japanese army in northern Taiwan during World War II.

"Lee Yong-soo, 71, is scheduled to visit the site at an ROC Air Force base in Hsinchu, some 60 kilometers south of Taipei, on Saturday, to ascertain whether or not it really once accommodated a Japanese military brothel," said a spokeswoman for the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation (TWRF), which is hosting Lee's visit.

The visit is part of the foundation's efforts to push the Japanese government to formally apologize for forcing a large number of Asian women, including many from Taiwan, South Korea and the Philippines, to work as sex slaves for Japanese military servicemen during World War II, the spokeswoman said.

Lee made a previous TWRF-sponsored trip to Taiwan last year for the same purpose, but was denied access to the Hsinchu air base on that occasion, the spokeswoman said, adding: "With the assistance from New Party Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta, Lee will be able this time to enter the Hsinchu air base to inspect the presumed brothel remains.

"If the site is proved to be the remains of a Japanese military brothel, we'll have more concrete evidence to pressure Japan into making a public apology for its past sins and compensating the surviving former comfort women, most of whom are now in their 70s and live in solitude," the spokeswoman said.
She further said that local women's rights activists are encouraged by the publication of a United Nations investigative report on the comfort women issue.

According to the report, the Japanese government forced more than 200,000 foreign women to become sex slaves during World War II. The report demanded Japanese compensation for all the surviving victims.

Nevertheless, the TWRF spokeswoman said the battle to force Japan to apologize and provide compensation is far from over, as the country remains unrepentant and recalcitrant despite the recent release of the UN report.
The spokeswoman said the TWRF will continue joining forces with women's rights groups in other Asian countries to file lawsuits with Japanese courts against the Japanese government over the issue.

The Japanese government set up a private Asian Women's Fund in 1995 that has offered to compensate each former comfort woman with 2 million Japanese yen for her suffering. Many of the women, however, have refused compensation unless it comes directly from the Japanese government.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUSEUM OF HISTORY FORGES SISTER TIES WITH CATEDRA GAUDI

TEXT.P: A bridge between Taiwan and Spain was formed with the establishment of a sister relationship between Taipei's National Museum of History and Spain's Catedra Gaudi of the Polytechnic University of Catalunya.

Huang Kuang-nan, head of the Taipei museum, described the Catedra Gaudi as a museum devoted to the preservation and promotion of architectural art, the aesthetic spirit of Antonio Gaudi (1852-1926) and architectural exchanges between the Eastern and Western worlds.
Huang said at a news conference Wednesday that he hoped the sister ties can open a door to the cultural and artistic interaction between Eastern and Western architecture.

He added that he hopes the "Art of Gaudi's Architecture" exhibition, which opens Thursday at the national museum on Nanhai Road, will inspire Taiwan people to improve their living environment and raise concerns over the quality of public buildings.

A total of 110 works, including architectural plans, photographs, building models, furniture and components for a Gaudi-style building will be used to illustrate different aspects of Gaudi architecture during the one-month exhibition.

In addition, experts from Catera Gaudi, one of the exhibition's three sponsors including the Museum of History and the Chinese Architects Association, will take interested members on tour of Gaudi's curvaceous, colorful wonder-world in a three-dimensional multimedia presentation.
This is a particular treat as this type of presentation has never been shown outside Spain, exhibition organizers said.

The multimedia performance will systematically introduce and interpret the unique Gaudi arts and their multifarious appearances covering cubism, surrealism, expressionism, and constructivism, the museum said.

Gaudi, one of the world's most creative architects, built a world that does not fall into any established academic art categories. He drew inspiration from his observation of humans, animals, plants, mountains and other forms of natural creation then implemented them into the construction of buildings without straight lines or completely plane surfaces because he claimed these "shapes" did not exist in nature.

Based on these ideas, Gaudi designed buildings with vivid colors, curved surfaces, flowing lines and spaces. He also often used diagonal supports resembling flying buttresses, which are external wall supports popular in Gothic architecture.

The best-known works of the architectural genius include the Casa Mila, the unfinished hillside Park Guell, and the unfinished Sagrada Familia in Barcelona which is probably the city's most famous landmark.

After dedicating 12 years of his life to realizing his biggest and most inspiring construction project -- the Sagrada Familia -- Gaudi died at the age of 74 in a traffic accident. Only the facade of the planned church was completed at that stage of construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S TOTAL TRADE FELL BY 8.4 PERCENT IN JULY

TEXT.P: Singapore's total trade at current prices, on a three-month moving average basis, contracted by 8.4 percent in July compared to the same period last year, the Singapore Trade Development Board (TDB) announced Thursday

Exports were down by 1 percent, with non-oil domestic exports dropping marginally by 0.4 percent and non-oil re-exports increasing by 3.8 percent. Oil domestic exports weakened further, declining by 23.6 percent from year-earlier levels. Meanwhile, non-oil imports shrank by 13.9 percent.

The total value of Singapore's trade in July amounted to S$30.4 million (US$17.88 million). Exports totaled S$15.66 million, while imports stood at S$14.74 million, according to figures released by the TDB.
On a monthly basis, Singapore's non-oil domestic exports fell by 2.3 percent in July, reversing the 6.1 percent increase in June.

Domestic exports of electronics dropped by 5 percent, reflecting the oversupply in key electronic segments. Non-oil re-exports moderated to 2.8 percent, reflecting weak re-exports to regional economies as well as Japan and Hong Kong, the TDB said.
Non-oil imports, a short-term leading indicator of manufacturing sector, contracted further by 16.7 percent, the fifth consecutive month of negative growth, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ADOPTION OF CHINESE CHILDREN LIKELY TO RISE

TEXT.P: Mainland China and Australia have signed an agreement making the Australian adoption of Chinese children easier, the Sydney Morning Herald reported Thursday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the paper's correspondent David Lague reported that the mainland will open the doors of its orphanages to Australians after Canberra dropped a regulation stating that children adopted from overseas are automatically wards of the minister of immigration upon their arrival.
Beijing earlier objected to this regulation because it effectively rendered the children stateless until authorities recognized the adoption process.
Many Australians are desperate to adopt children overseas because of a shortage of available children for adoption in their country.

In 1971, the daily reported the number of kids for adoption was close to 10,000, but the figure plummeted to only 700 in 1997 with only 269 children coming from overseas. Most of them came from South Korea, India and Thailand.

Prospective adoptive parents have welcomed the news but they warned the red tape plus a strong bias imposed by states and territories in Australia could remain major hurdles for Australian couples wanting to adopt kids.

China has been a constant source of children adoption for the United States, Canada and Western Europe, but no agreements have yet been signed between these countries and the mainland. American parents alone adopt about 4,000 children, mostly girls, each year, the daily reported. By Peter Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE OF KINMEN HOPEFUL THEIR HOME WILL NEVER AGAIN BE BATTLEFIELD

TEXT.P: Kinmen, the island group which has always been shrouded in a veil of military mystique, is now being opened to tourism, and its people are hopeful that their home will never again be a battlefield.

Following the recent increase in exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, real estate advertisements for property in Xiamen City, in mainland China's Fujian Province, are now common in Kinmen's news media. The coast of Fujian is just 2 kilometers from Kinmen at its nearest point.

Although it is not certain exactly how many Kinmen people have bought houses in Xiamen, the number is without doubt fairly high, and a development which would have been completely unthinkable 40 years ago.

The Chinese communists began a 44-day bombardment of the Kinmen island group on Aug. 23, 1958. A total of over 474,900 shells were fired on an area of some 150 square kilometers during the battle. In the 20 years which followed, Kinmen was harassed by a total of over 977,000 shells containing communist propaganda, which were fired on alternate days until 1978.
The system of military administration on Kinmen was dismantled on Nov. 7, 1992, when a civilian county council was formed, formally bringing the people of Kinmen into the fold of democracy.

This can be illustrated by the vociferous calls by the people of Kinmen for their own "three mini-links" with mainland China, and highlights the freedom of speech now enjoyed by the local people. The so called "three links" refer to direct shipping, postal, and business links across the Taiwan Strait, for which Beijing has been pushing hard.

The people of Kinmen want their own direct links with the mainland, so that they can make the 40-minute boat trip to and from the mainland without fear of arrest. The journey currently takes more that 50 hours, as travelers must go via Taiwan and Hong Kong owing to the lack of direct links between Taiwan and the mainland.
Ultimately, though, this issue can only be resolved by Taipei and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO DONATE US$50,000 FOR MAINLAND CHINA FLOOD RELIEF

TEXT.P: The Singapore government will make a humanitarian contribution of US$50,000 to mainland China as relief aid for its flood victims, the Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced on Thursday.

A statement released by the Foreign Ministry said that massive flooding in mainland China has caused extensive damage, injury and loss of lives. It added that the decision to provide aid was taken following an appeal from the Red Cross and Red Crescent.
Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong also sent a message of sympathy to Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BOURSE UP, CURRENCY DOWN

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market continued a surge on Thursday following a dramatic rise on Wednesday, while the local currency remained depressed after a one-day rally, analysts said.
The All Ordinaries Index, which fell about 13 points in morning trade due to profit-taking, reversed its trend in the afternoon and finished 22.4 points higher to close at 2658.5.
The Australian dollar closed at 59 US cents on Thursday, down sharply from Wednesday's close of 59.78 US cents.
Analysts said the volatile trend will continue for as long as the Asian economic crisis remains the focus of concern for many investors.

Hong Kong's chief executive Tung Chee Hwa on Thursday announced that the former British colony has now entered a recession, which will have a negative effect on the Australian stock market in coming days. The territory is one of Australia's major trading partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES TRYING TO IMPROVE INVESTMENT CLIMATE

TEXT.P: Philippines Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barrican said on Thursday that the Estrada administration is exerting more effort to win back investors' confidence in the Philippines, especially the confidence of investors from Taiwan.

Asked what assurances the government can give to foreign investors to make the Philippines an attractive investment destination, Barrican said the government is undertaking a series of moves to improve the situation.
The spokesman said the Labor Department has taken a more aggressive stance in conciliation and mediation, to avoid strikes and work stoppages.
He also said steps are being taken to put a stop to the rampant kidnapping of wealthy businessmen, many of whom are Chinese or of Chinese descent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT'S SON VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Joseph Victor Ejercito, son of Philippine President Joseph Estrada, arrived in Taiwan on Thursday for a three-day visit.
Ejercito called on Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang soon after his arrival. He will visit the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of National Defense, and the Tourism Bureau on Friday.
Ejercito will also meet with Premier Vincent Siew later on Friday before attending the 45th anniversary of the founding of the Junior Chamber of the Republic of China.
Ejercito is scheduled to leave the island on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SIGN INVESTMENT GUARANTEE PACT WITH INDIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan will sign an investment guarantee agreement with India late this month, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Thursday.

Lin Neng-chung, director-general of the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), will lead a delegation to India later this month and ink the accord, according to Wang.

The economics minister said the inking of the investment guarantee accord with India is of great importance to bilateral ties, as India has maintained closer relations with neighboring mainland China over the past 40 years.
Wang said the MOEA, in conjunction with the China External Trade Development Council, has worked out an export expansion package targeting several potential markets, including India.

MOEA statistics show that two-way Taiwan-India trade totaled US$1.2 billion in 1997, up 30 percent from 1996. Taiwan exports to India hit US$550 million last year, while Indian imports to Taiwan reached US$660 million. Taiwan investment in India totaled about US$36 million as of July 1997, focusing mainly on the textile, automobile accessory, and chemical industries.

Wang revealed that the MOEA is also seeking to clinch investment guarantee pacts with South Korea, Poland, Saudi Arabia, Costa Rica, and Guatemala. Taiwan has already signed similar accords with 18 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COUNCILORS URGED NOT TO RUB SALT INTO INDONESIA'S WOUNDS

TEXT.P: The Council of Taiwanese Chambers of Commerce in Indonesia (CTCI) on Thursday sent a letter to the Taipei City Council urging its members not to rub salt into Indonesia's wounds.
The letter, signed by CTCI President Liu Shuang-chuan, expressed concern over recent violent incidents in front of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei.
During the incidents, demonstrators against the rape of ethnic Chinese women in Indonesia threw bags of urine, burnt Indonesia's flag, and physically attacked the vice chairman of the office.
The CTCI slammed the violence as barbaric acts that should be condemned, and asked Taipei City Councilor Lee Cheng-lung, who reportedly slapped the Indonesian official, to stop grandstanding.

The letter noted that although history should not be forgotten, people should not counter violence with violence, and pointed out that at a time when the Indonesian government and people are trying to heal the nation's wounds, the councilor's action just adds fuel to the flames.
His style of council violence serves only to further endanger the safety of the lives and property of Taiwan businessmen in Indonesia, the letter said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ROLE IN 1958 BOMBARDMENT OF KINMEN (PART I)

TEXT.P: The United States played a critical role in both of the Taiwan Strait crises, one in 1958 and the other in 1996. Although the roles were different due to international circumstances, the US wielded its influence through real military power, playing the role of "guardian of peace." The US also opened the doors for dialogue to prevent further conflict.

During the 1958 bombardment on Kinmen, the ROC and the US still had diplomatic relations. The US maintained a mutual defense command in Taipei and the US Seventh Fleet also provided defense for Taiwan.

In addition, the US dispatched four destroyers from the Mediterranean Sea to waters close to Taiwan. The aircraft carrier "Midway" was also mobilized with the US Navy acting to protect logistic missions. In terms of arms shipments, the US supplied F86 jet fighters, "Rattlesnake" air-to-air missiles, and eight-inch heavy artillery to defend Kinmen.

Nearly four decades later, the mainland Chinese conducted missile tests in 1996 off Taiwan's southern and northern coastlines, followed by "live-fire" air force and naval maneuvers, heightening the tension of the Taiwan Strait.

The Clinton administration first warned Beijing not to misinterpret the situation. Later, the aircraft carriers "Nimitz" and "Independence" as well as their escort battle groups were dispatched to waters off Taiwan, marking the largest-scale deployment of US naval forces in this region since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975.
In an interview with the Central News Agency, Shen Lyu-shun, director of the Foreign Ministry's North American Affairs Department, talked about the difference in the two Taiwan Strait crises.
He noted that the 1958 bombardment of Kinmen happened during the Cold War between the United States and the Soviet Union, and that the ROC and the US still maintained formal relations at that time.
During the two crises, Shen remarked, "The US had played the same role as guardian of peace, and it's understandable that peace was maintained through the display of real power."

According to declassified top-secret documents from the US Department of State as reported by Japan's Asahi Shimbun newspaper, during the peak of the 1958 Taiwan Strait military clash, the US military had considered using nuclear weapons against the mainland to protect Kinmen and Matsu.

That report said a memorandum by officials with the US State Department indicated that should the Chinese Communists attack Kinmen, Matsu, the Taiwan proper or South Korea, there would be a need for the US to counterattack with nuclear arms. The targets of such counterattack were Shanghai, Hangzhou, Nanjing and Guangzhou.

In fact, the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty covered only the security of the Taiwan proper. The offshore islands, including Kinmen and Matsu, were excluded from the perimeter. That was an apparent flaw in the nation's defense.
Nevertheless, Beijing's war-like actions prompted grave concerns for the US and led to the implementation of the Formosan Resolution that helped bolster the security of the outlying islands. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: US ROLE IN 1958 BOMBARDMENT OF KINMEN (PART II)

TEXT.P: In 1955, both houses of the US Congress passed a joint resolution, authorizing the president to mobilize military power to protect "related positions and territories" of Taiwan. Its purpose was to supplement the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty whose target was limited only to the security of Taiwan proper.
But the US government was cautious over such a move, knowing well that the joint resolution once implemented, might provoke the mainland Chinese.
Some political observers said that judging from the declassified documents from the State Department, the US government's analysis of the 1958 Taiwan Strait crisis was "very accurate."

The US predicted that mainland China would not likely invade Taiwan or launch a direct attack against the outlying islands. The most probable option was to form a blockade on the outlying islands and to try to enforce an air blockade. That prompted the US to place its focus on air defense and on logistic supplies for the outlying islands.
The situation on the Taiwan Strait worsened year by year, and in 1958, the ROC government hoped that the 1955 congressional resolution would be implemented at an early date.

This led then Foreign Minister George Yeh, who assumed his duty at the end of August that year, to tell the American side that "the security of Taiwan's outlying islands is closely connected to the security of the Western Pacific region." His statement was strongly considered by the US.

It has been learned that then US Vice President Richard Nixon once described Yeh's statement at a National Security Council meeting as "very correct." And on Sept. 4, 1958, the US secretary of state announced the implementation of the 1955 joint resolution.

Seeing that the US had taken such a strong move, the Chinese Communists decided to change their attitude and on Sept. 6 they announced their plan to resume ambassadorial-level talks with the US. That was the origin of the subsequent "Warsaw Talks."

In his interview with the CNA, Shen Lyu-shun pointed out that from the US responses during the 1958 and 1996 Taiwan Strait crises, people could see a pattern developing in the US' handling of matters. While showing its determination to maintain peace, it opened the doors for a peaceful resolution of disputes.

As Taipei and Washington had formal diplomatic relations in 1958, about two months after the Aug. 23 massive shelling on Kinmen by the Chinese Communists, then US Secretary of State John Foster Dulles flew to Taipei on Oct. 21 to meet with President Chiang Kai-shek.

And because both countries had severed their formal diplomatic relations, after the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, Ding Mou-shih, secretary general of the National Security Council, held secret talks in the US with deputy White House national security advisor Samuel Berger. And at the same time, White House national security advisor Anthony Lake held talks with Beijing's Vice Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu.

William Perry, who was US defense secretary during the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, made private trips to mainland China and Taiwan in 1997. He had also played a constructive role by proposing that mainland China and Taiwan increase communications through an unofficial "second channel" to reduce mutual misunderstanding and to prevent the occurrence of clashes. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: US ROLE IN 1958 BOMBARDMENT OF KINMEN (PART III)

TEXT.P: Back in October 1958, when Dulles visited Taiwan for talks with President Chiang Kai-shek, he also put strong pressure on Taiwan to renounce the use of force against the mainland.

Although the president did not bow to the pressure, in order to give a friendly response to Dulles' suggestion, the ROC stated in a Sino-American joint statement issued on Oct. 23, 1958, that returning to the mainland to rescue the people was the government's sacred mission. However, it pledged that this would be done not through military force, but through Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People.

Two days later, then mainland Chinese Defense Minister Peng Dehuai announced Beijing's decision to implement an alternate day shelling strategy, virtually marking the end of the bombardment of Kinmen.

During his visit to Taipei, Dulles also told Chiang that instead of becoming a military-style country, Taiwan should strive to build up its peace-loving image and to become the true inheritor of traditional Chinese culture.
Shen Lyu-shun said that during the 1958 and 1996 Taiwan Strait crises, the US Congress provided powerful support for Taiwan, which he described as very important.

Shen, who was working for the ROC mission in Washington, D.C. during the 1996 crisis, recalled that both houses of the US Congress passed resolutions overwhelmingly in favor of the ROC at that time. He said a retired congressional leader even called up the ROC mission to show his support for Taiwan's democratization and offered to help Taiwan overcome the crisis.
Ever since the 1996 crisis, the international community has been concerned about the probability of a reoccurrence of such a crisis and of finding a way to prevent it.
Some American scholars have even said that the chance of a military clash in the Taiwan Strait is now higher that any time since 1979 because more and more people in Taiwan are seeking independence.

But Darryl Johnson, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, does not share that view. He said in an interview with CNA that he does not think the chance of a new crisis or military clash in the Taiwan Strait at the present time is any higher than in the past.
"We hope the (cross-strait) atmosphere will ease and improve. That is the goal of President Clinton and of the US government," he said.
Johnson said that during Clinton's recent visit to mainland China, he reiterated the US government's policy on arms sales to Taiwan and its commitment to honoring the Taiwan Relations Act.
Shen said he believes the United States will continue to address the security of Taiwan and the Western Pacific under the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act.

From the standpoint of diplomacy, he said, the United States hopes to maintain peace without resorting to military force if possible, adding that it will continue to take precautionary steps to prevent the reoccurrence of cross-strait crises.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORTS AND EXPORTS DOWN IN 1ST HALF OF AUGUST
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By Bear Lee and Leah Lai)

TEXT.P: Asia's financial meltdown is taking its toll on Taiwan as the island's trade in the first half of August continued to register a double digit decline, statistics from the Finance Ministry show.

The statistics indicate that exports in the 15 days totaled US$4.43 billion, with imports of US$3.86 billion, a 10.6 percent and a 15.9 percent decline, respectively, from the same period of last year.
Hsu Kuo-chung, chief of the ministry's statistics department, said that judging from the records for the first half of August, Taiwan's foreign trade will continue to drop for the rest of this month.
But compared to July, during which Taiwan saw its exports and imports drop by 16.3 percent and 22.1 percent, respectively, the scale of export and import shrinkage is likely to narrow, Hsu went on.
He added that it remains to be seen whether this improvement will continue in the coming months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S LIAISON OFFICE IN DURBAN TO BE CLOSED
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By J.S. Chang and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will close its liaison office in Durban, a big city in eastern South Africa, from Sept. 14, sources from the liaison office said on Thursday.
All relevant consular affairs will be transferred to Taipei's liaison office in Johannesburg, the diplomatic sources said.
The liaison office in Durban was Taipei's consulate-general before the ROC and South Africa severed their diplomatic relations on Jan. 1 this year.
The current director of the Durban liaison office, Lin Song-huann, will serve as a division chief in Taipei's representative office in Pretoria after the closing of the Durban office.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT$1.3 TRILLION ECONOMIC STIMULUS PROJECT APPROVED

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan on Thursday approved a NT$1.2955 trillion (US$37.334 billion) "domestic demand expansion" project aimed at boosting domestic economic growth by expanding public investment.

According to the terms of the stimulus project, the government will accelerate the implementation of construction budget bills for fiscal 1999 and 2000, totaling NT$1.1018 trillion. In addition, an extra NT$193.7 billion will be poured into public investment.

In the field of private investment, the government will encourage the private sector to invest in over NT$200 million-worth of manufacturing projects, power plants, public construction projects, industrial development projects in eastern Taiwan, leisure facilities in western Taiwan, industrial-commercial compounds, and industrial parks.

Premier Vincent Siew said in a press conference that as the fallout from the Asian financial turmoil continues to affect Taiwan, the government is obliged to introduce the two-year economic stimulus project in order to revive the local economy.

Siew said the most important task facing the government in the long run is upgrading the overall level of local industries, which will allow Taiwan to catch up with advanced countries in 10 or 20 years. In order to achieve this, the Cabinet will convene a series of economic meetings and work out a long-term economic development project within six months, he added.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development said that the project will have only a limited effect on Taiwan's economy for fiscal 1998, pointing out that it will prompt the economy to post additional growth of just 0.31 percentage points.
However, it added, growth for fiscal 1999 will be boosted by 0.71 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER COMPUTER INTERNATIONAL POSTS NEGATIVE GROWTH

TEXT.P: The regional economic crisis has caused Acer Computer International Ltd. (ACI) to post negative growth in consolidated revenue and profit for the first half of this year, ACI announced on Thursday.

ACI's revenue fell 22 percent to S$593.6 million and net profit after tax fell 98 percent to S$352,000, compared to the first half of 1997. Interim earnings per share fell from 10.75 cents to 0.21 cents, according to the company.

ACI's performance was very much affected by losses suffered by its associate company Acer Computec Latino America (ACLA) in which ACI has a 35.9 percent ownership stake. Discounting losses in ACLA and other associate companies, ACI's net profit before tax fell 47 percent to S$9.22 million, the company said.

ACI is still among the top five PC players in the Asia Pacific region, excluding Japan. The company also saw positive growth in the first half of 1998 in markets such as India, the Middle East, South Africa, and Australia.

ACI, a member of the Taiwan-based Acer Group, was listed on the Main Board of the Singapore Stock Exchange in September 1995. The company is responsible for the sales, marketing, service and assembly of Acer products in the Asia Pacific region, South Asia, Africa, and the Middle East.
ACI operates over 30 offices in 20 countries and has more than 1,000 employees supporting over 10,000 dealers in more than 60 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO REMAINS UNCERTAIN ON BEIJING'S `THREE NOES' DEMAND: MOFA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday that the government will closely watch any change in Japan's position on the "three noes" regarding Taiwan, as Japan seems uncertain on the issue.

Citing information gained through bilateral channels, Hu said Japan seems not to have made a final decision on whether it will officially spell out support for Beijing's "three noes" demand during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan early next month.

Calling on Japan not to yield to Beijing's demand and risk damaging the interests of the region and itself, Hu said Beijing should also understand that bullying Taiwan will only hurt cross-strait ties, which will serve no useful purpose.

Meanwhile, Japan's mass-circulation Sankei Shimbun reported on Thursday that Tokyo has turned down Beijing's request to codify its backing for the "three noes" in a bilateral official document to be signed during Jiang's September visit to Japan.

Citing an official with the Japanese Foreign Ministry, the newspaper said in a front-page story that "Tokyo cannot accept Beijing's demand, as signing a new document on the "three noes" will create new principles for Japan in its dealings with Taiwan."

According to the official, Taiwan-Japan relations, including historical links, are different to the links between Taiwan and the United States, and it is thus natural for Japan to have a different policy toward mainland China than the United States.

The official stressed that Japan has no intention of engaging with Taiwan beyond the framework set our in the 1972 "joint declaration" and the 1978 "peace agreement" inked by Tokyo and Beijing. He added that Japan "fully understands and respects" that Taiwan is an inalienable territory of mainland China, and that Tokyo forswore its jurisdiction over Taiwan upon its surrender at the end of World War II.

Although Beijing expects Tokyo to codify its stance toward Taiwan in the new bilateral document, the official said Tokyo, on the other hand, wishes to use the two countries' "action guidelines" regarding international issues as the framework for the new document, and believes that it is unnecessary to mention its policy toward Taiwan in this respect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OVERSEAS TOURIST SPENDING DOWN

TEXT.P: Spending by Taiwan tourists traveling abroad fell to US$1.69 billion in the second quarter of 1998, down US$440 million from the same period of last year, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Thursday.

Shih Yen, director-general of the CBC's Economic Research Department, attributed the decrease to the large fall in the new Taiwan dollar, a result of the financial crisis which broke out about one year ago in Southeast Asia.
The drop in the local currency has led to rising costs for overseas trips, which has greatly affected the willingness of local people to go abroad.
Overseas tourist spending by Taiwan travelers hit a record high of US$8.45 billion for 1995, and the fall in the second quarter of this year represents a rarity in recent years, Shih added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BABY-SELLING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: Police on Thursday cracked down on a baby-selling criminal operation in Taipei, arresting two women and retrieving four babies.

Acting on a tip-off, police in the early hours of Thursday morning arrested Fu Juei-chiao, 51, a nurse at a gynecology clinic in Taipei, and Liao Pau-chu, 49, who served as a broker, or "white glove," at their respective residences in Taipei.

Suspicious account books were also found in both residences. Based on information obtained from the account books, along with the suspects' confessions, police wasted no time retrieving four babies which had been sold -- two girls and two boys -- in Taoyuan and Hsinchu counties. Their ages ranged between eight months and one year.

Fu was accused of selling babies at prices of between NT$400,000 and NT$500,000, as well as counterfeiting birth certificates to make the babies appear to be the natural children of the buyers. However, police said that more investigation will be needed to find out whether or not the babies had been stolen from their natural parents.

Fu denied all the accusations, saying she served only as a bridge between families who wanted to adopt children and those who had difficulties in raising their own children. According to Fu, "she was helping people; she was doing good things."

Police found that this is not the first time Fu has been involved in the baby-selling business. Earlier this year, she received a six-month jail term, convertible into fines, for counterfeiting documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: ETHNIC CHINESE ALLEGEDLY CASTRATED IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has instructed its representative office in Indonesia to collect information regarding reports that a number of ethnic Chinese were allegedly castrated during riots in that country in May.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu, who returned from a weeklong visit to Paraguay on Wednesday, said that the representative office in Jakarta has so far found no evidence to suggest there is any truth in the unsubstantiated and unconfirmed reports, either from police or medical records.
However, Hu pointed out that the victims might have been too afraid to report the cases, adding that the ministry's representative office in Jakarta will make efforts to substantiate the allegations.
Meanwhile, Lee Joko Mulayanto, representative of the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office to Taipei, said that his government has already set up a committee to look into the reports.

Mulayanto told a group of legislators who came to the representative office to express their concern over the reports, that the committee is calling on the victims to come forward with their stories, adding that he will report its findings to the ROC government within the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Cabinet on Thursday approved a pump priming package to help boost domestic demand.
The China Times: Taiwan will adopt a more pragmatic approach toward arms dealing with the United States.
The United Daily News: The Cabinet on Thursday approved a massive NT$1.3 trillion stimulus package to revitalize the local economy.
The Liberty Times: The public-sector investment will reach NT$1.2 trillion over the next two years.
The Independence Morning Post: The Hualien reservists administration office is suspected of involvement in a vote-buying scandal.
The Commons Daily: A delegation of legislators with different political stripes to visit Japan to explain Taiwan's stance on the so-called "three noes" against this country.
The China Post: The government adopts a stimulus package to boost economy.
The China News: The KMT pushes a Taiwan Provincial Government downsizing plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUTE LEAVES RECOMMENDED AS HIGHLY NUTRITIOUS VEGETABLE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The nutritional value of Corchorus Olitorius, one of Asia's two jute plants which yield a fiber used in making sacks and cordage, is as high as that of ginseng, researchers announced.

The plant's leaves are tasty and rich in calcium -- three times higher than in spinach, potassium and other valuable minerals and fibers, a horticulturist from the Taiwan Agriculture Research Institute said.
A recent Japanese inquiry into the C. Olitorius prompted the institute to examine the plant further, said Shen Pai-kuei, a horticultural researcher with the organization.
Although C. Olitorius, which is indigenous to India and Burma, was introduced to Taiwan from Thailand three years ago, it remained commercially untapped until in recent months.

Investigation into the mineral content rate in the C. Olitorius leaves revealed that it was the highest among all other known vegetables in Taiwan, which explains why the Japanese wanted its seeds, Shen said.
The plant, which favors warm and damp weather, can easily be cultivated in ordinary land, even on salty and barren Penghu islands, said Shen.

The jute leaves can be harvested a month after the plant sprouts leaves. It has dark green leaves seven- to 11-centimenter long, small yellow flowers and small grayish-green seeds. The plant, which stands some 150 centimeters high when fully grown, can yield another batch of fresh leaves in 20 days. The harvest season extends for as long as four months between early July and late November, said Shen.

To prepare it as a dish, Shen recommended boiling the leaves quickly for about a minute, then cooling it and serving it cold with a sauce. It will taste equally good when it is cooked in egg soup. Shen and his colleagues have even written a booklet of recipes for the vegetable.

DOC.HEADLINE: QANTAS REGISTERS HIGH PROFITS DESPITE ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: Qantas Airways, Australia's largest airline operator, chalked up high earnings in the most severe market conditions since the Gulf War in 1991.
Qantas, one of the few international airlines which serves both sides of the Taiwan Strait, announced Thursday a 20.6 percent increase in its net profits for the fiscal 1997-98.
Despite the Asian economic crisis and unprecedented fare discounts, the Australian carrier reported close to A$305 million (US$220 million) in profits.
Qantas Chairman Gary Pemberton indicated that the airline would not likely maintain last year's profit level in the current year, which ends in June 1999.
He attributed the possible lower profits to the continuing volatility in Asia and pressure on air ticket prices as the discounting battle continues unabated.

Qantas, a publicly run company in Australia, has a fleet of more than 120 planes. It set up a subsidiary -- Australian Asia Airlines -- in 1991 to open air links between Australia and Taiwan, the first since Canberra switched its recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1972.
This air link has helped boost two-way tourist industry relations between Taiwan and Australia. In 1997 alone, more than 150,000 tourists from Taiwan visited Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK MARKET AND DOLLAR PLUNGE IN VOLATILE TRADING

TEXT.P: Australian shares on Friday reversed their previous rally following losses on Wall Street and the Nikkei while the currency took another beating to trade below 59 US cents.
The All Ordinaries Index plunged 33.4 points in morning trade to 2,625.1 from Thursday's close of 2,658.5 after an 81-point fall in Wall Street and another drop in Japan's stock market.

Analysts said Australian stocks rose Thursday due to encouraging company profits and stronger regional bourses buoying the local market. However, that sentiment was short-lived because of falling prices in commodities in the world market.
"The rally on Thursday was short-lived and the market will continue to be volatile as more and more investors become nervous and cautious," one analyst said.
The Australian dollar was left scarred after running into a wall of aggressive US hedge fund sellers who unloaded the currency for the rising Japanese yen in morning trade on Friday.
The Australian dollar was trading at 58.86 US cents on Friday morning compared to Thursday's close of 59.14 US cents.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SEAFOOD SAID GOOD FOR HEALTH

TEXT.P: Australia seafood contains more omega-3 oils than fish from the Northern Hemisphere and is therefore healthier, according to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) in Canberra.
The latest study by CSIRO scientists showed that omega-3 is code for the fatty acids that decrease the likelihood of a person contracting heart disease, high-blood pressure and rheumatoid arthritis.

They said a joint study and an examination of nearly 200 species of Australian fish by the CSIRO's marine research and division of human nutrition shows that Australian seafood has between 10 and 100 times more omega-3 than beef, lamb or chicken, and is lower in cholesterol, according to the Australian on Friday.
The daily quoted Peter Rothlisberg, a CSIRO marine scientist, as saying that all seafood was good for people, but different types of fish contained different types of oil in varying amounts.
Mavis Abbey, a nutrition expert, was quoted as saying that interest in fish-oil had been triggered by evidence that eskimos in North America experienced a very low incidence of heart disease.
"Omega-3 fatty acids also appear to have additional favorable effects on blood vessel function," Abbey said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE STILL IS WORLD'S BUSIEST PORT

TEXT.P: Singapore maintained its position as the world's busiest port with 808 million gross tonnes handled last year in the face of keen competition from regional ports.

Singapore also held its place as the world's top bunkering port with sales totaling 16.94 million tonnes, the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) said in its annual report released Thursday.
It said 130,333 vessels called the Singapore port in 1997, while total cargo tonnage handled by the port rose by 4.2 percent to 327 million tonnes.
Singapore's merchant fleet also grew, expanding by 2.53 million gross tonnes to 20.77 million gross tonnes, making it the eighth-largest fleet in the world.
To boost the Singapore Port's competitiveness, the MPA decided last year to liberalize tug-boat services.

It lifted restrictions on the purchase of new tugs for replacement purposes, and removed the requirement for towing service providers to charter or time-share new tugs to the Port of Singapore Authority Corporation.
Financially, MPA ended the year with a net surplus of S$60.9 million (US$34.89 million). The bulk of its S$150.4 million operating income came from port dues and marine services.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIVIDED CHINA IS A FACT UNDENIABLE, SAYS MAC

TEXT.P: The fact that China is divided is an historic as well as political reality that is undeniable, said Sheu Ke-sheng, spokesman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Friday.

Sheu said the Chinese mainland has been governed by the Beijing authorities while Taiwan, Penghu (Pescadores), Kinmen (Quemoy) and Matsu have continuously been governed by the Republic of China government. Over the past half century, the People's Republic of China has never -- not for a single day -- exercised jurisdiction over Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu.

Sheu made the remarks in response to a letter from mainland China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS). The letter, which reached Taipei on Friday, said Beijing opposes Taipei's intention to "espouse" that Taiwan and mainland China are two political entities under separate rules, and that they are "temporarily two Chinas."

The MAC vice chairman said the ROC has continuously been a sovereign country since its inception 87 years ago, and since 1949 two distinct political entities have existed on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

ARATS, in its strongly worded letter to its Taipei counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said SEF officials have never been allowed to travel to the mainland to negotiate issues over the welfare and interests of the Taiwan people in the past years, and they will never be allowed to do so in the future.

ARATS also blamed SEF for intentionally boycotting Beijing's initiatives in pushing for discussions on Taiwan investment guarantees and the interests of Taiwan travelers on the mainland by insisting that the "jurisdiction" issue should be clarified first.

Sheu stressed that the ARATS letter, apparently not friendly, will not influence SEF's work to prepare for SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu's forthcoming visit to the mainland, probably in September or October.

Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the Kuomintang's Mainland Research Department, said the ARATS letter is aimed at manipulating development prior to Koo's mainland visit so that ARATS and SEF will begin with political talks instead of discussing technical issues.
SEF prefers to first take care of technical issues before handling political matters in its negotiations with ARATS.
ARATS and SEF are intermediary bodies which are authorized by their respective governments to handle exchanges in the absence of official ties.

SEF Chairman Koo has been invited to visit mainland China in September or October this year to meet his ARATS counterpart, Wang Daohan, for a meeting. Koo and Wang met in Singapore in April 1993 for an ice-breaking rendezvous, which loosely established a framework for regular talks between the two sides in the future.

Koo was scheduled to meet Wang again for a second "Koo-Wang" talks in 1995. The meeting was never realized as Beijing unilaterally suspended talks after President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in the summer of 1995, which Beijing viewed as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN URGED TO TREAT TAIPEI, BEIJING ON EQUAL FOOTING

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Friday urged Japan to extend equal treatment to the two political entities on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

"We earnestly hope that the Japanese government will face up to the reality that China is now separately ruled by two political entities and that Japan can treat the two entities on an equal footing," Lee said.
He made the appeal in a recent interview with the Japanese monthly magazine "Bungei Shunshu."

The president said the Republic of China has no intention of interfering with engagement between Japan and mainland China. Nevertheless, he went on, the premise is that such engagement should not disrupt peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, nor should it undermine the ROC's national interests or the security and well-being of Taiwan's 21.8 million people.
Moreover, Japan should simultaneously upgrade its relations with the ROC while engaging with mainland China, he said.
The president went on to say he thinks Japan has invited mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to make a state visit early next month mainly to foster peace in Asia in the 21st century.

However, Lee said he doesn't think mainland China accepted the invitation in the same spirit. "Beijing is very likely to take advantage of the event to pressure Japan to throw support behind its `three noes' policy on Taiwan, and to exclude Taiwan from the coverage of the US-Japan defense cooperation treaty.

"We are hopeful that Japan can fully understand mainland China's true intention," Lee said, adding that if Japan truly intends to safeguard Asia-Pacific regional peace, it should forge closer cooperative relations with the ROC.
Noting that Japan has clearly explained its policy toward Taiwan in the past, Lee said he sees no need for Japan to reaffirm its stance on the Beijing-proposed "three noes" during Jiang's visit.
"My personal view is that economics remains the main problem between Japan and mainland China. I hope the Japanese leadership will not do any nonsensical things during Jiang's visit," he said.

He made special mention of the fact that US President Bill Clinton's words in Shanghai in June were similar to those uttered in talks between Jiang and former Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto last September.

Clinton said at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai on June 30 that there will be no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.
Lee said he thinks Clinton chose his words carefully.

"There is a big gap between `no support' and `opposition.' I think `no support' is a neutral phrase that complies with Washington's `no involvement' or `no interference' stance on cross-strait issues," Lee said.

Turning to cross-strait relations, Lee said the key objective of the ROC's mainland policy lies with maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and forging mutual trust and positive interaction.

Based on these priority goals, Lee said, the ROC has never given up its expectations of a resumption of cross-strait dialogue since Beijing unilaterally suspended institutionalized bilateral consultations more than three years ago.

"Through our strenuous efforts, the two quasi-official intermediary bodies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- have finally reached a consensus that SEF Chairman C.F. Koo will make a landmark visit to the mainland this fall," Lee said.

The president further expressed his hope that institutionalized cross-strait talks will be resumed soon so that the two sides can exchange views and mend their differences, paving the way for better cross-strait ties and contributing to regional peace and stability.

As for Taipei-Tokyo relations, Lee said he looks forward to seeing Japan's academic, political and business communities gain a deeper and more accurate understanding of Taiwan's developments in political, economic, social, and various other fields, in order to further boost bilateral friendship and cooperation for mutual benefit.
Given the rate at which younger people are joining the two countries' political and business elite, Lee said, this younger generation on both sides should reinforce contacts and engagements.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG HEAD BLASTS `GO SLOW, BE PATIENT' POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 20 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The head of the Taiwan-based Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) on Thursday criticized the ROC government's "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China, saying it has hindered Taiwan entrepreneurs doing business there.

FPG Chairman Y.C. Wang also said that because of steadfast opposition from the government, the group has withdrawn from a controversial power plant project in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province. The FPG's stake has now been taken over by foreign investors from Japan, Germany and Hong Kong, he added.
But for the sake of his personal credibility, he himself has maintained a "very small" personal stake in the project, he said.

The FPG originally estimated that the US$3 billion power plant would require US$2.3 billion-worth of syndicated loans. Three FPG enterprises under the FPG -- Formosa Plastics, Nan Ya Plastics and Taiwan Chemical & Fiber -- would have contributed US$420 million, or 60 percent of the remaining US$700 million.
Turning to a long-moribund project to build a naphtha cracking plant in Haicheng, also in Fujian Province, Wang said this plan may be resurrected.

As far back as ten years ago, the FPG planned to build the plant at a cost of more than US$6 billion, but the idea was shelved when mainland authorities failed to meet Wang's financing and other terms.
However, he also said that there are many other places in the mainland that are worth investing in.

Wang was reluctant to directly answer questions on when the FPG's investment in the mainland would start again, only saying obliquely that there are about 20 months left in the tenure of ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
He also said that while Lee has made great contributions to the democratic development in Taiwan, he had reservations about his performance in other aspects.

Wang, dubbed "the god of management" in Taiwan, also said there are an estimated 30,000 or more Taiwan businessmen in the mainland, and that a way must be found for them to band together in order to protect their interests and maintain their competitiveness.
He suggested the idea of establishing special "zones" in the mainland as a way in which Taiwan businessmen could better protect their interests.
He noted that Taiwan's processing industry has been unable to maintain its momentum at home since about a decade ago, and has had to move overseas.

He said that it is better to invest in the mainland than in the Southeast Asia, because the countries of Southeast Asia have adopted liberal economic systems. Taiwan businessmen who invest in the region will bring Taiwan's processing technology with them, which will allow local manufacturers to learn and profit from Taiwan's expertise. This will ultimately result in extra competition for Taiwan.
The mainland, by contrast, has adopted an econometric system, and finds it is not easy to compete with Taiwan.
Wang, who arrived in New Jersey on Monday, was hosting a visiting Fujian delegation led by Chen Mingyi, secretary of the Fujian provincial committee of the Chinese Communist Party.
Chen said in New York on Wednesday that the thermal power plant has been going on according to schedule, but he did not say who the investors are.
Wang was slated to leave for Texas on Friday to brief Chen about an FPG petrochemical plant there.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SEEKING TO FORGE SOLIDARITY PRIOR TO ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang will hold a meeting over the weekend to forge a spirit of solidarity for the year-end legislative and mayoral elections.

During the second plenary session of the KMT's 15th Central Committee, the participants will listen to reports on party and government affairs, discuss the election campaign, and reshuffle the Central Standing Committee.
The scale of changes in the Central Standing Committee, though modest, will be a principal focus of the meeting.
The KMT Central Standing Committee has 33 seats, including 16 appointed by President Lee Teng-hui in his capacity as party chairman, and 17 elected positions.
It is known that John Chang, KMT secretary-general, will take the appointed seat vacated by Presidential Adviser Lee Huan, who tendered his resignation earlier this week.

The other 15, including Premier Vincent Siew, Presidential Adviser Wu Poh-hsiung, National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, Examination Yuan President Shu Shui-teh, Legislative Yuan President Liu Sung-pan, and Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei, will remain unchanged.
Five elected members, including Hsu Li-teh, James Chu, Hsieh Lung-sheng, Tai Tung-yuan and Yeh Chin-feng, will no longer compete for seats for various reasons.

Those expected to fill their positions include Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, and National Assembly Deputy Su Nan-cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURE EXCHANGE DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 57.47 points to close at 7,213.47.
The bourse opened at 7,268.14 points, 2.7 lower than Thursday's close, and continued to fall until close of trading.
A total of 1.28 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$58.33 billion, down from Thursday's NT$63.9 billion.
Of the eight major categories, only cement and construction stocks remained unchanged.

All other major categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.9 percent, textile issues at 0.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.6 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on Taipei's stock index futures registered a general decline.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September dropped 49 points to close at 7,225. Those for December slid 76 points to close at 7,430, while those for March decreased 49 points to close at 7,452.
Contract transactions for the three months amounted to 301, nine, and one, respectively. No transactions were registered for October or June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were listed as follows: 7,274 points for September; 7,301 for October; 7,506 for December; 7,501 for March; and 7,642 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCUMENTS REVEAL CHIANG KAI-SHEK'S PLAN TO RECOVER M'LAND
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 21 (CNA) (By Chang Fang-ming and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A series of documents recently declassified by the US government have revealed that Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek had planned to recover five southern provinces of mainland China during the height of the Vietnam War.

Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun quoted a report from Washington, D.C. on Friday as saying that the declassified documents disclosed that Chiang proposed in 1965 that ROC troops should join US forces fighting in Vietnam to stage an assault from Indochina on the Chinese mainland.

The proposal, broached to then US Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara by the generalissimo's son, Chiang Ching-kuo, who was the ROC defense minister at that time, said the ROC troops could mount an assault on the southern Chinese provinces of Guangdong, Guangxi, Yunnan, Guizhou and Sichuan, with the objective of recovering the five provinces once and for all.

According to the documents, which focus on military and intelligence information about Taiwan and mainland China between 1964 and 1968, Chiang Ching-kuo emphasized to McNamara that anti-communist sentiment in the five provinces was the strongest among all the provinces of the mainland, and that the generalissimo enjoyed a high reputation among the people there.

McNamara agreed to have the proposal studied, but the US Joint Chiefs of Staff poured cold water on the plan, on the grounds that such an assault would not work without direct American involvement in the form of air and naval support, according to the documents.
In addition, there was no concrete intelligence to indicate that the people in the five provinces would support the ROC.
