In March 1967, then US President Lyndon Johnson also voiced opposition to the Chiang proposal, saying that the "recovery of the mainland" mission would trap Taiwan in a great dilemma, and trigger the risk of greater destruction across the Taiwan Strait, the documents said.

The documents also disclosed that the US was aware of Beijing's plan to conduct its maiden nuclear test on Oct. 16, 1964, and that Washington proposed to Moscow that the two sides make a joint effort to undermine the test. The proposal was apparently rebuffed by Moscow.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar plunged NT$0.133 to the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 34.69.
The local currency opened at 34.578 and was trade between 34.584 and 34.699.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$230 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK GOVERNOR CONCERNED ABOUT US DEBT

TEXT.P: The United States will likely get into trouble sooner or later due to its heavy foreign debt, Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China, said in a speech Friday.
The US is the world's top debtor with US$1.5 trillion in foreign debt, Perng said.

He remarked that the US dollar has continued to remain strong since 1995, as the Japanese yen began its slide. This can be attributed to the fact that the two countries were undergoing different economic cycles, Perng analyzed. The US economy has been booming with high interest rates, while Japan's economy hit bottom with interest rates kept at a too-low level.
Owing to the huge difference in interest rates, Perng went on, Japanese capital rushed out on a large scale to buy US government bonds and thereby contributed to the US dollar's stability.
However, the bank governor added, the heavy demand against a somewhat short supply of the greenback is a "very unhealthy condition."

Being the world's political, economic and military superpower, the US can still attract credit from many nations and keep its economy in a relatively prosperous state despite the fact that the US is the top debtor in the world, Perng commented.

After the European Union's euro makes its debut next year, he added, it will supersede the deutsche mark as the hard currency and will follow the suit of the US dollar as an option for investors world-wide.

What is worth noting, the governor said, is that as a result of the integration of the European economy through the euro and the integration of the North American economy through maneuvering of the US, Asian countries will be pressured to further develop their economies.
All Asian countries should cooperate in advance to deal with the emerging situation, otherwise the prospects will not likely be rosy, Perng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOURISTS TO BE BANNED FROM IMPORTING FRESH FRUIT FROM OCT. 1

TEXT.P: From Oct. 1, tourists returning from overseas will not be allowed to bring fresh fruit into the country, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced on Friday.

Lee Ching-lung, director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Quarantine under the COA, said that a number of insect pests and plant diseases have been imported into Taiwan via unquarantined fresh fruit brought in by local tourists, posing a serious threat to the island's agriculture and ecology.
Current laws allow travelers to bring up to two kilograms of fresh fruit into Taiwan.

Lee called on the public to abide by the new regulation, adding that some 20 bureau officials will be stationed at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan to help inspect luggage for violations.
Any fresh fruit found will be regarded as contraband and confiscated, Lee said, adding that serious violations will invite prosecution.

Yang Pin-chih, agricultural professor at National Taiwan University, said that the Mediterranean fruit fly and the Mexican fruit fly are two of the biggest threats to Taiwan's fruit farmers. If the Mediterranean fruit fly should invade the island, it would be a major disaster, he warned.

The apple snail, introduced from abroad to be farmed as a food source, is a prime example of how introduced species can wreak havoc on the island's ecosystem, Yang said. The voracious gastropods, which attack rice plants, have few natural predators and breed rapidly. Escapees have been very successful in virtually overrunning the island's paddies.
Each year the government spends some NT$160 million to keep down the number of snails, and so far a total of NT$3 billion has been poured into the work, to little avail.
Yang also singled out the Brazilian turtle, the silver leaf white fly, and the Asian palm weevil as damaging to Taiwan's agriculture and ecology.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 MORE F-16 FIGHTERS ARRIVE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Three more US-built F-16 jet fighters arrived at an ROC Air Force base in the southern county of Chiayi on Thursday, military sources said on Friday.

The Air Force General Headquarters said in a news release that the US manufacturer of the advanced fighters was originally scheduled to deliver five F-16s to Taiwan, but one of the planes developed engine problems on its flight from the United States to Taiwan.
The leader of the flight team ordered the plane to make an emergency landing on the Japanese island of Okinawa, escorted by another F-16, the Air Force Headquarters said.
As the delivery was handled by the manufacturer of the plane, Lockheed Martin Co., the Air Force Headquarters said it has asked the company to offer a briefing on the cause of the incident.
The Republic of China struck a deal with the United States in 1992 for the purchase of 150 F-16s as part of its military modernization plan. Some 50 F-16s have so far been delivered to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, the ROC has also ordered 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters from France to replace its aging fleet and upgrade air defense capabilities. The ROC Air Force has taken delivery of some 30 of the Mirage fighters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA INTERVIEW WITH GEN. HAU ON 8-23 BOMBARDMENT OF KINMEN

TEXT.P: The communist Chinese bombardment of Kinmen during the 44-day Taiwan Strait Crisis in 1958 is one of the most special cases of war in history, Gen. Hau Pei-tsun, former chief of the general staff, said Friday.
During the crisis, the troops of mainland China pounded the islands of Kinmen with 474,000 artillery shells, but they failed to seize the islands.

Hau, who was the commander of the ninth division of the garrison troops on Kinmen at that time, said in an interview with the CNA that he believed Mao Tze-tung was then afraid of provoking the United States into war with mainland China.
He said he believed Mao's real intention to wage the war was to test US determination to help defend Taiwan, because Mao hoped to seize Taiwan by force sometime later.
Taiwan's success in defeating mainland China in the crisis marked the beginning of steady economic development and democratization on Taiwan, Hau said.
He pointed out three reasons for the bombardment of Kinmen, which occurred at the height of the Cold War between the Soviet Union and the United States.

He said tension between the two superpowers in the Middle East was very high at that time. Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev, who visited Beijing about one month before the bombardment, wanted to divert US attention to the Far East by asking Mao to shell Kinmen, Hau said.

Mao, who had incurred the wrath of mainland Chinese people by initiating various disastrous social movements, such as the Great Cultural Revolution and the Great Leap Forward, wanted to divert the attention of the people to a conflict with Taiwan.
The third reason for the bombardment is Mao's intention to test US determination to support Taiwan as mentioned earlier.
Hau said US assistance and the use of US-made weapons, such as the Rattlesnake air-to-air missiles, were important in winning the war.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OPPOSES ANY FORM OF TERRORISM: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday that the Republic of China opposes any form of terrorism and revealed that Washington briefed Taipei about its attacks on suspected terrorist bases in Afghanistan and Sudan.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said it was usual practice for the United States to report its anti-terrorist strikes to other countries because such activity requires international effort.
The ROC supports the US attack, Wu said, adding that the international community should join forces to crack down on the spread of terrorism around the world.

Wu's comments come after US forces on Thursday attacked a suspected terrorist base in Afghanistan and a chemical weapons facility in Sudan which were allegedly involved in the deadly explosions at the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania on Aug. 7.

As to the security measures at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de-facto US embassy here, Wu said the AIT has maintained close contact with Taipei authorities since the African embassies were attacked. He added that local police have stepped up patrol and security efforts in the neighborhoods of foreign embassies.

Chen Kuo-huang, director of MOFA's West Asian Affairs Department, said Afghanistan has been very unfriendly to Taipei since 1950 when the Islamic country shifted diplomatic recognition to Beijing. Currently, there are no ROC nationals in Afghanistan and two-way trade between the two countries is limited, Chen noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SERVICE HELD TO MARK 40TH ANNIVERSARY OF AUG. 23 BOMBARDMENT

TEXT.P: On behalf of President Lee Teng-hui, Defense Minister Chiang Chung-ling on Friday paid his respects to the officers, soldiers and civilians who were killed during the Aug. 23 artillery bombardment of Kinmen.
On the approach of the 40th anniversary of the military campaign, a public rites and memorial service, presided over by Chiang, were held in Kinmen to commemorate those who died in the battle.
The rites and service were held at the Martyrs Shrine on Taiwu Mountain Public Cemetery, and the Kinmen County Social Education Hall respectively.

More than 900 people, including Vice Chief of the General Staff Lee Chieh, Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Tang Yao-ming, Fukian Provincial Governor Yen Chung-cheng, representatives of the officers and soldiers who took part in the battle, and representatives from all walks of life in Kinmen, participated in the ceremonies.

The battle broke out on Aug. 23, 1958 when the mainland Chinese forces launched a cluster of artillery bombardments on Kinmen and its adjacent islets at 6:30 p.m. Over 470,000 shells were fired by the mainland gunners within 44 days on a 150-square kilometer area.
A total of 587 officers and men died in the battle and another 2,016 were injured. In addition, a total of 80 civilians were killed, and 85 were seriously injured.
The mainland's ambition to invade Taiwan was thwarted by the steadfast armed forces of the Republic of China, and stability in the Taiwan Strait was assured, Chiang said.

He pointed out that the artillery battle had a decisive impact on Taiwan's future as people were given a choice between freedom or slavery. He told the representatives of those who took part in the military campaign that they earned the prosperity of the island through the blood and sweat of their deceased loved-ones.

The defense minister expressed the hope that the sound of artillery shells on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will never be heard again. Problems between the two sides can be solved with patience and wisdom, Chiang added.

"In this way, the commemoration of the Aug. 23 Taiwan Strait Military Campaign can have a special significant and value, and the battle can shine brighter in the first leaf under the cover of the history", he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MEETS WITH PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT'S SON

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday met with Joseph Victor Ejercito, son of Philippine President Joseph Estrada.
Siew welcomed Ejercito to Taiwan, saying that the Republic of China and the Philippines have maintained close, stable relations with ranking officials often exchanging visits.
Taipei will continue to allow Philippine laborers to come to the island for work, Siew said, adding that this workforce has contributed to Taiwan's economic development.

To seek even closer bilateral ties, Taiwan will continue to assist the Southeast Asian country with economic development plans as well as encourage more Taiwan businessmen to invest in the country, the premier stressed.
Siew suggested that Manila provide more convenient channels for foreigners to apply for investment projects if it wants to attract more foreign investment.

On Asia's financial turmoil, Siew said the Philippines and Malaysia have been emerging from the shadow of the crisis. He reiterated that Taiwan would like to contribute to regional stability and is willing to help those troubled Asian countries shake off their financial troubles.
Ejercito arrived in Taiwan on Thursday for a three-day visit at the invitation of the Junior Chamber of the Republic of China. He is scheduled to leave the island on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MISSION LEAVES FOR GUIANA TO VIEW LAUNCHING OF ST-1 SATELLITE

TEXT.P: A delegation of Taiwan telecommunications officials, media executives and journalists left for the French colony of Guiana in South America on Friday to watch the launching of the Republic of China's first commercial satellite.

"The satellite, dubbed ST-1, will be launched on Aug. 25 from the Kourou Space Center in French Guiana aboard Arianespace No. 4 rockey owned by Arianespace Co., a famous satellite launch company," said a spokesman for the state-run Chunghwa Telecom Co.

The 44-member delegation, composed of officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, and senior executives from major local television companies and radio stations, is headed by Chunhwa Telecom Chairman Chen Yao.
The mission members also included officials from the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau, both of them Chunhwa Telecom's big customers.
The ST-1 satellite system, jointly owned by Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecom Ltd., will orbit 36,000 kilometers above the earth, roughly above the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.

"Built by Matra Marconi Space Co. of France, the new satellite will be launched into a geostationary orbit synchronized with 88 degree E," the Chunghwa spokesman explained, adding that the good orbital location will help ensure that the satellite will enjoy high elevation angles throughout Southeast Asia.

Equipped with a number of advanced transponders, the new satellite system is expected to be especially helpful to businesses involved in remote communications, video and audio broadcasting, and information transmission, the spokesman said.
The new satellite cost a total of US$240 million, with Taiwan and Singapore splitting the cost. The satellite system includes a ground control station each in Taiwan and Singapore.

Taiwan's central control station is located on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei. Chunghwa Telecom has also constructed other ground monitoring stations in Panchiao, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Fanshan to ensure smooth operations.
If the planned Aug. 25 launch proceeds smoothly, the new satellite system will be able to operate at least 12 years in space. Its actual life span can reach 13 years.

The ST-1 satellite will have 12 C-band transponders and 16 Ku-band transponders. Its C-band coverage stretches from the Middle East to Japan and Southeast Asia, including Taiwan, Singapore, mainland China, the Philippines, Indonesia, Indochina and the Indian Subcontinent.

The Ku-band coverage is divided into two regions-- K1 and K2. The K1 area focuses on Taiwan, Singapore, coastal mainland China, the Philippines, Indonesia and Malaysia, while K2 provides coverage of the Indian Subcontinent.

Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecom struck the joint-venture deal in September 1995 based on the principles of equality and reciprocity with an aim to meet the growing market demand and improve communications services to their clients.

DOC.HEADLINE: `THREE LINKS' ACTIVISTS QUESTIONED

TEXT.P: Eighteen activists detained by police in Kinmen earlier Friday for violating a government ban by traveling directly to the mainland were released after a preliminary interrogation by a prosecutor, police said.
The activists were accused of violating the National Security Law and the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

The group was co-headed by Tsao Yuan-chang, a National Assembly member, and Taipei County Councilor Kin Chieh-shou, both of whom claimed to have played the role of pioneers of direct shipping, trade and communications between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The group was aboard the "Hawaii No. 3" vessel. It left northern Taiwan's Shenao port on Tuesday, bound for fishing grounds in the seas north of the island. Shortly after setting off, the ship changed its registered course, and headed directly for Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian Province, according to police.

The boat reached Xiamen on Wednesday. After a one-day visit, the group left for the Taiwan-controlled island stronghold of Kinmen, in a second attempt to travel directly across the Taiwan Strait without going via a third country.
However, they encountered ROC police patrol vessels near Kinmen. Maritime police demanded to board the vessel, but were rejected, whereupon the two sides became locked in a stalemate.
The confrontation at sea lasted for around 20 minutes, until the ship docked at Hsinhu. However, the activists continued to resist police demands to board, and the standoff continued.
Shouting for "three direct links" with mainland China, they were echoed by more than 10 supporters on shore, led by National Assembly member Lee Chu-fang of the opposition New Party.

Kin said the "taboo-breaking" voyage was aimed at promoting the "mini three links," which would allow direct commercial, shipping and postal exchanges between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China.

He stressed that similar sailings between the two front-line islands and mainland China have been going on unofficially for years. Although illegal, it is no secret that Taiwan fishing vessels often make direct sailings to mainland territory in order to save costs, Kim said.
He added that their action was taken only to highlight a fact long ignored by the government.
During the group's stay in Xiamen, Kim noted that they met with ranking city officials. Kim and Tsao both belong to the New Party, which strongly favors Taiwan's reunification with the mainland.
The New Party is the smallest of the three main political parties in Taiwan.
Legislator Chen Kuang-fu, a member of the radical Taiwan Independence Party, on Friday filed charges against Kim and Tsao for their "betrayal of Taiwan and collaboration with the enemy."
He also urged New Party heavyweights Jaw Shau-kong and Wang Chien-shien to issue a public statement condemning their members' behavior.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE NUMBER OF VISITS TO DOCTORS HITS 7.7 TIMES IN SIX MONTHS

TEXT.P: People covered by the national health insurance program visited their doctors an average of 7.7 times in the first half of the year, statistics from the Directorate-General of Budget Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed.
The figure is up from the 7.3 times registered for the same period last year.

During the first six months of the year, the National Health Insurance Bureau received medical bills totaling NT$129.3 billion (US$3.73 billion), up 8.8 percent from the same period last year, the DGBAS said.
On average, the medical fees each insured individual applied for was about NT$6,293 during the six-month period.

As of the end of June, 20.6 million people around the island have taken part in the national health insurance program, representing an increase of 349,000 people from the year-earlier level. The figure suggests that 96.1 percent of Taiwan residents are covered by the compulsory health insurance program.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, PHILIPPINES TO STRENGTHEN COOP. IN AGRICULTURE AND FISHERY

TEXT.P: The cooperation between the Republic of China and the Philippines in the areas of agriculture and fishery will be strengthened in the future, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Friday.

Joseph Victor Ejercito, son of Philippine President Joseph Estrada, visited the Cabinet-level COA Friday to exchange views on bilateral cooperation in the fields of agriculture and fishery, investment, as well as the flow of technology.

During the meeting, the COA agreed to provide the Philippines with agricultural technological training and select some Philippine agricultural enterprises to proceed with an experimental cooperation program.

Ejercito arrived in Taiwan Thursday to attend the 45th anniversary of the Junior Chamber of the Republic of China in his capacity as the president of the Junior Chamber of the Philippines. He called on Peng Tso-kuei, chairman of the COA, Friday morning.
The Philippines has been severely hit by the Asian financial turmoil and needs foreign capital and technology to help it recover industries and increase food production, Peng said.
Taiwan has experience in developing of agriculture and advanced technology, and also has plenty of private capital. The island can be a big help to the Philippines, Peng added.
He said the ROC will push for more mutual visits by ranking officials on both sides through agriculture and fishery relations.
Peng also hopes that through the official dialogue channel, the Philippines will improve its investment climate to encourage Taiwan's agricultural enterprises to invest there.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF NICARAGUAN LABORERS TO ENTER TAIWAN UNDECIDED

TEXT.P: The number of Nicaraguan nationals to be permitted to work in Taiwan will be decided by market demand, Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairman Chan Hou-sheng said Friday.

Although Nicaraguan Labor Affairs Minister Wilfredo Navarro announced in Taipei Thursday that the two countries had signed a letter of intent with Taiwan agreeing to import 5,000 Nicaraguan laborers, Chan said the two countries only discussed the content of the pact and have yet to reach a final agreement on the actual numbers.
The market demand will determine the number, Chan said, adding that the two sides are scheduled to ink a formal agreement in October, which must be first approved by the Executive Yuan.

Lin Tsong-ming, director-general of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, said they will also have to take into consideration the willingness of local employers to hire Nicaraguans in determining the quota number.

The government has put a freeze on the quota of foreign workers permitted to the island. Currently, only those major public construction projects worth over NT$200 million (US$5.7 million) can bring in foreign workers on a case-by-case basis, Lin said. The quota for each such project is about 500 foreign workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWSMEN WITNESSED 1958 BOMBARDMENT OF KINMEN (PART I)

TEXT.P: Over 300 journalists risked their lives to report to the world about Beijing's ambition to invade Taiwan during the historical bombardment of the Kinmen islands by the mainland forces beginning on Aug. 23, 1958.

During the 44-day marathon shelling of Kinmen, a key island in the Taiwan Strait protecting Taiwan and the Penghu islands, a total of 587 officers and soldiers were killed. Other casualties included the drowning of six Chinese and foreign reporters.

On Sept. 26 that year, eight Chinese and foreign reporters attempted to land in the midst of a battle via a Marine Corps landing craft. Under heavy shelling, the vessel developed engine trouble as it approached Kinmen's Liaolo Bay.

The landing craft sank, and six of the eight reporters drowned or went missing along with three crewmen. The six reporters who lost their lives included Hsu Po-chiu of the Taiwan Shin Sheng Daily News, Wu Hsu of the China Daily News, Mr. Yasuda of Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun, and Mr. Choe of the Korean Times. The two surviving reporters were Yen Chung-tzo of the Young Warriors Daily News and Mr. Okuto of Japan's Kyodo News Service.
Despite the deaths, over 300 Chinese and foreign newsmen, with their pens and cameras, had managed to report from the frontline the aggressive actions the mainland Chinese forces were engaging in.

Earlier then Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev visited Beijing on July 31 for talks with Mao Zedong and Zhou Enlai. Both sides issued a joint statement after their talks, and political observers sensed that the stalemate situation in the Taiwan Strait was going to undergo a change.

Early in August that year, the Republic of China's Defense Ministry disclosed that the Chinese Communists had deployed squadrons of MiG jet fighters to the coastal airports in Fukien and Guangdong Provinces. Flotillas of speed torpedo boats and boats equipped with cannons had also been dispatched to Fukien's Santuao Base. Beijing did not hide its intention of invading Kinmen and Taiwan's other outlying islands.

On Aug. 14, ROC Air Force's F86 "Saber" fighters shot down three MiG-17 jets, while the navy sank four mainland Chinese cannon vessels. It was then that the international news media began to turn their attention to the Taiwan Strait, expecting the arrival of some "big news."
As expected, the Chinese Communists mobilized hundreds of artillery to shell Kinmen from 6:30 p.m. on Aug. 23. That marked the start of the 44-day bombardment of Kinmen.

Lo Chao-chun, who served as a photographer for the army at that time, recalled that the first group of the scores of Chinese and foreign reporters went to Penghu by warship on Aug. 28 that year, waiting for chance to proceed to Kinmen.
But owing to the massive shelling, these reporters could not leave for Kinmen until Sept. 2 when they embarked for the island by a landing craft.
Good luck was not with them. When the landing craft reached Kinmen's Liaolo Bay, it encountered sea battles between the two warring navies.

Only few reporters were able to land on the battlefield by transferring onto small boats across rope ladders. Chang Chia-hsiang, now chairman of the Chinese Television System, was one of them. He was a reporter for the Young Warriors Daily News at that time. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWSMEN WITNESSED 1958 BOMBARDMENT OF KINMEN (PART II)

TEXT.P: For safety and security reasons, the ROC Defense Ministry and the US military authorities in Taiwan stopped accepting applications for newsmen to cover the news on Kinmen on Sept. 15. But the restrictions were lifted on Sept. 24.

C.C. Yau, a senior adviser to Reuters in Taipei, was among the first group of reporters to land on Kinmen after the bombardment. He said his group left Taipei's Sungshan Airport by a C46 transport at 4 a.m. on Sept. 24.

The propeller-powered plane made a stop at Penghu and reached Kinmen at 5 a.m. Shortly after the reporters disembarked from the plane, the mainland Chinese forces resumed their massive shelling, forcing them to run to the slope for cover.

In the afternoon, Yau said officers had told them that the air force's F86 Sabers downed 10 MiG fighters over the Taiwan Strait. It marked the world's first use of the air-to-air "Rattlesnake" missiles in air battles.
Hona Yee, now Taipei bureau chief for the Pan-Asia Newspaper Alliance (PANA), was one of the few woman reporters to cover the Kinmen bombardment. She worked for a photo news publication at that time.

She recalled that she was not able to join the first group of reporters to Kinmen because the navy did not permit women aboard warships. Her wish to cover the historical mission was realized after authorities decided to take newsmen to the frontline in military aircraft.

On Sept. 26, the second group of Chinese and foreign reporters went to Kinmen by a naval ship. Eight reporters were transferred to an LVT landing craft when the ship sailed into Kinmen's Liaolo Bay. Unfortunately, the vessel sank and six of the eight reporters lost their lives.

Yen Chung-tzo was one of the two survivors. In an interview with the CNA he was reluctant to recall the incident. He said, "A newsman's life is the same as that of a soldier. The difference is the duties they have to bear."

DOC.HEADLINE: 20TH CENTURY'S LAST SOLAR ECLIPSE CAN BE SEEN SATURDAY MORNING

TEXT.P: The 20th century's last solar eclipse can be seen in Taiwan early Saturday morning, the Taipei City Astronomy Science Observatory said Friday.
The observatory will open its doors at 7:20 a.m. to allow the public to observe the celestial event.

Due to different angles, residents of Indonesia and Malaysia will be able to see the solar annular eclipse, while residents of Taiwan will be able to see a partial eclipse, sources of the observatory said.

Those in the northern regions of Taiwan will be able see the solar eclipse beginning at 7:40 a.m. An hour later, about 30 percent of the sun will be covered by the moon. The sun will reappear in full at 9:50 a.m. The entire eclipse is expected to take two hours and 30 minutes, an official from the observatory said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang opened the second plenary session of its 15th Central Committee on Saturday.
The China Times: The United States fired sea-launched cruise missiles against what President Bill Clinton said were "terrorist" targets in Afghanistan and Sudan on Thursday, killing at least 26 people and injuring 50 others.
The United Daily News: Technology talents with advanced academic degrees will be allowed to serve substitute military conscription terms.
The Liberty Times: The United States fired 100 cruise missiles against alleged terrorist targets in Afghanistan and Sudan on Thursday, resulting in at least 26 deaths.
The Independence Morning Post: US cruise missiles struck on alleged terrorist sites in Afghanistan and Sudan on Thursday.
The Commons Daily: Minister of Justice Cheng Chung-mo vows to eradicate organized crime.
The China Post: The United States braces for reprisal after missile strikes on alleged terrorist sites in Afghanistan and Sudan on Thursday.
The China News: The United States hit back at terrorists on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ISRAELI REPRESENTATIVE VOWS TO BOLSTER TAIWAN-ISRAEL TIES

TEXT.P: Uri S. Gutman, the newly appointed Israeli representative in Taiwan, arrived recently in Taipei to assume his post, a source from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Saturday.

Gutman, who succeeds Acting Representative Akiva Tor, is the first professional diplomat appointed by Tel Aviv to be its representative in Taiwan, said Chen Kuo-huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Department of West Asian Affairs.
Tel Aviv appointed its first representative to Taipei in 1993. Gutman's two predecessors were both trade officials from Israel's Ministry of Industry and Trade, Chen said.

Gutman has said that in addition to continuing to bolster bilateral business and trade links between Israel and Taiwan, he will also further strengthen substantive exchanges in the fields of environmental protection, science and technology, education and culture, according to Chen.

The 39-year-old career diplomat has been with the Israeli Foreign Ministry since 1989. He was appointed deputy consul in Israel's consulate-general in Istanbul, Turkey in 1991, and has also served as a liaison officer in the Israeli embassy in Stockholm, Sweden.

Taipei and Tel Aviv forged a memorandum of understanding in June on exemption of marine transportation income tax between Taiwan and Israel. An executive protocol on temporary admission of goods is also under discussion, paving the way for the two governments to sign an agreement on the preferential treatment in the near future, Chen said.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Israel totaled US$540 million in 1997, up a whopping 20 percent from 1996's US$430 million, according to Foreign Ministry tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE IN 'NO HASTE' POLICY

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh reiterated on Saturday that there will be no change in the government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China.
The top mainland policy planner made the statement in response to Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Wang Yung-ching's fresh criticism of the government's mainland investment policy.
Chang said Wang has every right to express his personal views or opinions, adding: "I would not make any comments on the veteran tycoon's opinions."
Nevertheless, Chang said, the government has its own policy which cannot be adjusted simply because of criticism by a few people.

"The `no haste, be patient' policy is based on our national situation and relations across the Taiwan Strait," Chang noted, stressing that there is a practical need for Taiwan to maintain the policy since Beijing has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan.
Moreover, Chang said, a number of public opinion polls conducted by both government and private institutions have consistently shown that the majority of local people support the policy.

Under the policy, Taiwan companies are banned from investing in major infrastructure construction projects in mainland China, and are also required to apply for prior government approval in cases where the capital needed for a single investment project exceeds US$50 million.

Without a green light from the ROC government, the FPG was forced to withdraw earlier this year from a controversial thermal power plant investment project in Zhangzhou in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian.
FPG Chairman Wang said in New York on Wednesday that the group's stake in the Zhangzhou power plant project has been taken over by investors from Japan, Germany and Hong Kong.
As Taiwan's largest private manufacturing group, Wang said, the FPG is unlikely to defy the government's mainland investment policy.

Nonetheless, the tycoon, known as "the god of management" in Taiwan, doubted the government's wisdom in adopting such a policy. "It's regrettable that the FPG has had to withdraw from the Zhangzhou project, which I think would have been a good bet."
Wang further said a long-moribund FPG plan to build a massive petrochemical complex in Haicang, Fujian Province, may be revived after President Lee Teng-hui's current tenure expires in May 2000.
Wang declined to elaborate on the substance or the timeframe of the Haicang project, only saying obliquely that there are only 20 months left in Lee's tenure as president.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO INTRODUCE FLEXITIME FOR MILITARY PERSONNEL

TEXT.P: The Australian Defense Force (ADF) will introduce flexitime later this year to allow military personnel to work part-time, work from home, rest up following difficult periods of service, and negotiate flexible work hours with their commanding officers.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that the radical departure for the military -- one of the most rigid workplaces left in the community -- is seen as an attempt to make the ADF more attractive to those with families.
ADF officials said the policy is also aimed at helping retain staff who wish to "fulfill education, training, or other aspirations," and to meet care responsibilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC ANNOUNCES ANTI-DOPING MOVES

TEXT.P: Australia scored a victory in its fight against drugs in Olympic sports when the International Olympic Committee (IOC) on Friday announced it will set up an international anti-drug agency.
The IOC decision was announced on Friday by IOC President Juan Antonio Samaranch, who retracted from comments he made last month that use of drugs in some sports could be overlooked.
The Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG), which strongly criticized Samaranch's earlier remarks, welcomed his new statement.
Samaranch said the agency will conduct its own out-of-competition testing of top athletes in Olympic sports and work with international sporting federations to coordinate their anti-doping policies.
The agency will also operate a "roving" laboratory which will help officials in poorer countries conduct drug testing for major sporting events, he said.
Australian organizers want to make the Sydney Olympic Games in 2000 totally drug-free.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOL CONSUMPTION CAN IMPAIR CONCEPTION: STUDY

TEXT.P: Drinking even moderate amounts of alcohol may impair a women's ability to conceive, according to a new Danish medical study.

The results of the study, published on Saturday in the British Medical Journal, have surprised doctors as it had previously been thought that only heavy drinking had such an effect on women, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.

Australian doctors said the Danish study has prompted a call for Australian general practitioners to place greater emphasis on "pre-conception counseling" to encourage better health in women before they become pregnant.
The study followed 430 couples, aged 20 to 35, who were trying to conceive for the first time. For six menstrual cycles, they were surveyed about diet and lifestyle.
The researchers found that women who consumed up to five alcoholic drinks a week were less likely to have conceived than those who did not drink at all.

The more alcohol they drank, the less likely they were to have conceived. About 64 percent of those who had fewer than five weekly drinks became pregnant during the study, compared with 55 percent of those with a higher intake, according to the study.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SAUDI ARABIA ECONOMIC COOPERATION CONFERENCE TO OPEN IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu will visit the Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh from Oct.9 to 12 for the annual bilateral conference on economic cooperation, a foreign official said on Saturday.

The two countries have taken turns to sponsor the conference since the first meeting in Taipei in 1976 to discuss trade and economic cooperation, and technology exchanges, said Chen Kuo-huang, director of the Department of West Asian affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Chen said the conferences have continued despite the fact the ROC and Saudi Arabia severed diplomatic links in 1990. The two countries still enjoy a close cultural and economic relationship, he added.

According to MOFA statistics, Saudi Arabia is Taiwan's largest trade partner in the Middle East. Two-way trade in 1997 hit US$2.5 billion, most of which took the form of Saudi crude oil imported into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE TECHNOLOGY SERVICE SYSTEM TO BE INTRODUCED

TEXT.P: A system is to be introduced to allow conscripts with high technology educational backgrounds to perform research and development service rather than military duty, the Executive Yuan reported on Saturday.

The Defense Technology Service System (DTSS) will allow young men from graduate schools or higher-level educational institutes to continue their research careers without being interrupted by the two-year period of compulsory military service, said Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan.

It will also help solve the personnel shortage problems afflicting national and military research institutes, including the Industrial Technology Research Institute, the military Chung-shan Scientific Research Institute, and the Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest-level research institute, Liu said.

The DTSS is another plan devised as an alternative to regular military duty, and is part of an attempt to further reform the nation's military services. The government introduced a selective service system in April this year which allows conscripts to perform community service rather than joining active-duty military units.

The Excecutive Yuan on Friday convened a supra-ministerial meeting on science and technology development, presided over by Premier Vincent Siew. Participants included the ministers of national defense, education, interior, and economic affairs, as well as the head of the National Science Council and members of the Science and Technology Advisory Group.
During the meeting, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang formally broached the DTSS program for discussion among the relevant government agencies.
Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee also voiced his support for the proposal.

Lee said the modern function of a national defense force is to prevent war rather than to precipitate war, so there should be a variety of ways in which young men can serve the country. The DTSS would be a good option, he added.

The DTSS is expected to be put into practice in the near future as its implementation does not require new legislation. An amendment to relevant administrative orders will enough to legitimize the program, Executive Yuan officials said.
Siew instructed Tsai Chao-yang, a minister without portfolio, to lead a task force on the DTSS, which will be jointly implemented by the Ministry of Interior and the Ministry of National Defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CENTRAL AMERICAN COUNTRIES TO MEET
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Edward Chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Five central American countries and the Republic of China will hold a multilateral conference in El Salvador Tuesday to discuss Taiwan's economic development experience.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), and Jason Hu, minister of foreign affairs, will lead the ROC delegation to the meeting titled "Central American Countries to Share Taiwan's Economic Development Experience."
Foreign and economic ministers from El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica and Guatemala will also be on hand to represent their respective countries in the one-day gathering.

Chiang will preside over the meeting, which will cover the following three major topics: Taiwan's economic situation and its economic development experience; Central American countries' economic situation and development strategies; and ways to strengthen Taiwan's economic relations with central American countries.

Chiang and Hu are scheduled to arrive in El Salvador in the early hours of Monday morning. Shortly after their arrival, they will meet with El Salvador Vice President Enrique Borgos and then be interviewed for one of the country's newspaper. In the afternoon, they will visit Parliament Speaker Juan Duch Martinez.
At 5:00 p.m. that day, they will meet with El Salvador President Armando Calderon Sol. Later that night, a party will be held in their honor by President Calderon.
Chiang and Hu will proceed to Guatemala on Wednesday morning, where Hu will preside over a meeting attended by ROC diplomatic officials stationed in Latin America countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM SIEW ATTACHES GREAT IMPORTANCE TO 'KOO-WANG' MEETING

TEXT.P: China's reunification is an issue of two competing systems and a lifestyle choice, Premier Vincent Siew said on Saturday.

Taipei will continue to seek communication rather than confrontation, and negotiation rather than hostility with mainland China to improve cross-strait relations and create a climate which is ultimately conducive to reunification, he added.
Siew made the comments in his address to the second general meeting of the 15th Kuomintang Central Committee in his capacity as a KMT member who serves in a government post.

He said he attaches great importance to the proposed "Koo-Wang" meeting which is expected to be held in autumn, and he hopes that negotiators from the two sides will sincerely exchange views to work out agreements from differences.

Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan -- heads of the two intermediary bodies, Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- met for a landmark meeting in Singapore in April 1993 which laid a framework for regular talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. Their meeting has since been called the "Koo-Wang" talks.
Siew stressed that Taiwan fully supports reunification with the mainland under the principles of democracy, freedom and equality of wealth.
However, Taiwan firmly opposes the "one country, two system" formula which is controversial, anti-democratic and inequitable, he noted.

Taipei also steadfastly insists the fact that the Republic of China is a sovereign country independent from the People's Republic of China, and firmly opposes any bilateral or multilateral dialogue or negotiations in the international community that may damage Taiwan's interests, Siew emphasized.

On the issue of local politics, the premier said he finds it rewarding that his Cabinet has managed to successfully meet major social and political challenges as well as severe tests in public opinion over the past year. Siew assumed the premiership on Sept. 1, 1997.

At this crucial juncture at the turn of the century, Siew said his Cabinet will strive to realize the national modernization engineering by reforming the government, revitalizing the economy, and restructuring society.
His Cabinet has mapped out a blueprint to create a more efficient government and a just system which will contribute to sustainable development, Siew added. "All we need now is action," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN COMFORT WOMAN VISITS REMAINS OF FORMER JAPANESE ARMY BROTHEL

TEXT.P: A former South Korean comfort woman confirmed on Saturday that the east wing of the Hsinchu Air Base in northern Taiwan was the remains of a military brothel run by the imperial Japanese army during World War II.
Lee Yong-soo, 71, made the confirmation after an emotional insepction tour of the site where she once worked as a sex slave for Japanese military servicemen for about three years.
The site now accommodates a three-story dormitory for ROC Air Force officers and enlisted men stationed at the air base.
A tearful Lee recalled that she was abducted from her South Korean hometown by Japanese troops at a night in 1944 to work as a sex slave.
Lee was just 16 years old when she was sent to a brothel owned by a Japanese air force suicide squad stationed at a place completely strange to her.
Lee said she didn't know where she was until a Japanese suicide squad officer, surnamed Hasegawa, told her that the place was named Hsinchu, a city in northern Taiwan.

Lee described her life in the Japanese military brothel as a nightmare. She was confined to live in the brothel, a two-story wooden house. As she was only allowed to move around in an area within 100 meters in front of the brothel, Lee said she could only remembered that there were lush fields and a small river near the brothel.
Lee broke into tears when she stood by the bank of the small river that has often appeared in her dreams over the past 50 years.
Lee, who managed to return to her home in Taegu in southeastern Korea after Japan surrendered to the Allied Forces, said she was grateful for being able to re-visit the site.

"Although the I had bitter memories about the site, I hope the discovery of the remains of the former Japanese air force brothel will help pressure the Japanese government to confess to its past sins of forcing a large number of foreign women to become sex slaves during wartime," Lee said.

Lee went on to say she will show the newly found evidence to the Japanese government and join forces with other surviving former comfort women to push Japan to make a public apology and compensate all surviving comfort women, most of whom are now in their 70s and live in solitude.
Besides Lee, 14 other Korean women also worked as sex slaves at the brothel. Lee said two of her "co-workers" were killed in an air raid by the Allied Forces.

Lee, who has never married because she felt bitterly ashamed of her ordeal as a sex slave, managed to pass an examination and enter a university four years ago to study international law and Japanese culture and history.

"I have entered the university in hopes that knowledge in these fields will enable me to help other surviving comfort women cope with their difficulties and to force Japan to apologize and provide compensation," Lee said.
Donning pure white Korean-style costume, Lee set up a makeshift altar under a tree at the previous site of the Japanese military brothel in memory of her first lover, Hasegawa.

Hasegawa was one of the Japanese "suicide squad" officiers she served at the Hsinchu brothel. Lee said she has fond memory of Hasegawa. "He was a gentle, polite man. He was always kind to me," Lee recalled, adding that she believed Hasegawa had sacrificed his life during the war.
Lee placed two dolls, both wearing traditional Korean wedding attire, in front of the altar for a rite symbolizing her marriage to Hasegawa.

"I have regarded Hasegawa as not only my first lover but also my husband over the past 50 years," Lee said. "I hope today's rite will help ensure that I'll be able to live a happy life with Hasegawa in the heaven."

Lee arrived in Taipei on Thursday under the auspices of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation. She last visited Taipei in August 1997. During that trip, she was denied access to the Hsinchu air base. With the assistance from New Party Legislator Hsieh Chi-ta, Lee managed to visited the site this time.

According to a United Nations report released recently, Japan forced more than 200,000 foreign women, mostly Asians, to become sex slaves during World War II. The report demanded the Japanese government to compensate all the surviving victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY TELLS TAIWAN TO TRUST US PROMISES

TEXT.P: The promises made by the United States to Taiwan prior to US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China are trustworthy, ROC de facto ambassador to the United States Stephen Chen said on Saturday.

Chen said that based on his experience in Washington, he believes the United States will keep its promises. US officials had assured Taipei that there would be no change in US policy toward Taiwan, Taiwan's interests would not be sacrificed as a result of Clinton's mainland trip and the US will continue its arms sales to Taiwan.
Chen is in Taipei to attend the second plenary session of the ruling Kuomintang's 15th Central Committee.

In an interview with the radio news program "Face the Public," Chen said the Taiwan public's concern over the "three noes" policy spelled out by Clinton is understandable, but they should note that the US government had made promises to Taiwan prior to the visit.

The "three-noes" policy refers to no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan to enter any international organizations which require statehood for membership.

President Lee Teng-hui's comment that Clinton's stated support for the "three noes" policy had a psychological influence on the people in Taiwan was "quite accurate," Chen said. But, he added, the statement was described by the US government as a repetition of its set policy toward Taiwan.

Asked if the "three-noes" policy will damage Taiwan's efforts to increase its international presence, Chen said the US government has never supported Taiwan in its bids to enter any international organization which requires statehood for membership.

On Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations, Chen said Washington should maintain relations with Taipei parallel to its relations with Beijing. The US House of Representatives and Senate have passed several resolutions in support of Taiwan, signaling that the US Congress, or people across the United States, are sympathetic to Taiwan.

Chen also called on the people of Taiwan to have more confidence in the country, saying that as an open, democratic, and free country, the ROC's overall performance is definitely within the world's top 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIMARIES MAY BE RISKY, BUT THEY HAVE THEIR FUNCTION: NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: Holding primaries may be risky but it helps the party increase its interaction with constituents, New Party Convenor Chen Kuei-miao said Saturday.

The newly elected convenor said many people who did not have any previous association with the party took part in the primaries, and the social network established during the primaries will be important to the party in the year-end elections.
Chen took over the post from Chou Yang-sun, both of whom are legislators, in a ceremony held in Hsinchu. The event also marked the party's fifth anniversary.

Stating that the party is determined to stem irregularities in the primaries, Chen called on those seeking candidacy in the year-end elections to defend clean primaries. Voters will go to the polls at the end of the year to elect legislators as well as Taipei and Kaohsiung city council members including a mayor in each city.

Wang Chien-shien, the New Party's Taipei mayoral candidate, said although the primary elections may not be perfect and may have somewhat damaged the party's image, the fact that they were held is worthy of praise.
Wang said he hopes that those who fail to win a nomination will continue to fight for the party.
The New Party is holding its fourth round of open primaries on Saturday and Sunday. Rumors of bribery have been rampant since the month-long primary elections started on Aug. 1.

To show its determination to eliminate any form of vote-buying including offering money, gifts, free banquets to potential voters, the New Party on Monday revoked the qualifications of five candidates to run in the primaries, one of whom was incumbent Taiwan Provincial Assembly Deputy Sung Ai-ko.

DOC.HEADLINE: NA SPEAKER URGES COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF PARLIAMENTARY SYSTEM

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang should form a task force to thoroughly examine options in parliamentary reforms, National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien recommended Saturday.

In a written report submitted to the second plenary session of the KMT's 15th Central Committee, Chien called for a comprehensive review of the assembly's "parliamentary" role and the functional overlap between the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan.
In the Republic of China, the role of parliament is jointly filled by the National Assembly and the legislature in contrast to Western political systems.

However, amid recent political reforms, there have been calls for the abolishment of the National Assembly to increase congressional efficiency and to prevent conflict or a power struggle between the two representative institutions.
Most constitutional scholars and experts believe reform is the best solution to conflicts in the existing parliamentary system, Chien reported.

Reforms governing the National Assembly should not effect it in such a way that the pace of constitutional reforms is significantly slowed down, the speaker said. One of the assembly's key functions is to amend the Constitution.
Abolishing the National Assembly would not eradicate the current problems plaguing parliamentary operations, Chien said.

He stressed that an effective congressional system, which suits the society and adheres to the Constitution, can only be formed after all issues are examined such as the nation's constitutional spirit, political environment and political tradition.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies are as follows Sunday:
The United Daily News: Six Taiwan travelers were killed and eight others were injured in a traffic accident in Gansu Province, mainland China.
The China Times: Six Taiwan visitors were killed and eight others were injured in a car accident in northwest mainland.
The Central Daily News: KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui urged party solidarity for election victory.
The Liberty Times: Washington D.C. on the highest alert against possible retaliation from terrorists.
The Independent Morning Post: KMT reshuffled its policy-making Central Standing Committee.
The China Post: World Pauses for US President Clinton's sex admission.
The China News: Lee Teng-hui keeps grip on Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDEN'S REFUSAL TO ISSUE LIEN A VISA CALLED IMPROPER

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Sunday criticized the Swedish government's refusal to issue a visa to Vice President Lien Chan, calling the decision "inappropriate."

Stressing that Vice President Lien does not have plans to visit Sweden and that the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs has not made arrangements for such a trip, Hu called improper the Swedish Foreign Ministry's refusal to issue Lien an entrance visa.
Hu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters about foreign wire service reports regarding the matter.

Hu said neither Lien nor the Ministry of Foreign Affairs was aware of the incident and that his ministry will order the ROC representative office in Sweden to explain the government's stance to Sweden.
However, a ranking government official familiar with foreign affairs attributed the Swedish Foreign Ministry's decision to pressure from Beijing.

According to the official, Stockholm University originally planned to invite Lien to attend an international meeting, but it had not informed Lien or the ROC Foreign Ministry of the invitation. The mainland Chinese Embassy in Stockholm learned of the matter, filed a protest with the Swedish Foreign Ministry and asked for an explanation of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX TAIWAN TOURISTS KILLED IN NORTHWESTERN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Six Taiwanese tourists were killed and eight others injured when their van collided with a truck in northwestern mainland China, a local travel agent said on Sunday.

Fortuna Travel Service Co. said that the 14-member group was in a 17-seat van when the accident took place on a highway near Qingchuan, some 50 kilometers from Jiayuguan, Gansu province, at around 4:40 p.m. Saturday.
Six Taiwanese tourists -- five men and one woman -- as well as the driver of the van were killed. The injured were sent to a local hospital for treatment.

The group members, most of whom live in Taipei City and are in their 60s or 70s, were participating in Fortuna's "Silk Road" tour. They left Taipei Aug. 17 and were scheduled to return to Taipei Aug. 31.

Taipei Travel Agents Association said that it has contacted Liu Gangqi, deputy secretary of Beijing's intermediary body the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, which has promised to give all necessary assistance.

Relatives of the victims intending to travel to the mainland are finding it difficult to obtain passage. Because this is the busy season for the Silk Road tour, few seats are available on flights into the region.
The first group of 10 relatives left Taipei for Xian via Hong Kong Sunday afternoon and will travel to the crash site early Monday morning.
Gansu travel officials said this is the most serious travel accident involving overseas tourists in recent years and that they are paying special attention to the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVERSEAS TOURISM SPENDING MAY FALL TO SEVEN-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people are expected to spend less on overseas tourism this year, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Monday.
CBC officials estimate that only US$7 billion will be spent on overseas tourism, the lowest amount in the past seven years.

Since the government lifted the ban on overseas travel in 1979, spending on overseas tourism has risen every year since, officials said. The figure hit US$5 billion in 1991 and peaked at US$8.45 billion in 1995.
For the past two years, the figure has remained at US$8.1 billion, showing the enthusiasm of local people for overseas tourism.

The officials said the momentum for overseas trips lost its steam after the onset of regional financial turmoil in the latter half of 1997 and after the devaluation of Taiwan dollar against the US dollar, which made overseas travel to some destinations more expensive.
The officials said that overseas spending in the second quarter of this year totaled US$1.69 billion, down US$441 million, or 21 percent, from the same period last year.

But the officials said that though enthusiasm for overseas trips has dampened, domestic travel has increased, especially after the implementation of a five-day work week every other week, a policy that went into effect this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER WILL MAKE 3-DAY OFFICIAL VISIT TO GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu will arrive in Guatemala Wednesday for a three-day official visit at the invitation of the Guatemalan government.
Hu will be accompanied by his wife on the trip.

While in Guatemala City, Minister Hu will be received by Guatemalan President Alvaro Enrique Arzu Irigoyen and call on his Guatemalan counterpart, Eduardo Stein Barillas; President of Congress Rafael Eduardo Barrios Flores; and Guatemala City Mayor Oscar Berger Perdomo.

Guatemalan Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein Barillas will present Hu with the Order of Quetzal with Grande Cross in recognition of Hu's contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the two countries.

In return, Hu, acting on behalf of the ROC government, will confer on Barillas the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon for his contributions to promoting ties between the Republic of China and Guatemala.
During his three-day stay in Guatemala, Hu will also preside over a meeting on Thursday and Friday of ROC envoys and representatives to Latin American and Caribbean countries.

P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic and Planning and Development, Deputy Chairman Ming Chan-hwa of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and Deputy Director-General Chang Ping-nan of the Government Information Office will also attend the meeting.
Hu is scheduled to conclude his visit to Guatemala on Aug. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: P.K. CHIANG TO VISIT GUATEMALA ON WEDNESDAY
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Aug. 22 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, will arrive in Guatemala on Wednesday for a three-day visit.
Chiang will be accompanied by a group of economics officials and four members of the President Group.
While in Guatemala City, Chiang will call on Guatemalan Minister of Energy and Mining Leonel Lopez Rodas and on Economics Minister Juan Jose Serra.
Chiang will also attend a two-day meeting of ROC envoys and representatives to Latin American and Caribbean countries on Aug. 26-27.
The four-member delegation of the President Group who will accompany Chiang on the trip will study the possibility of investing in a power station in Guatemala.
Chiang is scheduled to conclude his visit Aug. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER'S PC MARKET SHARE IN LATIN AMERICA SHRINKS

TEXT.P: Bucking an upward trend of personal computer sales in Latin America, Acer's market share in the area shrank dramatically in the second quarter of 1998, according to the latest report by Dataquest Inc.

Latin American personal computer shipments reached 871,770 units in the second quarter of 1998, up 9 percent from the same period last year. Acer, however, lost ground in both market share and units sold.

Compaq continued to dominate the Latin American PC market, with a 17.7 share of the market, followed by IBM's 9.9 percent. Acer managed to maintain the No. 3 position with a 7.3 percent market share, compared with an 11.4 percent share last year.

Latin America benefited from increased shipments in the mobile market, which grew three times faster than the desktop market. "Better communications infrastructure, lower prices and a more dynamic business culture are pushing notebook sales, which experienced 28 percent growth in the second quarter of this year," said Luis Anavitarte, senior industry analyst for Dataquest's Personal Computer Quarterly Statistics Latin America program.

The top tier vendors are facing growing pressure from clone vendors, noted Anavitarte, adding that enhanced face-to-face service, dramatically lower prices and fast technological adoption are allowing clones to flourish in the region, as consumers feel increasingly comfortable purchasing non-name brand machines.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT ENDS ANNUAL PARTY CONGRESS

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) closed the second plenary session of its 15th Central Committee on Sunday, passing a resolution urging all KMT members to work for better cross-strait ties and for party victory in year-end elections.

Stable and harmonious cross-strait ties are in the interest of all Chinese people and serve as a cornerstone for persistent peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region, the resolution said. It called for continued exchanges and negotiations between the two sides in order to forge a mutually beneficial and trustworthy basis for a "win-win" situation for both sides.

In the face of year-end legislative elections and mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan's two largest cities, the resolution urged all KMT members to stand united and fully mobilize to help the party's candidates score victories.

The resolution also urged all KMT party members to devote themselves to the task of building an efficient government and an orderly society ruled by law, as well as to help the government promote its policy of pragmatic foreign diplomacy and stimulate the local economy.

In addition, it also expressed the hope that the Executive Yuan will complete necessary legislative processes as soon as possible to carry out the plan of downsizing the Taiwan Provincial Government, a major part of the government's restructuring reform efforts.
President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as KMT chairman, also delivered a speech at the closing ceremony of the two-day gathering.

Stressing that winning year-end elections is an important political task for the KMT that will have a great impact on the KMT's role as the ruling party, national security and the nation's future, Lee said the party must do its best to achieve victory.

Speaking of the 40th anniversary of the communist China's bombardment of the front-line island of Kinmen, a Cold War flash point in which 600 residents and soldiers were killed, Lee expressed his appreciation for the contributions and sacrifices made by ROC citizens and by members of the nation's armed forces, actions Lee said have laid a solid foundation for Taiwan's present stability and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND TO ISSUE VISAS TO TAIWAN VISITORS AT HK AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan travelers who own valid permits to travel to mainland China can apply for entrance visas at Hong Kong's airport starting in September, the Economic Daily News reported on Sunday.

The Hong Kong Immigration Office has allowed the China Travel Service to open a counter at Chek Lap Kok International Airport that will enable it to directly grant visas for Taiwan visitors wishing to go to mainland China, according to the newspaper.

Beginning next month, Taiwan passengers with valid travel documents for mainland China will be able to apply for visas at the Hong Kong airport, allowing them to depart for destinations in the mainland directly from the former British colony, the newspaper reported.

The Hong Kong Tourism Association estimates that the new measure will help woo more than 10,000 mainland-bound Taiwan passengers every month from Macao, from where they are already able to proceed directly to mainland China.
Currently, Taiwan passengers with valid travel permits for mainland China are allowed to make weeklong stopovers in Hong Kong.

Statistics compiled by the association show that the number of Taiwan travelers visiting Hong Kong last month increased 12 percent from June to 165,000. The number of Taiwan visitors to Hong Kong in the first seven months of this year grew 1.4 percent to 1.04 million from the same period in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 65 PERCENT SATISFIED WITH PM SIEW

TEXT.P: The approval rating of Premier Vincent Siew has rebounded to 64.2 percent, according to the latest poll.
The results of the poll, conducted by the Chinese Association for Public Opinion Research (CAPOR), were announced Sunday as the first anniversary of Siew's Cabinet draws near.
The public was most satisfied with the Cabinet's efforts to develop the economy (10.1 percent), followed by traffic network construction and education efforts.

Only 1.6 percent of poll respondents, however, said social order has been greatly improved in the past year, while 18.7 percent said there has been some improvement. Fifty-seven percent said the island's social order is unchanged from a year ago, while 19.1 said social order had deteriorated.
Some 44 percent of the public were positive of the overall teamwork demonstrated by Siew's Cabinet, while only 3.1 percent said they had demonstrated poor teamwork.

Chang Hung-chu, CAPOR chairman and president of Tamkang University, said that up to 86 percent of those polled said Siew's image is good, while 87.4 percent said they believe Siew's unassuming attitude has made him popular.
The approval rating of Siew slipped after the kidnap and murder of the daughter of a TV celebrity last year and after a series of aviation accidents earlier this year.

As to the viability of the build-operate-transfer model for pushing public construction projects, a model strongly supported by the Siew Cabinet, 75 percent of those polled were positive. The BOT model refers to the building of certain projects by private sector companies or consortia before transferring them to the government after operating them for a certain period of time.
The poll included responses from ROC citizens islandwide 20 years old or older and was conducted Aug. 20-21. In all 1,067 responses were obtained, and the poll's margin of error was 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERANS COMMEMORATE KINMEN BOMBARDMENT

TEXT.P: Veterans gathered Sunday on the outpost island of Kinmen to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Kinmen Bombardment.

The 125-member delegation, composed of those who took part in defending the island during the bombardment and their dependents, visited the Martyr's Shrine in the Taiwu Mountain Cemetery, to pay tribute to the fallen soldiers.
The commemoration ceremony was presided over by General Chan Chi-hsiu, then a divisional commander of the "Lions Troop" when the mainland launched the shelling on Aug. 23, 1958.
Also witnessing the ceremony were six retired generals, Kinmen Defense 0ommander Chu Kai-sheng and his deputy, Hu Chen-pu.

The Lions Troop was responsible for mobile combat and logistics operations during the bombardment. The underground construction of "Chingtien Hall" deep inside a mountain was one of their famous works.

During the 44-day marathon shelling of Kinmen, a key island in the Taiwan Strait protecting Taiwan and the Penghu islands, a total of 587 officers and solders were killed. Other casualties included the drowning of six Chinese and foreign reporters.
Many of the veterans were in tears when they burned incense for their fallen brethren.
Meanwhile the first 8-23 Bombardment Victory Monument was inaugurated in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, on Sunday.
The 25.5-meter-high monument, located in Chungcheng Park, was dedicated in a solemn ceremony presided over by Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih and Vice Defense Minister Fang Shou-lu.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S FIRST SATELLITE TO BE LAUNCHED TUESDAY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's first commercial satellite -- ST-1 -- is scheduled to be launched from Guiana, a French colony in northeast South America, on Tuesday.

The US$240 million satellite was built by France-based Matra Marconi Space Co. with investments by Chunghwa Telecom Co. and Singapore Telecom Ltd. in a concerted effort to provide their clients with improved hi-tech communications services.

Matra Marconi Space, a joint venture between France's Lagarder Group and Britain's GEC Group, plays a leadership role in Europe's satellite-making industry. It has 2,300 and 2,700 employees, respectively, in France and the United Kingdom.
Tuesday's launch of the ST-1 satellite will be jointly witnessed by Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Chen Yao and his Singapore Telecom counterpart.
The ST-1 satellite system will orbit 36,000 kilometers above the Earth, roughly above the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung.
Chunghwa Telecom has located its central monitoring control station on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei and has constructed other ground stations on other parts of the island.
The Republic of China's first commercial satellite will be carried and launched by an Arianespace No. 4 rocket, marking the 78th mission for the rocket and the 109th such mission for Arianespace Co.
Arianespace, set up in 1980, is the world's first commercial space transport company. It was jointly established by 36 leading aviation and electronics firms and 13 banks in Europe.

So far, Arianespace has successfully launched 144 satellites, 123 of which are telecommunications oriented. Over the past nine years, two-thirds of the telecommunications satellites sent up by western countries were launched by Arianespace, an average of one launch per month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: President Lee Teng-hui commends the contribution of the Battle of the Taiwan Strait, which began on Aug. 23, 1958 with communist China shelling the ROC-held outlying islands of Kinmen.
The China Times: US Time Magazine predicts that mainland China's 1998 economic growth rate may only stand at 3 percent.
The United Daily News: A Patriot anti-missile defense umbrella is taking shape in the greater Taipei area.
The Liberty Times: The National Police Administration will be subject to investigation for failing to offer promotions to 39,000 qualified police officers.
The Independence Morning Post: KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui on Sunday urged all party members to gear up for the year-end three-in-one elections.
The Commons Daily: KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui on Sunday pushed the ruling party to stand united and reach out to the people in order to win the critical year-end elections.
The China Post: KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui calls on the ruling party to mobilize for the year-end elections.
The China News: China crash kills six Taiwan tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI URGED TO LOWER VISA THRESHOLD FOR CHINESE-INDONESIANS

TEXT.P: A Chinese-Indonesian community leader on Monday urged Taiwan to relax its visa restrictions for young Indonesian females of Chinese origin, in turn making Taiwan a haven for those fleeing sexual violence in Indonesia.

Hsu Nai-lu, secretary-general of the Chinese-Indonesian Association in the Republic of China, said the nightmarish rapes, assaults and killings of ethnic Chinese women during riots in May is still lingering in Indonesia, and ethnic Chinese families with daughters are still trying to send their children abroad, in some cases to Taiwan.
Taiwan would be the place where most Chinese-Indonesians sought refuge if not for the difficulties in obtaining visas, Hsu said.

Hsu said that most of the visas the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs grants Chinese-Indonesians allow them to stay in Taiwan for two weeks to two months, but cannot be extended. This is insufficient to meet the needs of ethnic Chinese families with daughters, he said.

Hsu suggested that Taipei liberalize visa restrictions for Chinese-Indonesians aged under 20 to allow them to study in Taiwan and flee riotous violence in Indonesia. People in Taiwan need not worry that the looser regulations would result in a loss of jobs to Indonesian workers, as those admitted would be youngsters, Hsu added.

Officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, however, defended the current visa restrictions, saying the ministry has tried its best to help ethnic Chinese women come to Taiwan since the riots erupted in Indonesia in May.

The ministry has granted visa extensions to ethnic Chinese from Indonesia who have relatives in Taiwan and has quickly processed visas for those who were physically or mentally wounded during the rioting to allow them to seek medical help in Taiwan, the officials pointed out.
The number of young Chinese-Indonesians seeking to study in Taiwan has increased by leaps and bounds since May, they said.
Since early June, 58 young ethnic Chinese from Indonesia applied to come to Taiwan to study. Before the riots, however, no Indonesians or perhaps only one per month would apply.

In addition, those seeking to come to Taiwan specifically to study Mandarin -- all of whom must obtain recommendations from ROC-related organizations -- increased in number from 24 in April to 34 in June and 118 in July, according to ministry tallies.
Of the applicants, 80 percent were girls, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT URGED TO CRACK DOWN ON GIRL-SELLING RINGS

TEXT.P: The government should step up its crackdown on rings that sell teenage girls for prostitution, an official of a woman's group urged on Monday.

Chen Chih-tung, section chief of the Taipei Women's Rescue Foundation, made the call at a press conference held at the Legislative Yuan to coincide with the third anniversary of the implementation of regulations to prevent child and teenage prostitution.
Chen said that girl-selling rings have targeted girls, especially aborigine teenage girls, from broken families or those who run away from home, forcing them into prostitution throughout the island.
Noting that many notorious masterminds of girl-selling rings are still at large, he urged the National Police Administration (NPA) to track them down as soon as possible.
Chen urged the Prosecutor Office and the NPA to set up task forces and cooperate with social workers to curb the teenage prostitution trade.

Responding to the requests by Chen, Ke Li-lin, chief prosecutor under the Ministry of Justice, said that civic groups may not realize the severe shortage of prosecutors in local district courts, adding that it is hard for the ministry to form a task force at present.

Participants in the press conference also included representatives from the Garden of Hope, the End Child Prostitution Association, and Legislators Chu Huei-liang of the New Party and Shen Fu-hsiung of the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE TO BE HIGH-END BUSINESS IN NEXT CENTURY: LEE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's agriculture, seemingly backward compared with its other sectors, promises to become a major money-maker because of high-end technologies that will be developed in the next century, President Lee Teng-hui said on Monday.

Addressing the opening of the fourth National Agricultural Conference, Lee said Taiwan's agricultural sector is not a backwater of the island. In fact, it may become a star business, making the most money of all Taiwan's sectors.

Lee, an agronomist who held a prominent post at the Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, the predecessor of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, said with the infusion of a large amount of capital and state-of-the-art biotechnologies, the agricultural sector is promising to regain the glory it enjoyed about 20 years ago.

To survive severe import competition resulting from Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), the agricultural sector must accelerate modernization -- absorbing cutting-edge biotechnologies -- and beef up its capitalization, which can be done by collecting funds through the stock market, Lee noted. The more agriculture-related companies that become listed, the more money the agricultural sector will get, he said.

Once the agricultural sector becomes a technology-oriented industry with sufficient capital support, Taiwan can once again become a major agricultural contributor to the world village as it did two decades ago by successfully developing the "miracle rice" -- the Taichung No. 1 indica rice -- which helped Asia tide over a food crisis, Lee said.
