More than 300 delegates from agricultural, academic, government and law-making bodies are taking part in the two-day conference, which is devoted to discussions mainly on Taiwan's WTO bid and its implications, as well as the opening for sale of lands zoned for agricultural use.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN EXPORT PROMOTION AGENCY PROMISES OVERHAUL

TEXT.P: The Australian Trade Council (Austrade), similar to Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), is overhauling its services to Australian exporters after being criticized for poor services and high hosts.

The Australian National Audit Office (ANAO) in a report scathingly attacked Austrade, which is engaged mainly in export promotions of Australian products and helping Australian companies invest abroad, because "it falls short of consistently high standards and does not necessarily represent value for money."

"The current approach to recovering costs does not assist Austrade to evaluate effectively the cost-effectiveness of its service-delivery activities. Also Austrade's approach to measuring the export impact of its activities can be substantially improved to reduce costs and increase reliability," the ANAO report said.

Austrade Managing Director Charles Jamieson said his agency would improve the delivery of its services to its clients, simplify its pricing policy, step up staff training and boost awareness among exporters of what benefits they could gain from the export promotion agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE CAN RIDE OUT REGIONAL STORM: PM GOH

TEXT.P: Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong Sunday night told Singaporeans that, acting together, they can "ride out the storm" and secure a brighter future.
"Steering through this storm to safety is Singapore's biggest challenge since I became prime minister eight years ago," he said in his National Day Rally address.

He pointed out that a capable and steady team was in charge and would lead the country through its present tough times, but he emphasized that it also needed the people's cooperation and support and that they must organize themselves to prepare for increased competition after the crisis.

Goh's two-hour address centered on how the Singapore government was responding rationally and realistically to its twin challenges of handling relations with its neighbors and restructuring its domestic economy.
He told the nation what back-room work Singapore had done to help Malaysia and Indonesia weather the regional crisis even though ties with them have hit a rough patch.
Singapore has been observing a month-long celebration to mark its 33rd National Day, which falls on Aug. 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE IS TRYING TO HELP NEIGHBORS: PM GOH

TEXT.P: Singapore has helped Malaysia by holding onto several billion ringgit in its foreign reserves even though it knows the currency may slowly depreciate further, Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong revealed in his National Day Rally address Sunday night.
The move was among several that Singapore has undertaken to help Malaysia and Indonesia in their current crises, he said.

Of the Malaysian currency, he said: "Had we sold them, the ringgit would have depreciated further. In addition, we have deposited some of these ringgit with Malaysian banks in Malaysia, even though the interest rates are much less than we could earn by leaving the ringgit offshore in Singapore."
He made this point when he elaborated at length in his address on the state of relations between Singapore and its two closest neighbors.
He pointed out that Singapore's economy was intertwined with those of the two countries.
Goh noted that Singapore also has more than S$10 billion invested in Malaysia, spread among 1,000 companies, while its banks have another S$21 billion in loans in Malaysia.
Regarding Indonesia, he said that Singapore pledged US$5 billion along with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) last November to restore confidence and has also tried to help defend the rupiah.
Singapore still has several trillion rupiah deposited with Bank Indonesia, he added.
It also has S$4 billion worth of investments in Indonesia, and Singapore banks have made another S$4 billion in loans to that country.

Singapore was also giving humanitarian assistance to Indonesia, Goh said. "Beyond that, our best and most practical contribution now is not to finance Indonesia's budget deficit or food subsidies through the IMF, but to help Indonesia re-start a part of its economy which has stalled."

Goh's remarks come at a time when Malaysia has accused Singapore of sabotaging it during its period of difficulty, while Indonesian President B. J. Habibie has described Singapore as being less than friendly toward Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES VOWS VIGILANCE IN FACE OF TERRORISM

TEXT.P: Stressing that terrorism "is the common enemy of mankind," the Philippines presidential office, Malacanang, has assured foreigners -- be they involved in foreign missions or business ventures here -- that the Philippine government is committed to fighting terrorism.

Presidential Spokesman Fernando Barican stressed this point as he responded to threats made recently by the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) that US interests in the Philippines will be attacked by terrorists.
Barican said Manila has international obligations under international laws as well as "has general obligation under the Constitution to protect all persons and private property."
"We take that responsibility seriously," Barican told reporters during a press briefing.
"We will protect the interests of all citizens and of all foreigners who are doing their business or residing in the Philippines or passing through the Philippines," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG REMAINS BEIJING'S WINDOW ON THE WORLD: BOOK

TEXT.P: More than one year after its handover, Hong Kong remains mainland China's window on the world and a contact point with mainland China for the world, according to a new book by an Australian journalist.

"Comrades and Capitalists," written by Roman Callick, a correspondent of the Australian Financial Review in Hong Kong, said the future of Hong Kong is closely related to the economic development of mainland China.
Mainland China's many markets retain a primary attraction for Hong Kong, which was created as a result of the "China trade," Callick said.

But demand in mainland China is becoming stagnant and is likely to remain so for some time as mainland China undergoes a vigorous and overdue reform of its financial structures while Beijing continues to place a premium on lowering inflation, he said.
"Within China, Hong Kong will still be regarded, for many years, as somewhat exotic, even 'foreign,' and thus a place to which profits are only grudgingly repatriated," he said.

If mainland China's premier, Zhu Rongji, fails in his attempt to modernize mainland China's economy, Hong Kong will face immense difficulties, he said in his first book published by the University of New South Wales.

Some Hong Kong investors might then attempt to liquidate funds held in mainland China, to re-apply them elsewhere. Such an outcome would not be popular in Beijing. What would happen to Hong Kong's massive container port? The Hang Seng Index would need to be re-calibrated as a result of the likely marginalization of "red chip" mainland stocks, Callick said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-OWNED TOURIST HOTEL IN PALAU INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A four-star tourist hotel jointly owned by Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and one of the most influential families in Palau was inaugurated in the capital of the South Pacific island nation on Monday.

Speaking at the inaugural ceremony, Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the KMT Business Management Committee, said the posh Outrigger Palasia Hotel Palau symbolizes a big step forward in friendship between the Republic of China and Palau.
"In addition to its commercial value, we believe the joint-venture project will help boost bilateral relations between our two countries," said the economist-turned-business executive.

The KMT, reputed as the world's richest political party with assets worth more than NT$100 billion, controls an 80 percent stake in the US$10 million joint-venture project. The remaining 20 percent is held by Senator Alan Seid, a Palau political heavyweight who is widely believed to become the country's next president.
Given Seid's political clout, Liu said he is convinced that substantive Taiwan-Palau relations and cooperation will make significant headway following the opening of the new hotel.

With beautiful maritime and underwater scenery, Palau has long been one of the world's most popular diving, fishing and recreational resorts. It has consistently attracted a large number of tourists from around the world, particularly those from Japan.
Liu said the annual return on investment in the Outrigger Palasia Hotel will reach an estimated 15 percent and that the KMT will be able to recover all of its capital investment in seven years.

Liu recalled that the KMT promised to invest more in Palau when construction of the new hotel began some three years ago. As the two countries have not yet established formal diplomatic ties, Liu said the KMT must hold discussions with the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs before it launches new investment projects in Palau.

Speaking on the same occasion, Palau Vice President Tommy Remengesau said he is delighted to see the opening of the new hotel, which he said will not only help promote Palau's tourism industry but will also stimulate the country's overall economic development.
Meanwhile, Seid, who provided the land for Outrigger Palasia Hotel, said he hopes the new hotel will operate smoothly and help inspire more Taiwan-Palau cooperative projects.

Located on Palau's largest island of Koror, Outrigger Palasia Hotel has 165 guest rooms. From the hotel, it takes only a five-minute drive to reach Palau's major diving and recreational center. In the initial stage, the hotel will be managed by the well-known Outrigger hotel management firm in Hawaii on behalf of its owners.

With a population of 15,000, Palau is 2,850 kilometers southeast of Taiwan. It takes about three and a half hours to fly directly from Taiwan to Palau. Taiwan's Far East Air Transport Corp. currently operates four round-trip flights between Taiwan and Palau per week.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH DEATH RATE AMONG ELDERLY CHALLENGED

TEXT.P: A Taipei City government official on Monday questioned figures which put Taiwan's death rate among the elderly who lived alone at the highest in Asia.

Chen Chu, director of city government's Department of Social Affairs, said the number provided by the Taipei Elders Foundation (TEF) is sensational and asked foundation officials to provide a basis for the figure.
TEF reported that between January and July, it handled 408 death cases of elderly residents living alone in Taiwan. The figure surpassed that of Japan and is reportedly the highest in Asia.

Chen said the foundation had provided falsely inflated numbers in the past, citing the cases of abused among the elderly. TEF reported that there were 384 abuse cases, and when the bureau investigated 100 of the 175 cases the foundation provided, it found that only eight cases were legitimate.
A TEF official said he stood by the death figure, claiming that it had been compiled from information gathered from the newspaper, police records and foundation staff investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF BARRED FROM OFFERING ACCIDENT ASSISTANCE IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Officials from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) have been denied permission to travel to mainland China to assist in the aftermath of a car accident in which six Taiwan tourists died, SEF sources said Monday

The semi-official SEF faxed three letters to its Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), since Sunday with further information about the Taiwan tourists. The letters also requested permission for one SEF official to travel with the relatives of the victims to offer assistance.

Although the request was rejected, Tsai Chin-mei, deputy director of SEF's travel services department, traveled with the second batch of Taiwan relatives to Hong Kong Monday morning to await permission to proceed to the mainland.
Tsai may return to Taipei Monday evening if the SEF does not obtain permission by then, said SEF Deputy Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing.
Wu said he telephoned his ARATS counterpart, Liu Gangqi, Monday morning to gain approval for Tsai's travel to the mainland. Liu turned down the request.
Six Taiwan tourist were killed and eight others injured in a car accident Saturday in the remote area of Kansu Province in northwestern China along part of the ancient "Silk Road."

This marked the second occasion which ARATS rejected a SEF request for travel to the mainland to help Taiwan residents in need of assistance since Kaohsiung City Councilor Lin Ti-chuan was killed in a botched kidnapping incident late July.
ARATS threw cold water on SEF's offer to help, adding that it would handle the accident without any assistance from SEF.

Chin Shao-kang, son of a Taiwan resident who was among the six Taiwan tourists killed in the car accident, said he does not understand why should ARATS bar SEF from extending humanitarian help to the relatives of the victims who lost their lives in a country where law and order is a rarity.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang is gearing up to forge ties with the newly formed Japanese government as two high-level party officials will travel to Japan this week.

KMT Secretary-General John Chang is scheduled to leave for Tokyo on Wednesday for a five-day visit. It marks his third overseas trip aimed at promoting "party diplomacy" since he assumed his current post late last year.

In addition to meeting with influential figures of Japan's ruling and opposition parties, the KMT's top day-to-day affairs manager will also brief Japanese authorities on Taiwan's stance and policy on relations across the Taiwan Strait.
During his stay in Tokyo, Chang, a former foreign minister, will attend a seminar to be sponsored by the Asian Elite Society on Thursday.

The Asian Elite Society is a Tokyo-based private association founded by Michio Ochi, a Japanese legislator and son-in-law of the late Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda. The association's members include elite individuals in political and commercial sectors in major Asian countries.
Chang will be able to exchange views with a number of influential Asian politicians and senior business executives on a variety of regional issues during the seminar.
The KMT secretary-general will also meet with Yoshiro Mori, general secretary of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, and other LDP heavyweights.

Meanwhile, Chen Peng-jen, director of the KMT's Department of Party History, is scheduled to travel to Japan on Thursday. Chen, a Japanese affairs expert, is expected to meet privately with Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.

Chen, an old friend of Obuchi, will brief the prime minister on Taiwan's stance on cross-strait relations amid reports that Beijing is lobbying Tokyo to announce its support of the so-called "three noes" policy against Taiwan during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's planned visit to Japan.
Jiang was originally scheduled to make a state visit to Japan in early September, but he announced the postponement of the trip Friday due to the serious floods devastating many mainland regions.

The "three noes" refer to no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.
The "three noes" came into the limelight after US President Bill Clinton mentioned them at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai on June 30.
Despite Beijing's pressure, Japan reportedly is still reluctant to explicitly throw its support behind the "three noes" against Taiwan.
Chang's and Chen's Japan visits are part of Taiwan's efforts to dissuade the Japanese government from yielding to Beijing's pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S MILITARY AGAINST NON-COMMERCIALIZATION

TEXT.P: Beijing's decision to separate business from the military has recently become a topic of great interest among Hong Kong's media. Some have indicated that stopping mainland China's military from operating businesses would be similar to getting a drug addict to stop taking drugs.

Allowing the military to run businesses has been seen as Chinese President Jiang Zemin's strategy to winning the hearts of the troops and the support of the army. However, now that the military has tasted the sweetness of profiting from commercialization, it has become a practice very difficult to end.

Earlier this year on July 11, the Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) held an expanded convention. Jiang, as CPC General Secretary, proposed the following resolutions: military and police forces be prohibited from running businesses; smuggling operations conducted by the military and police forces be attacked; and decrease the number of troops.

These three resolutions have been strongly opposed by armies nation-wide, informed sources in the mainland said. A campaign was even launched in major military regions and academies to openly protest against the resolutions.

The party committee secretary of the air force of the People's Liberation Army complained that the commercialization of the PLA was enacted into law by CPC Central Committee, State Council and CPC Central Military Commission in May 1985, March 1989 and July 1992 respectively. How could a party committee secretary explain the change to officers and the rank-and-file in such a sudden move, he asked.
In a democratic nation, it would be inconceivable that an army would be permitted to operate commercial businesses. To make matters worse, the mainland's army is also engaged in smuggling.

US-based Business Week disclosed recently that the smuggling activities conducted by mainland China's military has gone from ordinary merchandise to rifles, ammunition and even Chinese-made arms and missiles to Pakistan and Iran.

Evidence indicates that Beijing is serious about stamping out commercial activity and smuggling in the military. This may be perhaps because Jiang envisions that corruption in the army would be the prelude to the downfall of a regime.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ INVESTIGATING RUMORS OF MAINLAND INTERFERENCE IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is investigating rumors that mainland Chinese capital may be flowing into Taiwan to interfere in the year-end elections, Minister of Justice Cheng Chung-mo said Monday.
Cheng made the remarks during a visit to prosecutors in Taichung, central Taiwan.
He said his ministry will step up security in the run up to the elections for legislators, Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors and city councilors scheduled for Dec. 5.

The minister would not confirm whether there was any substantive evidence supporting the rumors or individual cases, but stressed that the investigations would not target any specific individual or party.
The ministry is checking out every detail to see if the rumors are true, and is looking into all possible channels in which mainland capital may enter Taiwan, Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose NT$0.119 against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at NT$34.809.
The greenback opened at 34.815 and was traded between 34.692 and 34.850.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$279 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES STUMBLES ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices stumbled on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, plunging 255.62 points to close at 6957.75.
The local bourse opened at 7128.97 points, 84.4 lower than Friday closing.
A total of 1.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$77.187 billion (US$2.22 billion).

Electrical shares fell the most at 4.9 percent, followed by plastic and chemical issues at 4 percent; textile issues at 3.5 percent; paper and pulp shares at 3.4 percent; financial stocks at 2.5 percent; both cement and foodstuff shares at 2.4 percent; and construction issues at 2.2 percent.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also slumped, while trading posted a whopping increase.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September tumbled 270 point to close at 6,955 with 919 contract transactions, the highest trading volume since the opening of TAIEX on July 21.

The TAIEX Index Futures for October dropped 281 points to 7,000 with 21 contract transactions, while those for December dropped 210 points to 7,220 with nine contract transactions and those for March moved down 152 points to 7,300, with 20 contract transactions.
No transactions were registered for next June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB GEARING UP TO FIGHT HK DRUG RINGS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) is gearing up to fight international drug rings, particularly those based in Hong Kong, the United Daily News reported on Monday.

The paper quoted MJIB sources as saying that Hong Kong and Thai drug rings have targeted Taiwan for expanding their illegal business because contraband narcotics can fetch much higher prices on the island than in many other places.

"Taiwan does not produce any contraband drugs, while its demand for narcotics has continued rising. With limited supplies, local narcotics prices are four to five times those in mainland China, Hong Kong and major Southeast Asian countries," an MJIB officer was quoted as telling the paper.
Attracted by lucrative profit opportunities here, the officer said, major Hong Kong criminal rings are scrambling to smuggle drugs into Taiwan.

In the past, the official said, large Hong Kong criminal rings, such as Sin Yee On and 14K triads, focused on controlling the narcotics trade in that territory. As a result, only small Hong Kong gangs or individual drug dealers had developed ties with their Taiwan counterparts.
"The situation has changed in recent years," the official said, adding that the MJIB has intercepted several batches of narcotics smuggled by members of the 14K triad, the No. 2 gang in Hong Kong.
According to the official, the 14K triad has been trying hard to establish an islandwide drug distribution network here.
On Aug. 9, the MJIB managed to bust a drug trafficking ring, headed by Chan Wei Man, a member of Hong Kong's largest underworld gang Sin Yee On.
"It was the first time that the MJIB has discovered that even the Sin Yee On triad intended to make introads into Taiwan's narcotics market," the official said.

He pointed out that major Hong Kong gangs do not just want to share a slice of the large Taiwan pie. "They intend to dominate the Taiwan market by establishing their own distribution centers on the island," the official noted.
Other MJIB sources also said major Hong Kong triads seem to have adopted long-term strategies to tap into the Taiwan market.

For instance, the sources said, Hong Kong drug trafficking rings usually give attentive care to their members who are serving jail terms in Taiwan. Some Hong Kong prisoners have even developed close ties with Taiwan inmates with a view to help their gangs expand drug sales netwroks here.

The sources further said major Hong Kong gangs have even hired retired Hong Kong police officers to help them smuggle drugs into Taiwan as they have better skills to shun surveillance by Taiwan's law enforcement officers.

Among international drug traffickers, the sources said, those from Hong Kong are the most difficult to pin down. Afrter the MJIB's Taipei outpost managed to seize several batches of narcotics smuggled by Hong Kong gangsters, major Hong Kong triads have now moved their local oeprations centers from northern Taiwan to central and southern parts of the island, the sources said.

More worrisome is that mainalnd China may be using Hong Kong gangsters to infiltrate Taiwan, the sources said, adding that a member in the Chan Wai Man drug trafficking ring busted on Aug. 9 once worked for China Resources Co., a Hong Kong-based affiliate of mainland China's Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation.

MJIB investigations show that Deng Deming once worked for China Resources as a formal staff member for six years. It is worth further probes why Deng, given his career backgrounds, had been involved in cross-border drug trafficking, the sources said.
Since the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949, China Resources have served as Beijing's major information source in Hong Kong, the sources said.

MJIB Director Wang Kuang-yu said earlier this month that since Hong Kong reverted to mainland China's rule in July 1997, Beijing has used Hong Kong as a major conduit to collect information about Taiwan's political, military and economic conditions.
"It has become yet another challenge for MJIB agents to detect undercover communist spies when they bust drug trafficking rings operated by Hong Kong citizens in the future," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN NOT OPPOSED TO DIALOGUE WITH MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Aug. 23 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of the ROC's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that his ideal is for Taiwan to become a democratic, prosperous, and independent country.
Lin made the remarks in an interview with Newsweek magazine, excerpts of which were carried in the Aug. 31 issue of the US-based magazine which hit newsstands early this week.
Lin also said that he does not oppose dialogue, or the development of relations, between Taiwan and mainland China.

Describing the campaign for Taiwan independence as good for both sides of the Taiwan Strait, Lin said he believes that the mainland will change, and that after 10 or 20 years of efforts on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, mainland China will no longer deem it necessary to take over Taiwan.

Asked about former DPP chairman Hsu Hsin-liang's campaign to boost relations with the mainland, Lin said that this is Hsu's personal stance, and does not reflect official DPP policy. Some DPP officials feel that Hsu is moving too fast in his push for increased engagement with the mainland.

Lin said that there is a general consensus that Taiwan should conduct dialogue and develop relations with the mainland, but pointed out that the DPP has to prevent the mainland from taking the opportunity to undermine the security of Taiwan.

He also criticized mainland China's handling of the murder of the party's Kaohsiung city councilor Lin Ti-chuan in northern mainland China, saying that but for strong protests by Lin's family, the mainland authorities might have turned down the family's request that a DPP official accompany them to the mainland to identify the body of their daughter.

On a more personal note, Lin, whose mother and two young daughters were killed 18 years ago at their home, said that he has weathered the most painful period of his life. For him and his family, the tracking down of the killer is not so important as a resolution of the unsolved case to uphold social justice, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL TRAVEL AGENTS WARN OF POOR SERVICES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Sources from Taiwan's travel industry warned of inadequate travel services in mainland China, adding that people planning on traveling there should take extra care.

The comments come after six Taiwan tourists were killed and eight others injured in a car accident Saturday in a remote area of the northwestern province of Gansu. The tourists were visiting Jiayuguan City along the ancient trading route known as the "Silk Road."

Taiwan-based travel agencies first began organizing trips to the Silk Road seven years ago, said Wang Chi-han, vice chairman of the ROC Travel Quality Guarantee Association and president of the Changhan Travel Agency.
It has emerged, along with Zhangjiajie in Hunan Province and Jiouzhaigou in Sichuan Province, as one of the most popular tourist destinations in the mainland among Taiwan visitors, he noted.

According to Wang, about 13,000 Taiwan tourists traveled to the Silk Road in 1997, up from the previous level of 5,700 in 1996. He estimated that more than 20,000 Taiwan tourists will travel to the Silk Road on packaged tours this year.

Taipei Association of Travel Agents Chairman Chen Hsin-hao said the number of Taiwan tourists participating on Silk Road tours this year will grow by at least 20 percent as a result of a promotion campaign by the Gansu travel industry in Taiwan earlier this year.

However, Chen called on Taiwan tourists planning travel to the remote region to be cautious because there are greater difficulties in obtaining reliable transportation and accommodation along the Silk Road route, especially during the summer peak seasons.

The disastrous flooding currently effecting much of the northeastern and eastern regions of the mainland have led many tourists from around the world to shift their travel destinations to along the Silk Road, Chen noted.

The ROC Tourism Bureau issued a warning for Taiwan tourists to be more careful when selecting transportation vehicles and drivers while touring the Silk Road after Saturday's accident. A tourism official who had traveled to the region last year said this is especially important as tours may take thousands of kilometers.

The bureau also urged travelers to be more informed prior to embarking on their trip as the quality of services and facilities is uncertain. It also advised tourists to avoid traveling to the Three Gorges and the flood-plagued regions.

A mainland Chinese travel agency said the number of tourists traveling to the Silk Road region so far this year has more than doubled from the same period last year, making it very difficult to hire a car or get a hotel room along the route.
Many local businesses have been taken by surprise at the influx and are reportedly unprepared for the number of tourists.

A local travel agency based in Gansu said it has been very difficult for travelers to reserve airplane and train tickets for cities along the Silk Road, adding that there is also a shortage of hotel accommodations.

Major cities other than Lanzhou, Urumqi and Trupan along the Silk Road in Gansu and Xinjiang Provinces are accessible only via road transportation, making travel conditions even worse, the Gansu travel agent said. Some areas do not even have tap water or flush toilets, he added.

Although Chen estimated that visits by Taiwan people to mainland China will reach around 1.68 million this year -- up from 1.5 million in 1997 -- tourists rather than business travelers will account for the increase.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION TO URGE JAPAN NOT TO VOICE THREE-NOES POLICY

TEXT.P: A legislative delegation of various political stripes left on Monday for Japan to express its concern that Tokyo might voice a "three-noes" policy toward Taipei under pressure from Beijing.

Wang Jin-pyng, vice president of the Legislative Yuan and head of the 19-member mission, said at the Chang Kai-shek International Airport that the delegation has no intention of interfering with Japan's engagement with other countries, but insists that Japan's foreign relations should not influence the well-being and interests of the 21.8 million residents of the island.

Wang said that as far as he knows, Japan has never acknowledged that mainland China has sovereignty over Taiwan, and stressed that the delegation will not accept any announcement by the Japanese government regarding a "three-noes" policy toward Taiwan.

This policy, spelled out by US President Bill Clinton during his trip to the mainland in late June, refers to no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan membership in international organizations that require statehood.

Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will visit Japan in the coming months, when he is expected to ask Japan to exclude the Taiwan Strait from the area covered by the defense cooperation between Tokyo and Washington, Wang said. The delegation will express concern over the issue and urge Japan to continue to play a key role in maintaining Asia-Pacific peace, despite Beijing's pressure.

The legislator said that the delegation also hopes the Japan government will not agree to forge any kind of military cooperation agreement with the mainland that will be seen as a "strategic alliance partnership."
The delegation is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TAIWAN DOLLAR DROPS 20% SINCE ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar has depreciated 20.1 percent since the beginning of the Asian financial crisis more than one year ago, according to statistics released by the Central Bank of China.
Compared with June last year, Indonesia's rupiah has suffered the biggest drop among the region's currencies, losing 70.89 percent, and leaving it the weakest currency in Asia.

During the same period, Thailand's baht has fallen 40.75 percent; followed by Malaysia's ringgit with a 40.25 percent cut; the Philippine peso, down 39.17 percent; the Korean won, down 32.01 percent; the Japanese yen, down 20.54 percent; the Singapore dollar, down 19.19 percent; and the Hong Kong dollar, down 0.02 percent.
The changes in Asia's currencies compared with December last year are as follows:

The rupiah, down 52.05 percent; the yen, down 9.42 percent; the ringgit, down 8.06 percent; the peso, down 6.6 percent; the new Taiwan dollar, down 6.24 percent; the Singapore dollar, down 4.95 percent; and the Hong Kong dollar, down 0.01 percent.
However, the won and the baht went up by 29.78 percent and 12.86 percent, respectively, during the period.
Taiwan foreign exchange dealers said that the statistics indicate the Asia financial meltdown, which has battered most of the major economies of the region, is showing signs of abatement.

But they warned that with the recent worsening of Russia's financial situation and the lingering pressure for the devaluation of the yen, mainland China's renminbi, and the Hong Kong dollar, the crisis is far from over. The US dollar continues to be the strongest currency in the region's foreign exchange markets, the dealers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOW TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN ARE COPING WITH ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has remained relatively unscathed by the Asian financial crisis that began in Thailand in July last year, largely because the public and private sectors have responded wisely to the situation.
However, Taiwan's businessmen are increasingly worried about the approach of a second financial upheaval amid a seemingly unavoidable global slump.
Chen Fei-lung, chairman of Namchow Chemical Co., said in an interview with CNA that he is pessimistic about Taiwan's future economic prospects.
He cited the following reasons as the basis for his gloomy outlook:

-- Many of Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have moved their operations out of Taiwan to mainland China and Southeast Asia in the past few years, greatly eroding the basis of Taiwan's manufacturing sector;

-- Taiwan has placed too much weight on the development of high-tech industries, a policy which has begun to cause side effects as it fails to make the best use of Taiwan's human resources, the country's most important assets;
-- Taiwan's stock market is likely to slip further amid the uncertain global economic circumstances; and
-- Non-economic factors, such as the wasting of funds in election campaigns, and huge expenditure in social welfare, are dimming the country's economic prospects.
Namchow Chemical has invested NT$1 billion in Thailand.

To avoid losses caused by the drastic devaluation of the Thai baht, Chen said, his company has turned 90 percent of its production in Thailand over to export. Only 10 percent of its output is currently set aside for local consumption, and sales are mostly transacted with cash so as to reduce the risk of bad credit.
The company has also continued to increase its capital so that it can increase its bank borrowing, with most of the new borrowing in Thai baht rather than the strong US dollar.

Tseng Huan-cheng, general manager of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp., said Taiwan has not been hit as hard as other Asian countries in the financial crisis, mainly because of the government's conservative monetary policy and the comparatively healthy structure of Taiwan's industry.
The devaluation of Japan's currency poses no major threat to Taiwan's semiconductor industry, because most purchases from Japan are quoted in US currency, he said.

Although a large part of the industry's production equipment is imported from Japan, Tseng said that following the recent economic slump, many producers have put off their expansion plans in order to reduce costs.
He pointed out that Taiwan has gained weight in the world's semiconductor industry, and should strive for continued development rather than relying on the failure of its foreign competitors.
Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the ruling Kuomintang's Business Management Committee, said competitive and flexible management has helped Taiwan's SMEs to weather the crisis.
He added that the nation's huge foreign currency reserves and the government's conservative financial policies have also served as effective shields against the financial storm.

In order to avoid over-dependence on the US currency and to avoid the occurrence of a second financial crisis, Liu urged Asian countries to consider the establishment of an "Asia Currency Unit" (ACU) system under the Asian Development Bank (ADB).

The ACU would be a single Asian currency for the whole region, in the same manner as the European Union's new Euro. This would give the Asian economy as a whole far greater power to resist the strength of the US dollar.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-PRC SHOWDOWN OVER TAIWAN COULD MATERIALIZE BY 2018: REPORT

TEXT.P: A US-mainland China showdown over Taiwan could materialize by 2018, and it is imperative that the United States have the forces to use in such a crisis, according to a new report by the US National Defense University.

The report, titled "1998 Strategic Assessment: Engaging Power for Peace," characterizes the People's Republic of China, India and Russia as US security strategy "wild cards" that could influence a best-case scenario in which other large powers are friends that share responsibilities.
The three nations also could shape a worst-case scenario in which large powers foment instability, encourage proliferation and prepare to challenge US military supremacy.
Looking 20 years into the future, the report says the PRC is the most likely of the three to become a threat to the interests of the United States and allies it defines as "core states."
The study outlines concerns about Chinese nationalism, economic potential, and some inherently conflicting interests with Washington that could pose a challenge to US forces over the next 20 years.
"The gradual growth of Chinese power projection capabilities will unsettle regional security and demand US attention, even if no hostile Chinese intentions are evident," the report says.
It adds that a showdown over Taiwan between the United States and the PRC could materialize by 2018 and that the United States should be prepared to meet that scenario.
The report cites the PRC as a US security strategy "wild card," and categorizes Taiwan as a "core partner" which can help the US shoulder security burdens.

The report, which was published by the US National Defense University's Institute for National Strategic Studies, has been presented to US Army Gen. Hugh Shelton, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA AND YOUNG TIBETANS SPLIT ON TIBETAN CAUSE

TEXT.P: Tibet's Dalai Lama is seeking autonomy for Tibet through non-violent means, but many young Tibetans are becoming impatient and want to resort to armed struggle to win Tibetan independence.

In exclusive interviews with the Dalai Lama and Tibetan leaders in exile in India, Australia's Special Broadcasting Corporation (SBS) reported a split between Tibet's spiritual leader and some young and well-educated Tibetans.
These young Tibetans have become impatient with the Dalai Lama's approach to the Tibetan issue.
The SBS reported that mainland China recently made a surprising offer to the Tibetans in exile in India, saying they would be allowed to return to Tibet if they gave up the independence movement.
Meanwhile, the Dalai Lama is optimistic that the recent visit to mainland China by US President Bill Clinton bodes well for Tibet.

"China proper is becoming a more open society, with more freedom of expression, and more and more Chinese, especially intellectuals and some writers, openly criticize their own government policies," he said.
But some young Tibetans, and some older ones, want to resort to armed struggle for the chance of returning to Tibet someday, the SBS reported.

Lhasang Tsering of the Tibetan Center for Advanced Studies in India said: "Something negative has come from" the recent visit of Clinton to mainland China, because he recognized Tibet as part of China.
"The US is on record as recognizing Tibet as an independent country. Now who is he (Clinton) today to go against history and say Tibet is a part of China?" he asked.
A leader of the Tibetan Young Congress, a radical wing in India, said many young Tibetans advocate full independence for Tibet. "It's high time for China to have a dialogue (with us)," he said.
However, the Dalai Lama advocates patience. He said positive change "does not come next month or next year. I think positive things are developing (in China)."
But he said he understands the impatience and frustration of many young Tibetans who want a resolution to the Tibetan problem.

"But I feel if they look from a wider perspective, they will see positive signs and the hope that is there," the Dalai Lama said, adding that the rest of the world has the responsibility of bringing mainland China into the mainstream of democracy.
"It's wrong to isolate China, because the country has the potential to become a world economic power," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE UP TO 2.93% IN JULY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate reached 2.93 percent in July, up 0.23 percentage points over the preceding month, as many newly-graduated youngsters have entered the job market.

According to statistics released on Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), the number of employed workers at the end of July totaled 9.27 million, up 107,000 over the same month of last year.
Jobless workers by the end of last month had soared to 280,000, an unemployment rate of 2.93 percent.
After seasonal adjustment, the rate stood at 2.69 percent, up 0.02 percentage points over last month, and 0.07 percentage points up on the figure of one year ago.

The statistics indicate that Taiwan's labor force topped 9.55 million at the end of July, up 47,000 over June's figure. The participation rate of the labor force was 58 percent, representing a 0.2 percentage point increase over June.
The average period of unemployment in July was 19 weeks, down three weeks from June. For first-time job-seekers, unemployment lasted for an average of 14 weeks, down seven weeks from one month ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS FACING CRISIS

TEXT.P: TransAsia Airways, a domestic airline company, might be forced to reduce its flight services from Tuesday if a serious dispute between the airline's management and pilots cannot be resolved.

Expressing anger over a management decision to cut their pay, representatives of the almost 70 TransAsia pilots which fly the carrier's ATR turboprop planes announced on Monday night that all ATR pilots will stop work from 11:00 p.m. on Monday.

Pilot Chen Pei-chung said at a press conference that the company notified them of substantial pay cuts on Aug. 5 without prior consultation. The cuts reached a monthly average of NT$50,000 per employee. Pilots' pay will be cut to NT$120,000 from NT$200,000, while co-pilots will have their pay slashed to NT$80,000 from NT$120,000.
In addition, Chen said that four pilots were told they were to be suspended without warning from Aug. 20. Meanwhile, the airline also announced that several foreign pilots would be hired.

Chen said that despite several rounds of negotiations between the company and representatives of the pilots, the last of which was held on Aug. 17, the airline's management refused to make any concessions, claiming that "this is set policy and there is no way to change it."

The airline's decision has caused negative psychological factors in the ATR pilots, and has aroused panic, Chen said, pointing out as the pilots are afraid their current anxiety might endanger flight safety, they decided to stop working.

Although TransAsia Airways, founded in 1951, currently has twelve A321-131 and A320-231 jet planes as well as thirteen ATR 72-210A and ATR 42-200 turbine propeller airplanes. The carrier operates 18 domestic flights each day flights each day, in addition to offering seven international charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MARINE SENTENCED FOR DEFECTING 24 YEARS AGO

TEXT.P: A former marine who defected to mainland China in a patrol boat from a frontline island 24 years ago was sentenced on Monday to five years imprisonment by a military court.
Wu Miao-hu, 47, was also stripped of his political rights for five years by the Marine Corps Military Court.

The court said that Wu, a former Marine Corps lieutenant captain, defected to the mainland in 1974 when he was posted at Wuchiu, a Taiwan-controlled military outpost off the coast of mainland China's Fujian Province. 0 The court also said that Wu, who served as commander of an amphibious search squad, commandeered the patrol boat by forcing three other crewmen at gunpoint to jump overboard during a regular exercise, and sailing the boat to communist-controlled Nanri Island, also off the Fujian coast.

Wu reentered Taiwan as an ordinary mainland resident on March 27 this year, and was found by police to be a wanted fugitive on April 8 when he tried to register as a permanent resident in his native rural township of Kungkwan, Miaoli County.
Although now a resident of mainland China, Wu was still taken into custody and prosecuted.
He has ten days to appeal his sentence.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT RECEIVES SWAZILAND'S FOREIGN AND TRADE MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday received visiting Foreign and Trade Minister of Swaziland Albert H. Shabangu, who he welcomed and asked to convey his personal greetings to Swaziland's King Mswati III.

Lee told Shabangu that the Republic of China is more than willing to help Swaziland boost its economy and standard of living, adding the ROC government will encourage local businessmen to invest in the African state.
He also urged Swaziland to improve its investment environment in order to lure foreign capital.

In order to further consolidate ROC ties with Swaziland, the president told Shabangu that he had appointed Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, as his personal envoy to Swaziland on the occasion of Swaziland's 30th anniversary of independence which is also the 30th birthday of King Mswati III.
Shabangu for his part said that he was impressed by the ROC's ability to remain relatively unscathed by the Asian financial crisis.
Shabangu was accompanied by his wife and by Swaziland Ambassador to the ROC Clifford S. Mamba at the meeting with Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The government vows to take measures to stabilize stock and foreign exchange markets.
The China Times: After the joint entrance examinations are abolished, senior high schools will be required to admit at least 50 percent of students assigned by city and county educational administrative authorities based on the Ministry of Education-designed basic academic level tests.
The United Daily News: 67 TransAsia Airways pilots resign.
The Liberty Times: Taiwan's stock index plunged below the 7,000-point psychological barrier on Monday over Russian turmoil.
The Independence Morning Post: Taiwan's stock index fell below the 7,000-point barrier on Monday, while the New Taiwan dollar also depreciated more than 10 cents against the US dollar.
The Commons Daily: Law enforcement authorities are concerned about suspected inflow of capital from mainland China and local criminal gangs into the domestic securities markets.
The China Post: Taiwan's share prices plunged on Monday over global woes.
The China News: Taiwan stocks go through the floor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA TAKES STEPS TO RESTORE TIES WITH NIGERIA

TEXT.P: Canada is taking the first steps toward restoring diplomatic ties with Nigeria as the African country has made some positive moves toward a more democratic system, a ranking official said Monday.
Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy added, however, that Canada has not yet made a final decision on whether to reopen its high commission there.

Canada cut off diplomatic relations with the African country two years ago after its dictatorship executed several prominent dissidents. Ottawa has since tried to lead an international boycott of the military government, to little avail.

Axworthy met with the Nigerian ambassador to the United Nations and discussed Nigeria's commitment to a general election in March, the establishment of an electoral commission, the release of prisoners and the creation of more opportunities for trade unions.
"There has been, we believe, a series of quite positive decisions taken," Axworthy told a news conference.

"We wanted to establish this diplomatic presence in Nigeria so we can begin to assess what's going on and be in a position to help make recommendations on how the Commonwealth can support the developments," he said.
David Kilgour, Canada's secretary of state for Africa, plans to visit Nigeria in September and a Canadian diplomat will be posted there.
Canada has said it will give financial and technical aid to support the country's transition to democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUG, ENVIRONMENTAL CRIMES HAVE GREATEST IMPACT ON CANADA

TEXT.P: Drug smuggling and environmental crime top the list of organized crimes that have the greatest impact on Canadian society, a government report said Monday.

The study, released by Solicitor General Andy Scott, noted that drug trafficking and abuse are costing Canadians billions of dollars every year. It defined environmental crime as the improper storage and disposal of hazardous waste.

Economic crime, like securities and telemarketing fraud, costs Canadians at least C$5 billion (US$3.3 billion) annually, according to the report, yet it is low on the list of law enforcement priorities.

Between 8,000 to 16,000 illegal immigrants are smuggled into Canada each year, and counterfeit products cost approximately C$1 billion annually, while money laundered in Canada may range from C$5 billion to C$17 billion a year, the report said.
Scott announced the results of the report in a speech to the Canadian Association of Chiefs of Police in Edmonton.

The study found that the impact of organized crime is wider than has been estimated and goes beyond obvious consequences such as violence and economic losses, to less conspicuous social, environmental, health and safety damages.

Scott also outlined the main elements of his proposed National Action Plan on Organized Crime. Although it is a work in progress, he said he was encouraged by the police chiefs' participation in the development of the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SATELLITE OF TAIWAN, SINGAPORE TO BLAST OFF WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The launch of a Taiwan-Singapore owned US$240 million "ST-1" satellite is on schedule to blast off Wednesday at 7 a.m. (Singapore time) from Kaourou, French Guiana, the Straits Times reported Monday.

The ST-1 satellite, owned by Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecom, will be launched by an Ariane-4 rocket built by French-based Arianespace. It has passed all its pre-launch tests, and nothing barring an act of nature will likely stop its flight into space.
Once in space, the satellite will be one of the most powerful telecom satellites in orbit over Asia, providing telecommunication and broadcasting services over most of the region.
The 3.2-tonne geostationary satellite, built by the European company Matra Marconi Space, will orbit at 36,000 km above Earth and is expected to be in service for about 12 years.

Preparations for take-off are at its final stages. The rocket will be fueled only three hours prior to launch due to the explosive nature of the liquid oxygen and hydrogen fuel. A team of 100 engineers will be on hand to monitor the launch.
French Guiana lies between Surinam and Brazil in South America. Its proximity to the equator, calm weather conditions and low population density make it a popular launch site for satellites.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARSH PENALTIES SOUGHT FOR DRUG-CHEATING ATHLETES

TEXT.P: The Australian Olympic Committee (AOC) called for harsh punishment of drug-using athletes and their suppliers so that the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney will be a clean sporting event.
AOC president John Coates said suppliers of performance-enhancing drugs should be subject to the same penalties for narcotics dealers which can range to life imprisonment.

Coates urged state and federal governments to introduce the toughest criminal penalties in the world for users and traders of sports drugs, including jail sentences of up to two years for athletes found guilty of cheating.
He said the current criminal penalties are inadequate as there is evidence anabolic steroid abuse has outstripped that of heroin or cocaine in the general community.
"If we are to ensure that the 2000 Olympic Games are not remembered as the 'drug games,' immediate action is required," he said.
He said the current penalties, which range from fines to a maximum penalty of two years in jail, were significantly lighter than narcotics cases and were not sufficient as a deterrent.
Coates has submitted letters to Prime Minister John Howard and state premiers requesting governments to introduce strict penalties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREGNANT SMOKERS SAID EXPOSING FETUSES TO CANCER

TEXT.P: Women who smoke during pregnancy reportedly risk transmitting a highly carcinogenic substance to their fetuses, according to a new study by the University of Minnesota in the United States.

The study found that pregnant women who smoke can pass on a tobacco by-product called NHK which is one of the strongest carcinogens in tobacco smoke. Traces of NHK were found in the urine of infants born to women who smoked, according to the Australian Medical Association (AMA).
These latest findings have fueled the AMA's campaign to discourage pregnant women from smoking, AMA President David Brand said.
"It's time for us all to get serious about helping women quit before pregnancy and staying smoke-free afterwards," Brand said.

"Smoking during pregnancy is associated with low birth weight, increased fetal, neonatal and prenatal mortality, sudden infant death syndrome, ectopic pregnancy and spontaneous abortion," he said. "We have always known it was bad for women to smoke during pregnancy but now, for the first time, we have hard graphic facts that the baby is exposed to these cancer-causing chemicals, due to the mother's smoking habits."

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE SAID ONLY CAUSE OF CONFLICT IN TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Strait is one of Asia's remaining flash points but conflict will erupt only if Taiwan declares independence, a new report on US military strategy said,
Strategic Assessment 1998, published by the National Defense University (NDU) in Washington, also predicted that Taiwan pressure for new US arms sales will diminish over the next three years.

This is partly due to the fact that Taiwan's armed forces have just completed a procurement cycle, with the exception of air defense systems, and it needs time to assimilate the new systems, the annual report said.
Taiwan recently acquired 150 US-made F-16 and 60 French Mirage fighter aircraft, six French Lafayette-class and seven US Perry-class frigates.

Another reason why arms sales would be reduced is the expected resumption of talks between Taiwan and the mainland, the report said. Cross-strait talks broke off after Beijing suspended a meeting scheduled for July 1995 as a protest to President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States.

The 280-page document, produced by the NDU's Institute for National Strategic Studies and published earlier this month, is the fourth such assessment in as many years. The assessment does not reflect government views but is intended to inform and influence policy makers and academics.
While discussing the challenges in the Asia-Pacific region, the report said that the Korean peninsula and the Taiwan Strait remain "the two most probable sites of conflict."
Conflict in the Taiwan Strait is "probable only if Taiwan declares independence," it said.

Although the cross-strait problem is political and should be solved by the two sides through negotiation, the report said the United States is involved because the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979 requires Washington to provide the island with necessary material for it to defend itself.
The report added that, whatever the cause, "any US administration would come under significant pressure to defend Taiwan were conflict to occur."

Given the likely resumption of cross-strait talks, the best strategy for Washington is to continue to assert insistence on a peaceful settlement by supporting dialogue and by using arms sales to Taiwan to maintain the military balance across the strait.
The United States might also use political channels to convey its concern to Taipei about any unilateral attempt to alter the status quo in the Taiwan Strait, said the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BEER MAKER SUFFERS LOSSES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia's leading beer maker reported A$167 million (over US$105 million) in losses from efforts to enter mainland China's beer market.

Foster's Brewing Group said it would sell its interest in two breweries in Tianjin and Guangdong Provinces and concentrate on expanding its brands in the highly competitive market through its joint-venture operation in Shanghai.

Foster's reported a write-down of A$105 million (US$66 million) across the group after a review of its assets and a board decision to move away from brewery ownership toward global brand management, the Australian Financial Review said.
The write-down was offset by the A$480 million (US$300 million) in profit from the sale of its 50 percent stake in a brewery in Canada earlier this year.

Foster's Chief Executive Ted Kunkel said the group had "placed a stake in the ground," in reference to doing business in mainland China. Its decision to enter the mainland market had been correct but the company was too aggressive by establishing operations in three different locations which proved too costly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TO AVOID CONFLICT, US MUST PROVIDE ROC WITH ARMS: REPORT

TEXT.P: US arms sales to Taiwan would deter Beijing from forcing its hand in the Taiwan Strait dispute and is seen as the only way the United States can avoid getting entangled in a war with the mainland, a policy analysis said.

Ted Galen Carpenter, vice president for defense and foreign policy studies at the Cato Institute, wrote in his report that US officials must at the same time make it clear that under no circumstances will the United States intervene in a war between the island and the mainland.

Identified as an especially controversial aspect of President Bill Clinton's June visit to China was his stated commitment to the "three noes" policy with regard to Taiwan. The policy involves no US support for an independent Taiwan, "two Chinas" or "one Taiwan and one China," nor Taiwan membership in any organization for which statehood is a requirement.
Despite the Clinton administration's insistence that US policy had not changed following the president's statement, there was widespread skepticism in both the United States and Taiwan.

Although Clinton stopped short of accepting Beijing's position that Taiwan is nothing more than a renegade province of the People's Republic of China, the opposition not only to Taiwanese independence but also to Taiwan's hopes for lesser forms of international recognition confirmed a major change in Washington's position, Carpenter added.
Washington's position since 1972 had been that the United States did not challenge Beijing and Taipei's assertion that there is one China and Taiwan is part of China.
But Clinton went much further, signaling US hostility to the possibility of an independent Taiwan or even Taiwanese membership in international organizations.

Clinton's statement drew condemnation from the Republican leadership in Congress and from sources as politically diverse as the Wall Street Journal and the Washington Post. Parris Chang, a Democratic Progressive Party member of Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, bitterly accused Clinton of "selling out" Taiwan.
Although concern about the president's comments is justified, such criticisms misidentify the primary danger arising from Washington's policy shift, Carpenter noted.

The real problem is that Clinton's policy has a built-in, extremely dangerous contradiction. His statements in Shanghai indicate that the United States now considers Taiwanese independence an illegitimate option. This is a far cry from merely acknowledging that most Taiwanese and mainland Chinese endorse the theoretical goal of "one China."

The implications of that change in language go far beyond the escalation of US opposition to Taipei's bid to join the United Nations and other international bodies. More tangibly, Carpenter continued, Clinton's policy shift presages a reduction and eventual elimination of arms sales to Taiwan -- as already suggested by several East Asia experts who want Washington to mollify Beijing by such measures.

Yet the president also implied that Washington would intervene militarily to defend Taiwan from attack. That "accommodationist" approach combines the worst, most dangerous features of appeasement and firmness, added the Cato analyst.

Nearly as dangerous is the policy of all-out support for Taiwan that many American conservatives suggest, Carpenter said. A US security guarantee to Taiwan would lack credibility and, given the emotional determination of mainland Chinese to pursue reunification, could easily entangle the United States in a war with a nuclear-armed power.
That is all the more likely because enthusiasm for formal independence is growing in Taiwan, and the United States would be pressured to back that bid, the report added.

The only solution, concluded Carpenter, is for the United States to allow increased arms sales to Taiwan, thus enabling it to build a self-sufficient defense and an effective deterrent to coercion by Beijing.

At the same time, US officials must make it clear to both Beijing and Taipei that Taiwan is not a vital US interest and that under no circumstances will the United States intervene in a war between the mainland and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC OIL PRICES TO BE LOWERED AGAIN WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced yet another oil price cut on Tuesday, reflecting slumping crude oil import costs.
Starting Wednesday, domestic prices for a variety of petroleum products will be lowered by an average of 1.31 percent, a spokesman for the state monopoly said.
This is the fourth time since July that the CPC has offered an across-the-board price cut for its products amid a downward spiral in international crude oil prices.
Altogether, the state monopoly has lowered its prices by a total of 5.69 percent since July.

Under current government regulations, the CPC is allowed to adjust its prices within a range of 6 percent over three consecutive months. Beyond this range, the CPC must obtain prior approval from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA). If the CPC wants to cut prices again in the near future, it must first secure a green light from the MOEA.
After Wednesday's adjustment, the retail price for premium gasoline will drop to NT$17.4 (US$0.5) per liter from the current NT$17.6, while fuel oil prices will be slashed by NT$74 per kiloliter.
The price for research octane number (RON) 95 gasoline will decline to NT$17.2 from NT$17.4 and RON 92 unleaded gasoline will be cut to NT$16.2 from NT$16.4.
The price for high-grade diesel will fall to NT$12.4 from NT$12.5, while normal-grade diesel will slide from NT$11.3 to NT$11.2.
Meanwhile, prices for household-use and vehicle-use liquefied petroleum gas will be cut by NT$0.18 and NT$0.1, respectively, per kilogram.

The CPC spokesman said the new prices were calculated based on three criteria -- crude oil prices at NT$12.61 per barrel, a currency exchange rate of NT$34.64 against the US dollar and the company's annual profit target of NT$22.2 billion.
With weak crude oil prices in the international market, CPC's crude import costs dropped to an average of US$11.62 a barrel in July, the lowest level in more than a decade.

As a result, the state monopoly registered a pre-tax profit of NT$4.1 billion for the month, or NT$1.87 billion over its target. Against this backdrop, the CPC decided to further lower prices for its products starting Wednesday.

The company first offered a 1.57 percent cut in prices for its products on July 1, and again trimmed its prices by an average of 1.28 percent on July 22. On Aug. 12, it announced a further 1.53 percent cut.

The CPC has conducted weekly reviews of domestic petroleum prices since March in an attempt to have its prices fluctuate in tandem with international crude oil prices and the local currency's exchange rate against the greenback.

Economic observers said the CPC's oil price cuts will help maintain domestic price stability. Nevertheless, another state monopoly, Taiwan Power Co., said it will not lower its electricity rates because the latest CPC price cuts will have only a limited effect on its power generation costs.
