DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.001 against the greenback in Taipei Tuesday, closing at 34.808.
The local currency opened at 34.765, and was traded between 34.72 and 34.824.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$211.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECOND WOMEN'S PRISON OPENS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second women's prison was inaugurated in central Taiwan's Taichung City on Tuesday.
Minister of Justice Cheng Chung-mo, in presiding over the opening ceremony, noted that men and women inmates are required to be placed in different penitentiaries.
In the past, however, there were relatively few women inmates. As a result, they were placed in special women's cells in regular prisons, he said.

But with women's cells becoming more congested every day, the establishment of separate prisons for women has become necessary. The first such prison was opened in the southern city of Kaohsiung three years ago.
The new women's prison can accommodate more than 1,000 inmates. The ministry is planning to build another women's prison in northern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HAS NO RIGHT TO DICTATE TAIWAN'S ACTIONS: DPP HEAD

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of the ROC's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said on Tuesday that Taiwan is a sovereign state and that mainland China has no right to dictate Taiwan's actions.
Lin was responding to remarks made Monday by mainland's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council that if Taiwan really desires unification, it should not do four things.
Foremost, Beijing asked Taiwan not to cite the "different social systems" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as a reason to refuse unification.

In addition, Taiwan should not promote the upgrading of its combat capacity part; continue to promote its bid to join the United Nations; or continue to refuse the establishment of direct links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Lin said that if mainland China really wants to unify with Taiwan, it should not "run contrary to the course of unification," as the people of Taiwan will not be intimidated, and bullying will only arouse antagonism from the Taiwan people.
Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, said that Beijing's views are not conducive to the upcoming high-level meeting between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Yen responded to Beijing's four "should not's" with four of his own: the mainland should not disregard public opinion in Taiwan; advocate the use of force against Taiwan; impose its "one China" principle as the prerequisite for the resumption of cross-strait talks; or insist on political negotiations without regard to the interests of the people.
Lin said Taiwan would use every peaceful means and possible channel to communicate its position with the international community, but the fact that Taiwan remains a sovereign state has not changed.
No county, including the United States or mainland China, has the right to interfere with Taiwan's actions, he said.
Yen also said that it is unwise for Beijing to issue the "four should not's" at a time when the world is calling for an easing of tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES TOTAL US$83.6 BILLION IN JULY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China sat on US$83.61 billion in foreign exchange reserves at the end of July, the world's third-largest such stockpile, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Tuesday.
The total represents an increase of US$321 million over the previous month's figure.

Since financial turmoil struck throughout Asia in the latter half of last year, Taiwan's central bank has intervened in the monetary market several times, dumping US dollars, which reduced Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves and attracted widespread public attention.

The Japanese yen's plunge last June resulted in devaluation pressure on the New Taiwan dollar. In recent months, the CBC has intervened in a very public way to prop up a sagging NT dollar. Such intervention cost Taiwan US$1.16 billion in foreign reserves, resulting in a balance of US$83.29 billion in June, a seven-month low.
The yen fluctuated less wildly in July, which in turn stabilized the NT dollar.

CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said recently that the CBC did not use a single dime in July to stabilize the foreign exchange rate, which is the primary reason for the rise in Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves.
At the end of June, Japan's foreign exchange reserves totaled US$205.87 billion; mainland China's, US$140.05 billion; and Hong Kong's, US$77.9 billion, according to statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1 TAIWAN STUDENT KILLED IN CAR ACCIDENT IN TEXAS, 6 OTHERS INJURED

TEXT.P: One ROC student was killed in a car crash in the southern US state of Texas on Monday and six other Taiwan students were injured in the same accident, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) reported on Tuesday.

"The mishap took place in the northern Texas city of Amarillo at 3 a.m. on Aug. 24 local time," MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said, quoting reports from the Republic of China's representative office in Houston.

Wu said all the seven students aboard the crashed car were studying at Texas A&M University's Commerce campus. Six of them were doing on master's programs and the remaining one was an undergraduate student.

The deceased student was identified as Chen Po-chang, Wu said, adding that two of the injured, Tang Kuang-han and Yang Chih-ping, sustained serious injuries, but they are in stable conditions after receiving emergency medical treatment.
The four other students, identified as Chen Yi-chun, Chiang Hui-ying, Wang Pei-chen and Lou Wei-li, only sustained mild injuries and were already discharged from the hospital, Wu said.

The university's Chinese students association informed the ROC representative office of the mishap shortly after its occurrence, Wu said, adding that a staff member at the office has traveled to Amarillo to help handle related affairs and express concern for all the victims.

In addition to ordering the Houston office to offer all necessary assistance to the students, Wu said MOFA will help the students' families secure travel papers in the shortest possible period of time so that they can travel to Texas to care for their children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS SLASH FLIGHT SERVICES

TEXT.P: Local air carrier TransAsia Airways was forced to slash its flight services on Tuesday as a result of the sudden resignation of 67 pilots.

TransAsia spokesman Ho Chih-hwai said that the airline has had to leave all thirteen of its ATR turboprop planes in the hangar, at least until Friday, which is the deadline for the pilots to back down and report for work.

Beset by a serious dispute between the airline's management and pilots over pay cuts, Ho said that the company's stance is firm, adding that if the pilots insist on resigning, foreign pilots will be recruited to fill the vacancies.

A total of 90 flights will have to be canceled from Tuesday as a result of the dispute, but Ho reassured passengers with reservations that the company will arrange for them to take flights with alternative carriers.

Chang Chia-juch, vice minister of transportation and communications and director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, called on Tuesday for the airline's management and pilots to leave their negotiation channels open, and for each party to make some concessions. Passenger rights should remain the highest priority, he stressed.

Although he said the ministry will not intervene in the dispute, Chang pointed out that his ministry will look into claims that some of the ATR pilots were placed on the resignation list without their consent.

Sixty-seven of the carrier's 72 ATR turboprop pilots announced on Monday that they would stop working from 11:00 p.m. that evening to protest against a management decision to drastically cut their pay.

Pilot Chen Pei-chung said at a press conference that they received unexpected notification of substantial pay cuts on Aug. 5. The cuts amount to a monthly average of NT$50,000 per employee. Pilots' pay will be cut to NT$120,000 from NT$200,000, while co-pilots will have their pay slashed to NT$80,000 from NT$120,000.
In addition, Chen said that four pilots were told without warning that they were to be suspended from Aug. 20. Meanwhile, the airline also announced that several foreign pilots would be recruited.

The decision has caused negative psychological factors in the ATR pilots, and has aroused panic, Chen said, pointing out that as the pilots are afraid their current anxiety might endanger flight safety, they decided to resign. Airline pilots are not allowed under Taiwan law to go on strike.

TransAsia Airways, founded in 1951, currently has thirteen ATR 72-210A and ATR 42-200 turboprop planes, as well as twelve A321-131 and A320-231 jet planes. The carrier operates 18 domestic routes, in addition to offering seven international charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC REPORTS MIXED MONEY SUPPLY GROWTH RATES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's credit status is expected to remain relaxed as the growth of the domestic money supply was stable in July, although the three main indexes indicated mixed growth, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported Tuesday.

The broadly defined M2, which comprises cash in circulation, checking accounts, demand and savings deposits, and quasi-money (including time deposits and treasury bills), grew at an annual rate of 8.34 percent in July, the highest year-on-year increase in the past three months.

However, the narrowly defined M1A, which comprises currency in circulation and checking and demand deposits, dropped 1.46 percent in July compared with the previous month. The decline represents a 27-month low, officials from CBC's Economic Research Department said.
The M1B -- the M1A plus passbook savings deposits -- also dropped 0.98 percent in July, a 30-month low. The M1B is considered by some economists the most effective gauge of Taiwan's credit status.
Of the indexes, only the M2 posted an increase in July, which the CBC researchers attribute mainly to less government savings and the relatively low comparison base of one year ago.

The annual growth rate of savings in major financial institutions, including banks and post offices, stood at 7.82 percent at the end of July, the lowest monthly year-on-year increase since January. In comparison, the growth rate was 8.1 percent at the end of June.
Growth in bank lending and financial investments also slowed to 8.82 percent in July from June's figure of 9.72 percent. July's figure is an eight-month low, the officials said.
An anemic domestic stock market and Asia's financial crisis are mainly responsible for the negative growth in the M1A and M1B indexes in July, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST DENGUE CASE MAY HAVE BEEN TRANSMITTED BY IMPORTED MOSQUITOES

TEXT.P: The first reported case of locally contracted dengue fever might have been caused by Aedes mosquitoes that reached Taiwan among imported cargo, the Department of Health (DOH) reported on Tuesday.

Hsu Hsu-mei, deputy director of the Bureau of Communicable Diseases under the DOH, said that the Kaohsiung City home and workplace of the 28-year-old victim had been inspected, but no Aedes mosquito breeding sites had been spotted.

Hsu said that preliminary findings suggest that the Aedes mosquitoes, the carrier of the sometimes fatal disease, had been brought into the country along with imported cargo. The victim, who works at Kaohsiung port, might have been bitten during the course of his work, she added.

However, the official said that the department has not ruled out the possibility that the man might have contracted the infection outside of Kaohsiung, as he visited a pear orchard in Pingtung County in early August.

The Kaohsiung health department has so far collected blood samples from 104 residents living in the same neighborhood as the victim, as well as blood samples from 60 of the victim's colleagues, to see if any one else has caught the disease.

The DOH revealed the case on Monday, saying that while the other 60 or so reported dengue victims had contracted the disease while traveling in Southeast Asian countries, the Kaohsiung port worker has not left the country within the past six months.

The DOH said that the man was rushed to hospital on Aug. 11 for dengue-related symptoms including skin rash, fever, headache, nausea, joint pain and loss of appetite. However, the hospital did not report the case to the DOH until Aug. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES ENVOY TO US TO WORK TOWARD BETTER ROC-US TIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received Stephen Chen, the ROC's representative to the United States, on Tuesday and instructed him to strive to elevate substantive relations between the two countries.

During the hour-long meeting, Chen briefed the president on the American public's reaction to last June's Beijing summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

He analyzed the current state of Taipei-Washington relations, the American people's general reaction to the Clinton-Jiang talks, as well as the way in which the Republic of China is dealing with the development.

After hearing the briefing, President Lee asked Chen to work to further enhance all-out substantive relations with the United States in all fields, including academia, the news media, Congress, think-tanks and administrative organizations.
The president instructed Chen to continue efforts to improve communications with the US government.
Chen has been in Taipei for the just-concluded second plenary session of the Kuomintang in his capacity as a member of the KMT's Central Advisory Committee.

In addition to briefing President Lee, Chen offered separate reports to other ranking officials, including Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council; Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general of the Presidential Office; and Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
Officials disclosed that during Chen's meeting with the president, he also reported the US government's basic stance on visits to the United States or transits through it by high-level ROC officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 40% OF LOCAL PEOPLE SUPPORT TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 40 percent of local people support Taiwan independence, while about 80 percent give a thumbs down to the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme, according to the results of a public opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The telephone poll of 1,008 adult residents throughout the island, conducted by the Rising People Foundation on Aug. 13-15, found that 39.9 percent of the respondents think Taiwan should move toward independence in the future, compared to 31.2 percent who said Taiwan should reunify with mainland China.
Meanwhile, 15 percent of those surveyed said the status quo should be maintained forever.
Survey results also showed that 79.4 percent of the respondents oppose the "one country, two systems" unification formula.

If the ROC surrendered its sovereignty and jurisdiction of defense and foreign affairs to mainland China and Beijing promised not to interfere with Taiwan's internal and economic affairs, 80.7 percent said they oppose unification under such conditions. Even if Taiwan were allowed to retain its own military, 71.7 percent said they still couldn't accept such unification terms.

As for Taiwan's future, 33.7 percent said they believe that Taiwan's status quo can be maintained for more than 30 years; 9.5 percent said they think the status quo can be maintained for 20 to 29 years; 17.2 percent said they believe the status quo can be maintained for 10 to 19 years; 13.2 percent said they think the status quo can be maintained for five to nine years; and 4.4 percent said they believe the status quo will change in less than five years.

The same survey further showed that 61.9 percent of the respondents see the need for Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, C. F. Koo, to meet his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, this fall to discuss issues of mutual concern.

As for the agenda for the much-anticipated Koo-Wang meeting, 80 percent said the two sides should discuss the possibility of signing an investment guarantee agreement to protect the interests and safety of Taiwan investors in mainland China, while 78.4 percent said cooperation in fighting crime and mutual legal assistance should be included in the agenda.
Only 46.5 percent said issues related to Taiwan's future status, unification or independence, should be discussed at the planned Koo-Wang meeting.

Asked if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait were to hold political talks, 37.6 percent said issues concerning Taiwan's participation in international organizations should be included in the agenda; 36.8 percent said the two sides should discuss a mechanism to prevent cross-strait military confrontation; 26 percent said the two sides should mull issues related to Taiwan's future.

The survey also found that 61.5 percent oppose the proposal: "Taiwan recognize it is part of China and promise not to declare independence in 50 years, but agree to give up forever its attempt to seek independence 50 years later, while Beijing promise not to attack Taiwan in 50 years."

Meanwhile, 75 percent of the respondents said they have never been to mainland China, and 53.5 percent said if Taiwan were to negotiate sovereignty issues with mainland China, the Taiwan delegations should include representatives from all major political parties here as well as professionals from related fields.

Analyzing the poll results, a spokesperson for the Rising People Foundation said there are no major differences in opinions concerning Taiwan's future or cross-strait relations among local people of different party affiliation or origin.

"As far as Taiwan's future status and cross-strait relations are concerned, no major differences exist between native Taiwanese and those who come from families which moved to Taiwan after the Chinese communists took control of the mainland in 1949," the spokesperson added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH LOSE GROUND

TEXT.P: Share prices tumbled on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday after a sharp plunge in the previous session, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, dropping 49.42 points to close at 6,908.33.

The bourse opened at 6,948.95 and fell as low as 6,811.43. Dealers said that the market was dominated by a bearish sentiment after the index fell through the psychologically important 7,000-point barrier Monday, a decline attributed to uncertainty over the soundness of the island's economic fundamentals.
A total of 1.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$79.28 billion (US$2.28 billion), compared with the previous session's turnover of US$77.19 billion.

Construction issues fell the most at 1.9 percent, followed by textile shares at 1.7 percent, plastic and chemical stocks at 1.6 percent, financial issues at 1.3 percent, paper and pulp stocks at 1.2 percent, and cement shares at 1 percent.
Foodstuff issues rose 1 percent and electrical engineering stocks moved up 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also slid.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September lost 6 points to close at 6,949, with 780 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for October dropped 79 points to finish at 6,930, while those for December plunged 201 points to 7,019 and those for March moved down 90 points to 7,210. Contract transactions for these futures totaled 23, 11 and 17, respectively.
No transactions were registered for June.

The reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 6,955 for September; 7,009 for October; 7,220 for December; 7,300 for March; and 7,324 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROC VISITORS
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, El Salvador, Aug. 24 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Salvadoran President Armando Calderon Sol on Monday received a visiting ROC delegation led by Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang and Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
The delegation, composed of officials from the CEPD and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, arrived here earlier that same day.
Emphasizing the traditional close and cordial bilateral relations between the two countries, Calderon expressed the hope that two-way ties will be further strengthened through increased exchanges.

Chiang said the major purpose of his visit to El Salvador is to discuss cooperative ventures with five central American diplomatic partners -- El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica, and Guatemala -- on how to promote the economic development of these countries.

The CEPD chairman also reported to Calderon that the ROC delegation and the foreign and trade ministers from the five central American countries will hold an economic cooperation conference here on Tuesday to discuss ways of realizing bilateral cooperative projects.

After a year of research following a similar meeting held last year in Taipei, Chiang said that bilateral relations can be further cemented in the areas of trade, investment, and tourism. He expressed the opinion that the Republic of China and the five Central American allies should clinch an agreement soon to accelerate their plans to set up a joint free economic zone in Central America.

Central America has emerged as an attractive investment prospect following the year-long Asian financial storm, Chiang said, adding that the ROC government has worked out a series of incentives for Taiwan businesses interested in investing in the region.

So far, three Taiwan firms have signed agreements to set up strongholds in a Taiwan-invested industrial zone in El Salvador. If they can begin their operations there by the end of this year, it will create up to 5,000 job opportunities for local residents. Another four Taiwan companies are also planning to move in, which will create a further 12,000 job opportunities.
For his part, Hu said that he found that El Salvador has made noticeable progress over the past four years, adding that he now has greater confidence in encouraging Taiwan businesses to invest.
In an interview with the local press later the same day, Hu called for a bilateral accord to avoid double taxation in order to woo more Taiwan investors to El Salvador.
According to the foreign minister, there are 14 Taiwan companies currently operating in El Salvador, all of which are making a profit.
Hu revealed that the Rebar Group, one of Taiwan's leading enterprises, is planning to open facilities at the Taiwan-funded industrial zone if construction of the complex can be completed by November.

Should the Rebar Group set up shop there, Hu said other Taiwan businesses will undoubtedly follow, because Rebar is a respected concern comprising banks, food and insurance companies, hotels, real estate brokerages, and a cable television network.
He expressed the hope that more hi-tech Taiwan businesses will invest in El Salvador and help upgrade local industries.

Chiang and Hu also visited Salvadoran Vice President Enrique Borgos, who hailed Taiwan's economic and political prowess, and expressed appreciation for the ROC government's willingness to share its development experience with his country.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BUSINESS LEADERS CALL FOR IMPROVED INTERNATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Teng Chia-ling and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan business leaders are urging the government to help guide local enterprises in their efforts to upgrade as soon as possible, in order to enhance their international competitiveness.

Since Thailand announced the adoption of a floating exchange rate for the Thai baht on July 2, 1997, igniting a series of foreign exchange rate battles in Southeast Asia, the financial turmoil has spread like a plague from Thailand to the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Japan.

However, Taiwan has remained relatively unscathed by the financial disaster, which the business leaders attribute to the small government foreign debt, as well as the ability of it's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to react quickly to change.

Kao Ching-yuan, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said in an interview with CNA that many Southeast Asian countries, with high ratios of both foreign debts and bad accounts, have been proven too weak to withstand the onslaught of the financial firestorm.

However, he went on, Taiwan's situation is different. Most of its SMEs, which make up the majority of Taiwan's enterprises, are highly capable of coping with changing situations, and are able to use their own funds to adapt and surmount the crisis.

Chu Chih-yang, honorary chairman of the Chinese National Research Institute of Industry & Commerce Construction, pointed out that the SMEs, which account for about half of the total national output and employ some 75 percent of the nation's workforce, are the mainstay of Taiwan's economy.

He said he believes that close cooperation between SMEs and their satellite plants, and the flexible use of their own funds, have also helped prevent them from suffering excessive impact from the financial crisis.

Chen Kuo-ho, chairman of the research institute, noted that another important factor that has helped minimize the influence of the financial turmoil is the traditionally strict and conservative management style prevalent in the country's SMEs.

Tai Sheng-thung, chairman of the National Association of Small & Medium Enterprises, ROC, also pointed out that the SMEs, with more than 30 years of business experience and production technology, together with the prudent screening system employed by Taiwan's financial institutions, have also helped buffer the economy.
He added that the SMEs did not use excessive credit to borrow and were therefore able to safely tide themselves over the difficulties of economic recession.

Meanwhile, the business leaders also expressed their hope that the government will move one step further, and present concrete measures to cope with the financial crisis and boost economic prosperity.

Both Wang You-theng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, and Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, urged the government to encourage private investment and promote industrial development in Taiwan.

Koo said the stabilization of the political situation should be the government's top priority in leading the nation's enterprises through the financial storm. If the political situation can retain long-term stability, he said, then foreign investors will naturally have more confidence to invest in Taiwan, and the economy will grow accordingly.

Kao, Chu, Chen, and Tai were unanimous in their suggestion that the government should: help enterprises to improve production technology; provide a good climate for capital or fund raising; draft related laws and policies; and implement government reconstruction.

In addition, they said, both government officials and entrepreneurs should earmark more funds for research and development of better technology and production techniques, instead of using their capital for speculation. This, they said, will prevent Taiwan from marching down the road toward a bubble economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE MINISTRY TAKING SHAPE

TEXT.P: A proposal to form a ministry of agriculture was broached at a just-concluded national agricultural conference, the head of the Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Tuesday.

The framework of the new ministry, which is aimed at streamlining the government and preparing the country for entry into the World Trade Organization, was one of the focuses of the two-day National Conference on Agriculture which ended on Tuesday.

The proposal calls for an expansion of the COA framework from six departments, one bureau, and one administration, to six departments, four bureaus and two administrations, said COA head Peng Chuo-kui.

The existing functions of the COA will be redefined under the new structure, and the research institutes under the Food Bureau, and the Department of Agriculture and Forestry of the Taiwan Provincial Government, will be transferred to the jurisdiction of the new ministry, said Peng.

DOC.HEADLINE: PESSIMISM OVER TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: An increasing number of manufacturing sector businessmen believe the country's economic development will slow down in the second half of this year, according to a survey by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER).

The TIER survey, conducted in July, shows that 35.8 percent of businessmen polled shared this pessimistic view, up from 26.3 percent in a similar survey in June, while 21.4 percent expect a more active economy in the latter half of this year than in the past six months, down from June's 23.7 percent.

The number of those who believe Taiwan's economy will not change this year fell to 42.8 percent from the previous 50 percent, illustrating general pessimism toward the island's future economic development, TIER researchers said on Tuesday.

The July survey indicates that most businessmen in the manufacturing sector saw their output in July maintained at the same level as June. However, they also had higher inventories, and suffered decreasing orders and declining profits due to lower prices.

These findings show that the recession is expected to significantly slow Taiwan's economic growth, the TIER experts said, warning that it will be difficult for the island to achieve its target of 5.3 percent economic growth this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF REGRETS ARATS SNUB

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Tuesday wrote another letter to its Beijing-based counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), expressing regret at being denied permission to assist Taiwan car accident victims in northwestern mainland China.

The semi-official SEF faxed three letters to ARATS on Sunday and Monday, expressing its willingness to send a SEF official to the mainland to offer help in the aftermath of a car accident on Saturday in which six Taiwan tourists died and eight others were injured in Gansu Province, said SEF Deputy Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing.
The accident occurred in a remote area of Gansu Province, along part of the ancient Silk Road.
ARATS turned down the offer, saying that it would handle the situation without any assistance from the SEF.
Wu said it is regrettable that the SEF offer of help was rejected repeatedly.

In its Tuesday letter to ARATS, the SEF discounted the latest ARATS response as contrary to the truth. The ARATS letter said that SEF officials have never been allowed to travel to the mainland to negotiate issues concerning the welfare and interests of Taiwan people in past years, and that they will never be allowed to do so in the future.
The SEF argued that its officials have indeed traveled to the mainland to help resolve problems arising from accidents in which Taiwan visitors' lives have been lost and their property damaged.
Wu said he does not understand why ARATS is denying this, or why it has made an about-face and barred SEF officials from traveling to the mainland.

Wu said he hates to see that a "gray area" exists with respect to interaction and mutual assistance between the two intermediary bodies, adding that this issue should also be included for discussion in future negotiations.

The SEF letter also requested ARATS to help the relatives of the Taiwan accident victims, and make sure they are accorded the proper treatment, that their opinions are respected concerning the handling of the bodies, that the eight injured be given proper medical care, that the cause of the accident be probed, that compensation be discussed, and that Taiwan media personnel be given help when they travel to Gansu to cover the story.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET VALUE DOWN 27 PERCENT SINCE MARCH

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange continued to slide for a second day on Tuesday, and statistics show that some 27 percent of the stock market's total value has evaporated since last March.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, closed at 6,908.33, down 49.42 points from the preceding day, bringing the total value of the stock market to NT$8,088.6 billion.
The figure represents a decrease of 27.7 percent in total value compared with the figure for March 2 (NT$11,187.9 billion) when the index hit the year's high of 9,277.09 points.
According to the statistics, about 211.58 billion shares were listed on the stock market at that time. The average price of each share was NT$52.87.
Since then, the index has dropped 25.53 percent, with the number of shares rising to 241.16 billion, meaning that the average price of each share has slipped to NT$33.45.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY (PART I)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top economic planner said that Taiwan has been better able to tackle the Asian financial crisis than many other countries because it's financial and industrial development policies are good and are properly implemented.
P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks in a recent interview with the CNA.
Taiwan will stimulate its domestic demand and encourage private investment in order to tide over the financial crisis sweeping Asia, he added.
The following is the transcript of the interview:
Q: The Asian financial crisis has devastated the economy of many countries for a year. Taiwan has fared relatively well amid the crisis. Can you please explain why?

A: The Republic of China on Taiwan is one of the three countries in the region that are able to achieve economic growth this year. In addition, our currency depreciation is relatively mild, and our stock market is rather stable, when compared with those of other Asian countries. All of these indicate that our economy is rather healthy.
I believe this is because our financial policy and industrial development policy are appropriate.

Because of trade surplus, we have accumulated a big amount of foreign exchange reserves. And our foreign debts are almost nil, when compared with those of many other Asian countries. This is because we have enough savings for domestic investment, and because we have steadily carried out our financial policy.

In the past decade, we have successfully transformed our labor-intensive industries into technology-intensive industries, as can been seen from the vigorous development of our information industry. As a result, our export trade and our economy have been growing pretty well in the past 10 years.

The economy of Singapore and Taiwan are rather healthy, because the financial and industrial development policies of the two countries are pretty good. Japan's economy is the second largest in the world because of its successful industrial development policies. But its financial policy has plunged its economy into deep recession.
Q: Can you shed some light on the impact of the Asian financial crisis on Taiwan? What factors will affect the recovery of the Asian economy?

A: Like flu, the financial crisis is sweeping all countries in Asia. It reduces domestic demand, raises jobless rates, causes currency depreciation, cuts investment, pushes up consumer prices, and decreases imports.

As a result, Taiwan's export trade in the first seven months of this year was eight percent lower than a year earlier. Fortunately, our exports to Europe grew seven percent during the period, and the exports to the United States and Central America increased one percent. Our exports to Japan and South Korea reduced 25 percent during the period, but it was caused by external factors. Exports to Asia account for 50 percent of Taiwan's total export trade. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY (PART II)

TEXT.P: I believe the economic performances of Indonesia, Japan, and mainland China are pivotal in the future stability of the Asian economy.
Political instability, drought, and high jobless rates are hurting the economy of Indonesia, which may affect the pace of economic recovery in other Asian countries.

Japan's jobless rates have climbed to 4.1 percent, and the Japanese yen is still weak, after the country's financial policy failed. The Japanese people's lack of confidence in the economy was attributable to the Liberal Democratic Party's loss in recent parliamentarian elections. The new cabinet appears to be unable to solve the problems of bad loans and weak currency. The government is now trying to revive the economy by cutting taxes and increasing public spending.

The economy and export trade of mainland China are being hurt by the government control of foreign exchange rates. The control has greatly reduced the import of many materials and semi-finished products from Taiwan for processing in mainland China.

We hope that the Japanese government will enact laws to revitalize its stock and foreign exchange markets. It will benefit Japan and other Asian countries, and help stabilize the currency of mainland China.
Q: What measures should the government take to maintain Taiwan's economic development when the impact of the Asian financial crisis is still lingering?

A: Our trade surplus has reduced sharply. Its contribution to our economic growth has dropped below zero. To make up the loss we have to stimulate the domestic demand. We don't have to cut taxes to stimulate consumption, because our domestic consumption is quite normal. What we are going to do is increasing investment. We are drafting a program to increase public investment by increasing budgets and facilitate private investment by improving the investment climate and helping investors overcome their difficulties.

We plan to add more than NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) to our government budgets in fiscal 1999 and 2000 to expand domestic demand. We hope that, by doing so, we will also be able to improve the condition of our economy and make the long-term development of our economy possible.
Q: What economic role is Taiwan going to play in Asia?

A: We have brought forth a program for strengthening our economic and trade cooperation with Southeast Asian countries. The main points of this "going south" program is to increase financial aid to Taiwan investors in these countries, establish holding companies, and provide job training opportunities to the youths in these countries. But our aids to these countries are rather little in comparison with those from Japan.
Certain business leaders of Taiwan will meet in September for the establishment of a holding company, hoping that the company will help revive the economy of Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN AFRICAN DELEGATION LEAVES FOR KINSASHA

TEXT.P: A delegation of the Southern African Development Community (SADC) left on Tuesday for Addis Ababa, Luanda and Kinshasa, in an effort to implement decisions reached by an SADC summit meeting held in Pretoria on Sunday.

The delegation, headed by South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo, includes South African Defense Minister Joe Modise, Mozambican Foreign Minister Leonardo Simao, Tanzanian Foreign Minister Jakaya Kikwete, and Zambian Foreign Minister Keli Walubita.
The delegation will travel to Addis Ababa on the first leg of the mission, where it will hold discussions with the secretary-general of the Organization of African Unity (OAU), Salim Ahmed Salim.
Salim will then join the delegation on the Luanda and Kinshasa legs, where they plan to meet with President Jose Eduardo dos Santos and President Laurent Kabila.

Nzo said the delegation will "seek to implement the decisions of the SADC summit, and in particular to ensure that the belligerents (in the Democratic Republic of Congo) respect the call for an immediate cease-fire."

DOC.HEADLINE: AFGHAN TERRORISTS THREATEN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: An Afghan terrorist group with strong links to the Saudi Arabian millionaire terrorist Osama bin Laden, has warned Australia of revenge attacks if Canberra continues to support the US fight against terrorism.

The warning was issued by Harkat ul Mujahedeen, whose training camps were hit by US missiles last week. It singled out Australia, the United Kingdom and Germany for reprisals if these countries continued to cooperate with the United States.

"We have given this ultimatum to Australia because they have supported American missile strikes against innocent Muslims in Afghanistan and Sudan," Harkat central secretary Allah Wasaya Qasim told the Australian newspaper on Monday from his headquarters in Rawalpindi.
"But if they withdraw their support there will be no threat against their interests," he added.
The threats follow a statement attributed to bin Laden, who is wanted for the recent bombings in Africa, in which he declared "the war has just started."
Harkat was placed on a US list of known terrorist organizations which ran two of the six training camps allegedly financed by bin Laden and targeted in Thursday's missile strike by the United States.
The United States also bombed a chemical plant in Sudan that allegedly produced an agent used in the deadly nerve gas VX, and in which bin Laden was an investor.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR PLUNGES WHILE BOURSE RISES

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar plunged to a 12 year low on Tuesday as more investors unloaded currency, but the local stock market regained considerable ground following a plunge on Monday, market analysts said on Tuesday.
The Australian dollar closed at 57.41 US cents on Tuesday, compared to Monday's close of 58 US cents.

The All Ordinaries Index closed 25.9 points higher on Tuesday at 2627.7 against Monday's close of 2601.8. The index plunged 33.2 points on Monday from last Friday's close due to falls on Wall Street and other major markets.

Analysts said the plunge on Monday was due to negative forces in both Japan and Russia. Tuesday's plunge was due to the same reasons, coupled with worrying news on the economic recession in Eastern Europe and Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S ENUNCIATION OF `THREE NOES' UNACCEPTABLE TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of 19 Taiwan legislators met with leaders of Japan's political parties on Tuesday to express concern about mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's upcoming visit to Japan.

During a meeting with the Taiwan lawmakers, Yoshiro Mori, secretary-general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, said he fully understood their concern that the visit may result in an outcome harmful to Taiwan's interests, and promised to pass the concern on to the Japanese government.

Wang Chin-pin, vice president of the Legislative Yuan and leader of the delegation, said it would be unacceptable to Taiwan if Japan codifies the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan that US President Bill Clinton stated in Shanghai in late July.

Wang said he told Mori that Japan should not succumb to Beijing's request to exclude Taiwan from the US-Japan defense cooperation program. Japan should continue to play the key role defending peace in the Asia-Pacific region, and avoid to play into Beijing's hands to forge a strategic partner relationship with mainland China, Wang said.
Later in the day, members of the supra-party Legislative Yuan mission also met with leaders of other Japanese political parties for talks of mutual concern.

They met with Toshiko Hamayotsu, chief of the opposition Komei Party, Takenori Kanzaki, chief of the New Party Peace, and Yukio Hatoyama, acting secretary-general of the Democratic Party, Japan's largest opposition party, as well as a dozen other members of the same parties.
The Taiwan lawmakers were also scheduled to meet members of the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, a supra-party organization in the Japanese parliament, on Tuesday evening.
Later in the evening, Sadanori Yamanaka, chairman of the pro-Taiwan body and a former Japanese international trade and industry minister, was to host a dinner in honor of the Taiwan legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA INSTRUCTED TO RESOLVE DISPUTE IN THREE DAYS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Tuesday gave TransAsia Airways an ultimatum: Resolve its latest management-pilot dispute by Friday or have its ART turboprop flight concessions withdrawn.
CAA officials issued the warning and also urged the carrier's management to communicate with their pilots over the wage dispute.
The officials stressed that no dispute can be allowed to sacrifice the interests of customers.
Earlier this month, the airline decided to slash the salaries of pilots who fly ATR turboprop aircraft by a monthly average of NT$50,000 (US$1,437) per employee.
The cuts translate as reductions to NT$120,000 (US$3,448) from NT$200,000 for pilots, while co-pilots had their pay slashed to NT$80,000 (US$2,299) from NT$120,000.
The cuts triggered a mass resignation on Monday night by the company's 67 ART pilots after negotiations with management broke down. Airline pilots are not allowed to strike under Taiwan law.

The resignations forced the carrier to cancel 90 domestic flights on Tuesday, causing chaos in the island's air traffic. Thousands of passengers were forced to change their flight plans or endure long waits at the country's airports.
TransAsia executives remained firm on the pay cuts, and said the company will simply hire foreign pilots if the local crews do not withdraw their resignations.
The flight suspensions will last at least until Friday, according to the carrier which operates 18 domestic flights each day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Ministry of Finance announced four measures on Tuesday to bolster the battered stock market.
The China Times: The Ministry of Finance unveiled a four-point package on Tuesday to stabilize the slumping stock market.
The United Daily News: The Ministry of Finance Tuesday unfolded a package of measures to prop up the local stock market in the wake of a sustained drop in stock prices over the past two days.
The Liberty Times: The Ministry of Finance Tuesday mapped out guidelines for stabilizing the plunging domestic bourse.
The Independence Morning Post: The Ministry of Finance gave four badly needed shots in the arm to the bearish stock market on Tuesday.
The Commons Daily: President Lee Teng-hui may seek reelection to let Taiwan enter a second "republic" era.
The China Post: The Ministry of Finance moves to boost stocks.
The China News: The Ministry of Finance sets out guidelines for the local stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MJIB PROBES POSSIBLE MAINLAND ROLE IN TAIWAN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau (MJIB) will thoroughly investigate whether mainland Chinese capital is entering Taiwan under the intention of effecting year-end elections, prosecutors said Wednesday.
Taiwan High Court Public Prosecutor General Lu Ren-fa said although he has heard the rumors, he has not received any concrete evidence to support the claims.

The MJIB will closely monitor related developments in this regard and the island's government will never allow any outside force to influence Taiwan's political process, he said, adding that authorities will severely punish anyone found guilty of such involvement.

Lu's remarks came after local newspapers reported that mainland China is attempting to influence Taiwan's elections for legislators islandwide as well as city councilors and mayors in Taipei and Kaohsiung through political contributions.
Results of the December elections will have a profound impact on Taiwan's overall political climate and the political alignment in the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF MOVES TO PROP UP STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's weighted price index dropped 94 points to close at 6,814 Wednesday despite a government announcement Tuesday of a four-point stimulus package aimed at propping up the plunging stock market.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF) announced that beginning on Wednesday, four stimulus measures will be taken to help invigorate the sagging Taiwan stock market which has shed more than 5 percent in three days.

Share prices tumbled 3.5 percent on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Monday and 0.7 percent Tuesday, sending the market barometer below the psychologically important 7,000-point barrier. This is having a worrying impact on domestic consumption and economic growth, the ministry said.

Finance Minister Paul Chiu announced in a news conference late Tuesday that the percentage of guaranteed money required of short-sellers -- those who sell "borrowed" stocks in the hope of buying them back at cheaper prices -- will be raised from the current 70 percent to 90 percent of the stocks' initial prices.

Secondly, the Securities and Futures Commission will require the board of directors and supervisors of listed and over-the-counter companies to present affidavits proving that their ownership stakes are not lower than the minimum government-stipulated levels.

Thirdly, the government will discuss with local securities brokers and stock dealers why quite a few initial public offerings and rights offerings this year have fallen below their original offering prices, and jointly work out countermeasures.

In addition, Chiu said, the MOF will seek to determine why domestic mutual funds have been selling stocks lately, particularly Tuesday. Qualified foreign institutional investors and domestic stock dealers, however, were not buyers Tuesday.

Hu Ting-wu, president of the China Development Corporation, welcomed the four stimulus measures, describing them as a move demonstrating the government's sincerity in helping invigorate the stock market.

Hu, however, said the long-term stability of Taiwan's stock market will hinge on the development of the international financial markets, particularly the US markets, and fundamentally financial structures of the domestic listed companies rather than stimulus packages.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS TO ASIA FALL AFTER CRISIS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: US agricultural exports to Taiwan and the rest of Asia fell by an average 30 percent in the first half of this year largely as a result of the region's financial turmoil.

The latest US Agricultural Department statistics showed that US$860 million worth of US agricultural products were shipped to Taiwan in the first half of 1998, a 34.7 percent decrease from the previous level of US$1.32 billion registered in the same period of 1997.

Taiwan was America's fifth-largest agricultural export market, lagging behind Japan, Canada, Mexico, and South Korea, but ahead of the Netherlands, Hong Kong, mainland China, Germany, and Britain, according to the same tallies. Shipments all declined to the top 10 countries with the exception of Mexico and Britain.

Exports to mainland China dropped by 6.5 percent in value to US$720 million in the January-June period, while shipments to Hong Kong fell by 5.8 percent to US$746 million from last year. Export value to Japan and South Korea dropped by 12.6 percent and 29.6 percent respectively in the first half of the year.

Meanwhile, export value to member states of the Association for Southeast Asian Nations plunged by an average 37.4 percent during the same six-month period, ranging from a 56.4 percent slide to Indonesia and a 23.2 percent fall to Thailand.

According to the US Agricultural Department, America exported US$26.4 billion worth of agricultural products in the first half of 1998, down 5.9 percent, or US$1.65 billion from last year. It attributed the fall mainly to the dulling demand from Asian markets as a result of the financial crisis which broke out about a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL ON UNOFFICIAL VISIT IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: CKS International Airport, Taoyuan, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang departed Taipei for Japan on Wednesday for a five-day unofficial visit.

Invited by the Small Groups of Japan to take part in the Sixth Asian Gathering, Chang is expected to meet with prominent figures in Japan's ruling and opposition parties, youth and opinion leaders, as well as political and business leaders from other Asian countries, for discussions on a wide variety of issues.

The Asian Gathering, a Japanese version of the annual Prayer Breakfast held in the United States, has been held annually since 1993. It is aimed at accelerating exchanges among lawmakers, political, business, and opinion leaders, to pool opinions on regional, national, and domestic issues.

Chang said at the airport that he does not exclude the possibility of meeting Japanese Cabinet members during his stay, although he insisted that no such meetings have been included in his planned itinerary.

During the visit, significant at a time prior to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's upcoming visit to Japan, Chang is expected to exchange views with Japanese lawmakers from the ruling and opposition parties on regional and international affairs, as well as cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
He is also expected to meet with members of the supra-party Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, 13 of whom are members of the Japanese Cabinet. Five of the 13 dietmen maintain good relations with Taiwan.
