DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST SATELLITE LAUNCHED INTO ORBIT

TEXT.P: A satellite owned by Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecom was successfully launched into orbit Tuesday in French Guiana by the European company Arianespace.
Liftoff of the US$240 million ST-1 satellite took place at 8:07 p.m. (7:07 a.m. Taiwan time) in Kourou on an Ariane-44P launcher.
The satellite, Taiwan's first, was made by France's Matra Marconi Space and marked Ariane's 37th consecutive successful launch.

"The ST-1 satellite was placed in orbit under optimum conditions and deadlines. Taiwan and Singapore now have first-hand experience of the very best in space transportation service," Arianespace Chairman and CEO Jean-Marie Luton said after the launch.

The satellite weighed 3.255 tonnes at liftoff, it is equipped with 15 Ku-band and 14 C-band transponders and will cover an area extending from the Middle East to the Far East, from its orbital position over the Indian Ocean at 88 degrees east.
Developing 6.5 kW of power, the ST-1 will be one of the most powerful telecom satellites in orbit over Asia, Arianespace said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STOCK, FOREIGN EXCHANGE MARKETS REMAIN VOLATILE

TEXT.P: The Australian stock and foreign exchange markets remained under strong pressure Wednesday morning as share prices and the dollar continued their decline.

Market analysts said the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) was checking prices in the London market Tuesday night as the slide of the Australian stock and foreign exchange markets fueled speculation that the bank could intervene any time.
In June, the RBA spent A$2.63 billion (US$1.64 billion) to support the Australian dollar from falling at a drastic pace.
The Australian dollar was trading at 57.55 US cents in morning trade, marginally higher than the 57.41 US-cent close on Tuesday.
The All Ordinaries Index fell 18.8 points on the morning trade from Tuesday's close to 2,627.7 following a rise of 25.9 points.
Analysts said as the markets were becoming more volatile, many investors were being more cautious. The markets are more speculative than in the past, leaving investors easily burned.

A global economic crisis is at the center of concern as Russia is seen collapsing on top of Asia and Latin American economies are also in trouble. Russia's woes could trigger a big rush in export commodities which would hit commodity prices internationally, said James Shugg of the London-based branch of Australia's Westpac Banking Group.
"People are also talking about an election. That is weighing on the Australian dollar," he said.

Analysts said the Australian stock market came under pressure after bad news from Latin America and Russia. These countries will likely flood the international market with cheap commodities which would also drive down prices for Australian exports, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLOWER PRICES SOAR AS CHINESE VALENTINE'S DAY APPROACHES

TEXT.P: As Chinese Valentine's Day nears, domestic flower prices are soaring, with roses registering the steepest price hikes, market sources reported on Wednesday.
Chinese Valentine's Day, also known as Chi Hsi festival in Taiwan, is celebrated on the seventh day of the seventh moon on the lunar calendar and falls on Friday this year.
Over the years, marketing and promotional efforts by retailers have made the exchanging of gifts an increasingly common practice among young couples.

Flowers are perhaps the most popular gift item. Depending on the type of flower and the color, flowers can represent different messages. Red roses symbolize true love, and yellow roses represent friendship. Lilies mean gaiety and red tulips are a declaration of love.
Statistics compiled by the Taipei Flower Marketing Co. show that floral prices in metropolitan Taipei have picked up by 50 percent to 100 percent in recent days.

A company spokesman said wholesale prices for locally grown red and pink roses have surged to between NT$300 (US$8.62) and NT$500 (US$14.37) for 20 stems in the past week, up more than 60 percent from a month ago.
Prices for imported red and pink roses are between NT$550 and NT$600 per 20-stem bouquet on the wholesale market, the spokesman added.
Nevertheless, the spokesman said, the hikes in flower prices this year are generally lower than last year's because of a domestic economic slowdown.

In the past few years, exotic purple roses were the most popular Chinese Valentine's Day flower. A single stem of an imported purple rose could fetch up to NT$500 in retail markets as the festival neared.
However, the spokesman said, the market situation has changed this year, with a new species of green rose emerging as the best-selling flower.

"With unique white-green color shades, green roses have become an instant hit since it was introduced to the local floral market for the first time earlier this year," the spokesman said, adding that wholesale price for a 20-stem bouquet of green roses now stands at NT$1,500.

Prices for other flowers have also risen with the advent of Chi Hsi, the spokesman said. Prices for a 20-stem bouquet of locally grown lilies jumped to NT$400 or NT$500 recently from about NT$250 a month ago.
The Chi Hsi festival is based on the romantic legend of two star-crossed lovers -- the Cowboy (Altair in Western astronomy) and the Weaving Maid (Vega).
According to Chinese folklore, the two became engaged in a passionate love affair and neglected their duties, upsetting the Jade Emperor, the ruler of the Heaven and equivalent to the Almighty God.
As punishment, the Jade Emperor permanently separated the couple by placing a river between them. The two, however, were allowed to reunite on Chi Hsi.
On this particular day, the two would cross a bridge formed by sympathetic magpies and share their experiences and feelings. Chi Hsi is said to have been observed as Lover's Day since ancient time.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND'S FLOOD TOLL SAID TO BE BIGGEST COVER UP SINCE CHERNOBYL

TEXT.P: The death toll in mainland China's worst flooding in 44 years may be one of the biggest cover ups since the Chernobyl nuclear accident in 1986, Western experts said.
Beijing authorities said the death toll will not exceed 4,200 despite the widespread devastation to homes and land.

More than a quarter of mainland China's population has been effected by floods that have ravaged river basins in the north and south for up to three months. Flood control efforts have ensured that casualties are kept to a minimum, the head of the China Flood Control and Drought Relief Headquarters said.

"There have been some casualties, but given that China has a population of 1.2 billion and the sheer scale of the floods, the figure is very, very small," Zhou Wenzhi told a news conference on Tuesday. He said accurate figures on the dead toll and the cost of flood damage were extremely difficult to calculate.

Tens of millions of people are now said to be living on the tops of dikes in rapidly deteriorating conditions. Chinese officials said efforts are now being concentrated on ensuring that there is no outbreak of disease among the homeless. The most serious health hazards were the common cold, conjunctivitis, diarrhea and dermatitis from prolonged exposure to water.

The death toll will be much higher than the official figure, a journalist was quoted by ABC's correspondent Jane Hutchisen as saying. J. Becker said mainland Chinese government's attempt to play down the extent of the damage was the biggest cover up since the Chernobyl nuclear plant in the former Soviet Union leaked radiation in 1986.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ATTENDS CANADIAN CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Republic of China was in Edmonton, Alberta Monday to attend the 15th Biennial World Conference of the International Association for Volunteer Effort (IAVE).
Delegation leader and Minister of the ROC's National Youth Commission Lee Jih-chu delivered the conference's first address which included a message from ROC President Lee Teng-hui.
The president said governments may be committed to tackling crime, drug abuse, pollution and other social problems but they are constrained by limited resources.

"This is one area that volunteer organizations and individuals can play an essential role by helping to secure a better life for the inhabitants of this world," Minister Lee told the 3,000 delegates from 87 countries including the People's Republic of China.

She said although the ROC began to promote volunteer services much later than many Western nations, the movement has gathered momentum in recent years with the support of top government leaders such as the president, vice president and premier. Now, there are over 22,000 non-profit, non-government organizations are giving volunteer service in Taiwan, she added.
On average, about one-fourth of Taiwan's population has been involved in volunteer service, and "this proportion is still increasing," the minister added.
The 18-member ROC delegation, which includes 14 civilian groups leaders, is "here to learn and to share the experiences in rendering volunteer service," she said.

Lee also took the opportunity to promote Taipei's bid to host a future world or Asia-Pacific IAVE conference. Hong Kong and India have also shown an interest in hosting the next regional meeting. A decision is expected in November.

Before arriving in Canada on Aug. 22, the ROC delegation visited several prominent volunteer groups in Washington, D.C., including The Points of Light Foundation, America's Promise -- The Alliance of Youth and the Peace Corps.
The ROC delegation is scheduled to leave Canada on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.006 against the greenback in Taipei Wednesday, closing at 34.802.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.794, and had a low of 34.825.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$219 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB SEEKING CAPITAL FROM AUSTRALIA TO HELP AILING ASIAN NATIONS

TEXT.P: The Manila-based Asian Development Bank (ADB) is attempting to raise US$625 million in capital from Australian investors to help financially-strapped countries in the region.

Peter Balon, assistant treasurer of the ADB, recently met fund managers in Sydney and Melbourne to discuss issuing up to A$1 billion (US$625 million) in bonds, the proceeds of which would help Indonesia, South Korea and other Asian countries in need of assistance.
Balon told the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday that Australian representative at the ADB Eric Thorn made the suggestion that Australia would be interested in supporting the funding.
Canberra expressed support for the effort as it would boost Australia's aspirations in becoming a regional financial center and reconfirm the country's commitment to Asia.
The ADB needs additional funds to support its involvement in rescue packages organized by the International Monetary Fund for Indonesia, Thailand and South Korea.
The ADB ended last year with a funding outcome of almost US$6 billion compared with its target of only US$2.6 billion, which was proposed before the Asian crisis began.

"As a result of the fund requirements for this year expanding, we wanted to expand on our investor universe -- in particular, working with markets that we hadn't tapped in the past," Balon told the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA, RUSSIA TROUBLES BODE ILL FOR ALL

TEXT.P: The crisis situation in Russia and the looming crisis in mainland China have major implications for the rest of the world, the Toronto Star said Tuesday.

The major risk from Russia is global recession and deflation while the risk from mainland China is devaluation, the daily's economic editor David Crane wrote. Floundering economies in the world now need to get back onto the growth path again, he added.

Crane said the situation in Russia is especially alarming. Boris Yeltsin's decision to bring back former Premier Viktor Chernomyrdin represents a desperate bid by Yeltsin to cling to power as his authority crumbles.

There are also concerns that the new government will hold back on economic reforms, delay planned steps to force Russian industry and industrialists to pay the taxes they owe, and flounder with accelerating inflation and a recession, he warned.

Meanwhile, mainland China's ambitious plans to restructure money-losing state enterprises and a technically insolvent banking system are in serious doubt, he said. Mainland China is not generating the economic growth it needs to absorb the millions of workers who will lose their jobs through restructuring.

At the same time, Beijing's hopes of raising capital to finance restructuring, through the listing of many more Chinese companies on the Hong Kong stock exchange, have also been dashed by the sharp fall in the Hong Kong exchange and its lack of interest in new issues, Crane pointed out.

While Beijing will not likely devalue its currency this year unless the situation gets much worse, there are real fears it could do so next year to strengthen its economy and create more jobs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH DROP AGAIN

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 94 points to close at 6,814.33.

Encouraged by a rebound on the New York Stock Exchange, and four favorable measures announced by the Ministry of Finance, the bourse opened at 6,996.32 points, up 87.99 from Tuesday's close, and experienced a high of 7,017.4. However, heavy selling pressure brought share prices down again in the second half of trading.

A total of 1.66 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.98 billion, decreasing from the previous trading session which saw 1.71 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$79.28 billion.

All eight major categories posted losses, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 2.1 percent; followed by construction shares at 2 percent; pulp and paper issues at 1.9 percent; both bank and insurance stocks and plastics and chemical shares at 1.5 percent; cement stocks at 0.4 percent; foodstuff shares at 0.3 percent; and textile issues at 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures also slid.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September dropped 159 points to close at 6,790, with 839 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for October moved down 164 points to finish at 6,800, while those for December decreased 121 points to 6,880, and those for March plunged 260 points to 6,950. Contract transactions for those three futures were 33, 25 and 33, respectively.
No transactions were registered for June.

The reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 6,949 for September; 6,964 for October; 7,001 for December; 7,210 for March; and 7,318 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: `THREE LINKS' ACTIVISTS INDICTED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's public prosecutors-general stressed on Wednesday that any infringements of the laws governing the ban on direct links between Taiwan and mainland China will be punished.

Lu Ren-fa made the statement in response to Tuesday's indictment of three lawmakers, who sailed from Taiwan directly to the mainland Chinese port of Xiamen in Fujian Province without official permission last Tuesday.

National Assembly Deputy Tsao Yuan-chang, Taipei County Councilor Kin Chien-shou and Jungho City township councilor Huang Hsi-lin, as well as the skipper of the "Hawaii No.3" and his wife, two reporters, and four activists advocating Taiwan sovereignty of the Tiaoyutais, a disputed island group in East China Sea, were on Tuesday indicted for violating the National Security Law and the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area.

According to the indictment handed down by the Kinmen District Prosecutor's Office, all 11, along with seven mainland Chinese crewmen, allegedly planned to make a direct cross-strait voyage on Aug. 18.

The group, headed jointly by Tsao and Kin, had informed the media in advance of their impending arrival from Xiamen on Taiwan-controlled Kinmen Island on Aug. 20, and told waiting reporters of their "mini three links" idea, the indictment said.

The "mini three links" calls for direct shipping, trade and postal links between Kinmen and mainland China. Although the island group is controlled by the ROC, it lies only two kilometers from the mainland coast at its nearest point.
Lu cited current laws which state that ships, aircraft, and other transportation devices of the Republic of China should not navigate to mainland China without official permission.
Offenders risk a maximum three-year jail term, or fines of up to NT$15 million (US$431,000), Lu warned.

He especially rebuked the accused who serve in public positions for allegedly setting themselves up as pioneers to defy the nation's laws, stressing that justice will prevail and that convicted offenders will be severely punished.

However, Tsao defended the group's actions, saying they had never planned to sail to the mainland, but were bound for the Tiaoyutais. The ship was only forced to head toward Xiamen because of heavy fog, Tsao said, adding that their advocacy of "mini direct links" with mainland China was made on the spur of the moment.

Kin, the skipper, and the "Defend the Tiaoyutais" activists claimed that they had planned to sail to the disputed Japanese islands to declare Taiwan sovereignty over them, but changed course after being informed of a possible Japanese blockade.
Their vessel subsequently suffered engine failure, prompting them to seek assistance in Xiamen, Kin said.

The two accused journalists concurred with this defense, saying they were dispatched to report on the group's Tiaoyutais activity. They claimed to be unaware of any plans to make the "taboo-breaking" voyage, according to the Kinmen Prosecutor's Office.
Kin had declared upon arrival on Kinmen that the voyage was aimed at promoting the "mini three links" as a first step toward "three direct links" between Taiwan and the mainland.

He explained that similar sailings have been going on unofficially for years, saying it is no secret that Taiwan fishing vessels often make direct crossings to mainland territory in order to save costs.
Taiwan has prohibited direct shipping, commerce and communication with mainland China for nearly 50 years since the two sides split following the civil war.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RED CROSS TO DONATE GOODS TO M'LAND FLOOD VICTIMS

TEXT.P: The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China said on Wednesday it will donate NT$20 million (US$574,713) worth of goods to help relieve flood victims in mainland China.

Chang Sung-mao, secretary-general of the Red Cross Society, said the society has received NT$6 million in cash donations from local residents as of the end of July for helping flood victims along the Yangtze River.

"We'll use the money to purchase rice, pharmaceuticals, quilts and other daily necessities and medical supplies to help mainland flood victims," Chang said, adding that the first shipment of relief goods is scheduled to arrive in mainland China in early September.
Chang said the ROC Red Cross Society will ask its mainland counterpart to help dispatch relief products to various flood-stricken provinces.
Chang said the society will continue to woo local trade and industry associations to donate money or goods to help mainland flood victims on humanitarian grounds.

Heavier than usual rains have caused successive waves of flooding in many central and southeastern mainland provinces along the Yangtze River as well as northeastern provinces along the Songhua and Nenjiang rivers this summer that have killed more than 4,000 people and left millions homeless. Mainland China's state media said recently that damage from the floods will surpass US$24 billion.

The floods, which have affected 240 million mainland Chinese, nearly a fifth of the country's population, could shave half a percentage point off mainland China's economic growth this year, Beijing's official Xinhua News Agency reported earlier this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12 MAINLAND CHINA FISHERMEN NABBED IN `SEA QUELL' OPERATION

TEXT.P: Twelve mainland Chinese poachers were nabbed on a beach on the frontline island stronghold of Kinmen on Wednesday, in a pre-dawn action by a joint police and military task force.

The "Sea Quell" task force, formed jointly by the military, the military police, and the police, was established recently in response to increasing concern by Kinmen residents who have been complaining that mainland fishermen are raiding their offshore farms during the night to steal shellfish.
A police spokesman said the mainlanders, seven of them women, will be investigated to find out whether they had any additional motives for landing on ROC soil.
Wednesday's operation was the first carried out by the new task force.

The arrested mainlanders all claimed to come from the fishing village of Oucu, which is near the port of Xiamen in Fujian Province. They said they were brought in two boats to Kinmen, where they were supposed to collect shellfish at low tide and wait to be picked up again at high tide.

The poachers were later taken to Taiwan for further questioning. They are expected to remain at a detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants before being repatriated, Kinmen police authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCE MINISTER PUZZLED BY STOCK MARKET FALL

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Paul Chiu said on Wednesday he will ask the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) to investigate why stock prices have fallen despite a stimulus package announced on Tuesday.
Buoyed by the new package, stock prices rallied when trading began at 9 a.m. on the local bourse, but lost steam after 11:15 a.m. The bourse ended up losing 95 points, to close at 6,814.
Chiu said that the SFC will discuss the reasons for the end-of-session fall with stockbrokers.
Pointing out that among the Asian stock markets, only Japan and Hong Kong were lackluster, he urged investors to have confidence in Taiwan's sound economic fundamentals and financial structure.
The four-point stimulus package announced by Chiu on Tuesday comprised:

-- a percentage increase from 70 percent to 90 percent of initial stock prices for guarantee money required of short-sellers -- those who sell "borrowed" stocks in the hope of buying them back at cheaper prices;

-- the SFC will require the board of directors and supervisors of listed and over-the-counter companies to present affidavits proving that their ownership stakes are not lower than the minimum government-stipulated level;

-- the government will discuss with local securities brokers and stock dealers why quite a few initial public offerings and rights offerings this year have fallen below their original offering prices, and jointly work out countermeasures; and

-- the Ministry of Finance will seek to determine why domestic mutual funds have been selling stocks lately, particularly on Tuesday, despite the fact that qualified foreign institutional investors and domestic stock dealers were not buying that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER STRESSES COOPERATION WITH CENTRAL AMERICA
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday that Taipei will enhance economic cooperation with friendly Central American nations to help their economic growth.

Hu, who was visiting El Salvador to discuss cooperative ventures with five central American diplomatic partners, made the remark in an address at a seminar on how to share Taiwan's experience in economic development with its Central American allies--El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica, and Guatemala.

The nations of Central America, geographically located as a springboard into South and North America, are endowed with cheap labor, and well-suited to the development of agricultural, fishery, and tourism resources, Hu said, adding that Taipei is willing to provide whatever aid is necessary to assist their economic development.

The foreign minister said he will suggest the creation of an investment environment which can attract foreign capital, strengthen export competitiveness, and boost tourism resources to attract visitors from Taiwan.

He noted that Taipei's assistance will be based around investment in agricultural and fishery cooperation, and disclosed that Taipei has sent a total of 77 agriculture, fishery, and handicraft technicians, to provide assistance in Central America.

He also revealed that the ROC government will set a 12-year budget for the formation of a foundation for economic cooperation between the ROC and the nations of Central America, and will hold seminars to introduce Central American markets to Taiwan.

In order to assist the development of the small- and medium-sized enterprises in the region, Hu pointed out that Taipei has provided consultation services, and that volunteer workers have also been sent to Costa Rica, Honduras, and El Salvador, while discussions are under way to send volunteers to Nicaragua and Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE OF TAIWAN UNWILLING TO UNITE WITH MAINLAND CHINA: DPP

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said on Wednesday that Taiwan should make clear to mainland China when negotiators from both sides meet this fall that the people here do not want reunification.

Lin proposed that Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu make a statement in this vein to his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), when they meet in Beijing later this year.

Responding to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's recent remarks that "the question of unification with Taiwan should not remain unsettled for too long," Lin stressed that unification will take place only when the majority of Taiwan's people agree to the idea. Beijing's leaders should therefore have second thoughts about their unification policy, he added.

According to the chairman of the pro-independence opposition party, maintaining the status quo means that Taiwan will remain separate from Beijing's rule, and as far as the DPP is concerned, this means continuing moving toward its goal of Taiwan independence.

Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-yen told reporters that Beijing's top priority at the moment is fighting the flooding which has devastated a large part of mainland China's northeastern and northern regions. "Imminent unification with mainland China is impractical," Chiu said, "because pressure for Taiwan to unite with the mainland is coming at the moment from the international community rather than from Beijing. A tough line from Beijing will not bring any new pressure to bear on Taiwan," he noted.

In the face of the upcoming second Koo-Wang meeting, Chiu said that Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, should relay the will of the Taiwan people to Wang, and tell the mainland bluntly that Taiwan is unwilling to unite with the mainland.

The Chinese communists should discuss the issue sincerely and openly with Taiwan if Beijing wishes to achieve its goal of unification, he pointed out, adding that schemes to undermine Taiwan will lead nowhere. "Resort to use of force will be an even worse method of obtaining such a goal," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER, CEPD CHIEF HEAD FOR GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu, and P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), were scheduled to leave El Salvador for Guatemala on Wednesday.
Hu and Chiang, traveling at the head of a delegation of Taiwan economic and foreign affairs officials, arrived in El Salvador on Monday and met with Salvadoran President Armando Calderon Sol.
On Tuesday, Chiang and Hu co-presided over a seminar which addressed Taiwan's sharing of its economic development experience with Central American nations.

Participants in the seminar, including the foreign and economic ministers of five Central American nations -- El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica, and Guatemala -- agreed to adopt effective measures to increase bilateral cooperation in economics, trade, investment, and tourism.
During his stay in Guatemala, Hu will preside over a meeting of ROC diplomats stationed in the Latin American and Caribbean regions to study ways of boosting the ROC's ties with the region.

He will also call on Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu, and Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein. The two foreign ministers will decorate one another with medals in recognition of their contributions to increased friendly bilateral relations.
Meanwhile, Chiang will meet with Guatemalan Minister of Energy and Mines Leonel Lopez Rodas to discuss the possibility of energy cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RETURNING TOURISTS REQUIRED TO SUBMIT HEALTH DECLARATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) on Wednesday reminded local travelers returning from Southeast Asia that they must submit a health declaration upon re-entry to facilitate control of the spread of contagious diseases.

Wu Tsung-neng, director of the National Quarantine Service under the DOH, said the new regulation requires all inbound passengers aboard direct flights from Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam, Cambodia, and Myanmar, to fill out the health declaration forms.

"We have adopted the measure amid reports that an epidemic of dengue fever is raging in Southeast Asia," Wu said, adding that 59 cases of foreign-originating dengue fever infections have been reported in Taiwan so far this summer.
Wu said all 59 cases originated in Southeast Asia, and that many of them were tracked and confirmed with information provided in the passenger health declarations.
In one instance, health authorities earlier this month managed to track three members of a single Kaohsiung family through information provided in their health declarations.

"The family of three returned from Thailand on Aug. 11. They reported in their health declarations that they had developed symptoms of vomiting, fever and skin rashes before boarding their return flight," Wu said. "Follow-up physical checkups confirmed that all three had been infected with dengue fever."

He added that the new regulation had also allowed the DOH's National Institute of Preventive Medicine to detect a case of a Taipei resident who became infected with diarrhea during a trip to Thailand.
Wu also cautioned that epidemics of contagious gastroenterological diseases such as cholera and diarrhea are likely to break out in flood-stricken areas of mainland China.
He encouraged local people returning from trips there who develop symptoms to report their condition to health authorities, in order to help prevent the spread of any communicable diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN AND OVERSEAS CHINESE INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN DECREASES

TEXT.P: A total of US$1.9 billion worth of investments in Taiwan by foreigners and overseas Chinese was approved by the Ministry of Economic Affairs during the first seven months of this year, according to statistics released Wednesday.
That figure represents a drop of US$690 million, or 26.85 percent, from the corresponding period one year earlier, although the number of approved investments increased by 165.
Economics officials attribute the decline to two large-scale projects approved in June 1997, both of which significantly boosted that year's final foreign investment tally.

The manufacturing of electronics, including information technology products, and electrical appliances remained the darling of foreign investors, followed by the finance and banking industries, import/export operations, the service sector, and the wholesale and retail sectors.
Investments in these five categories accounted for 74.82 percent of the total value of approved investments.

Meanwhile, Taiwan businessmen invested US$1.98 billion in overseas investment projects during the first seven months of this year. The total is 19.33 percent higher than that of the same period last year.

Holding companies; the finance and insurance industries; electronics and electrical appliance manufacturing; the manufacturing of wooden, bamboo and rattan wares, import/export operations; and the manufacturing of basic metal products accounted for 83.89 percent of Taiwan's overseas investments.
Most foreign investment from Taiwan went to the Virgin Islands, followed by, in order, the United States, Vietnam, Singapore and Thailand.
With the exception of Thailand and Vietnam, Taiwanese businessmen are investing less in Southeast Asia because of the region's financial turmoil.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, CENTRAL AMERICAN NATIONS TO SET UP STRATEGIC ALLIANCE
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, Aug. 25 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and several Central American nations agreed on Tuesday to establish a strategic alliance to promote trade, investment and tourism, as well as technology transfers and cooperative projects.

The agreement was reached at a seminar focusing on how Taiwan can share its economic development experience with Central American nations. The seminar, which took place in San Salvador, was presided over by ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang.

Foreign ministers and economics ministers from El Salvador, Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras, and Nicaragua attended the historic seminar. Other participants included officials from the Dominican Republic and Belize.
At the seminar the following conclusions were reached:

--The Republic of China will invest in and cooperatively develop agricultural and fishery sectors within those countries named in the alliance and promote the development of trade, human resources, tourism and basic infrastructures.

In addition to establishing the strategic alliance, seminar participants agreed to sign a free trade agreement; to set aside economic development funds; to sign investment promotion and protection agreements and a double taxation avoidance pact; to sign fishery and manpower cooperation agreements; to develop processing zones; and to enhance the development of small and medium-sized enterprises in the Central American nations.

During the seminar it was also suggested that an export center for Central American nations be established to coordinate with the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) to promote Central American exports to the Republic of China, and that ROC and Central American economics ministers meet annually to enhance trade relations.
It was further suggested that such meetings be preceded by technical committee meetings presided over by vice ministers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN SORGHUM LIQUOR EYEING INTERNATIONAL MARKET

TEXT.P: Kinmen County Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai said on Wednesday that he is looking for overseas agents to promote Kinmen Kaoliang (sorghum) liquor worldwide.
Chen, who is also chairman of Kinmen Distillery Co., noted that the sale of Kinmen Kaoliang now accounts for 40 percent of the county's annual revenue.
He said that the distillery will award agent rights to such regions as mainland China, Northeast Asia, Southeast Asia, Europe, and North and South America.
Taiwan's President Group was awarded the right to serve as Kinmen Kaoliang's domestic agent for a period of two years, starting this month.

The Kinmen County-owned distillery currently produces 10 million kilograms of sorghum liquor each year. In anticipation of Kinmen Kaoliang making inroads into liquor markets throughout the world, Chen is seeking partners to produce sorghum liquor especially for export.
The company's partners, Chen said, will handle the financing and marketing aspects of the production operations, while the Kinmen Distillery will provide its brand name, factory and expertise.

Just as tobacco and wine producers have had to sell their products worldwide to achieve sustained profits, Kinmen Distillery must sell its product worldwide to bring more money into the county's coffers, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BODIES OF TAIWANESE TOURISTS IN MAINLAND TO BE CREMATED

TEXT.P: The families of six Taiwanese tourists killed in an car accident while traveling in mainland China's northwestern province of Gansu have agreed to allow the bodies of the deceased to be cremated on Friday, sources from the Taipei Travel Agents Association said on Wednesday.

The cremation will be held at a public funeral parlor in Jiayuguan following a traditional Buddhist ritual on Friday, seven days after their death. Families of the victims, carrying the ashes of their beloved, will fly from Jiayuguan to Lanzhou, Gansu's capital, on Saturday and then fly back to Taiwan via Hong Kong. They are expected to arrive back in Taipei on Sunday.

The accident occurred on Saturday when the van that was carrying a group of 14 Taiwanese tourists collided with a truck on a highway near Wingchuan, some 50 kilometers from Jiayuguan. The collision killed six Taiwanese tourists -- five men and one woman -- as well as the driver of the van. Eight tourists were injured, one -- Wu Mei-fang -- critically.

All the injured except Wu have been discharged from the hospital and are on their way to Taiwan. Following their arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Wednesday night, they will be sent to Taipei Veterans General Hospital to receive further treatment.

Wu remains in the intensive-care unit in a hospital in Jiouquan. With six broken ribs, she has developed pulmonary emphysema and other complications. Wu's family, which is at her sides, has decided to send for doctors from Taiwan for consultations.

The tour group members, most of whom live in Taipei City and are in their 60s or 70s, were participating in the "Silk Road" tour of mainland China. They left Taipei on Aug. 17 and were scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 31.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM CELEBRATES SATELLITE LAUNCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first telecommunications satellite was launched into orbit on Wednesday, prompting Chunghwa Telecom President Lu Hsue-chin to break out the champagne to celebrate a new era in Taiwan's telecommunications development.

At a broadcast center stationed at a Chunghwa Telecom building in Taipei, Lu and James Youdale, vice chairman of France's Arianespace, the company responsible for carrying the ST-1 satellite into space, watched the launch from a television screen.

Chunghwa Telecom said the first trial of the new satellite will take place in two months. If all goes well, the satellite will be used to provide advanced telecommunications services and to deliver improved communications between Taiwan and its offshore islands and between Taiwan and the rest of the world, company executives said.
Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecom jointly spent a total of US$240 million to build the ST-1 in 1995, with each party enjoying a 50 percent stake in the joint-venture.

Equipped with 15 Ku-band and 14 C-band transponders, the ST-1, designed and build by Matra Marconi Space, covers an area extending from the Middle East to the Far East from its orbital position 36,000 kilometers above the Earth.
Besides the construction of the satellite, the investment project also entailed the construction of two ground control centers, one each installed at Chutzihu in suburban Taipei and in Singapore.
Chunghwa Telecom has also set up facilities in Panchao, Taichung, Kaohsiung and Fengshan to receive signals from the satellite, according to the company.
The ST-1 was carried into orbit by an Ariane 44P from Kourou, French Guiana, at 7:07 a.m. Wednesday local time. It is regarded as one of the most powerful telecom satellites orbiting over Asia.
Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Chen Yiao told CNA in Guiana that with the successful launch, his firm will consider further strengthening cooperation with Singapore Telecom through an exchange of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMICS MINISTER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT ECONOMY (PART I)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said that Taiwan's economy is very likely to begin to recover by the end of next year, and that it is the proper time to stimulate domestic demand and increase private investment now in Taiwan.

In a recent interview with the CNA, Wang said he is optimistic about Taiwan's economy because its economic fundamentals are good. He predicted that private investment in Taiwan will grow 16 percent this year, as compared to the 15.6 percent growth registered in 1997.
The following is the transcript of the interview:

Q: Taiwan is doing pretty well amid the current Asian financial crisis. Why is Taiwan better able to weather the financial storm than most other countries in Asia? How are we going to maintain our economic development?
A: Let us start from an analysis of our own qualities and the outside environment.

Japan, South Korea, and Southeast Asian countries are in deep financial crisis, mainly because their banking systems are suffering from huge amounts of bad loans. Speculative land investments made by Japanese enterprises in Japan and Southeast Asian countries have further aggravated the situation.

On the contrary, Taiwan's financial system is pretty healthy, and the economic fundamentals are good. Last year, our economy grew 6.8 percent, private investment increased 15.6 percent, and industrial production index rose 8 percent, while the inflation and jobless rates were as low as 0.9 percent and 2.7 percent respectively.

Currently, we have about US$80 billion in foreign exchange reserves, and our foreign debt is rather low. The foreign debts of many neighboring countries have exceeded US$150 billion, which may bring them a bad headache during a financial crisis.
In addition, our small and medium enterprises are more active and more competitive than those of many other Asian countries.

Q: You just mentioned the quality of Taiwan's small and medium enterprises, which became obvious during the Asian financial crisis. But they are now complaining about slow business and shortage in funds. How is the Ministry of Economic Affairs going to help them?

A: It is undeniable that the small and medium enterprises are facing difficulties during the economic slowdown. Most of them are in traditional business. Their ability to compete in the world market tends to go down, when labor and land are getting more and more expensive in Taiwan because of continuous economic growth. Under these circumstances, they have only two ways to go. One is to move their production lines to mainland China or Southeast Asian countries, where labor and land are cheaper. The other way is to upgrade their business to produce high value-added products.

It takes money to go either way. The government has been trying to help them get enough funds. For example, the Executive Yuan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and certain state-run enterprises have set up special funds to help qualified applicants upgrade their business or finance their research and development programs. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER OPTIMISTIC ABOUT ECONOMY (PART II)

TEXT.P: Q: The Ministry of Economic Affairs has attached great importance to private investment projects of over NT$200 million. But the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has decided to suspend its aid program for such investments. How is your ministry going to finance such investments?
A: This is a complicated issue. It involves several government agencies. I am not in a position to make a comment now.

Q: Does the Ministry of Economic Affairs have plans to tackle the problems Taiwan businesses may face, if the renminbi is devalued ? As you know, Beijing is under increasing pressure to devalue its currency, because the Japanese economy is still in recession, and the floods in central and northeast China have caused great financial losses. The devaluation of the renminbi may cause a new round of currency devaluations in Asia.

A: Taiwan is not immune to any international financial crisis. The devaluation of Asian currencies in the second half of last year has caused the devaluation of Taiwan's currency and the sharp reduction of its export trade.

The devaluation of the Japanese yen and the financial loss caused by the floods have put more and more pressure on Beijing to devaluate its currency. In addition, the adjustment of its currency value is subject to political intervention, because mainland China is not a fully free economy. Therefore, the value of the renminbi is relatively hard to predict. Taiwan businessmen have to take precautionary measures against the possible devaluation of the mainland Chinese currency.

Q: The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics of the Executive Yuan has revised down this year's economic growth to 5.3 percent, a sharp decline from last year's 6.8 percent. Export trade declined substantially in the first half of this year. Can you share with us your view on the economic recovery in Asia and Taiwan, and on how to maintain Taiwan's economic growth?
A: The Wharton Economic Forecasting Association (WEFA) of the United States has predicted that Taiwan's economy will grow 5.2 percent this year. The two estimates are pretty close.

The WEFA also forecast that the economy will grow 0.6 percent in Japan and 1.2 percent in Singapore this year, while the growth rate of Indonesia will be minus 13 percent. Almost all economies in Asia are in recession.
Taiwan's 5.3-percent growth is not bad, if compared to those of other countries in the world.

The Asian economy is unlikely to recover in the short term. The demand for Taiwan products in the Asian market has declined, defeating our trade promotion efforts. It is the proper time to depend on our domestic market for growth.

What we can do to stimulate domestic demand is to increase public construction projects and facilitate private investments. The CEPD and the Ministry of Economic Affairs are carrying out programs for this purpose. It is estimated that the total amount of private investments will increase 16 percent this year.

I am optimistic about Taiwan's economy, which is very likely to recover in late 1999 or early 2000. We should stimulate domestic demand and increase investment at a time when the economy is in deep recession. If we do so, we shall be able to meet the increasing demands of foreign markets when the economy recovers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO POSSIBILITY OF INTERIOR MINISTER'S QUITTING: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Although ROC Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen has offered to resign, the government has no intention of accepting any such resignation, Premier Vincent Siew was quoted as saying on Wednesday.
Huang, who was in charge of carrying out the government's plan to downsize the Taiwan Provincial Government, has come under fire for his plan to ax or re-appoint provincial government employees.

On Tuesday Huang offered to quit if the provincial government employees, angry over what they described as being dismissed with only 12 months of severance pay, did not accept within 10 days Huang's plan.
Siew was quoted by government spokesman Chen Chien-jen on Wednesday as lauding Huang's efforts to follow through with the restructuring plans.

Siew believes Huang has vigorously defended the provincial government employees' interests while laying off non-essential staff, said Chen. Moreover, Siew ordered Cabinet Secretary-General Chang Yu-huei to persuade Huang to stay on the job, Chen said.

Chen also called for self-discipline and calm from the group of provincial government employees who plan to hold a rally in Taipei on Thursday and to appeal the Executive Yuan for help in safeguarding their jobs.

Chen said that Siew as well as other related officials at the Executive Yuan will approach seriously the issue of reducing the size of the provincial government and will carefully defend the rights of provincial government employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA'S ILLS NOT EXPECTED TO AIL ROC

TEXT.P: The financial crisis in Russia is expected to have only a limited impact on the Republic of China because of the relatively small amount of two-way trade between the two countries, the Central Bank of China (CBC) predicted on Wednesday.

Russian President Boris Yeltsin has tried but failed to end the crisis, in which the Russian ruble suffered its worst fall in nearly four years on Tuesday, after Russia's government and central bank devalued the ruble Aug. 17.
A ranking official with the CBC's Economic Research Department pointed out that the largest impact will be felt by European countries, especially Germany, which has lent a lot of money to Russia.

If the financial crisis continues to worsen, the official said, the German mark will be the first to bear the brunt. Whether Russia's crisis will prove contagious and infect all of Europe has been the subject of much attention.

But the official still foresees limited local effects from the crisis, as two-way trade between Russia and the Republic of China is limited, while no financial institutions in either country has branch offices in the other.
In 1996, Taiwan exported US$141.20 million worth of goods to Russia while it imported US$1.63 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN RUSSIA WATCHING RUBLE'S TUMBLE

TEXT.P: With the ruble's continued slump, Taiwan businessmen in Russia have become more cautious in their operations, the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said on Wednesday.
CETRA officials noted that the ruble closed at 7.86 to the US dollar Tuesday and that over the past 10 days the ruble has fallen nearly 26 percent in value against the greenback.
Whereas 55 percent of all consumer goods on the Russian market were imported previously, the sharp depreciation of the ruble has reduced by half that percentage.
CETRA officials said that presently there are more than 20 Taiwan businesses in Russia, selling such products as computers, shoes, textiles and lamps.
To avoid losses from the sharp fluctuations of the ruble, most Taiwan businesses have adopted conservative and cautious attitudes, they said.
The officials said that they are closely watching the depreciation of ruble as it could destabilize the Deutche mark and Euro, or the single European currency. Germany is Russia's largest creditor.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT CHIEF DENIES THREE LINKS ARE STEPPING STONES TO WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Wednesday denied news reports that it would allow direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links in return for being allowed to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) before mainland China.
"We have never heard such a thing, nor have we discussed it internally," said Lin Yi-fu, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade.

Reports said that in order to "soften Beijing's stance" that it be admitted into the WTO before Taiwan, Taiwan's economics and trade authorities are considering the establishment of the three links in exchange for Taiwan being allowed into the world trade body first.
Although Beijing has eagerly sought to establish the links, Taipei has consistently rejected the proposal, citing national security concerns.

Taiwan, which applied to join the world trade regulatory body in 1990 under the name "Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen, and Matsu," has completed negotiations with all of the 26 WTO contracting bodies that sought bilateral negotiations with the island and has signed formal entry agreements with 23 of them.

Of the three WTO members with which Taiwan has yet to sign an agreement, the European Union is expected to sign a pact in September, and Hong Kong has said that it would not be the last to sign an agreement.
A final agreement with the last remaining party, Canada, seems unlikely at the moment because of its request that Taiwan opens its door to Canada's exports of pork bellies, chicken meat and offal.
Although Taipei has led Beijing in the race for WTO membership, Beijing has long demanded -- with the support of many WTO members -- that it be admitted first.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI LABORER DIES OF UNIDENTIFIED CAUSE

TEXT.P: A Thai laborer who came to Taiwan just one month ago was found dead in his dormitory in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, police said on Wednesday.
Duanguam Wasan, 27, was employed by a local construction company to help build an east-west expressway. Wasan's roommate found him dead in his bed at around 5:30 a.m. Wednesday.
Police said that Wasan led a simple life since coming to Taiwan in mid July. No wounds were found on Wasan's body, and they have initially ruled out the possibility of murder, police said.
Police have contacted his family so that they could come to Taiwan soon.
Local health officials are now looking into Wasan's death to determine whether he was killed by a virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEGOTIATIONS BETWEEN TRANSASIA AIRWAYS AND PILOTS YIELD NO FRUIT

TEXT.P: The latest round of negotiations between TransAsia Airways and representatives of the local air carrier's 67 pilots who resigned earlier this week ended Wednesday night without yielding any results, one of the participants said.
Lee Chung-chien, chairman of the Pilots Association of the Republic of China, said that both sides have reached a consensus in the talks, but he refused to disclose the nature of the consensus.
Earlier in the day, TransAsia reiterated its stance that the Friday deadline for the 67 pilots who fly ATR turboprop planes to back down and report for work will not be extended.

Carrier spokesman Ho Chih-hwai, however, admitted for the first time that both the airline's management and the 67 pilots who resigned on Monday in protest against substantial pay cuts should be blamed for the incident.

Defending the pay cuts, which amount to a monthly average of NT$50,000 (US$1,437) per pilot, Ho said that what the airline has done is to "adjust the pay structure" of the pilots, not slash their pay.

Ho said that if the 67 pilots are willing to return to their posts by Friday, their behavior during the past several days would be forgiven. But two of the pilots -- Chen Pei-Chung and Wang Dao-lung, who have represented the disgruntled pilots on many occasions -- were suspended by the airline on Tuesday on the grounds that what they have said and done have damaged TransAsia's image. Ho said that if Chen and Wang wish to return to the airline, they must first undergo an investigation.

The resignation of 67 out of the carrier's 72 ATR pilots have forced the airline to leave almost all 13 of its ATR turboprop planes in their hangars, which means a total of 90 flights have been canceled per day since Tuesday.

TransAsia Airways, founded in 1951, currently has 13 ATR 72-210A and ATR 42-200 turboprop planes, as well as 12 A321-131 and A320-231 jet planes. The carrier operates 18 domestic routes, in addition to offering seven international charter flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: NIGERIAN CON MEN TEST WATER IN TAIWAN AGAIN

TEXT.P: A group of con men operating from Nigeria are testing the waters in Taiwan once again, warned police officers on Wednesday.
They said that a letter presented to them recently by a local trader for examination has proved to be a fake.

They refused to divulge the contents of the letter from Nigeria but said it is reminiscent of a scheme that was perpetrated in Taiwan in 1995, which a Taiwan woman was tricked into paying US$200,000 as a kickback to a ring of Nigerian con men.
The money was paid in hopes of getting US$1 million as a reward for providing her US bank account to the ring so that they might launder money through it.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SEEN SWITCHING PARNERS FROM JAPAN TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The United States is switching partners from its old ally, Japan, to mainland China, said former Australian Prime Minister Paul Keating, noting that Beijing has become the unlikely standard bearer of Asia's economic growth.

In a speech in Melbourne last Friday, Keating said mainland China rather than Japan has become the standard bearer of Asian economic growth. He said a US-mainland China relationship is a positive step.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the Australian Financial Review correspondent Rowan Callick reported that the recent decision by US President Bill Clinton to pass by Japan in his visit to mainland China sent a clear message that Washington was switching partners.
While mainland China has been praised to the skies for its defense of the yuan, Japan has been savaged for its weakness and incompetence, the daily reported.

The daily reported mainland China's diplomats are highly skilled at using any situation to their advantage and that they appear to be encouraging their leaders to act on the presumption that the "special relationship" is already here to stay with the next step possibly being G7 membership.
Why then should the world's greatest power limit its options by continuing to link itself primarily to fading, fuddy-duddy Japan? the daily asked.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRIME MINISTER SAYS AUSTRALIA LUCKIER THAN SOUTH AFRICA

TEXT.P: Australia has not been marginalized for its White Australia Policy, and the country is luckier than South Africa, which has been punished for its apartheid policy, according to former Prime Minister Paul Keating.

In a speech in Melbourne last Friday, Keating warned that the rise of the One Nation Party has done immeasurable damage to Australia because not a day has gone by without a major Asian newspaper carrying a story about the party or its leader, Pauline Hanson.

He said racism -- apart from being morally wrong -- hurts Australia's economic fortunes, which are now being affected by how the country is viewed as well as by traditional concerns such as the price and supply of bulk commodities like iron ore and coal.
He said Australia has been "dead lucky" not to be marginalized like South Africa over the old White Australia policy.
He said people would see the value of Australian standing by its Asian neighbors -- particularly during tough times -- when the "brouhaha of these debates is over."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Taiwan's first telecommunications satellite was launched on Wednesday.
The China Times: Taiwan's first telecommunications satellite, ST-1, lifted off perfectly to its orbit on Wednesday from a spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana in South America.
The United Daily News: Russia's banking system may collapse as its currency depreciated drastically again on Wednesday.
The Liberty Times: Taiwan's telecommunications industry has entered a new stage following Wednesday's successful launch of its first telecommunications satellite.
The Independence Morning Post: Some 1,000 Taiwan Provincial Government staff members will demonstrate against the "downsizing" plan in front of the Executive Yuan Thursday morning.
The Commons Daily: The Commons Daily's commentary on US President Bill Clinton's June 27-July 3 state visit to mainland China was reprinted in a US monthly magazine.
The China Post: The Taiwan Stock Exchange was hit by a confidence crisis.
The China News: The government's intervention failed to stem a downward spiral in the local stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN 1.03 POINTS ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices dropped slightly on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 1.03 points to close at 6813.3.
The local bourse opened at 6706.32 points, 108.01 lower than Wednesday closing.
A total of 1.99 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$88.69 billion (US$2.548 billion).
Cement shares rose the most at 1.9 percent, while electrical shares moved up 1.4 percent and foodstuff stocks edged up 0.2 percent.

Financial shares fell the most at 1.3 percent, followed by plastic and chemical issues at 0.8 percent; construction shares at 0.6 percent; paper and pulp shares at 0.4 percent; and textile issues at 0.1 percent.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September increased 45 point to close at 6,835 with 1,137 contract transactions, the first time the trading volume broke 1,000 contracts level since the opening of TAIEX on July 21.

The TAIEX Index Futures for October dropped 34 points to 6,800 with 51 contract transactions, while those for December dropped 49 points to 6,890 with 17 contract transactions and those for March remained unchanged, with 7 contract transactions.
No transactions were registered for next June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were listed as follows: 6,790 points for September; 6,834 for October; 6,939 for December; 6,950 for March; and 7,159 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT AFFECTED BY RUBLE MELTDOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses in Russia have become more cautious as the depreciating ruble tumbles at an alarming rate, sources from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said Thursday.

Taiwan's computer giant Acer Inc. and about 20 other Taiwan corporations which maintain investments in Russia have already felt the impact of the country's economic meltdown triggered by unstable politics and questionable financial policies, said CETRA Secretary-General Ricky Kao.

Russia's troubled economy plunged to new lows as the currency shed 10 percent of its value over the last few days to 7.85 rubles to the US dollar. The battered currency has depreciated 26 percent against greenback in 10 days.

CETRA officials stationed in Moscow said with the ruble's continued slump, market shares of imported commodities are expected to shrink by half from the current level of 55 percent to about 25 percent, dealing a heavy blow to foreign investments and suppliers. Those products expected to be mostly effected include foodstuffs, footwear, television sets, refrigerators, automobiles, washing machines and costume ornaments.

Prices of personal computers and peripherals have skyrocketed and some dealers have stopped offering quotations. Footwear dealers have resorted to buying up US dollars for fear that they would suffer even greater losses when the ruble drops further.

The European Union is particularly concerned about the sinking ruble as the deutsche mark has soared 69 percent to 7.6 rubles in frantic trading in Moscow. Germany is the biggest creditor nation of Russia with debts totaling US$60 billion, Kao said.
