DOC.HEADLINE: 'SILK ROAD' ACCIDENT VICTIM IN CRITICAL CONDITION

TEXT.P: The condition of one of the eight Taiwan tourists injured in a car accident in mainland China is unstable and critical, sources from Jiayuguan, a township along the ancient "Silk Road," said Thursday.

Wu Mei-fang sustained several broken ribs and a ruptured lung after a van transporting 14 Taiwan tourists was hit head on by a truck on a highway near Qingchuan, about 50 kilometers from Jiayuguan, Gansu Province, at around 4:40 p.m. last Saturday.
Six Taiwan tourists -- five men and one woman-- as well as the driver of the van were killed in the collision, and eight others were injured.
After treating and putting Wu under observation for four days, doctors said Wu is in critical condition.

The US Pruco Life Insurance Company, which maintains an overseas emergency rescue center in Beijing, is considering whether to send a medical team to offer Wu medical assistance and may transfer her to Beijing if her condition allows, sources said. Wu has a life insurance policy with the US company.

Most of the other injured Taiwan tourists have returned to the island while the bodies of the six killed will be cremated in Jiayuguan. Relatives of the diseased are expected to bring the ashes home to Taiwan on Saturday, sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES CLINTON'S SUPPORT IN INTERNATIONAL ARENA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu and Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Thursday expressed its warm welcome to US President Bill Clinton's reaffirmation of Washington's commitment to the Republic of China on Taiwan.

MOFA was responding to a recent Clinton letter to US Senator Robert G. Torricelli (D-NJ) in which the president said the United States will support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that do not require statehood and will also find appropriate ways for Taiwan's voice to be heard in those that do.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the ministry was delighted to see Clinton reaffirm that there were no changes in US policy toward Taiwan in a clear, definite and steadfast manner after his June 25-July 3 state visit to mainland China.
"We welcome and appreciate Clinton's firm support for our national cause," Wu stressed.

He pointed out that some pro-Taiwan US lawmakers either jointly or individually wrote to Clinton prior to his mainland visit asking the president not to do anything that might undermine the ROC's national interests.

"After his return from the mainland, Clinton has written to all those congressional members, assuring them that his administration has done nothing unfavorable to Taiwan in its high-level engagement with mainland China," Wu said

He added that Clinton also assured those American lawmakers that there will be no change in US policy toward Taiwan following his mainland visit and that the US will continue to provide Taiwan with sufficient defensive weapons in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

"I will continue to develop our strong unofficial relations with Taiwan and to assure Taiwan is provided the defensive weapons necessary for it to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability," Clinton said, adding that his administration was pleased to support the Senate Resolution passed in June reaffirming US commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act and calling on Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Clinton also told Torricelli that he made clear in his June 27 meeting with President Jiang Zemin of "our insistence that differences between the PRC and Taiwan be resolved peacefully. That was the message I conveyed as well when I ordered deployment of two carrier battle groups to the waters near Taiwan in March 1996."
"We strongly support cross-strait dialogue, but we do not intend to mediate, prescribe the agenda, nor pressure Taiwan to negotiate (with the PRC)," Clinton wrote in the letter dated Aug. 18.

The history of the past quarter century provides evidence that Taiwan has fared best when US relations with the PRC are on an even keel and that Taiwan suffers when tensions in US-PRC relations rise. "This paradoxical but clear relationship convinces me that improvement in US-PRC relations over the last several years will strengthen Taiwan's interests and security," wrote Clinton.
Clinton further said he is pleased that Taiwan and mainland China have moved closer toward resumption of a formal cross-strait dialogue since his June visit to the mainland.
"I believe that this, along with continuing US support within the framework I have outlined above, will best guarantee the future security, prosperity and freedom of Taiwan," the letter concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION SATISFIED WITH JAPAN VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The four-day visit by 19 Taiwan legislators to Japan has helped to advance relations between Japan and the Republic of China, said Wang Jin-pyng, vice president of the Legislative Yuan and head of the visiting delegation, at a press conference in Tokyo Wednesday.

Wang said all the Japanese politicians and academic heavyweights they have met have expressed support for Taiwan and Taiwan's interests. Meanwhile, the knowledge and experience gained by the delegation during their visit can be used to safeguard ROC national interests, he noted.

Defining ROC interests, Jao Ying-chi, executive director of the Policy Coordination Committee of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang, said Taiwan is an independent sovereignty that practices democracy. This fact should be respected by the international community, he said.
However, Beijing continues to try to deny the fact and to threaten to use force against the island, Jao said.
Taiwan has called for disputes between the two sides to be resolved in a peaceful manner, Jao said.
Democratic countries around the world should not allow Taiwan to be isolated from the international community, Jao said, because his country needs a place in the community to contribute itself.
The delegation's visit was to call on Japan's leaders to respect the interests and rights of the Taiwan people and to collaborate with Taiwan to promote the Asia-Pacific prosperity.

They also declared the Republic of China will never accept Japan's codification of the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan voiced by US President Bill Clinton during his mainland China visit last July, Wang said.
The legislative leader added that he has also urged Japan not to succumb to Beijing's request to exclude Taiwan from the US-Japanese defense cooperation agreement.

During his meeting with the secretary-general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, Yoshiro Mori, Wang also said Japan should not play into Beijing's hands and forge a strategic partnership with mainland China.
The lawmakers arrived in Japan on Monday and will return home Thursday, except for Jao and a few others, who will travel to Bangkok for a conference of the World Freedom and Democracy Alliance.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON REAFFIRMS COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said Washington would support Taiwan membership in international organizations that do not require statehood and will find appropriate ways for Taiwan's voice to be heard in those that do.
In a letter to US Senator Robert G. Torricelli (D-NJ) dated Aug. 18, Clinton wrote that US policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged.

"I will continue to develop our strong unofficial relations with Taiwan and to assure Taiwan is provided the defensive weapons necessary for it to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability," the president promised.

"My administration was pleased to support the Senate Resolution passed earlier this month reaffirming our commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act and calling on the PRC to renounce the use of force against Taiwan," he added.

Clinton also told Senator Torricelli that he made clear in his meeting with President Jiang Zemin of "our insistence that differences between the PRC and Taiwan be resolved peacefully. That was the message I conveyed as well when I ordered deployment of two carrier battle groups to the waters near Taiwan in March 1996."
"We strongly support cross-strait dialogue, but we do not intend to mediate, prescribe the agenda, nor pressure Taiwan to negotiate (with the PRC)," Clinton wrote.

The history of the past quarter century provides evidence that Taiwan has fared best when US relations with the PRC are on an even keel and that Taiwan suffers when tensions in US-PRC relations rise. "This paradoxical but clear relationship convinces me that improvement in US-PRC relations over the last several years will strengthen Taiwan's interests and security," wrote Clinton.
He said he is pleased that Taiwan and the PRC have moved closer toward resumption of a formal cross-strait dialogue since his June visit to the mainland.
"I believe that this, along with continuing US support within the framework I have outlined above, will best guarantee the future security, prosperity and freedom of Taiwan," the letter concluded.

The Washington-based Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) said Wednesday that a US House resolution calling on the Clinton administration to assist Taiwan in joining the World Health Organization is in line with President Clinton's "appropriate ways for Taiwan's voice to be heard" in the international community.

FAPA expressed the hope that the Clinton administration would put into practice the president's promise if and when the House passes the resolution. The resolution has so far been signed by 53 members of the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR HITS 12-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar plunged to 56.1 US cents at one point on Thursday, the lowest level since July 1986 when it was traded at 57.1 US cents.
The dramatic fall of the Australian dollar was attributed to the free fall of the ruble after Russia's central bank gave up its support of the currency.

The ruble has lost over 40 percent of its value against the US dollar in the last few months, and the Russian economy risks collapsing further if nothing is done to stop the depreciating currency, analysts said.

Problems with the ruble follow the Asian economic crisis which shows signs of deepening while Latin America and Eastern Europe are now seen as the next victims of this global economic slowdown, they added.
The Australian dollar closed at 57.32 US cents on Wednesday, down 0.68 US cents from Tuesday's close.
Analysts said the foreign exchange market was in a panic as investors dashed to unload the Australian dollar to cut their losses.

They said despite the panic sentiment, the Australian dollar was not in a free fall like the ruble. But the fall in the value of the Australian currency, affected by falling international commodity prices, is accelerating.

The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) has not recently intervened in the foreign exchange market, but it continues to monitor the situation. In June the RBA spent A$2.63 billion (US$1.64 billion) to prop up the Australian currency.
"I expect the RBA will intervene if the Australian dollar is heading toward a free fall in coming days or weeks," one analyst said.
If the current situation continues unabated, the Australian dollar could fall to 55 US cents then fall further to 50 US cents in coming weeks, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW TO PRESIDE OVER PUMP-PRIMING MEETING

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew is scheduled to preside over an inter-ministerial meeting Friday to pool the Cabinet's wisdom on pump-priming measures to prop up Taiwan's economy.
Siew called for all Cabinet members to contribute to the discussion, aimed at boosting domestic demand and, ultimately, stabilizing the economy.

Siew said he is confident that the Republic of China on Taiwan will not only tide over the current regional economic crisis but will weather the storm in a way that raises eyebrows throughout the world.

Taiwan's economy has been an exemplar for the world, Siew said, adding that Taiwan must stand firm against the economic turbulence that has battered Southeast Asia, East Asia, and Central and South America.

No Cabinet-level agencies should shirk their responsibility to work toward improving Taiwan's economy, Siew said. He even called on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for support, pointing out that economic troubles at home will affect relations abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS CUTTING AUSTRALIAN INCOME, JOBS: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: The effects of the Asian economic crisis on Australia may continue for over a decade, economic experts said.

Australia's national income is expected to drop by US$3.1 billion or almost 1 percent, living standards will likely fall by about A$13 billion (US$8.13 billion) and unemployment will increase by about 0.3 percent, they said. Some analysts have not ruled out the possibility of an economic recession in Australia.

Five of Australia's leading economic modellers spent the last six months examining the impact of the Asian crisis on the domestic economy and found that the crisis would cut Australia's economic growth by about 1 percent over the coming year.

Peter Downes, a senior treasury official, said growth in gross domestic product could fall by up to one percent as a result of a short-term slump in Australia's exports in the first 12-24 months of the Asian crisis. The loss of national income was equivalent to A$5 billion (US$3.1 billion).

Chris Murphy, a former senior treasury official, said the main cost to Australia would most likely be to income and not production. Private consumption in Australia could drop by around 2.5 percent due to the Asian crisis.
The model of the Canberra-based Access Economics (AE) suggests that Asia will be a big problem for the Australian economy in 1999.

"The bottom line is that Asia will drag Australian growth down below trend in the second half of 1998 and for much of 1999," AE director Chris Richardson said. "The upshot is a loss to Australian national income of around 1.2 percent in the year prior to the Olympics, the equivalent of A$8 billion."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LEADERS SHOW SUPPORT FOR IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Leaders from a few Australian businesses, trade unions, churches, and welfare groups recently showed their support for immigrants.

A joint statement was issued by the Australian Council of Social Services, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Business Council of Australia and religious leaders. It called for a renewed commitment to a "tolerant, open, generous-hearted Australian society."
Former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, who several months ago tried but failed to issue a similar statement signed by four prime ministers, was behind the initiative.

The statement, issued on Wednesday, said more than four out of 10 Australians were postwar immigrants or the children of immigrants -- with more than half coming from non-English speaking backgrounds. It also said immigration has enriched Australia's society and fortified the national economy.

"The statements, attitudes and policies of the One Nation Party, including their opposition to an enhanced national immigration program, simply do not recognize the demographic, social or economic realities of our nation," the joint statement said.

"They threaten Australian jobs by undercutting the growth that flows from an open economy. They threaten both our internal cohesion and our international reputation. They should be decisively repudiated by all Australians," it added.

The statement said Asia would remain fundamentally important to the future economic welfare of Australians and that the signatories believed they had the right and the responsibility to "express deep concern at what is happening to Australia at the present time."

David Oldfield, principal adviser to One Nation leader Pauline Hanson, told reporters that the joint statement was "nothing more than a political attack" and that its signatories were clearly supporting multiculturalism and globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARRIAGE RATE HITS 100-YEAR LOW IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Australia's marriage rate has registered a 100-year record low, and close to one in every two people will never marry, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
ABS figures indicate an estimated 44 percent of men and 42 percent of women in Australia will never marry compared to 25 percent and 26 percent respectively in 1977.

The survey figures indicate that Australians have given up hope of finding a committed, satisfying lifetime relationship, Australian Family Association President Susan Bastick told the Sydney Morning Herald.
However, the number of Australians living in de facto relationships jumped to 744,000 compared to 584,000 in 1991. About a third of those in de facto relationships had previously been married.

Bastick said there was more social support for people divorcing than for those trying to work out their differences. Another reason for the decline in marriages was because many people see others divorcing and they do not want to put themselves in a position where that would happen to them.
For every two marriages in Australia, there is one divorce, according to ABS figures. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: NIGERIAN MILITARY RULER ABUBAKAR INTENDS TO RETIRE NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: Nigerian military ruler Abdulsalam Abubakar has reaffirmed his intention to leave politics after the civilian takeover of the Nigerian government in May of next year.
After his three-day visit to South Africa Wednesday afternoon, Abubakar said in Pretoria that he has put 35 years of service into the military and he is going to retire quietly to village life.
The last elections in Nigeria in 1993 were annulled by the military.
Abubakar said he believed his visit to South Africa brought understanding among South Africans for Nigeria's approach to bring back democracy.
He said Nigeria accepted advice from South Africa on its transition process in view of the South African experience of emerging peacefully from apartheid to become a free society.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar climbed NT$0.01 against the greenback Thursday in Taipei, closing at 34.792.
The local currency opened at 34.791 and was traded between 34.786 and 34.801.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$177 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-GAMBIAN DOUBLE-TAXATION AVOIDANCE ACCORD PASSED

TEXT.P: The ROC's Executive Yuan on Thursday passed a bilateral agreement, forged in July, on avoiding double taxation and tax evasion with The Gambia.

The agreement was signed by ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Gambian counterpart, Momodou Lamin Sedat Jobe, on July 22 in Taipei. It was formed to protect investors' interests and simplify taxation procedures, according to the Ministry of Finance.
The agreement is expected to enhance trade and economic cooperation between the two countries.
Taipei established diplomatic relations with the African country in July 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: LESOTHO GENERAL ELECTION TO BE RECOUNTED

TEXT.P: A recount of votes cast in Lesotho's May 23 general election is set for the weekend, according to South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki.
Mbeki returned to South Africa Wednesday afternoon after brokering an agreement between Lesotho's government and opposition leaders in Maseru.
On Tuesday and Wednesday, Mbeki and representaives of the presidents of Botswana and Zimbabwe met leaders of the three main opposition parties and the ruling Lesotho Congress for Democracy (LCD).
During the meetings Mbeki presented an interim report compiled by the Langa Commission, which investigated opposition claims of election irregularities.
The report said there was evidence that Lesotho's Independent Electoral Commission mishandled the May 23 poll, which saw the LCD win 79 of the 80 seats in the national assembly.
The Lesotho government asked Mbeki to convey the message that it is prepared for a recount to the opposition parties.
Opposition parties' leaders reportedly indicated they were happy with what has been achieved so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT WARNS RENMINBI WILL FALL 6 PERCENT AGAINST US DOLLAR BY 2000
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Chang Yuan-hsiang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The exchange rate of the renminbi, mainland China's currency, will drop to 8.80 renminbi, or yuan, to one US dollar by the year 2000, a decline of 6 percent from its current exchange rate, predicted a mainland Chinese economist.

Fan Gang, director of the Institute of Economics in Beijing, pointed out that the renminbi will be under heavy devaluation pressure over the next two years, as the economy will be impacted by several peripheral factors.

The famous mainland economist said many factors have dragged down the mainland's economic growth rate: the government's strict control of investment; serious non-performing loan problems encountered by state-owned enterprises and financial organizations; the Asia's financial turmoil; and the reform of the state-owned enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S WHOLESALE TRADE INDEX DROPS DURING SECOND QUARTER

TEXT.P: Singapore's overall domestic wholesale trade index during the second quarter of this year was down 10.5 percent from its year-earlier level, the Singapore Department of Statistics (DOS) said Thursday.
Excluding petroleum, the index fell 10.9 percent.
Compared with the second quarter of last year, the overall foreign wholesale trade index fell by 13.5 percent in the second quarter.
Excluding petroleum, the index slipped 13.9 percent.
The sharp decline in the index was partly attributed to the 31.1 percent fall in the wholesaling of textiles, apparel and personal effects, DOS said.
Dealers trading in timber, paints and construction materials continued to earn less during this year's second quarter with sales down 21.4 percent compared with one year ago.
Likewise, the wholesale turnover of electronic and electrical components and industrial machinery fell 20 percent, while that of petroleum and petroleum products was down 9 percent.
General wholesale traders, however, reported a rise of 37.8 percent in earnings during the second quarter of this year, DOS said.

As to foreign wholesale trade, DOS indicated that sales of food, beverages and tobacco grew 25.4 percent, while all other wholesale activities reported slower business. Hardest hit was the wholesaling of timber, paints and construction materials, in which turnover tumbled 44.8 percent.

This was followed by the wholesale trade of textiles, apparel and personal effects, down 31 percent, and office equipment, computers and accessories, down 26.2 percent. The turnover of petroleum and petroleum products also declined 12.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: `KINGDOM OF BUTTERFLIES' LOSING ITS SUBJECTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is losing its renown as the natural habitat of a huge variety of butterflies, an environmental activist warned on Thursday, blaming the situation on a combination of factors.

Chen Wei-shou, president of the Taiwan Butterfly Protection Association, said the number of butterflies and the variety of species to be found in Taiwan's most precious butterfly habitat -- the area around the southern Taiwan mountain township of Meinung -- have declined dramatically in recent years.

Meinung Butterfly Valley in Kaohsiung County was discovered by scientists to be home to numerous species of colorful butterflies early this century, when Taiwan was under Japanese colonial rule. The valley entered the international limelight more than 10 years ago, when footage of millions of brightly colored butterflies darkening the skies was shown on television. Taiwan has since been reputed to be the "kingdom of butterflies."

Chen said that as recently as 10 years ago, visitors to the valley could see throngs of butterflies, known locally as a "big occurrence," three times each year -- in April, June and October, respectively.
"Such dazzling, magnificent scenes, however, have now become history," Chen said, adding that the "big occurrence" now appears only once a year, usually in October.
Worse yet, Chen said, the scale of the "big occurrence" has dwindled substantially in the past few years.

"In its heyday, as many as 113 butterfly species could be seen in the valley, including some highly treasurable indigenous species," Chen said, adding that the number of strains now spotted in the valley dropped to 80-plus three to four years ago, and further fell to about 50 this year.
Several rare species, such as Byasa febanus, Kaniska canace drilon and Traides aeacus kaguya, have all disappeared in the Meinung Valley, Chen noted.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the numbers have also declined drastically. "In the past, one could see more than 20 million butterflies dancing in the skies during a `big occurrence.' Today, however, the number has shrunk to just slightly more than 100,000," Chen lamented.
The dramatic decline is not only worrying local entomologists and butterfly fans, it has also drawn concern from American and Japanese environmentalists and academics, Chen said.
Some Japanese and American experts have traveled to the Meinung Valley to probe possible causes of the decrease in the number and species of butterflies.

Chen quoted several experts who attribute the decline to two reasons: Climatic changes in southern Taiwan have resulted in a blurring of the seasonal differences between the dry and rainy seasons; and deforestation has deprived butterflies of their natural and vital ecosystem.
Nevertheless, Chen said, further studies are needed to determine the exact causes of the disappearance of so many of the beautiful creatures.

Chen further called on the government to devote more funds and energy to environmental protection and butterfly conservation. "Otherwise, no butterfly can be seen in the Meinung Valley in the not too distant future," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION ARRIVES IN GUATEMALA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 26 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: An ROC delegation led by Foreign Minister Jason Hu and Chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development P. K. Chiang arrived in Guatemala City Guatemala, Wednesday for a two-day visit.
They were greeted at the airport by Guatemalan Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein and ROC Ambassador Wu Jen-hsiu, as well as by representatives of the country's Chinese community.

In a brief statement issued on arriving in Guatemala, Hu extended cordial greetings to the government and people of Guatemala on behalf of the Republic of China and said that he looked forward to closer ties with the Latin American state.
Hu will preside over a meeting with ROC envoys to Latin American countries on Wednesday and pay a courtesy call on Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES PROTEST OUTSIDE EXECUTIVE YUAN

TEXT.P: A group of more than 1,000 employees of Taiwan's provincial government on Thursday traveled to the Executive Yuan to demand that their working rights be secured after the downsizing of the provincial government by year-end.

The demonstrators came all the way from the seat of the Taiwan provincial government -- Nantou County in central Taiwan. Some 20 tourist buses took them to the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall compound in downtown Taipei on Thursday morning, from where they marched in procession to the Executive Yuan.

Holding placards and banners, the employees marched peacefully for about an hour to the Executive Yuan, shouting slogans such as "Support the Downsizing of the Provincial Government but Oppose its Abolishment," "Abolishment of the Provincial Government is Unconstitutional," and "Fight For Our Working Rights."

Yang Chaur-shin, chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, and Wei Chi-lin, director-general of Central Personnel Administration, came out of the building to accept a petition from the marchers. Twenty provincial government employees were also invited to have talks with the two central government officials.

The petition expressed concern that the central government's true purpose is to abolish, rather than downsize, the provincial government, and set out the provincial government employees' demands for dignity, working rights and protection.

It said the central government should not force them to retire or dismiss them with severance pay, and demanded that their new jobs should be in the same geographic areas as their current work locations. The workers should not be forced to leave their families to work in different areas, the petition said.

Kuo Cheng-hsi, chairman of the "Taiwan Provincial Government Employees Self-Rescue Alliance" and organizer of the event, said that if the demonstration does not obtain a goodwill response from the central government, he will not exclude the possibility of staging another mass demonstration in Taipei in early September.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TRYING TO STRENGTHEN UNITY BY PROPAGANDA

TEXT.P: Beijing has launched a propaganda campaign to strengthen national unity and divert the attention of the people from the government's performance in economic reforms by making use of the floods now damaging the country.

The Hong Kong Standard reported Thursday that Ding Guanggen, chief of the Propaganda Department of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee, has just convened a national meeting of Chinese communist propagandists on how to widely spread messages about the floods damaging central and northeastern China.

In the closed-door meeting, Ding wanted the propagandists to stress in the campaign the cooperation between the People's Liberation Army (PLA) and the general public in fighting the floods, and their self-sacrifice and meritorious services to the people.
The report said the campaign is also aimed at neutralizing the aversion of the people to the corruption and illegal activities of the PLA.

The report also said that, although Beijing leaders are anxious to eliminate corruption, they are afraid that the image of the government may be badly damaged if the people are allowed to know too much about government scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA LABOR-MANAGEMENT TALKS BREAK DOWN

TEXT.P: Pay talks between pilots with TransAsia Airways and the carrier's management broke down on Thursday, and the pilots announced that they had suspended negotiations with the management.

Chen Pei-chuan, representative of the 63 pilots who staged a demonstration outside the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) headquarters to protest the carrier's plan to cut salaries, said they decided to halt bilateral negotiations because the management refused to back down on the decision.

Sixty-seven of TransAsia's 72 French-Italian ATR turboprop pilots resigned en masse late on Monday following the carrier's announcement that ATR pilot salaries would be cut by up to 30 percent from next month, to make up for operational losses of NT$8 million (about US$230,000) in the first half of this year.
Chen demanded that TransAsia make severance payments and issue leave certificates to its pilots if the airline cannot avoid cutting salaries.
Only two of the 67 pilots returned to work on Wednesday after TransAsia threatened to hire lower-paid pilots from the Czech Republic.

Meanwhile, CAA Deputy Director Chang Kuo-cheng said CAA has demanded that TransAsia work out a new plan of operations before 8:30 a.m. on Friday, and explain its measures to deal with the situation. If TransAsia fails to work out a reasonable plan by that deadline, Chang said the CAA will cancel TransAsia's operating rights on 10 domestic routes.

Cheng said the CAA will call a meeting on Saturday to discuss punishments for TransAsia and for pilots found to have neglected their duties, but he stressed that the CAA will not interfere in the labor-management dispute.
The dispute has gravely affected TransAsia's operations over the past several days, forcing the carrier to cancel more than 100 flights to destinations around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TAKES DELIVERY OF ANOTHER EIGHT MIRAGE FIGHTER JETS

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Thursday took delivery of a further eight of the 60 Mirage 2000-5 jet fighters it ordered from France in 1992.

The eighth shipment of the advanced fighters arrived at the eastern Taiwan port of Hualien on Thursday afternoon, according to sources from ROC Air Force Headquarters. The planes were then towed to a nearby air force base, the sources said.
The delivery brought to 52 the number of French-built warplanes that have arrived in Taiwan to date. The last eight are expected to be delivered in mid-December.
Taiwan struck the NT$167.6 billion deal for the 60 aircraft with France in 1992. The first five arrived on May 5, 1997.
The purchase is part of the air force's second-generation warplane build-up plan. The planes are replacing the country's aging fleet of American-built F-104Gs as high altitude aerial interceptors.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY FLASHES BLUE LIGHT OF RECESSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy flashed a blue light in July, a sign of economic recession on the government's five-color composite assessment system, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Thursday.
The CEPD officials said that the first blue light in 26 months came after three consecutive months of yellow-blue lights.
They pointed out that the blue light signals a need for the government to adopt a powerful package to stimulate the economy.

Under the five-color assessment system designed by the CEPD for Taiwan's economic status, a blue light represents an economic recession; a yellow-blue light indicates a slowdown; a green light signifies steady growth; a yellow-red light means the economy is heating up; and a red light represents an overheated economy.

The ratings are determined according to nine major economic indicators: export value; new export orders; industrial production; manufacturing inventories; total employment outside the agricultural sector; money supply; stock prices; the check default rate; and bank lending to the private sector.

The leading index also fell by 1.7 percent in July, or the second highest drop since the Asian financial storm broke in mid-1997, indicating that an economic recovery will be impossible this year. Any chance of the recession bottoming out will not be likely until the first quarter of next year.

Chen Pao-juei, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said that the Asian financial crisis has caused Taiwan's exports in the first seven months of this year to register negative growth of 8 percent. With the economies of Southeast Asian countries still in disarray, it will be difficult to boost the domestic economy through exports.
Meanwhile, the CEPD announced the result of a survey of domestic manufacturers which shows that manufacturers have become more pessimistic about the island's economic prospects.
Twenty-seven percent of the respondents now think the economy will deteriorate further, up from 25 percent in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN WANT INVESTMENT PROTECTION PACT WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of Taiwan businessmen interviewed in a recent survey urged Taipei to conclude an investment protection agreement with Beijing.

The March-April survey of 110 Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China was commissioned by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), and carried out at 20 symposiums held in Shenzhen and Donguan, both in Guangdong Province.
They also urged the government of the Republic of China to lift its prohibition of Taiwan-based banks operating in mainland China.

More than 60 percent of those surveyed said they had experienced disputes while doing business in mainland China, with the most common complaints being trouble with local authorities, and patent or copyright infringements, each of which accounted for 25 percent of the total.
Soured real estate deals and industrial disputes were next, each responsible for 16 percent of the total, while disputes with mainland companies made up another 11 percent.
Ninety-nine percent of the disputes were settled through "monetary handouts," or "negotiations," the survey revealed without further elaboration.
These disputes provide opportunities for gangsters to become involved in settlement issues, and sometimes develop into political issues between Taipei and Beijing, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA MAY SUSPEND ATR FLIGHTS FOLLOWING BREAKDOWN OF PAY TALKS

TEXT.P: TransAsia Airways announced on Thursday that it may suspend some of its domestic ATR flight services on Saturday following a breakdown in pay talks with 65 of its pilots.
A TransAsia executive said it will be hard for the airline to operate its ATR flights this Saturday, as only four pilots are available to fly the carrier's 16 flights scheduled for that day.
The official noted that applications by any pilots who are willing to return to work will be handled on a case-by-case basis.

Of TransAsia's 10 domestic routes flown by its fleet of ATR turboprop planes, the carrier will seek to maintain normal flight services between the offshore islands of Kinmen and Penghu, but may consider suspending four other routes, including two solely served by the airline, due to a lack of manpower, according to the official.

Suspension of flights over the past few days has seriously affected the carrier's operations, with its average passenger load dropping from 16,000 per day to around 7,500, the TransAsia executive said, adding that the company will submit a new plan of operations for the next three months to the Ministry of Transportation and Telecommunications on Friday.

Meanwhile, Chen Pei-chuan, representative of 63 of the pilots who staged a demonstration outside the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) headquarters to protest the carrier's plan to cut salaries, announced that they had suspended negotiations with management, because it had refused to back down on the decision.

Chen also presented a letter signed by 62 pilots demanding that TransAsia either withdraw its salary cut plan before Aug. 31, or immediately make severance payments and issue leave certificates to its pilots in accordance with the law, as their contracts with TransAsia are no longer valid.

Sixty-seven of TransAsia's 72 French-Italian ATR turboprop pilots resigned en masse late on Monday following the carrier's announcement that ATR pilot salaries would be cut by up to 30 percent from next month, to make up for operational losses of NT$8 million (about US$230,000) in the first half of this year.
Only two of the 67 pilots returned to work on Wednesday after TransAsia threatened to hire lower-paid foreign pilots.
Meanwhile, CAA Deputy Director Chang Kuo-cheng said CAA has demanded that TransAsia work out a new plan of operations before 8:30 a.m. on Friday, and explain its measures to deal with the situation.
Chang said the CAA will call a meeting on Friday to discuss adjustments of domestic flight services with other airlines following the TransAsia incident.

The TransAsia labor-management dispute has gravely affected the aviation company's operations over the past several days, forcing the carrier to cancel more than 100 flights to destinations around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD URGES IMPLEMENTATION OF ECONOMIC STIMULUS PLAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Thursday urged government agencies to fully implement an economic stimulus plan worked out recently to expand domestic consumer demand.

As the fallout from the year-long Asian financial crisis is more serious than expected, and as the situation may further escalate, the CEPD said the relevant government agencies must do their best to promote the plan to help stimulate the local economy.

Meanwhile, the five-color assessment system designed by the CEPD to gauge Taiwan's economy flashed a blue light in July for the first time since June 1996, indicating that the local economy has entered a recession.

Citing data recently released by the Economist magazine, the CEPD reported that the world's economic growth will slow this year to just 2.3 percent, down from the 3.6 percent recorded for 1997. It added that the crisis-plagued countries of Southeast Asia will be unable to recover from the current recession until 2001.

The CEPD also pointed out that the European financial market may become more volatile following the financial turbulence which broke out last week in Russia, while mainland China may not be able to achieve its targeted 8 percent economic growth this year because of the recent flooding which has devastated large parts of its northeastern and northern regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL VISITS JAPANESE COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: A visiting high-ranking official from the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang met on Thursday with three leading officials of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party.

Accompanied by ROC representative to Japan Chuang Ming-yao, KMT Secretary-General John Chang visited his Japanese counterpart, LDP Secretary-General Yoshiro Mori, to exchange views on issues of mutual concern.

During their meeting, Mori reminisced about meeting with late President Chiang Ching-kuo when Chiang was president of the China Youth Corps. Mori's subsequent remarks indicated that he has harbored friendly feelings toward the ROC since a young age.

Chang, a former ROC foreign minister, told Mori that if Tokyo and Beijing sign a document that gives Taiwan a feeling that it is further isolated in the international community, the stability of the Asia-Pacific region might be adversely affected.

Without specifically mentioning the "three noes" policy, Chang was expressing concern that during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan in the coming months, Japan might enunciate the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan under pressure from Beijing.
Later in the day, Chang visited other LDP ranking officials -- Policy Affairs Research Council Chairman Yukihiko Ikeda, and Executive Council Chairman Takashi Fukaya.
Describing the conversations as "frank and constructive," Chang said that he believed the meeting helped them gain a better understanding of each other.

Asked if he mentioned the "three noes" policy, Chang said that the conversations covered topics including Jiang's delayed Japanese visit and further engagement between Tokyo and Beijing. Chang said that he has expressed clearly Taiwan's stance on the issue, adding that the Japanese side promised to pass Taiwan's comments to Japanese Premier Keizo Obuchi.

The "three noes" policy, spelled by US President Bill Clinton during his visit to mainland China earlier this year, refers to no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan membership in international organizations that require statehood.
Chang arrived in Japan on Wednesday for a five-day visit, his third overseas trip aimed at promoting "party diplomacy" since he assumed his current post late last year. (Mike Chang and Lin Wen-fen)

DOC.HEADLINE: WLFD ANNUAL CONFERENCE TO BE HELD IN BANGKOK

TEXT.P: The World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD) is to open its 30th annual conference in Bangkok on Friday.
In a press conference called on the eve of the opening, WLFD President Chao Tze-chi said that the three-day meeting will focus on the Asian financial crisis.
More than 200 members from 145 countries around the world will discuss the global impact of the Asian financial crisis, said Chao.

A written letter of congratulations from Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will be read at Friday's opening, and ROC Minister of Finance Paul Chiu will give a speech on how Taiwan has weathered the crisis on Saturday.
The WLFD, founded in 1954, is a private organization aimed at improving freedom and democracy around the world, said Chao.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: US President Bill Clinton said in a recent letter to Senator Robert G. Torricelli that the United States will support Taiwan's membership in international organizations.
The China Times: Russia's stock and foreign exchange market crashes have further worsened the global economy.
The United Daily News: Russian financial turmoil has destabilized securities markets around the world.
The Liberty Times: The Ministry of Education opposes the proposed inclusion of teachers into Labor Standards Law coverage.
The Independence Morning Post: Elderly farmers and fishermen will be able to receive NT$3,000 in pension fund per month.
The Commons Daily: The United States will help Taiwan enter some international organizations.
The China Post: The Taiwan economy is in recession: CEPD.
The China News: TransAsia pilot strike talks crashed on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASHES OF 'SILK ROAD' ACCIDENT VICTIMS TO RETURN HOME SUNDAY

TEXT.P: The families of six Taiwan tourists killed in a traffic accident in mainland China's northwestern province of Gansu will bring the ashes of their beloved ones home Sunday, the Taipei Travel Agents Association (TTAA) said on Friday.
The bodies of the six victims were cremated Friday after a memorial ceremony Friday morning.

The families, carrying the ashes of their beloved ones, will fly from Jiayuguan, Gansu province, to Beijing for an overnight stay Saturday. They are scheduled to return to Taipei via Hong Kong Sunday afternoon.
The six victims were part of a 14-member Taiwan tour group taking part in the "Silk Road" tour of mainland China.
The accident took place last Saturday when a van carrying the group collided with a truck near Qingchuan, some 50 kilometers from Jiayuguan.
Along with six Taiwanese tourists, the driver of the van was killed. Eight other Taiwan tourists were injured in the accident.
One of the injured, Wu Mei-fang, sustained several broken ribs and a ruptured lung in the accident. Wu, who is still hospitalized in the mainland, may return to Taiwan on Sunday.

TTAA officials said that on Thursday the families of the victims negotiated with the mainland on compensation terms. Mainland officials offered US$29,000 in compensation to the families of each victim killed, but the victims' families rejected the offer.
Taiwan's intermediary Straits Exchange Foundation may have to intervene to help the families in the compensation negotiations, TTAA officials said.
