DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOLDS DIALOGUE WITH SOUTH PACIFIC FORUM NATIONS

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation, led by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Wu Tzu-dan, is in Micronesia attending a dialogue meeting with member nations of the South Pacific Forum, the region's largest political and economic group.

The sixth "Taiwan/Republic of China - Forum Country Dialogue" opened Friday morning in the Micronesian capital of Pohnpei. Participating in the forum are representatives of Tonga, Tuvalu, Nauru, the Solomon Islands, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Palau and Niue, as well as the South Pacific Forum Secretariat.

According to Tsai Hsien-jung, deputy director of East Asian and Pacific affairs for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the ROC delegates will discuss cooperation in trade, investment, agriculture and fishery.

The South Pacific Forum comprises 16 independent nations, federal states and self-ruled governments: Australia, New Zealand, Nauru, Fiji, Tonga, the Solomon Islands, Tuvalu, Papua New Guinea, Western Samoa, Vanuatu, Kiribati, the Cook Islands, the Marshall Islands, Niue, Micronesia and Palau.
Four of the forum nations -- Nauru, Tonga, Tuvalu and the Solomon Islands -- maintain formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, while several others have trade links.
Taiwan has held five rounds of dialogue with South Pacific Forum nations since 1993 when it was admitted into the regional forum as a dialogue partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER PUSHES FOR DOMESTIC INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Friday that it is high time to accelerate domestic demand and investment.

Despite indications of crises of confidence in economies at home and abroad, Wang said he is still optimistic about Taiwan's economic prowess, believing that the economy will pick up steam late next year, early 2000 at the latest.

"We should stimulate domestic demand and facilitate investment at home when the economy is witnessing its lowest lows." By doing so, the island's export sector will be in a position to take advantage of a global economic recovery, once it begins, Wang said.

Addressing a meeting with local business and industrial leaders on strategic measures relating to the "Year 2000" computer problem, Wang said he is confident that domestic investment will grow by more than 16 percent this year, making it the prime mover behind Taiwan's economic growth at a time when the exports are experiencing an early winter.

Wang said Taiwan's economy flashed a "blue light" in July -- a rating in Taiwan's color-coded economic analysis index that indicates a recession. The plunge in the Russian ruble, coupled with steep falls in stock markets worldwide, have clouded global economic prospects, he said, adding that a rebound is unlikely until late next year.

Kao Chin-yen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, meanwhile, called for the government to take stimulus measures to help the business and industrial sectors tide over the current difficulties. The measures he recommended include lowering bank interest rates, relaxing the credit market, stabilizing New Taiwan dollar exchange rates and improving the efficiency of public investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN COMES BACK FROM THE DEAD

TEXT.P: A Canadian man who was declared dead stunned medical officials by coming back to life just minutes before he was to be shipped to the morgue.
Rene Desforges, 65, who suffered from an advanced state of emphysema, said Thursday what happened to him was a miracle.
The resident of Gatineau, Quebec, began suffocating last Friday evening at his home. By the time he arrived at a local hospital, he was completely unconscious.
Desforges was declared dead and was being disconnected from a respirator when he started breathing again.
Five days later, not only had Desforges recovered but doctors said his health was better than ever. Doctors, too, said the occurrence can only be explained as a miracle.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ARMS DEAL SIGNIFIES NO CHANGES IN US POLICY: MND

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense's announcement of a plan to sell US$350 million worth of defensive weapons to Taipei indicates that there is no change in Washington's arms sales policy toward Taiwan, military officials said on Friday.

The officials made the remarks after the Pentagon announced on Thursday that pending congressional approval, the United States will provide Taiwan with a variety of military hardware, including 61 Stringer air defense missiles, Harpoon anti-ship missiles, MK-46 torpedoes and related equipment and service.

If the US Congress doesn't voice opposition to the plan within the specified period of time, this will be the first Taipei-Washington arms deal since US President Bill Clinton made a high-profile visit to mainland China two months ago.

"We welcome the Pentagon's move," said a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND), adding that continued US sales of defensive weapons related equipment to Taiwan will help maintain peace in the Asia-Pacific region.

Following Clinton's mainland trip, the Clinton administration has on many occasions reaffirmed that it will continue to furnish Taiwan with defensive weapons necessary to ensure the island's security in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.

"The Pentagon's announcement marks a concrete US action proving that there is not any change in the US arms sales policy toward Taiwan in the wake of Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland trip," said another MND official who preferred anonymity.
Pending congressional approval, the Pentagon said the United States will provide Taiwan with 61 dual mount Stinger missile launchers, 728 missile rounds and associated hardware for US$180 million.
The package deal will also include 58 Harpoon anti-ship missiles to be mounted on Taiwan's US-made F-16 jet fighters and eight Harpoon training missiles for US$101 million.
In addition, The United States will sell 131 MK-46 torpedoes and related equipment for US$69 million. The torpedoes will be used by Taiwan's S-70 helicopters for anti-submarine warfare.
The Pentagon said in a news statement that Taiwan intends to use these weapons to maintain its air defense capability.
It further said the proposed deal is consistent with US laws and policy and will not affect the basic military balance in the Asia-Pacific region.

According to the Pentagon, the prime contractor for the Stinger systems and torpedoes is Raytheon Systems Co. of Lexington, Massachusetts; and the main contractor for the Harpoon missiles is McDonnell Douglas Aerospace of St. Louis, now owned by Boeing Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: US ANNOUNCES PLANNED MILITARY SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense on Thursday announced US$350 million in proposed military sales to Taiwan, the first since President Bill Clinton's trip to mainland China nearly two months ago.
Pending Congressional approval, the United States will provide Taiwan with 61 Stinger air defense missile launchers, 728 missiles and associated hardware for US$180 million,
According to the Pentagon, the sales will also include 58 Harpoon anti-ship missiles to be mounted on US-made F-16 fighter jets and eight Harpoon training missiles for US$101 million.
In addition, Taiwan will acquire 131 MK-46 torpedoes and related equipment for US$69 million. These will be used by the island's anti- submarine S-70 helicopters.

The announcement is expected to be welcomed by Taipei as authorities there are waiting to see whether Washington lives up to its promise to continue supplying defense weapons, particularly after President Clinton's meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in late June.
Beijing leaders have repeatedly protested against US arms sales to Taiwan and have asked for a halt to the transactions.
The Pentagon said that the proposed sales are consistent with US laws and policy and will not affect the basic military balance in the region. (by Jay Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TOUGHENS ENTRY CONDITIONS FOR SKILLED MIGRANTS

TEXT.P: The Australian government has substantially toughened the entry conditions for skilled migrants.
In a statement faxed to CNA Friday morning, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said that the changes will seek to maximize economic benefits to Australia.

"According to economic modeling commissioned by my department, Australia will be some A$95 (US$60) per person better off as a result of the greater focus placed on these categories of the Migration Program," he said.

He said a major change to the Independent and Skilled Australian Linked (SAL) categories will be to establish minimum threshold criteria for skills, age and English language ability to all independent and SAL categories.

"From July 1, 1999, all new applicants in these categories will have to be less than 45 years of age, have vocational level English and have a skilled occupation with qualifications recognized in Australia," he said. "Establishment of minimum threshold will not only do away with some anomalies in the current points test, but will also enable us to introduce other factors more focused on obtaining employment in Australia."

The additional employability factors include five additional points if the applicant's spouse also meets the threshold requirements for skills, age and English language ability and another five extra points if the applicant obtained his diploma, trade certificate or degree from an Australian educational institution.
Australia has set the immigration quota in fiscal 1998-99 at 68,000, unchanged from the previous year's level.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT TO REVISE GROWTH FORECAST

TEXT.P: The Australian government is expected to revise soon its economic growth target for next year after the release of data showing business investment has been falling for six months.

Federal Treasurer Peter Costello said on Thursday that the government would be releasing new economic and fiscal forecasts next week to coincide with the publication of June 1998 quarter national accounts data.

He acknowledged that his updated budget outlook would involve a more pessimistic view of the country's economy. The government earlier set the growth of its gross domestic product (GDP) at 3 percent for 1998-99.

Private economists said the Australian economy would be fully affected by the impact of the Asian crisis in the second half of 1998, and they expected the GDP will only grow between 1.75 percent and 2.5 percent between July 1998 and June 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR PLUNGES TO RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar plunged to a record low while the country's stock market opened about 100 points lower in step with market declines in the United States and around the world.

The Australian dollar fell to 55.6 US cents in Friday morning trade after closing at 55.9 US cents Thursday, the currency's lowest value since it was floated in 1983. The previous low, 57.1 US cents, was set July 28, 1986.
Meanwhile, the All Ordinaries Index plummeted about 100 points when the market opened Friday, and although it later regained some ground, it was still down about 80 points by late morning.

Dealers attributed the sharp fall to the dumping of the Australian dollar by major foreign investors in Japan, the United States and Europe, and they said they believe the dollar could fall as low as 50 US cents.

The dumping of the Australian dollar was sparked by concern that Russia's economy is spiraling out of control. All trading in the Russian ruble was halted on Thursday amid speculation that international banks had suffered losses of US$50 billion from their Russian exposures.
Economists noted that countries in Eastern Europe and Latin America were heading toward similar catastrophes.
Financier George Soros confirmed that his hedge fund alone had lost US$2 billion.

Economists attributed the Australian market's Thursday plunge to the ailing currency, which has been hammered by fears that economic turmoil in Asia and Russia could impact Australia's domestic economic growth, as well as global economic growth.

"The fall in the Australian dollar reflects the fact that commodity currencies are increasingly coming under pressure," said Hugh Dougherty, a strategist with Merrill Lynch. "It is a case of global events taking their toll on vulnerable currencies with the effects impacting equity markets."
"Until the Australian dollar stabilizes, investors will continue to stand on the sidelines," said John Bowie Wilson, director of BNP Equities Australia.
Brokers said a quick solution to the current problems in Australia's stock and currency markets is unlikely.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA NO LONGER SAFE FOR INVESTORS: ECONOMISTS

TEXT.P: Australia, often described as "a lucky country," is no longer a safe haven for stock and currency investment as the country is being dragged down by collapsing economies in Russia, Asia and elsewhere, economists said.

In the past week, the Australian dollar and stock market have been savaged by the economic and financial problems in Russia and Latin America, which are the latest victims following the Asian economic crisis, which struck in the second half of 1997.
Economists said the United States has become a safe haven for many investors, including those from Asia and other countries.

Japan, now in a recession, is expected to find it difficult to escape from its current mess, as its problems have been building for years as a result of Tokyo's reluctance to reform its financial sector.

Australia's exports to Japan and other Asian countries account for about 60 percent of its overall exports. Despite its efforts to shift its exports to other markets, including the United States, Europe and the Middle East, Australia cannot compensate overnight for slowing sales to Asia, economists said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALAN PRESIDENT REAFFIRMS STAUNCH SUPPORT OF ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Aug. 27 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu reaffirmed his staunch support of the Republic of China when he met with ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Thursday.
The president said Guatemala will continue to support the ROC's bid to assume its rightful place in the international community.

Hu was accompanied at the meeting by ROC Ambassador to Guatemala Andrew Wu and Francisco Hwang, director of the Department of Central and South American Affairs under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Guatemalan Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein was also present.
Hu conveyed the best regards of ROC President Lee Teng-hui to Arzu, and the two then exchanged views on a wide range of issues of mutual concern.
Hu also donated US$50,000 to Arzu on behalf of the ROC government to aid in relief work for the victims of a mudslide in a western Guatemalan village on Wednesday which injured more than 40 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON: TAIWAN'S VOICE SHOULD BE HEARD

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton has told a senator that the United States will try to find appropriate ways for Taiwan's voice to be heard in those international organizations that require statehood for membership, even though the United States does not support Taiwan's membership in such organizations.

In his letter of Aug. 18, 1998, to Sen. Robert Torricelli, a Democrat from New Jersey, President Clinton also assured that US policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, and that under the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, the United States will continue to provide defensive weapons necessary for Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability.
The full text of the letter is as follows:
I appreciate your letter about Taiwan sent before my trip to the People's Republic of China. Let me describe to you my discussions on this important subject.

Taiwan's development of a prosperous economy based on free market principles, its emergence as our seventh largest trading partner, and its adoption of a democratic system that protects fundamental human rights are important achievements that benefit not only Taiwan but the entire region.

The policies of US Administrations over the last three decades toward Taiwan and the PRC have helped create the atmosphere in which democracy and prosperity in Taiwan have flourished. I am committed fully to assuring that this successful record continue.

Our policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged through the exchange of presidential visits in the last nine months. I articulated publicly and privately during my trip all of the core elements of that policy. We have a "one China" policy based on the three US-PRC Joint Communiques. Our strong unofficial relations with Taiwan and our continued support for appropriate defensive arms sales to Taiwan are based on the Taiwan Relations Act.

These documents establish the key principles that have guided our policy for nearly two decades, including our firm expectation that any resolution of differences between Taipei and Beijing be exclusively by peaceful means, our arms sales to Taiwan, and our policy of not supporting Taiwan independence, "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas," or Taiwan membership in organizations requiring statehood for membership.

We do, however, support Taiwan's membership in international organizations that do not require statehood and will work for appropriate ways for Taiwan's voice to be heard in those that do. We strongly support cross-Strait dialogue, but we do not intend to mediate, prescribe the agenda, nor pressure Taiwan to negotiate. None of these elements of our policy is new. Our adherence to the Taiwan Relations Act and the three Joint Communiques has been confirmed by each Administration since their enactment and negotiation. Our "one China" policy has been explicit since President Reagan confirmed it in a letter to General Secretary Hu Yaobang in 1982.

Our position on Taiwan dates back at least to Henry Kissinger's 1971 visit to China ad was put on the record by Deputy Secretary Christopher in 1979 hearings on the Taiwan Relations Act (the ruling party of Taiwan did not then and does not now support independence for Taiwan either). Our position on "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas" dates back to the 1982 Joint Communique negotiated by the Reagan Administration.

Our expectation of a peaceful settlement is reiterated in each of the Joint Communiques. And our support for cross-Strait exchanges ad dialogue was first asserted by Secretary of State Shultz in 1987.

I made clear in my meeting with President Jiang our insistence that differences between the PRC and Taiwan be resolved peacefully. That was the message I conveyed as well when I ordered deployment of two carrier battle groups to the waters near Taiwan in March 1996. My Administration was pleased to support the Senate Resolution passed earlier this month reaffirming our commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act and calling on the PRC to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

I will continue to develop our strong unofficial relations with Taiwan and to assure Taiwan is provided the defensive weapons necessary for it to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability. The history of the past quarter century provides strong evidence that Taiwan has fared best when US relations with the PRC are on an even keel and that Taiwan suffers when tensions in US-PRC relations rise. This paradoxical but clear relationship convinces me that improvement in US-PRC relations over the last several years will strengthen Taiwan's interests and security.
I am pleased that Taiwan and the PRC have moved further.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES EARLY RESUMPTION OF SYSTEMATIC DIALOGUE CHANNELS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday presented four "should's" in a response to the four "should not's" rhetoric issued by mainland China earlier this week.
MAC officials said mainland China should:

-- renounce the threat of force against Taiwan, and instead seek to solve bilateral differences in a way that takes into consideration the welfare of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the aspirations of the international community;
-- adopt a more positive and constructive manner, without imposing preconditions on negotiations; and
-- try to seek appropriate resolution of issues of mutual concern via existing channels.

Mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council said on Monday that if Taiwan desires unification and increased exchanges with the mainland to promote cross-strait prosperity, then it should:
-- refrain from citing the different social systems on either side of the strait as reasons for rejecting unification;
-- not upgrade its combat capacity to incite belligerent sentiments;
-- cease its bid for membership in the United Nations with the claim that the island needs a larger international presence; and
-- not hinder direct trade, postal, and transportation links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, or economic exchanges and cooperation.

MAC Vice Chairman and Spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng said that mainland China's insistence on refusing to renounce the use of force, its reluctance to face the political reality of separate rule, and its unwillingness to launch political and social reforms such as protection of human rights and promotion of democracy, have been the basic stumbling blocks to improved cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW ISSUES INSTRUCTIONS ON BOOSTING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday instructed government agencies to organize a task force within the next week to promote domestic consumption and pump up Taiwan's sluggish economy.
Siew gave the order during an inter-ministerial meeting aimed at reviewing the government's economic stimulus programs and working out the most efficient incentives to implement the plans.

He urged more effort to be made to boost domestic demand and stabilize trading in both the stock and currency markets, pointing out that the government and private sector should concentrate their strength to save the country from a crisis triggered by the regional financial meltdown.

The premier also instructed his cabinet ministers in charge of economic and financial affairs to implement budgeted projects immediately, to encourage the purchase of constructed buildings, and to set up new regulations for private investment applications on building power plants.

The Executive Yuan has initiated a compound stimulus package to boost domestic demand which it is hoped will maintain Taiwan's annual economic growth at the level of 5 percent to 5.5 percent this year and next.
However, whether or not the measures can be put into practice effectively will depend on the government's efficiency and determination.

Taiwan's economy flashed a blue light, representing a recession, in the latest government assessment for July. It is the first blue light in 26 months, and follows three consecutive months of yellow-blue, which signals a sluggish economy.

The government has recently been forced to lower its economic growth prediction to some 5.3 percent, a figure expected to fall further if no effective steps are taken to stop the trend caused by the year-long Asian financial turbulence which has now extended to Russia.
In response to the recession signal, the Central Bank of China is said to be keeping a loose monetary policy aimed at guaranteeing an abundant capital supply.

Meanwhile, it has been reported that the bank is to open this year's third meeting of its board of directors and supervisors in mid-September to determine the best moment to adjust downwards the reserve requirement.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SECRETARY-GENERAL MEETS LEADERS OF JAPANESE OPPOSITION PARTY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By F.M. Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A nation's importance should not be gauged solely by the number of nations with which it maintains formal diplomatic relations, Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang said on Friday.

Chang, who arrived in Tokyo on Wednesday for a five-day unofficial visit, said that although the ROC maintains formal diplomatic relations with only 27 nations around the world, it has regional clout and importance in the Asia-Pacific region greater than that wielded by two-thirds of the countries in the world.
Chang made the remarks during a meeting with ranking officials of the Democratic Party, Japan's largest opposition party, formed only a year ago by a coalition of smaller parties.

He met with Yukio Hatoyama, acting secretary-general of the Democratic Party, and Yukihisa Yoshida, chairman of the Council of Democratic Party Dietmen in Both Houses, for discussions on how to bolster ties between the KMT and the Democratic Party, and to exchange views on other issues of mutual concern.

Yoshida, who is scheduled to fly to Taipei for a visit on Saturday, said Japanese should still be grateful to the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek for his leniency to Japan at the end of World War II which prevented Japan from falling apart in the years following the war.
Yoshida also lauded the ROC for its ability to remain relatively unscathed by the Asian economic turmoil.

He expressed his party's grave concern about the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan enunciated by US President Bill Clinton in Shanghai in early July, and said his party will try its utmost to render help to Taiwan whenever possible.

In return, Chang thanked Yoshida for his support for Taiwan. He said the ROC and Japan have long been inextricably linked, and still maintain close ties despite the absence of formal diplomatic relations.

Chang and his group were scheduled to meet on Friday afternoon with Sadanori Yamanaka, chairman of the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, a pro-Taiwan supra-party organization in the Japanese parliament, for talks on a wide range of issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: LANDMINES FOUND ON KINMEN BEACH

TEXT.P: Police on the outlying island of Kinmen cordoned off a beach on its northeastern shore on Friday after a contractor found it to be strewn with mines.

The contractor, who had been commissioned to build a breakwater on the beach, found suspicious "lunch box-shaped" objects while he was clearing the area with a bulldozer. After checking with troops stationed nearby, the objects were found to be anti-personnel mines, and the construction work was suspended immediately.
Further inspection found the whole beach to be strewn with at least 50 or 60 of the heavily corroded mines, which were almost indistinguishable from rocks.
Kinsha Township Government Secretary Chen Kun-ti said he still had a vivid recollection of three local people who were killed after inadvertently stepping on mines on the beach four decades ago.

After cordoning off the beach, the police alerted the Kinmen Defense Command to send a special mine-clearing squad to remove the mines, but warned that with the passing of time and tides, the mines may have moved from their original position.

During the four-decade rivalry between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the military has deployed thousands of anti-personnel and anti-tanks mines on the frontline island's beaches to deter invasions by mainland forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.034 to the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 34.826.
The local currnecy opened at 34.683 and was traded between 34.681 and 34.87.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$331.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) plummeted on Friday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, losing 89.53 points to close at 6,723.77 points.
Investor confidence was shaken by an economic recession signal issued by the government on Thursday and a sharp overnight drop on Wall Street, dealers said.
The bourse opened at 6,625.37, and fluctuated between 6,615.94 and 6,802.4.
A total of 1.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.03 billion (US$2.56 billion).
Losers outnumbered gainers 368 to 70, with 48 shares remaining unchanged.
All eight major stock categories suffered losses.

Plastic and chemical issues slumped the most at 1.9 percent; followed by textile and electrical engineering stocks, which both plunged 1.7 percent; foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent; construction issues at 1.1 percent; financial stocks at 0.6 percent; papermaking issues at 0.5 percent; and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, affected by a bearish sentiment in the stock market, trading on the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange (TAIMEX) also suffered a drop on Friday.
Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September fell 140 points to close at 6,695 with 1,285 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for October lost 100 points to finish at 6,700, while those for December dropped 138 points to 6,752 and those for March moved down 95 point to 6,900.
Contract transactions for these futures totaled 57, 23 and four, respectively.
No transactions were registered for June.
The TAIMEX reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 6,835 for September; 6,800 for October; 6,890 for December; 6,995 for March; and 6,715 for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO JOIN AUSTRALIA'S FAST-TRACK VISA SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Republic of China nationals will be subject to Australia's Electronic Travel Authority (ETA) fast-track entry visa system from July 1, 1999, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday.

Director-General Chu Chien-yi of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs quoted Australian Immigration and Multiculturalism Minister Philip Ruddock, who announced on Wednesday that Taiwan and Hong Kong will join 29 other countries on the ETA fast-track visa system from July 1, 1999.
Chu said the ETA is a simple, fast and efficient way of providing tourists and short-term business travelers with permission to enter Australia.

The system also includes pre-clearance for entry that reduces the time needed to process passengers on arrival, Chu said, adding that Australia will start to make necessary arrangements here in the near future to pave the way for implementing the new system for ROC nationals.
The ETA is currently available to nationals of 29 countries, including the United States, Britain, parts of Western Europe, Singapore, and Japan.
The expansion of the ETA system is expected to improve Australia's ability to handle the expected rise in visitor numbers, particularly in the run-up to the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney, Chu said.
Chu also reported that the bureau has set up an emergency liaison center to help ROC expatriates who need emergency assistance to get in touch with ROC overseas representative offices.
He said the bureau's visa office at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport has been serving as the emergency liaison center since it became operational early this month.

"We decided to set up the center mainly because the number of ROC nationals traveling abroad has increased significantly in recent years and many of them sometimes require emergency assistance," Chu said.

With the opening of the new center, Chu said, travelers abroad who cannot get in touch with ROC overseas representative offices can seek the center's assistance through their families or friends in Taiwan. "The center will then help them contact our overseas representative offices," Chu added.
The center offers round-the-clock services, Chu said. Its telephone numbers are (03) 398-2629 and (03) 383-4849.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF MAINLAND CHINA'S ECONOMIC CONDITION

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), led party elite on a visit to the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research on Friday, to gain a better understanding of mainland China's economic condition.

As the financial turmoil which began in Asia in 1997 is now sweeping the whole world, DPP leaders feel it is essential to develop a better understanding of world economic affairs, especially those of mainland China.

DPP Secretary-General Chiou I-jen, Financial Subcommittee Convener Wu Nai-jen, Treasurer Ker Chien-ming, Director of the Chinese Affairs Dept. Yen Wan-ching, and DPP legislators familiar with economic affairs, were briefed by the Chung-Hua Institute on mainland China's current economic situation.
As economic topics have long been the DPP's weakest point in its performance in the legislature, the DPP has recently been making greater efforts in that field.

Senior officials have contacted heads of enterprises in Taiwan, such as Chairman of the Board of the Grand Commercial Bank Wu Li-pei, and General Manager of I Mei Food Co. Gao Chih-ming, asking them to serve as DPP advisers.

In addition, the DPP is also enhancing its knowledge of economic affairs by recruiting new academic members, including Director of the Institute of Economics Hu Sheng-cheng, Vice President of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research Hong Te-sheng, and National Taiwan University professors Chen Pou-Chih, Wu Chung-chi and Chang Ching-hsi.
However, the party's understanding of mainland China is still superficial, remarked Financial Subcommittee Convener Wu.

He added that the DPP is desperate to acquire in-depth knowledge of the mainland's current and long-term problems, such as whether the renminbi is to be devalued, the Yangtse River flooding, and the problem of rising unemployment exacerbated by the selling off of state-owned enterprises, as well as future industrial trends in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WELCOMES BENIGN CROSS-STRAIT COMPETITION: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan always welcomes benign cross-strait competition in the implementation of their own systems, Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) of the Executive Yuan, said Friday.

Taiwan and mainland China are in fact always in competition in various fields, including the field of political, and economic systems. "We always welcome benign cross-strait competition in systems, believing that such competition will benefit all Chinese people," Sheu said.
He said Beijing has been implementing various reform programs in recent years with a purpose to transform their rigid systems.
Sheu made the remarks in response to recent communist Chinese rhetoric that the idea of "one country, two systems" has nothing to do with cross-strait competition in social systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER JAPANESE PREMIER COMMENTS ON `THREE NOES' POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Japan should add another "no" to the "three noes" policy if it is forced by Beijing to enunciate the policy toward Taiwan, former Japanese Premier Yasuhiro Nakasone proposed on Thursday.

Nakasone said in a speech that whether or not Japan will follow in the footsteps of the United States and spell out the "three noes" policy has become a major concern for Taiwan, Japan's Sankei Shimbun reported on Friday.

The former Japanese premier said that if enunciation of the "three noes" policy becomes necessary during mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit to Japan in the coming months, Tokyo should add another clause to the policy -- no support for the use of force in solving cross-Taiwan Strait disputes.

The "three noes" policy refers no support for Taiwan independence, no support for "two Chinas," or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan membership in international organizations which require statehood.
The newspaper also reported that a visiting official from the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang met on Thursday with three leading officials of the Liberal Democratic Party.
It said that during the meetings, KMT Secretary-General John Chang asked the Japanese government not to voice the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDERWORLD FIGURES URGED TO KEEP AWAY FROM POLITICS

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Cheng Chung-mo on Friday urged local gang leaders not to try to get involved in politics as law enforcement authorities have geared up to eradicate money and violence from the local political arena.

Cheng made the call amid reports that some underworld figures are preparing to take part in the year-end legislative elections in hopes that electoral victory will help enhance their clout and protect them from legal penalties for their criminal activities.

Cheng said the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) has set up special panels to track capital flows of major criminal rings, including sources of their capital. The MJIB will also recruit and train volunteers to help track activities of major underworld gangs.
Moreover, Cheng said, the State Public Prosecutor General's Office already set up a special task force in June to monitor and investigate vote-buying activities.

"The task force will cooperate closely with the MJIB, police authorities and grass-roots law enforcement offices to stem vote-buying," Cheng said, adding that all those who are involved in vote-buying will be brought to justice.
Cheng further said the anti-organized crime campaign launched by his predecessor, Liao Cheng-hao, will never be ceased or scaled down.

"There will be no end to our fight against organized crime," Cheng said, pledging that the Ministry of Justice will make every effort to prevent any gang leaders or underworld figures from entering the Legislative Yuan.

Meanwhile, Cheng said, the ministry has also intensified surveillance to prevent ring leaders from sneaking back to Taiwan from mainland China to disrupt social order or hinder the year-end elections for the Legislative Yuan and for mayors and city councils of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Cheng cautioned those who intend to run in the Dec. 5 three-in-one elections to keep alert and avoid accepting cash contributions from unidentified sources.
Cheng made the call amid reports that mainland China may use Taiwan gangsters hidden on the mainland to manipulate or sabotage the critical year-end elections.
Cheng further said three of the five people who were arrested earlier this month for alleged involvement in cross-border drug trafficking have complicated political backgrounds.
Among the five detained drug traffickers, one was a local resident, one came from Malaysia and three were from Hong Kong.
"The three Hong Kong passport holders all have complicated family or career backgrounds," Cheng said.

The minister declined to elaborate on their background, but he admitted that there might be "serious political motivations" behind the drug trafficking deal, masterminded by Chan Wai Man, a member of Hong Kong's largest criminal gang Sin Yee On.
In the Aug. 9 raid, MJIB agents managed seized large amounts of heroin, worth more than NT$100 million in street value, which were smuggled by the Chan Wai Man group into Taiwan from Hong Kong.

Cheng said the MJIB is still making in-depth investigations into the case. According to press reports, one of the three Hong Kong drug dealers used to be a ranking mainland Chinese public security officer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHERY SECTOR OPPOSES APEC PACKAGE

TEXT.P: Representatives from some 40 fishery associations from across the island met Friday to discuss an initiative that would eliminate tariff rates for fishery products by 2005

The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation's (APEC) Early Voluntary System of Liberalization (EVSL) package would hit Taiwan's two million fishermen hard, said Cheng Mei-lan, chairperson of the Taiwan Provincial Fishery Association.

Taiwan has promised to slash its import duties for fishery products to no less than 20 percent by 2004 from the current level of 27 percent as a part of negotiations to join the World Trade Organizations.

However, the EVSL agreement, proposed during the 1997 APEC summit in Vancouver, requires products in nine sectors -- including fishery products -- among APEC member countries to be subject to a zero tariff rate by 2005.
If Taipei goes ahead with the EVSL plan, it proves that the government is not looking out for the interests of Taiwan fishermen, Cheng argued.

Wei Ker-ming, secretariat of the Board of Foreign Trade, urged Taiwan fishermen to work out countermeasures to deal with the current situation in which economic liberalization has become the trend around the world.

During an APEC meeting held this June in Malaysia, ministers decided to implement the EVSL plan as soon as possible, as early as next year. Concrete measures and details to carry out the package will be worked out in an APEC ministerial meeting slated for September.
The United States, Australia, New Zealand, and Canada have all expressed strong support for the EVSL package, while Taiwan, mainland China, Japan and South Korea are more reserved about the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, THAILAND LAWMAKERS SEEKING CLOSER TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Haungiee Sae-chia & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from the Republic of China and Thailand on Friday pledged to establish the ROC-Thailand Lawmakers Friendly Association in an attempt to boost "parliament diplomacy."

Visiting ROC Legislator Rau Yin-chi and Thai Representative Surasak Thiampraser signed the agreement which would increase the exchange of visits, comments and information between lawmakers from the two sides.

Rau, who is leading the eight-member delegation, is also the ruling Kuomintang's executive director of Policy Coordination Committee. He said that at a time when the ROC and Thailand have no diplomatic relations, parliament diplomacy will help enhance friendly ties and understanding between the two countries.
The ROC Legislative Yuan has established similar associations with their counterparts in the United States, Britain, Canada, Japan and South Africa, Rau added.

Krasae Chanwongse, who serves as vice chairman of Thailand's Democrat Party, said during his recent visit to Taiwan he felt that lawmakers from the two countries should strengthen their ties. As relations between the ROC and Thailand have made great strides since ROC representative to Thailand Stephan Hsu assumed his post years ago, it is time that lawmakers from both sides further interact.

ROC representative to Thailand said he was glad the long-expected ROC-Thailand Lawmakers Friendship Association was finally established, adding that he hopes the lawmakers from the two sides can work toward realizing the goals of the association.
The ROC legislative mission arrived in Bangkok on Thursday for a three-day visit. They are scheduled to return to Taiwan on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MISSION HEADS FOR JAPAN

TEXT.P: A non-partisan delegation composed of National Assembly deputies is scheduled to leave for Japan on Sunday to lobby for Tokyo's support ahead of Chinese President Jiang Zemin's visit there.

The delegation will present Japanese opinion leaders with a position paper explaining Taiwan's stance on cross-strait affairs. It states that other countries should not make comments related to cross-strait ties and urges Tokyo not to do anything which could damage Taiwan's interests during the coming summit between Jiang and Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi.

Everyone in the Republic of China on Taiwan strongly believes that the cross-strait dispute should be resolved peacefully and rationally by the two sides on an equal footing, the paper stated. No foreign country is in the position to make biased comments on issues regarding "one China," "one China and one Taiwan," or "one country, two systems."

The position paper called on Japan to back Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations and warned that Beijing may further pressure Tokyo to sign a joint document on the "three noes" regarding Taiwan. US President Bill Clinton was cited as an example as he publicly declared his support for the "three noes" during his recent visit to the mainland.

Japan's support for Taiwan would be in Tokyo and Asia's best interests, the paper said, adding that it hoped Japan would not sacrifice its existing friendship with Taiwan for the sake of special interests.

The delegation is expected to meet with Sadanori Yamanaka, president of the Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship at the Diet, as well as legislators from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and the Komei Party. The mission is scheduled to return to Taiwan on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR DOMESTIC INVESTMENTS TO INCREASE BY 73% IN 1998

TEXT.P: Major domestic investment projects scheduled for completion by the end of 1998 are expected to increase 73 percent from last year, Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said Friday.
Major investment projects are defined as the projects each with an investment value of over NT$200 million (US$8.69 million).

Wang made the announcement after a Cabinet meeting on Taiwan's finances and economy. He said major investment projects posted a year-on-year growth of 89 percent in the first seven months of 1998 to NT$268 billion (US$7.76 billion), and was estimated to increase by 73 percent to NT$457 billion (US$13.24 billion) over the year.
The figures did not include private investment projects below NT$200 million (US$5.79 million) which are forecast to grow by 16 percent in 1998 in value.

Domestic demand stemming from these projects will offset losses in Taiwan's export industry as a result of the region's economic crisis, and help stimulate the island's economic development, Wang said.
With expanding domestic demand in mind, Cabinet members decided to establish an ad hoc panel to charter a course to boost the island's economy.
Premier Vincent Siew asked the Ministry of Economic Affaris (MOEA) and the Council for Economic Planning and Development to work out guidelines for the panel's operations within a week, Wang said.
Siew also asked the MOEA to arrange meetings with local business leaders so that he can exchange views with them on economic issues.
Wang said the MOEA will consult with members of the local business community before calling such gatherings.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC OFFICIALS OPPOSE DEVALUATION OF NT DOLLAR

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) officials expressed opposition Friday to further depreciating the New Taiwan dollar to boost Taiwan's exports in an attempt to fuel its economy.

Director General of Foreign Exchange Department Chou A-ting told reporters that the contraction of Taiwan's exports lies more in the shrinking of national incomes of Taiwan's neighboring states than in the price of Taiwan's merchandise.

If that is the case, further depreciation of the NT dollar would not do much to boost the sale of Taiwan goods to people in neighboring countries who have seen their purchasing power substantially dwindle due to their shrinking income, Chou said.
On the flip side, stabilizing exchange rates will encourage investment at home and broaden domestic demands, Chou pointed out.

Taiwan's economy is affected more by the ups and downs of the US market than that of Russia which is plagued by financial turmoil. A slightly weakening greenback will ease the downward pressure on currencies in most Asian countries, said Chou.

CBC Deputy Governor Hsu Yi-hsiung shared Chou's views. He said at a separate occasion on Friday that a monetary policy, of which the foreign exchange rate is but a part, is not a panacea for all economic and financial ills.

There is no need to devalue the NT dollar because of Russia's financial woes, Hsu said, adding that Taiwan-Russia trade only accounts for 1 percent of Taiwan's total imports and exports. Nevertheless, he said he would continue to monitor the global economic situation closely and take appropriate measures accordingly.

DOC.HEADLINE: WLFD ANNUAL CONFERENCE OPENS IN BANGKOK
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Haungiee Sae-chia & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Over 300 representatives from 50 countries were on hand at the start of the World League for Freedom and Democracy's (WLFD) 30th annual conference in Bangkok on Friday.

WLFD President Chao Tze-chi from the Republic of China said during the opening ceremony that world peace cannot be achieved unless dictatorship and autocracy, which still exist in some countries, are totally eliminated.

Chao cited nuclear tests, racial and regional conflicts, financial turmoil, environmental problems, cultural differences, and conflicts resulting from the changing of political systems as potential threats to human security.
He urged countries around the world to work together to cope with the current financial troubles and to help poor countries toward the goal of a prosperous world.
Written letters of congratulations from ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Secretary-General of the United Nations Kofi A. Annan were read at the ceremony.

President Lee in his letter stressed that being a member of the international community, the ROC is willing to share its experience in economic and democratization developments. The ROC is obliged to contribute to world peace and prosperity, he added.
The three-day meeting will finish on Sunday. Founded in 1954, the WLFD is a private organization aimed at promoting freedom and democracy around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: DING MOU-SHIH TO VISIT SWAZILAND, MALAWI

TEXT.P: National Security Council Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih will head a delegation to Swaziland and Malawi on Sept. 3, diplomatic sources said on Friday.

Ding, as the special envoy of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, will attend celebrations for the Kingdom of Swaziland's 30th anniversary of independence and the 30th birthday of King Mswati III on Sept. 6.
Ding and his delegation will then proceed to Malawi on Sept. 8, where he will call on Malawi President Bakili Muluzi to discuss methods of improving bilateral relations and cooperation.
Ding will also meet with Taiwan's agricultural missions and members of the Chinese community in both African states before returning to Taipei on Sept. 13.

Other members of the delegation will include Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Director Timothy C.T. Yang of the Foreign Ministry's African Affairs Department, several business leaders and the Lang Yang Dance Troupe.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE URGED NOT TO REMIT MONEY TO RUSSIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) on Friday urged Taiwan students in Russia and their family members to temporarily stop remitting money to Russia or other countries of the Commonwealth of Independent States.

The ministry made the comment as money transferred into Russia at present could be frozen by local banks. According to the latest information, Russia has reportedly stopped the trading of foreign currencies.

The MOE made the call after Russia's financial turmoil saw the ruble depreciate by 20 percent in the last few weeks. The drop in the ruble has been blamed for the heavy losses seen in stock markets around the world recently.

The crisis has also left about 200 Taiwan students studying in Russia, mainly in Moscow, in a very difficult situation. The MOE's outposts and those of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Russia also have encountered the same problem.
According to the MOE, the foreign ministry is seeking to find ways to channel money to ROC government outposts in Russia, and the only option now is to keep US dollars in hand.
The MOE urged Taiwan students in Russia to take extra care of their personal safety and property as social order may worsen amid the current wave of uncertainty.

In the event of an emergency or any difficulties, the ministry called on Taiwan students to contact its Moscow office at the following telephone numbers 002-7095-956-3786; 002-7095-737-9246; or fax numbers 002-7095-737-9245; or e-mail: robin@glasnet.ru.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOKYO'S POLICY TOWARD TAIWAN WILL NOT CHANGE, KMT SEC-GEN. TOLD
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang met former Japan Defense Agency Director General Sadanori Yamanaka in Tokyo on Friday to exchange views on Japan's relations with the Republic of China and mainland China.
Yamanaka told Chang during their hour-long discussion that Japan's policy toward Taiwan will remain unchanged not only in the Diet, but also in the government.
Yamanaka is president of the Dietmen's Council for Japan-ROC Relations, a supra-party organization formed by 315 Diet members from both houses to promote substantive relations with Taiwan.

In the past two days, Chang has held separate talks with ranking members of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and the Democratic Party, Japan's main opposition party, to explain the political positions of the KMT and those of the government.

Chang said his initial impression was that Japan would stand firm in its developing relations with mainland China. He told the Chinese media that during his talks with Yamanaka, he fully expressed Taipei's concern over Japan's relations with mainland China.
He said he believed Japan would not harm Japan-ROC relations when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin makes a state visit to Japan in the future.

The KMT secretary-general said many Japanese lawmakers are friendly toward the ROC and among the 20 Cabinet members, 13 belong to the Dietmen's Council Japan-ROC Relations. Therefore, he felt optimistic about Taipei's relations with Tokyo.
Chang arrived in Tokyo on Aug. 26 at the invitation of a private group comprised of elite politicians from Asia. He is scheduled to return to Taipei on Aug. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: Premier Vincent Siew on Friday reaffirmed the government's determination to stabilize stock and foreign exchange markets.
The China Times: The United States will sell Stinger air defense missiles, anti-ship Harpoon missiles and torpedoes for anti-submarine warfare.
The United Daily News: World securities markets were reeling as Russian turmoil worsened.
The Liberty Times: Russia may take an about-face as its economic reforms encounter great setbacks.
The Independence Morning Post: Global stock markets plunged over Russian financial upheaval.
The Commons Daily: Premier Vincent Siew Friday unveiled nine steps to stimulate domestic demand.
The China Post: Dow slipped and European stock markets faltered in early Friday trading.
The China News: Premier Vincent Siew acts to boost confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEVEN ILLEGAL MAINLAND CHINA IMMIGRANTS NABBED

TEXT.P: Seven illegal immigrants from mainland China were rounded up, while two others died and another two were still missing after trying to sneak ashore in central Taiwan, police said on Saturday.

An initial investigation found that the 11 illegal immigrants, each of whom had paid 10,000 renminbi to a "snakehead," or smuggler, boarded a vessel from a fishing port in Fujian Province, on Friday night.

By 3 a.m. on Saturday, the ship was close to the Taiwan port of Wangkung, Changhua County. The illegal immigrants said that at that point the boat's captain, fearing detection by ROC marine patrols, asked them to swim ashore.
However, because of their unfamiliarity with the surroundings, and the strong currents in the area, they were swept toward offshore commercial oyster beds.
Six of the immigrants -- four men and two women -- clung to the wooden spikes of the oyster farm and called for help until they were noticed by a passing fisherman at 5:30 a.m.

Police and coast guard officers later found a man and a woman, identified as Zhou Jintu and Xu Shouhong -- who had drowned and had been washed ashore, while another mainlander who had made it to shore was later arrested.
Police said they are still looking for the two missing illegals, adding that the seven survivors have been sent to a detention center in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.
