DOC.HEADLINE: EXHIBITION OF CONTEMPORARY CHINESE ART TO OPEN IN NY

TEXT.P: A major touring exhibition of contemporary Chinese art will open in New York on Sept. 15, to run until Jan. 3, 1999.

"Inside Out: New Chinese Art," co-organized by the Asia Society, New York, and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, will explore how the challenges of rapid modernization, changing political realities, and conflicting global, ethnic, and local identities have spurred artists in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan, as well as artists who left mainland China in the late 1980s.

The exhibition will consist of more than 80 works created between 1985 and 1998, encompassing a significantly greater range of artistic mediums than any other previous exhibition of contemporary Chinese art.

The New York exhibition will be followed by simultaneous presentations at San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco, and a further tour. A rich and innovative series of performances, lectures and symposia is also planned to complement the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN STATE MAY LEGALIZE INTERNET GAMBLING

TEXT.P: The New South Wales government is expected to legalize Internet gambling, which will make it the first state in Australia to allow gaming operators to set up virtual casinos for the booming number of on-line punters.

Internet gambling has grown into a worldwide industry generating more than US$625 million a year, and NSW Gaming Minister J. Face has recognized that rather than trying to stop Internet gambling outright, it may be best to control it through legalization.
Face said the NSW government can more closely monitor the gambling industry by licensing local operators, as well as being able to extract tax revenue.
But the opposition branded Internet gambling "the most insidious and invasive form of gambling that exists" and has called for it to be banned.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTION PROPOSED TO DEREGISTER ONE NATION PARTY

TEXT.P: The former personal secretary of One Nation leader Pauline Hanson is moving to deregister the party, saying she will seek a court injunction to block almost A$500,000 (US$312,500) in public funds from going into the party's coffers.
Barbara Hazelton, a former close friend and confidante of Hanson, said One Nation was never properly registered.
She said she will seek an injunction in the Queensland Supreme Court on Monday to immediately prevent the funds from being released to the party.

Hazelton's move has received full backing from prominent Liberal Party parliamentarian Tony Abbot, who earlier asked his good friend, Prime Minister John Howard, to condemn Hanson and put One Nation last in the voting preference in the next federal election.

Hazelton quit her job as Hanson's secretary after the June 13 election in Queensland, accusing Hanson's two advisers -- David Ettridge and David Oldfield -- of manipulating One Nation and running the party as a business instead of a political body.

She told the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday that she hopes her action will get "every member who thinks they belong to Pauline Hanson's One Nation to actually find out just exactly what it is they belong to."
If Hazelton's move is successful, it will be a serious blow to One Nation because the party will be unable to use the funds for the next federal election campaign, political analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices rose on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 12.15 points to finish at 6,735.92.
The local bourse opened at 6,766.8, 43.03 points higher than Friday closing.
In all, 1.42 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$62.465 billion (US$1.811 billion).

Construction shares rose the most at 0.7 percent, followed by both electrical engineering issues and paper and pulp shares at 0.4 percent; and both financial stocks and foodstuff shares at 0.1 percent.
Textile stocks fell 0.3 percent, while cement shares dropped 0.2 percent and plastic and chemical shares edged down 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September increased 33 point to close at 6,728 with 698 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for October moved up 10 points to 6,710 with 34 contract transactions, while those for December dropped 38 points to 6,761 with 9 contract transactions and those for March rose 25 points to 6,880, with 20 contract transactions.
No transactions were registered for next June.
The reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were listed as follows: 6,695 points for September; 6,700 for October; 6,799 for December; 6,855 for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN YOUTH MISSION TO VISIT AUSTRALIA, NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: A youth goodwill mission from Taiwan will arrive in Australia next week to stage one performance each in Canberra and Perth before moving on to perform in New Zealand.
Led by Professor Tsiang An-kuo, the group, comprising 19 students from several Taiwan universities, will arrive in Canberra on Sept. 2.

The group will give a performance of traditional Chinese dance and music at the Llewellyn Hall of the School of Music of the Australian National University on Sept. 4, and will perform in Perth on Sept. 6.
The group will then leave for New Zealand, where it will stage further performances before winding up its tour on Sept. 14.
The mission aims to promote cultural exchanges across international borders through dance, song and Chinese folk arts.

Taiwan has sent similar goodwill missions to many countries since 1974. This year's mission will also visit Europe and North America. (By Peter Chen) ENDITEM/J ZCZC CEP009 08-29-98 GIGANTIC BALLOON CAUSES TROUBLE FOR CANADIAN AIR FORCE
Ottawa, Aug. 28 (CNA) Canadian fighter jets scrambled over the Atlantic Ocean to shoot down a potentially dangerous intruder, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. reported on Friday.
But the "bandit" managed to stay aloft, despite a hail of fire from the two CF-18's, the national broadcaster said.

"That's not a bad trick, considering the intruder is a gigantic runaway helium balloon. The 50-story-high unmanned research station lost navigational control over Saskatchewan on Monday, drifting across the country and out over the Gulf of St. Lawrence," the CBC said.
It quoted Transport Canada as saying that the balloon posed a serious hazard to airplanes, and that air traffic across the Atlantic had been re-routed.
The Department of National Defense said the cannon holes inflicted by the fighters will bring the balloon down eventually.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER PRESENTED WITH KEYS TO GUATEMALA CITY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu is scheduled to arrive back in Taipei on Sunday after winding up a weeklong visit to El Salvador and Guatemala.
Sources from Guatemala said that Hu left for Taiwan via the United States on Friday after concluding a three-day visit to the Central American country.

Before his departure, Hu visited Guatemala City Mayor Oscar Berges, and was presented with the keys to Guatemala City. The foreign minister then visited Guatemala's Parliament Speaker Rafael Barrios to exchange views on issues of mutual concern. He also thanked the Guatemalan parliament for its long-term support for the ROC.

A day earlier, Guatemalan Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein Barillas conferred on Hu the Order of Quetzal with Grande Cross, in recognition of his contributions to the development of bilateral relations. In return, Hu, acting on behalf of the ROC government, conferred on Barillas the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon for his contributions to promoting ties between the Republic of China and Guatemala.
Hu embarked on his Central American trip on Aug. 23, along with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.

They first visited El Salvador, where they presided over an economic cooperation conference and a "Taiwan Experience" workshop on Aug. 25 attended by foreign ministers and economic ministers from five Central American diplomatic partners of the ROC -- El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica, and Guatemala.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND PROPERTY MARKET HIT BY DRAMATIC SLUMP

TEXT.P: New Zealand's property market has slumped dramatically because of the Asian financial crisis and plunging stock and currency markets, with sales of houses and commercial buildings down from between 25 percent to 70 percent.
Australian real estate analysts attributed the slump to high interest rates, a rapidly slowing economy, political instability, and the end of a long cyclical upswing in the housing market.
Auckland and Christchurch have been hit hardest, and buyers can name their prices, according to New Zealand's largest real estate franchise chain.

Property developers and housing agents say it is difficult to predict when the property market will recover, now that the financial crisis has spread from Asia to Russia, Latin America and eastern Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAD OF MITSUBISHI CHEMICAL TAIWAN BRANCH HONORED

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Saturday bestowed an economic medal on Tadatoshi Sata, chairman of Mitsubishi Chemical Corp. Taiwan branch.

During the decoration ceremony, Wang said that the medal is in recognition of Sata's outstanding contributions to the promotion of investment in Taiwan, the upgrading of ROC industry, and the improvement of the Sino-Japanese trade imbalance.

Wang noted that Mitsubishi is Japan's largest chemical manufacturer, and said that since Sata's assignment to Taiwan in 1987, he has helped introduce hi-tech, high valued-added products to the island, which have contributed to the upgrading of the local chemical industry and to the development of the electronics industry.

Mitsubishi Chemical Corp. has invested NT$1.8 billion (US$51.72 million) in its Taiwan branch. The branch has an annual turnover of NT$2 billion (US$57.47 million), and its re-exports to Japan are worth an annual total of NT$600 million (US$17.24 million).
Sata expressed thanks for the positive recognition, and said he will continue to promote industrial cooperation between the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE STILL INTENDS TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Despite recent squabbling over sovereignty issues across the Taiwan Strait, ROC President Lee Teng-hui still aspires to make a "journey of peace" to mainland China to pave the way for China's eventual unification, a senior official said on Saturday.

The Presidential Office official, who preferred to remain anonymous, made the statement in response to a newspaper report that a mainland think tank is studying the feasibility of the leaders of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait meeting in a neutral setting.

According to the report, the think tank believes that a meeting between Lee and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, will bring about a major breakthrough in cross-strait relations, and may even help Lee and Jiang share a Nobel Peace Prize.
Commenting on the report, the official said Lee has consistently endeavored to seek a breakthrough in the current cross-strait impasse.
"Nevertheless, he is doing so not for the sake of a Nobel prize, but for the common interest of all Chinese people," the official stressed.

The ROC president mentioned in his 1996 inaugural speech that he hopes to make a "journey of peace" to the mainland to set the stage for cross-strait rapprochement. Lee has also expressed his desire to meet Jiang in an international setting for wide-ranging talks.
"Even though current cross-strait relations have failed to proceed as smoothly as expected, Lee's wishes remain unchanged," the official explained.

He further said that at the moment, the ROC government's highest priority in cross-strait issues is that a long-planned autumn meeting between C.F. Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), can be held smoothly.
"We also look forward to seeing cross-strait relations make headway following the proposed Koo-Wang meeting later this year," the official said.
ARATS sent a message to SEF earlier this month, inviting Koo to visit the mainland either in September or in October to meet with Wang for talks on matters of mutual concern.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Government sources said the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which oversees SEF operations, has tentatively decided to let Koo head a delegation of SEF officials to visit the mainland in October for the meeting with Wang.

The sources said the MAC hopes mainland authorities will agree to Taiwan's proposal that SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwi-yow visit the mainland prior to Koo's trip to set an agenda for the much-anticipated meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO VISIT CENTRAL EUROPE IN LATE SEPTEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, Aug. 28 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will send a trade delegation to Austria, Hungary, Poland and Russia in late September.

The trade mission is slated to arrive in Vienna on Sept. 24. During its two-day stay in Austria, delegates will visit the federal commercial association, meet with heads of the country's trade council and Austria's vice economic minister, as well as senior trade and economic officials.
In addition, the mission will visit the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Austria, which will arrange a meeting between CETRA delegates and leading Taiwan business representatives in Austria.

From Sept. 26 to Sept. 27, during the mission's two-day sojourn to Hungary, the delegates are scheduled to meet with government officials and leaders in Hungary's industrial and commercial sectors. The trade mission will also visit CETRA's office in Budapest and the Taipei Representative Office in Hungary.

Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, will attend the Sino-Poland Economic Cooperative Convention on Sept. 29 in Warsaw. Members of the CETRA mission are also expected to participate in the gathering.

During the convention, a cooperative agreement is expected to be signed between CETRA and Poland's Investment Bureau. Top-ranking officials from BOFT, CETRA and the Euro-Asia Trade Organization will meet with vice ministers of Poland's finance and economic ministries, as well as the chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce to discuss cooperative efforts.
On Sept. 30, CETRA will host the opening ceremony and a news conference to mark the launch of its Taiwan Trade Center in Warsaw.

Members of the CETRA mission will leave Warsaw for Moscow on Oct. 1 for a two-day tour. Its itinerary in Moscow includes a visit to the CETRA office, the Taipei-Moscow Economic & Cultural Coordination Commission Representative Office, the Chambers of Commerce and Industry, as well as a tour of the World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND CONSIDERS 15-DAY LANDING VISAS FOR TAIWAN GROUP TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has yet to receive official confirmation that Thailand will offer 15-day landing visas to group tourists from Taiwan, officials said Saturday.
MOFA officials were responding to a Thai immigration official's comments in Taipei on Friday that Taiwan nationals could enjoy the preferential treatment next month.
Although Bangkok has yet to formally announce the proposal, it is indeed mulling the option, officials said.

Those to be covered by the new status would be group tourists of a certain number yet to be determined. Individual travelers are not included in the proposal. Also, Bangkok has stipulated that Taiwan travel agents must coordinate with Thai travel agents to qualify for the special visas.
Jetturong Neakhum, Thailand's commnader of the Bureau of Immigration, said upon his arrival in Taiwan that his country will give landing visas to Taiwan group tourists.
The Thai official is also here to promote Thailand to Taiwan investors at a presentation held Saturday at the Taipei International Convention Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: PILOT STRIKE FORCES NORTHWEST TO SUSPEND TAIWAN FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: Northwest Airlines suspended its flight service to Taiwan on Saturday after a mass strike was called by its pilots union, the US-carrier's Taiwan office said.
Northwest had operated two routes daily to and from Taiwan, they were Taipei-Tokyo-Detroit, and Taipei-Osaka-Seattle. The carrier served an average of 500 US-bound passengers a day.
The airline will arrange for passengers who have reservations with Northwest to take alternative carriers, the Taiwan office said.

Contract negotiations between Northwest's management and representatives of some 6,200 pilots regarding pay and job security broke down at 0400 GMT Saturday. This led the fourth-largest US carrier to announce the suspension of all flights of its 406 aircraft, which includes eight cargo planes.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL REFUTES BEIJING'S FOUR 'SHOULD-NOTS'

TEXT.P: Beijing leaders should stop addressing Taiwan with a hegemonic attitude if they seek to improve bilateral relations and realize the reunification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, a ruling Kuomintang official said on Saturday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Research Department, made the remarks in response to four demands mainland leaders made last week. Beijing's statement said Taipei should accept the four demands or so-called four "should nots" if it is serious about national unification.

The four "should nots" are that Taiwan should not use differing social systems as a reason to refuse unification with the mainland; Taiwan should not continue to beef up its military strength; Taiwan should not seek to develop international relations; and Taiwan should not ban direct transport, postal and trade links across the strait.
Commenting on Beijing's demands, Chang said Taiwan has never refused to unify with the mainland. "Taiwan merely insists that unification hinges on democracy on the mainland," he noted.
Chang went on to say that Taiwan's unification with the mainland is attainable only if Beijing were willing to carry out democratic reforms.

"We see few reasons why Beijing insists on adhering to a failed communist system. Similarly, Beijing has no reason to expect a democratic Taiwan to be integrated with a China which will remain under communist rule," Chang explained.
Regarding Beijing's demand that Taiwan suspend its effort to boost its defense capability, Chang said Beijing should provide incentives for Taiwan to cease to do so.

"Beijing must renounce the use of force to reduce our security concerns," the KMT official said, adding that there is only one purpose for Taiwan to keep its military forces -- to defend itself against a potential attack from the mainland.

Chang further said if the cross-strait military balance were sabotaged, the possibility of mainland China attacking Taiwan will increase. "Such a scenario violates our goal of pursuing peaceful unification of the two sides," he added.
The mainland affairs expert also said there is little possibility that Beijing's demand for Taiwan to discontinue its efforts in expanding international relations will be met.

Noting that diplomacy symbolizes a nation's sovereignty, he said Taiwan must develop diplomatic relations and expand its international presence to facilitate cross-strait dialogue on an equal footing.
Meanwhile, Chang said, the key obstacle to direct cross-strait trade, communications and transportation lies with Beijing's refusal to recognize Taiwan's judicial authority.

"Opening such links requires each party to recognize the other's jurisdiction," he noted, adding that the two sides should sign a peace treaty to end hostilities before the so-called "three links" are established.
The KMT official furtehr said maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait and promoting China's democratization are the party's ultimate goals in forging cross-strait rapprochement.

Speaking on the same occasion, Wu Hsin-hsing, a deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, said mainland China's recalcitrant insistence on a "one country, two systems" unification scheme based on its "one China" principle is a major obstacle to cross-strait negotiations.
Wu also urged mainland China to unequivocally renounce the use of force against Taiwan to create a favorable climate for China's peaceful unification under a free and democratic system.

"I don't think the leaders of either side of the Taiwan Strait will likely resort to the use of force in resolving cross-strait issues. Against this backdrop, Beijing has nothing to lose in making a public renunciation of the use of force against Taiwan," he explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF SIX KILLED IN APARTMENT FIRE

TEXT.P: Six members of one family, including four young children, were killed in an apartment fire in Tainan, a southern city in Taiwan, police said on Saturday.

The fire broke out at the three-story building at 5:00 a.m. in a furniture store on the first floor, police said. Fifteen fire engines and over 100 fire fighters were called to the scene, and the fire was contained within half an hour of their arrival.
All of the victims lived on the third floor and were unable to escape the fire. They had died of smoke inhalation.
The deceased were identified as Haiso Ho-tzu, 57, her daughter Chou Hsiou-yin, 32, Haiso's granddaughters Chou Ko-ting, 11, Chen Hong-yin, 10, Chen Hong-tin, 8, and Chen Tzu-yi, 2.
Residents on the first and second floors escaped from the burning building without serious injury.
Police suspect Chou's husband, Chen Der-chen, of having started the fire as neighbors said Chen had returned home drunk and quarreled with his wife shortly before the fire broke out.
Chen has denied the charges, claiming that the fire had already broken out when he returned home. He is currently in the custody of prosecutors under suspicion of arson.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSASIA AIRWAYS TO OFFER 14 ATR FLIGHTS SUNDAY

TEXT.P: TransAsia Airways will offer a total of 14 flights on five domestic routes on Sunday using its ATR turbo aircraft, an airline spokesman said on Saturday.

With the service of 18 pilots, the spokesman said, the carrier will be able to offer one round-trip flight each on its Kaohsiung-Kinmen, Taipei-Hualien and Kaohsiung-Makung routes, and two round-trip flights each on CKS International Airport-Kaohsiung and Taipei-Taitung routes.
ATR flight services on other routes will continue to be suspended, the spokesman said, adding that all the airline's Airbus flights will operate normally.

Airbus flights account for 70 percent of TransAsia's total daily transport capacity. The company's Airbus planes can hold up to 13,000 passengers on its Taipei-Kaohsiung, Taipei-Tainan, Taipei-Kinmen, Kaohsiung-Kinmen and Taipei-Makung routes everyday, the spokesman said.
A total of 67 TransAsia ATR pilots resigned en masse on Tuesday to protest a major pay cut. Through negotiations, 13 pilots have agreed to return to work.
The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) called a flight safety evaluation meeting on Saturday to discuss the TransAsia labor-management dispute.
After the meeting, CAA Deputy Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng said the administration will further investigate the case before deciding on the punishment for both parties.

Noting that the dispute has caused a near paralysis to the island's air traffic in the last few days and seriously infringed on passengers' rights, Chang said both parties should be penalized in accordance with current regulations.

As this was the first time that a labor-management dispute at a domestic airline has so seriously effected passengers' rights, Chang said the CAA must deal with the case with prudence and caution to avoid setting a bad example.
"We'll make further probes and studies before making a final decision on the issue," Chang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GUATEMALA CONGRESS SUPPORTS ROC BID TO JOIN UN

TEXT.P: The Congress of Guatemala recently adopted a resolution, showing strong support for the Republic of China's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations.

The resolution pointed out that the Republic of China (ROC) was established in 1912 as the first democratic republic in Asia and was one of the founding members of the world body. The UN deprived the ROC of its membership in favor of communist China by UN Resolution No. 2758 at its 26th General Assembly, ignoring the legitimate rights of the ROC and its people to join the world body.

The UN resolution ignored the representation of the 22 million ROC citizens in the world body, and in organizations governing world health, environmental protection, education, and culture. It is necessary to review the UN resolution, since the world situations have changed greatly in the past 28 years, the resolution said.

The ROC has developed into a democratic country with a popularly-elected government. It is also one of the world's major countries in terms of trade and economic development. The ROC has been a sovereign country since its establishment in 1912, although it lost a lot of territory in civil war in 1949, the resolution added.

The world community should review the ROC case and find a proper way for it to join the UN, the resolution said. Proposals to let the ROC join the UN in accordance with the "universal membership principle" of the UN Charter deserve special attention, it added.
The resolution said that the Congress of Guatemala supports the ROC's bid to join the UN and the related world organizations.
It also resolved to send the resolution to UN Secretary General Kofi Annan and the government leaders of Central American countries and Panama.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE INVESTMENTS IN TAIWAN TO INCREASE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Economic Minister Wang Chih-kang said Saturday that he has full confidence in the increase of domestic demand and private investments in Taiwan.

Speaking at a meeting on the economic ministry's program for promoting export trade, Wang said that the government hopes to stimulate the economy amid the Asian financial crisis by increasing exports and domestic demand, and that his ministry will send officials to help investors tackle their problems.

Wang said that private investments will grow 16 percent this year in Taiwan, and that 251 major investment projects of more than NT$200 million (US$5.75 million) each will be completed by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The government takes measures to prevent international speculators from entering into Taiwan's markets.
The United Daily News: The government bans sales of Soros funds in a bid to prevent speculations.
The China Times: Another policeman committed suicide after shooting to death his girl friend.
The Liberty Times: Taiwan on the alert for international speculators.
The Independence Morning Post: A policeman committed suicide after killing his girl friend.
The Commons Daily: Former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang was hospitalized for brain injury.
The China Post: Soviet Prime Minister ruled out any return to Soviet past amid mounting Western fears about the fate of market reforms.
The China News: TransAsia Airways' daily flights will be cut to 44 from 120 after pilots walked off the job. (by Bear Lee)

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER RETURNS AFTER LATIN AMERICAN VISIT

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu arrived in Taipei Sunday morning after winding up a weeklong visit to El Salvador and Guatemala.

While in El Salvador, Hu attended a ministerial conference on economic and foreign affairs between the Republic of China and its five Latin American allies -- El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras, Costa Rica and Guatemala.
He also presided over a "Taiwan Experience" workshop, in which Taiwan shared its experiences in economic development with the country's Central American diplomatic allies.

After the workshop, the minister left for Guatemala, where during his three-day stay Hu presided over a meeting of ROC envoys to countries in Central and South America. He also called on Guatemalan President Alvaro Arzu.
Hu also met with Guatemala's parliament speaker, Rafael Barrios. Hu thanked the Parliament for its long-term support for the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG LOSING ALLURE AS CROSS-STRAIT CONDUIT

TEXT.P: Indirect cross-strait trade via Hong Kong totaled US$5.04 billion in the first half of 1998, down 7.7 percent from the same period in 1997, statistics compiled by the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) show.

Indirect mainland Chinese exports to Taiwan via Hong Kong during the first half of the year were off 1.2 percent from a year ago, totaling US$820 million, while indirect Taiwan exports to mainland China declined 8.8 percent to US$4.22 billion during the same period, according to BOFT tallies. The imbalance left Taiwan with a surplus of US$3.4 billion, down 10.5 percent from its year-earlier level.
Indirect cross-strait trade via Hong Kong registered the largest year-on-year increase, 17.3 percent, in 1993, but the growth rate dived soon after, falling to just 1.4 percent in 1997.
In addition to the effects of the Asian financial crisis, BOFT officials attributed the lower growth to increased transshipment trade across the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan and mainland China agreed to open offshore transshipment services in 1997, allowing vessels flying foreign flags to ship cargo destined for a third country between Taiwan's southern port city of Kaohsiung and Xiamen and Fuzhou, port cities in mainland China's Fujian province. The agreement lowered cross-strait shipping costs and allowed cargo to be shipped across the strait more quickly than before.
Hong Kong's status as the major transshipment hub in indirect cross-strait trade will continue to fade over time, BOFT officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CREDIT CARD CHARGES IN TAIWAN CLIMB TO ALL-TIME HIGH

TEXT.P: The total value of goods and services purchased by credit card in Taiwan this year is expected to reach a record NT$400 billion (US$11.49 billion), according to the Central Bank of China (CBC).
CBC statistics show that credit card charges in Taiwan amounted to NT$227.81 billion (US$6.55 billion) during the first half of this year, up NT$73.63 billion from its year-earlier level.
This vigorous growth in the credit card market reflects wider circulation of so-called "plastic money."
Transactions through automated teller machines (ATM) are on the rise as well.
The total amount of money deposited, withdrawn or transferred via ATM machines in Taiwan in 1991 was NT$1.06 trillion. Last year that figure totaled NT$4.83 trillion, according to CBC statistics.
Meanwhile, consumer loans from local banks around the island amounted to a record NT$3.48 trillion (NT$100 billion) in July, up NT$25.75 billion from the previous month, according to the CBC.
Most loans were for building or repairing homes or buying cars, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO HOLD MEETING ON DOWNSIZING PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), will preside over a party meeting Wednesday on downsizing the Taiwan Provincial Government.

President Lee will give a keynote speech outlining the KMT's downsizing policy to assuage discontent arising from the matter, sources close to the KMT said, adding that the meeting will also discuss measures and laws to carry out the plan.

According to the sources, discussions will center on the future status of the Taiwan Provincial Government, which will be deprived of self-governance powers and placed under the central government's direct jurisdiction.

ROC Vice President and KMT Vice Chairman Lien Chan, and three other KMT Vice Chairmen -- Li Yuan-tsu, Yu Kuo-hwa and Chiu Chuang-huan -- as well as Premier Vincent Siew, Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong and other ranking government officials will take part in the meeting.

There have been disputes between the central and provincial governments as to what extent the provincial government should be streamlined in accordance to the consensus reached at the inter-party National Development Conference in December 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLDS OF PICASSO AND CHANG DA-CHIEN TO BE DISPLAYED IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The "World of Picasso" exhibition will open at the National Palace Museum in suburban Taipei in late September.

The exhibition, sponsored by the museum, China Daily News corp. and the Dimensions Art Educational Foundation, will display 45 oil paintings, 26 drawings and three sculptures from Spain's Pablo Picasso, one of the most influential artists of this century.
The exhibition includes works from Picasso's teenage years, as well as ones from his Blue Period (1901-1904), Rose Period (1904-1906), Cubist Period and Classical Period, according to the museum.

Another exhibition opening in late September will feature works by Chang Da-chien, an innovative painter known for enlivening traditional Chinese painting. Chinese art societies both in Taiwan and abroad are said to be staging the exhibition, in which 124 masterpieces will be shown.
Works in the exhibition will be lent by museums and art collectors in Taiwan, Hong Kong, the United States, Canada, France and Spain.
The Chang Da-chien exhibition will open Sept. 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC BUSINESS LEADERS CALL FOR IMPROVED INTERNATIONAL COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Taiwan business leaders are urging the government to help guide local enterprises in their efforts to upgrade as soon as possible, in order to enhance their international competitiveness.

Since Thailand announced the adoption of a floating exchange rate for the Thai baht on July 2, 1997, igniting a series of foreign exchange rate battles in Southeast Asia, the financial turmoil has spread like a plague from Thailand to the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Japan.

However, Taiwan has remained relatively unscathed by the financial disaster, which the business leaders attribute to the small government foreign debt, as well as the ability of it's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to react quickly to change.

Kao Ching-yuan, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said in an interview with CNA that many Southeast Asian countries, with high ratios of both foreign debts and bad accounts, have been proven too weak to withstand the onslaught of the financial firestorm.

However, he went on, Taiwan's situation is different. Most of its SMEs, which make up the majority of Taiwan's enterprises, are highly capable of coping with changing situations, and are able to use their own funds to adapt and surmount the crisis.

Chu Chih-yang, honorary chairman of the Chinese National Research Institute of Industry & Commerce Construction, pointed out that the SMEs, which account for about half of the total national output and employ some 75 percent of the nation's workforce, are the mainstay of Taiwan's economy.

He said he believes that close cooperation between SMEs and their satellite plants, and the flexible use of their own funds, have also helped prevent them from suffering excessive impact from the financial crisis.

Chen Kuo-ho, chairman of the research institute, noted that another important factor that has helped minimize the influence of the financial turmoil is the traditionally strict and conservative management style prevalent in the country's SMEs.

Tai Sheng-thung, chairman of the National Association of Small & Medium Enterprises, ROC, also pointed out that the SMEs, with more than 30 years of business experience and production technology, together with the prudent screening system employed by Taiwan's financial institutions, have also helped buffer the economy.
He added that the SMEs did not use excessive credit to borrow and were therefore able to safely tide themselves over the difficulties of economic recession.

Meanwhile, the business leaders also expressed their hope that the government will move one step further, and present concrete measures to cope with the financial crisis and boost economic prosperity.

Both Wang You-theng, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, and Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, urged the government to encourage private investment and promote industrial development in Taiwan.

Koo said the stabilization of the political situation should be the government's top priority in leading the nation's enterprises through the financial storm. If the political situation can retain long-term stability, he said, then foreign investors will naturally have more confidence to invest in Taiwan, and the economy will grow accordingly.

Kao, Chu, Chen, and Tai were unanimous in their suggestion that the government should: help enterprises to improve production technology; provide a good climate for capital or fund raising; draft related laws and policies; and implement government reconstruction.

In addition, they said, both government officials and entrepreneurs should earmark more funds for research and development of better technology and production techniques, instead of using their capital for speculation. This, they said, will prevent Taiwan from marching down the road toward a bubble economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHIEF TALKS ABOUT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top economic planner said that Taiwan has been better able to tackle the Asian financial crisis than many other countries because it's financial and industrial development policies are good and are properly implemented.
P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), made the remarks in a recent interview with the CNA.
Taiwan will stimulate its domestic demand and encourage private investment in order to tide over the financial crisis sweeping Asia, he added.
The following is the transcript of the interview:
Q: The Asian financial crisis has devastated the economy of many countries for a year. Taiwan has fared relatively well amid the crisis. Can you please explain why?

A: The Republic of China on Taiwan is one of the three countries in the region that are able to achieve economic growth this year. In addition, our currency depreciation is relatively mild, and our stock market is rather stable, when compared with those of other Asian countries. All of these indicate that our economy is rather healthy.
I believe this is because our financial policy and industrial development policy are appropriate.

Because of trade surplus, we have accumulated a big amount of foreign exchange reserves. And our foreign debts are almost nil, when compared with those of many other Asian countries. This is because we have enough savings for domestic investment, and because we have steadily carried out our financial policy.

In the past decade, we have successfully transformed our labor-intensive industries into technology-intensive industries, as can been seen from the vigorous development of our information industry. As a result, our export trade and our economy have been growing pretty well in the past 10 years.

The economy of Singapore and Taiwan are rather healthy, because the financial and industrial development policies of the two countries are pretty good. Japan's economy is the second largest in the world because of its successful industrial development policies. But its financial policy has plunged its economy into deep recession.
Q: Can you shed some light on the impact of the Asian financial crisis on Taiwan? What factors will affect the recovery of the Asian economy?

A: Like flu, the financial crisis is sweeping all countries in Asia. It reduces domestic demand, raises jobless rates, causes currency depreciation, cuts investment, pushes up consumer prices, and decreases imports.

As a result, Taiwan's export trade in the first seven months of this year was eight percent lower than a year earlier. Fortunately, our exports to Europe grew seven percent during the period, and the exports to the United States and Central America increased one percent. Our exports to Japan and South Korea reduced 25 percent during the period, but it was caused by external factors. Exports to Asia account for 50 percent of Taiwan's total export trade.
I believe the economic performances of Indonesia, Japan, and mainland China are pivotal in the future stability of the Asian economy.
Political instability, drought, and high jobless rates are hurting the economy of Indonesia, which may affect the pace of economic recovery in other Asian countries.

Japan's jobless rates have climbed to 4.1 percent, and the Japanese yen is still weak, after the country's financial policy failed. The Japanese people's lack of confidence in the economy was attributable to the Liberal Democratic Party's loss in recent parliamentarian elections. The new cabinet appears to be unable to solve the problems of bad loans and weak currency. The government is now trying to revive the economy by cutting taxes and increasing public spending.

The economy and export trade of mainland China are being hurt by the government control of foreign exchange rates. The control has greatly reduced the import of many materials and semi-finished products from Taiwan for processing in mainland China.

We hope that the Japanese government will enact laws to revitalize its stock and foreign exchange markets. It will benefit Japan and other Asian countries, and help stabilize the currency of mainland China.
Q: What measures should the government take to maintain Taiwan's economic development when the impact of the Asian financial crisis is still lingering?

A: Our trade surplus has reduced sharply. Its contribution to our economic growth has dropped below zero. To make up the loss we have to stimulate the domestic demand. We don't have to cut taxes to stimulate consumption, because our domestic consumption is quite normal.

DOC.HEADLINE: WLFD SUPPORTS ROC'S PARTICIPATION IN INTERNATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS

TEXT.P: The World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD) urged the United Nations to accept the Republic of China on Taiwan as a full member and called on its 145 members to support the Republic of China's efforts to play a more active role in international organizations.
The delegates from 52 member-countries approved the joint communique of the WLFD's 30th Annual General Conference after a three-day meeting. The WLFD is a non-governmental organization.
In the joint communique, the WLFD said it believed "the Republic of China on Taiwan should be given the chance to participate in the work of international organizations and other global forums."

The WLFD also approved a resolution supporting the Republic of China's inclusion in international organizations. The resolution hails the Republic of China as "a fully democratic country which has achieved spectacular economic development and is one of the world's principal trading nations and a major international economic force."
The resolution stresses that the Republic of China has significantly contributed both financially and technologically to many countries' development.

The resolution also indicated that the international community has reacted positively to the Republic of China's pursuit of representation in international organizations, as evidenced by its membership in the Asian Development Bank, the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference and its active role in various regional institutions of Southeast Asia and Central and South America.
The Republic of China withdrew from the United Nations in 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: WLFD URGES UN MEMBERS TO TRUST IN CONSENSUS

TEXT.P: The World League for Freedom and Democracy (WLFD) approved a joint communique during its 30th annual meeting, which ended Sunday in Bangkok, urging UN members to have greater trust in the consensus of its member countries to achieve justice.
In the same communique, the WLFD said it believes the Republic of China on Taiwan should be given the chance to participate in international organizations and other global forums.

The non-governmental UN organization expressed its concern at the pressure brought to bear by the presence of refugees on some countries and the ethnic, racial and religious problems that sometimes stem from the influx.

Regarding the Asian economic crisis, the communique said the policies and programs of the International Monetary Fund require serious examination to ensure they are effectiveness in providing relief to nations in economic crisis.

Regarding terrorism, the WLFD delegates stressed the need for greater international cooperation in the fight against all forms of terrorism and expressed its concern that unilateral, excessive and ill-targeted retaliation measures might be counterproductive and lead to adverse consequences.
The closing ceremony of the three-day 30th WLFD annual meeting was presided over by WLFD President Chao Tze-chi. One hundred delegates from 52 countries took part in the meeting.
Nine ROC officials attended the meeting. The head of the Taiwan delegation, Yao Yin-chi, is to return home Monday afternoon. The others departed Bangkok Sunday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUCHA LINE AWARDED ISO 9002 CERTIFICATION

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Sunday hailed the Mucha line of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit System receiving ISO 9002 certification, calling it an honor to both Taipei and the entire island.

Chen attributed the certification to the hard work and contributions from the entire staff of the municipally run Taipei Rapid Transit Company (TRTC). He said it is a great achievement that the French-built Mucha line is operating so smoothly now, having experienced fires, derailments and other mechanical problems in the months after the line was first opened.

Chen made the remarks after the Bureau of Commodity Inspection and Quarantine awarded the certificate to the TRTC for the excellent quality of service on the Mucha line of the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit System, which was officially opened to the public March 28, 1996.

The Mucha line, Taipei's first mass rapid transit line, is the second project by the Taipei City Government to win ISO 9002 certification, the first being the city's population administration and household registry department, which won the certification for the quality of its services.
TRTC Manager C. L. Chen said the company will apply for ISO 9002 certification for the quality of service on its Tamsui line, Taipei's second operational mass rapid transit line, early next year.
Chen said the TRTC will also seek ISO 9002 certification for both lines' repair and maintenance operations, establishing a standard of excellence for company staff members.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN HSU HOSPITALIZED WITH HEMATOMA

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, hospitalized Saturday afternoon after suffering an acute headache, has been diagnosed as having a three-centimeter hematoma inside his brain.
Hsu, 58, said he was feeling better Sunday, but his condition has forced him to cancel planned political appearances.
Doctors have not yet decided whether to operate to remove the hematoma. Meanwhile, Hsu remains hospitalized and only his family is being permitted to visit him.
He was admitted Saturday afternoon to Taoyuan's Yangmei Hospital.

After learning of Hsu's hospitalization, DPP executives, including party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, former Chairman Shih Ming-teh and secretary-general Chiu Yi-jen, sent messages to express their deep concern.
According to an aide close to Hsu, the hematoma was apparently caused by an attack by pro-independence protesters during the Aug. 1 ceremony in which Hsu handed over the party's reigns to Lin.
The aide said Hsu did not feel well after the attack and that he later began vomiting and developed a fever. His headache worsened after a recent fall at home caused by headache-induced insomnia.

Now chairman of the Hsin-Hsing Min-Tzu (Rising People) Foundation, Hsu has been preparing for DPP primaries, set for early next year, in which the party will select a candidate for the 2000 presidential elections.
Plans by his foundation to issue a white paper on cross-strait policy may also be affected by Hsu's hospitalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER SETS FEDERAL ELECTIONS FOR OCT. 3

TEXT.P: Alarmed by worsening economic turmoil in Asia, Russia and elsewhere, Prime Minister John Howard on Sunday afternoon set federal elections for Oct. 3.

In an impromptu press conference in Canberra, Howard said he called on the governor-general earlier in the day and recommended to him that the House of Representatives be dissolved and the election be held on Oct. 3.
He said economic management would be the key issue in his bid for a second term. "In the area of taxation, we have a plan for the nation's future. Labor (Party) has a serious promise to buy votes."
But Labor leader Kim Beazley said: "Mr. Howard does not have a plan for the nation. He has a plan for a tax. A tax which would be like a dead-head for our national economy.
Howard, however, said the tax would strengthen Australia and boost employment.
Beazley is promising his own tax cuts worth A$5 billion (US$3.12 billion) for low-income earners and working families.
Political analysts said Howard was forced to announce an earlier election than planned because of fears that continued economic turmoil would cost Howard support.

"Howard is worried by this scenario. The longer he waits for the next election, the less support he will get as the economic agenda will turn bad for him and make him more difficult to sell his policies," one analyst said.
The coalition government of Liberal and National parties under Howard can afford to lose only 17 seats in the House of Representatives.
Meanwhile, the Australian Democrats Party said it was worried by this year's election because the One Nation Party would be fielding candidates in both Senate and House elections.
"If One Nation succeeds in winning a few seats at the House of Representatives and to become a balance of power, it would be the House of horrors," the Democrats leader said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REMAINS OF TAIWAN TOURISTS RETURNED

TEXT.P: The ashes of six Taiwan tourists killed earlier this month while in the northeastern province of Gansu in mainland China were returned to Taiwan Sunday.
The six had been participating in the "Silk Road" tour of mainland China when their tour van collided with a truck.
Family members of the decreased, holding shrines inscribed with the names and holding photos of their beloved, arrived at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport near Taipei in the afternoon.
Helped by officials from the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and airport police, they quickly passed through customs and boarded a bus, which took them to the Taipei Second Funeral parlor.
SEF is Taiwan's semiofficial organization in charge of bilateral exchanges with mainland China in the absence of formal government contacts.
In addition to the six Taiwan tourists killed, eight others were injured in an accident, which took place on a highway near the city of Jiayuguan on Aug. 22.
Wu Mei-fang, one of the injured, is still receiving medical treatment at a local hotel in Jiuquan, near Jiayuguan. The other seven tourists returned to Taiwan a few days ago.
Meanwhile, the family members of those killed are preparing to begin compensation talks next week.

The Taipei Association of Travel Agents, the ROC Travel Quality Guarantee Association and the Fortuna Travel Service Co., organizer of the tour, will first negotiate the issue with family members, while SEF officials will help the families seek compensation from the mainland.
The driver of the van is said to have been chiefly at fault in the accident. His family, however, has said that it does not have the ability to compensate the families of the Taiwan tourists.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S BUSINESS CONFIDENCE DROPS TO RECORD LOW

TEXT.P: Business confidence levels in Australia have slumped to record lows, said Prime Minister John Howard, who also warned that the full impact of the Asian financial crisis is expected to hit the country in the coming months.

The index of business confidence, prepared by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI), tumbled from 48.9 points in the second quarter of 1998 to 39.9 points mid-way through the third quarter.
"Business is rightly worried about the trends and has judged that the effect of the present high level of international instability will lower growth," ACCI chief executive Mark Peterson said.
"It could hardly be otherwise," he added.
"The circumstances of the world economy reinforce the absolute need that the economic foundations of Australia be as strong as possible," Howard said.
"As we look out an unfriendly -- even hostile -- economic world around us, we are able to say that Australia has weathered that storm remarkably well," he added.
But Howard warned the worst was still to come in terms of the full impact of Asia's ills on the Australian economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS SEE SLOWDOWN OF CFC-12 INCREASE

TEXT.P: German researchers have discovered the evidence of a leveling off in the growth of the ozone-depleting chemical CFC-12 in the upper atmosphere over Europe, said Dr. Paul Lehman, an atmospheric scientist at Australia's Bureau of Meteorology.

But Lehman told the Sydney Morning Herald that the total volume of CFC-12, which is used in the refrigerator as coolant, is still increasing. CFC-12 lasts longer in the environment than any other ozone-unfriendly chemical and accounts for 30 percent of all CFCs in the atmosphere.

Inert in the lower atmosphere, CFCs undergo a chemical reaction that produces ozone-destroying chlorine and bromine as CFCs rise to meet the ozone layer -- 10 to 40 kilometers above the Earth, he said.
"The level of CFC production and atmospheric loading is leveling out, but there are a great lot of uncertainties with respect to the ozone hole," he said.
He said Australian experts have detected an increase in the atmospheric levels of another chemical, halon-1202, which is also strongly linked with the destruction of ozone.

Australia is pressing to have halon-1202 included in the Montreal Protocol agreement on the phasing out of chemicals destructive to the atmosphere, said Dr. Paul Fraser, a scientist at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization in Canberra.
CFCs are responsible for 80 percent of ozone loss and halons for the other 20 percent, Fraser said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA TO SPEAK AT ASIAN AWARDS CEREMONY

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada has been invited as guest of honor and speaker to the 1998 Ramon Magsaysay Award presentation ceremonies to be held on Aug. 31 in Manila.
The occasion also marks the 40th anniversary of the award, which was named after former President Magsaysay, whose birthday falls on that day.

During the ceremonies, five outstanding Asians will be honored. The Magsaysay Award was first given in 1958. Over the past 40 years, 191 individuals and 15 institutions or organizations have received the award.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC WARNS FOREIGN SPECULATORS NOT TO TAMPER WITH LOCAL UNIT

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) on Monday warned international speculators not to set their sights on Taiwan, saying they would be thoroughly routed if they attempt to attack the New Taiwan dollar.

Chou Ah-ting, director-general of the CBC's Foreign Exchange Department, aimed the warning squarely at US investor George Soros after newspapers reported that Soros' Quantum and Quota funds seek to destabilize Taiwan's financial market.
Soros reportedly lost US$3 billion in the Hong Kong stock market on Saturday following market intervention by the Hong Kong government, which has accused Soros of trying to manipulating its markets.

Stressing the CBC's determination to combat international speculators, Chou said the CBC is closely monitoring Soros' movements in the local financial market and that an initial government investigation has found no evidence to support the allegations that Soros' funds are preparing to launch an assault on the NT dollar.

Chou said the soundness of Taiwan's financial market makes it impossible for international speculators to benefit from attacks on the local currency. He added that speculators cannot obtain large amounts of local currency -- a necessary prerequisite for launching an attack -- since the CBC banned non-delivering forward trading on May 20 of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S GOLD PRODUCTION HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Australia's gold production industry has lost none of its luster even amid plunging global gold prices, as increased production has enabled the industry to outshine its competitors in South Africa and North America.
Australia's gold production rose 6 percent in fiscal 1997-98 to a record 318 tons from 1996-97 levels, brushing off both negative market sentiment and falling global prices.

"Gold production on an annual basis has continued to rise. The industry is performing well despite the widespread negative market sentiment over the past year," said Sandra Close, managing director of the Melbourne-based mining consulting group Surbiton Associates, told the Australian Financial Review.
Gold prices plummeted to an 18-year low of US$276.50 an ounce on Friday on fears of widespread selling from producing countries such as South Africa, Australia and Canada.
The slide was sparked by major hedge funds anticipating the sales which were tipped in response to the commodity-based currencies of the countries being crushed on world markets.

Close said Australia's gold industry proved itself the most efficient in the world and has largely avoided the massive shutdowns and redundancies which have plagued the biggest producer, South Africa and the second largest, North America.
Australia ranks third in terms of gold production in the world and exports its bullion to many countries, including Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong, Japan and other Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, ISRAEL TO SET UP SCI-TECH COOPERATION FUND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Israel have agreed to establish a cooperative fund to promote research in sophisticated industrial technology, a visiting Israeli official said on Monday.

"The two sides are now negotiating technical details concerning the proposed fund, including the amount and operational rules," Max Livnat, senior deputy director-general of the Ministry of Industry and Trade of Israel, said in an exclusive interview with CNA.
If the proposal is realized, it will be the first cooperative fund between Taiwan and Israel.

"The fund will lay a solid foundation for the two countries to cooperate in high-technology research and development," Livnat said, adding he is convinced that both countries will benefit from the project because they complement each other in many high-tech fields.

Livnat, who arrived in Taipei on Sunday for an eight-day visit, said Israel has promoted science and technology research cooperation with other countries by setting up joint funds to finance R&D projects.
"We have established sci-tech cooperative funds with the United States, Singapore, Germany, France and the Netherlands," Livnat said.
Among those funds, the US$110 million US-Israel cooperative project is the most successful, he said.

Livnat said the United States and Israel each contributed US$55 million to the fund and used interest income to finance high-tech research and development. Board members of the fund meet twice a year.
"Over the past 20 years, the fund has managed to help nurture many noted enterprises in both countries," Livnat said.
Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties between Taipei and Tel Aviv, Livnat said he does not see any obstacle to the proposed establishment of a joint Taiwan-Israeli fund.
"We reached a conclusion, even if you don't have diplomatic relationship, you can do a lot of things," he explained, adding that he does not see any sensitivity in nonpolitical areas.
Asked when the proposed Taiwan-Israeli fund can be inaugurated, Livnat said the Office of the Chief Scientist of Israel is expected to make a final decision after details are worked out with Taiwan.
Meanwhile, Livnat denied a newspaper report that he will negotiate defense technology cooperative projects with Taiwan during his current visit.
"My visit has nothing to do with defense affairs. I am completely not involved in any defense project," the senior Israeli official stressed.
Livnat went on to say he will take advantage of his current trip to promote Taiwan investment in Israel.

Noting that Israel is widely recognized as a technologically advanced country, Livnat said Israel has signed free trade agreements with the United States, the 15-member European Union, Canada, Mexico, Turkey and many East European countries.
Against this backdrop, Livnat said, Israel can serve as a bridgehead for Taiwan companies to tap into the Middle East and European markets.

Livnat also said his country welcomes Taiwan's participation in a series of events to be held in celebration of Israel's 50th founding anniversary. These include many large-scale trade and economic conferences such as the Oct. 13-16 Prime Minister Economic Conference and the Nov. 9-12 telecommunications technology trade fair.
In addition, Livnat said a delegation composed of senior executives of 28 Israeli high-tech firms will visit Taiwan on Sept. 16-17 to seek joint-venture partners.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Israel has grown steadily in recent years. In 1997, Taiwan exported US$315.6 million worth of products to Israel, and imported US$226.2 million worth of Israeli merchandise.
Livnat will visit Taiwan's major economic, trade and industrial institutions and meet with senior ROC officials during his stay here.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES, FUTURES BOTH LOSE GROUND

TEXT.P: Stock prices in Taiwan fell Monday with the market dominated by increasing pessimism over huge losses in Hong Kong.
Local investors expressed concern over the Hong Kong government's inability to extinguish speculation, and are worried that Taiwan may be the next target for widespread speculation, brokers said.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's (TAIEX) weighted price index, the market's key barometer, plunged 185.81 points to close at 6,550.11.
Losers outnumbered gainers 415 to 33 with 33 remaining unchanged.
In all, 1.52 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$64.3 billion (US$1.85 billion).
All eight stock categories experienced declines. Plastic and chemical shares suffered the highest drop of 5.1 percent.
The depressed atmosphere also effected the futures market.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for September declined 162 points to close at 6,566, with 922 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for October dropped 143 points to 6,574, with 56 contract transactions. Those for December lost 120 points to 6,620 and those for March fell 162 points to 6,717. Transactions for the two futures both posted 14 contracts, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL INVESTORS URGED TO STAY CALM
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Aug. 31 (CNA) (By Flor Wang and Stanley Cheung)

TEXT.P: Vice Finance Minister Wang Rong-chou on Monday urged local investors to stay calm and confident despite a string of slides in the domestic stock market.

Attributing recent falls in the local bourse mainly to the psychological impact of the Hong Kong market's recent plummet, the vice finance minister called on investors to have confidence, and said the Finance Ministry has instructed the Securities and Futures Commission to closely watch movements by foreign speculators to ensure fair and rational operations in the local stock market.
Wang made the remarks following a slide of 185.81 points in the local stock market on Monday. The weighted index, the local stock market's key barometer, closed at 6,550.11.

Hong Kong stock shares tumbled by more than 400 points on Monday after government intervention over the weekend in a bid to foil international speculators. The Hong Kong government, which accused US investor George Soros of attempting to manipulate its market, reportedly spent US$8 billion last Saturday in a frenzied buying spree to prop up the Hong Kong stock market.

Meanwhile, major Chinese-language newspapers in Hong Kong, including the Oriental Daily News and the Wen Wei Po, carried extensive reports on a decision by Taiwan authorities to ban sales of Soros' Quota and Quantum funds on the island.

The Oriental Daily News said the initiative will help Taiwan save large amounts of foreign reserves to defend against Soros' attacks on its currency, while the Wen Wei Po maintained its traditional support of government crackdowns on illegal speculative trading.

Dao Tung, an economic analyst with the Credit Suisse First Boston (Hong Kong) Ltd., told CNA he believes that it will be very hard for international speculators to attack Taiwan's financial markets as they have in Hong Kong, because Taiwan's financial market is more tightly controlled than Hong Kong's.
"International hedge funds will find it very difficult to destabilize Taiwan's financial market using the same methods which they used in Hong Kong," he claimed.

Addressing Taiwan's decision to ban local banks from selling Soros' funds, Dao described it as a "natural" move following the year-long Asian financial crisis, which he said has hit some emerging markets in the region very hard.

Those crisis-plagued countries, and even Taiwan, will undoubtedly want to impose some restrictive measures on foreign capital movement in their local markets, he noted, adding that "basically, one country has the right to take measures necessary to defend its own financial sector."
